Scallop insurance in bank

Author: Huber, Ron

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]22 Nov 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413992970?accountid=10457

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Scallop+insurance+in+bank&amp;author=Huber%2C+Ron&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-11-22&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: A Bangor Daily News story (Oct. 25-26) described how the number of scallops on Georges Bank has jumped since fishing closures were put in effect several years ago. This may bring visions of future bounty to many a scalloper, but unless there is to be another boom-bust pounding of the resource, why not take out some "scallop insurance?" Here's how:
Researchers know that scallops live up to 20 years in the wild, and that is not until they have reached their 12th year that fertility is at a maximum. These "dinner plate" size scallops can produce 150 million eggs per year, compared to a mere 10 million eggs in a 4-year-old harvestable juvenile.
But under the past and, likely, future fishing regulations, by their fifth year virtually all Georges Bank scallops are captured (or killed and left on the bottom by heavy offshore scallop dredges).
A few years ago, Nova Scotia fisherman Kirk Munro suggested to scientists that the U.S.-Canada offshore border would be a perfect place for a scallop reserve. The idea: Keep this $100 million a year industry on as steady a keel as possible by protecting a permanent large community of fully grown spawners. The challenge: Two nations manage the Georges Bank scallop fishery.
In the mid-1980s the United States and Canada divvied up control of Georges Bank. It took quite a battle -- from confrontations offshore all the way to the International Court of Justice at The Hague in Holland. There, this world court divided ownership of this sprawling sunken territory (as big as Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Connecticut combined). Since then, the U.S.-Canada offshore border through this submerged plateau, with its underwater canyons, great plains of mud, and current-swept watery Saharas of san and gravel has been called the "Hague Line."
U.S. and Canadian scientists have been busy studying the ecology of scallops out on Georges Bank's Northern Edge and Northeast Peak, where turbulent water and plenty of food make things ideal for this popular bivalve. This is also where the Hague Line crosses Georges Bank.
One thing learned is that scallop larvae hatched on Georges Bank, stay there. Twice a day, the tide pushes water (and scallop eggs and larvae in season) back and forth across the Bank around 40 miles. At the same time, the prevailing current there moves clockwise around the bank at around five miles daily.
According to biologist Martin Willison of Dalhousie University, Nova Scotia, and American researcher Richard McGarvey, with those prevailing currents and tidal flows, a 10-kilometer-wide no-take reserve along the length of the Hague Line would "have a substantial effect on scallop recruitment throughout the bank," according to the Centre for Wildlife and Conservation Biology in Wolfeville, Nova Scotia. "A protected zone along the entire length of this line ... may suffice to enhance and stabilize the scallop fisheries in both the USA and Canada. For this protective zone to be effective, all commercial and destructive activities must be excluded, with the exception of shipping lanes."
In other words, more egg production, more larvae drifting to new homes across the Georges Bank plateau. More scallops.
In the BDN article, Maine Department of Marine Resources official Chris Finlayson said the spectacular increas of scallops on Georges Bank shows that closures could be an important scallop management tool lacking in the present scallop management plan.
The challenge is to designate permanent reserves offshore, where scallops can live their natural 20-year lifespan, as opposed to temporary closures, which will inevitably succumb to the boom-bust syndrome once re-opened.
A wild area on the Hague Line will also provide Gulf of Maine scientists something they desperately need -- a large undisturbed area of the Gulf of Maine and Georges Bank where they can learn how wild marine nature actually works. At present, virtually every square inch of the gulf and Georges Bank is worked over with drags and dredges, up to twice a year. As a result, marine scientists have no natural areas to use to gain `baseline' information about how marine life behaves in its natural setting. Without such basic data, the results of even the most elaborately designed computer models are questionable. We can see where flawed modeling based on incomplete data has brought us.
Creating a marine reserve on the border will require cooperative efforts between citizens and diplomats of both nations. But it can be done. We have cross-border parks and wilderness areas on land. We must likewise set aside a part of our underwater public domain from exploitation, or we will be doomed to repeating over and over the disasters of the past.
Why not take out a little "scallop insurance"?
Ron Huber of Rockland is director of the Coastal Waters Project, a citizens' association dedicated to protecting and restoring the Gulf of Maine.

Snowe seeks funds for controlling algae

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]17 Nov 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413868405?accountid=10457

Abstract: U.S. Sens. Olympia Snowe and John Breaux of Louisiana have introduced the Harmful Algal Bloom Research and Control Act of 1997 authorizing increased funding for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and providing a "focused and appropriate" response to harmful algal blooms in the United States. Algal blooms, which are damaging outbreaks of frequently toxic algae, affect coastal states and territories and have been increasing during the past 30 years. Scientists have not been able to explain the phenomena and there is no alternative but to close affected areas to swimming and fishing, Snowe said.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Snowe+seeks+funds+for+controlling+algae&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-11-17&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   WASHINGTON -- U.S. Sens. Olympia Snowe and John Breaux of Louisiana have introduced the Harmful Algal Bloom Research and Control Act of 1997 authorizing increased funding for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and providing a "focused and appropriate" response to harmful algal blooms in the United States.
One form of algal bloom is Maine's red tide, which costs millions of dollars from closed clam flats.
Algal blooms, which are damaging outbreaks of frequently toxic algae, affect coastal states and territories and have been increasing during the past 30 years. Scientists have not been able to explain the phenomena and there is no alternative but to close affected areas to swimming and fishing, Snowe said.
A recent outbreak of Pfisteria in the Chesapeake Bay has resulted in media attention, but Pfisteria is just one example of the larger problem of algal blooms, Snowe said.
"In my state of Maine," Snowe said, "we have outbreaks of paralytic shellfish poisoning every year which require the closure of clam flats along the coast, and the loss of millions of dollars in potential income." She said other regions also suffered, including the Georges Bank, where blooms cause $3 million to $5 million in damage each year. In 1991 in Washington state, an outbreak caused losses of razor clams valued at more than $15 million. Off Alaska, as much as $50 million worth of shellfish are put off-limits each year because of the outbreaks.
The Snowe-Breaux legislation focuses federal support on NOAA research and provides a specific annual authorization of $10.5 million for fiscal 1998, 1999 and 2000, to fund the Ecology and Oceanography of Harmful Algal Blooms project, part of NOAA's Coastal Oceans Project.
The legislation also would upgrade NOAA research lab capabilities, provide education and extension services through sea grant colleges and universities, augment federal and state monitoring for early detection, and provide grants to states under the Coastal Zone Management Act.

Scientist: 105-day shrimp season is too long

Author: Walter Griffin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]11 Nov 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413904883?accountid=10457

Abstract: "The scheme upon which the industry advisers came up with the 105-day season is based on the assumption that the catch per day will be directly related to the amount of shrimp out there," Department of Marine Resources biologist Dan Schick said Monday. "The problem is, our research indicates that the biomass of shrimp out there is in decline." The ASMFC is a panel of scientists and industry representatives appointed by the federal government to regulate fisheries in state and federal waters. Schick serves as an adviser to the panel. He had recommended a shrimp season from Feb. 1 to March 31, a total of 59 days. Last year's season was 156 days. Schick based his recommendation on physical surveys conducted on the northern shrimp population over the past two decades and the tonnage of shrimp landed this year. More than 7,000 tons of shrimp were harvested during the 1996-97 season.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Scientist%3A+105-day+shrimp+season+is+too+long&amp;author=Walter+Griffin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-11-11&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- Despite protests from the scientific community, the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission has imposed a northern shrimp season of 105 days, twice the number of days scientists recommended.
"The scheme upon which the industry advisers came up with the 105-day season is based on the assumption that the catch per day will be directly related to the amount of shrimp out there," Department of Marine Resources biologist Dan Schick said Monday. "The problem is, our research indicates that the biomass of shrimp out there is in decline."
The ASMFC is a panel of scientists and industry representatives appointed by the federal government to regulate fisheries in state and federal waters. Schick serves as an adviser to the panel. He had recommended a shrimp season from Feb. 1 to March 31, a total of 59 days. Last year's season was 156 days.
Schick based his recommendation on physical surveys conducted on the northern shrimp population over the past two decades and the tonnage of shrimp landed this year. More than 7,000 tons of shrimp were harvested during the 1996-97 season.
ASMFC members rejected Schick's recommendation during a meeting in Gloucester, Mass., last Friday.
Instead, commissioners decided that the season for harvesting shrimp in the Gulf of Maine will open Dec. 8 and close May 22. No shrimp fishing will be allowed on Saturdays and Sundays. In addition, shrimp fishing will be shut down from Christmas to New Year's Eve and from March 16 through March 31.
The season for catching shrimp in traps similar to those used to catch lobster will run from New Year's Day through Feb. 28.
Although the fisheries panel rejected his recommendation, Schick maintained that the accumulated scientific data paints a troubling picture of the shrimp stock. He said the ASMFC decision was based on the immediate economic needs of a troubled fishing industry instead of the long-term health of the shrimp stocks.
"There is just too much economic pressure, where people have overextended themselves," Schick said. "To a person, they are hoping shrimp will sustain them for another year. The shrimp resource in the Gulf of Maine is not that big. There are just too many people trying to make a living on the Gulf of Maine for the resource that is out there. It's not built to take that kind of pressure."
Schick said his research data point to a situation similar to that of the late 1970s, when the shrimp population experienced a dramatic decline and fishing was halted. He said the approximately 275 shrimp boats working the Gulf of Maine are captained by experienced, skilled shrimpers.
"The problem is that the reason these fishermen are still around is that they are the best at finding the concentrations of shrimp. These shrimp harvesters have the ability to find more shrimp. Last year they harvested 7,000 metric tons in 156 days. I think they could take 7-8,000 tons in 105 days this year," Schick said. "The ability for industry to hurt itself to the point where we might have to close it down is astounding. It seems very short-sighted to go for a maximum shrimp catch this year."
Schick noted that it only took a few years of overfishing to decimate ground fish stocks and the same could happen with shrimp. Like shrimp, ground fish regulations were established by a federal council weighted by members more concerned about economic than environmental issues. Schick said there is always a danger of overfishing when industry is given a strong hand at making policy.
"This whole business was touted as a wonderful example of co-management and industry getting together, but I question whether it's working," he said. "I really have to question whether it's in the best interest of industry to let the fox guard the hen house one more time."

Subject: Commercial fishing; Shellfish; Regulatory agencies; Restrictions; Harvest

Location: Rockland ME US New England

People: Schick, Dan

Few petitioners collect signatures at Maine polls

Author: From Staff Reports

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]05 Nov 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/414091042?accountid=10457

Abstract: Although nine petitions were approved for circulation by the Secretary of State's office, only three were seen at polling places in northern and eastern Maine. Signatures were collected at scattered polling places to force a vote on the repeal of a tax credit for Bath Iron Works, on whether to allow doctors to prescribe marijuana for medicinal use, and to limit pesticide spraying. Petitions seeking to legalize marijuana and to limit campaign contributions were circulated in Ellsworth. If the petitions get at least 51,131 signatures, they will appear on next year's ballot. Bangor City Clerk Gail Campbell said she was concerned when she read that so many petitions could be circulating at polling places. She was, therefore, surprised to find people collecting signatures at only two of Bangor's nine polling places. Volunteers gathered signatures on the BIW tax credit repeal for part of the day at the Civic Center. The medical marijuana and pesticides petitions were circulated at Fifth Street School.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Few+petitioners+collect+signatures+at+Maine+polls&amp;author=From+Staff+Reports&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-11-05&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Far fewer people showed up at the polls to collect signatures on petitions Tuesday than had been expected.
Although nine petitions were approved for circulation by the Secretary of State's office, only three were seen at polling places in northern and eastern Maine. Signatures were collected at scattered polling places to force a vote on the repeal of a tax credit for Bath Iron Works, on whether to allow doctors to prescribe marijuana for medicinal use, and to limit pesticide spraying. Petitions seeking to legalize marijuana and to limit campaign contributions were circulated in Ellsworth. If the petitions get at least 51,131 signatures, they will appear on next year's ballot.
Signatures were also sought for petitions on local issues in some areas.
Bangor City Clerk Gail Campbell said she was concerned when she read that so many petitions could be circulating at polling places. She was, therefore, surprised to find people collecting signatures at only two of Bangor's nine polling places. Volunteers gathered signatures on the BIW tax credit repeal for part of the day at the Civic Center. The medical marijuana and pesticides petitions were circulated at Fifth Street School.
A volunteer who collected signatures on the medical marijuana petition and asked not to be identified for fear of upsetting his employer said about a third of voters he asked agreed to sign the petition. He said only a handful were hostile to the idea.
The volunteer said he was the only one collecting signatures in Bangor but that there were more volunteers in the surrounding area. Election wardens said some groups likely had trouble finding volunteers to collect signatures and were forced to curtail their efforts.
Petitions to raise the minimum age to buy cigarettes to 21, to allow video slot machines at parimutuel betting establishments, to ban federal fuel mandates, to change shellfish licensing and to enact stricter state and congressional term limits were also approved by the secretary of state.
In Ellsworth, a father-and-son team, members of the Green Party, collected signatures on a half-dozen petitions. Most popular was a proposal to criminalize pesticide spraying from the air, which had attracted more than 100 signatures by midafternoon, and a proposal to end tax benefits or other subsidies for Bath Iron Works. A local petition asked Blue Hill Memorial Hospital to stop incinerating waste.
A proposal for a referendum to legalize marijuana gathered 21 signatures, by 2:30 p.m. but 31 voters supported a referendum to legalize marijuana for medicinal purposes.
In Dover-Foxcroft, the only petition being circulated was the Bath Iron Works petition, and people were stopping to sign it, according to Dover-Foxcroft Town Clerk Barbara Moore.
Sangerville residents were more interested in signing a petition for the reconstruction of Route 23 in Sangerville than they were on voting on the issue of widening the turnpike, said Town Clerk Alice Moulton.
The Route 23 reconstruction request was the only petition available for the voters' consideration in this Piscataquis County town.
In Fort Kent, signatures were collected on petitions to limit campaign contributions and to restrict herbicide and pesticide spraying. The BIW, pesticides and medical marijuana petitions were circulated in Lincoln. Voters were asked to sign the medical marijuana petition in Millinocket.

Tales of a Seafarer's Wife The latest in long line of Down East cooks creates demand for fine food

Author: Letitia Baldwin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]05 Nov 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413912631?accountid=10457

Abstract: Go for a Sunday drive down to Jonesport. Take in the sparkling waters of the Moosabec Reach. Cross the bridge to Beals Island, where small, family owned fishing wharves flank the rocky shore. Hike through the moss-carpeted fir and spruce forests broken by granite ledges on Great Wass Island. Then, cap the day with dinner at the Seafarer's Wife back in Jonesport. A hand-painted sign of a woman clad in a yellow apron, gazing through a telescope out to sea, points the way to the restaurant that has drawn people from every state and countries as far-flung as New Zealand. Born and raised in Jonesport, Faye Carver is the force behind the Seafarer's Wife. She comes from a long line of fine Down East cooks. Both her mother and grandmother once ran restaurants in town. Four years ago, carrying on her family's tradition, she opened a restaurant with an accent on fine dining.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Tales+of+a+Seafarer%27s+Wife+The+latest+in+long+line+of+Down+East+cooks+creates+demand+for+fine+food&amp;author=Letitia+Baldwin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-11-05&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Go for a Sunday drive down to Jonesport. Take in the sparkling waters of the Moosabec Reach. Cross the bridge to Beals Island, where small, family owned fishing wharves flank the rocky shore. Hike through the moss-carpeted fir and spruce forests broken by granite ledges on Great Wass Island.
Then, cap the day with dinner at the Seafarer's Wife back in Jonesport. A hand-painted sign of a woman clad in a yellow apron, gazing through a telescope out to sea, points the way to the restaurant that has drawn people from every state and countries as far-flung as New Zealand.
Born and raised in Jonesport, Faye Carver is the force behind the Seafarer's Wife. She comes from a long line of fine Down East cooks. Both her mother and grandmother once ran restaurants in town. Four years ago, carrying on her family's tradition, she opened a restaurant with an accent on fine dining.
Classical music wafts through the air. Candles are lit. Tables are set with white, hand-crocheted placemats. Napkins are tied with satin ribbons. A vase of tiny red carnations and baby's breath graces each table. Old china creamers and sugar bowls are set out.
Wearing a long, white apron and bonnet, Tanya Carver Shaw greets and attends to diners while her mother, behind the scenes, busily prepares the various dishes offered last Sunday evening. As appetizers, she serves melt-in-your-mouth crab canapes, steamed mussels and butter, cheese and crackers, and clusters of grapes and other fresh fruit. A choice of French onion soup or crabmeat stew and a light garden salad follow.
It's not hard to choose a main course. The Seafarer's Wife obtained fresh sea scallops on the opening of Maine's scallop season the previous day. Tender and savory, the shellfish have been baked in a creamy sauce.
A combination of haddock, shrimp, scallops and lobster sauteed in butter, scampi or cream sauces -- called Fisherman's Bounty -- and citrus pork roast were among the other dishes offered. The main course was accompanied by squash puree and an unforgettable blueberry sauce. Freshly baked dill bread comes with the meal.
For dessert, it was a tough choice between apple nut pudding; Seafarer's mud pie, a multilayered concoction of brownie crust, coffee ice cream, toasted almonds and whipped cream; and angel pie made of merengue and raspberries. The old-fashioned pudding was a perfect end to a rich meal.
Sound like a $100 dinner? In terms of quality food and service, it was. But the five-course meal actually cost just under $50 for two people, including tax and tip. Beverages were not included in the flat price. Alcohol is not served, but people can bring their own wine and beer.
Emerging from the kitchen wearing a starched white apron, the creator of the Seafarer's Wife chats with diners. She looks at home in her dining room decorated with a Home Comfort cook stove, ship's lantern, family pictures, crocheted quilts and other heirlooms.
In an interview the next day, Faye Carver tells how she was born in her paternal grandmother Clara Pliskowski's Cozy Corner Restaurant that once stood near the old Underwood sardine-packing plant in Jonesport.
Carver's mother, Virginia Dyer, was and still is an excellent cook who worked at a local inn before opening her own restaurant, Ginny's Food Shop, back in the 1940s. Her pea soup, baking powder biscuits and apple pie were much in demand.
"She made everything stretch. One of the local men used to say, `Man, look at that pea soup. You could add water and make it last a week,"' Carver recalls. "Mumma makes the most beautiful pie crust. Everytime I make something, I think of her."
Carver got an early start in the kitchen. By the age of 12, she was helping out in the kitchen at the inn where her mother worked. She was barely visible behind the kitchen counter.
"One of the salesmen who stayed there always said he was going to buy me a chef's hat so he could see my nose move back and forth," she says, chuckling.
Carver attended school in Jonesport and wound up marrying another Jonesporter, Judson Carver III. He served first in the Air Force and later the Coast Guard. They had one daughter and three sons. They lived all over the country before coming home to Maine nearly a quarter of a century ago.
Carver says she had always dreamed of having her own restaurant, but she didn't consider the idea seriously until her children were all grown up and out of the house four years ago. It took some prodding from her daughter, Tanya.
"I said, `Judd, please can I turn that living room into a dining room?" she remembers asking her husband. He told her, "Do it, go ahead, I don't care."
After cleaning and rearranging her turn-of-the-century home, Carver gathered her family around to brainstorm about how best to go about starting a restaurant. She didn't want to compete with local eateries, but felt there was a need for a restaurant specializing in fine Maine cuisine.
Housed in her front parlor, the Seafarer's Wife started out with only seven tables and four main courses: beef, chicken, haddock and lobster. She and her daughter and daughters-in-law waited on tables. Seating was and still is by reservation only.
Carver's mustard pickles, lobster stew, twice-baked potatoes, Fishermen's Bounty, mud pie puddings and other home-style food proved a hit with Mainers and seasonal visitors to the area. Before too long, to get a reservation took three weeks.
"What tickles my palate is what I think other people might want," she says.
Carver never envisioned she would have quite so much success. She soon found her tiny kitchen was far from adequate. It was so small she couldn't cook and wash dishes at the same time. Also, while she was cooking, her husband was sequestered upstairs.
"He was just like a little mole. We called it his O.J. Simpson quarters," she says.
After another family confab, the Carvers decided to build a larger Seafarer's Wife, with an adjoining eatery called the Ol' Salt, on Route 187 near Snare's Creek. They opened for business last June and are open seven days a week.
A dynamic woman who never stops, Carver doesn't mind that she has only one day off a week. Like her mother and grandmother, she takes pleasure in and prides herself on her cooking.
Last summer, she and her husband celebrated their 40th wedding anniversary.
"Guess where we ate? Guess where we went for dinner?" she asks, laughing.
Chilled Blueberry Soup
Ingredients 3 cups wild blueberries (fresh or frozen) 2 cups apples peeled and cored 1/3 cup lemon juice 3/4 cup white wine or apple juice 1/4 cup honey 2 cups plain, low-fat yogurt 3/4 cup sour cream
Topping: 3/4 cup sour cream 3 tablespoons horseradish 1/2 tablespoon lemon juice
Puree blueberries, apples, lemon juice and honey in blender or food processor. Strain and add yogurt and sour cream. Blend for a few seconds and chill. Serve dollop of topping.
Down East Seafarer's Sauce
Sauce: 2 cups wild blueberries 1 cup water 1/3 cup sugar 1 tablespoon cornstarch 1 20-ounce can crushed pineapple 1 large packet raspberry Jell-O
Topping: 1 8-ounce package cream cheese 1/3 cup plain yogurt or sour cream 1/3 cup sugar
Bring water, sugar and blueberries to a boil. Add heaping tablespoon of cornstarch dissolved in 1/3 cup water. Cook until thickened. Remove from heat and add crushed pineapple.
Dissolve raspberry Jell-O in 1 cup boiling water and add to above mixture. Pour into mold. Mix ingredients for topping until smooth. Place a dollop on conservelike sauce on plate.
Mumma's Grapenut Pudding
1 quart milk 1 cup sugar 2 eggs 1 cup grapenuts 1 teaspoon pure vanilla Pinch of salt
Place milk and grapenuts in double broiler. Heat until grapenuts have softened. Beat sugar, eggs and salt in a bowl. Add to double boiler. Let mixture simmer until thick around the edges, stirring occasionally. Add vanilla and chill.
The Seafarer's Wife on Route 187 is open 5:30-8:30 p.m. seven days a week, tel. 497-2364.

Maine voters to see array of petitions Groups grown tired of Legislature's pace

Author: Susan Kinzie Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]03 Nov 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/414092833?accountid=10457

Abstract: That's why she left part-time environmental activism and her organic farm in Jonesboro to work full time on her citizens initiative to limit pesticide spraying. She's now working in Augusta with a few volunteers, building a network of volunteers at colleges and in towns across the state, some of whom will hit the polls Tuesday with petitions. If they can get 51,131 signatures, which represents 10 percent of the voters in the last gubernatorial election, they can get the question on a future ballot. A populist movement around the turn of the century resulted in a constitutional amendment in 1909. By 3-to-1, Maine voters chose the right to bypass the Legislature when needed. Over the past 80 years or so, that has brought issues such as repealing the income tax, ending nuclear power, banning slot machines and repealing the moose hunting season up for a direct vote. There are 11 petition drives out there now, with at least three pending approval by the Secretary of State's Office. The issues range from capping the sales tax at 3 percent to term limits and repealing the tax credit for Bath Iron Works. The methods used are nearly as diverse as the causes. Some are grass-roots efforts, spreading by word of mouth and the Internet. Others are helped by national organizations which bring money and expertise.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Maine+voters+to+see+array+of+petitions+Groups+grown+tired+of+Legislature%27s+pace&amp;author=Susan+Kinzie+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-11-03&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   AUGUSTA -- The way Nancy Oden, one of Maine's growing number of political activists, sees it, the issue of whether to allow pesticide spraying is simple.
"Does anyone have the right to poison everyone's water? ... What's going on now is a giant experiment of how much poisoning we humans can take before we get sick and die. The answer is -- no more."
That's why she left part-time environmental activism and her organic farm in Jonesboro to work full time on her citizens initiative to limit pesticide spraying. She's now working in Augusta with a few volunteers, building a network of volunteers at colleges and in towns across the state, some of whom will hit the polls Tuesday with petitions. If they can get 51,131 signatures, which represents 10 percent of the voters in the last gubernatorial election, they can get the question on a future ballot.
Those volunteers will not be alone. There will be lots of people with a wide variety of petitions at the polls Election Day, part of the state's constantly growing experiment in direct democracy. It's a simple idea: Bypass the Legislature, and let the people decide.
But even though the ability to put questions on the ballot is a coveted form of democracy -- it's possible in only about a third of the states -- some people believe it is becoming too simple.
They say the complications of the public policy-making in the Legislature are a necessary part of good laws; that the rhetoric in the campaigns is oversimplified; and that too many groups are finding it too easy to initiate legislation.
"Since the early '90s the number {of petitions circulating} and the amount of activity has dramatically increased," said Rebecca Wyke, assistant secretary of state. "It used to be a rare event. Now everyone thinks they can do one."
A populist movement around the turn of the century resulted in a constitutional amendment in 1909. By 3-to-1, Maine voters chose the right to bypass the Legislature when needed. Over the past 80 years or so, that has brought issues such as repealing the income tax, ending nuclear power, banning slot machines and repealing the moose hunting season up for a direct vote.
Until the 1970s, there were only six citizen-initiated bills that ended up on the ballot. In the 1990s, there already have been nine.
There are 11 petition drives out there now, with at least three pending approval by the Secretary of State's Office. The issues range from capping the sales tax at 3 percent to term limits and repealing the tax credit for Bath Iron Works. The methods used are nearly as diverse as the causes. Some are grass-roots efforts, spreading by word of mouth and the Internet. Others are helped by national organizations which bring money and expertise.
Both frustration with the political system and a greater awareness of current events -- through technology such as the Internet -- have contributed to the phenomenal growth of citizen initiatives in Maine and across the United States, according to several experts. Last year there were 90 citizen iniatives on November ballots across the nation.
For someone trying to organize from the ground up, a rural state like Maine can be a huge obstacle. "I feel the burden of {51,131} signatures is excessive," said Oden.
But Wyke said it has become much simpler to collect the necessary signatures. "In 1909 I have to imagine it was a huge undertaking. Now the transportation infrastructure and communications are so much better -- the Internet makes it easier to get the message out -- computers, phones, fax, all make it a lot easier.
"I don't know that it's too easy," she said slowly, thinking it over. "I am discouraged that people use this as an alternative to the legislative process rather than a last resort. It was meant to be when the public rises up because the Legislature will not pass something that they want to pass -- a safety net. ... The legislative process provides a good deal of debate, public hearings, committee discussions, and legislators can amend the bill. ... Put it on a petition and it doesn't matter what kind of debate it engenders -- it passes and can't be changed."
Oden said she has tried for years to change the way pesticides are used in Maine without bypassing the legislative process, and it never worked. She told about reading the label of a pesticide to some bureaucrats: "It said, `Fatal if absorbed through the skin, swallowed or inhaled.' I said, `What does this mean to you?"' pointing to the word `fatal.'
"They just looked at me with blank eyes. There are no answers," she said.
Donald Christen started trying to influence the Legislature to legalize marijuana in 1989, he said, but got fed up with the slow pace.
"No one wants to talk about it, people are scared to do anything. Big Brother is watching," Christen said. He estimated that 200,000 to 300,000 people in Maine smoke pot. "If so many people are doing this, why are they persecuting us like they are?"
He has been arrested several times for marijuana trafficking, and is furious with the police and "the war on drugs which is a war on the citizenry of the United States." Volunteers will be at the polls Tuesday with two petitions Christen started: one to legalize marijuana and the other to legalize marijuana for medical purposes.
Carol Palesky, who has worked on several initiatives to try to lower taxes, says it's extremely important that residents have the right to petition government because "our elected officials, when they go to make laws in the Legislature, are under such political pressure from special interest groups giving donations that they take the meat out of legislation and leave loopholes to those who give the money."
Palesky believes that people who aren't elected aren't beholden to special interests with a lot of money.
She was convicted in August of aggravated forgery for tampering with petitions and is awaiting sentencing. Meanwhile, she is working on two new initiatives -- one to eliminate the snack tax and reduce the sales tax to 3 percent; the other to commit all lottery proceeds to fund education. As of Nov. 1, neither had been approved for circulation by the Secretary of State's Office.
John Brier Jr. has seen firsthand the influence of money, he said, and what big companies can do with their profits. While in Russia last summer he saw a "mobile disco," huge tents containing a dance club paid for by a giant tobacco company, that was moved from city to city by big trucks painted with cigarette advertising.
To get in, you had to show that you had bought five packs of their cigarettes -- no money allowed.
"That's clearly drug-dealer mentality," Brier said. "Move into the neighborhood, get 'em hooked, move on." Because he has seen marketing efforts like that by tobacco companies, and because he learned while researching his master's thesis in health care administration that only 1 percent of smokers began smoking after they were 20 years old, he believes the best way to prevent people from getting hooked on cigarettes is to require that people purchasing a pack be 21 or older.
He doesn't feel like he has time to wait for the Legislature to act: It's a public health crisis, he said, so he has to act fast. "It's so hard to get things done when you've got special intersts, lobbies. It's so hard to get things done. I am bypassing that bog-down. I'll bring it to the people."
But bringing it to the people isn't so easy if you're working full time, he said; he is coordinator of a program at the University of Maine at Augusta. He started the petition last year, but now "it's at a standstill. Initially I was able to set up a group, about 30 people around the state willing to help. But that's where I am now. I need to raise money. Fifty thousand dollars could get it done."
Last week a company from California -- Progressive Campaigns Inc. -- called him, he said, and told him it has organized petition campaigns in several states. Nationally, it's not unusual for companies to charge $1 to $3 per signature.
No one was answering the phone at Progressive Campaigns on Friday, and a message left on its answering machine was not returned that day.
As long as registered Maine voters are collecting the signatures and not earning money for each signature, it's perfectly legal to pay people for a citizens initiative effort. "That is the way things are headed, I guess," said Wyke. There have been national organizations donating money and time to Maine initiatives in the past, she said.
"Many times the people circulating these petitions are paid to circulate them, although in other circumstances it truly is all volunteer-based. It raises free speech issues and campaign funding issues," she said. "It's not always as grass-roots as people think."
William Coogan, an associate professor of political science at the University of Southern Maine, said that about half of the efforts are successful. But ironically, considering the intent of the right to petition, "the side that spends the largest amount of money is successful a very large percentage of the time, close to 90 percent of the time. This type of campaign is particularly susceptible to the influence of big money" on voters.
But for someone like Brier -- who saw his grandmother smoke four packs of cigarettes a day and die of emphysema, saw his uncle die of lung cancer, knows that his mother has been unable to quit smoking, and knows that 3,000 children in Maine start smoking every year -- $50,000 to get the issue on the ballot may well be worth it. "Just think what the state pays every year" on smoking-related illnesses, he said; it makes $50,000 look like small change.
While he knows firsthand how difficult it is to collect the signatures, he thinks the number required is fair. "If it were lower, probably too many issues would make it. It means that when things do come to a vote, a lot of people believe in it enough to sign. If you watered it down it would take away from the credibility of the process."
Christen, who is a full-time activist ("I could probably never get a job," because of his marijuana advocacy, he said), said if fewer signatures were required, it would be easier for people to participate in government. "This makes it very hard for the poor people to participate. If you have the money it doesn't take much to get the circulation, but if you don't have any money and the law is controversial and people who would like to change things are worried they might lose their job and this and that, it sure does make it hard. If 300,000 people in the state of Maine smoke pot, how is it we're having so much trouble collecting the signatures?"
As for Oden, she has been worrying about pesticides for 25 years or more. "I've tried science, logic and begging and pleading ... I finally said, it's getting late here. It's getting late in the poisoning of the earth. If people say, `I don't have time,' nothing will change. ...
"I'm trying to get back some control of the things that affect our health, our lives. It's just a little bit of democracy."
Statewide citizen initiatives

Lecture to focus on clam fishery

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]28 Oct 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413968338?accountid=10457

Abstract: None available.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lecture+to+focus+on+clam+fishery&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-10-28&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BLUE HILL -- In partnership with the Gulf of Maine Council on the Marine Environment, the Marine Environmental Research Institute will offer its second lecture in a series of Coastal Awareness Forums to educate the community about what can be done to help improve water quality and restore the clam fishery.
The forum "Clamming: Can the Fishery Be Restored?" will be held at 7 p.m. Thursday, Nov. 6, at the Blue Hill Public Library.
Panelists from local water quality monitoring groups, the Department of Marine Resources and the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery, along with a local clam warden, municipal officials and local diggers will discuss the status of the clam fishery in Maine.
The third forum, "Fisheries Co-management: Can Fishermen Manage Themselves?" will be held Dec. 4 at the Blue Hill Public Library.
For information, or to request an issue book outlining the clamming issue, call MERI's Patrice Farrey at 359-8078.

Regulation plan would cut season to replenish scallops

Author: Letitia Baldwin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]25 Oct 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413889910?accountid=10457

Abstract: ELLSWORTH -- Sea scallops have thrived on Georges Bank since those fishing grounds were closed to rebuild groundfish stocks several years ago. But the mollusks have not fared as well elsewhere in federal waters along the East Coast. To replenish scallop stocks, the New England and mid-Atlantic fishery management councils are proposing a mechanism enabling them to close fishing areas at critical times of the year, and other measures as part of proposed Amendment 7 to the federal Atlantic Sea Scallop Fishery Management Plan. Georges Bank -- a shallow shelf stretching from East of Cape Cod to the Canadian boundary line -- traditionally had been a prime fishing area for Maine scallop fishermen who hold federal licenses and fish beyond the 3-mile state limit. But that area was closed to fishing because of the collapse of cod, haddock and yellowtail flounder several years ago.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Regulation+plan+would+cut+season+to+replenish+scallops&amp;author=Letitia+Baldwin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-10-25&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ELLSWORTH -- Sea scallops have thrived on Georges Bank since those fishing grounds were closed to rebuild groundfish stocks several years ago. But the mollusks have not fared as well elsewhere in federal waters along the East Coast.
To replenish scallop stocks, the New England and mid-Atlantic fishery management councils are proposing a mechanism enabling them to close fishing areas at critical times of the year, and other measures as part of proposed Amendment 7 to the federal Atlantic Sea Scallop Fishery Management Plan.
The councils, which manage the scallop fishery in federal waters, unveiled Friday the proposed regulations in Ellsworth at the first of a series of public hearings. Other hearings are scheduled for Washington, D.C., New Jersey and Fairhaven, Mass.
Georges Bank -- a shallow shelf stretching from East of Cape Cod to the Canadian boundary line -- traditionally had been a prime fishing area for Maine scallop fishermen who hold federal licenses and fish beyond the 3-mile state limit. But that area was closed to fishing because of the collapse of cod, haddock and yellowtail flounder several years ago.
"We are seeing a phenomenal growth of sea scallops in closed areas at Georges. In some places, they have increased sixfold. That's an impressive growth," John Williamson, a Maine representative on the New England Fishery Management Council and its scallop committee, told the half-dozen scallopers who turned out at the Ellsworth meeting.
Chris Finlayson, a Maine Department of Marine Resources official, said the dramatic growth of scallops on Georges Bank shows closures are an effective management tool lacking in the present scallop management plan.
Southwest Harbor fisherman Brett Mitchell countered that scallop stocks never were depleted on Georges Bank, and prohibiting scallop dragging has only worsened the situation. He used to fish that area.
"The fact those areas have been closed has put pressure in the mid-Atlantic area. Now that area has been pounded," he said.
In Maine, about 355 boats are licensed to fish for scallops in federal waters. But only a handful of scallop boats fish full time far beyond the 3-mile limit. Maine scallop draggers are also much smaller than their counterparts elsewhere along the eastern seaboard, ranging in length from 30-70 feet.
Several years ago, the Atlantic Sea Scallop Management Plan was adopted in an effort to cut harvesting in half. Initially, full-time scallopers were given a maximum of 240 days at sea per year. That figure dropped to 164 this year and is supposed to be reduced to 142 for the next two years.
However, because some scallop grounds since have taken such a pounding, federal fishery scientists are saying full-time scallopers should be limited to as little as 108 days next year.
As part of Amendment 7, the councils are proposing that those fishermen who want to get out of the scallop fishery be given a one-time chance to sell their active days at sea to other federal license holders for whom the industry is still a viable livelihood.
Southwest Harbor seafood dealer Cheryl Harper said such a move could put the fishery in the hands of large corporations that own multiple scallop boats.
"In my mind, only a few big people would be controlling the fishery," she said.
Southwest Harbor fisherman Wade Stroud said he thought scallopers should be given the option of buying days at sea but they should be limited to no more than 240 days per vessel.
"Some people don't want to be in the fishery. That's their way out," he said.

Subject: Fishing industry; Federal regulation; Seafoods; Amendments

Location: Ellsworth ME US New England

Company / organization: Name: New England Fishery Management Council; SIC: 9512

Passamaquoddy fishing trial to begin Tribe claims ancestral right

Author: Diana Graettinger Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]22 Oct 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413970498?accountid=10457

Abstract: The trial of 13 Passamaquoddy fishermen who face charges in Calais District Court for exercising what they claim is their ancestral right to fish in salt water without a state license is expected to begin Thursday morning. He said it is ridiculous to believe the tribe gave up its identity in 1980. "Passamaquoddy means `people who catch pollock,"' he said. "Someone is trying to force the ridiculous notion on us that somehow we agreed to stop being Passamaquoddy." Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Passamaquoddy+fishing+trial+to+begin+Tribe+claims+ancestral+right&amp;author=Diana+Graettinger+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-10-22&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: CALAIS -- The trial of 13 Passamaquoddy fishermen who face charges in Calais District Court for exercising what they claim is their ancestral right to fish in salt water without a state license is expected to begin Thursday morning.
Assistant District Attorney Paul Cavanaugh said Tuesday the state will argue the 1980 Indian Land Claims Settlement Act settled the issue of jurisdiction and made tribal members subject to state law like everyone else.
Fred Moore, the tribe's legislative representative, said Tuesday the tribe did not give up its sovereign right to saltwater fishing when it signed the land claims settlement.
He said it is ridiculous to believe the tribe gave up its identity in 1980. "Passamaquoddy means `people who catch pollock,"' he said. "Someone is trying to force the ridiculous notion on us that somehow we agreed to stop being Passamaquoddy."
The federal land claims settlement extinguished Indian claims to 12.5 million acres that three of the state's four tribes claimed as their aboriginal hunting grounds. The three tribes -- the Passamaquoddy, Penobscot and Maliseet -- were granted self-governing authority similar to municipal home rule.
But nagging disputes about how the settlement act should be interpreted still exist. Saltwater fishing rights were never addressed specifically or resolved in negotiations, according to observers familiar with the agreement.
Although the tribe and the state have been at the bargaining table trying to resolve the issue, marine patrol wardens began summoning tribal members late last year for various saltwater-fishing violations, including taking sea urchins out of season and dragging for scallops without a license.
All of the defendants live on or near the Passamaquoddy reservation at Pleasant Point. They include::
Allie P. Beal, taking sea urchins out of season and two counts of violation of municipal shellfish laws.
Roger K. Brackett, Kenneth J. Newell Jr. and Joseph M. Sapiel, taking shellfish from contaminated flats.
Donell J. Dana Sr., fishing for scallops without a scallop boat license.
Carroll C. Francis and William J. Smith, 20 percent of clams undersize.
Carl J. Jillson Sr., 20 percent of clams undersize and fishing without a shellfish license.
Cecil R. Larkin, two counts of failure to stand by for a marine patrol officer and 20 percent of clams undersize.
Karli G. Murphy, fishing for elvers without a tag.
Francis L. Sapiel Jr., fishing for scallops without a scallop boat license, fishing for scallops without a noncommercial scallop license, and dragging for sea urchins without a license.
Clifton E. Smith Jr., 20 percent of clams undersize and two counts of taking shellfish without a license.
Ronald J. Trott Jr., taking shellfish without a license.
Before the trial begins, 4th District Court Judge John Romei will have to rule on a motion to dismiss the case filed by J. Hilary Billings, a tribal lawyer.
In the motion, Billings claims the state court does not have jurisdiction over the matter because "saltwater-fishing practices consistent with Passamaquoddy tribal heritage, culture and tradition are not subject to regulation by the state."
The attorney maintains that the Legislature and the Passamaquoddy Joint Tribal Council have responsibility over tribal saltwater-fishing rights and both sides are committed to a negotiated resolution.
In hopes that a negotiated resolution could be reached, tribal officials earlier this month spent two hours with Gov. Angus King. After that meeting, tribal leaders said the encounter had cracked open the door for future discussions on the issue, but at the same time they vowed that tribal fishermen would continue to fish Maine's coastal waters without licenses.
Tribal leaders also met with federal officials earlier this month to discuss their right to hunt federally protected porpoises. The Passamaquoddys consider the hunting of porpoises a sacred rite they have performed for generations. After that meeting, the two sides agreed to continue to meet and talk.

German wines require education for novices Learning how to read labels important first step

Author: Chris Plumsted Special to the NEWS

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]22 Oct 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413938247?accountid=10457

Abstract: Everything has a starting point. If you have ever had a glass of wine in your life, the first one may have been a German wine known as a Liebfraumilch. Go ahead, admit it. We've all had Liebfraumilch. There. Doesn't that feel better? Grape variety. This should be indicated, but is not always in lesser-quality wines. The major German varieties include Riesling, Muller Thurgau, Silvaner, Grauburgunder (or Pinot Gris), Weissburgunder (or Pinot Blanc), Scheurebe (a Riesling/Silvaner cross), Rieslaner (another Riesling/Silvaner cross), Gewurtztraminer and Spatburgunder (Pinot Noir), which is a red variety. Most exports to the United States are white. Quality and ripeness level. This is the complicated stuff. On the low end of quality are wines labeled Landwein and Tafelwein. (They usually taste like they sound.) The next level is Qualitatwein bestimmter Anbaugebiete (or QbA). These are wines of fairly decent quality. The next level is Qualitatwein mit Pradikat (or QmP). These QmP wines are listed in ascending order of dryness to sweetness. They are Kabinett, Spatlese, Auslese, Beerenauskese (BA), Eiswein (ice wine) and Trockenbeerenauslese (TBA).

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=German+wines+require+education+for+novices+Learning+how+to+read+labels+important+first+step&amp;author=Chris+Plumsted+Special+to+the+NEWS&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-10-22&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Everything has a starting point. If you have ever had a glass of wine in your life, the first one may have been a German wine known as a Liebfraumilch. Go ahead, admit it. We've all had Liebfraumilch. There. Doesn't that feel better?
You know what I'm talking about, those long thin bottles with happy nuns in the vineyard or the long black cylindrical ones that look like shock absorbers. I can remember my parents serving the stuff at special occasions. They would really be splurging if the holy sisters of the vineyard were on the table.
If that was your first taste of German wine, it may have been your last -- until now.
If you put the words German and beverage in the same sentence, it usually conjures up a stereotypical image of a hefty dude wearing leiderhausen hoisting buckets of pilsner with a bratwurst-eating grin on his face. The solution to this nonsense? Educate yourself with some basics -- and taste the wines.
German wine labels
German wine labels can be somewhat confusing. While many changes in their labeling system have taken place, it still wouldn't hurt to get some basic facts about their viticulture. So here are some fundamentals. Don't worry about the pronunciation of many of these terms; you may hurt yourself.
The wine producer. This is the most critical factor for the quality of the product. Look for the term Erzeugerabfullung or Gustabfullung. This is equivalent to Estate Bottled.
Grape variety. This should be indicated, but is not always in lesser-quality wines. The major German varieties include Riesling, Muller Thurgau, Silvaner, Grauburgunder (or Pinot Gris), Weissburgunder (or Pinot Blanc), Scheurebe (a Riesling/Silvaner cross), Rieslaner (another Riesling/Silvaner cross), Gewurtztraminer and Spatburgunder (Pinot Noir), which is a red variety. Most exports to the United States are white.
Region of origin. These can be even more specific than the major producing regions, which include Mosel, Saar and Ruwer; Rheingau; Nahe; Baden; Rheinhessen; Rheinpfalz; Franken.
Vintage. The year of the grape harvest from which the wine was made.
Alcohol content. The beauty of many of these wines is their relatively low alcohol content and amazing balance.
Dryness. The term "Trocken" means dry. The term "Halbtrocken" means semi-dry.
Quality and ripeness level. This is the complicated stuff. On the low end of quality are wines labeled Landwein and Tafelwein. (They usually taste like they sound.) The next level is Qualitatwein bestimmter Anbaugebiete (or QbA). These are wines of fairly decent quality. The next level is Qualitatwein mit Pradikat (or QmP). These QmP wines are listed in ascending order of dryness to sweetness. They are Kabinett, Spatlese, Auslese, Beerenauskese (BA), Eiswein (ice wine) and Trockenbeerenauslese (TBA).
At the urging of one of its resident wine gurus and sales people, Doug Snell, a longtime friend of importer Rudi Wiest, local beverage distributor Pine State Trading has recently made a large commitment to German wines, having showcased about a dozen recently. If all you have ever had for German wine has been your parents' Liebfraumilch, now is the time to change course. Many of these wines are available now locally at wine stores and in restaurants by the glass.
1995 Iphofer Kalb Estate Silvaner $15
This wine has a nice mineral aroma, extremely crisp and dry. The same relative acidity that you would expect in a French Muscadet. Real clean and extremely dry with spicy nuances, beautifully long finish. It would go very well with shellfish. Interestingly bottled in a "Mateus"-styled bottle. (If you've gotten this far, you know what that is.)
1996 WH Heger Estate Pinot Gris $14
It has a very spicy aroma. Nice fruit, not unlike a Burgundian-styled Chardonnay. Wonderfully balanced with an apricot-like flavor that lingers in the aftertaste.
1995 Fritz Haag Estate Riesling $15
Nice light color with a cinnamon spice aroma. Nice and dry flavors with kind of a peachy flavor and once again a surprisingly long aftertaste. This wine could stand up very well to spicy Asian cooking.
1995 Rhineriver Selection, Cellars International $8
Nice light golden color with a honeyed aroma. It has a very pleasing fruity flavor with a nice medium crisp aftertaste. If you're not brave enough to bridge the Liebfraumilch gap on your own, try this wine. It has a vague similarity with one exception -- it's good.
1996 J.J Prum Estate Riesling $12
Kind of an earthy floral aroma with a light straw color. Full of tropical flavors like mangoes with a nice long finish -- very complex. Wow! I really like this wine.
1996 Saarburger Rausch Kabinett $16
Very delicate aroma. Nice smooth fruit flavors once again followed by crisp amazing acidity that you just don't even suspect.
1995 Urziger Wurzgarten Kabinett $15 --
Nice, subtly styled but not understated. It has a really nice honey flavor balanced by crisp acidity.
1995 Fritz Haag Brauneberberger Juffer-Sonnenuhr Spatlese $31 --
Explosive flavors, not your ordinary Spatlese. This is a real mouthful of wine. Full of flavor with the nice concentration of fruit that you would expect from a quality wine with a superbly long aftertaste. On a par with some of the highest-quality white wines I have ever tasted. I can't believe it's only 8 percent alcohol.
1995 Karthauserhof Spatlese $24 --
A nice elegant style of wine with layers of peach flavors. A good bit crisper in style than the Fritz Haag and not as complex, but overall an excellent wine.
1995 Ungsteiner Herrenberg Scheurebe Spatlese $19 --
This wine has a different, more herbal aroma and flavor that separates it stylistically from the rest. The flavor is pleasing and the sweetness is somewhat cloying, but it is balanced by a really nice aftertaste.
1995 Pfeffingen Ungsteiner Honigsackel Gewurztraminer Spatlese $19 --
Spicy, full and earthy aroma, golden-colored. Sweetly flavored but balanced. Full of rich spices and interesting layers. An excellent dessert wine.
As you try these wines, you will notice that they are magnificently balanced. With their crisp acidity, they have the tendency to be excellent food wines. The natural contrast for these wines is generally spicy foods such as Thai, Indian or even Mediterranean. Because of their elegance and balance, try to pair them off with foods that you would normally have with Chardonnay.
To learn more about German wines, try The German Wine Page: http://www.cogsci.ed.ac.uk/ml There is an excellent book, "Life Beyond Liebfraumilch" by Stuart Pigott. One of the very best quick reference books is "The Simon & Schuster Pocket Guide to German Wines."

Dredging worries clammers Project would ease journey for destroyers at BIW

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]13 Oct 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413974449?accountid=10457

Abstract: A plan to dredge a portion of the Kennebec River to make way for destroyers at Bath Iron Works could mean trouble for clammers. The mud diggers say they agree the dredging is warranted, but they don't think enough is being done to prevent the project from polluting and perhaps smothering some of the bivalves.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Dredging+worries+clammers+Project+would+ease+journey+for+destroyers+at+BIW&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-10-13&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PHIPPSBURG -- A plan to dredge a portion of the Kennebec River to make way for destroyers at Bath Iron Works could mean trouble for clammers.
The mud diggers say they agree the dredging is warranted, but they don't think enough is being done to prevent the project from polluting and perhaps smothering some of the bivalves.
Members of the Army Corps of Engineers, which plans to move about 50,000 cubic yards of the riverbed next month, met with clammers Thursday to tell them about the project.
At two sections of the river, the 500-foot-long destroyers have trouble steering past underwater ridges of sand that have collected along the bottom since 1989, when the river was last dredged.
At the worst spot, Doubling Point, the bottom rises in some places to within 21 feet of the surface, eight feet above the bottom of the ships. In the narrow, fast-moving channel, the ships are forced to make a near 180-degree turn to get past the rising sand.
The corps' director of the project, William Kavanaugh, said he believes the impact on marine life in the area will be negligible. The material to be removed from the river bottom is about 95 percent sand, not the silt and other sediment that typically carries far along the currents, or breeds the bacteria that can force clam-flat closure.
Kavanaugh said the last dredging didn't disrupt clamming along the river.

Woman's encounter with Brady Gang changed the course of her life

Author: Dick Shaw Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]04 Oct 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413987980?accountid=10457

Abstract: Sometimes Marjorie Marsh Quigg believes the Brady Gang came into her life for a reason. In a turn of events so odd it might be fiction, her daughter was born because two gangsters died. And even stranger, in the weeks before the shootout, she rubbed shoulders with the outlaws while working at her father's cafe. Tucked behind Main Street at 101 Pickering Square, near the site of the present Key Plaza, Forrest B. Marsh's Pine Tree Restaurant was a favorite Brady Gang haunt, Quigg said, because it was out of the way, around the corner." Then a new bride of 20, Quigg was a part-time cashier who helped prepare the daily menus whenever her father and mother - known as Queenie" or Mother Marsh" - needed her help.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Woman%27s+encounter+with+Brady+Gang+changed+the+course+of+her+life&amp;author=Dick+Shaw+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-10-04&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Sometimes Marjorie Marsh Quigg believes the Brady Gang came into her life for a reason. In a turn of events so odd it might be fiction, her daughter was born because two gangsters died. And even stranger, in the weeks before the shootout, she rubbed shoulders with the outlaws while working at her father's cafe.
Tucked behind Main Street at 101 Pickering Square, near the site of the present Key Plaza, Forrest B. Marsh's Pine Tree Restaurant was a favorite Brady Gang haunt, Quigg said, because it was out of the way, around the corner."
In common parlance, they had probably cased the joint before they ever came in to dine," the Bangor woman recalled.That was always at 5 minutes to 8 in the evening, just before closing time. I suppose they could eat at that hour without anyone seeing them."
Then a new bride of 20, Quigg was a part-time cashier who helped prepare the daily menus whenever her father and mother - known as Queenie" or Mother Marsh" - needed her help.
Greeting three men seated at a front window table one night, she sized them up as well-dressed, soft-spoken city slickers.
There was nothing about them that aroused my suspicions, but you just knew they were different, even before they said anything," she remembered. They were not refined, a little hard looking. But certainly not gangster types. All of the girls loved to wait on them because they tipped so well."
One evening, Quigg said, her father was unable to serve the trio an hors d'oeuvre they'd ordered. As they stood up to greet him, he said, Gentlemen, I hope you'll find everything satisfactory. But I don't have oysters on the half shell tonight. Come back in a few days and I'll have them for you."
They agreed, content to eat their steaks. For small men they had voracious appetites, Quigg remembered, no daily specials for them."
A week or so later she bumped into the threesome again a few blocks from the Pine Tree. Hurrying back to the restaurant one afternoon after buying a $3 suede belt at Rines Department Store at 43 Main St., she was startled when the driver of a black touring car parked at the curb honked his horn at her. She jumped, the three hoods in the front seat giggled, and that's when I saw the teeth of one of the men. He had beautiful teeth," she recalled.
The other half of her story has a different twist. On the morning of Oct. 12, following weeks of medical problems, Quigg was scheduled to consult with her surgeon at a local hospital for a possible hysterectomy. Her husband, Paul, and other family members were anguished over her decision, fearing a vibrant, young woman soon might be unable to bear children.
She unpacked her overnight bag after Paul burst into their home with startling news. There had been a shooting downtown and her surgeon, Dr. John Bud" Thompson, was detained at another hospital to help assist with a wounded FBI agent, Walter Walsh.
Quigg reassessed her need for surgery and, to her surprise and her family's delight, she soon became pregnant. On July 7, 1938, her daughter, Nancy Jane, was born. Her only child, Nancy Smith, now 59, is a teacher in East Taunton, Mass., with two sons of her own.
On Oct. 13, Forrest, Queenie and Marjorie were horrified to see mug shots in the morning papers revealing the three young men from the Pine Tree Restaurant as America's most-wanted criminals.
The shootout was shocking in a way," Quigg recalled. My parents and I just thought, "Well, there's some reason why this happened to our family."
Illustration Caption: Marjorie Quigg encountered the three bandits at her father's Bangor cafe. (NEWS Photo By Michele Stapleton)

Sorrento mussel farm receives 10-year lease

Author: Catherine Heins Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]04 Oct 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413944075?accountid=10457

Abstract: SORRENTO -- Great Eastern Mussel Farms has received a 10-year exclusive lease to grow blue mussels in a 14.3-acre patch of Flanders Bay, off the eastern shore of Sorrento, despite protests from a few residents. The Department of Marine Resources authorized the permit, one of about half a dozen active mussel leases statewide, last month. Great Eastern, based in Tenants Harbor, expects the site to yield up to 7,000 bushels of the mollusks per year. Great Eastern has been growing mussels since 1979. The company harvests, processes and markets about 150,000 bushels of mussels a year. [Chip] Davison said Great Eastern also has leases in Stonington and Trenton, and has harvested wild mussels in Flanders Bay for years.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Sorrento+mussel+farm+receives+10-year+lease&amp;author=Catherine+Heins+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-10-04&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: SORRENTO -- Great Eastern Mussel Farms has received a 10-year exclusive lease to grow blue mussels in a 14.3-acre patch of Flanders Bay, off the eastern shore of Sorrento, despite protests from a few residents.
The Department of Marine Resources authorized the permit, one of about half a dozen active mussel leases statewide, last month. Great Eastern, based in Tenants Harbor, expects the site to yield up to 7,000 bushels of the mollusks per year.
"That area is very good for mussels," said Great Eastern's president, Chip Davison. "And it's not a good lobster area."
Great Eastern has been growing mussels since 1979. The company harvests, processes and markets about 150,000 bushels of mussels a year. Davison said Great Eastern also has leases in Stonington and Trenton, and has harvested wild mussels in Flanders Bay for years.
"What's new about this is that we seed the beds instead of waiting for nature to do it."
Davison said juvenile mussels can reach adult size in a year if they are transplanted from wild beds and spread thinly. In the wild, they are often so densely packed that it takes 12 years for them to grow to full size.
More than a third of Maine's mussel harvest is now cultivated instead of simply collected from the wild, according to Michael Hastings, director of the Aquaculture Innovation Center in Brewer.
Great Eastern plans to spend about two weeks a year seeding the mussels, and another two weeks dragging them -- a noisy process that some Sorrento residents, such as John Dedam, aren't thrilled about.
Dedam, who lives on Treasure Island just south of the leased site, said he opposes the permit not just because of the noise but also because he has seen the aftermath of dragging and feels that it damages the ecology of the bay.
"It was almost like someone drove a bulldozer over it and pushed everything aside," said Dedam. He and his wife, Connie, a Sorrento selectman, asked the DMR to deny the permit at a public hearing in August. Dedam said he wasn't surprised, however, to learn last week that it had been approved.
The mussels will be unloaded at the Winter Harbor Marine Trading Co.
"It's a plus for us," said boat yard manager Ernest Rice. Rice said that though the effects of dragging may still be controversial, growing the mussels at least replenishes the supply.
