____________________________________________________________

Maine fishermen flexing their mussels Fishermen catching on to mollusks

Author: Letitia Baldwin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]04 Oct 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413902430?accountid=10457

Abstract: With demand growing for the bearded mollusk, several dozen Maine fishermen, fish farmers and other people are looking to capitalize on the trend. For a year now, they have been learning the method to produce prime mussels that has proved the most cost-effective in major mussel-producing nations such as Spain, Portugal and New Zealand. From Freeport to Eastport, 39 Mainers have been experimenting with gear used to grow mussels on ropes suspended from wooden rafts floating in the ocean. They see cultivation of the blue-black mollusks as a means to supplement their income at a time when scientists are warning that shrimp, lobsters, sea urchins and other marine resources are being overfished. Frenchboro lobsterman Daniel Lunt has fished for nearly two decades. In a year, he has raised mussels from seed to market size on ropes suspended from a wooden raft moored off the ferry terminal in Lunt's Harbor.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Maine+fishermen+flexing+their+mussels+Fishermen+catching+on+to+mollusks&amp;author=Letitia+Baldwin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-10-04&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Steamed in white wine or served on the half shell as hors d'oeuvres, blue mussels have steadily gained in popularity among Americans and at fine restaurants across the United States.
With demand growing for the bearded mollusk, several dozen Maine fishermen, fish farmers and other people are looking to capitalize on the trend. For a year now, they have been learning the method to produce prime mussels that has proved the most cost-effective in major mussel-producing nations such as Spain, Portugal and New Zealand.
From Freeport to Eastport, 39 Mainers have been experimenting with gear used to grow mussels on ropes suspended from wooden rafts floating in the ocean. They see cultivation of the blue-black mollusks as a means to supplement their income at a time when scientists are warning that shrimp, lobsters, sea urchins and other marine resources are being overfished.
Frenchboro lobsterman Daniel Lunt has fished for nearly two decades. In a year, he has raised mussels from seed to market size on ropes suspended from a wooden raft moored off the ferry terminal in Lunt's Harbor.
"It would be a lot of work before it became someone's sole job. But it could be worked into a nice supplement pretty easy," Lunt summed up this week.
For a decade now, Brooklin resident Paul Brayton has been experimenting with suspension culture. A former mussel draggerman and seafood dealer, he is aiming to raise mussels on a commercial level starting next year.
Brayton says the beauty of raising mussels this way is the fact it doesn't involve feeding or treating the mollusks as has to be done in other types of aquaculture.
"All you are really doing is taking what nature is already producing and enhancing its opportunity to grow," he said this week.
Called suspension culture, fishermen collect mussel seed on ropes hanging from wooden rafts. Once enough seed has collected, the baby mollusks are fed into a hopper. They emerge from it in netlike socks, where they grow to market size suspended in the water. A raft measuring 20 by 24 feet can yield up to 300 bushels worth about $6,000. Currents, water temperature and site selection are key for such operations to succeed.
Suspension culture does require permits from both the Maine Department of Marine Resources and the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. Regulations for experimental aquaculture operations are being drafted by the DMR.
Maine's mussel fishery dates back at least a century. Traditionally, the mollusks have been harvested from the wild with hand rakes or by fishing vessels equipped with chain-sweep drags. In recent years, harvesters have been sewing mussel seed on the sea bottom to produce a meatier, better-quality product.
Over the past three decades, Maine's annual mussel landings have soared from 3,025 pounds worth $3,025 to 5.6 million pounds valued at $2 million, according to the National Marine Fisheries Service.
While the harvest has grown, Maine's top mussel processor and marketer says it has not been enough to meet growing demand for the tastier, thin-shelled mollusks sought by restaurants and supermarket chains across the United States.
"Demand has exceeded supply," Carter Newall, biologist and research and development coordinator at Great Eastern Mussel Farms in Tenants Harbor, reported this week.
In recent years, Great Eastern Mussel Farms has led the effort to produce higher-quality mussels. The company has been leasing sea bottom, sewing mussel seed and letting the mollusks develop to marketable size. Now, the company is promoting the even more profitable suspension culture.
Canada has invested research dollars to raise mussels using the rope-culture method in waters off Prince Edward Island. That province is now producing considerably more mussels than Maine. The cultivated creatures boast a greater meat-to-shell ratio, and thinner shells easier to crack open. They sell for 80 cents to $1 a pound.
"It's a real lesson for us. They have focused on development," Newall said. He said Maine needs to catch up.
Years ago, some Maine aquaculturists tried raising mussels on ropes suspended from floating rafts. The technique proved too labor-intensive. But the technology has been vastly improved since then.
Last year, Newall organized the Mussel Working Group made up of fishermen and other interested people to get rope culture under way in Maine waters. The initiative has been backed financially by the Island Institute in Rockland and the Brewer-based Maine Aquaculture Innovation Center.
Since last year, group members have been testing pot warp and other types of rope to determine what is suitable for Maine waters. They concluded a black rope with fuzzy strands -- resembling the branches of an artificial Christmas tree -- produced in New Zealand proved to be the most effective.
Island Institute supplied two experimental rafts while some fishermen and aquaculturists have built their own platforms. The Mussel Working Group also has acquired some Spanish equipment for shifting juvenile mussels from ropes to grow-out socks, and for declumping the harvested mollusks.
Newall says participants in the mussel project are aiming to grow mussel on a commercial scale within two years.
"This suspension technique offers traditional fishermen a potentially ideal way to supplement their income," he said.
Illustration Caption: Corrie Roberts and Tim Dowling, field researchers with the Island Institute, check ropes of mussels from their seed-collection raft near Allen Island, where the institute is experimenting with raising mussels. Corrie Roberts holds a rope from a grow-out raft the Island Institute is using to raise mussels. A 1-year-old mussel. (NEWS Photos by Bob DeLong)

Mercury can be deadly

Author: Wood, Clair

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]03 Oct 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413856747?accountid=10457

Abstract: Officials in Waterville have been shaken in recent weeks by the discovery of large quantities of toxic mercury metal in an abandoned warehouse. It will ultimately cost thousands of dollars to effect a cleanup but the more worrisome aspect is its possible health effects on those who have been exposed to it for years. The majority are children who played in liquid metallic mercury at the site and often carried it home to contaminate their entire households. Many persons have now been left to wonder about the toxicity of mercury. The literature is full of horror stories regarding mercury poisoning that surfaces with such symptoms as severe nausea and pain, irregular gait, convulsions, mental disorientation, and death. One of the earliest documented examples of mercury posioning gave rise to the old saying, "mad as a hatter," and came from the symptoms exhibited by workers who used mercury compounds in the manufacture of felt hats years ago. In the 1950s more than 650 people died, and thousands fell ill, due to mercury from industrial waste pumped into Minamata Bay in Japan being taken up by fish and shellfish. Many of the most tragic victims were newborn children who suffered permanent brain damage and other birth defects due to the mother having eaten mercury-contaminated seafood while pregnant.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Mercury+can+be+deadly&amp;author=Wood%2C+Clair&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-10-03&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Officials in Waterville have been shaken in recent weeks by the discovery of large quantities of toxic mercury metal in an abandoned warehouse. It will ultimately cost thousands of dollars to effect a cleanup but the more worrisome aspect is its possible health effects on those who have been exposed to it for years. The majority are children who played in liquid metallic mercury at the site and often carried it home to contaminate their entire households. Many persons have now been left to wonder about the toxicity of mercury.
The short answer is that it is extremely toxic both as a free element and in many of its compounds. For the next two weeks, this column will review the hazards of mercury and the poisonous effects it is having on the environment and people of Maine.
The literature is full of horror stories regarding mercury poisoning that surfaces with such symptoms as severe nausea and pain, irregular gait, convulsions, mental disorientation, and death. One of the earliest documented examples of mercury posioning gave rise to the old saying, "mad as a hatter," and came from the symptoms exhibited by workers who used mercury compounds in the manufacture of felt hats years ago. In the 1950s more than 650 people died, and thousands fell ill, due to mercury from industrial waste pumped into Minamata Bay in Japan being taken up by fish and shellfish. Many of the most tragic victims were newborn children who suffered permanent brain damage and other birth defects due to the mother having eaten mercury-contaminated seafood while pregnant.
A graphic example of just how poisonous mercury compounds can be happened at Dartmouth College this past June. Dr. Karen Wetterhahn, a professor of chemistry, died after spilling a few drops of the compound dimethylmercury on her hands. Even though she was wearing protective gloves enough of the deadly compound penetrated the latex, and was absorbed into the bloodstream, to cause her death.
Tons of waste mercury found its way into Maine's rivers during the early days of papermaking. Two compounds necessary for papermaking are chlorine and sodium hydroxide. These were prepared by breaking down a saturated brine solution in an electrolytic cell using mercury metal as the cathode. When the electrode was recharged, mercury sludge was simply dumped into the river on the assumption that the heavy liquid metal would settle deep into the silt of the river bottom out of harm's way. What was not understood at the time is that bacteria converts metallic mercury into water-soluble and fat-soluble forms of methyl mercury that work their way into the food chain and ultimately into Maine's birds and aquatic life. Mercury contamination is also due, in significant measure, to ash from coal-fired power plants in the central United States being borne eastward by prevailing winds and deposited in the northeast. Whatever the source, it is a fact of life that Maine's seemingly pristine wilderness is carrying a mercury burden that has rendered many gamefish unsafe to eat.
The following is a quotation from a 1997 advisory on fish consumption from the Bureau of Health of the Maine Department of Human Services: "Pregnant women, nursing mothers, women who may become pregnant, and children less than 8 years old, should NOT EAT warm water fish species (bass, pickerel, perch, sunfish, crappie) caught in any of Maine's inland surface waters. Consumption of cold water species (trout, salmon, smelt, cusk) should be limited to 1 meal per month. The consumption of older cold water fish (e.g. a large lake trout) should be avoided."
Persons not coming under the above categories should limit their consumption to 2 to 3 meals per month. This is a mercury advisory so, in essence, this toxic metal has placed much of Maine's gamefish off limits to a sizeable segment of the population. Next week's column will deal with the hazards of metallic mercury and some of the surprising places it turns up.
Clair Wood is the Bangor Daily News science columnist.

Hundreds expected for cleanup Coastweek event marked by volunteers' effort

Author: Orna Izakson Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]02 Oct 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413857278?accountid=10457

Abstract: Jennifer Litteral, the assistant harbor master in Bar Harbor, is looking forward to giving away hundreds of T-shirts when volunteers descend on the town to help haul garbage off the shore and out of the water. Bar Harbor had the largest turnout in the state for last year's annual Coastweek cleanup, with 250 volunteers. Those workers gathered 168 bags of garbage weighing 2,600 pounds, Litteral said, filling three dump trucks. Coastweek officially starts Saturday with beach cleanup efforts around the state and other activities continuing through Oct. 11. Bar Harbor will be hosting cruise ships on Oct. 4, Litteral said, and so had to pick Oct. 11 for its cleanup day.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Hundreds+expected+for+cleanup+Coastweek+event+marked+by+volunteers%27+effort&amp;author=Orna+Izakson+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-10-02&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Jennifer Litteral, the assistant harbor master in Bar Harbor, is looking forward to giving away hundreds of T-shirts when volunteers descend on the town to help haul garbage off the shore and out of the water.
Bar Harbor had the largest turnout in the state for last year's annual Coastweek cleanup, with 250 volunteers. Those workers gathered 168 bags of garbage weighing 2,600 pounds, Litteral said, filling three dump trucks.
"It was so big last year, people were so into it, that I have a feeling we're going to get more people" this year, she said.
Coastweek officially starts Saturday with beach cleanup efforts around the state and other activities continuing through Oct. 11. Bar Harbor will be hosting cruise ships on Oct. 4, Litteral said, and so had to pick Oct. 11 for its cleanup day.
But Litteral is so confident about increased participation this year that she has ordered 350 shirts to give away to cleanup volunteers. The shirts feature artwork by Lulu Zhang, a third-grade pupil at the Conners School in Bar Harbor.
Bar Harbor also had last year's highest turnout of divers to help remove old tires, bottles, sunglasses and other debris from under the waves. Seventeen divers and eight boats participated in 1996.
Certified scuba divers need to bring nothing other than their desire to help, Litteral said. Wet suits and scuba gear all have been donated by Rockland Boat, Inc. of Southwest Harbor. Interested divers should contact the Bar Harbor harbor master's office at 288-5571 so workers there can make sure appropriate equipment is available.
The annual program is the biggest environmental event in Maine each year. In 1996, 3,123 people around the state each carried an average of about 10 pounds of garbage off Maine's shoreline, collecting a total of 30,806 pounds of litter -- about 126 pounds per mile.
Paul Dest, the Coastweek coordinator in the Maine State Planning Office, said turnout ultimately will depend on the weather. But he already has received an unprecedented number of calls from school groups this year, which may translate into more children helping clean the beaches.
Dest and local coordinators have scheduled events in most Maine counties, including cleanups at parks, beaches and along rivers. Some events focus solely on children, such as Saturday's event at Toothacher Cove on Swan's Island, sponsored by the Center Drive School.
Most events, however, are free and open to anyone who wants to participate as long as space allows.
Special events range from boat cruises and historical tours to underwater cleanups and opportunities to paint city streets. The Maine Chapter of the Sierra Club, for example, will offer participants an opportunity to protect waterways near Bangor and Portland from oil pollution.
Each year, motor oil is thrown away or spilled down driveways and parking lots into city storm drains, fouling rivers and coastal waters. On Saturday, Bangor volunteers will hit the streets to paint those storm drains with the message "Don't Dump: Drains to the River." For more information on the event, contact Matt Scease of the Sierra Club at 761-5616.
Other special events include a presentation by ecologist and former commercial fisherman Sherman Hoyt on cooperative efforts that led to the opening of shellfish beds in the St. Georges River at 7 p.m. Friday at the Penobscot Marine Museum in Searsport.
The Hurricane Island Outward Bound School will host two free one-hour cruises around Rockland Harbor Saturday. The boats will accept passengers on a first-come, first-served basis and leave at 10 a.m. and 11 a.m. from the Rockland Pier.
Other cruises, with park naturalists from Acadia National Park on board, leave daily during the week from Northeast Harbor and Bar Harbor. For more information about the trips, call 276-5352 for the Islesford historical cruise out of Northeast Harbor, or 288-3322 for the Frenchman Bay Nature Cruise out of Bar Harbor. Prices for the trips range from $12 to $15 for adults, and reservations are recommended.
Rangers from Acadia National Park offer special programs during the week, including hawk watching, easy walks and presentations about geology and fall foliage.
The Maine State Museum in Augusta offers a variety of programs, including a hands-on look at lobsters and how they are caught, an examination of creatures that live in tide pools, and an opportunity to sew sails using traditional tools.
County coordinators have more information about the location of cleanup events in their areas:
York County: Nancy Bayse, 646-1555 ext. 18;
Cumberland County: Mathew Scease, 761-5616;
Sagadahoc County: Don Hudson and Lynne Flaccus, 882-7323;
Lincoln County: Ginny Libby, 563-1475, or Doris Balant, 563-1216;
Knox County: Roy Salzman, 596-7072;
Waldo County: Ann Moffit, 548-0334;
Hancock County: Ron Beard, 1-800-287-1479;
Washington County: Charles Parker, 483-3824.
For statewide information, contact Dest at the State Planning Office, 287-5305.

Species migration

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]29 Sep 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413927017?accountid=10457

Abstract: I greatly appreciated Clair Wood's recent column {Sept. 19} concerning species migration as a global threat. While he stated that little is being done and federal laws allow importation of species until it becomes a problem, in fact, certain federal agencies are very concerned with the accidental introduction of exotic species. Congress passed HR 4283, the Invasive Aquatic Species Act, in October 1996 that mandates the U.S. Coast Guard to monitor ballast water discharge from large ships while at U.S. poarts, and to have ships voluntarily comply with the practice of exchanging ballast water from foreign ports in the open ocean in depths over 10,000 feet deep, to help prevent the accidental introduction of exotic species to the United States. This fact also requires that scientific panels be set up for several areas to conduct research to determine invasions and the best methods of reducing new invasions.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Species+migration&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-09-29&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: I greatly appreciated Clair Wood's recent column {Sept. 19} concerning species migration as a global threat. While he stated that little is being done and federal laws allow importation of species until it becomes a problem, in fact, certain federal agencies are very concerned with the accidental introduction of exotic species. Congress passed HR 4283, the Invasive Aquatic Species Act, in October 1996 that mandates the U.S. Coast Guard to monitor ballast water discharge from large ships while at U.S. poarts, and to have ships voluntarily comply with the practice of exchanging ballast water from foreign ports in the open ocean in depths over 10,000 feet deep, to help prevent the accidental introduction of exotic species to the United States. This fact also requires that scientific panels be set up for several areas to conduct research to determine invasions and the best methods of reducing new invasions.
In March, the Quoddy Spill Prevention Group, a volunteer organizaton concerned with environmental issues of the Quoddy region in Down East Maine, held a forum at which representatives from 17 Canadian and 12 American agencies and ports were present to discuss methods of control and amelioration of exotic species to the Gulf of Maine and to discuss the impact the new federal bill might have on shipping. The QSPG sponsored a presentation at the Gulf of Maine Marine Council (GOMMC) at Campobello, New Brunswick, in June during which the Coast Guard gave a very professional presentation of their role in carrying out the new federal laws. The GOMMC, consisting of government officials from the states and provinces surrounding the Bay of Fundy and Gulf of Maine, are addressing the issue of setting up a scientific panel fo the Gulf of Maine to study this probelm. Dr. Jim Carlton of Wilson College in Mystic Conn., the world's foremost authority on accidental introduction via ballast water, has documented at least seven exotic species in the Gulf of Maine during the last decade, and has stated that there will be at least one new damaging introduction to the gulf before the year 2000.
The wheels of federal and state bureaucratics can grind very slowly but at least they are in motion. There have been several horror stories on a global scale, including the deaths of 50,000 people in Peru who were killed by cholera introduced in 1991 from the Amazon River by a freighter, the closing of all Gulf of Mexico oyster harvests due to the introduction of this same virus in the mid-1990s, as well as the familiar zebra mussel introduction to the Great Lakes. With the passing of HR 4283, at least the issue is being recognized and addressed, and hopefully in the near future these accidental introductions can be significantly reduced. Steve Crawford Chairman Quoddy Spill Prevention Group Eastport

Students: Give me Liberty Blue Hill school's opening day filled with enthusiasm

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]25 Sep 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/414058431?accountid=10457

Abstract: On Wednesday, the 15-year-old freshman from Brooklin arrived for his first day of class to find himself the object of individual attention personified, as the sole student enrolled in "Real Math." Wednesday was opening day at the Liberty School, the latest pioneering effort in secondary education in Maine. The new high school seeks to provide students with plenty of individual attention and more than a measure of independence, commodities some say are wanting in more traditional education. The school is the brainchild of co-founder and acting director Arnold Greenberg, best known as founder and former owner of the Left Bank Cafe, a funky local venue attracting nationally known performers.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Students%3A+Give+me+Liberty+Blue+Hill+school%27s+opening+day+filled+with+enthusiasm&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-09-25&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BLUE HILL -- Garrett Poole is in a class by himself.
On Wednesday, the 15-year-old freshman from Brooklin arrived for his first day of class to find himself the object of individual attention personified, as the sole student enrolled in "Real Math."
No problem, said teacher Larry Reynolds, who spent the next 70 minutes seated at a small wooden table with Garrett, with whom he reviewed basic algebra, even as power tools whined just outside the window.
Wednesday was opening day at the Liberty School, the latest pioneering effort in secondary education in Maine. The new high school seeks to provide students with plenty of individual attention and more than a measure of independence, commodities some say are wanting in more traditional education.
The school is the brainchild of co-founder and acting director Arnold Greenberg, best known as founder and former owner of the Left Bank Cafe, a funky local venue attracting nationally known performers.
"This is great. The kids are really high -- very excited about their classes," said Greenberg, a former educator who is teaching a variety of courses including tap dancing, one of his specialties.
A published poet and author of a book on education, Greenberg served in administrative posts at other alternative schools in the Northeast for many years before coming to Blue Hill more than a decade ago.
As a self-described "democratic learning community," the Liberty School has enrolled 40 students presumably seeking greater autonomy as they pursue their educations.
That would be true for Garrett Poole, whose parents home-schooled him and enrolled him in a Christian school before this year.
"Here, the students are not going to sit at school for eight hours and get 45 minutes of education," said Garrett's father, Gerard Poole, a shellfish dealer known for his independent views. He likes the idea that his son can design his education according to his own interests.
Nonetheless, as a parent, the elder Poole knows some of his more traditional peers are skeptical of an open-campus school like Liberty. "I've heard all kinds of comments that this will be some kind of hippie or yuppie school. And believe me, I'm neither, as you can tell by looking at me."
Wearing beads and bell-bottoms, 16-year-old junior Bethany Sargent of Blue Hill agrees that observers need to see beyond stereotypes.
"I think it's been viewed because we don't have grades that it's gonna be a bunch of people who want to slack off and don't want to work," Sargent said. "But our evaluations will tell us our weaknesses and strengths, and because we'll be self-motivated, it's going to be a lot harder."
Sargent has served since last spring on the school's community council, an organization including students, faculty and administrators that will set school policy and make decisions on day-to-day affairs.
Formerly enrolled in the local high school in Blue Hill, the student who lists her special interests as art and music craves more individual attention.
"I went to George Stevens Academy for two years," said Sargent. It's a pretty good school, but there's so many students that it's hard for the teachers to work one-on-one, which is what a lot of students need."
Sargent's first class Wednesday was an independent study course on the 1960s with half-time humanities teacher Robin Furth, one of two Liberty instructors who taught at Surry Elementary School before making the switch.
"Where I taught, there were many fine teachers, and I believe in public education. But I thought I'd really like to work with older students in an alternative setting," explained Furth, a poet whose special interests are World War II and the 1960s.
As one of Liberty's seven regular teachers, Furth likes the greater freedom of students to choose their own courses and craft independent studies. "I have high hopes and dreams for the school. Time will tell," she said.
Describing himself as a teacher with four courses and 400 ideas, Reynolds has high aspirations as well.
"I spent last year teaching in Africa. I had a great time, and I was at a school where the people treated me excellently. I want to take some of you and go back there," Reynolds told Liberty School students this week. He has suggested students take a school trip to Africa to get to know the people and the landscape.
A pilot, Reynolds also will teach an aviation course for which 12 students already have signed up. As is true with all courses, the class will teach a blend of practical skills, including navigation and flying, as well as attempt to put the subject in perspective -- in this case through the literature of flying by authors like Antoine de Saint-Exupery.
In the meantime, school organizers have some very down-to-earth concerns to worry about. The state Department of Education has not designated Liberty as eligible to receive tuition, due to some unresolved issues including certification that state officials identified during a site visit last week. Greenberg hopes to achieve a tuition-eligible designation Sept. 30, when officials will visit again.
The school's goal is to raise about $175,000 toward capital expenses this year. But its operations will depend primarily on tuition, as will all but a handful of students, said Greenberg.
As a maverick enterprise in education, the Liberty School will without doubt operate in a fishbowl, Greenberg said this week.
"We have a responsibility to other students in other schools to demonstrate that students can be trusted and have freedom," said the school director. "I just feel very confident we're going to make a big dent in education in Maine."
Illustration Caption: The atmosphere in Mark Hibbins' math class was relaxed as students met for the first time at Liberty School in Blue Hill. Hibbins told students he wanted them to feel comfortable and to work hard in class. (NEWS Photo by Susan Latham) Arnold Greenberg, acting director of Liberty School in Blue Hill, teaches a class on Mark Twain (right) to a group of seven students on the first day of classes at this nontraditional school. Student Bethany Sargent (above) meets with instructor Robin Furth to start work on an independent study project on the 1960s. (NEWS Photos by Susan Latham)

Title: Courts:   [ALL Edition ]

Publication title: Bangor Daily News; Bangor, Me.

____________________________________________________________

Calcium research advances Bar Harbor firm

Author: Michael McDonald Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]11 Sep 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413878694?accountid=10457

Abstract: A marine biotechnology company that was recently founded in Bar Harbor, AquaBio Products Sciences, announced Wednesday that it had formed a strategic partnership with a pharmaceutical company in Utah that promises to boost the number of its employees from two to 20 in the next year. Dr. Ira Levine, the chief operating officer of AquaBio Products, said at a press conference in Augusta that research by the small start-up firm has resulted in "basic technologies that will certainly lead to hundreds of millions of dollars of sales in pharmaceuticals" for the Utah company, NPS Pharmaceuticals Inc.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Calcium+research+advances+Bar+Harbor+firm&amp;author=Michael+McDonald+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-09-11&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: AUGUSTA -- A marine biotechnology company that was recently founded in Bar Harbor, AquaBio Products Sciences, announced Wednesday that it had formed a strategic partnership with a pharmaceutical company in Utah that promises to boost the number of its employees from two to 20 in the next year.
Dr. Ira Levine, the chief operating officer of AquaBio Products, said at a press conference in Augusta that research by the small start-up firm has resulted in "basic technologies that will certainly lead to hundreds of millions of dollars of sales in pharmaceuticals" for the Utah company, NPS Pharmaceuticals Inc.
The Bar Harbor company is housed at the Mount Desert Island Biological Laboratory and was founded by three Harvard Medical School colleagues: Dr. William Harris, Dr. Edward Brown, and Dr. Steve Hebert.
The company does research on fish and other marine species, identifying the sensors that control the metabolism of calcium. This research, Levine said, had led to potential commercial applications in the health care industry. AquaBio is developing drugs that may be used by NPS Pharmaceuticals to treat calcium-related health problems, such as osteoporosis and thyroid problems.
Levine also said that the research into calcium metabolism can be commercially applied in the aquaculture industry, improving the growth of fish, shellfish, and sea vegetables.
AquaBio, which is valued at about $4 million, has already signed a contract to use its research to improve production at Great Bay Aqua Farms, a sushi producer in New Hampshire, said Levine.
Gov. Angus King, who attended the announcement of the partnership, said it represents "exactly the kind of new industry that we want to attract to Maine" and "puts Maine at the forefront of marine biotechnology innovation."

____________________________________________________________

King hails Eastport's Estes Head port

Author: Diana Graettinger Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]08 Sep 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413964069?accountid=10457

Abstract: Gov. Angus King is a polished media personality, but Saturday, during Eastport Port Days, he was upstaged by diminutive Molly King, his charming daughter, who will turn 4 on Friday. While waiting for her father to take his turn at the podium, Molly King was busy eating oyster crackers and writing on the program with a pen. Occasionally, Molly had a short comment, but for the most part, her dark brown eyes were focused on her artistic efforts. The governor and U.S. Rep. John Baldacci were in Eastport Saturday to help celebrate construction of the $15 million port at Estes Head. The port will replace a smaller downtown port and will allow for more shipping traffic in and out of Eastport. Currently, shipping in the downtown port is primarily related to pulp from Georgia Pacific Corp. of Baileyville. The port, expected to be open in July 1998, has been designed to broaden the types of goods and materials shipped in and out of Eastport.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=King+hails+Eastport%27s+Estes+Head+port&amp;author=Diana+Graettinger+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-09-08&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: EASTPORT -- Gov. Angus King is a polished media personality, but Saturday, during Eastport Port Days, he was upstaged by diminutive Molly King, his charming daughter, who will turn 4 on Friday.
While waiting for her father to take his turn at the podium, Molly King was busy eating oyster crackers and writing on the program with a pen. Occasionally, Molly had a short comment, but for the most part, her dark brown eyes were focused on her artistic efforts.
When it was the governor's turn to speak, he acknowledged his young daughter's activity. "Well now you know, governors' kids squirm too," he told an attentive audience of more than 150 people.
The governor and U.S. Rep. John Baldacci were in Eastport Saturday to help celebrate construction of the $15 million port at Estes Head. The port will replace a smaller downtown port and will allow for more shipping traffic in and out of Eastport. Currently, shipping in the downtown port is primarily related to pulp from Georgia Pacific Corp. of Baileyville. The port, expected to be open in July 1998, has been designed to broaden the types of goods and materials shipped in and out of Eastport.
"I want to congratulate everyone who made this new port happen, the people who supported the bond issue, the legislators who supported it and the people from the Department of Transportation," the governor said.
King, who sprinkled his talk with levity, related an incident several weeks ago that focused on the statewide demand for infrastructure improvements and lower taxes. "I was north of here, this is an absolutely true story, and I went into a little general store and a lady was behind the counter. She saw me come in and said `Hah, it's Mr. Tax Man,' and then practically in the next breath she said, `Which way are you going.' I said south. She said, `Good, I hope you have a bumpy ride so you fix that road," King said.
He said the project at Estes Head is on schedule and within budget.
King said that efforts like the port project required a partnership among local, state and federal officials. He said it was that kind of partnership that made Estes Head a reality.
The pier's original design called for a 634-foot, two-berth pier that would accommodate a ship up to 900 feet long on the outer side, which will have a water depth of 65 feet at mean low water, and a second vessel up to 550 feet long on the inner berth, where the water depth is 40 feet at mean low water.
When construction began, the port authority had $13.5 million to spend on the project, only enough to build a 574-foot, single-berth pier.
Early this winter, the Eastport City Council gave the port authority permission to borrow an additional $821,000 to extend the pier to its two-berth potential,
The governor predicted that during the next 10 years, Washington County residents would have to grapple with the issue of how to maintain the quality of life in the face of economic growth.
"How do we keep what we love about this place while at the same time we are growing. This is already an issue in southern Maine. That is something we will have to address. ... We are very lucky that we are not the coast of New Jersey. But we have to be careful to be more thoughtful than they were 50 or 100 years ago in developing the coast to the south of us. We must maintain this incredible place and what is attractive to us and at the same time develop so people can make a decent living," King said.
John Baldacci echoed King's enthusiasm for the new port and the theme of partnership that made Estes Head a reality.
"It doesn't take just one person to do something. Our entire {U.S. congressional} delegation, the governor, all the local officials, state legislators and state senators who are here today and all of you are what it took to make it a success," he said of Estes Head.
Baldacci said that under the House of Representative's transportation funding formula, the state should receive $17 million a year.
Illustration Caption: Gov. Angus King (left) and U.S. Rep. John Baldacci were on hand for events this weekend in Eastport. (NEWS Photo by Diana Graettinger)

Clam digging may return to Portland area

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]25 Aug 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413844901?accountid=10457

Abstract: Cleaner waters could mean the return of clam digging at Lamson Cove on Little Diamond Island and two other islands near Portland. If the clams they find turn out to be as clean as the water is, some islanders could soon enjoy a coastal rite that has been illegal in their locales for decades. Joseph Payne, baykeeper for the nonprofit Friends of Casco Bay, led digging excursions to three Portland island shellfish beds in the past two weeks in an effort to blow holes in a shellfishing ban that stretches across the whole southern end of Casco Bay.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Clam+digging+may+return+to+Portland+area&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-08-25&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PORTLAND -- Cleaner waters could mean the return of clam digging at Lamson Cove on Little Diamond Island and two other islands near Portland.
Environmentalists and scientists began sifting through the muddy cove last week for soft-shell clams.
If the clams they find turn out to be as clean as the water is, some islanders could soon enjoy a coastal rite that has been illegal in their locales for decades.
They can start digging their own steamers and chowder clams.
The reopened clam flats -- including some within Portland city limits -- also would be a symbolic achievement in the effort to reverse coastal pollution.
Joseph Payne, baykeeper for the nonprofit Friends of Casco Bay, led digging excursions to three Portland island shellfish beds in the past two weeks in an effort to blow holes in a shellfishing ban that stretches across the whole southern end of Casco Bay.
"All of this has been closed for as long as anyone can remember," Payne said. "It's a part of our heritage that's been lost."
The state is considering opening some clam flats on Peaks and Cliff islands, and between Little Diamond and Great Diamond islands.
There aren't many islanders who remember getting clams from the flats, at least not legally. It's not even clear when the bans started here, but it probably was even before the end of the steamship era.
"I think Portland has been closed a long time, probably back into the 1930s," said John Hurst, marine resources scientist at the Maine Department of Marine Resources. The area was definitely closed when he started the job in 1951, Hurst said.
Shellfish tend to accumulate whatever pollutants are flowing into the water, including bacteria from sewage that can make people sick. And it was obvious in the 1950s that Maine's rivers and coastal waters contained untreated sewage. The waste was easy to see and smell, said Hurst. The tide turned in the 1960s and 1970s. Landmark cleanup laws were passed. Communities built their first sewage treatment plants and began to focus on industrial discharges.

Guidance counselors visit UMaine-Machias

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]23 Aug 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413844879?accountid=10457

Abstract: Thirty guidance counselors representing high schools from as far away as Idaho, Wisconsin and New York took a close look at the college programs and campus setting of the University of Maine at Machias on Aug. 7. In addition to a tour of UMM, they visited Beals Island Shellfish Hatchery and Roosevelt Campobello International Park to become acquainted with a region known for its unique rural lifestyle.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Guidance+counselors+visit+UMaine-Machias&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-08-23&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: MACHIAS -- Thirty guidance counselors representing high schools from as far away as Idaho, Wisconsin and New York took a close look at the college programs and campus setting of the University of Maine at Machias on Aug. 7. In addition to a tour of UMM, they visited Beals Island Shellfish Hatchery and Roosevelt Campobello International Park to become acquainted with a region known for its unique rural lifestyle.
David Baldwin, director of admissions on the Down East campus, said the Machias visit was the fourth on the group's weeklong tour of college campuses in the state. The program is sponsored annually by the Down East Consortium of Maine Colleges as a way to acquaint guidance counselors with postsecondary educational opportunities in Maine that are available to high school graduates.
Members of the consortium, in addition to UMM, are Husson College, Maine Maritime Academy, Colby College and the College of the Atlantic. Each has its specialty programs and each its particular Maine setting, Baldwin said.

Seafood consumption held steady in 1996

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]16 Aug 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413854414?accountid=10457

Abstract: Seafood consumption in the United States remained steady in 1996, with 3.9 billion pounds eaten. This equated to 14.8 pounds of seafood per person.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Seafood+consumption+held+steady+in+1996&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-08-16&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: WASHINGTON -- Seafood consumption in the United States remained steady in 1996, with 3.9 billion pounds eaten. This equated to 14.8 pounds of seafood per person.
Americans have eaten about 15 pounds of seafood per year since 1990, according to officials from the Commerce Department's National Oceanic and Atmospheric Adminstration.
Of the 14.8 pounds of seafood eaten per person in 1996, it was estimated that 10.0 pounds were fresh or frozen fish or shellfish, 4.5 pounds were canned seafood, and 0.3 pounds of seafood was cured.

Fish catch earnings dip in '96 For 3rd year, Maine leads Eastern Seaboard states in value of haul

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]15 Aug 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/414050142?accountid=10457

Abstract: None available.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Fish+catch+earnings+dip+in+%2796+For+3rd+year%2C+Maine+leads+Eastern+Seaboard+states+in+value+of+haul&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-08-15&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PORTLAND -- Government regulations and declining fish stocks sank the financial haul for fishermen along the Eastern Seaboard last year, federal officials said Thursday.
Revenues from commercial fisheries from Maine to Virginia last year totaled $939.9 million, down 4 percent, or $43 million, compared with 1995. The decrease is the first after several years of steady increases in fishermen's earnings.
Jon Gibson, spokesman for the National Marine Fisheries Service, said the decline was due to several factors.
"For some species of fish there are smaller populations, so fishermen aren't catching as much. And because there are small populations, there are more fishery management regulations."
For the third year in a row, Maine led the 10-state region with $247.9 million in revenue. Massachusetts followed with $231.4 million, Gibson said.
Before 1994, Massachusetts had always taken first place.
Maine was able to retain its top position because it has a large number of high-value species, including lobster and salmon, and because fishermen in Maine land more than 50 different species, like sea worms, sea urchins and hagfish. "Maine's diversity has played a key role in its ability to maintain high revenue year after year," Gibson said.
But for Maine fishermen, 1996 was not a good year compared with the year before. Revenue for fishermen in Maine decreased by 9 percent compared with 1995, largely because of a reduction in sea urchin landings and lower prices for farm-raised Atlantic salmon.
"When the sea urchin fishery started years ago it was a virgin population, so of course catch rates are going to go down," Gibson said.
Only two states -- Massachusetts and New York -- showed an increase in revenue. Rhode Island remained the same at $70.7 million. And the six other states -- New Jersey, Virginia, Maryland, Connecticut, New Hampshire and Delaware -- all showed decreases.
Of all the fisheries, lobster was once again the top moneymaker.
New England harvested 71.4 million pounds of lobster worth $242.2 million in 1996, a 13 percent increase since 1995. But lobstermen only caught 1.4 million more pounds of lobster, showing a significant increase in the cost per pound, Gibson said.
Maine accounted for 44 percent of the lobster harvest, Massachusetts had 27 percent and New York trailed with 13 percent. The remaining 12 percent was divided among Rhode Island, Connecticut, New Hampshire and New Jersey.
Sea scallops trailed behind lobster with 17 million pounds worth $96 million, and blue crab collected $62.6 million -- down from $75 million in 1995.
Other top moneymakers were Atlantic salmon, surf clams, menhaden, eastern oyster and goosefish. However, all of those species earned less in 1996 than in 1995.
Fishermen in the mid-Atlantic area took in less money last year partly because of decreased landings of menhaden, an industrial fish used in fish meal and fish oil. In 1996, fishermen caught 615.9 million pounds of menhaden worth $37.3 million dollars, compared with 752.6 million pounds in 1995, worth $45 million.
There was no change in revenue for New England groundfish, which have been heavily regulated to try and bring back dwindling stocks. The Northeast's three traditional groundfish species -- cod, haddock and yellowtail flounder -- collectively accounted for revenues of $35.8 million in both 1996 and 1995.
Fishery revenue and weight, 1996
Here's a list of commercial fisheries revenue and weight in 1996 for states from Maine to Virginia in millions of dollars and millions of pounds:
Maine -- $247.9; 259.7 pounds.
Massachusetts -- $231.4; 236.7.
New Jersey -- $94; 179.3.
Virginia -- $90.4; 629.7.
New York -- $86.7; 61.3.
Rhode Island -- $70.7; 137.5.
Maryland -- $52.5; 69.
Connecticut -- $48.4; 20.9.
New Hampshire -- $13.5; 11.1.
Delaware -- $4.3; 5.7.
Total: $939.9; 1,611.
Source: National Marine Fisheries Service
Illustration Caption: Lobsterman Bill Franklin of Buxton tosses back an undersized lobster on Back Cove in Portland. (AP File Photo)

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]07 Aug 1997: 1.

Ten Ways to Lobster Eatery celebrates crustacean Chinese-style

Author: Cheryl Wixson Special to the NEWS

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]06 Aug 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413888681?accountid=10457

Abstract: None available.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Ten+Ways+to+Lobster+Eatery+celebrates+crustacean+Chinese-style&amp;author=Cheryl+Wixson+Special+to+the+NEWS&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-08-06&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Since August has been designated the official Maine lobster month, I love to fish out more ways to consume my favorite crustacean, Homarus americanus.
When I heard through the grapevine that one of Bangor's popular restaurants, the Oriental Jade, was serving lobster 10 ways, I swallowed the bait and contacted Lilian Lo, who, with her husband Victor, owns and operates both the Oriental Jade in Bangor and Noodles and Company in Brewer. After explaining my interest in eating something new and expanding my knowledge of the world's cuisines, Lilian and Victor graciously invited me into their restaurant kitchen to experience firsthand some facets of Chinese-style cooking.
I was fascinated to learn that the combined cuisines of China have often been compared with French cuisine as having made the greatest contribution to the world of food. Chinese cooking styles have been divided into five main regions: Southeastern (Canton), East Coast (Fukien), Northeastern (Peking-Shantung), Central (Honan), and Western (Szechwan-Hunan). Lilian explained to me that the styles used at the Oriental Jade and Noodles and Company are Southeastern and Northeastern (Canton and Peking-Shantung) as New England people enjoy these best.
An excellent chef himself, Victor related that the keys to Chinese cooking are fresh ingredients and organization. He proudly escorted me through his gleaming kitchen with its 13 wok stations, stainless-steel work tables for vegetable preparation, electronically controlled Fryolators and a huge pot for making chicken stock. Because of careful organization, a Chinese restaurant can prepare an enormous number of elaborate dishes within a short time. The Oriental Jade's 12 chefs and 75 staff members prepare food for more than 5,000 people every week in the largest Chinese kitchen north of Boston.
With the exception of the egg roll and spring roll wrappers and five kinds of fresh noodles that are delivered from New York three times per week, everything else is prepared by hand in this kitchen. Chicken stock is made fresh every day, and unlike European-style broth, it is just the pure, rich taste of chicken with an undercurrent of ginger. Vegetables, meat and seafood are delivered fresh daily. The staff spends hours chopping, mincing and slicing.
The traditions of Chinese cooking maintain that all good dishes are based on three elements: color, aroma and flavor. In today's health-conscious society, we should also add one more element: nutrition. Chinese cooking is very healthful.
A good Chinese cook is an artist, and I had the pleasure of watching John Lee, the head chef, create this masterpiece, Lobster Scampi Lo Mein.
Lobster Scampi Lo Mein
5 ounces fresh lobster meat 2 ounces zucchini, sliced 8 ounces fresh egg noodles 6 ounces chicken stock 2 ounces light cream 1/2 teaspoon sugar 1 1/2 tablespoons vegetable oil 10 medium mushrooms, sliced 1 ounce Spanish onion, diced 2 scallions, chopped 1 teaspoon dry sherry 1/2 teaspoon salt dash of white pepper 1/2 teaspoon minced garlic 1 teaspoon roux (melt 2 tablespoons of butter over low heat with 2 tablespoons flour)
Heat 3 quarts of water until boiling. Add noodles and cook until tender, about three to four minutes. Drain well and keep warm on a pasta dish.
Heat the oil in a wok until hot. Sear the lobster on all sides and remove from wok.
Add the onions to the hot oil and stir-fry for 15 seconds. Add garlic, zucchini, mushrooms and sherry and stir-fry for one minute. Add chicken stock and bring to a boil. Add salt, sugar, white pepper. Add scallions, flour mixture. Blend well. Add cream and lobster meat.
Serve lobster and vegetables over cooked noodles.
The aroma was fresh, pleasant and inviting. The flavors were a perfect combination of buttery noodles, crisp vegetables, sweet onion and garlic and delectable lobster. Chinese people like a sense of harmony and balance in their foods, and watching John Lee in motion was like observing a fine musician in love with his music.
The most common techniques in Chinese cooking are stir-frying, deep-frying, steaming, braising and poaching. Victor cautioned me that home cooking is different than his restaurant cooking because of the temperature of the wok. Temperature is critical in stir-frying because the rapid and intense cooking preserves the texture and vitamin content of foods. Indeed, as I watched the dazzling motions of his chefs preparing a dish, spatulas in both hands and regulating the gas nozzles for the woks with their knees, I was impressed.
Up until just a few years ago, very few Chinese kitchens had traditional style ovens. Steaming was one of the most-used, straightforward, energy-saving cooking techniques. Lilian's favorite lobster preparation is the steamed Maineland lobster, which she describes as a traditional Maine favorite with an international reputation. I found it to be simple yet admirable, understated yet memorable -- the very essence of Chinese cooking.
Steamed Maineland Lobster
1 1 1/4-pound Maine lobster 1/2 teaspoon salt 1 teaspoon sugar 4 slices fresh ginger 1/2 lemon, sliced
Remove lobster head, discard legs and remove claws, cracking them with the back of the cleaver. Cut lobster tail lengthwise and into chunks. Mix lobster with salt and sugar. Place a deep dish in a bamboo steamer. Arrange lobster in the bamboo steamer, top with lemon slices and fresh ginger. Steam for 12 minutes. Serve immediately.
In China, seafood is abundant and treated with great reverence, according to Lilian. While lobster is not served everyday, it is often served at celebrations and always on New Year's. For your special occasions, the chefs at the Oriental Jade, with 48 hours notice, will prepare such mouthwatering delicacies as Easter Lobster Rolls, Lobster Polynesian Salad, Lobster Seafood Soup and Lobster Lychee.
The Chinese have a healthy respect for food and know that good eating is always a matter of good cooking. In the preparation of Maine Lobster Hong Kong, cornstarch is used to coat the lobster to seal in the natural juices and keep the lobster in its shell during the baking process.
Maine Lobster Hong Kong
1 1 1/4-pound lobster 4 scallions cut into 2-inch sections (separate green and white sections) 2 teaspoons soy sauce 1/2 teaspoon oyster sauce 10 slices of fresh ginger 2 tablespoons rice wine or sherry 6 ounces chicken stock 1 teaspoon sugar 1/8 teaspoon white pepper cornstarch: enough to cover the lobster vegetable oil: enough to cover the lobster for blanching cornstarch liquid (1 teaspoon cornstarch, 1/2 teaspoon sugar, 1/2 teaspoon soy sauce mixed with 1 tablespoon of water)
Cut lobster lengthwise and discard organs. Chop lobster into chunks, remove claws and crack the shell of the claws with the back of the cleaver. Put chunks of lobster in medium strainer.
Dust lobster chunks with cornstarch.
In a wok, heat vegetable oil until hot, blanch lobster in hot oil for 2 minutes, remove and drain.
Remove all excess oil, leaving 1 tablespoon of oil in wok. Add ginger slices and white scallions and stir-fry for 10 seconds. Add lobster chunks, splash in rice wine, then stir-fry for 10 seconds. Add chicken stock and remaining seasoning, cover and bake in wok for one minute. Remove wok cover and add cornstarch liquid to finish. Add green scallions and stir-fry until shiny and smooth.
Dining Chinese-style is always a memorable communal experience. During the Oriental Jade's month-long celebration of Maine lobster, your family and friends may enjoy 10 different preparations of lobster including Luxurious Lobster Fried Rice, Lobster Cantonese, Lobster Wor Bar and Maine Lobster Wor Bar. Each dish will be individually prepared to order, the composition an unconscious yin and yang presented in conspicuous juxtaposition.
Over the centuries, alternately buffeted by famine and blessed with the splendors of a great civilization, the Chinese have experimented with all things edible both for sheer survival and to perfect their cooking techniques for sensual enjoyment. Their food, with its rare delicacy and rustic simplicity, has sustained a culture for more than 2,000 years and has journeyed well all over the world. I feel very fortunate that it has traveled to Bangor and I have had the opportunity to meet the able team of Lilian and Victor Lo, to experience their labors of love in the meeting of East and West with the Oriental Jade's Maine lobster cuisine.
Illustration Caption: Oriental Jade chef David Lin (left) and owner Victor Lo prepare bamboo steamed Maineland lobster. Three dishes Oriental Jade is offering in August are Lobster Fried Rice, Steamed Maineland Lobster and Maine Lobster Hong Kong. (NEWS Photos by Bridget Besaw)

____________________________________________________________

Fest ritual steams PETA Boiling death `excruciating' for lobsters, says group

Author: Walter Griffin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]02 Aug 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413890038?accountid=10457

Abstract: None available.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Fest+ritual+steams+PETA+Boiling+death+%60excruciating%27+for+lobsters%2C+says+group&amp;author=Walter+Griffin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-08-02&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- Fortunately for the Maine Lobster Festival there are a lot more people who love eating lobsters than allowing them to swim free.
As thousands of festival-goers sat munching on their succulent cooked crustaceans Friday afternoon, protesters from People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals reminded as many as they could that "Being Boiled Hurts."
Accompanied by a guy in a lobster costume with a cauldron wrapped around his belly, PETA spokeswoman Dawn Carr urged the public to give lobsters a chance. "There is no humane way to kill a lobster," she said.
Though PETA members usually concentrate their animal protection efforts on testing laboratories, once a year they announce being "steaming mad" over the annual festival and abandon their sweltering Virginia headquarters for the cool coast of Maine. Carr said they also make appearances at sport fishing tournaments.
Perhaps PETA's efforts are beginning to pay off. According to the latest figures provided Friday by the U.S. Commerce Department, Americans consumed 3.9 billion pounds of seafood during 1996. That represents a per-capita consumption level of 14.8 pounds per person, which is a modest decrease of 0.2 pound from the 1995 level. Still, Americans have consumed about 15 pounds of seafood per-capita each year since 1990.
Of the seafood consumed per person in 1996, 10 pounds were fresh or frozen fresh or shellfish, 4.5 pounds were canned seafood and .3 pounds were cured. Imported fish and shellfish comprised 57 percent of the seafood consumed in the United States last year, a 3 percent increase from 1995's imports.
While the 50,000 or so people expected to visit the four-day festival come to Rockland for the food and fun, PETA is dead serious about protecting the lobster. As anyone who has ever dropped a lobster into a pot of boiling water can see, they point out, lobsters die while trying to scratch and claw their way to freedom.
"We are here to suggest that people no longer eat lobster," Carr said. "Lobsters experience excruciating suffering when put in a pot of boiling water."
Carr said that PETA wants mankind to exhibit "compassion to even the smallest, oddest animal. We will fight for any animal alive. No one would accept someone torturing a lobster, yet that is exactly what is being done here today."
Carr suggested that the 50,000 lobster lovers must be victims of a "mass cultural state of denial" by returning to the festival year after year. She pledged that PETA would continue its protest until the tastes are changed forever.
"Just because something has gone on for a long time does not mean that it must endure," she said. "We have to continue to question these practices."
Illustration Caption: Isaac Greenrose (above) waves hello to a lobster (Cindy Brennan) representing People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals during the Maine Lobster Festival in Rockland on Friday. The group's Dawn Carr holds a sign with PETA's message. Rockland resident Barbara Emerson (below) showed up at the festival wearing one of her 45 hats for all occasions. (NEWS Photos by Susan Latham)

Old Town's Dow wins rifle championship

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]25 July 1997: PDA.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413872061?accountid=10457

Abstract: None available.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Old+Town%27s+Dow+wins+rifle+championship&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-07-25&amp;spage=PDA&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: WARREN - An Old Town man took first place among 24 competitors at the Maine State Highpower Rifle Championship held July 19 at the Oyster River Range, and won an excellence in competition match run by the U.S. Department of Civilian Marksmanship the following day.
David Dow fired a score of 778 out of 800 possible points in the match, which included stages at 200, 300 and 600 yards and positions including off-hand, sitting and prone.
The second high-scoring shooter was Emery Bassett of Essex Junction, Vt., who fired a 764, taking first master honors.
Bassett did not qualify for overall second-place in the match, however, because he is not a Maine resident. That award went to Harry Davis of Freeport, who fired 752.
Mac Daggett of Thomaston fired the top score for the Match Rifle category, separate from the service rifle classification, firing a score of 747.
Other winners and scores were Harry Davis, first expert, 752; David Yates of South Paris, first sharpshooter, 706; Denis Paine of Topsham, first marksman, 701; Sam Overlock, 17, of Warren, first junior, 706.
Dow fired a 470 of 500 possible points in the excellence in competition match held July 20 at the Oyster River Range. Scoring second-place was Scott Folsom of Hampden, with a score of 468. The match is a qualification event in which shooters seek classification as distinguished shooters by the DCM.

____________________________________________________________

Heartfelt thoughts shared on EMMC anniversary Hospital's first bypass conducted 10 years ago

Author: Jenna Russell Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]23 July 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413872802?accountid=10457

Abstract: None available.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Heartfelt+thoughts+shared+on+EMMC+anniversary+Hospital%27s+first+bypass+conducted+10+years+ago&amp;author=Jenna+Russell+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-07-23&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BANGOR -- Linwood and Verda LeClair remember what it was like to travel to Boston for heart surgery. The Bangor couple also know the convenience of cardiac care close to home.
On Tuesday, the 10th anniversary of the first heart bypass in Bangor, the LeClairs joined other former patients, doctors and nurses at Eastern Maine Medical Center for a celebration and a look back.
A dozen years ago, while the community was still fighting for the state's permission to build a heart center north of Portland, Linwood LeClair found himself in need of angioplasty. The procedure opens clogged arteries by inserting and inflating tiny balloons, clearing away debris to let blood pass to the heart.
LeClair went to Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, where his surgery was postponed for a week because of incoming emergencies. "I had to go down and find myself a room," his wife recalled. "It was a difficult experience."
Coming back to Maine, they stayed one step ahead of a hurricane. Verda LeClair worried about the storm, and her husband.
"It's horrendous driving in Boston when you're well, let alone after surgery, when you're weak," she said.
Fortunately for the LeClairs, EMMC was an option by the time Linwood needed more heart surgery 2 1/2 years later. He is one of nearly 5,000 patients to undergo coronary bypass at the facility in the last decade. About 5,000 others have had angioplasty.
Nowadays, it's hard to remember the time, not so long ago, when heart patients were placed on waiting lists in Portland and routinely transported hundreds of miles by ambulance, while some legislators and state officials insisted Maine didn't need a second heart center.
But Bangor had a stubborn handful of leaders who wouldn't take no for an answer, whose persistence paid off after months of hard work and some dark hours. Jack Kelsey was a member of a YMCA exercise group for cardiac patients who took the heart center on as a personal mission.
In May 1985 with other members of his fitness group, Kelsey delivered bags of petitions bearing 10,000 signatures to the governor's office in Augusta. He was told to deliver them elsewhere.
"We walked in with the media and we were asked to leave," he remembered Tuesday, speaking under a tent on the hospital lawn near the Riverside Inn. "I said to the man, `You're going to ask five people who've had open heart surgery to carry this someplace else?'
"I guess we hit the right key, because suddenly people became very aware of the need for heart surgery right here."
Around the edges of the tent, medical staff members displayed heart models and diagrams and explained surgical instruments used in a bypass, where another vessel -- often a leg vein -- is moved to the heart to help blood flow there. An X-ray technician held a lightweight, modern-day pacemaker as small as a silver dollar next to an older, much larger model almost the size of a Walkman.
Behind the podium hung rows of small quilts made by hospital staff to mark the heart center's anniversary. One featured the traditional heart shape in its center; another had a red cloth blob more like the organ's squishy reality.
Dr. Robert Clough, hired from Texas 10 years ago to lead the new heart program, was on hand Tuesday to thank his first patient, Lee Turner of Shirley Mills, who underwent a triple bypass July 22, 1987.
Since then, the number of cardiologists has increased to 14, the number of heart surgeons to three, a second operating room has been added with talk of a third, and the number of annual surgeries has grown from 300 the first year to 700 in 1996, he said.
"Someone once said it was a brave man who ate the first oyster," Clough said. "I've often wondered what kind of man is it who puts his heart in the hand of a surgeon from away."
News stories at the time reported Turner's first words after surgery as "I want to go fishing." Tuesday, the 75-year-old celebrity said he remembers being wheeled to the operating room -- and, thankfully, nothing more. "I was pretty tickled," he said of his role in EMMC history.
His good health today lets him enjoy life near Moosehead Lake.
"If I want to go mow the lawn, I mow the lawn. If I want to get down under a car and work on it, I do. I shovel snow, I feed the squirrels," he said.
More good news was offered by Dr. Robert Hoffman, who said heart disease rates are starting to fall as the public starts to understand prevention and the roles of smoking, exercise and cholesterol. Such progress will take years to make a real difference.
"Clearly prevention is the future of cardiology," he said. "Does that mean the heart center will close in five years? Not likely."

Wolf tale timely for young readers

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]12 July 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413904197?accountid=10457

Abstract: None available.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Wolf+tale+timely+for+young+readers&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-07-12&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PRESCHOOL, KINDERGARTEN
IS IT TIME? by Marilyn Janovitz, New York: North-South Books, 1994 and 1996 hardcover, 32 pages, $12.95, paperback $5.95.
This bouncy, rhyming story about a father wolf getting his wolf cub ready for bed is one that may actually help to make a parent and child's nighttime experience quite a pleasant one. Checking his watch often, the father wolf guides his young wolf with questions throughout the story taking him from a nice, bubbly bath to being finally tucked in only after the wolf cub has brushed his "fangs" and given a "howl."
Colored pencils and watercolors combine to create soft, airy drawings that complement the light rhythm of Marilyn Janovitz's text. A question-answer format will invite a positive response from the listener or reader. Especially fun will be the "chiming-in" for the howling. If in a creative mood, children and their parents might even create original rhymes particular to their own evening routines using the pattern established in the story. Repetitive lines with a playful spirit will engage pre-readers and beginning readers encouraging their early reading skills.
Is it time to read a book? Yes, it's time to read this book!
GRADES ONE-THREE
POLAR, THE TITANIC BEAR by Daisy C.S. Spedden, illustrated by Laurie McGaw, Little, 1995, 64 pages, $17.95.
Imagine the excitement of discovery as you look through a relative's soon to be discarded old trunk and find a true children's story of the Titanic, a story as experienced by an F.A.O. Schwartz Steiff polar bear! Leighton H. Coleman graciously shares this charming treasure, as he discovered it, adding facts and insights into a long lost era.
Daisy Corning Stone Spidden wrote this short story for her 8-year-old son Douglas as a Christmas present in 1913. It recounts the traveling adventures of young Douglas and his favorite stuffed animal, "Polar." They sail to Madeira where Douglas gets measles. He is quarantined and Polar suffers the indignity of a disinfectant bath. The pair go sledding at their home in Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and play on the beach at their summer home in Bar Harbor. When the weather once again turns cold they're off to Algiers. Slowly, they make their way home, stopping at Monte Carlo, Paris, Cannes and finally in Cherbourg, France, where they are to board the new wonder ship the Titanic.
The book is interspersed with actual photos of Douglas with Polar, and the beautiful watercolor illustrations of Laurie McGaw. The epilogue is chock-full of historical facts and photos. This is an exciting read-aloud to hold the interest of young and old. It gives a timeless humanity to history, and Daisy's love for her only child will reach out through the pages.
GRADES FOUR-SIX
THE WORRY STONE by Marianna Dengler, illustrated by Sibyl Graber Gerig, Rising Moon, 1996, $14.95.
"The Worry Stone" is a delightful story connecting past, present and future generations of storytelling. An elder named Amanda goes to the park every day and spots young Jason sitting quietly by himself, left out of the games. She suspects he is lonely and could use company so she enchants him with her worry stone and stories.
The story Amanda tells Jason was one her grandfather told her when she was young and alone. It made her feel fortunate and special to have a worry stone and she is ready to pass down her story and her stone to Jason.
The beautiful light of the watercolor and pencil illustrations by Sibyl Graber Gerig reflect the wonderfully told tale of Marianna Dengler. The legend of the worry stone was originally passed down from the Chumash Indians who would be pleased that the tale of "The Worry Stone" is being kept alive.
YOUNG ADULTS
ANGELS OF THE SWAMP by Dorothy Raymond Whittaker, Walker and Co., New York, 1992, 209 pages, $18.
During the Great Depression, in the summer of 1932, three young people -- 15-year-old Taffy, an orphan, 12-year-old Jody, living with an alcoholic uncle, and 18-year-old Jeff, an unemployed city boy from Tampa -- find themselves seeking relief from unsatisfactory home lives by surviving on an island off the west coast of Florida.
The story starts as Taffy is poling a skiff to Crane's Bog, a familiar, safe haven until the snakes take to the water. There she meets Jody, in his own skiff, battling a badly infected knee. They pair up and pole to Pelican Island, 100 miles away, a place Jody remembers from shellfishing. Jeff enters their lives, finds a way to earn money and brings them closer together.
This book, one in the American History Series for Young People, is steeped in the flora and fauna of the swamps and islands of Florida. It is based largely on the author's experience as a child on Tampa Bay. In an author's note she tells of the livelihood of the fishermen during the Depression years. All through the story she weaves these details into an easily read, touching novel for young adults.
