____________________________________________________________

Searching for the origins of winespeak Jefferson may be to blame

Author: Chris Plumsted Special to the NEWS

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]23 June 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413850332?accountid=10457

Abstract: None available.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Searching+for+the+origins+of+winespeak+Jefferson+may+be+to+blame&amp;author=Chris+Plumsted+Special+to+the+NEWS&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-06-23&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The other day I was e-mailed a wine description: "The color of the wine was deep golden. It stood tall in the glass and had ripe tropical fruit flavors and an everlasting finish." All I'm getting here visually is a large overripe banana in a glass.
The American art of "winespeak" has evolved into a horrendous jumble of adjectives that lends about as much comfort as the pretentious people you see in the wine stores clutching their Robert Parker reviews and vintage charts as if they were growths on their bodies.
OK, so I, too, am guilty of using this annoying winespeak. I worked for almost 12 years in the wine business, so it was hard not to be immersed in it. I spent much of that time trying to erase this verbal facade from the memories of wait staff who are the messengers of their generation passing it down to the next. It was a daunting task. Throughout, the most commonly asked question was: Where did this wine language come from?
I have a theory. Wine and viticulture was introduced to the United States primarily by statesman Thomas Jefferson. His sojourns to France gave him a taste of their culture and their wine. Enamored of these, he introduced this magnificent culture to the U.S. Eighteenth-century European tableside service, wine descriptions (in French, soon to be translated into English) and wine making were suddenly being Americanized. So there it was -- French wine culture brought to the U.S.A. -- translated and frozen in time.
For the first century or more of its development, this terminology was appreciated only by the wealthy, because there was no good-quality wine being made in the United States back then. It was all being shipped from Europe. The average person could not afford it, so wine and the language that had evolved around it became the syntax of the wealthy and pretentious. Add another century or so of economic ups and downs, slow (but progressive) appreciation and understanding of good wine, and this is what we have become: a society of people who use wine descriptions they are uncomfortable with.
Additionally, we put a lot of our trust in a handful of popular self-proclaimed experts who rate fine wines the same way a high school paper is graded. Wine writers can be interesting, but maybe they smoked a great big stinky cigar right before they panned your favorite Cabernet. Or maybe a New York cabbie just flipped them off, and they're just generally having a really bad day.
The solution? Become your own wine guru. Learn what the descriptions mean. Develop your own syntax. Rate your own wines. Record or write down everything you taste.
I have prepared a starting point. Listed below are definitions and examples of some of the more commonly utilized descriptive terms for wine, both used and abused by society today.
Dry
Try to explain how a liquid can be dry to a room full of 20-something-year-olds. Here it is. Very simply, the wine term "dry" means lacking sweetness. No sugar -- maybe a fruit flavor -- but no sweetness whatsoever. If you want to try one of the driest wines made, try a Muscadet (mus-cah-day). Muscadet is a town in France's Loire Valley, which is noted for its seafood. Muscadet is the wine to be served with oysters. It is bone dry. Some notable brands are Ragotierre, Domaine de la Batardierre and Sauvion. All for under 10 bucks.
Fruity
How can you not feel like Julia Child saying this word? This is a really misunderstood term. I hate using it. Most people think fruity means sweet. What it really means in wine terms is tasting like a fresh fruit. If you pick a Macintosh apple off a tree and bite into it, you will taste the freshness of the apple, but very little sweetness. If you want to taste a wine that is "fruity" -- not sweet -- try a wine made from Chenin Blanc, like Dry Creek or Beringer, or a Riesling from Alsace like Trimbach. If you prefer red, try a Beaujolais-Villages from Duboeuf or Jadot.
Tannic
Most people have experienced this taste sensation whether they know it or not. If you have ever had an overly strong cup of tea or bitten into unsweetened chocolate, that taste is tannic acid. One wait-person described it to me as "fuzzy sweaters on my teeth."
Grapes that produce red wine have varying amounts of tannic acid. Over a period of years, the tannic acid will fade, giving the wine a much smoother taste. Some tannic acid will dissipate by letting red wine "breathe," to be open for a while. White wine has only trace amounts of tannin. You can't notice it at all in the taste.
If you want to experience tannic acid, buy a young (1994 or 1995) Cabernet Sauvignon from California. Try something in the $10 to $15 price range and you will taste the tannic acid. Most American-made Cabernets are released long before they are ready to drink. Being so young makes them somewhat hard and tannic. Try putting them away for a couple of years and see how they develop.
Oaky
When wine is vinified there are several courses it can take. It can be fermented in stainless steel tanks, filtered, then bottled. Or it can be fermented in oak barrels and-or sent to oak barrels after fermentation to age. Oak aging is the ancient French hand-crafted method of letting wine develop. Complex grape varieties such as Chardonnay and Cabernet Sauvignon benefit greatly from this process. The result is an oaky or woody flavor. The oak will sometimes lend a vanilla nuance to the flavor of the wine. A really good example of this that I have tried recently is the 1994 Bonterra Chardonnay from Mendocino made by Fetzer. It really has a nice (not offensive) oak flavor and is made from 100 percent organically grown grapes.
Earthy
A wine with an earthy -- or shall we say "barnyard"? -- aroma is not a bad thing. One of the most amusing things I ever witnessed was in a cellar in Burgundy where I was watching a bunch of very pleased French wine makers exclaiming that the wine smelled earthy. Actually they used a different adjective. Good Pinot Noir should have a nice earthy or organic aroma. Bad Pinot Noir smells like a pile of burning tires. If you would like to try a good "earthy" Pinot Noir, try Robert Mondavi's 1994 unfiltered -- about $17 -- it's excellent. If you prefer a more delicate style, try the David Bruce 1994 Russian River Reserve -- $25.
Restaurants, distributors or businesses sponsoring or hosting a wine tasting event or individuals with questions about wine can reach me by mail at Chris Plumstead, 446 North Road, Newburgh 04444, or by e-mail at theBDNvine@aol.com. Deadlines for late July-early August events is July 14.

Principal Charles F. Pease of Shead High School, Eastport, has announced the honor parts for the Class of 1997.
Melissa Mitchell, valedictorian, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Brian Mitchell of Eastport. She has served as president of the Student Senate, vice president of the National Honor Society, and co-editor of the student newspaper, The Shead Sentinel. A finalist in the Boston University Latin Scholarship Exam, she has been awarded gold and silver medals in the National Latin Exam. She has received the Georgia Pacific Corp. scholarship and the National League of Women Engineers award. In addition to serving as manager of the girls basketball team, she has been active in volleyball, softball, band, varsity club, and community theater, as well as the Hugh O'Brien Youth Foundation and United States Academic Decathlon. Missy will attend Bates College in Lewiston, where she will study political science in preparation for law school and a career in law.
Elissa Blanchard, co-salutatorian, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bret Blanchard of Dennysville. Elissa has served as vice president of the Student Senate, treasurer of the National Honor Society, and assistant editor of The Oracle, the Shead yearbook. She has received the Good Citizenship Award from the Daughters of the American Revolution. Active in cheerleading, she has participated in band, tennis, and varsity club. Elissa plans to attend Central Maine Technical College in Auburn, before pursuing an advanced degree in nursing.
Charity Johnson, co-salutatorian, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roland Johnson of Eastport. Johnson has served as secretary of the National Honor Society, vice president of the National Honor Society, co-editor of The Shead Sentinel, and layout editor of The Oracle. A gold medalist in the National Latin Exam, she also is the recipient of the 1997 Principal's Award and has attended Upward Bound and Girls State. Her other activities include basketball, volleyball, softball, cheerleading, the varsity club, the outing club, band, chorus, and the United States Academic Decathlon. Charity will attend Elmira College in Elmira, N.Y., where she will study secondary education in preparation for a career as an English teacher.
Second honor part has been awarded to Kristy Studdy Lingley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne Lingley of Dennysville. She has served as treasurer of the Student Senate and manager of the soccer team, and has been active in National Honor Society, basketball, softball, outing club, varsity club, and band. Kristy has been awarded two gold medals in National Latin Exam, and the Maine Scholars Achievements Award. She attended Girls State, and was the Washington County representative to the Bigelow Science Lab marine biology workshop. Active in community service, she has worked as a peer tutor, a recreational basketball coach, and a volunteer at the Beals Island shellfish hatchery. Lingley will attend Maine Maritime Academy in Castine, where she will major in ocean studies.
Third honor part has been awarded to Amanda Newcomb, daughter of Dolly Newcomb of Perry. Amanda has served as class president, president of the National Honor Society, and senior section editor of The Oracle. Newcomb plans to attend the University of Maine in Orono where she will major in biology before attending medical school.
Fourth honor part has been awarded to Bobbi Lea Ricker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Darlington Ricker Jr. of Perry. Bobbi Lea served as class treasurer for four years and was art director of The Oracle. She has participated in basketball, volleyball, cross country, Student Senate, chorus, outing club, and National Honor Society. Bobbi Lea will attend the University of Maine at Presque Isle where she will major in physical education and art.
Graduation ceremonies will be held at the high school at 8 p.m. June 12.

Residents deed Glidden Midden to local land trust Historic shell deposit to be preserved

Author: Walter Griffin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]16 May 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413843257?accountid=10457

Abstract: None available.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Residents+deed+Glidden+Midden+to+local+land+trust+Historic+shell+deposit+to+be+preserved&amp;author=Walter+Griffin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-05-16&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: NEWCASTLE -- The Glidden Midden, a prehistoric pile of oyster shells on the banks of the Damariscotta River, has been deeded to a local land trust.
Left behind by ancient peoples and described as one of the most significant shell deposits of its kind in Maine, the Glidden Midden has been deeded to the Damariscotta River Association by George and Josephine Hart of Glidden Point.
"George and Jo have not only always opened their property for all who sought to visit this national treasure, but acted as dutiful stewards while maintaining the natural environment with which it is associated," Damariscotta River Association President Suzanne Johnson noted. "We, on behalf of the community, are most grateful for their faith in us and for the continuing opportunity to maximize protection of this unique resource for public benefit."
Known to a generation of field-tripping midcoast area students, professional and amateur anthropologists, the Glidden Midden is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. It is the largest of its kind in New England, according to Peter Knauss, executive director of the river association.
Knauss said middens are the refuse of indigenous peoples or, more specifically, "piles of refuse that develop around habitation or exploration sites."
Middens are composed of high proportions of oyster shell, mixed in with other discarded cultural debris. Thousands of middens have been found along the coast, but none compare to the Glidden site. Shells there are piled more than 30 feet high for hundreds of feet along the river.
The 10-acre Glidden Midden is a part of a much larger DRA conservation easement contributed by the Harts in 1991 for protection of the upper river's natural and scenic environment.
The Harts have owned, cared for and shared with the public the natural beauty of the midden area since they purchased the riverfront site in 1955. Before that, the land was owned by the Glidden family of Boston, a noted shipbuilding family whose ancestors began spending summers in Maine in the 1750s.
Among the potential findings that are of particular interest to today's scientists, according to Maine Historic Preservation Commission archaeologist Dr. Arthur Spiess, are tiny bone fragments preserved from Maine's acidic soil by the alkaline nature of the shells.
Knauss said scientists believe rising sea levels and the confluence of salt and fresh water from the river provided perfect conditions for a major oyster population in the waters of Great Salt Bay. He said native populations feasted on the oysters for more than 1,500 years.
Because of the shells' fragility and problems with erosion, the midden must be protected, Knauss said, a point the DRA will continue to emphasize to visitors. The shell heaps cannot be disturbed in their natural condition in any way by the public.
Knass said a major excavation of the Whaleback Midden across the river from the Glidden site took place in 1887. Now owned by the Bureau of Parks and Lands, records and artifacts retrieved from that excavation yielded examples of pottery, stone and bone artifacts, wigwam floors, and fire hearths that provide a "superb record of native American life and the local ecological conditions which supported it." The same artifacts remain intact in the Glidden Midden.
Damariscotta's middens probably represent discards through several distinct eras of occupation over a period of about 1,500 years, beginning perhaps some 2,500 years ago. Their setting, size and composition have been the object of archaeological study and a visual wonder for generations of visitors. Today's technology, tied to geological, anthropological and related work by Spiess and other colleagues will help to yield new insight into the human history of Maine long before European settlement.
The middens appear as a bright white riverbank where the Damariscotta crosses Route 1. There is no access from the highway, but the middens can be observed by boat or by taking the 3-mile Salt Bay Heritage Trail, which can be reached from Mills Road.
As a nonprofit organization, the river association has a better opportunity than its former owners to obtain grant funds to preserve the midden. The Glidden Midden represents a critical focus for the other prehistoric and historic lands in the upper river, which soon will be included in a National Register of Historic Places District.
The Harts' contribution represents all aspects of DRA's mission of preservation and promotion of natural, cultural and historic heritages. DRA preservation ensures new education and scientific benefits through associated programs with area schools, tours, lectures and research.
Later this year, the DRA will have a brochure available with maps and explanations about the Damariscotta River's natural and historic resources, with particular emphasis on the upper river, its middens and opportunities to enjoy various sites.

50th Maine Lobster Festival expected to fill up all rooms in midcoast area

Author: Emmet Meara Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]13 May 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413857707?accountid=10457

Abstract: Don't look for a motel room in the area for the weekend of July 31-Aug. 2. Virtually every room in the area has been booked for the 50th annual Maine Lobster Festival.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=50th+Maine+Lobster+Festival+expected+to+fill+up+all+rooms+in+midcoast+area&amp;author=Emmet+Meara+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-05-13&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- Don't look for a motel room in the area for the weekend of July 31-Aug. 2. Virtually every room in the area has been booked for the 50th annual Maine Lobster Festival.
Chamber Director Gil Merriam said his organization is getting calls from the Augusta area for information on the festival, because they have been getting so many calls for rooms.
Festival officials are expecting record crowds, probably 70,000 for the three-day event, and will probably order 18,000 pounds of lobsters for the visitors, a modern record.
"The records are not perfect, but I believe that way back when they were selling four lobsters for one dollar, they sold 20,000 pounds," Merriam said. "People would come by and load up with lobsters for picnics."
The festival started in Camden 50 years ago, when you got all the lobster you could swallow for $1. The festival grew so popular that it was moved to Rockland, where there was much more room.
After a fallow period a few years ago when it was actually proposed that the festival be canceled, a new generation of volunteers surfaced and re-energized the annual event. Since that low point, the crowds have gotten bigger and the weather better every year. Last year, an estimated 65,000 visitors consumed 14,000 pounds of lobster.
Merriam has developed a successful mailing program to 375 newspapers across the country. "It's quite effective and quite cheap," he said. "We can always tell when a paper runs a story by the number of calls we get from a certain area. We get a bunch of calls from Indiana one day, then New Jersey a few days later and we know newspaper stories have run."
It is said every year, but this year will be the "biggest and best" festival ever, according to Merriam. The festival has contacted former sea goddesses around the country and at least half of the 50 beauty contest winners are expected to attend, Merriam said.
In "the most ambitious production ever done in Harbor Park," according to entertainment director Chuck Kruger, the festival will offer Motown legends the Temptations for the Saturday night headliner.
The smooth Temptations collected 43 top 10 singles, 14 No. 1 records and four Grammy awards. Led by original member Otis Williams, the group will perform hits including "My Girl," "The Way You Do The Things You Do," "Ain't Too Proud To Beg" and "Papa Was A Rolling Stone."
The musical group Beatlemania will present an evening of tribute to the Beatles from the early days through the Sgt. Pepper period. The group now performs in Florida at the British Pavilion at Epcot at Disney World. "They jumped at the chance to come to Maine for the Lobster Festival," Kruger said.
Kruger said the other acts will include a tribute to Buddy Holly, stand-up comedy, two traditional banjo bands, jazz in the eating tent, Rick Charette and the Bubblegum Band, a tribute to George Gershwin and the swing band Eight to the Bar.
A high-quality bronze commemorative festival coin will be designed by Blackinton Mint of Attleboro Falls, Mass., and sold at the event.
A special 50th anniversary tent will be a feature on the Mildred Merrill Park. Historic marching organizations will represent each of the five decades in the annual parade. The theme of this year's parade will be "Claws of red, memories of gold."
The festival will feature the Sea Goddess pageant and coronation, the Great International Crate Race, and the traditional displays at tents on the public landing.
The USS Klaring, a fast frigate built at Bath Iron Works, will visit the festival along with several Coast Guard vessels.
More than 100 vendors have signed up for the event. The festival will include a cooking contest and art show, waterfront demonstrations and activities, carnival rides, visits to the Navy and Coast Guard vessels and the traditional 10K road race.

Exporter airs mussel plan

Author: Letitia Baldwin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]02 May 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413845557?accountid=10457

Abstract: Growing market demand for premium blue mussels across the nation has prompted Maine's leading mussel exporter -- Great Eastern Mussel Farms -- to cultivate the mollusk in a growing number of prime spots along the Maine coast instead of harvesting them in the wild.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Exporter+airs+mussel+plan&amp;author=Letitia+Baldwin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-05-02&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: SORRENTO -- Growing market demand for premium blue mussels across the nation has prompted Maine's leading mussel exporter -- Great Eastern Mussel Farms -- to cultivate the mollusk in a growing number of prime spots along the Maine coast instead of harvesting them in the wild.
"Chip" Davison, president of Great Eastern Mussel Farms in Tenants Harbor, said Wednesday night that only so many mussels can be harvested from the wild and that limit is being reached. He said cultivating the shellfish is the only way to meet demand for a tastier, meatier product sought by restaurants and supermarket chains across the United States.
Davison said Maine's mussel industry also faces tough competition from Canada's Prince Edward Island, where islanders are raising mussels on ropes suspended from floating rafts. The cultured mollusks command about double the price of those harvested in the wild.
"Aquaculture is really where the action is going to be in the future," Great Eastern's president predicted. "We feel we need to do more farming."
Davison was speaking to a dozen Sorrento and Sullivan residents who attended a public hearing held on Great Eastern's application for exclusive rights to cultivate mussels in a 14.3 acres of water northwest of Treasure Island in Flanders Bay. The Maine Department of Marine Resources held the hearing and DMR Commissioner Robin Alden must decide whether to approve the application by late summer.
Linked to the mainland by a small causeway lined with granite boulders, Treasure Island lies off the eastern shore of Waukeag Neck in Sorrento. The small island has two year-round households. Its population jumps to eight families in the summer.
For over a decade, John and Connie Dedham have lived year-round on Treasure Island. The couple enjoy kayaking, snorkeling, bird-watching and beachcombing. They note their island boasts a nesting pair of loons as well as otters, seals and other wildlife. Bald eagles feed in the area.
The Dedhams fear more dragging -- the method used to harvest the cultured mussels -- will further erode the heavily dragged area. They say local wormers and clam diggers complain fishing draggers have wiped out the flats on the island's northern side. They say eelgrass, rockweed and kelp beds have also been damaged.
"We feel it is a possibility dragging can create an imbalance in the marine life in our cove," Connie Dedham said. "What we saw in our cove looked like clear-cutting of a forest."
In the summer, the Dedhams say they are already awoken or can't sleep some nights due to the noise of the fishing draggers' diesel engines and hydraulic gear as they tow the bay.
"Sounds like someone driving a Caterpiller tractor out there," John Dedham said. "It's pretty annoying when you want to go to bed."
Of American Indian descent, the Dedhams are also concerned possible Indian artifacts might be destroyed by dragging in their cove. They noted the Watson archaeological site, listed on the National Register of Historic Places, is farther up Flanders Bay.
Responding to the Dedhams, Davison said the mussels would be raised outside the intertidal zones where wormers and clammers dig. He added the mussel farm would not interfere with lobstering since there are only half a dozen lobster pots on the site's outer rim.
Great Eastern biologist Carter Newall said the mussel seeding would take at most six days per year and the harvesting 20 days every other year. During that period, he said. there might be two boats working at a time. He said the mussels would be offloaded in Winter Harbor.
As for the noise made by the draggers, Davison said he has no control over when the independent mussel draggers fish. As for his own captains, he said one's an early bird and the other isn't. He pledged to deal with any problems arising from his company's two boats.
Actually, Davison said, Great Eastern has been seeding mussels near Treasure Island for over a decade. He said the DMR permit would give his company exclusive rights to raise and harvest the mollusks in the area. He said the zone would be delineated by half a dozen buoys saying "sea farm."
Sorrento resident James West lobsters and drags for mussels year-round. He has fished from Portland to Eastport.
"I have never had any trouble with clammers or wormers because we don't fish where they fish," he said.
Winter Harbor mussel dragger Ray Timmons urged DMR official Laurice Churchill to recommend approval of Great Eastern's permit. He said wild mussel stocks are being depleted.
"If we don't start farming, we are going to be out of it sooner or later," he said.
Sorrento resident Sturgis Haskins asked what Great Eastern's future plans are for Flanders Bay.
Davison said Flanders Bay holds great potential for mussel farming and he hopes area fishermen will get interested and cultivate the mollusk.
"I would love to see some locals get involved with it," he said. "The only reason we have our two boats is nobody else would do it."
Davison said a group of Maine aquaculturists and other interested people are holding an informational meeting about mussel cultivation at 7 p.m. Tuesday, May 6, at the Ellsworth Public Library. He said the public is encouraged to attend.
Illustration Caption: Great Eastern Mussel Farms is asking the state for exclusive rights to cultivate blue mussels in the outer cove between Treasure Island and the golf course in Sorrento. (NEWS Photo by Letitia Baldwin)

Rockport author Dietz dead at 90 Writer was co-author of 'Andre the Seal' book with trainer Goodridge

Author: Walter Griffin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]30 Apr 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413860524?accountid=10457

Abstract: None available.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Rockport+author+Dietz+dead+at+90+Writer+was+co-author+of+%27Andre+the+Seal%27+book+with+trainer+Goodridge&amp;author=Walter+Griffin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-04-30&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKPORT -- Lew Dietz, the Maine writer who brought the story of Andre the Seal to the world, has died at age 90.
Dietz, who co-wrote the popular "A Seal Called Andre" in 1975 with Andre's friend and caretaker, Harry Goodridge, died at Penobscot Bay Medical Center on Sunday after a short illness.
During a 60-year writing career, Dietz wrote more than 20 books and hundreds of magazine articles. But it was the heartwarming tale of Andre the Seal that earned Dietz a lasting reputation. "A Seal Called Andre" tells of an orphaned harbor seal rescued from the rocky coast by the late Rockport Harbor Master Harry Goodridge.
Goodridge raised Andre from a pup and taught him tricks that delighted thousands of locals and summer visitors during 15 years of daily performances from Andre's "stage" in Rockport Harbor.
Adapting to fame like a seal to water, the camera-loving Andre was a natural for publicity. Andre made headlines when he left Maine each fall to winter at the New England Aquarium in Boston and in the spring when he swam home to Rockport. Media tracked Andre's every move as he made his way up the coast.
When he died in July 1986, Andre was mourned worldwide. Just as a statue of Andre overlooking Rockport Harbor keeps his legend alive, Dietz's book also remains in print. The story of the orphan seal has been translated into Japanese and was made into a popular Hollywood movie.
Goodridge's daughter Carolyn said Dietz and her father were the best of friends long before they collaborated on the Andre book.
"They were old friends long before Andre came on the scene. They were hunting buddies," Goodridge said Tuesday. "As for the Andre part of it, Harry wasn't much of a writer and Lew was. That's why he came into the picture."
Goodridge described Dietz as "a wonderful guy. I was a very close friend of his right up to his death. He was 40 years older than me, but he had a wonderful, active mind. He was just a wonderful man."
Dietz also was known for another collaborative venture, 1977's "Night Train at Wiscasset Station," a text and photograph volume that is considered a Maine classic. Dietz's crisp prose descriptions, combined with the photographs of his friend, the legendary Rockland photographer Kosti Ruohomaa, have delighted readers for two decades.
Although known as a Maine writer, Dietz was born in Pittsburgh on May 22, 1906, and raised in Westfield, N.J. He studied journalism at New York University and briefly practiced his craft in Paris. He soon returned to New York where he found work in advertising.
By 1932, Dietz decided he had had enough of city life and struck off for Boothbay Harbor to begin a career as a free-lance writer. By the end of the 1930s, Dietz was penning stories for such major publications as the Saturday Evening Post, Collier's and American Magazine.
In Boothbay, Dietz married his first wife, Margaret Hawkey. The couple resettled in the Camden-Rockport area during World War II where Dietz played his part by signing aboard at the Camden Shipyard when the yard was pressed into action churning out wooden-hulled minesweepers.
Always an avid outdoorsman, Dietz began writing tales of the Maine woods for Field and Stream and other publications once the war ended. By the late 1940s, he created a series of boys books on the outdoor life of hunting, fishing, trapping and guiding, always with an emphasis on adventure and conservation.
In the early 1950s, Little, Brown and Co. published "Jeff White, Young Woodsman," the first of a five-volume series featuring a young adventurer. Dietz wrote a half-dozen other fiction books for Little, Brown and also wrote "The Allagash" for Holt, Rinehart and Winston's "Rivers of America" series.
As a founding contributor to Down East magazine, over the next three decades Dietz contributed scores of articles, primarily on outdoors subjects. His last contribution to Down East was a piece of fiction published in 1988. He also wrote for True, Yankee, Geo and Redbook. His work is included in several anthologies.
After his first marriage ended in divorce, Dietz married the painter Denny Winters in 1960. The couple established an informal artistic salon in the large white house overlooking Rockport Harbor where Dietz was to reside for more than half a century. Winters was one of the founders of Maine Coast Artists. Dietz was instrumental in obtaining Rockport's old firehouse for a gallery. The gallery continues in operation.
Dietz served six years on the Maine Commission on the Arts and Humanities. He was also chairman of the Rockport Conservation Commission and was instrumental in efforts to preserve the Oyster River Bog. As a Democrat, Dietz was a rarity in Republican Rockport, but he served for years on the party's county and state committees. He was a delegate at the 1968 Democratic Convention in Chicago, where he took a stand against the Vietnam War.
One of seven children, Dietz was preceded in death by five brothers and a sister. Winters died in 1985. A memorial service will be held for Dietz this summer.
Illustration Caption: Lew Dietz was a familiar face in Rockport. (Ben Magro Photo)

Bacteria may fight caterpillar

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 Apr 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413863741?accountid=10457

Abstract: None available.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Bacteria+may+fight+caterpillar&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-04-24&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PORTLAND -- Caterpillar-killing bacteria could provide Portland with a safer way of ridding its Casco Bay islands of the health problems the insects cause.
Testing will begin this spring on the bacteria, which could replace the controversial pesticide used to kill browntail moth caterpillars that have caused rashes and respiratory problems on the islands.
The discovery comes too late to stop the planned spraying of Dimilin on the islands next month, but state and federal researchers say the bacteria could be used to get rid of the caterpillars next spring.
Browntail moth caterpillars first appeared in Maine in 1989 and have become a particular problem on Portland's islands. Their tiny hairs become airborne and land on people, causing a severe, itchy rash that persists for days. The hairs also can cause breathing problems.
Despite the health hazards the caterpillars pose, many islanders, particularly on Peaks Island, have opposed use of Dimilin. The pesticide can harm lobsters and other shellfish, and its long-term effects on human health and the environment are unknown.
The new bacteria, however, are engineered to kill only a particular insect and pose no risk to humans, the environment, aquatic life or even other insects.
The browntail-killing bacteria were discovered this winter by Normand Dubois, a U.S. Forest Service microbiologist, and researchers at the Northeastern Center for Forest Health in Hamden, Conn. The bacterium is a combination of two strains of an established bacterial insecticide called Bacillus thuringiensis, or Bt.
When a caterpillar eats it, the Bt mixes with certain cells on the caterpillar's stomach wall, seeps into its blood and kills it.
Biologists will begin testing the bacteria's effectiveness in late May, when the caterpillars are actively feeding on the foliage.
The testing probably will be done somewhere on Peaks Island, said Richard Bradbury, a Maine Forest Service entomologist who will conduct the tests with Dubois and Jeff Tarling, Portland's arborist.
The Bt will be applied from the ground, not sprayed from an airplane. The group must find the right mixture of the bacteria, because browntails are finicky and won't eat foliage if they suspect something is wrong, Dubois said.
"What we want to do is prove that it will work in nature as well as it works in the lab," he said. "That's why we have to go with the ground application this year."
The caterpillars emerge from their webs in early May, feed voraciously and grow to 1 1/2 inches long before becoming moths in the summer. Portland is preparing to spray Dimilin on Little Diamond Island, Cushing's Island and infested parts of Peaks Island. The aerial spraying is planned for the third week of May, weather permitting, Tarling said.
State law requires the city to have written permission from property owners before spraying. About half of Peaks Island property owners have indicated they would allow the spraying.
The growth of the browntail's population is slowing, but the caterpillars, which may be found on hardwood trees within three miles of the ocean from Cape Elizabeth to Port Clyde, show no signs of disappearing.

12 communities vie for hatchery clams Biologists hope to stem fishery's free fall

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]16 Apr 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413920715?accountid=10457

Abstract: The state's softshell clam landings have dropped by 72 percent in the last 15 years. Now biologists hope to use thumbnail-sized clams to create a sustainable fishery. Later this month, the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery will announce the names of towns in the midcoast, southwest and Down East parts of the state that will receive a million free seed clams. The clams will be used to seed dormant flats, and perhaps eventually increase productivity. Twelve applicants are vying for the project, from Wells in York County to Edmunds and South Trescott in Washington County. Midcoast communities include Wiscasset, Waldoboro, and the five-town shellfish coalition of Newcastle, Boothbay, Boothbay Harbor, Edgecomb and Damariscotta.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=12+communities+vie+for+hatchery+clams+Biologists+hope+to+stem+fishery%27s+free+fall&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-04-16&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: WALPOLE -- The state's softshell clam landings have dropped by 72 percent in the last 15 years. Now biologists hope to use thumbnail-sized clams to create a sustainable fishery.
Later this month, the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery will announce the names of towns in the midcoast, southwest and Down East parts of the state that will receive a million free seed clams. The clams will be used to seed dormant flats, and perhaps eventually increase productivity.
Twelve applicants are vying for the project, from Wells in York County to Edmunds and South Trescott in Washington County. Midcoast communities include Wiscasset, Waldoboro, and the five-town shellfish coalition of Newcastle, Boothbay, Boothbay Harbor, Edgecomb and Damariscotta.
Hatchery outreach coordinator Ken Vencile says the state's unstable clam supply has resulted in the loss of thousands of jobs and millions of dollars from the Maine economy. It also has contributed to the loss of some conventional clam markets, and prevented the expansion of new ones.
"We want to see if this is a viable way to sustain the fishery," said Brian Beal, shellfish biologist with the University of Maine at Machias, and the Beals Island Project. "We're looking at ways to help create a more sustainable fishery, rather than a boom-or-bust one."
Beal said the project had hoped to announce the selected areas this week, but investigators are still examining flats.
For now, the clams to be used in the project are growing in the tanks in the Darling Marine Center, waiting to be scattered across coastal mud flats.
In June, they will be covered with mesh fine enough to keep out birds and crabs. Within half an hour, they will settle into the mud, and three years later, they will have grown to their legal harvest size.
Winning towns must agree to enforce their clamming ordinances, involve area schools, and provide volunteers willing to make a three-year commitment to monitor water quality, assess the growth and survival of the clams in the plots and attend meetings to discuss the results.
The plots will be monitored monthly, but hatchery administrators are relying on local enforcement to keep people away from the closed areas. "We're hoping they will see the potential of this project and give it a chance to succeed," Vencile said.
Biologists will be watching to see if the numbers of wild seed clams increase in the project areas.
"We've noticed that when we put netting down it seems to attract wild clam settlers," said Vencile.

____________________________________________________________

Farmers organize market in Pittsfield Local vendors solicited for enterprise to begin in June; meeting planned next week

Author: Sharon Mack Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]12 Apr 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413859558?accountid=10457

Abstract: Last summer, Tom Roberts brought his organically grown produce, herbs and flowers to Hathorn Park and set up a small farmers market. He had participated in the Orono market for years but was tired of traveling so far from his Pittsfield farm. "This was based on the response I got last summer from my customers and from several other farmers in the area," said Roberts this week. One of the complaints he often received was that his customers never knew which day he would be at the park and what his hours were. By organizing, said Roberts, and setting a schedule, his customers can be assured of a dependable market date or dates.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Farmers+organize+market+in+Pittsfield+Local+vendors+solicited+for+enterprise+to+begin+in+June%3B+meeting+planned+next+week&amp;author=Sharon+Mack+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-04-12&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PITTSFIELD -- Last summer, Tom Roberts brought his organically grown produce, herbs and flowers to Hathorn Park and set up a small farmers market. He had participated in the Orono market for years but was tired of traveling so far from his Pittsfield farm.
The venture was so successful that over the winter Roberts recruited several other farmers and has organized the Pittsfield Farmers' Market, which they hope will debut in June.
"This was based on the response I got last summer from my customers and from several other farmers in the area," said Roberts this week. One of the complaints he often received was that his customers never knew which day he would be at the park and what his hours were. By organizing, said Roberts, and setting a schedule, his customers can be assured of a dependable market date or dates.
He already has commitments for this season from two farmers -- a producer of strawberries and cider from Thorndike and a cantaloupe farmer from Athens. "We are looking for different types of vendors that will give our shoppers the broadest variety," said Roberts. Local farmers, shellfish and fish vendors, bakers and craftspeople will be welcome at the organizational meeting next week.
A farmers market, said Roberts, is the perfect marriage of the rural and urban sectors of a community. "When you shop at a farmers market, you see who grew it. Part of the aura of the market is the direct connection with the farmer. We realize we are not just selling a product, we are selling our personality as well. It is a whole, package presentation."
Roberts became well-known last year for his creative vegetable displays, stacking crates filled with colorful vegetables and using baskets, flowers and herbs to soften the look. He is very much the picture of a farmer: cap perched on his head, long, graying beard, suspenders and boots.
"The response I got from folks was that I had good stuff and I knew how to display it," said Roberts. He feels that a citizens board would be invaluable in helping keep the market pure; that is, eliminating tailgate peddlers who buy their produce from other farmers or supermarkets and then resell it as their own.
"We don't want a flea market. This is a not a fire sale. Any type of product or craft should be juried, and it must be grown by the presenters themselves and be farm-related," said Roberts.
Roberts said an organizational meeting next week will begin the process, including setting up a board to help manage the market. "When you have competing vendors, there are naturally bound to be disputes. We need to have a body that doesn't involve just the farmers to arbitrate and set rules," said Roberts. "I'm looking for avid shoppers, who live in town, to become a liaison between the farmers, the town, set the rules, days of operation."
The meeting is set for 7 p.m. Wednesday, April 16, in the council chambers of the Pittsfield Municipal Building. Roberts encourages any local farmer or producer and interested residents to attend.

Seafood firm visits Down East Ellsworth, Lubec, Eastport eyed as possible sites for processing

Author: Diana Graettinger Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]05 Apr 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413906915?accountid=10457

Abstract: Representatives of a Connecticut-based firm, PSD Group, visited Ellsworth, Lubec and Eastport Friday to inspect possible sites for a fish and shellfish processing plant. Lubec Community Development Director Chet Childs told the Board of Selectman Thursday night that he had been contacted by Maine and Co., a state-sponsored economic development group that works with the Office of Community Development. Childs said Friday the group seemed favorably disposed to the area. "Obviously noncommittal at this point, but they were impressed with the size of the area, the potential work force that could be drawn from Machias to Robbinston, and the fact that we have excellent water in Lubec," Childs said.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Seafood+firm+visits+Down+East+Ellsworth%2C+Lubec%2C+Eastport+eyed+as+possible+sites+for+processing&amp;author=Diana+Graettinger+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-04-05&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: LUBEC -- Representatives of a Connecticut-based firm, PSD Group, visited Ellsworth, Lubec and Eastport Friday to inspect possible sites for a fish and shellfish processing plant.
Lubec Community Development Director Chet Childs told the Board of Selectman Thursday night that he had been contacted by Maine and Co., a state-sponsored economic development group that works with the Office of Community Development.
"Their job is to go out and find businesses and try to get them to relocate to Maine," Childs said.
Childs said PSD needed a 25- to 50-acre site, preferably on the water, to build its facility. He said the company predicted the plant would create more than 100 jobs the first year, as many at 300 jobs by the third year.
Childs said Friday the group seemed favorably disposed to the area. "Obviously noncommittal at this point, but they were impressed with the size of the area, the potential work force that could be drawn from Machias to Robbinston, and the fact that we have excellent water in Lubec," Childs said.
In Lubec, there is a large parcel on the bay on Pleasant Street, across from the sewer treatment plant near the downtown area. Although much of it is wetland, Childs said he had spoken to Department of Environmental Protection officials who told him it could be reclaimed. But the town would have to mitigate that change by creating wetlands in other areas.
"What they are looking for is suited by that property. They want to be close to a fishing community, they said within 15 miles of the water, but they want right on the water if they can get it," Childs said.
If the company locates in the Down East area, Childs said, it probably would want the benefit of an enterprise zone or a tax-increment financing package. The TIF program was created by the Legislature several years ago to attract new business and additional employment to an area.
Childs said the land to be inspected was assessed at $153,200. He said the property, including a portion owned by Boston University, was available for sale. He said he was uncertain why it had been valued at such a high price. "It's pretty much worthless land," he said.
After the meeting, Childs said the company apparently had looked at property farther south on the coast but was unable to locate an appropriate spot. "Apparently they were looking for more space than was available down there, so they are coming Down East," he said.

Lobster council wins praise Bills to extend, kill panel aired at Augusta hearing

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]01 Apr 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413850520?accountid=10457

Abstract: The philosophical question of whether the state should force lobstermen to pay for marketing got swamped Monday beneath a wave of warm feelings for the Maine Lobster Promotion Council. The Legislature's Marine Resources Committee held public hearings on two bills pertaining to the council, one to keep it alive for four more years and one to kill it. Although attendance at the hearing was hampered by bad weather, more than a dozen spoke in favor of the council, with only two against. The bill to abolish the council is sponsored by Rep. Jim Layton, R-Cherryfield. He told his fellow committee members the Legislature and the Department of Marine Resources "should not be in the business of assessing and collecting taxes for this. The industry itself should determine whether there is a need for this and create its own method of funding it. I'm not against a Lobster Promotion Council, but the promotion effort should come from the industry, as it is with potatoes, blueberries and sardines."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lobster+council+wins+praise+Bills+to+extend%2C+kill+panel+aired+at+Augusta+hearing&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-04-01&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: AUGUSTA -- The philosophical question of whether the state should force lobstermen to pay for marketing got swamped Monday beneath a wave of warm feelings for the Maine Lobster Promotion Council.
The Legislature's Marine Resources Committee held public hearings on two bills pertaining to the council, one to keep it alive for four more years and one to kill it. Although attendance at the hearing was hampered by bad weather, more than a dozen spoke in favor of the council, with only two against.
The council, created by the Legislature in 1991 to boost Maine's premier seafood product, has as its primary source of funding mandatory surcharges on state-issued licenses. The amount ranges from $25 to $75 per year for harvesters, depending upon the class of license, and $200 for dealers. The council's annual revenue from the surcharges has ranged from $245,000 to $310,000.
The bill to abolish the council is sponsored by Rep. Jim Layton, R-Cherryfield. He told his fellow committee members the Legislature and the Department of Marine Resources "should not be in the business of assessing and collecting taxes for this. The industry itself should determine whether there is a need for this and create its own method of funding it. I'm not against a Lobster Promotion Council, but the promotion effort should come from the industry, as it is with potatoes, blueberries and sardines."
The only other person to speak for abolishing the mandatory fees was lobsterman Craig Sprowl of Boothbay, who also said participation in a promotion effort should be voluntary.
Those coming out for the council and its funding mechanism included state officials, dealers and many harvesters who said they originally were opposed to the mandatory fee but had been won over by the council's work, especially in creating a stable market and in allaying consumer fears about the safety of eating shellfish.
"I was against the council at the start," said Harvey Crowley of Corea, president of the Downeast Lobstermen's Association. "I've been a fishermen for 50 years, I've seen the market glutted, I've seen prices so low I've had to tie my boat up. What I've seen since the council started is that for $25 a year, I'm able to go fishing."
Lobsterman Steven Robbins of Stonington said he was "amazed that there's even a bill out there to repeal this. We're getting a lot of bang for our buck. To do away with this would be a terrible mistake."
Robbins, as did several others, said the council has been particularly effective in responding to the adverse publicity about contamination in shellfish, such as the discovery of dioxin in tomalley, the Portland oil spill and red tide.
Marine Resources Commissioner Robin Alden said she "always has been skeptical of government marketing efforts, but this is a good example of what the consolidation of funds can accomplish. Their promotion, appearances at trade shows, consumer education, crisis management, responding to negative campaigns have all been very effective on a very small budget, and they've used this assessment to leverage hundreds of thousands in grants."
Jeff Kaelin, executive director of the Maine Sardine Council, said while his group is funded by voluntary contributions from packers, the nature of the lobster business makes the mandatory fee the only workable approach. "It's easy for us to tax ourselves -- there's only four companies packing sardines. In the lobster industry, you have hundreds, thousands, of independent operators. The surcharge is the only equitable way."
Judy Powell of the state Department of Agriculture also supported the mandatory fee.
Sue Barber, executive director of the lobster council, said stiff foreign competition and the somewhat stagnant American consumption of seafood makes the effort to expand into new markets a necessity.
While not taking credit for it, Barber noted that the dramatic increase in Maine lobster harvests since 1990, from 28 million pounds worth $59 million to nearly 40 million pounds worth $105 million last year, has been accompanied by a modest but appreciable increase in boat price, a development that seemingly defies the law of supply and demand.
"We've had this tremendous increase in production with no glut, no tie-ups," Barber said.
The Marine Resources Committee has several lobster bills on its agenda this session, including proposals on restricting entry into the fishery, an owner-operator requirement for licensure and a repeal of the trap tag law passed last session. Because the weather prevented many lobstermen from traveling to Augusta Monday, the committee will continue its hearings at a later date, probably next week.

____________________________________________________________

Shellfish bill packs hearing Loss of municipal control at issue

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]28 Mar 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/414021096?accountid=10457

Abstract: The bill, sponsored by Sen. Marge Kilkelley, D-Wiscasset, would abolish municipal shellfish ordinances and replace them with one state standard, a change supporters say would open the clam flats to all, and that opponents claim would destroy the local expertise and volunteerism that has the industry on the rebound. A veteran of 10 years in the House before moving over to the Senate this year, Kilkelley told the committee that friends and foes alike have said the bill "is probably the craziest thing I've ever done as a legislator," but she added inequalities in access to the resource makes it worth the fight. Since 1963, state law has required that towns make only 10 percent of the clam licenses they issue available to nonresidents of the town, at up to twice the price. While that may have been acceptable 34 years ago, Kilkelley said, the reality of today is that many who rely on income from shellfish harvesting can no longer afford to live on the coast.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Shellfish+bill+packs+hearing+Loss+of+municipal+control+at+issue&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-03-28&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: AUGUSTA -- Early this legislative session, several members of the Marine Resources Committee predicted that a bill to wrest shellfish management from municipal control would be the hot item on their agenda.
Those seers proved to be accurate Thursday as more than 200 harvesters, town and state officials, fisheries scientists and legislators packed a public hearing to argue history, economics, logistics, logic and the always emotional issue of public access to natural resources.
The bill, sponsored by Sen. Marge Kilkelley, D-Wiscasset, would abolish municipal shellfish ordinances and replace them with one state standard, a change supporters say would open the clam flats to all, and that opponents claim would destroy the local expertise and volunteerism that has the industry on the rebound.
A veteran of 10 years in the House before moving over to the Senate this year, Kilkelley told the committee that friends and foes alike have said the bill "is probably the craziest thing I've ever done as a legislator," but she added inequalities in access to the resource makes it worth the fight.
Since 1963, state law has required that towns make only 10 percent of the clam licenses they issue available to nonresidents of the town, at up to twice the price. While that may have been acceptable 34 years ago, Kilkelley said, the reality of today is that many who rely on income from shellfish harvesting can no longer afford to live on the coast.
Kilkelley said she decided to write the bill after talking to a constituent from inland Whitefield. "This is a man with two kids who told me he was lucky enough to get a nonresident license this year, but couldn't count on one for next year. If people are going to support their families, they need access to our resources. They need an opportunity to work and to earn a living."
With most of the state's shellfish powers already on record as being opposed to the change, Kilkelley, describing herself as "a very practical person," admitted it is unlikely the bill will make it out of committee. "Instead, I ask you to use this as a vehicle to look at the public policy issues involved, and to determine how the unintended negative consequences of the current law can be ameliorated."
In addition to asking the committee to consider increasing the nonresident license allotment and revising the price structure, Kilkelley said the law must be amended to ensure that licensing decisions made by a town are based upon science and not societal pressures. Kilkelley also asked for a review of the tight restriction some towns place on nonresident recreational licenses.
Several supporters said towns have become too territorial in enforcing their shellfish ordinances. They questioned how clams could be deemed the property of towns while all other natural resources, from lobster to white-tailed deer, are open to all.
"It's a darn shame to shut out people from Augusta, Waterville or Skowhegan," said Clark Jones of Wiscasset. "I can go up there to hunt deer, but they can't come to my town to dig a peck of clams for a picnic."
Lori Howell, vice president of Spinney Creek Shellfish Co., said that although some towns have managed the resource well, "the standards of municipal enforcement are not high enough. We could sell two to three times as many clams if we'd get beyond these territorial boundaries and get on with the business of increasing production."
While supporters ran out of speakers long before their one-hour time limit expired, opponents lined the length of the Augusta Civic Center auditorium waiting to get in their shots.
First up was Bob Cummings of the Phippsburg Shellfish Committee, who, as did many others to come, said clams are a different kettle of fish from other resources in that properly managing a flat takes an enormous amount of volunteer effort that only locals can provide.
"It's the people of these towns that have fought to clean up the flats and to restore this resource," Cummings said. "It's only the local people who have the political will to do what's right. It would take $100,000 of state money to do what Phippsburg volunteers do every year. History has shown again and again that that which everyone owns, no one protects."
Sen. Phillip Harriman of the Yarmouth-Brunswick region agreed that the local volunteers who clean up flats, monitor water quality, reseed and survey would disappear if the bill became law.
Jack Schneider of Georgetown said he was "totally perplexed" as to how anyone could consider jeopardizing the livelihoods of more than 1,800 commercial harvesters by taking responsibility for clam management from local volunteers and turning it over to "those bureaucrats in Augusta."
Speaking as an Augusta bureaucrat, Marine Resources Commissioner Robin Alden said she, too, was puzzled and opposed. "There is a long history, going back to Colonial times, of local management of this local resource," Alden said. "We rely on our partnership with towns -- shellfish demands intense management and hard work. It demands a sense of stewardship and responsibility that comes from these municipal ordinances, that creates this direct link between use and management."
Alden said local efforts to restore contaminated flats have led to the reopening of more than 21,000 acres of flats in the last two years and estimated the cost of replacing the volunteer work at more than $1 million.
University of Maine shellfish biologist Brian Beal called Kilkelley's bill "poorly thought-out and illogical" by assuming that the local volunteerism would continue under state control. "Instead of wasting our time defending local control and comparing clams to deer, we should be here today debating a nonexistent bill on enhancing managment of this resource," Beal said.
The committee, which had only a few questions for those testifying, will sort through the comments gathered during the hearing at a work session next Thursday.

`Great Chefs' cooking up a great fund-raiser

Author: Joni Averill Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]28 Mar 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413834814?accountid=10457

Abstract: You can still make reservations for the 12th annual "Evening With The Great Chefs" fund-raiser at 6 p.m. Monday at Jeff's Catering in Brewer. The event, including an auction, benefits the National Kidney Foundation of Maine. NKF volunteer Jennifer Walton hopes all 350 tickets will go because of the outstanding auction items and fabulous foods donated for the benefit. For years, bronze sculpturist Forest Hart has contributed to the auction. This year, Walton said, it is "`Perky,' a little red fox with a value of $300." The event offers food prepared by students at Penobscot Job Corps Center and United Technology Center of Bangor. Representing the health field will be chefs from Eastern Maine Medical Center and Acadia Hospital.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=%60Great+Chefs%27+cooking+up+a+great+fund-raiser&amp;author=Joni+Averill+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-03-28&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: You can still make reservations for the 12th annual "Evening With The Great Chefs" fund-raiser at 6 p.m. Monday at Jeff's Catering in Brewer. The event, including an auction, benefits the National Kidney Foundation of Maine.
NKF volunteer Jennifer Walton hopes all 350 tickets will go because of the outstanding auction items and fabulous foods donated for the benefit. For years, bronze sculpturist Forest Hart has contributed to the auction. This year, Walton said, it is "`Perky,' a little red fox with a value of $300."
KISS radio offers $800 worth of advertising. You could get a year's free paging from New England Page, restaurant certificates, furniture, or signal your choice for a variety of activities from theater to music events.
Walton, a kidney transplant recipient, is pleased that professional auctioneer and fellow recipient Ben Tilton of East Corinth will be at the microphone. Ben Tilton and Sons work the audience into a generous bidding mood. "He and his sons all participate, and it's really kind of neat," she said.
The event offers food prepared by students at Penobscot Job Corps Center and United Technology Center of Bangor. Representing the health field will be chefs from Eastern Maine Medical Center and Acadia Hospital.
Restaurants taking part are the Sea Dog, Jasmine's, the Olive Garden, Feta's, the Lemon Tree, Governor's, Geaghan's Roundhouse, the Brown Bag, Killarney's, The Mex, and Steve's Stagecoach.
Specialties prepared by chefs at the University of Maine Wells Commons will be served with favorite staples from the Brick Oven Bakery and The Bagel Shop. Wholesale food suppliers include Jordan's, Sisco, Carl Smith, Northcenter, Maine Shellfish, Grant's Dairy, Shop 'n Save, and Shaw's Hogan Road.
Call 942-1028 for tickets.
In the spirit of the season, the staff of Hope House, providing emergency shelter and services for people with substance abuse problems, sends thanks to those helping improve the lives of its guests.
Chris Olsen reports that Jack Quirk and Chevrolet-Geo recently donated a 1985 Subaru station wagon to provide transportation for Project Hope. The new program, coordinated by Jim Harney, enables homeless individuals and those in Hope House transitional housing become involved in community service projects such as food distribution by S.H.A.R.E. and Shalom Zone.
On Wednesday, The Bangor Noontime Lions Club awarded Hope House a $1,600 grant to purchase a new computer system for maintaining a donor record database, publishing a newsletter, printing educational materials and information for fund-raisers, and providing access to the Internet to help identify new funding sources.
In the same spirit, thanks come from Dennis Marble, executive director of the Greater Bangor Area Shelter, to those who have given time, talent and money to improve that Main Street facility.
"Our shelter has needed some renovations for quite awhile, especially regarding the downstairs offices area," Marble wrote. In the past several weeks, "terrific improvements" have been made to the facitilty, which lacked adequate staff office space, had only one area for private conversation and two phone lines for six staff members and 30 guests.
Community Health and Counseling Services, Bangor Area Visiting Nurses, Northeast Occupational Exchange, Wabanaki Mental Health Associates, and the Greater Bangor Area Crisis Stabilization Services often had staff helping guests only to be hampered by lack of telephone access.
Two new offices have been added plus a third phone line. Funding came in a $12,00 grant from Region III Department of Mental Health, Mental Retardation and Substance Abuse Services, coordinated by Kerry Slack. Additional work will be funded with this grant.
But the value of the grant was far exceeded "due to the unselfish, volunteer efforts and donations" by members of the community, Marble wrote.
"The major work has been done by Robby Speirs and the other folks with Habitat for Humanity."
Greatly appreciated assistance also came from Ron Lunn and Portland Glass; Bob Kelly, House Revivers; Norm Taylor, Jeff Taylor and Mike Tompkins, Taylor Communications; Mark Martin, director of Home Builders Institute affiliated with Penobscot Job Corps Center; and Dan Kinney of Kinney Electric.
"Cindy Raymond, a young woman who lives near the shelter," Marble wrote, "took it upon herself to make a set of curtains so guests would have privacy when meeting in the director's office."
We can tell you, if your business or organization is remodeling or redecorating, to call GBAS at 947-0045 to find out if the shelter can use what you no longer need. GBAS appreciates any donations.
"All of this support is one more chapter in this community's history of helping our homeless," Marble wrote, "and we are sincerely and profoundly grateful.'

Maine's beloved `Brownie' honored Cooking guru Mildred Brown Schrumpf makes Women's Hall of Fame

Author: Ruth-Ellen Cohen Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 Mar 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413907370?accountid=10457

Abstract: Fans of Brownie [Mildred Brown] Schrumpf gathered Saturday afternoon at the University of Maine at Augusta to celebrate her induction into the Maine Women's Hall of Fame, and to sing the praises of the beloved 94-year-old cooking guru whose folksy food column appeared weekly in the Bangor Daily News for four decades. The Maine Women's Hall of Fame, established in 1990, is co-sponsored by the Maine Federation of Business and Professional Women and the University of Maine at Augusta. Past inductees include the late Sen. Margaret Chase Smith and Mabel Wadsworth of Bangor who helped establish the Maine Family Planning Association. Born in Readfield in 1903, Brownie graduated from the University of Maine with a degree in home economics. She was the assistant 4-H Club leader for Maine and the Penobscot County 4-H Club agent in the 1920s and '30s, and later taught home economics at the University of Maine, Orono, and cooking at the YWCA in Bangor.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Maine%27s+beloved+%60Brownie%27+honored+Cooking+guru+Mildred+Brown+Schrumpf+makes+Women%27s+Hall+of+Fame&amp;author=Ruth-Ellen+Cohen+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-03-24&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: AUGUSTA -- Fans of Brownie Schrumpf gathered Saturday afternoon at the University of Maine at Augusta to celebrate her induction into the Maine Women's Hall of Fame, and to sing the praises of the beloved 94-year-old cooking guru whose folksy food column appeared weekly in the Bangor Daily News for four decades.
Mildred Brown Schrumpf, affectionately known as Brownie, was unable to attend the ceremony due to illness. But a nephew, Roland LaVallee of Winthrop, accepted the certificate for her, and attorney Dana Devoe of Orono presented it to her Sunday at the Orono Nursing Home where she now lives.
Schrumpf was one of two Maine women inducted this year into the Hall of Fame based on her outstanding contribution to improving opportunities for all Maine women. Ethel {Billie} Wilson Gammon of Livermore Falls, founder of the Washburn-Norlands Living History Center, also was chosen for the honor.
The Maine Women's Hall of Fame, established in 1990, is co-sponsored by the Maine Federation of Business and Professional Women and the University of Maine at Augusta. Past inductees include the late Sen. Margaret Chase Smith and Mabel Wadsworth of Bangor who helped establish the Maine Family Planning Association.
Schrumpf and Gammon became the 11th and 12th members of the Hall of Fame.
On Saturday, friends, family and colleagues happily shared memories of Brownie, the diminutive cook, home economist, nutritionist, author and teacher who was never without a smile and a wise piece of culinary advice. Her cookbooks, "The Flavor of Maine" and "Memories from Brownie's Kitchen," became staples in kitchens everywhere.
Brownie's cooking and teaching prowesses, knowledge of food preparation, boundless energy and community spirit were recalled by Fred Hutchinson, president of the University of Maine; U.S. Rep. John Baldacci; Katherine Musgrave, UM professor of nutrition; and NEWS reporter Joni Averill, representing publisher Richard J. Warren who was not able to attend the ceremony.
Born in Readfield in 1903, Brownie graduated from the University of Maine with a degree in home economics. She was the assistant 4-H Club leader for Maine and the Penobscot County 4-H Club agent in the 1920s and '30s, and later taught home economics at the University of Maine, Orono, and cooking at the YWCA in Bangor.
Throughout the 1950s and '60s, Brownie was the Maine Food Products Promoter for the Maine Department of Agriculture. She also ran a series of food demonstrations on television and served as assistant executive director and acting director of the General Alumni Association of the University of Maine.
"Everywhere there was a need, there was Brownie," said Priscilla Dodge of Dixmont, a retired librarian who remembered Brownie cooking meal after meal for the families of those who were ill, visiting local nursing homes, shopping for groceries for senior citizens and chauffering them about.
Dodge said that Brownie would often say that "older people don't like to drive in bad weather."
"The funny thing is, these people were five or 10 years younger than Brownie herself," said Dodge, chuckling. "She just never seemed to age."
Dodge, a retired librarian, said that when she became aware that the Women's Hall of Fame Committee was looking for nominees, she immediately thought of Brownie. Dodge joined the NEWS and the University of Maine General Alumni Association in nominating Schrumpf for the Hall of Fame.
"If she's not in it, she should be," contended Dodge, who, as a child, would watch her mother cut Brownie's recipes out of the newspaper and refer to her with any cooking query.
"She represented Down East cooking at its best," Dodge recalled Saturday. "Whenever my mother had a problem with a recipe, there was Brownie on the other end of the phone."
UM President Frederick Hutchinson also retained fond memories of Brownie, who taught home economics to his wife, Dione. On their way home from school, his two daughters and other children in the Orono neighborhood would make a beeline for Brownie's kitchen where she'd heap homemade cookies upon them, he said.
Meanwhile, U.S. Rep. John Baldacci said that Brownie also had been his father's home economics teacher at UM and that she instilled in him a love for good food and for cooking.
"He had so much respect for her," said Baldacci, whose father died several years ago. "She made a real impact on him. He would have wanted me to speak here today."
Katherine Musgrave, a professor of nutrition at UM, said Saturday that when she first moved to Maine from the South in the 1960s, she was unfamiliar with how to prepare shellfish and would often call Brownie late at night for culinary advice.
"I knew she would be up long after midnight," Musgrave said, chuckling. "She had boundless energy."
"Brownie exemplifed what we try so hard to teach in nutrition education -- that food must be good and the preparation simple," the professor added.
Musgrave said that in 1973 when the energy crisis precipitated an interest in canning foods, she counted on Brownie to always have "a ready answer."
"Brownie had more knowledge about canning, pickling and preserving than could be found in any extension or food book," she said."And the beauty of Brownie was that she never tried to teach anything that she hadn't done herself."
Meanwhile, Joni Averill of the NEWS said Brownie's columns were not so much about food, but about living.
"Her food columns weren't really about mixing ingredients properly to make a product, they were about mixing ingredients properly to make a life," Averill noted.
"If you read several of Brownie's columns, you discover at the outset you're not really reading at all. You are actually standing beside her, in her kitchen, and she is gently, firmly, lovingly, instructing you. She is not talking to you, she is guiding you through a process that is guaranteed to succeed if you follow her directions," Averill told the group.
Roland LaVallee happily recalled the homemade candies his aunt would continually bestow upon the family.
"The caramels were my favorite," he said.
Rick Warren, NEWS publisher, agreed that everyone coveted Brownie's famous confections.
"We all eagerly looked forward to holidays when Brownie would bring in samples of her holiday cooking to share with us. It was the lucky ones who first saw her coming through the door, because they often got all her soft, creamy caramels," he wrote in a statement which Averill presented at the celebration.
Meanwhile, LaVallee said Brownie would have been "flattered to pieces" to have received such accolades on Saturday. Still, everyone agreed that the lively little cook deemed pats on the back totally unnecessary.
"She'd have done everything exactly the same way without the recognition," said Hutchinson.
Illustration Caption: Brownie Schrumpf, 94, was inducted Saturday into the Maine Women's Hall of Fame at the University of Maine at Augusta. (NEWS Photo by Susan Latham)
