Cranberry Crisis

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 Mar 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413853630?accountid=10457

Abstract: None available.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Cranberry+Crisis&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-03-24&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: If fishermen in the Machias-Machiasport-Cutler and Milbridge-Harrington-Addison areas have yet to inform themselves about Cherryfield Foods' proposed cranberry project in Washington County, then perhaps it is time they did so. This project, if approved by the Department of Environmental Protection, will allow the company to convert 1,337 acres of natural wetlands and uplands in the drainages of the Machias and Pleasant rivers into artificial cranberry bogs, reservoirs and tailwater ponds. This affront to the environment is bad enough, destroying natural wetlands and drawing off large amounts of water from the aquifers during the driest times of the season to fill the reservoirs and flood the bogs.
Worse, however, are the additional pesticides that will find their way into our rivers and coastal waters. Aren't all the pesticides dumped on an additional 900 acres of cranberries? Supposedly, Cherryfield Foods' will have a system of tailwater ponds to hold the pesticide-contaminated water that is drained off the craberry bogs. Does anybody believe these will work? Does anybody believe the pesticides will not seep down into our groundwater, and that the tailwater ponds will not overflow and end up in our rivers?
What further harm will these additional pesticides cause to our already beleaguered fisheries? What will happen when the elver run coincides with an early spring application of pesticides and heavy rain causing flooding? What will happen to the aquatic microorganisms fed upon by shellfish? What will happen to lobsters that feed upon organisms killed by the pesticides? Can anyone at DEP answer these questions for us? Of course not, so why would the agency charged with protecting our environment permit this project? I urge concerned fishermen to call or write their legislators and Jeff Madore at the Department of Environmental Protection. Paul K. Donahue Bangor

Wells Sanitary District faces environmental fine

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]21 Mar 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413855089?accountid=10457

Abstract: Sanitary district officials say they will fight a $50,000 fine levied by the Environmental Protection Agency. The federal agency says the district's treatment plant discharged too much chlorine into the ocean, which posed a risk to shellfish. The violations date back to 1993, according to the EPA.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Wells+Sanitary+District+faces+environmental+fine&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-03-21&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: WELLS -- Sanitary district officials say they will fight a $50,000 fine levied by the Environmental Protection Agency.
The federal agency says the district's treatment plant discharged too much chlorine into the ocean, which posed a risk to shellfish. The violations date back to 1993, according to the EPA.
Dennis Thayer, superintendent of the district, says that on several occasions the amount of chlorine exceeded federal levels, but he said it was "minuscule amounts ... less than in your drinking water."
"We're going to fight this," Thayer said. "The check isn't in the mail."
The district has three weeks to appeal the citation.
The treatment plant was one of six in New England cited by EPA for discharge violations.
State environmental authorities also have questioned the EPA's actions.
"There's really a question as to how bad this situation is," said Stuart Rose, a water-resources supervisor with the Maine Department of Environmental Protection.

Safeguarding seafood FDA initiative aims to curb food-borne illnesses

Author: Jenna Russell Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]18 Mar 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/414026093?accountid=10457

Abstract: A nationwide initiative launched by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration is designed to prevent future food-borne illness outbreaks. By the end of this year, an estimated 1,000 Maine residents employed by more than 300 seafood processing firms will learn to comply with new inspection guidelines. Contamination will be prevented through use of the Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point system, known as HACCP. First developed in reponse to NASA concerns about food-borne illness in astronauts, the system has been around for years as a voluntary program. What is new is the mandate that will require its implementation. About 30 volunteers in Maine have been trained as HACCP instructors. So far they have shared their knowledge with 220 participants in nine three-day training courses offered from Boothbay to Machias, in Burlington, Vt., and Portsmouth, N.H. A 10th course was wrapped up this week on Vinalhaven.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Safeguarding+seafood+FDA+initiative+aims+to+curb+food-borne+illnesses&amp;author=Jenna+Russell+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-03-18&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: When players for the Providence College men's basketball team ate tainted salmon at a restaurant buffet in New York City early this month, it cost them the next day in a key Big East tournament matchup against Villanova.
Crippled by illness, the Friars lost their shot at the tournament title. No doubt the loss was painful, but it could have been worse for the disappointed players. Thousands of times every year, food poisoning is fatal.
A nationwide initiative launched by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration is designed to prevent future food-borne illness outbreaks. By the end of this year, an estimated 1,000 Maine residents employed by more than 300 seafood processing firms will learn to comply with new inspection guidelines.
Contamination will be prevented through use of the Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point system, known as HACCP. First developed in reponse to NASA concerns about food-borne illness in astronauts, the system has been around for years as a voluntary program. What is new is the mandate that will require its implementation.
About 30 volunteers in Maine have been trained as HACCP instructors. So far they have shared their knowledge with 220 participants in nine three-day training courses offered from Boothbay to Machias, in Burlington, Vt., and Portsmouth, N.H. A 10th course was wrapped up this week on Vinalhaven.
Other sessions are scheduled this spring in Machias, Portland and Ellsworth, and training will likely continue through the end of the year.
"Part of it is just building up an information base, an understanding of bacteria, viruses and chemicals," said Mahmoud El-Begearmi, University of Maine Cooperative Extension nutrition and food safety specialist.
A professor of food science and human nutrition, he is part of the team working to provide the state with HACCP training. The Department of Marine Resources, the state Department of Agriculture and the National Marine Fisheries Service are other cooperating agencies.
Together they formed the Northern New England Seafood Alliance last year to ensure that affordable, effective training would be available to those who need it. The cost has been kept to $100 per person. Other providers are charging as much as $675 for the same training, according to alliance Vice Chairman Ron Hoelzer of the Brewer-based Maine Sardine Council.
While some seafood processors were skeptical at first about the need for HACCP, attitudes statewide are improving dramatically, he said. Many participants have been relieved to learn that better record keeping will be the biggest required change in their process.
Assistant Manager Bob Hessler was one of a half-dozen employees from Ellsworth's Maine Shellfish Co. trained in HACCP methods early this year. A distributor of fresh and frozen seafood, and a clam and shrimp processor, the business employs about 50 people.
"I think HACCP is requiring seafood companies to do what good seafood companies are already doing," Hessler said. "If you're not a good seafood company, you might have to make some big changes. If you are good, you have to document it -- prove it."
"On the first day, there's a tremendous amount of apprehension and animosity," Hoelzer said of the training sessions. "By the end of the second day there's a real positive attitude. The third day we hold a workshop for people to work on their own HACCP plans. The enthusiasm is sometimes overwhelming. It's inspiring."
Enthusiasm aside, experts seem to be divided on the likely impact of the HACCP system. A 1991 study by the Institute of Medicine, a branch of the National Academy of Sciences, endorsed HACCP use but found little evidence that added controls at the processing level would reduce cases of illness. Money would be better spent inspecting fishing waters, according to the study group.
There were about 6,000 reported cases of seafood-borne illness from 1978 to 1987. Seafood caused just 3.6 percent of all food poisoning cases in that 10-year period, according to the 1991 report.
The greatest risk came with consumption of raw oysters, clams and mussels. Most related illnesses are mild and not reported. No amount of precaution in processing can entirely eliminate the risks of eating raw mollusks.
Hoelzer said a handful of deaths a few years back led to a "perceived problem" so severe the seafood industry finally asked the FDA to help ease public fears. The two groups worked together to mandate the HACCP program.
Under the old style of quality control, inspectors tested a small percentage of a finished product and assumed, if the sample was OK, that it represented everything else. The problem lay in the assumption, Hoelzer said.
HACCP works in reverse to examine steps in the process before problems occur, focusing on "critical points" where the hazard risks are highest.
For crab meat, one of those critical points is cooking, said El-Begearmi. Under the new program crab processors will track cooking temperatures and durations to ensure that contamination risk is minimized. A critical point in the production of other seafoods is storage temperature. Above 40 degrees, bacteria grow much faster, said the professor.
Charlie Tait of Cap Morrill's Fishmarket in Brewer said the firm began work on HACCP plans a year ago. Twice-daily temperature checks of freezers have already been implemented. He expects full HACCP adoption to be costly in terms of time and money, though he's not sure yet what changes will be needed.
Tait believes the effort will make seafood safer if followed exactly, but expects some smaller processors will go out of business because they can't afford to comply with the program.
The HACCP course teaches about types of processing hazards, how they produce illness, where they turn up and how to identify and prevent them. While every processing firm must produce a course graduate, it is not necessary to train every employee.
Those who are trained are responsible for conducting a hazard analysis of their workplace before the guidelines become law Dec. 18, and again every year or whenever the product or process is changed. Federal regulators will conduct on-site inspections to ensure compliance, said Willis Cobb of the FDA's Augusta office, seafood program manager for the New England district.
Tait is skeptical about enforcement of the regulations. He said government agencies like the FDA "are being given more to do all the time with smaller budgets."
"It's not going to be as effective as it could be because they're not going to have people to monitor it," he said. "They're just not going to have the budget to go out and do what they know they should be doing."
There's plenty they should be doing, he said, such as stopping some processors from using unethical tricks that include adding chemicals to scallops to boost their weight.
Cobb said Maine and Massachusetts have similar numbers of seafood firms, and are the Northeastern states most affected by the regulations. Alaska and Washington are other major producers of seafood.
El-Begearmi said that half the seafood consumed in the United States is processed overseas, and for the sake of fairness plants there will also be required to use the HACCP system in producing exports.
"Processors here will not be unduly pressured," he said.
Despite some initial resistance, the seafood industry is likely to benefit in the long run from the stricter safeguards.
"The whole idea is to make the seafood consumers go and buy at the supermarket or fish market wholesome, safe and free of any contamination that could cause injury," El-Begearmi said. "I think people will have more confidence in the industry."
Illustration Caption: Bangor resident Gary Roberts serves a customer at Cap Morrill's Fishmarket in Brewer. The market already is following new FDA guidelines, which don't go into effect until December, to record freezer temperatures. (NEWS Photo by Linda Coan)

Company / organization: Name: Food & Drug Administration--FDA; NAICS: 922190

State offers grants for boat pump-outs

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]18 Mar 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413947020?accountid=10457

Abstract: The State Planning Office's Maine Coastal Program has grants available for creation of boat pump-outs and sewage disposal systems covering 75 percent of the equipment and installation costs of a pump-out, up to $7,500.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=State+offers+grants+for+boat+pump-outs&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-03-18&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: AUGUSTA -- The State Planning Office's Maine Coastal Program has grants available for creation of boat pump-outs and sewage disposal systems covering 75 percent of the equipment and installation costs of a pump-out, up to $7,500.
The grants are designed for smaller systems and dump stations or to help meet costs of more expensive systems.
Sam Brody of the Maine Coastal Program said, "We strongly encourage people who own marinas or groups that manage boat access areas to apply for the grants while the funds are available. The grant process is very simple, flexible, and the turnaround time is quick."
Places with pump-out stations provide a service to boaters and help keep Maine waters clean. Raw or poorly treated sewage can spread disease, contaminate shellfish beds, and lower oxygen levels in water, affecting fish and other marine animals.
The federal government established a five-year grant program administered by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and in Maine by the Coastal Program. So far, 23 marinas have been awarded grants for pump-outs.
To apply for a grant or for more information, call Brody at 287-5649 or write to him at the Maine Coastal Program, Station 38, Augusta 04333.

____________________________________________________________

Eastport clammers fined $1,300 each for harvesting in local closed area Pair support statewide standard

Author: Diana Graettinger Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]12 Mar 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413838900?accountid=10457

Abstract: It should have been a simple charge of taking clams in a closed area, but the case took on greater significance when two clammers argued that Eastport's shellfish ordinance was keeping them from making a living for their families. Thomas Cook, 36, and Robert Carter, 35, were in 4th District Court Tuesday to resist attempts to charge them with clamming in a closed area, and in a conservation area. Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Eastport+clammers+fined+%241%2C300+each+for+harvesting+in+local+closed+area+Pair+support+statewide+standard&amp;author=Diana+Graettinger+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-03-12&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: CALAIS -- It should have been a simple charge of taking clams in a closed area, but the case took on greater significance when two clammers argued that Eastport's shellfish ordinance was keeping them from making a living for their families.
Thomas Cook, 36, and Robert Carter, 35, were in 4th District Court Tuesday to resist attempts to charge them with clamming in a closed area, and in a conservation area.
Although the men were found guilty of the violations and each fined $1,300, they vowed outside the courtroom to continue their battle against the Eastport ordinance. They said they wanted the state to regulate clamming.
Earlier this year, Sen. Marge Kilkelly, D-Wiscasset, sponsored a bill that would scrap town clam harvesting rules and replace them with a statewide standard and a single state clamming license.
Last year, the Eastport Marine Resources Committee, in an effort to protect Carrying Place Cove, and with the approval of the clammers, opened only 60 of the cove's 240 acres to shellfish harvesting. Orange-tipped stakes were installed to mark the open area. The cove is located off Route 190, near the Eastport scenic sign.
Cook said that when the original 60 acres was open, Will Hopkins, project coordinator for the Cobscook Bay Clam Restoration Project, who has been instrumental in developing a conservation plan, had assured them that there were 2,400 bushels of clams in the area. Cook said only 150 bushels were available for harvest.
In December, clammers dug in the closed area, and Cook and Carter later were summoned for the violation.
A group of clammers again met with the committee and asked that at least half of Carrying Place Cove be open to them. Although an additional 60 acres was opened in January, Cook and Carter said Tuesday the new area already had been dug dry.
The Eastport Shellfish Conservation Ordinance, which regulates clamming activities in the community, was approved in 1995.
Cook said he believes only the state should regulate clamming. "I want the state of Maine to take this over and get rid of idiots like Will Hopkins," he said.
Contacted Tuesday afternoon, Hopkins said he had no comment.
If the state regulated clamming, clam diggers could purchase a state license that would allow them to clam anywhere in the state, Cook said.
Carter and Cook said they would be unable to pay their fines. "I already told the judge I am not paying. I am surprised he didn't lug me off," Carter said.
The men said they would be back on the flats today, but they were uncertain which side of the conservation line they would be on.
"Somebody has got to listen. We have to get someone's attention because if we don't, clamming as we know it is going to be gone," Cook said.
Assistant District Attorney Paul Cavanaugh said that if the men did not agree with the city's ordinance, there were procedures to amend it.
"This ordinance includes many references on how to amend it. The city council presumably amends ordinances, and they {the clammers} need to make their political pitch. If they win -- it's amended, if they don't -- it stays the same," Cavanaugh said.

Creating marine-related jobs focus of forum Committee of 50 sponsors annual gathering

Author: Letitia Baldwin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]05 Mar 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413841356?accountid=10457

Abstract: Bruce Sidell, director of the University of Maine's newly founded School of Marine Sciences, used that example Tuesday to illustrate how scientific research can benefit industry. He was speaking to dozens of public and private sector leaders at a science, research and economic development forum sponsored by the Action Committee of 50. Founded two decades ago, the Action Committee of 50 comprises 150 members of the public and private sectors in the Greater Bangor area. The group's aim is to promote economic development in eastern Maine. This year's annual forum focused on Maine opportunities to create jobs and economic growth in marine-related industries. James Mullen, director of Acadia Hospital in Bangor and past chairman of the Maine Chamber & Business Alliance, noted marine-related scientific research in Maine has fostered $40 million in economic activity over the past five years. He said that research was conducted with less than $1 million in state funding.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Creating+marine-related+jobs+focus+of+forum+Committee+of+50+sponsors+annual+gathering&amp;author=Letitia+Baldwin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-03-05&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BANGOR -- In the early 1960s, a Stanford graduate student on a research trip to Antarctica found fish swimming in frigid waters where their body fluids normally would freeze. He discovered the fish possessed an unknown class of biological molecules that prevent ice crystals from growing.
Over the years, biochemist Arthur DeDries' discovery has prompted businesses to explore the possibility of using the matter to prevent agricultural crops from freezing. The particles also have been considered for cold storage of hearts and other organs for transplant, and to eliminate the ice crystals that form in ice cream.
Bruce Sidell, director of the University of Maine's newly founded School of Marine Sciences, used that example Tuesday to illustrate how scientific research can benefit industry. He was speaking to dozens of public and private sector leaders at a science, research and economic development forum sponsored by the Action Committee of 50.
Founded two decades ago, the Action Committee of 50 comprises 150 members of the public and private sectors in the Greater Bangor area. The group's aim is to promote economic development in eastern Maine. This year's annual forum focused on Maine opportunities to create jobs and economic growth in marine-related industries.
The forum's panelists ranged widely, from Albert Carver of Carver Shellfish on Beals Island to Dr. Tom Long, director of the Center for Innovation for Biomedical Technology at the University of Maine.
James Mullen, director of Acadia Hospital in Bangor and past chairman of the Maine Chamber & Business Alliance, noted marine-related scientific research in Maine has fostered $40 million in economic activity over the past five years. He said that research was conducted with less than $1 million in state funding.
"That's $40 generated for every dollar put in by the state. I think the benefits of leveraging partnerships are very clear," Mullen said.
Last month, the Department of Economic & Community Development released a status report on the state's economic development strategy. The report says the state's Department of Marine Resources has set three goals to "put Maine on the map in cold-water marine science and business."
DMR Commissioner Robin Alden reiterated those goals at Tuesday's forum. She said her department aims to stabilize the number of jobs in Maine's traditional fisheries at 22,000 by 2001, and double those in aquaculture from 500 to 1,000.
Her agency also strives to make the state a world-class center for marine research as well as a marine biotechnology center.
Alden sees the involvement of Maine's 14 marine research institutions as key in achieving the DMR's goals. She noted only 75 of the 2,000 marine species in the Gulf of Maine now are harvested commercially. She said related marine research could help in the development and responsible harvesting of new seafood products.
"Marine science, in itself, is good business," she said.
Maine's aquaculture industry -- largely Atlantic salmon -- generates more revenue than any other fishery after lobster. Last year's harvest yielded $46.3 million worth of pen-raised fin fish.
Charleton Ames, chairman of Sea Run Holdings -- a Maine company raising steelhead trout and Atlantic salmon in Eastport -- said Maine's aquaculture industry has the fortune of being widely accepted by the general public unlike Washington state fish farmers who are seen as a threat by environmental groups.
Ames stressed, however, that Maine salmon farmers face tough competition from Chile, Norway and other countries. He said the state's science community has a role to play in developing and securing new marine-related industries.
"We need a marine science map of Maine to know where the marine institutions are and who can do what," he said. "We cannot survive on salmon alone. We need other species to grow."
UM's Long promoted biotechnology as a means to diversify and strengthen Maine fisheries. He is also chairman of the board of a South Carolina biotechnology company that uses marine microorganisms to produce the pink coloring that is injected into pen-raised salmon.
"I think the biggest opportunity and need is to have more effective management," he said. "Having more research is very important."
Joe McGonigle, director of the Maine Aquaculture Association, pointed out Maine's aquaculture industry generates the most revenue after lobster yet the United States is light-years behind the world's leading producers of pen-raised salmon.
"Our nation is a Third World country when it comes to aquaculture," he said. "I think it's because the money isn't there."
McGonigle said Maine's aquaculture industry is exploring other species such as cod, halibut and sea urchins, but the state needs to catch up with innovations just over the border in New Brunswick. He noted the Canadian salmon producer Connors Brothers Ltd., which produces the herring-based feed given to pen-raised salmon.
McGonigle warned that one formidable obstacle lies ahead in the expansion of Maine's salmon industry. He fears speculative environmental concerns about the interaction of wild and farmed species could hurt the industry.
"One of these ocean pens is going to tip or rip, and some of those fish are going to escape," he said. "Much of the concern {about genetic interaction} is speculative. Many of the wildlife scientists have been trained to ask what could happen. That is something that fundamentally has to change."

Renewing the Civilized Dinner Potpies harken back to a time when gentlemen would congregate for a filling meal at their clubs

Author: Cheryl A. Wixson Special to the NEWS

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]03 Mar 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413872584?accountid=10457

Abstract: My feelings about eating are influenced by the season, the weather, my disposition and any other elements of the day. I want to feel good when I dine. In March, as the daylight lingers later in the afternoon and the blustery winds blow, what takes the chill off and makes me feel good are pot pies. The pot pie is a homey, functional dish that may evoke recollections of a calico-aproned grandma in a warm, cozy kitchen thriftily recreating yesterday's leftovers. But my associations with pot pies include gentlemen of the business world sitting at linened tables set with fine china, and chefs in tall white hats and checked pants, who, at the waiter's notice, slip an egg-washed pastry of goodness into a hot oven and pull out an aromatic, golden-crusted furl of flavor. [Charles] Fuller's recipe for Lobster and Oyster Pie -- individual pies for restaurants and clubs -- calls for "blanched oysters and lobster meat in equal quantities, a thick lobster sauce thinned with a little oyster liquor, individual pie dishes with the lobster and oysters, moistened with the sauce, strewn with chopped parsley, covered with puff paste, egg washed and backed -- a rattling good selling dish."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Renewing+the+Civilized+Dinner+Potpies+harken+back+to+a+time+when+gentlemen+would+congregate+for+a+filling+meal+at+their+clubs&amp;author=Cheryl+A.+Wixson+Special+to+the+NEWS&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-03-03&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: When once asked to define the meaning of regional cuisine, my simple reply was "what you feel like eating." Perplexed looks indicated that perhaps eating for those who posed the question -- as for many of us -- had become more a necessary function of life, not a moment of joy.
My feelings about eating are influenced by the season, the weather, my disposition and any other elements of the day. I want to feel good when I dine. In March, as the daylight lingers later in the afternoon and the blustery winds blow, what takes the chill off and makes me feel good are pot pies.
The pot pie is a homey, functional dish that may evoke recollections of a calico-aproned grandma in a warm, cozy kitchen thriftily recreating yesterday's leftovers. But my associations with pot pies include gentlemen of the business world sitting at linened tables set with fine china, and chefs in tall white hats and checked pants, who, at the waiter's notice, slip an egg-washed pastry of goodness into a hot oven and pull out an aromatic, golden-crusted furl of flavor.
In all the years I ran the Tarratine Club, my grandest feeling was when the daily luncheon specials I placed on the menu would sell out. Pot pies would every time.
Just recently I discovered a "Culinary Handbook" published in 1904 for the Chicago restaurant trade. Charles Fuller, the gourmand and author, detailed 15 recipes for savory pies, including beef, chicken, blackbird, pigeon, veal and oyster, and rabbit.
Fuller's recipe for Lobster and Oyster Pie -- individual pies for restaurants and clubs -- calls for "blanched oysters and lobster meat in equal quantities, a thick lobster sauce thinned with a little oyster liquor, individual pie dishes with the lobster and oysters, moistened with the sauce, strewn with chopped parsley, covered with puff paste, egg washed and backed -- a rattling good selling dish."
At the turn of the century, the growth of the railroads gave birth to America's fine restaurants. Produce and ingredients, once only available in certain regions of the country during specific seasons, became accessible to first-class culinary institutions. The beginning of the industrial revolution was a time of great prosperity, and Fuller urged his compatriots to "celebrate good times in a great land, land of grain, meat and vegetables, with food that cannot be surpassed anywhere."
In the kitchen of 1904, particularly the catering fraternity, the preparation of food was not taken lightly. Ranks of chefs and kitchen help would bone carcasses, make stock, wash and chop vegetables, and bake pastries. The laborious results of these properly run kitchens -- always by men -- would be food enjoyed both as nourishment and entertainment.
Gentlemen would congregate daily at their "club," not to grab a quick bite to eat, but to dine. They would check their hats and workday at the door, and enjoy the camaraderie of their fellow club members as well as a finely prepared hot meal. After rousing political discussions, perhaps even a hand or two of cards, they would return to their business, invigorated.
As the information-age revolution ushers in a new century, perhaps it's time to renew our culinary heritage and return to some civilized dining. With a little extra planning, and a collection of recipes and pastry dishes, we could check our hectic and fragmented lifestyles at the door, and enjoy our families and the luxury of a relaxing eating experience with a savory pot pie.
The individual components of Asparagus Pastry may be prepared a day or two early and stored in the refrigerator. When ready to dine, simply assemble the tart and bake. This is a delicious accompaniment to roast beef, or a delectable first course in an elegant meal.
Asparagus Pastry
For the crust: 2 cups flour 2/3 cup butter Salt 1 tablespoon sugar
Sift together flour, sugar and a good pinch of salt. With a pastry blender or in a food processor, cut in the butter until the mixture resembles coarse sand. Add no water. Work into a ball, wrap and chill for an hour or more. Press into buttered 10-inch pie dish or tart pan with your fingers until you have a smooth crust of even thickness. Bake in preheated 375-degree F. oven until just brown, about 20 minutes.
For the filling: 2 pounds asparagus 1 1/2 cups rich Bechamel sauce 2 ounces grated Swiss or Gruyere cheese
Clean and peel the ends of the asparagus and cut into 1-inch pieces. Steam until tender (about 10-15 minutes, depending upon age of asparagus -- only testing will tell). Put the asparagus in the pie shell, pour the Bechamel sauce over it, sprinkle with cheese, and put into medium-hot oven -- 400 degrees F. -- until brown on top. Serve hot.
Bechamel sauce: 2 tablespoons butter 2 tablespoons flour 2 shallots, minced 1 1/2 cups hot milk Peppercorns Thyme Bay leaf Salt Grated nutmeg
In a glass bowl in the microwave, heat the butter on medium setting until melted. Add the chopped shallots and cook on low heat for three minutes. Whisk in the flour, then whisk in the hot milk. Cook on medium-low and whisk until thickened. Add a few peppercorns, the bay leaf, nutmeg, salt and thyme. Cook on low for about five minutes. Strain through a sieve.
For Sunday dinner, I often roast a top-round or eye-of-the-round of beef that has marinated overnight in red wine and garlic. With the leftover meat and red-wine gravy from Sunday's dinner, I make Beef Pot Pies.
Beef Pot Pies
2 cups peeled and cubed potato 1 cup carrots 1 cup sliced celery
Cover vegetables with water and simmer with 2 bay leaves until vegetables are just tender.
1 cup frozen peas
1 cup sliced leeks, sauteed in 1 tablespoon butter
1/4 cup chopped, fresh parsley
2 cups rare roast beef, trimmed and cubed
2 cups gravy
1/2 batch Bakewell Cream biscuit dough or
2 sheets puff pastry (available in frozen section of
supermarket)
Drain vegetables and mix with leeks, peas, meat and gravy. Add 1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley. Salt and pepper to taste. Spoon mixture into buttered casseroles. Cover with puff pastry or biscuit dough. Bake in preheated 375 degree F. oven until bubbly and crust is golden. Makes 8-10 pies.
When chicken is on sale at the supermarket, buy one to make the filling for Chicken Pot Pies. Individually wrapped fillings will keep in the freezer along with the puff pastry. They will make an elegant supper when you are pressed for time. Serve the pies with fresh broccoli and cheese sauce, or sliced tomato and lettuce salad with bottled French dressing.
Chicken Pot Pies
One 3-4 pound broiler 1/4 cup flour 4 cups chicken stock 1/3 cup cold water 1/2 cup fresh lemon juice 1 sheet puff pastry 3 bay leaves Salt and pepper to taste 1 egg white
Cook chicken with stock, lemon juice and bay leaves in large pot until thermometer registers 170 and the chicken is starting to fall off the bone. Remove chicken to platter to cool. Strain cooking liquid and chill. Pick meat from bones and cut into chunks. Remove fat from reserved stock and measure out four cups into saucepan and bring to a boil. Whisk 1/4 cup of flour in 1/3 cup cold water until smooth. Whisk into simmering stock and cook until thickened. Whisk in 2 tablespoons heavy cream, and add salt and pepper to taste. In a large bowl, combine chicken with gravy. Grease six 550s (Hall casserole dishes). Spoon in chicken and sauce. Top with puff pastry and brush the top with beaten egg white. Bake pies in preheated 375 degree F. oven until bubbly and crust is golden brown, about 20 minutes.
Illustration Caption: Potpies were once a club man's lunch and were developed for the train industry. Asparagus and chicken are the main ingredients in two of the featured potpies. (NEWS Photos by Susan Latham)

Clamming takes a hit

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]28 Feb 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413829057?accountid=10457

Abstract: Brian Beal is right on target about Maine's clamming industry being under attack {BDN commentary, Feb. 15-16}. Clamming has taken a big hit over the last decade due to a natural down cycle in clams, overdigging, and clam flat closures, due partly to the federal government's one-size-fits-all standard for interstate shipping of all shellfish. Also, the understaffed, underfunded Department of Marine Resources' inability to keep up with the demand for water monitoring and shoreline surveys necessary to reopen clam flats.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Clamming+takes+a+hit&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-02-28&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Brian Beal is right on target about Maine's clamming industry being under attack {BDN commentary, Feb. 15-16}. Clamming has taken a big hit over the last decade due to a natural down cycle in clams, overdigging, and clam flat closures, due partly to the federal government's one-size-fits-all standard for interstate shipping of all shellfish. Also, the understaffed, underfunded Department of Marine Resources' inability to keep up with the demand for water monitoring and shoreline surveys necessary to reopen clam flats.
Recently, some positive changes have been occurring, particularly brought about by volunteers at the local level with DMR support. Sen. Marge Kilkelly's bill to do away with town laws would be a disaster for the industry. I believe in as much local control over our lives as we can get. The Kilkelly bill will end that for clamming. All the great efforts by volunteers up and down the coast to get flats open under local management plans will go down the tubes.
I've been digging for 40 years and I see this bill as a wakeup call for those of us who want to make a living clamming and are concerned about the future. I loved the freedom to dig where I wanted to in the good old days, before town laws, but those days are gone. Clammers have always been the most individualistic and disorganized in the Maine fisheries but now threats to the industry demand a change. Some good work is going on to create a clam advisory council and I'm hopeful that can help. But I feel strongly that we diggers need more than that; we need a statewide diggers association which can have some organization and unity. A strong voice that will be heard in Augusta. Peter Hope Thomaston

Maine Coastal Program seeking volunteers

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]26 Feb 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413829481?accountid=10457

Abstract: The Maine Coastal Program needs volunteers for the Penobscot Bay Marine Program, which offers 20 residents of the region five weeks of training in marine and coastal topics.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Maine+Coastal+Program+seeking+volunteers&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-02-26&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: AUGUSTA -- The Maine Coastal Program needs volunteers for the Penobscot Bay Marine Program, which offers 20 residents of the region five weeks of training in marine and coastal topics.
In return, the volunteers perform 30 hours of work in community service projects in the Penobscot Bay region and meet each month for additional training. Training will be held Tuesdays and Thursdays, beginning in early May. Topics include marine ecology, coastal geology, fisheries science, shellfish management, maritime history, and water quality.
Courses are taught by naturalists, marine biologists, coastal geologists, fish and wildlife biologists, and historians. The type of community service project is left up to the individual to choose, but Atlantic salmon restoration, education programs at a fish hatchery and in school classrooms, watershed survey, water quality monitoring, coastal cleanup, and interpretive walks are all areas where service can be done.
For information, call Laura Taylor or Steve Cole at 287-3261.

Clam diggers oppose bill to halt direct sales Move aimed at controlling quality of seafood

Author: Letitia Baldwin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]19 Feb 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413900203?accountid=10457

Abstract: Maine clam diggers from Boothbay to Stonington urged lawmakers to reject a bill Tuesday they say would rob them of the right freely to market their day's harvest and give shellfish dealers control over their livelihoods. The bill, sponsored by Sen. Jill Goldthwait, I-Bar Harbor, would prohibit commercial shellfish license holders from selling directly to restaurants or other retail businesses. Harvesters would be allowed to sell only to certified seafood dealers or consumers. The latter would require a state Department of Agriculture permit. Brent Perkins, a clam digger representing shellfish councils in Boothbay, Boothbay Harbor, Edgcomb, Newcastle and Damariscotta, dismissed the bill as a ploy by shellfish dealers to get control of the market. He said clam diggers rely on being able to sell to restaurants when shellfish dealers are not buying.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Clam+diggers+oppose+bill+to+halt+direct+sales+Move+aimed+at+controlling+quality+of+seafood&amp;author=Letitia+Baldwin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-02-19&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: AUGUSTA -- Maine clam diggers from Boothbay to Stonington urged lawmakers to reject a bill Tuesday they say would rob them of the right freely to market their day's harvest and give shellfish dealers control over their livelihoods.
Supported by the Maine Department of Marine Resources, LD 409 is aimed at protecting consumers from tainted seafood.
The bill, sponsored by Sen. Jill Goldthwait, I-Bar Harbor, would prohibit commercial shellfish license holders from selling directly to restaurants or other retail businesses. Harvesters would be allowed to sell only to certified seafood dealers or consumers. The latter would require a state Department of Agriculture permit.
Brent Perkins, a clam digger representing shellfish councils in Boothbay, Boothbay Harbor, Edgcomb, Newcastle and Damariscotta, dismissed the bill as a ploy by shellfish dealers to get control of the market. He said clam diggers rely on being able to sell to restaurants when shellfish dealers are not buying.
"I have dug millions and millions of clams, bushels upon bushels ..." he said. "I don't see where the sanitation issue comes in. Don't let them pull the sanitation wool over your eyes."
"The dealers are going to take over the industry," Stonington clam digger Robert Ray charged. "The only people who are going to lose is everybody but the dealer."
"These dealers are trying to snow you. Use your own common sense," Ed Miller, a retired, longtime clam digger from Bremen, urged legislators.
DMR Commissioner Robin Alden spoke out in favor of the bill, explaining that Maine shellfish laws do not fully comply with the rules of a nationwide group, the Interstate Shellfish Sanitation Conference, which sets standards for states shipping and receiving shellfish.
If Maine fails to comply, Alden said, Maine shellfish dealers could lose the right to ship out of state. She added that more stringent federal laws are also scheduled to take effect next year.
"If our program does not meet the standards set by the conference," she warned, "our entire ability to sell shellfish out of state could be jeopardized."
Maine shellfish dealers echoed the commissioner.
Lori Howell, vice president of Spinney Creek Shellfish in Eliot, said certified shellfish dealers are subject to and have gone to great expense to comply with current federal health and sanitary regulations.
Unless Maine tightens its shellfish regulations, Howell said, the state's shellfish dealers could lose their certification through the conference. She said that status entitles them to ship out of state and abroad.
Much of Maine's harvested clams and mussels are shipped out of state especially in the summer when demand and prices are high.
"If Maine loses its certification, that means you can't ship product out of state," Stephen Beathem, plant manager and clam buyer at Maine Shellfish Co. in Ellsworth, told legislators.
Losing those out-of-state markets, Beathem said, would have a devastating impact on Maine's economy.
"If Maine loses its certification, 50 percent of all clam harvesters will be out of work and the harvest diminished in value between 30 and 50 percent," he predicted.

Committee set to hear fisheries measures Territory extension among proposed bills

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]17 Feb 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413863386?accountid=10457

Abstract: At least one of three fisheries-related bills the Legislature's Marine Resources Committee will hear Tuesday is actually considered popular with Down East fishermen. The first, LD 276, is "An Act to Extend the Territorial Waters to 12 Miles for the Purpose of Marine Resource Protection and the Enforcement of Marine Resource Laws." Submitted by District 129 Rep. Paul Volenik of Brooklin, the bill expected to enjoy popular support addresses the problem of out-of-state fishermen sitting three miles off the Maine coast, taking female and off-sized lobsters that Maine fishermen must throw back due to the state's relatively restrictive conservation laws.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Committee+set+to+hear+fisheries+measures+Territory+extension+among+proposed+bills&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-02-17&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: AUGUSTA -- At least one of three fisheries-related bills the Legislature's Marine Resources Committee will hear Tuesday is actually considered popular with Down East fishermen.
Public hearings on the bills will be held at 1 p.m. Tuesday, Feb. 18, in Room 113 of the State Office Building in Augusta.
The first, LD 276, is "An Act to Extend the Territorial Waters to 12 Miles for the Purpose of Marine Resource Protection and the Enforcement of Marine Resource Laws."
Submitted by District 129 Rep. Paul Volenik of Brooklin, the bill expected to enjoy popular support addresses the problem of out-of-state fishermen sitting three miles off the Maine coast, taking female and off-sized lobsters that Maine fishermen must throw back due to the state's relatively restrictive conservation laws.
"That is a huge issue for fishermen and for us in that, although we can enforce our laws on Maine vessels outside three miles, we can't for other vessels," said state Sen. Jill Goldthwait, chairwoman of the Marine Resources Committee.
"This bill, frankly, is probably not going anywhere because of legal issues" involving the federal government, said Goldthwait. However, a draft proposal by the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission may result in Maine, New Hampshire and Massachusetts sharing joint control up to 30 miles offshore, she said.
A second hearing will focus on LD 409, "An Act Concerning Commercial Marine Fishing Licenses." Sponsored by the Department of Marine Resources, the bill would restrict commercial shellfish license holders to selling only to shellfish dealers or to actual consumers of the product. The idea is to ensure that tainted seafood can be traced back to a harvester for public safety's sake.
"It's probably a bill that dealers will love and harvesters will hate," said Goldthwait.
The third bill, LD 500, is "An Act to Protect Near-shore Groundfish Spawning Areas." The measure would identify spawning areas, and restrict fishing there. A similar bill failed last year when it was decided that more scientific information was needed for proper enforcement.
"In theory, protection of spawning areas is important to preserving fish stocks," said Goldthwait. A downside is that all fishermen could be restricted in such an area, regardless of whether they sought to harvest the spawning species.
The proposed bill also would affirm DMR Commissioner Robin Alden's authority to redesignate spawning areas as they fluctuate, a right Goldthwait said Alden already holds.
Stonington lobsterman Richard Parke said Sunday that such a law would be one more opportunity for Alden to "abuse her powers." Parke already has filed a lawsuit against Alden, protesting her decision in December to allow a seaweed cultivation operation amid traditional fishing grounds in the Bagaduce River near Castine.
Three public hearings on bills regarding fishing for elvers, or young eels, will be held at 2 p.m. Thursday, Feb. 20, in Room 113 of the State Office Building.
The first, LD 353, "An Act to Improve Management of the Elver Fishery," would prohibit the setting of fyke nets out of season and prohibit fishing the middle third of streams. Fyke nets are long bag nets kept open by hoops.
The second, LD 315, "An Act to Amend Laws Regarding Fees Charged in the Elver Fishery," would reduce fees to $50 per net.
The third, LD 528, "An Act Concerning Elver Fishing and Dip Nets," would limit fishing for young eels to that type of net.
Those unable to attend this week's hearings are asked to call or write committee members with their comments.

Winning Performance Turning a fat trick

Author: Larry Mahoney Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]17 Feb 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413831100?accountid=10457

Abstract: University of Maine hockey teammates Scott Parmentier and Shawn Wansborough had their eyes glued to the menu at the McDonald's in the Bangor Mall recently. Parmentier began the University of Nebraska football team's diet last summer and Wansborough, Parmentier's roommate, decided to follow the diet two months ago. For example, it lists low-fat foods that are the best choice for protein (for example, 95 percent lean ground beef or turkey; white meat tuna fish in water; fat-free cheese; 95 percent lean encased meats; and skim milk); foods that are considered second choice for protein (85 percent lean ground beef or turkey; dark meat tuna in water; low-fat cheese; 85 percent lean reduced fat encased meats; and 2 percent milk) and those considered third choice for protein, which dieters are urged to restrict.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Winning+Performance+Turning+a+fat+trick&amp;author=Larry+Mahoney+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-02-17&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: University of Maine hockey teammates Scott Parmentier and Shawn Wansborough had their eyes glued to the menu at the McDonald's in the Bangor Mall recently.
It wasn't that they needed to be reminded of the choices. They probably know the menu by heart.
What they were doing was trying to convince each other to enter the Cocoon of Calories; the Lair of Lard; the Farm of Fat.
Parmentier began the University of Nebraska football team's diet last summer and Wansborough, Parmentier's roommate, decided to follow the diet two months ago.
"It seemed everything Scott ate was a minimum of 99 percent fat-free. I felt guilty because I wasn't watching what I ate," said Wansborough. "Plus, the way he's been scoring this season, I figured it couldn't hurt."
Parmentier scored 19 goals through Maine's first 29 games to lead the team in that category. Parmentier had played in just 24 of the 29 games due to injury.
Getting back to McDonald's, Wansborough said the two of them gazed at the menu for 15 minutes.
"I'd say, `I'll get an Arch Deluxe if you do,"' said Wansborough.
Some friends from school eventually joined them.
"They were laughing at us," said Parmentier.
Despite the temptation, Parmentier and Wansborough, both juniors, eventually walked away without placing an order.
The Nebraska football diet is flexible and involves listing preferred foods for each nutritional requirement.
For example, it lists low-fat foods that are the best choice for protein (for example, 95 percent lean ground beef or turkey; white meat tuna fish in water; fat-free cheese; 95 percent lean encased meats; and skim milk); foods that are considered second choice for protein (85 percent lean ground beef or turkey; dark meat tuna in water; low-fat cheese; 85 percent lean reduced fat encased meats; and 2 percent milk) and those considered third choice for protein, which dieters are urged to restrict.
The third choice protein list would call for 75 percent lean ground beef, fried fish or seafood, regular cheese and whole milk.
The same type of listing is done for carbohydrates. There is a list of foods that provide good sources of vitamin E (almonds, salmon, sardines, mackerel, trout, clams, oysters and scallops); vitamins A and C (tomatoes, dark salad, grapefruit, winter squash); vitamin C (oranges, pineapple, raisins); and vitamin A (green peas, leaf lettuce, peaches, skim milk, yogurt).
Parmentier points out that the diet doesn't work by itself -- it must be used in conjunction with an ambitious exercise regimen.
"You can't have one without the other," said Parmentier, who works out religiously, as does Wansborough.
They adhere to Maine assistant coach Grant Standbrook's training program.
They both admit that junk food had been a staple of their diets.
"I used to love Burger King. I still do," said Parmentier. "I used to eat there all the time."
"And we also spent a lot of time at McDonald's for a while there," acknowledged Wansborough.
Nowadays, a typical Parmentier menu consists of three or four bowls of Special K cereal in skim milk for breakfast along with V8 juice and a fat-free grilled cheese sandwich; a lunch of four tuna and mustard sandwiches on Italian bread with V8 juice; and a dinner of rice covered with fat-free spaghetti sauce and fat-free cheese.
Another day, the dinner could consist of fat-free hot dogs.
A Wansborough breakfast will include Total Raisin Bran, scrambled Egg Beaters and English muffins; his lunch could very well be boneless chicken breasts and a bowl of cereal; and his dinner could be homemade pizza with fat-free cheese and low-fat sauce. A protein shake may accompany dinner.
He figures he eats 8 ounces of chicken a day.
"Scott eats a lot of tuna fish," said Wansborough. "I wish I liked it. It's so cheap. But I hate it."
Wansborough supplements his diet with a lot of low-fat or fat-free yogurt. He also enjoys frozen yogurt.
They try to limit their fat intake to 60 grams per day.
The players admit they stray from their diets on the weekends, when they often have back-to-back games and need extra nutrition.
"On Thursday night, before a Friday game, we load up on anything," said Wansborough. "We try to get a lot of calories in us."
Pasta is a popular choice.
Both players have lost considerable weight and feel it has improved their performances.
"I went from being in the worst shape of my life last May to the best shape of my life now," said Parmentier, who has dropped 20 pounds and has already eclipsed his previous single-season high for goals by five.
Parmentier obtained a copy of the Nebraska football diet when he played for the Omaha Lancers in the United States Junior Hockey League before coming to Maine. He got it from University of Nebraska football booster Irv Dana.
Wansborough, who is Maine's second leading point-getter behind Steve Kariya, has gone from 200 pounds at the start of dry land training camp in September to 182 pounds now.
"I feel quicker. I don't know if I am. I feel better on the ice," said Wansborough.
"It has made a huge difference," said Parmentier. "I never feel tired anymore. I have a lot of energy and I feel stronger."
"They have decreased their body fat," said Maine hockey trainer Paul Culina. "They are able to work harder now due to the fuels their bodies have received. They are stronger and they have more endurance."
And they also have enough self-discipline to simply stare at the McDonald's menu instead of placing an order.
Illustration Caption: Scott Parmentier (Above, left) pours a shake of egg substitute and frozen yogurt as he and Shawn Wansborough sit down for a dinner of chicken, corn and a roll. Parmentier (below) is off to his best season, with 19 goals in 31 games. (NEWS Photos by Michele Stapleton)

Maine's clamming industry under attack

Author: Beal, Brian F

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]15 Feb 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413855332?accountid=10457

Abstract: For some reason, every few years Maine's clamming industry has to endure political attacks that, if successful, would completely eliminate local control of town-sponsored shellfish management ordinances in favor of a state-run syste. To date, thankfully, these incursions have failed. This year, the battle lines in Augusta are being drawn for an eventual fight over yet another legislative bill to reduce to shreds the already fragile fabric of Maine's clamming industry. The threat this time is being sponsored by Sen. Marge Kilkelly of Wiscasset who has indicated that residents of inland communities are essentially being shut out from making a living from clamming. Those coastal communities without management plans such as Milbridge, Gouldsboro, Lamoine, Castine, Deer Isle, Stonington, North Haven, Rockland, Portland, etc. have chosen to exercise no local control over their clamming resource. Anyone holding a state clamming license may harvest clams in these communities providing the areas are not contaminated with fecal coliforms. There is an economic incentive for a community to manage its clamming resource, however. In 1985, University of Maine resource economist, Ralph Townsend, examined the effect of restricting licenses on the economic welfare of harvesters. He concluded that yield per unit of effort was 15 percent higher in communities that managed their resource than in those that did not.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Maine%27s+clamming+industry+under+attack&amp;author=Beal%2C+Brian+F&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-02-15&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: For some reason, every few years Maine's clamming industry has to endure political attacks that, if successful, would completely eliminate local control of town-sponsored shellfish management ordinances in favor of a state-run syste. To date, thankfully, these incursions have failed. This year, the battle lines in Augusta are being drawn for an eventual fight over yet another legislative bill to reduce to shreds the already fragile fabric of Maine's clamming industry. The threat this time is being sponsored by Sen. Marge Kilkelly of Wiscasset who has indicated that residents of inland communities are essentially being shut out from making a living from clamming.
Sen. Kilkelly's bill ignores history and, more importantly, the resource. Since 1963, coastal communities with clamming habitat have had the option of managing their clamming resource. Today, approximately half of the 100 coastal towns have engineered their own management plan (shellfish ordinance) which is closely scrutinized by Maine's Department of Marine Resources (DMR).
Those coastal communities without management plans such as Milbridge, Gouldsboro, Lamoine, Castine, Deer Isle, Stonington, North Haven, Rockland, Portland, etc. have chosen to exercise no local control over their clamming resource. Anyone holding a state clamming license may harvest clams in these communities providing the areas are not contaminated with fecal coliforms. There is an economic incentive for a community to manage its clamming resource, however. In 1985, University of Maine resource economist, Ralph Townsend, examined the effect of restricting licenses on the economic welfare of harvesters. He concluded that yield per unit of effort was 15 percent higher in communities that managed their resource than in those that did not.
Today, Maine's clamming industry is struggling because of a downturn in clam flat productivity. In the decade between 1985 and 1995, statewide landings declined 56 percent from 283,000 bushels harvested to 124,000. Over that same time, state clam licenses dropped 60 percent from 4,141 to 1,668. The decline in landings has not occurred evenly across the state, however. Since 1985, landings have dropped by 75 percent in Washington County and by 84 percent in Hancock County. Historically, these two counties accounted for 45 percent to 65 percent of all clams harvested in Maine. Today, less than 30 percent of all clams landed in Maine come from these two eastern counties. The loss of jobs in the clamming industry is not for want of harvesters, but from lack of resource. No one can provide an unambiguous answer as to why production has fallen so dramatically, however.
Although production levels today are low, the silver lining is that the industry and groups that support clamming in Maine have stepped up to the plate like at no other time in history to counteract these declines. A few examples of the kinds of activities that have begun to invigorate the clamming industry serve to highlight these efforts.
The Maine Cooperative Extension and the Maine State Planning Office have teamed up to provided technical assistance and funds to teach local volunteer groups about monitoring water quality and conducting shoreline surveys in an effort to assist DMR with sampling that has led to the opening of thousands of acres of clam flats across the state.
The Gulf of Maine Council on the Marine Environment recently announced its visionary of the year award which went to Sherman Hoyt, coordinator for the Georges River Clam Fishery Restoration Project, for efforts to pull together five communities along that river to form a Georges River Shellfish Management Committee.
Hundreds of acres of flats closed for more than 30 years in Eastport were recently opened thanks to the effort of another visionary, Will Hopkins, who, together with clammers from nine communities surrounding Cobscook Bay have formed a clam restoration project there.
The industry sponsored a statewide clam meeting during the Fisherman's Forum last year and this year for the purpose of bringing together groups from around the state to meet and discuss management issues and strategies.
This spring, the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery will initiate a three-year, large-scale, clam culture program in three communities along the coast to demonstrate methods that will hopefully result in a sustainable fishery.
The Kilkelly bill assumes that these and the myriad of other similar efforts will continue and that people will be as interested in shellfish management and water quality issues after local control is lost. Nothing could be further from the truth. Volunteers, shellfish harvesters, shellfish committees, and local elected officials work hard to manage the resource and improve water quality today because they know there will be direct dividends for themselves and their neighbors. Once local control is extinguished, there will be no incentive to undertake these management activities.
Also, the bill assumes an unrealistic level of oversight for a statewide management program. Currently, only three DMR biologists work the entire coast to assist municipalities with shellfish management issues. Their job already requires an excessive amount of field, laboratory, and desk work, so, how could DMR manage all the clam flats in the state effectively when there is insufficient manpower to assist fully the 50 or so communities engaged in management efforts today?
The Kilkelly bill would be an economic catastrophe. It would significantly hamper or possibly eliminate the unbelievable efforts of Maine citizens to rebuild the clamming industry to production levels seen previously in the 1970s and early 1980s.
Brian F. Beal is assistant professor of marine ecology at the University of Maine at Machais.

Passamaquoddy men enter no plea in fishing violations Pair claim Maine laws violate aboriginal rights of tribe

Author: Diana Graettinger Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]05 Feb 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413865645?accountid=10457

Abstract: Two Passamaquoddy men charged last year with violation of Maine's saltwater fishing laws were arraigned in 4th District Court Tuesday but refused to enter pleas, claiming Maine law does not apply to them because it violates the tribe's sovereign aboriginal rights. Allie Beal, 37, of Perry was charged last year with taking sea urchins during a closed period and taking clams from a closed area in violation of Eastport's Municipal Shellfish Ordinance. In January he was charged with digging and taking clams in a closed area, again in violation of the Eastport ordinance. "They declined to enter pleas, challenging the jurisdiction of the court," Assistant District Attorney Paul Cavanaugh said Tuesday at his office. Cavanaugh said that following the rules of court, not guilty pleas were entered for the two men.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Passamaquoddy+men+enter+no+plea+in+fishing+violations+Pair+claim+Maine+laws+violate+aboriginal+rights+of+tribe&amp;author=Diana+Graettinger+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-02-05&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: CALAIS -- Two Passamaquoddy men charged last year with violation of Maine's saltwater fishing laws were arraigned in 4th District Court Tuesday but refused to enter pleas, claiming Maine law does not apply to them because it violates the tribe's sovereign aboriginal rights.
Allie Beal, 37, of Perry was charged last year with taking sea urchins during a closed period and taking clams from a closed area in violation of Eastport's Municipal Shellfish Ordinance. In January he was charged with digging and taking clams in a closed area, again in violation of the Eastport ordinance.
Also arraigned Monday was Donell Dana, 40, of Perry who in November was charged with taking scallops without a scallop boat license.
"They declined to enter pleas, challenging the jurisdiction of the court," Assistant District Attorney Paul Cavanaugh said Tuesday at his office. Cavanaugh said that following the rules of court, not guilty pleas were entered for the two men.
Attorney Norman Toffolon of Machias represented the two men, but documents filed with the court asked that attorney Bruce Clark of Robinsonville, New Brunswick, an expert on sovereignty issues, be granted permission to also represent the pair.
The attorneys for Beal and Dana filed a motion to dismiss and a 54-page document titled "Confederate Native Court" in which they claim that "newcomer" courts -- all state and federal courts including the U.S. and Canadian supreme courts -- do not have jurisdiction over the legal issues involved.
The papers claimed that only the traditional Passamaquoddy court, "not to be confused with the modern Passamaquoddy Court," has jurisdiction.
"Upon taking judicial notice of the suppression and genocide of the native people caused by the prematurely assumed jurisdiction of the newcomer courts ..." this native court declares:
Jurisdiction rests with the native courts.
Should newcomer courts take exception with the rights of a native court, a third party court should adjudicate the matter.
Newcomer courts or their governments are welcome to submit evidence, law or argument to the native court.
Last year, Beal challenged the court's jurisdiction over his right to drag for sea urchins in waters off Eastport.
At that time, 4th District Court Judge John Romei agreed to delay Beal's arraignment until February to allow the tribe and state to continue negotiations over what the tribe claims is its aboriginal right to unrestricted fishing in "traditional territorial seas," including waters from Point Lepreau, New Brunswick, to Castine.
Last year, Sample argued for the delay.
Sample said when the tribe signed the Maine Indian Claims Settlement in 1980, it did not relinquish its aboriginal fishing rights.
Cavanaugh said the state had the right to respond to the 54-page document filed on behalf of the defendants and that a tentative court date on the issue had been set for March 11.
One issue the court will have to decide, Cavanaugh said, is whether Canadian attorney Clark will be allowed to represent the tribal members. "It is unusual, but not unheard of to have out-of-state council for important criminal defendants. ... It is up to either Mr. Toffolon or Dr. Clark to demonstrate to the court under our rules that we should recognize another nation's bar registry," he said.
The assistant district attorney said he thought Clark had been invited to represent the two men because he is well-versed in sovereignty issues.
"Dr. Clark brought enlightening information to our cause," tribal legislative Rep. Fred Moore said from his office in Augusta Tuesday night.
Moore said negotiations with the state have been "on again, off again."

Signs of population crisis seen in Canadian lobster industry Fishermen taking too many, leaving too few, says oceanographer

Author: Chris Morris The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]31 Jan 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413834408?accountid=10457

Abstract: FREDERICTON, New Brunswick -- Consumer appetite and commercial greed may be creating a crisis in Canada's East Coast lobster fishery. The loudest warning is coming from New Brunswick, where lobster fishermen have reported a steady and significant decline in their catches after record hauls in the early 1990s. Fisheries Minister Bernard Theriault of New Brunswick has asked Ottawa to act on conservation measures recommended in 1995 by the federal Fisheries Resource Conservation Council.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Signs+of+population+crisis+seen+in+Canadian+lobster+industry+Fishermen+taking+too+many%2C+leaving+too+few%2C+says+oceanographer&amp;author=Chris+Morris+The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-01-31&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: FREDERICTON, New Brunswick -- Consumer appetite and commercial greed may be creating a crisis in Canada's East Coast lobster fishery.
There are unsettling signs the population of the upscale crustacean may be going the way of the homely cod.
And conservationists in Atlantic Canada worry that bickering between fishermen's organizations and foot-dragging by Ottawa could spell disaster.
The loudest warning is coming from New Brunswick, where lobster fishermen have reported a steady and significant decline in their catches after record hauls in the early 1990s.
Fisheries Minister Bernard Theriault of New Brunswick has asked Ottawa to act on conservation measures recommended in 1995 by the federal Fisheries Resource Conservation Council.
"We do not have time to waste," says Theriault.
The problem is simple: with the collapse of the East Coast groundfishery, much more effort has been focused on the Atlantic lobster, which is prized the world over as one of the great gastronomic treats.
There are about 10,000 full-time licensed lobster fishermen in Atlantic Canada. There are also numerous poachers -- a factor that can't be overlooked in trying to assess the state of the shellfish.
Jean-Claude Brethes, a University of Quebec oceanographer who helped write the 1995 council report, summed up the situation in simple terms.
"We are taking too much and leaving too little," Brethes said from his office in Rimouski, Quebec.
"The exploitation rate is very, very high -- sometimes as much as 80 to 85 percent. It's very high and egg production is very low."
Technology has also increased pressure on lobster populations, says Michael Belliveau of the Maritime Fishermen's Union in Shediac, New Brunswick -- the self-proclaimed capital of the lobster-fishing world.
The crustaceans used to be able to scurry to deeper waters when inshore fishermen came calling. But picturesque wooden traps have been replaced by metal models and today's fishermen come with electronic, lobster-detecting devices.
"There's less refuge for the lobsters when you can go farther out to fish and you can fish a lot faster and much more efficiently," said Belliveau.
Nobody is predicting disaster at this point, said Belliveau.
Fishermen throughout the region realize resources are under pressure. Belliveau said there is general agreement steps must be taken to protect the lobster.
Some fishery groups in New Brunswick and Nova Scotia have voted in favor of increasing minimum catch sizes for lobsters. The idea is to give smaller, younger ones a chance to reproduce at least once before going into the pot.
But there's a big market in Europe for the smaller lobsters, and Prince Edward Island fishermen oppose the idea of restricting their catches to larger lobsters.
Many lobster fishermen point out that the crustacean, like the snow crab, is a cyclical creature and say there is no need to panic when the cycle is on the downswing.
"There's almost an ideological rigidity to it in the sense that P.E.I. fishermen are dead set against size increases, whereas our New Brunswick fishermen tend to favor them," said Belliveau.
"So we believe we're on the side of conservation and the Islanders aren't. There are a lot of different reasons for that. You won't find a fisherman now openly against conservation, but they have different views as to how that can be achieved."
Lack of consensus is the main reason for asking Ottawa to move in and impose conservation.
"If the lobster fishery ever disappeared in the Maritimes, hundreds of communities would be devastated," said David Coon of the New Brunswick Conservation Council.
"Given the incredible importance of the fishery, the federal Department of Fisheries is going to have to take a strong role here. They're going to have come down on the side of conservation and make the necessary decisions."
Jacques Robichaud, a federal fisheries spokesman in Ottawa, said consultation is continuing with lobster fishers in hopes of achieving agreement on conservation strategies.
