A recipe for sea ducks that doesn't require a rock

Author: Hennessey, Tom

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]25 Jan 1997: PDA.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413839000?accountid=10457

Abstract: Here, my youngest offspring, Hope - so named because my wife and I hoped she was the last of the lot - comes to mind. Not long after she'd had her fill of Pablum, Hope became especially fond of black duck. So much so that when she saw ducks flying over the river, which flows behind our house, she would come running to tell me. Come to think of it, my oldest daughter, Julie, never had to be force-fed, either. On Saturday mornings, when the house often was saturated with the aroma of beans baking around partridge or woodcock breasts, she would sit on the stairs and cry because the meal wouldn't be ready until suppertime. Mainers, those girls, from stem to stern. But seeing as special mention has been made regarding waterfowl as table fare, let's draw a bead on sea ducks and their way-off-target reputation of being unfit to eat. Even though you may never have signed your name to a duck stamp, chances are you've heard the oft-recited recipe for cooking sea ducks: "Place the duck on a rock and cook in a hot oven for four hours - then throw the duck away and eat the rock." That, kind reader, is pure poppycock; an old wives' tale spouted assertively by people who, obviously, never tasted the thick, succulent breast meat of, let's say, a properly prepared eider duck. To prove that, I hereupon offer a recipe that will bag the common fallacy that sea ducks are "fish with feathers." To the contrary, sea ducks - eiders, scoters (coots), old squaws - are not fish eaters. The ducks feed on mollusks, i.e., mussels, whelks, periwinkles, the latter being a staple in the diets of black ducks that spend winters on salt water.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+recipe+for+sea+ducks+that+doesn%27t+require+a+rock&amp;author=Hennessey%2C+Tom&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-01-25&amp;spage=PDA&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: For the most part, people born and raised in this neck of the woods were introduced to game dinners soon after cutting teeth. It comes with the territory. Seldom, then, is anyone late for supper when the menu features venison or partridge breast or moose steaks or rabbit meat. Likewise, it's safe to say no one has to be called to the table twice when waterfowl such as Canada goose, black duck, teal, or wood duck is being served.
Here, my youngest offspring, Hope - so named because my wife and I hoped she was the last of the lot - comes to mind. Not long after she'd had her fill of Pablum, Hope became especially fond of black duck. So much so that when she saw ducks flying over the river, which flows behind our house, she would come running to tell me. Come to think of it, my oldest daughter, Julie, never had to be force-fed, either. On Saturday mornings, when the house often was saturated with the aroma of beans baking around partridge or woodcock breasts, she would sit on the stairs and cry because the meal wouldn't be ready until suppertime. Mainers, those girls, from stem to stern.
But seeing as special mention has been made regarding waterfowl as table fare, let's draw a bead on sea ducks and their way-off-target reputation of being unfit to eat. Even though you may never have signed your name to a duck stamp, chances are you've heard the oft-recited recipe for cooking sea ducks: "Place the duck on a rock and cook in a hot oven for four hours - then throw the duck away and eat the rock."
That, kind reader, is pure poppycock; an old wives' tale spouted assertively by people who, obviously, never tasted the thick, succulent breast meat of, let's say, a properly prepared eider duck. To prove that, I hereupon offer a recipe that will bag the common fallacy that sea ducks are "fish with feathers." To the contrary, sea ducks - eiders, scoters (coots), old squaws - are not fish eaters. The ducks feed on mollusks, i.e., mussels, whelks, periwinkles, the latter being a staple in the diets of black ducks that spend winters on salt water.
Before we begin marinating and slicing and simmering, however, understand that my reason for writing this unlikely column is double-barreled: to deep-six the aforementioned old wives' tale and to reduce the wasting of sea ducks, particularly eiders, occurring with the ever-increasing interest in sea-duck hunting. The season is long, October to mid-January, daily limits are generous - seven on eiders, four on coots - and because the ducks respond well to decoys, hunters usually have ample shooting opportunity. Unfortunately, not all of the ducks shot are being disposed of on dinner tables. Although the daily limit on old squaws is seven, the smaller sea ducks are seldom hunted.
Now, first things first. The recipe, "Sea Ducks Jerome," recently was sent to me by Clarissa Trasko of Penobscot. No stranger to rigging eider decoys, Clarissa hunts with her husband, Fred, a fisheries biologist at the Green Lake National Fish Hatchery in Ellsworth. Clarissa said she received the recipe from Fred Kircheis, a fisheries biologist with the Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife. Obviously, Fred isn't averse to visiting offshore gunning grounds in the darkest and coldest hour preceding dawn.
Although some women would sooner tell their age than part with favorite recipes, Clarissa said "fire away" when I suggested giving Sea Ducks Jerome a shot here. I trust the fisheries biologists won't feel they've been foul-hooked. Also, my apologies for any offense to Jerome.
Fillet the breast meat from several eiders. Marinate the meat for 48 hours in buttermilk contained in glassware or crockery. Afterward, cut the meat into strips. Melt one-quarter pound of butter in a large pan, add three tablespoons of red currant jelly, the juice of half a lemon, a teaspoonful of dry mustard, and one cup of bourbon.
Admittedly, pouring the latter into a pot may be painful, but, believe me, you won't regret it.
After bringing the mixture to a hard boil, reduce the heat to a simmer, add the meat and cook for three to five minutes, depending on how you like meat done.
The recipe doesn't call for it, but soaking the filleted breasts overnight in a pot containing cold water and a tablespoonful of baking soda will remove most of the blood from the meat, thereby reducing the "gamey" taste.
Admittedly, my culinary expertise does not extend beyond toasting English muffins and making instant coffee. However, my wife's abilities with pots and pans are impressive. Better yet, Nancy doesn't shy away from cooking whatever I bring home from the hills or, in this case, the ocean. So it was that a week or so ago she prepared Sea Duck Jerome.
Simply put, it was delicious; by far, the best serving of sea duck I ever stuck a fork into. Without hesitation, I would describe the tender, juicy flavor as similar to roast beef. Allowing, however, that individual tastes differ, I wouldn't expect everyone to give Sea Ducks Jerome such high rating. But I'm sure anyone who tries the recipe will agree that sea ducks have been greatly maligned as being unfit to eat.
After finishing the delectable meal, which was seasoned throughout with expressions of epicurean delight, Nancy asked, "Well, what do you think?" To which I replied, "I think it's too bad the sea duck season has ended."

Initiatives would help marine areas NOAA plan could curtail offshore fishing practices

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]25 Jan 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413820424?accountid=10457

Abstract: Growing concerns about the damage being done to aquatic habitat have spawned federal and state initiatives to protect the breeding grounds of fish, shellfish and other marine life. On Friday, the U.S. Department of Commerce's National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced a plan to identify, conserve and enhance essential marine areas, a plan that could sharply curtail fishing practices, such as dragging, that are seen as damaging to critical habitat. Also on Friday, Rep. Paul Chartrand, D-Rockland, said he will sponsor legislation this session that could lead to certain critical fish spawning grounds along the Maine coast being designated as marine ecological reserves closed to fishing.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Initiatives+would+help+marine+areas+NOAA+plan+could+curtail+offshore+fishing+practices&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-01-25&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- Growing concerns about the damage being done to aquatic habitat have spawned federal and state initiatives to protect the breeding grounds of fish, shellfish and other marine life.
On Friday, the U.S. Department of Commerce's National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced a plan to identify, conserve and enhance essential marine areas, a plan that could sharply curtail fishing practices, such as dragging, that are seen as damaging to critical habitat.
Also on Friday, Rep. Paul Chartrand, D-Rockland, said he will sponsor legislation this session that could lead to certain critical fish spawning grounds along the Maine coast being designated as marine ecological reserves closed to fishing.
NOAA's plan is the first step being taken to meet essential fish habitat protection mandates included in the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act approved by Congress last year. Its purpose is to reverse the decline in fish populations from Alaska to Maine and in the Gulf of Mexico.
Under the mandate, regional fisheries councils and the states must work with NOAA's National Marine Fisheries Service to identify the essential habitats of all species managed under federal guidelines, which include most finfish, shellfish and marine mammals.
Activities, primarily fishing practices, that damage essential habitat must be mitigated and areas designated as essential habitat also will be given special protection from harm that originates on land, such as pollution and sediment discharge.
In a prepared statement, D. James Baker, the undersecretary of commerce for oceans and atmosphere, said NOAA's plan is a response "to the American public's concern about the diminishing quantity and quality of our marine habitat. The fisheries service will be working closely with the regional fisheries management councils, coastal states and other partners to protect and enhance the habitat essential to the fisheries and other living marine resources under our stewardship."
Chartrand's bill is being submitted at the request of constituent Ron Huber, head of the environmental group Coastal Waters Project. It would require the Maine Department of Marine Resources to study the habitat requirements of commercially desirable finfish and shellfish in state waters and to delineate certain spawning sites as off limits to harvesting.
The establishment of marine reserves along the Maine coast to serve as protected fish nurseries has been talked about for decades -- NOAA proposed a midcoast marine sanctuary in 1983 with no results. Huber says "It's time to act. With the drastic decline in fish species we're seeing, common sense tells us we have to set some areas of the ocean aside to let these species recover, to let some part of the marine world simply be."
The midcoast sanctuary proposed by NOAA 14 years ago would have stretched from the tip of the St. George peninsula to Bath. Rather than designate one large block of ocean as a reserve, Huber says the DMR study his proposal requires probably would find a greater benefit to designating several small, specific spawning grounds as reserves.
"There have been excellent studies on the spawning grounds of cod and haddock in the Gulf of Maine. It's fairly easy to see from this work that there are clusters of shoals and ledges in Cobscook Bay and from Penobscot Bay south that could be tremendously productive fish nurseries if left alone. Setting aside one large area would be asking fishermen in that area to commit economic suicide. We don't want that. In other parts of the world where reserves have been created, in fact, you'll see fishermen clustered around the edges of the reserve as it pumps out fish. That alone should be a tantalizing prospect for fishermen," he said.

Company / organization: Name: National Oceanic & Atmospheric Administration--NOAA; NAICS: 924120

Sturgeons won't stymie project Migration habits shouldn't interfere with work on Kennebec River

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 Jan 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413918751?accountid=10457

Abstract: The migration habits of the endangered shortnose sturgeon will not interfere with two construction projects planned along the Kennebec River, according to researchers. Scientists found that thousands of sturgeons are spending the winter near an island above Merrymeeting Bay. The study commissioned by the DOT will not be completed until July, but the initial results indicate the projects can proceed without harming the shortnose sturgeons' existence in the river.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Sturgeons+won%27t+stymie+project+Migration+habits+shouldn%27t+interfere+with+work+on+Kennebec+River&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-01-24&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BATH -- The migration habits of the endangered shortnose sturgeon will not interfere with two construction projects planned along the Kennebec River, according to researchers.
Scientists found that thousands of sturgeons are spending the winter near an island above Merrymeeting Bay.
That's good news for the state Department of Transportation, which plans to replace the Carlton Bridge in Bath. Bath Iron Works is also planning an expansion.
The study commissioned by the DOT will not be completed until July, but the initial results indicate the projects can proceed without harming the shortnose sturgeons' existence in the river.
"If we had found the sturgeon were wintering at the Carlton Bridge site ... that would have knocked us for quite a loop," said Scott Rollins, who is overseeing the study for the DOT.
The study findings must be reviewed by the National Marine Fisheries Service, which enforces the Endangered Species Act, as well as the Army Corps of Engineers.
Last fall, the state hired Thomas S. Squires Jr., a state marine resources scientist, to conduct the sturgeon field study. The $30,000 study uses sonic tags or transmitters implanted in 15 sturgeons to track their movements.
Scientists already knew the Kennebec River's 7,000 to 10,000 sturgeons spend summers in the nearby Sasanoa River feeding off mollusks and large crustaceans. But they didn't know where the fish spent winters.
"It surprised me that the fish headed upriver and not down," Squires said.
Already, the DOT has made plans to modify its construction schedule on the bridge. Rollins said the contractor will not be able to work on the middle section of the new bridge between April 15 and Oct. 1. That will leave two-thirds of the river channel open to migrating sturgeons.
Sturgeons are most threatened now by overfishing.

R.I. tests faux reefs as habitat for lobsters

Author: The Boston Globe11 The Boston Globe

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 Jan 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413884088?accountid=10457

Abstract: JAMESTOWN, R.I. -- It doesn't look much like the cutting edge of science: a crane methodically picks up boulders and rocks from a barge and drops them into the chilly waters of Dutch Island Harbor on Narragansett Bay. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, using $270,000 from a legal settlement with the owners of the wrecked tanker World Prodigy, has begun building six artificial stone reefs where lobsters can hide. This spring, juvenile lobsters no more than 3 inches long will be delivered to their new home. The reefs, each measuring 30 feet by 60 feet under 15 feet of water, supply what marine biologists believe is the one missing ingredient for lobsters in Dutch Island Harbor, a rocky bottom. Lobsters are abundant a scant half-mile away, but virtually absent from the fine silt of Dutch Island Harbor.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=R.I.+tests+faux+reefs+as+habitat+for+lobsters&amp;author=The+Boston+Globe&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-01-24&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: JAMESTOWN, R.I. -- It doesn't look much like the cutting edge of science: a crane methodically picks up boulders and rocks from a barge and drops them into the chilly waters of Dutch Island Harbor on Narragansett Bay.
But if the experiment works, fishermen five years from now will be harvesting lobsters from these now lobsterless waters, and a 1989 oil spill that killed fish and shellfish by the thousands will be just an unhappy memory.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, using $270,000 from a legal settlement with the owners of the wrecked tanker World Prodigy, has begun building six artificial stone reefs where lobsters can hide. This spring, juvenile lobsters no more than 3 inches long will be delivered to their new home.
"What we are trying to do is mimic the natural ecosystems of Narragansett Bay," explained John G. Catena, the agency's project director. Larval lobsters only 2 weeks old "look for this type of rocky cobble habitat to protect them from predators."
The reefs, each measuring 30 feet by 60 feet under 15 feet of water, supply what marine biologists believe is the one missing ingredient for lobsters in Dutch Island Harbor, a rocky bottom. Lobsters are abundant a scant half-mile away, but virtually absent from the fine silt of Dutch Island Harbor.
A lot is at stake in the lobster experiment, in part because of a far more damaging spill in Rhode Island last January when the barge North Cape ran aground, spilling 828,000 gallons of heating oil into Block Island Sound.
While the World Prodigy spill killed an estimated 175,000 lobsters, federal officials believe the North Cape spill killed 1 million or more, leaving a trail of dead lobsters 3 feet wide and at least a mile long near Point Judith. As a result, Rhode Island's lobster industry was shut down for 13 weeks.
The federal government and lobstermen are still negotiating a damage settlement with North Cape owner Eklof Marine Corp. But if lobster flourish on the man-made reefs of Dutch Island Harbor, Eklof could be required to build many more of them to offset the damage from the 1996 spill.
"This is experimental. We don't even know if {the lobster} will stay. There are no fences," said Bob Smith, president of the 100-member Rhode Island Lobstermen's Association, who nonetheless supports the lobster reefs. "What comes from this will give us ideas of what to do" in the North Cape talks.
Officials from Boston's Central Artery project also are watching Dutch Island Harbor, sending a consultant to see the man-made reefs Tuesday. The Central Artery soon must build a rock-covered habitat for blue mussels in Boston Harbor to replace shellfish beds destroyed at Spectacle Island, where fill from the project is being deposited.
Over the years, government agencies periodically have dropped rocks onto the sea floor to improve conditions for the lobster industry, but, until now, they haven't monitored the results closely enough to know whether the effort pays off, Catena said.
In addition, some fishermen are skeptical as to whether hatchery-raised lobsters actually increase the overall lobster population or if they simply take over territory that would have been occupied by wild lobsters.
This time, working with researchers from the Sea Grant Program of the University of Rhode Island, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is leaving nothing to chance.
The 500 to 1,000 young lobsters that will be placed on the reefs annually over the next four years will have wires implanted into one leg, allowing researchers to track their movements and survival. The wires, which are detected by a magnetic scanner, function like a supermarket bar code, providing detailed information about each lobster.
Also, federal and university officials will place hatchery-raised lobsters on only three of the six reefs, allowing them to compare population growth. Kathleen Castro of the University of Rhode Island believes that many lobsters may move into the harbor on their own.

Forensic overload State medical examiner threatens to leave `sinking ship' without more funding

Author: Renee Ordway Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 Jan 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413838589?accountid=10457

Abstract: Dr. Henry Ryan never felt the need to take former House Speaker John Martin out for oysters and beer. That allows Ryan to hire the additional staff immediately, without waiting for the new budget in July. The actual annual cost for those two positions is $90,000, according to Attorney General Andrew Ketterer, whose department oversees the Medical Examiner's Office. Of the 950 cases assigned to the Medical Examiner's Office, about 250 bodies end up being autopsied by Ryan or [Kristin] Sweeney. By being selective, Ryan has reduced by 1,000 annually the number of cases being accepted by his office for review.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Forensic+overload+State+medical+examiner+threatens+to+leave+%60sinking+ship%27+without+more+funding&amp;author=Renee+Ordway+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-01-24&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BANGOR -- Dr. Henry Ryan never felt the need to take former House Speaker John Martin out for oysters and beer.
Though some of his colleagues across the country who work with vast budgets and ample staff have told him that a plateful of oysters and a pint of beer to the right lawmaker could go a long way toward solving the chief medical examiner's problem.
That problem, of course, being money.
The prestigious doctor's response to such advice is remarkably simple and unmistakably blunt.
"I don't need that crap."
Instead the state's chief forensic pathologist, who is nearing retirement, stood before the Appropriations Committee last week and took a more direct approach in his quest for funding.
"I won't continue to captain a sinking ship, and you won't find anyone else to either."
While the size of the medical examiner's office staff has not increased, the workload has. It's not that more people are dying or that there are more suspicious deaths requiring autopsies. The problem is everything else.
Lawyers, insurance companies, police departments and every statistics-gathering agency in the nation pound on the doors seeking information about the manner in which people die.
Ryan doesn't dispute the importance of the data-gathering portion of his work. Streamlining statistical data and ensuring proper documentation were among the goals when the Chief Medical Examiner's Office was established in 1968.
But perhaps no one imagined how overwhelming compiling such data would become. There are snowmobile groups that want the cause of death on each snowmobiler killed in the state. And suicide prevention groups who want information about every suicide. And so on.
Then of course there is civil litigation, even paternity suits, that require endless tests that have become increasingly expensive to perform.
Ryan made his point and the Appropriations Committee unanimously approved $33,445 for two new positions, a phone clerk and an officer manager, long sought for the office.
That allows Ryan to hire the additional staff immediately, without waiting for the new budget in July. The actual annual cost for those two positions is $90,000, according to Attorney General Andrew Ketterer, whose department oversees the Medical Examiner's Office.
"The problem is that it's very difficult to find qualified people for that job. I have one leaving at the end of this month and the other one was threatening to leave February 15 if he didn't get some help. I mean I could have had people driving around with dead bodies in their cars asking me what to do with them. What am I going to do, ship them out of state?" said Ketterer.
The appropriation is expected to be signed by Gov. Angus King without further inquiry, since the governor suggested that Ryan make the pitch for the positions to the committee.
Those positions actually were approved in 1989, but the paperwork, which was the responsibility of someone in the Attorney General's Office, did not get filed in time and Ryan lost his funding. The next year was the start of the state's budget crisis.
Now Ryan says that the office is in such turmoil that not only is his deputy medical examiner, Dr. Kristin Sweeney, leaving, but that he may well consider leaving much earlier than his planned retirement in a year and a half.
"I want to leave something with a foundation so 21 years doesn't go down the drain," Ryan told members of the Appropriations Committee.
Ryan took on the role of chief medical examiner in 1975 and is credited with building the system that exists today.
Ryan, who is nationally renowned in his field, says that his office has been chronically underfunded for years. His office staff includes himself, Sweeney who plans to leave her position at the end of this month for another job, two autopsy assistants and two clerks. He also oversees a contractual medical examiner's staff of 250, though the vast majority of those are not active.
The number of staff has not changed since 1979, with the exception of one additional autopsy assistant.
Contractual medical examiners are located throughout the state and are certified to perform external examinations of bodies, determine a cause of death and sign the death certificate.
They consult with Ryan or Sweeney on those cases, most of which involve routine deaths.
If the death is routine or expected and the deceased is under the care of a physician, that physician can sign the death certificate, such as in the case of a cancer victim.
More complicated cases are assigned to the Medical Examiner's Office for review.
Of the 950 cases assigned to the Medical Examiner's Office, about 250 bodies end up being autopsied by Ryan or Sweeney. By being selective, Ryan has reduced by 1,000 annually the number of cases being accepted by his office for review.
With limited resources, Ryan has had to learn to set priorities.
"If a man with a heart problem stands up, clutches his chest and shouts, `Elizabeth, I'm coming to join you. It's the big one' and subsequently drops dead, chances are I'm not going to waste the taxpayers' money performing an autopsy and a multitude of tests on the body. No matter what the insurance companies want," Ryan said.
But the requests from other groups or people bogs down the system. Many times those individuals want information that Ryan does not consider scientifically relevent.
"And most of them of course want the information right now," Ryan said.
Perusing four piles of files accumulated on his desk, Ryan flips through them dramatically.
"These are not autopsies. Nor are these or these or these," he shouts.
Viewing one more closely, he exclaims, "This is from an attorney who wants results from a blood test. It's a 1994 case, but he needs the information right now."
While he talks, his clerks meander in and out of the office sticking phone messages in front of him. Four or five pile up during the two-hour interview.
It's all become just a bit too complicated for this 58-year-old man, who passionately enjoys fishing, reading classics and attending Mass.
To Ryan, the office's most important responsibility is identifying contagious diseases, such as outbreaks of meningitis, E. coli or tuberculosis.
"In cases of unexplainable death in healthy young people, it is absolutely essential to get to the bottom of it," Ryan said, "first and foremost, to prevent further deaths."
In some of those cases, the search may turn up genetic problems, which are critical to identify so that the deceased's family can know about potential problems in other or future family members.
Advances in genetic science have fortunately allowed for more testing to better identify genetic deficiencies, but those tests are expensive and the cost comes directly from Ryan's budget.
Ryan's second priority is to the criminal justice system. It's simply not enough anymore for medical examiners to say the person died of a gunshot wound. It is imperative that the work be complete and well documented.
Police officers and prosecutors want to know the cause of death, the time of death, the distance from which the person was shot, whether there were powder burns on the body, the condition of surrounding tissue and so on.
Such cases often involve consultations with toxicologists, entomologists, anthropologists and other pathologists.
Ryan is meticulously thorough, a characteristic appreciated by those in law enforcement.
His commitment to such important tasks finds him up at 4 a.m. every day typing his own autopsy reports, or performing other types of paperwork. The clerical staff in his office is so overwhelmed by other duties that autopsy reports can take up to six weeks to get typed.
Ryan or Sweeney then must prepare for trial and testify in court of their findings. Doing so sets Ryan up for a barrage of sometimes senseless questions, especially by defense attorneys searching for acquittal.
During one murder trial, Ryan was being questioned by an aggressive attorney who repeatedly asked the doctor if it was possible that the murder victim committed suicide or died of a heart attack.
"I think five bullet wounds to the temple would rule out suicide," Ryan testified. "And I find it highly unlikely that he died of natural causes and then someone shot him five times in the head," as the defense attorney seemed to suggest.
Ryan went on to testify that he supposed he could not rule anything out, including the possibility that an elephant fell from the sky and fired the bullets into the man's head.
Ryan has not much use for the justice system, when trials appear more scripted for show than justice. Science has allowed for such advanced testing that questions are being answered today that would never have even been asked 10 years ago.
The Medical Examiner's Office also performs tests in cases that may not involve criminal prosecution, but civil litigation. Cases such as fatal car or snowmobile accidents or fire deaths.
In doling out his limited dollars, Ryan is careful where the money is spent. He won't, for example, perform autopsies on accident victims who obviously died of head trauma, simply because an insurance company wants to make sure that the driver did not suffer a heart attack before crashing into the tree.
He's not afraid to say no and for that he often takes criticism.
"I'm not willing to pay for the tests involved in the off chance it may make a difference in a civil case," he said.
But they are tough decisions and he gets tired of making them.
So does his esteemed Sweeney, who will leave to work for UNUM Corp. at the end of this month.
She will not miss wearing her accountant's hat on one side of her head and her physician-scientist hat on the other.
Take the case of a 1-year-old child who died mysteriously.
During the course of examination, Sweeney knew right away that she needed to take a look at possible genetic problems.
She reviewed the family history, did a standard autopsy, with routine specimen testing. She did blood tests, toxicologies and tissue examination.
She did a metabolic screening, which involves sending a blotter of dried blood to a reference lab where they test for 30 of the most common genetic metabolic diseases.
The entire time she was taking the samples, performing the tests and sending samples away for testing, the cash register in her head was ringing.
How far should she go to search for the cause of the child's death?
The tests finally indicated the child had a genetic defect that affected microscopic filaments within her cells. Those filaments are the source of the cell's energy. When they don't work right a person is vulnerable to a variety of diseases.
There were more tests that could have been done to try to identify the exact abnormality. Sweeney tested for the most common abnormality caused by the genetic deficiency and it came back normal.
Ideally she would have continued in her search. Realistically, she could not.
"These are important tests for the surviving family members, and the potential children they may have in the future," she said.
These are the judgment calls she no longer cares to make.
With the $33,000 appropriated to him, Ryan hopes to hire an office manager and a phone clerk. Despite all of the scientific technological advances in his field, Ryan's office does not yet have voice mail.
Sweeney's $94,000 a year salary remains in the budget, which will allow him to hire a new deputy chief or perhaps someone to replace himself.
He no longer enjoys the job much and it will depend on the circumstances of the qualified candidates on how long he stays.
"If during the interview process the candidate whom I think would make the best choice would rather come in as chief, I would certainly step down," Ryan said.
With any state agency, budgets are always tenuous. Ryan says his office can't continue to function unless more money becomes available to attract qualified pathologists.
The alternative is an unpleasant prospect to police officers and prosecutors.
"I would suspect if the office was unable to function, we would revert to a county by county system. You'll have police and prosecutors who no longer have a central department to deal with. The results of that would be death investigations that aren't good," said Dr. Edward David, a contractual deputy medical examiner and a Bangor neurologist.
Illustration Caption: Dr. Henry Ryan, Maine's chief medical examiner, stands in the autopsy room in his offices in Augusta. Ryan holds a jaw specimen (below) that was part of a practice disaster charting. (NEWS Photos by Scott Haskell) Dr. Henry Ryan works his way through a pile of paperwork on his desk in Augusta. (NEWS Photo by Scott Haskell)

Efforts to protect coast hailed NOAA gives Maine volunteers high marks

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]23 Jan 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413879411?accountid=10457

Abstract: Maine's volunteer-driven effort to clean up and protect its coast has earned kudos of the finest kind from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. NOAA, a branch of the U.S. Department of Commerce, issued its evaluation of the State Planning Office's Maine Coastal Program this week, citing "outstanding improvements" made in the program, and dishing out special praise for the high level of volunteer work being done in such areas as pollution and habitat surveys, coastal cleanups and historic preservation. The report comes on the 20th anniversary of the Maine Coastal Program and the 25th of the federal Coastal Zone Management Act, which charged NOAA with identifying nationwide coastal problems and setting goals to resolve those problems.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Efforts+to+protect+coast+hailed+NOAA+gives+Maine+volunteers+high+marks&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-01-23&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- Maine's volunteer-driven effort to clean up and protect its coast has earned kudos of the finest kind from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
NOAA, a branch of the U.S. Department of Commerce, issued its evaluation of the State Planning Office's Maine Coastal Program this week, citing "outstanding improvements" made in the program, and dishing out special praise for the high level of volunteer work being done in such areas as pollution and habitat surveys, coastal cleanups and historic preservation.
The report comes on the 20th anniversary of the Maine Coastal Program and the 25th of the federal Coastal Zone Management Act, which charged NOAA with identifying nationwide coastal problems and setting goals to resolve those problems.
A NOAA team toured the state last September, evaluating 17 coastal protection and improvement projects in operation from Wells to Lubec, which fall under the umbrella of the state program.
Projects singled out by NOAA as being especially beneficial to the health of the shore included the seven-town cooperative effort to protect the Damariscotta River estuary, a state program to train and certify local code enforcement officers in coastal zone management, and the Shore Stewards Partnership and the Penobscot Bay Marine Volunteer Program, which train local residents in water-quality monitoring and other coastal issues.
Noting that the efforts of hundreds of volunteers to improve the coastal environment have resulted in the direct economic benefit of reopening thousands of acres of shellfish flats previously closed to harvesting by pollution, John McLeod, leader of the NOAA evaluation team, said the "success of Maine's program can really be connected to the way the people who run the program have gotten coastal communities involved in helping the coast. When we see so many people doing so much for the coast, we know right away we have an outstanding program."
In its 25 years of administering the Coastal Zone Management Act, McLeod said NOAA has found "that a balance between using the coast and preserving its resources is critical to the health of the coast and even to a state's economy. Finding a balance really demands that communities get involved."
Paul Dest of the State Planning Office said Wednesday the sparkling report card "is very welcome, but the high praise has to go to the hundreds upon hundreds of volunteers in communities up and down the coast. Their work in just one area alone -- water-quality monitoring -- is invaluable in locating sources of pollution and in increasing the public's awareness of the great impact what we do on land has upon the marine environment."
Dest said the attention NOAA gave to the Damariscotta River project "is particularly noteworthy. The plan these seven communities developed has won several awards and is being used as a model across the country for watershed management. It's a great example of value of volunteerism and regional cooperation."

Clam flats reopening throughout state The openings preserve Maine traditions, save jobs

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]20 Jan 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/414003664?accountid=10457

Abstract: For a while it looked as though the clamming industry in Maine was in trouble, with flats being closed because of pollution and federal regulations. But now an army of clam diggers, local shellfish wardens and environmentalists battling to save the flats are beginning to have success. Throughout Maine, state officials reopened about 10,000 acres of clam flats in 1996. In Freeport, state regulators are expected to open 170 acres of flats in the next couple of months. The openings would make 98 percent of Freeport's clam flats available for clamming, up from 35 percent in 1991. Yarmouth plans at the end of this month to offer its first commercial clamming licenses in a decade.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Clam+flats+reopening+throughout+state+The+openings+preserve+Maine+traditions%2C+save+jobs&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-01-20&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PORTLAND -- For a while it looked as though the clamming industry in Maine was in trouble, with flats being closed because of pollution and federal regulations.
But now an army of clam diggers, local shellfish wardens and environmentalists battling to save the flats are beginning to have success. Throughout Maine, state officials reopened about 10,000 acres of clam flats in 1996.
"A lot of us felt for a while that we wouldn't have jobs," said Stan Burnham, who is 36 and has worked as a clammer on and off since he was 15. "But now clamming has a good future."
In Freeport, Falmouth, Yarmouth and towns all up and down the coast, the state is reopening clam flats that have been closed for years.
In Freeport, state regulators are expected to open 170 acres of flats in the next couple of months. The openings would make 98 percent of Freeport's clam flats available for clamming, up from 35 percent in 1991. Yarmouth plans at the end of this month to offer its first commercial clamming licenses in a decade.
Besides preserving Maine traditions, the openings save jobs. In 1995, 1,666 licensed clammers in Maine harvested about 150 million clams and sold them for more than $8 million.
The cleanup effort also benefits wildlife and anyone who swims in Maine's waters or eats any kind of seafood, because it ensures the waters are clean.
"Keeping water safe for clams keeps it safe for everything, from lobsters to children swimming on the beach," said Mick McGivaren, Freeport's shellfish warden.
Fecal coliform has caused most of the clam-flat closures. The bacteria found in human and animal waste leaches into the tidal flats from sewage pipes, outdated septic systems and farmers' fields. Eating clams contaminated with the bacteria makes people sick.
When coastal development in the 1980s increased the amount of pollution flowing into the flats, the federal Food and Drug Administration tightened clamming regulations, requiring lower pollution levels and more extensive clam-flat monitoring. As a result, clamming was illegal by 1991 on nearly 20 percent of the state's clam flats, an area covering about 350,000 acres.
The situation was even worse in heavily-developed areas such as Casco Bay, where half the clam flats were shut down by 1993.
At the same time, budget cuts made it nearly impossible for the state to do the extensive pollution-source surveys and water testing necessary to reopen flats. The Department of Marine Resources has only six field operators to monitor the entire Maine coast.
"We were placed behind the eight ball," said Paul Anderson, director of the state's shellfish sanitation program. "We needed help."
Local environmental groups and town governments stepped in with cleanup and water monitoring efforts. Because of their help, only about 13 percent of the state's clam flats remain closed.

____________________________________________________________

Toxicologist studies dioxin, fish

Author: Smith, Andrew

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]18 Jan 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413852636?accountid=10457

Abstract: A recent column appearing in a weekend edition of the Bangor Daily News spoke of the ubiquitous presence of dioxins in our environment and the need to consider other dietary sources of dioxin than fish or lobster tomalley ("Of dioxin, fish and hamburgers," by Dr. Marquita Hill, Jan. 4-5). As the state toxicologist responsible for recommending the issuance of fish and shellfish consumption advisories to Maine's risk managers, I would like to respond to this column out of concern that some readers may conclude that the current fish and shellfish consumption advisories are unnecessary. First, I want to emphasize that the Maine Departments of Human Services, Environmental Protection, Inland Fish and Wildlife, and Marine Resources have jointly issued consumption advisories urging women of childbearing age to abstain from consuming any lobster tomalley (the green stuff in the body of the lobster technically referred to as the hepatopancreas) taken from Maine coastal waters, or any fish taken from the Androscoggin River, Kennebec River below Skowhegan, and Penobscot River below Lincoln. Others are encouraged to limit their consumption from these waters. These advisories remain in effect. How is it, one might ask, the public health officials could determine it necessary to issue such consumption advisories if as Dr. Hill states, "lobster tomalley is a tiny source" of dioxin; and why is it, she asks, that "if most human exposure to dioxin comes from meat and dairy products, we only hear about fish?" It is because the intake of dioxin from consuming lobster tomalley and fish only appear to be small sources relative to say beef intake of dioxin, when one computes dietary intakes based on national average food consumption rates and national average background concentrations of dioxin (as was done in the 1994 EPA document cited by Dr. Hill). These national food consumption rates average together the behavior of people who consume very little of a given food with those who consume a lot, and everyone in between.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Toxicologist+studies+dioxin%2C+fish&amp;author=Smith%2C+Andrew&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-01-18&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: A recent column appearing in a weekend edition of the Bangor Daily News spoke of the ubiquitous presence of dioxins in our environment and the need to consider other dietary sources of dioxin than fish or lobster tomalley ("Of dioxin, fish and hamburgers," by Dr. Marquita Hill, Jan. 4-5). As the state toxicologist responsible for recommending the issuance of fish and shellfish consumption advisories to Maine's risk managers, I would like to respond to this column out of concern that some readers may conclude that the current fish and shellfish consumption advisories are unnecessary.
First, I want to emphasize that the Maine Departments of Human Services, Environmental Protection, Inland Fish and Wildlife, and Marine Resources have jointly issued consumption advisories urging women of childbearing age to abstain from consuming any lobster tomalley (the green stuff in the body of the lobster technically referred to as the hepatopancreas) taken from Maine coastal waters, or any fish taken from the Androscoggin River, Kennebec River below Skowhegan, and Penobscot River below Lincoln. Others are encouraged to limit their consumption from these waters. These advisories remain in effect.
Having said that, it is important to emphasize that we have not issued any type of advisory on eating lobster meat, as the concentration of dioxin in the meat tissue is considerably lower than concentrations in tomalley.
How is it, one might ask, the public health officials could determine it necessary to issue such consumption advisories if as Dr. Hill states, "lobster tomalley is a tiny source" of dioxin; and why is it, she asks, that "if most human exposure to dioxin comes from meat and dairy products, we only hear about fish?" It is because the intake of dioxin from consuming lobster tomalley and fish only appear to be small sources relative to say beef intake of dioxin, when one computes dietary intakes based on national average food consumption rates and national average background concentrations of dioxin (as was done in the 1994 EPA document cited by Dr. Hill). These national food consumption rates average together the behavior of people who consume very little of a given food with those who consume a lot, and everyone in between.
Use of average background dioxin concentrations in dietary foods ignores areas with higher contamination of dioxins due to known point discharges of dioxins into the environment (e.g., paper mill wastewater effluent). These national estimates of average dioxin intake are important information to be used in assessing national population exposure and health risks. It is not necessarily the appropriate information for states to use when determining the need for consumption advisories to protect those individuals who consume more fish or shellfish than the average person, who happen to consume fish or shellfish with higher than average concentration of dioxins, or who happen to be uniquely sensitive to the toxic effects of dioxin.
The issuance of fish and lobster tomalley consumption advisories in Maine results from the fact that moderate levels of consumption of these foods (a meal a week) when taken from the above mentioned waters reults in dioxin intake above amounts at which we become concerned about the potential for developmental and reproductive toxicity. When assessing the potential for developmental or reporductive toxic effects, toxicologists have to consider the possibility that short-term exposure to a toxicant may be all that is needed to cause a toxic effect. This is because there are critical windows during pregnancy when the developing fetus in uniquely sensitive to chemical insult. Thus, when assessing the need for fish or shellfish consumption advisories, it is prudent public health policy to consider the possibility that some women of chilbearing age may ingest a number of fish or tomalley meals over a relatively short period of time (consider the pregnant woman on vacation in Maine duirng the summer). Over these shorter periods of time, intake of dioxin from lobster tomalley and fish can be the major sources of dietary exposure.
That we have not issued consumption advisories for meat or dairy products does not mean that these dietary sources are of no concern -- they may be, if further study confirms that limited initial data on levels of dioxins in these other dietary foods. However, it is worth noting that nutritional advice given to the public by state and federal health agaencies for prevention of cardiovascular disease and cancer (i.e., limit intake of meats and dairy products with high fat content and when eating meat, eat lean cuts) fortuitously also has the benefit of reducing intake of dioxins, as these chemicals accumulate in fatty tissues. I also want to emphasize that our current focus on fish and shellfish as dietary sources of dioxin does not mean people whould decrease their consumption of fish. Rather, the advisories are only urging people to avoid consuming fish from selected waters. Eating fish is good for you, and is to be encouraged -- another bit of nutritional advice given by public health agencies. Notably, the limited data on open ocean fish suggest dioxin contamination levels are low.
While widespread contamination of dietary foods with dioxin is unfortunate, there is good news to be told. There are ongoing federal and state programs to control dioxin emissions from the major emission sources thought to be contributing to this widespread contamination of food chains. National data suggest that dioxin concentrations in the envionment and in human body tissues are decreasing.
Here in Maine, both fish and lobster tomalley dioxin concentrations have been decreasing in response to ongoing efforts by the paper industry to reduce their discharge of dioxin into rivers. Governor King's initiative to bring Maine's stakeholders together to work toward further reducing the discharge of dioxins into our rivers will continue this trend, allowing us to eventually rescind all dioxin-related fish consumption advisories.
Dr. Andrew Smith is the state toxicologist within the Maine Department of Human Services, Bureau of Health, Division of Disease Control. Dr. Smith also holds an appointment as a research associate in the Department of Envionmental Health at the Harvard School of Public Health, and is a course instructor in Harvard's Center Continuing Professional Educaiton course: Analyzing Risk: Science, Assessment and Management.

Bill would scrap town clam rules Statewide standard urged

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]14 Jan 1997: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413837101?accountid=10457

Abstract: The bill, sponsored by Sen. Marge Kilkelly of Wiscasset, would scrap the myriad town clam harvesting rules and replace them with one statewide standard -- and one state clamming license. Although specifics of the bill are still to be written, the Lincoln County Democrat says battle lines already are being drawn. Under the current system, towns or groups of towns that have formed regional shellfish committees set the number of clam licenses they will issue each year, reserve most for town residents and make a small number available to nonresidents by lottery. State law requires municipal and regional shellfish ordinances to make the number of nonresident licenses no less than 10 percent of the number of resident licenses issued, and sets the maximum cost of a license at $200 for residents and $400 for nonresidents. In addition, commercial diggers must buy a $63 state license. Maine has about 1,600 commercial diggers.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Bill+would+scrap+town+clam+rules+Statewide+standard+urged&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1997-01-14&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- A proposal to abolish municipal shellfish ordinances creates the potential for a collision between two of Maine's most cherished traditions -- local control and open access to marine resources. It is expected to lead to heated testimony before the Marine Resources Committee this legislative session.
The bill, sponsored by Sen. Marge Kilkelly of Wiscasset, would scrap the myriad town clam harvesting rules and replace them with one statewide standard -- and one state clamming license. Although specifics of the bill are still to be written, the Lincoln County Democrat says battle lines already are being drawn.
"I've had a lot of calls about this. People are either very opposed or very supportive," Kilkelly said. "Nobody's in the middle. It definitely will be a big issue because it's an important issue. It's an issue of fairness."
Under the current system, towns or groups of towns that have formed regional shellfish committees set the number of clam licenses they will issue each year, reserve most for town residents and make a small number available to nonresidents by lottery.
State law requires municipal and regional shellfish ordinances to make the number of nonresident licenses no less than 10 percent of the number of resident licenses issued, and sets the maximum cost of a license at $200 for residents and $400 for nonresidents. In addition, commercial diggers must buy a $63 state license. Maine has about 1,600 commercial diggers.
Although there is considerable variation in what municipal and regional ordinances charge for licenses, few, if any, make more than the bare minimum available to nonresidents, according to Department of Marine Resources statistics.
For example, the ordinance jointly adopted by Wiscasset and Woolwich charges residents and nonresidents the same $150 for a license, but diggers must buy a separate license for each town. Each town issues 10 resident licenses a year and only one nonresident license.
A new five-town shellfish organization for Thomaston, South Thomaston, Warren, Cushing and St. George charges residents and nonresidents the maximum allowed by law for licenses, $200 and $400. The district sells 125 resident licenses per year and offers just 12 to nonresidents.
"It's the only fishery we administer that way and it's simply unfair," Kilkelly said. "The economic reality of the coastal regions is that the very people who rely on clams for essential income can no longer afford to live in the coastal communities. They're forced inland and are being cut off from this resource. Open access to a vital resource for all the people of Maine is, in this case, more important than home rule."
Kilkelly was elected to the Senate last fall after four terms representing House District 57. "Over the years, as the municipal ordinances gained strength, I'd hear from more and more of my inland constituents who were being shut out. As nonresidents in a lottery, they had maybe a 1-in-10 chance at getting a license.
"There's been a real domino effect -- as one town passed an ordinance that was very restrictive to nonresidents, the next town over would adopt one even more restrictive. I've heard of people who had to spend up to $1,000 for licenses as a nonresident," she said.
"We're supposed to be supporting small business development. Well, what's a smaller business than one guy out digging clams? The ability to earn a living should not be decided by these artificial boundaries, by what town you live in," she said.
Kilkelly said some municipal and regional committees have done good work in enforcement, flat reseeding, water-quality monitoring, and in making conservation work a condition of licensure "but it's been spotty. Some invest a lot into the resource, some do very little. I'd like to see the best of what the municipalities have done become the state standard."
The law would not take effect until next January, Kilkelly said, "to give us time to determine what the cost of this one state license should be and to set up a mechanism to continue using the expertise of the local shellfish committees in matters of conservation. We will need more state wardens, so the license fee has to be enough to raise the standard of enforcement, yet be more reasonable than what nonresidents of coastal towns are paying now, without placing any more burden on the local property tax."
Kilkelly said she expects strong opposition from coastal towns, "so I plan on working hard with the inland legislators to show them how their constituents are being shut out of this resource. I'm enough of a realist to know that this may not pass the first time around. If not, I'll at least use this as an opportunity to educate people on the negative way so many Maine citizens are being impacted by our current policies."

Mainers celebrate in own way Christmas workers serve the public

Author: Andrew Brownstein and Ruth-Ellen Cohen Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]26 Dec 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413948836?accountid=10457

Abstract: After serving Christmas lunch at Phillips-Strickland House in Bangor, Donald Peters (above left) gets a Christmas kiss from [Darlene Scripture] as they prepare their own meal. [Constance Kane] of Gouldsboro smiles as her husband, Forest, hugs granddaughter [Misty Fogg] of Virginia Beach (below) at Bangor International Airport after Fogg arrived for the holiday. [Ke-Shih Cheng], owner of Szechuan Garden on State Street in Bangor, whips up a flaming dish on Christmas. The restaurant was one of the few open for the holiday. (NEWS Photos by Michele Stap

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Mainers+celebrate+in+own+way+Christmas+workers+serve+the+public&amp;author=Andrew+Brownstein+and+Ruth-Ellen+Cohen+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-12-26&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BANGOR -- Hardly a creature was stirring on Wednesday, the sights of snowmen and the sounds of laughing children replaced by a peaceful silence.
On a distinctly unwhite Christmas, the tolling of the noontime church bells echoed past the empty sidewalks and storefronts of downtown Bangor.
But behind closed doors, people celebrated the holiday in their own way, meeting loved ones, watching movies or simply trying to earn a living.
In a dramatic crescendo of leaping flames and clanging pans, Ke-Shih Cheng resembled a video on fast-forward as he prepared the evening meals at State Street's Szechuan Garden. In just five minutes, Cheng, the restaurant's owner and chef, waved the steam away and produced a mouth-watering ensemble of shrimp in soy sauce and garlic chicken.
In the restaurant, Cheng Ouyang, the waiter on duty, was humming along to "Jingle Bell Rock" and thinking of Dec. 25 in his native Taiwan.
"It's called Constitution Day," he said. "It was a long time ago and I don't remember much about it. But I know we didn't have to work."
The owner smiled and chimed in, "We're open because it's convenient for the customers."
At Bangor International Airport, it was a day of many meetings and remembrances. And there couldn't have been grandparents more eager than Forest and Constance Kane of Gouldsboro.
In a Santa Claus hat, Forest Kane, 73, looked out the window overlooking the runway for signs of his grandaughter, Misty Fogg, a high school cheerleader living with friends and going to high school in Virginia Beach, Va.
"You know these young girls," he said as they waited. "Before they get off the plane they have to fix their hair and straighten their clothes."
The couple squinted and pointed the way teen-agers might await the sighting of a rock star.
"I see her," he said. "She probably can't see us through that little window," said Constance Kane, 63. The young woman finally made it through the gate, and her grandparents leaped from their front-row seats for a long-awaited hug.
Across town at the Greater Bangor Area Shelter, visitors shared a turkey lunch and presents provided by donors from throughout the region.
There were gifts from the second-graders at McGraw Elementary School in Hampden, wrapped in papier-mache and decorated with crayons. There were gloves, boots and turtlenecks collected by visiting nurses from stores such as L.L. Bean. Two presents were set aside for Vietnam veterans.
Christmas decor mixed with the center's warnings against drug abuse and unsafe sex, producing the strange sight of a ceramic Santa resting against a box of free condoms. According to Dennis Marble, the shelter's director, 34 people stayed at the shelter on Christmas, ranging from the homeless to recovering drug addicts and the mentally ill.
"We've had some emotional issues this morning because of where people find themselves on this holiday," said Marble.
But as they finished off a piece of Christmas cake, Anthony Brazzo and Christie Chessa celebrated the first anniversary of their meeting and looked forward to a wedding in August.
"You were sitting at the table in the corner and staring at me," remembered Chessa, 19, most recently of Brewer.
"We played cards but we were never on the same team," said Brazzo, 32, of Boston.
They met almost a year ago in January. Chessa was homeless, and Brazzo was seeking counseling for alcohol and drug addiction. Not everything has been rosy for the couple this year -- Brazzo was imprisoned briefly for theft -- but they said they now have an apartment and are looking forward to a new life in Bangor.
"We were living in Boston," he said. "I had to get away from there, from the gangs and the drugs. I'm not about to go back.
Bangor has a lot to offer. We've been given clothes and furniture. And like today, you can sit and talk to people."
Even though their circumstances may not have called up a Dickens story or a Norman Rockwell painting, local people found ways to enjoy the holiday.
Residents at the Phillips-Strickland House in Bangor assembled Wednesday afternoon in the dining room to partake of a festive Christmas dinner prepared by the kitchen staff. Some elderly residents of the boarding home had invited friends and family to join them for the feast, while others planned to visit relatives later in the day.
Marjorie Wentworth, 90, was counting on spending the afternoon curled up with a romantic novel. Wearing a bright red sweater with a holiday motif, the former teacher said that she would forgo the usual visit to relatives' homes, since climbing stairs had become difficult for her.
"This is my extended family, anyway," she said, pointing to the other residents, who sat chatting happily with each other, as they dug into steaming plates piled high with turkey, roast beef, mashed potatoes and gravy and boiled onions.
"I saw all my relatives on Thanksgiving," said 91-year-old Thelma Emery, "so I thought it would be nice to be with everyone here.
"And look what they do! They make it so festive!" added Emery, pointing to the gaily decorated tables, the bowls filled with shimmery red jello molds, the elegantly arranged relish trays.
"This is a good place to be!" agreed Peter Allen of Brewer, who had come to share Christmas dinner with his 89-year-old mother, Clara. Allen had brought his 24-year-old son, Peter Jr., here for the holidays from Manhattan.
After everyone was served, the kitchen crew, wearing white aprons and bright red Santa Claus hats, sat down to enjoy the feast.
Having to work on Christmas presented no problem whatsoever, they agreed.
"We get to be with a lot of nice people here," said Darlene Scripture of Hermon.
"This is our first family," declared Ella Getchell of Old Town as she looked around the dining room. "Next we'll be off to visit our own families -- our second families!"
Across town at the Concord Trailways Bus Station, Andrea Lyon, in a bright red Santa Claus hat, waited to board the 3:15 p.m.
express bus to Boston after spending Christmas with her parents in Machias.
Lyon, 30, was heading back to Simmons College in Boston where she is studying library science.
According to her parents, Jane and Elden, their daughter had been sporting the hat when she arrived in Bangor Dec. 22.
"I needed something to get me in the Christmas spirit!" the young woman said, laughing.
Meanwhile, bus driver Frank Hanscome was preparing for the run to Boston.
Hanscome said he had volunteered to work on the holiday. "I wouldn't know what to do if I didn't work on Christmas,"
said the genial bus driver, who celebrated the holiday last Saturday with his family in Scarborough.
Hanscome said that although his passengers would receive their usual snack of crackers and juice, they would be treated to the movie "Miracle on 34th Street" in honor of Christmas.
As of midafternoon, it was the movie, "Michael," which was drawing the largest Christmas Day audiences, according to Mark Cemodanovs, assistant manager of Hoyts Cinemas in Bangor.
Ed and Helen Vandenburgh of Corinna and Helen's mother, Bessie Flagg of Dexter, had chosen instead to watch "The Preacher's Wife" at the theater complex.
Although they had spent a traditional Christmas Eve opening presents and dining on oyster stew with other members of the family, the Vandenburghs were looking for a way to make some new Christmas memories. This Christmas was the first without Wyman Flagg, Bessie's husband and Helen's father, who died last spring. "The movie was fantastic!" said Ed Vandenburgh, as the family prepared to leave for home. "It was a nice way to vary the Christmas routine."
Meanwhile, Bill Perry, the manager of MacDonald's Market in Bangor, said it had been a typically busy Christmas Day.
Perry said that Christmas and Thanksgiving generally represent the store's "busiest days, moneywise."
"Everyone else shuts down," said Perry, recalling a steady stream of customers who had come in for "bread, milk, sugar, and whatever else they need to finish up their Christmas dinner."
Although, he remembered, there was that one customer who apparently was determined to defy tradition.
"Someone came in and bought a frozen salisbury steak dinner," Perry said, with a laugh.

Gulf protection plan approved Habitat restoration, reduced toxic contamination among goals

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 Dec 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413909058?accountid=10457

Abstract: At a recent meeting in Fredericton, New Brunswick, the Gulf of Maine Council on the Marine Environment adopted a new five-year plan that will help guide the work of government and private agencies committed to the stewardship of the gulf and its watershed. Five major topics are identified in the plan: restoring shellfish habitat; promoting the restoration of groundfish; addressing ecosystem and public health effects of toxic contaminants in the marine food chain; protecting and restoring significant coastal habitats; and reducing marine debris.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Gulf+protection+plan+approved+Habitat+restoration%2C+reduced+toxic+contamination+among+goals&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-12-24&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- A joint U.S.-Canadian organization has drafted a blueprint for the protection and management of the Gulf of Maine into the next century.
At a recent meeting in Fredericton, New Brunswick, the Gulf of Maine Council on the Marine Environment adopted a new five-year plan that will help guide the work of government and private agencies committed to the stewardship of the gulf and its watershed. Five major topics are identified in the plan: restoring shellfish habitat; promoting the restoration of groundfish; addressing ecosystem and public health effects of toxic contaminants in the marine food chain; protecting and restoring significant coastal habitats; and reducing marine debris.
The council was created in 1989 by the state and provincial governments of Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, New Brunswick and Nova Scotia to foster cooperative action on protecting and restoring the gulf.
The new plan, which covers the period 1996-2001, is a sequel to the first plan released in 1991, which laid the groundwork for guiding state, provincial and federal policies.
Some specific goals of the new plan are to reduce by 10 percent from 1990 levels the amount of toxic contaminants in bays, assisting in the restoration of 10,000 acres of significant coastal habitat, and improving the water quality in 12,000 acres of shellfish habitat.
David Keeley of the Maine State Planning Office said the council's work in its first seven years has been "a combination of educational programs, information sharing and hands-on projects to improve the marine environment. Our new plan builds on that, it looks for areas in which the council can help three state and two provincial and federal governments achieve something that's in everyone's interest -- a healthy and productive marine environment.
One of the council's first accompishments, Keeley said, "was to break what I call the `filing cabinet syndrome' that keeps information locked up in one government agency. The council's Web site is an electronic clearinghouse that makes all the information and research on the gulf available to all government agencies, researchers, academic institutions and the public -- anyone who is interested in the gulf.
Hands-on projects assisted by the council "have focused to a considerable extent on reducing marine debris, a significant problem. In Rockland, for example, the council helped finance the construction of a used oil container on the wharf. In general, the council looks for projects that are under way through a state, provincial or local initiative and could use some help."
Although the council does not have the force of law to back its positions, Keeley said, it "does have the strong support of three governors and two premiers, which gives a considerable amount of moral suasion. It's similar to other international agreements in that it builds on the common interests and the common goals."

People: Keeley, David

St. George man earns environmental award

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]18 Dec 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413950875?accountid=10457

Abstract: Hoyt was cited for his work to create clam management organization and open shellfish beds in the Georges River. He worked with local residents and the University of Maine Cooperative Extension and initiated a program to develop a clam management agreement and ordinance for five towns on the river.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=St.+George+man+earns+environmental+award&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-12-18&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ST. GEORGE -- The Gulf of Maine Council on the Marine Environment has awarded Sherman Hoyt of St. George its 1996 Visionary Award.
Hoyt was cited for his work to create clam management organization and open shellfish beds in the Georges River. He worked with local residents and the University of Maine Cooperative Extension and initiated a program to develop a clam management agreement and ordinance for five towns on the river.
Hoyt also trained clam diggers to identify pollution problems and as a result of these efforts, 700 acres of product clam flats were opened to harvesting in July.
Evan Richert, a council member and director of the Maine State Planning Office, said: "The work of Sherman Hoyt and the Gulf of Maine Aquarium has improved the quality of the Gulf of Maine Environment. They exemplify the good work occurring in the gulf, and their receipt of these awards is well deserved."

Beals Island hatchery to receive $10,000 grant

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]18 Dec 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413941252?accountid=10457

Abstract: The Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery will receive $10,000 from the Gulf of Maine Council on the Marine Environment to develop an outreach program for a Maine coastwide demonstration clam farm...

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Beals+Island+hatchery+to+receive+%2410%2C000+grant&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-12-18&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BEALS ISLAND -- The Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery will receive $10,000 from the Gulf of Maine Council on the Marine Environment to develop an outreach program for a Maine coastwide demonstration clam farm project.
Researchers and community groups will organize public meetings and coordinate field programs showing the value of clam farming.
The project is one of 14 in Maine, Massachusetts, Nova Scotia and New Brunswick that receive funding from the council, which was created in 1989 by the Canadian province governments, Maine, Massachusetts and New Hampshire to foster cooperation in the Gulf of Maine watershed.
