Eastport clammers oppose closed cove Diggers clash with panel's protection effort

Author: Diana Graettinger Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]18 Dec 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413834164?accountid=10457

Abstract: At around 11 a.m., wardens and Eastport and Maine State Police officers arrived. He said members of the Eastport Marine Resources Committee confiscated the nine bushels of clams and threw them on the beach. He said the clam diggers lost $450 worth of clams. Eastport police Officer Robert Gregory, who summoned six diggers, said he went to Carrying Place Cove after he received a report that the clam warden was having problems with diggers there. When he arrived, he said, there were about 18 men yelling at one another. He said the situation calmed down when police officers arrived. Although diggers are allowed to dig two bushels per tide at Carrying Place Cove, several diggers proposed an end to that limit. But others feared that move would seriously deplete the resource. "I think you've got to have a limit if you want to dig year-round," said Eastport digger Joel Dickey.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Eastport+clammers+oppose+closed+cove+Diggers+clash+with+panel%27s+protection+effort&amp;author=Diana+Graettinger+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-12-18&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: EASTPORT -- The Eastport Marine Resources Committee's effort to protect Carrying Place Cove by opening only a small portion of it to shellfish harvesting met with opposition over the weekend when clammers who strayed into the closed area were summoned by police.
Eastport digger Herbert Mitchell said that somehow the stakes that marked the line between the open and closed areas were removed, and he and some other clammers strayed over the line Sunday.
At around 11 a.m., wardens and Eastport and Maine State Police officers arrived. He said members of the Eastport Marine Resources Committee confiscated the nine bushels of clams and threw them on the beach. He said the clam diggers lost $450 worth of clams.
Eastport police Officer Robert Gregory, who summoned six diggers, said he went to Carrying Place Cove after he received a report that the clam warden was having problems with diggers there. When he arrived, he said, there were about 18 men yelling at one another. He said the situation calmed down when police officers arrived.
Monday night about 20 clammers were at the Marine Resources Committee meeting to protest the fact that they could dig on only 60 of the 240 acres at Carrying Place Cove. The cove is located off Route 190, near the Eastport scenic sign.
The resources committee was created about four years ago, but the Eastport Shellfish Conservation Ordinance that regulates clamming activities in the community, was approved only in November 1995. The committee has five members, appointed by the City Council and each serves for three years.
Before those clam flats were opened, committee members and diggers met to discuss how the resource should be managed. The diggers agreed to the 60-acre site, and they also agreed to harvest no more than two bushels per tide. Orange--tipped stakes were put in place to mark the open area. Public hearings were held by the City Council and the recommendations of the resource committee were approved.
During the first week, the clammers remained in the open area, but over the weekend the stakes mysteriously disappeared, and several diggers were found digging in the closed area.
Monday night, diggers said they wanted the open area at Carrying Place Cove extended to at least half the cove, but they could not agree on how many acres should be opened, or how many bushels a digger should be allowed to harvest each tide.
Eastport resident Will Hopkins, who acted as moderator, wondered how long the clammers would be satisfied if the line were placed at the midpoint of the cove.
"Until I start starving. Until the light bill gets behind. Then I'll be down here knocking on your door again," Eastport digger Tommy Cook said.
In addition to opening up more of Carrying Place Cove, several diggers suggested another conservation measure, to allow digging on only one tide, banning night digging. But that suggestion was opposed by most of the diggers at the meeting.
Although diggers are allowed to dig two bushels per tide at Carrying Place Cove, several diggers proposed an end to that limit. But others feared that move would seriously deplete the resource. "I think you've got to have a limit if you want to dig year-round," said Eastport digger Joel Dickey.
The one thing diggers seemed to agree on was that they didn't agree.

Gulf of Maine plan adopted International group aims to restore and preserve marine habitat

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]07 Dec 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413864472?accountid=10457

Abstract: FREDERICTON, New Brunswick -- The states and provinces bordering the Gulf of Maine adopted a new five-year plan Friday aimed at restoring and preserving the area's rich marine habitat. The Gulf of Maine stretches from Cape Sable, Nova Scotia, to Cape Cod, Mass., and includes Georges Bank and the Bay of Fundy. The Gulf of Maine Council includes representatives from Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Nova Scotia and New Brunswick. Its mission is to maintain and improve the gulf's environmental quality while allowing people to use its resources.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Gulf+of+Maine+plan+adopted+International+group+aims+to+restore+and+preserve+marine+habitat&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-12-07&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: FREDERICTON, New Brunswick -- The states and provinces bordering the Gulf of Maine adopted a new five-year plan Friday aimed at restoring and preserving the area's rich marine habitat.
Members of the Gulf of Maine Council said the main thrust of the plan is to rebuild shellfish beds, restore wetlands and reduce toxic contaminants in the bays of the gulf.
"It's a detailed blueprint to address the key issues concerning the environmental future of this precious international resource," said council Chairman Bernard Theriault, New Brunswick's fisheries minister.
The Gulf of Maine stretches from Cape Sable, Nova Scotia, to Cape Cod, Mass., and includes Georges Bank and the Bay of Fundy.
Fishing and shellfishing have been major industries in the gulf, sustaining the work of nearly 20,000 fishermen and contributing hundreds of millions of dollars to the region's economy in recent years.
The Gulf of Maine Council includes representatives from Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Nova Scotia and New Brunswick. Its mission is to maintain and improve the gulf's environmental quality while allowing people to use its resources.
New Brunswick environmentalist Janice Harvey, who attended the council meeting as an observer, was critical of the council and its objectives.
She said that in the six years since the council was created, its major accomplishment was improved communication between state and provincial bureaucracies.
"But we have seen no serious look at fish stocks, no action on some of the major problems," she said.
"We know, for example, that many commercial species use rockweed as very critical habitat, yet the New Brunswick Department of Fisheries, which chairs this council, is promoting a commercial rockweed harvest in the Bay of Fundy. Those two things are inconsistent."
She said the commercial fishery, already closed in some parts of the gulf, could disappear along with the spectacular bird migrations of the upper bay.
Harvey said environmentalists in the gulf region are organizing a Gulf of Maine alliance to put political pressure on the council "to get out there and start doing something."

____________________________________________________________

Mirth and feasting, about 1800

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]28 Nov 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413864520?accountid=10457

Abstract: Thanksgiving now was dawning! We children poked one another, and fairly giggled with unreproved delight as we listened to the crackle of the slowly unfolding document. That great sheet of paper impressed us as something supernatural, by reason of its mighty size, and by the broad seal of the State affixed thereto; and when the minister read therefrom, "By his Excellency, the Governor of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, a Proclamation," our mirth was with difficulty repressed by admonitory glances from our sympathetic elders. Then, after a solemn enumeration of the benefits which the Commonwealth had that year received at the hands of Divine Providence, came at last the naming of the eventful day, and, at the end of all, the imposing heraldic words, "God save the Commonwealth of Massachusetts." And then, as the congregation broke up a dispersed, all went their separate ways with schemes of mirth and feasting in their heads.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Mirth+and+feasting%2C+about+1800&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-11-28&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Harriet Beecher Stowe moved to Maine in 1850, with her husband, Calvin Ellis Stowe, a professor at Bowdoin College. In Brunswick, she wrote her famous "Uncle Tom's Cabin" and many stories about New England life, including "The Pearl of Orr's Island" (1862) and "Oldtown Folks" (1869). The latter offers a vivid description of Thanksgiving soon after the Revolutionary War, and is a particularly fitting reminiscence for today.
Are there any of my readers who do not know what Thanksgiving day is to a child? Then let them go back with me, and recall the image of it as we kept it in Oldtown.
People have often supposed, because the Puritans founded a society where there were no professed public amusements, that therefore there was no fun going on in the ancient land of Israel, and that there were no cakes and ale, because they were virtuous. They were never more mistaken in their lives. There was an abundance of sober, well-considered merriment; and the hinges of life were well oiled with that sort of secret humor which to this day gives the raciness to real Yankee wit. Besides this we must remember that life itself is the greatest possible amusement to people who really believe that they can do so much with it, -- who have that intense sense of what can be brought to pass by human effort, that was characteristic of the New England colonies. To such it is not exactly proper to say that life is an amusement, but it certainly is an engrossing interest that takes the place of all amusements. ...
When the apples were all gathered and the cider was all made, and the yellow pumpkins were rolled in from many a hill in billows of gold, and the corn was husked, and the labors of the season were done, and the warm, late days of Indian Summer came in, dreamy and calm and still, with just frost enough to crisp the ground of a morning, but with warm trances of benignant, sunny hours at noon, there came over the community a sort of genial repose of spirit, -- a sense of something accomplished, and of a new golden mark made in advance of the calendar of life, -- and the deacon began to say to the minister, of a Sunday, "I suppose it's time for the Thanksgiving proclamation." ...
We also felt its approach in all departments of the household, -- the conversation at this time beginning to turn on high and solemn culinary mysteries and receipts of wondrous power and virtue. New modes of elaborating squash pies and quince tarts were now ofttimes carefully discussed at the evening fireside by Aunt Lois and Aunt Keziah, and notes seriously compared with the experiences of other Aunties of high repute in such matters. I noticed that on these occasions their voices often fell into mysterious whispers, and that receipts of especial power and sanctity were communicated in tones so low as entirely to escape the vulgar ear. I still remember the solemn shake of the head with which my Aunt Lois conveyed to Miss Mehitable Rossiter the critical properties of mace, in relation to its powers of producing in corn fritters a suggestive resemblance to oysters. As ours was an oyster-getting district, and as that charming bivalve was perfectly easy to come at, the interest of such an imitation can be accounted for only by the fondness of the human mind to works of art.
For as much as a week beforehand, "we children" were employed in chopping mince for pies to a most wearisome fineness, and in pounding cinnamon, allspice, and cloves in a great lignumvitae mortar; and the sound of this pounding and chopping re-echoed through all the rafters of the old house with a hearty and vigorous cheer, most refreshing to our spirits. ...
At other times of the year we sometimes mummured at these labors, but those that were supposed to usher in the great Thanksgiving festival were always entered into with enthusiasm.
There were signs of richness all around us, -- stoning of raisins, cutting of citron, slicing of candied orange peel. Yet all these were only dawning and imitations of what was coming during the week of real preparation, after the Governor's proclamation had been read. ...
The cheering anticipation sustained us through what seemed to us the long waste of the sermon and prayers; and when at last the auspicious moment approached, -- when the last quaver of the last hymn had died out, -- the whole house rippled with the general movement of complacency, and a satisfied smile of pleased expectation might be seen gleaming on all the faces of the young people, like a ray of sunshine through a garden of flowers.
Thanksgiving now was dawning! We children poked one another, and fairly giggled with unreproved delight as we listened to the crackle of the slowly unfolding document. That great sheet of paper impressed us as something supernatural, by reason of its mighty size, and by the broad seal of the State affixed thereto; and when the minister read therefrom, "By his Excellency, the Governor of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, a Proclamation," our mirth was with difficulty repressed by admonitory glances from our sympathetic elders. Then, after a solemn enumeration of the benefits which the Commonwealth had that year received at the hands of Divine Providence, came at last the naming of the eventful day, and, at the end of all, the imposing heraldic words, "God save the Commonwealth of Massachusetts." And then, as the congregation broke up a dispersed, all went their separate ways with schemes of mirth and feasting in their heads.

Marine life weathered oil spill Long-term effects on creatures in Portland's Fore River unclear

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]12 Nov 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413835901?accountid=10457

Abstract: Preliminary studies indicate that the Sept. 27 oil spill in the Fore River caused no widespread mortality or oiling of marine life, but there is still concern about the spill's long-term impact. "We found a much more rich and diverse community down there than anybody expected to find," [John Sowles] said, expressing confidence that the immediate impacts of the spill were minimal. Seth Barker, oil spill coordinator at the Maine Department of Marine Resources, says he expected the survey to find plenty of dead shellfish, considering the magnitude of the spill and the fact that there was toxic No. 2 fuel oil in the mix.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Marine+life+weathered+oil+spill+Long-term+effects+on+creatures+in+Portland%27s+Fore+River+unclear&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-11-12&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PORTLAND -- Preliminary studies indicate that the Sept. 27 oil spill in the Fore River caused no widespread mortality or oiling of marine life, but there is still concern about the spill's long-term impact.
"There's always that question of {impaired} growth and reproductive effects and that sort of thing down the road," said John Sowles of the state Department of Environmental Protection.
Green crabs, periwinkles, anemones and other creatures that dwell on the river bottom appear to be healthy and active, as do finfish, mussels and clams, the preliminary studies found.
A diver who swam under the bow of the crippled tanker Julie N just 10 days after it struck a bridge and spilled 170,000 gallons of oil into the river found that even those waters were unexpectedly teeming with life.
"We found a much more rich and diverse community down there than anybody expected to find," Sowles said, expressing confidence that the immediate impacts of the spill were minimal.
Researchers from six states and federal agencies have been working over the past few weeks on a "pre-assessment" of the damage caused by the spill. These initial studies, estimated to cost $322,000, will help determine if more long-term research is needed and will lay the groundwork for a restoration plan.
Seth Barker, oil spill coordinator at the Maine Department of Marine Resources, says he expected the survey to find plenty of dead shellfish, considering the magnitude of the spill and the fact that there was toxic No. 2 fuel oil in the mix.
"They seem to have survived the exposure to the oil," he said. Many of the studies are ongoing, with their final results not expected until December or January, according to Paul VanCott of the Maine Department of Environmental Protection.
As a result, no formal conclusions about the damage to natural resources will be made until after the first of the year.
"As a practical matter, however, we will move as quickly as possible to restoration planning because we don't want to spend more time studying impacts than we have to," VanCott said.

Bond issues will aid Fort Knox, small businesses

Author: Doug Kesseli Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]06 Nov 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413934758?accountid=10457

Abstract: "I feel relieved," said George MacLeod, president of Friends of Fort Knox, which formed five years ago after voters in Maine nixed repairs to the fort for a second time in two years. "I feel that this is a major turning point for the Friends of Fort Knox," he said. The $1 million in repairs to Fort Knox was part of a $3 million bond issue to fund capital improvements to state parks and historic sites, including making them handicapped-accessible. Returns at 2 a.m. showed 59 percent of the voters approving the bond and 41 percent opposed. Even though support outpaced the opposition from the outset, early on MacLeod expressed some uncertainty about losing ground in southern Maine because the funds largely would go toward improvements in eastern and northern Maine.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Bond+issues+will+aid+Fort+Knox%2C+small+businesses&amp;author=Doug+Kesseli+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-11-06&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Mainers were in a spending mood Tuesday, backing $40.5 million in bond issues to clean up sewer systems and landfills, jump-start small businesses and fix up historic sites and parks in the state.
Early Wednesday morning, with 83 percent of the state's 646 precincts reporting, returns showed consistently strong support for the bonds, with most being endorsed by almost three-fifths of the voters.
It was never even close. That was good news for backers of the bonds and especially for the Friends of Fort Knox, an organization that has battled for about five years for increased attention and financial support for the most heavily visited historic site in the state.
"I feel relieved," said George MacLeod, president of Friends of Fort Knox, which formed five years ago after voters in Maine nixed repairs to the fort for a second time in two years. "I feel that this is a major turning point for the Friends of Fort Knox," he said.
The $1 million in repairs to Fort Knox was part of a $3 million bond issue to fund capital improvements to state parks and historic sites, including making them handicapped-accessible. Returns at 2 a.m. showed 59 percent of the voters approving the bond and 41 percent opposed.
Even though support outpaced the opposition from the outset, early on MacLeod expressed some uncertainty about losing ground in southern Maine because the funds largely would go toward improvements in eastern and northern Maine.
That seemed to make little difference. Almost half of the $3 million approved would go toward improving Churchill Dam, which controls water levels in the Allagash Wilderness Waterway. The waterway serves outdoorsmen and fisheries and is a natural habitat for fish and fowl.
The largest of the bond issues before voters, Question 5, would pump $16.5 million into statewide efforts to clean up massive automobile tire stockpiles, close solid waste landfills to safeguard drinking water supplies, and fund efforts to reduce hazardous discharges into the environment. It too was generating hefty support, with about 61 percent in favor.
Meanwhile, the bond issue for small business ventures received the greatest support, garnering 65 percent of the votes.
"I hope it carries through as the night goes on; this is critical for the state of Maine to move forward," said Charles Mercer, a spokesman for the Finance Authority of Maine, which would administer the small business loans that are part of the $11 million Question 6.
Through the sale of the bonds, the state would establish a $6 million loan program for agriculture and natural resource-based companies like farms and acquaculture enterprises that have potential but are considered risky investments by banks.
Small manufacturers would also be eligible for loans under the $5 million Small Enterprise Growth Fund, which targets businesses in high-growth fields that need a hand up. Companies eligible for the loans include those involved in marine sciences, biotechnology, precision manufacturing and computer software.
Upgrading of sewer treatment plants and public water systems was the impetus behind the $10 million bond issue Question 7. This bond received the public's backing with 63 percent of the vote.
With passage of the question will come $10 million in federal grants that will be combined with $2 million from the bond issue for loans to municipalities to improve sewer treatment facilities and to abate untreated discharges from sewer overflows.
Other money from the bond issue would be used to replace the Waldoboro Utility District discharge system, which is below environmental standards and has resulted in state officials closing nearby areas to shellfish harvesting.
Late Tuesday afternoon before polls closed, Secretary of State Bill Diamond was predicting that the bond issues would fare well with voters. The four bond issues represented the smallest bond request since 1989 and generally, Diamond said, people are feeling good about the economy.
And when they're feeling good, they tend to be more willing to approve bonds, according to state statistics.
The fate of a bond issue could also depend on happenstance, something as simple as where it appears on the ballot.
"There's always the fear that going down the ballot, voters will start to feel poor and not want to spend quite as much money when it gets down to the bottom," Diamond said. "It doesn't happen all the time, but it is a concern."
Overall, Maine voters have been fairly liberal about opening their wallets and purses and spending money. Based on statistics from Diamond's office, Mainers have approved bonds about 68 percent of the time since 1985.

People: Diamond, Bill

Scallop scramble under way Boats pack Cobscook Bay on opening day of season

Author: Letitia Baldwin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]04 Nov 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413904556?accountid=10457

Abstract: Maine's 1996 inshore scallop season, which opened at sunrise on Nov. 1, drew scores of scallop draggers lured by the prospect of making as much as several thousand dollars for a day's catch of the pearly-white marine creatures. Some boats anchored overnight to have first crack at the rich scallop beds in South Bay, Gouldsboro Bay and other prime areas. "It's a scallop factory," Marine Patrol Capt. [David Dent] says, surveying the scene, with binoculars from the helm of the Machias. The Machias draws up to a red-hulled dragger from Lubec. The drag is hauled up and rocks, crabs, scallops, seaweed, starfish and sea urchins cascade onto the "dumping" table. The crew sort through the muddy pile, tossing legal-sized scallops into plastic totes. Lubec Capt. [Mel Gallant] watches as Marine Patrol Specialist David Dent uses a brass ring to check for small scallops aboard Gallant's boat in Cobscook Bay. (NEWS Photo by Scott Haskell) Marine Patrol Officer [Jodi Mosher] surveys unshelled scallops on the deck of a boat in Cobscook Bay on opening day of scallop season. (NEWS Photos by Scott Haskell) [Robin Alden], Commissioner, Department of Marine Resources NEWS Graphic

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Scallop+scramble+under+way+Boats+pack+Cobscook+Bay+on+opening+day+of+season&amp;author=Letitia+Baldwin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-11-04&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: EASTPORT -- At the crack of dawn, under a violet- and orange-streaked sky, engines roared and scores of scallop boats fanned out Friday to fish South Bay and the myriad other coves and inlets in Cobscook Bay.
Maine's 1996 inshore scallop season, which opened at sunrise on Nov. 1, drew scores of scallop draggers lured by the prospect of making as much as several thousand dollars for a day's catch of the pearly-white marine creatures. Some boats anchored overnight to have first crack at the rich scallop beds in South Bay, Gouldsboro Bay and other prime areas.
On patrol since 4 a.m. Friday, Maine Marine Patrol Specialist David Dent and Officer Jodi Mosher said South Bay resembled a Christmas parade as dozens of draggers, their red and green navigational lights glowing in the dark, got a head start toward the fishing grounds.
"It looked like all of Lubec was coming up the bay," said Dent as he and Mosher headed out from Eastport for a second round of patrolling aboard the Marine Patrol vessel Machias.
Expecting an onslaught, the Marine Patrol and U.S. Coast Guard were out in force all along the coast. In a well-coordinated operation, their officers boarded scallop draggers to ensure they were equipped with proper safety and fishing gear. They also were present to assist in case boats collided, fishing drags got entangled, lobster gear got damaged or some other incident triggered by overcrowding occurred.
Also on hand to monitor the situation were Department of Marine Resources Commissioner Robin Alden; Herman Backman Jr., the DMR's regional coordinator and former president of the Downeast Lobstermen's Association; and Bob Peacock, chairman of the DMR's Marine Advisory Council.
Flying in a Marine Patrol plane up to Eastport early Friday morning, Alden said she had spotted 50 to 60 scallop draggers clustered around Black and Placentia islands off Mount Desert Island and a similar number concentrated in Gouldsboro Bay. She said there did not seem to be nearly as many draggers as reported last year.
"It's a lot of boats but it's not more than we expected," Alden said. "The Coast Guard has been a godsend. I don't know what we would have done without them."
Petty Officer Dave Candee, supervisor of the U.S. Coast Guard's search-and-rescue unit in Eastport, agreed there were fewer scallop draggers than last year. He counted 130 boats in Cobscook Bay.
"We had anticipated a heck of a lot of boats. This year was pale by comparison to last year," he said.
Candee said there were no boating accidents and few safety violations were found. He noted many scallop boats had voluntarily participated in the Coast Guard's marine safety program prior to opening day.
For a decade now, the DMR has prohibited scalloping in certain inshore areas for all or part of November. The season closes April 15.
The partial opening was instituted to prevent gear conflicts between scallopers and lobster fishermen. November is a prime month for lobstering. It's the time of the year when lobsters make their annual migration to deep, offshore waters where they spend the winter. Traditionally, lobster fishermen have kept their gear in the water to catch the crustaceans as they move offshore.
But the scallop season's staggered opening has put pressure especially on Gouldsboro Bay and other prime areas open to fishing from the start. On opening day, scallop draggers descend on those open areas still dotted with lobster traps. Lobstermen charge the overcrowding not only threatens their gear but also the migrating brood stock and juvenile lobsters.
In Cobscook Bay, local scallop fishermen complain the area is stripped clean in a matter of weeks, leaving them nothing to harvest the rest of the season. They also fear the heavy fishing is harming the scallop brood stock and juvenile population.
In addition, Cobscook Bay is subject to extreme tidal ranges that cause fast currents, choppy seas and tide rips. On opening day, the convergence of scallopers, many of whom are from out of town, makes dragging there even more perilous. A few years ago, two scallop boats got tangled and divers had to cut the drags.
Last month, Harvey Crowley, a Corea lobsterman and president of the Downeast Lobstermen's Association, said the towns of Gouldsboro, Steuben and Winter Harbor plan to petition the Legislature to close Gouldsboro Bay annually until Dec. 1.
Sitting with her legs braced on the stern of the Machias, as the Marine Patrol boat charged out of Eastport, Alden said her department is seriously considering a Dec. 1 opening for all scalloping areas, and other alternatives to the present staggered season.
"We are seeking a better way to open the scallop season," she said. "This kind of opening is not the optimal way to run a fishery, but a change would involve the scallop, shrimp, lobster and groundfish fisheries and the issues are very complex."
Ahead, the scene resembles a regatta. Scores of scallop draggers are scattered across South Bay. The boats zigzag across the choppy waters, managing miraculously to stay out of each other's path. They leave great brown swaths where sediment from the bottom of the bay has been kicked up from repeated tows.
"It's a scallop factory," Marine Patrol Capt. David Dent says, surveying the scene, with binoculars from the helm of the Machias. The Machias draws up to a red-hulled dragger from Lubec. The drag is hauled up and rocks, crabs, scallops, seaweed, starfish and sea urchins cascade onto the "dumping" table. The crew sort through the muddy pile, tossing legal-sized scallops into plastic totes.
"A lot of little ones compared to last year," Capt. Mel Gallant tells the Marine Patrol officers who use a brass ring to gauge whether the scallops measure at least the minimum legal size.
Undersized scallops was the main fishing violation found on more than a dozen fishing boats boarded by Dent and Mosher by early afternoon. Some of the juvenile mollusks discovered were as small as a silver dollar.
Commissioner Alden said the multitude of juvenile scallops bodes well for the 1997 scallop season, and she urged fishermen to toss the undersized creatures back into the sea.
"The abundance of undersized scallops is a good thing," Alden said. "If people stay off of them, they'll be there next season and worth a lot more money."
Illustration Caption: Lubec Capt. Mel Gallant watches as Marine Patrol Specialist David Dent uses a brass ring to check for small scallops aboard Gallant's boat in Cobscook Bay. (NEWS Photo by Scott Haskell) Marine Patrol Officer Jodi Mosher surveys unshelled scallops on the deck of a boat in Cobscook Bay on opening day of scallop season. (NEWS Photos by Scott Haskell) Robin Alden, Commissioner, Department of Marine Resources NEWS Graphic

YES on Question 7

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]31 Oct 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413847718?accountid=10457

Abstract: Do you favor a $10,000,000 bond issue for the following purposes: (1) $8,000,000 to construct water pollution control facilities, providing the state match for $10,000,000 in federal funds; and (2) $2,000,000 to address environmental health deficiencies in drinking water supplies? In the past 30 years, the state and its communities have invested hundreds of millions of dollars to clean up residential and commercial sewage and waste. The results have been spectacular on Maine's rivers. The benefits are obvious. The cost, however, is significant. This bond will continue that work, and make it more affordable in key areas.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=YES+on+Question+7&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-10-31&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Do you favor a $10,000,000 bond issue for the following purposes: (1) $8,000,000 to construct water pollution control facilities, providing the state match for $10,000,000 in federal funds; and (2) $2,000,000 to address environmental health deficiencies in drinking water supplies?
Part of a continuing investment in the quality of the Maine environment, the largest share of this bond, $8 million, will be combined with federal funds to pay for expansion or upgrading of waste water treatment plants.
In the past 30 years, the state and its communities have invested hundreds of millions of dollars to clean up residential and commercial sewage and waste. The results have been spectacular on Maine's rivers. The benefits are obvious. The cost, however, is significant. This bond will continue that work, and make it more affordable in key areas.
This bond is the first in three years to provide funds for construction and expansion of large centralized sewage treatment facilities. The $4 million for this purpose isn't nearly enough to significantly ease the financial pain on most municipalities, but it will help by reducing the amount some towns or districts will have to borrow to finance construction.
Revolving loan programs under the aegis of the state have worked well in Maine. This bond issue will create one for communities and districts that must improve their water systems to comply with the requirements of the Safe Drinking Water Act. The $2 million from Question 7 will be combined with federal funds to make loans, at no interest, for these local projects.
Proponents of the bond issue point out that more than 800 public water systems in Maine may be eligible to apply for these loans next year. The challenge to the state will be to devise a system of its own for filtering these requests and funding them in order of priority.
An additional $1 million from the bond will be distributed through the Small Community Grants Program. This will help sparsely populated Maine communities, where central collection and treatment plants are impractical, target their help to specific homes and businesses. Last year, 247 individual systems were built with these funds.
The bond also provides $1 million to pump up the Overboard Discharge Program that replaces commercial and residential systems that pollute coastal drainage areas and shellfish beds. This program can transform these areas, making them productive for shellfish harvesting and pollution free.
Maine voters have seen previous bond issues similar to Question 7. They have been approved. This one also deserves a YES vote.

Quebecers remain divided and edgy year after vote for separatism fails Political uncertainty causes economic woes; thousands go to other provinces

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]29 Oct 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413827200?accountid=10457

Abstract: Quebec's separatist-led provincial government doesn't minimize the economic woes. Premier Lucien Bouchard is convening a three-day summit of business and labor leaders Tuesday to seek a consensus on deficit-cutting, job creation and tax policies. Several prominent Quebec federalists were upset when the national government decided in September to ask the Canadian Supreme Court for a ruling on whether Quebec has the right to secede unilaterally. "Did we really talk to one another since last year?" he asked. "I'm not sure. I think this is very sad for the future of Quebec." [Gilles Proulx] contended it is easier for white and black leaders in South Africa to work together than for English and French speakers in Quebec.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Quebecers+remain+divided+and+edgy+year+after+vote+for+separatism+fails+Political+uncertainty+causes+economic+woes%3B+thousands+go+to+other+provinces&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-10-29&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: MONTREAL -- A year after the referendum that nearly split Canada in two, Quebec is as polarized as ever, its economy in disarray, and its morale soured by ceaseless debate over separatism.
Officially, Quebecers who opposed independence were the victors on Oct. 30, 1995, casting a bare majority 50.6 percent of the votes that were tallied during an evening of wrenching tension.
In many ways, however, the outcome turned Quebecers on both sides into victims. In part because of political uncertainty, outside investment in Quebec has shrunk and thousands of people are leaving for other provinces. Montreal's 12.6 percent jobless rate is the highest of any big Canadian city.
"Nobody should have to live with a sword of Damocles constantly hanging over their heads," Prime Minister Jean Chretien said during a recent foray into Montreal to preach the rewards of Canadian federalism.
Quebec's separatist-led provincial government doesn't minimize the economic woes. Premier Lucien Bouchard is convening a three-day summit of business and labor leaders Tuesday to seek a consensus on deficit-cutting, job creation and tax policies.
Bouchard hopes to gain support for painful government spending cuts that would, in a few years, prove to Quebecers and outsiders that his Parti Quebecois is capable of governing an independent, solvent nation.
And he wants the province on firmer financial footing when the next referendum takes place, perhaps in four or five years.
Monique Simard, vice president of the Parti Quebecois, said the turn of the century could be a highly symbolic moment for Quebec, though she stopped short of predicting the referendum would be held then.
"Four, five, six years -- in politics that's an eternity," she said in an interview. "But people who've been strong sovereigntists for 20, 25 years agree with our timetable. They are patient. It will happen some day."
Chretien and his federalist allies insist separation is not inevitable, but their strategies vary from week to week, sometimes in contradiction.
Several prominent Quebec federalists were upset when the national government decided in September to ask the Canadian Supreme Court for a ruling on whether Quebec has the right to secede unilaterally.
Justice Minister Allan Rock said the point was to show that Quebec, if it did vote to secede, would face tough negotiations over division of government debt and assets. But the move seemed to play into separatist hands.
"It's an attempt to treat Quebec as a captive people," said Bouchard.
Federalists strive to show Quebec the benefits of staying in Canada. Chretien just announced an interest-free, federal loan of $64 million to help Quebec's Bombardier Inc. develop a new passenger jet.
Yet some federalists can't resist spotlighting any bit of economic bad news in Quebec, hoping hard times will eventually erode the popularity that Bouchard consolidated with his passionate referendum campaigning last year.
Support for independence increased steadily in post-referendum opinion polls, peaking at 55 percent in June.
Since then, the trend has reversed. The latest monthly survey by the Montreal polling firm of Leger and Leger gave the federalist side a slight edge.
"It's clear that for Lucien Bouchard the honeymoon is over," said pollster Jean-Marc Leger.
"People are looking for effective government, not more talk about the constitution," he said.
Though bread-and-butter issues may be paramount for most Quebeckers, hard-liners in both the French-speaking majority and the Anglophone minority have ensured a persistent nastiness in the political climate.
Parti Quebecois militants have successfully pressed for tougher enforcement of language laws that restrict the use of English on signs.
Meanwhile, an aggressive English-rights movement has arisen for the first time, staging protests and rallies. One of its leaders, Howard Galganov, plans to defy language laws at a store to be opened in November and has dared Bouchard to make him a political prisoner.
Though most Quebecers speak at least a little of the other community's language, a deep gulf remains.
It was a rare occasion Wednesday at Magnan's, a beer-and-oysters tavern in Montreal, when talk-show hosts from French and English radio stations arranged a joint live broadcast. Tavern patrons and radio listeners engaged in lively bilingual discussion of whether the two communities can get along.
Gilles Proulx, a feisty separatist who is host of a show on the French station CKAC, gave a gloomy prognosis.
"Did we really talk to one another since last year?" he asked. "I'm not sure. I think this is very sad for the future of Quebec." Proulx contended it is easier for white and black leaders in South Africa to work together than for English and French speakers in Quebec.
But Proulx probably spoke for may on both sides with another comment.
"I'm fed up talking about this," he said. "I'd rather talk about hockey."

People: Chretien, Jean Bouchard, Lucien Leger, Jean-Marc Proulx, Gilles

Voters face $40 million bond parcel Supporters encourage 'prudent investments'

Author: From the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]26 Oct 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413887011?accountid=10457

Abstract: The Maine Department of Environmental Protection would use $2.5 million to investigate and clean up hazardous substance sites. Some $5 million would finance removal of tire stockpiles, and $9 million would be distributed to Maine cities and towns as reimbursement for closing solid waste landfills. On Route 1A north of Ellsworth, [Henry Aho] said, the DEP has equipped six households with water filters. He said the next step will be to pinpoint the contamination's origin and determine how best to deal with the hazardous material. Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Voters+face+%2440+million+bond+parcel+Supporters+encourage+%27prudent+investments%27&amp;author=From+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-10-26&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Four of the eight referendum questions on the Nov. 5 ballot ask Maine voters to approve issuing state bonds worth more than $40 million to finance a variety of environmental, economic and capital improvement projects.
If all four 1996 bond issues - listed as Questions 4 through 7 on the ballot - are approved, taxpayers will be obligated to repay $40.5 million in principal and a projected $11.5 million in interest.
The long-term borrowing package has generated little public debate or discussion, although a coalition of business, municipal and environmental organizations is supporting passage.
The Economic and Environmental Improvement Coalition says "prudent investments' not only will protect natural resources but also will stimulate the economy and improve Maine's cultural and recreational attractions.
The largest bond issue, Question 5, would raise $16.5 million for several environmental cleanup projects around the state. It includes funds for cleaning up hazardous waste, reducing dangerous scrap tire stockpiles and covering solid waste landfills.
Question 4 asks for $3 million to repair and improve state parks and historic sites. Another $10 million is requested by Question 7 to address drinking water and water pollution concerns.
The bond issue in Question 6 would provide $11 million to help create jobs through low-interest loans to small farm enterprises and small businesses with potential for growth.
Each bond issue is examined below. Question 4: Parks, historic sites Ballot Question 4 asks voters whether they support a $3 million bond issue to make capital improvements at state parks and historic sites. According to state officials, the objective of the bond issue is to "keep Maine's state park system a safe, attractive and vital part of the tourism economy."
The largest portion of the expenditure, $1.4 million, would fund the replacement of Churchill Dam, which controls water flow for canoeists and fisheries managers in the Allagash Wilderness Waterway.
"The Allagash is part of Maine's tradition and heritage, the epitome of the North Woods, and the most outstanding multiday canoe trip," said Herbert Hartman, director of the state Bureau of Parks and Lands.
The most recent dam was built in 1968, with a structural life expectancy of 15 to 20 years. A bond issue to replace the dam was defeated in 1990.
Hartman says deteriorating timbers at Churchill Dam have caused compression and settlement of the structure, impeding the proper function of the dam's gates. Continued deterioration would eventually result in the collapse of one or more of the timber cribs, making it difficult or impossible to control water levels. A consultant's study has predicted significant impacts on recreational resources if the dam is no longer functional. Water levels on Churchill and Eagle lakes are expected to drop from 3 to 7 feet depending on the season.
Chase Rapids, the renowned 9-mile stretch of the Allagash below Churchill Lake, would not be boatable during low-flow periods in July and August, and the stretch between Musquacook Stream and Michaud Farm would be as much as 20 percent lower.
The brook trout fishery would be diminished, and togue populations would drop as lower water levels adversely affected spawning areas, said Hartman. Waterfowl habitat would be reduced, as would flood control benefits.
The second-largest apportionment of bond issue funds would be $1 million to complete roof and masonry restoration at the Fort Knox State Historic Site in Prospect.
"Fort Knox is the state's most heavily visited historic site," said Hartman. "It's like the Allagash. It's one of the things that plays a unique role in the state's heritage."
The secretary of the interior has listed Fort Knox, a massive granite structure built to protect the Penobscot River in the mid-19th century, as a high-priority National Historic Landmark, due to the extent to which it is threatened by deterioration.
Funds would be used to finish final phases of capital improvements there.
Hartman said the Friends of Fort Knox, together with the bureau, had raised $900,000 toward improvements. But the roof is only half done, and interior masonry still needs work.
Friends spokesman George MacLeod says the fort has sustained water damage over the past 50 years due to failure of the roof and drainage system. The cumulative effects of moisture problems have caused sections of the fort to be closed to the public.
Without remedial work, the structure will soon pass the point of cost-effective restoration, MacLeod said recently.
The third expenditure of the bond issue would be $600,000 for renovations to make state parks and historic sites accessible to the disabled.
The Bureau of Parks and Lands has already provided some improved access, through existing funds, for its 50 state parks and historic sites. While new facilities under construction are being made accessible, significant needs remain at older sites.
Improved access to buildings, campsites, and recreational facilities is needed. Upgrades at public restrooms, pathways, trails, boardwalks, and parking lots would benefit the general public as well as the disabled, said Hartman.
By Stephany Boyd
Question 5: Environmental cleanup Hazardous-substance sites will be cleaned up, scrap tire stockpiles will be eliminated, and nearly two dozen Maine communities will be reimbursed for solid waste landfill closures if the $16.5 million "Environmental Bond," referendum Question 5, passes Nov. 5.
The Maine Department of Environmental Protection would use $2.5 million to investigate and clean up hazardous substance sites. Some $5 million would finance removal of tire stockpiles, and $9 million would be distributed to Maine cities and towns as reimbursement for closing solid waste landfills.
Since the mid-1980s, Maine voters have authorized $14.5 million for hazardous-substance cleanups. To date, the DEP has received and investigated 400 reports of contaminated sites. DEP officials say substantial work remains to be done at 50 locations.
In many of the cases, DEP officials say site investigation and cleanup costs are covered by the private parties who generated the hazardous substances.
Henry Aho, supervisor of the DEP's Uncontrolled Hazardous Substance Site Program, says much of the $2.5 million earmarked for hazardous substance cleanup would be used to cap an abandoned industrial landfill in the Oxford County town of Paris.
The balance, Aho said, would be used to deal with ground-water contamination affecting private residences in Ellsworth, PCB-contaminated soil at the Green Hill Quarry in Meddybemps and other long-overdue cleanup projects.
"We have sites which have been on the back burner for a while that we need to deal with," Aho said Thursday. "They are not sites in highly populated areas, but they need to be addressed."
On Route 1A north of Ellsworth, Aho said, the DEP has equipped six households with water filters. He said the ground water was contaminated by a waste oil collection operation from 1963 to 1980. He said the next step will be to pinpoint the contamination's origin and determine how best to deal with the hazardous material. In the Washington County town of Meddybemps, Aho said, the Green Hill Quarry contains gravel contaminated with polychlorinated biphenyls, commonly known as PCBs. He said the carcinogenic material is believed to have infiltrated the gravel from leaking electrical transformers. He said the gravel pit is not being quarried.
Aho said the Ellsworth and Meddybemps projects could wind up on the back burner again should another hazardous-substance site posing a greater public health threat surface. He said the Eastland Woolen Mill in Corinna has the potential to be one such site. He said chlorobenzene, a flammable liquid used to dye wool, has contaminated the immediate area's ground water.
"It's definitely a public health threat," he said. Voters will decide whether to authorize $5 million for the continued elimination of scrap tire stockpiles throughout Maine.
The state produces about 1.7 million scrap tires annually. The five largest piles boast 40 million scrap tires.
Jim Glasgow, a DEP environmental specialist, says tire stockpiles are a fire hazard. He said tire fires can cause significant environmental damage from toxic soot fallout and oil and water runoff.
"Our big focus has been fire," he said Thursday. "The only way we can have any assurance is to remove these tire stockpiles and send them to recycling operations."
Glasgow said the $5 million would be used to eliminate the state's largest pile of 20 million scrap tires in Bowdoin. He said stockpiles in Durham, Greenwood, Nobleboro and Meddybemps are also targeted.
If the Environmental Bond passes, $9 million will be distributed to Maine cities and towns that closed and capped their solid waste landfills during this year's construction season.
In the late 1980s, the Legislature mandated the closure of municipal landfills to protect drinking water supplies. To date, Maine voters have approved seven landfill closure bonds totaling $59 million. Some 261 of 392 municipal landfills have been shut down.
Ted Wolfe, coordinator of the DEP's Landfill Closure and Remediation Program, expects 22 municipalities will have closed their landfills by year's end and will be entitled to reimbursement. He said the state will reimburse 75 percent of the communities' costs.
Wolfe said Augusta, Waterville, Litchfield, Houlton, Corinna, Eastbrook, Franklin, Tremont, Jonesport, Columbia Falls, Danforth and Machias are among the communities that will likely benefit from the bond issue.
Wolfe said Maine has one of the most proactive landfill closure programs in New England.
By Letitia Baldwin
Question 6: Job growth, economy Tom Gocze runs Access Technologies, a small business in Bangor with big ideas. But as an inventor looking for ways to improve energy efficiencies in the home, Gocze has found it difficult to find backing for his projects.
Financial institutions are often gun-shy of new products which have not yet been proved and have no guarantee of success. And the banks, he said, are looking for immediate returns in a field where there are often dry spells and paybacks are sometimes slow.
In November, Maine voters will be asked on referendum Question 6 to approve $11 million in bonds aimed at making it easier for small businesses to upgrade or expand their existing facilities, spread out into new markets, or develop new products.
The bonds, if approved, would be broken down into two categories: $6 million for agriculture and natural resources-based industries and the remaining $5 million for enterprising businesses with high-growth potential.
Although Mainers have approved bond issue loans for the potato industry and for economic recovery during the credit crunch in the past, these new loans would reach businesses previously not afforded access to the low-rate loans.
"This bond issue is designed to meet needs that we've never tried to meet before," said Charles Mercer, director of external affairs for the Finance Authority of Maine, which would administer the programs. A special 11-member board appointed by the governor will make the decisions on the investments in the Small Enterprise Growth Program.
Both loan programs are revolving-door projects, meaning that as the loans are paid back, the funds will be made available for new loans.
Mercer said the loans are a way to create new jobs in emerging and expanding high-tech industries such as biotechnology, software development and pharmaceuticals at a time when traditional industries such as textiles and footwear are declining. They also are expected to help bolster other traditional Maine industries such as dairy farms and new ones such as cranberries.
Under the Small Enterprise Growth Fund, entrepreneurs and small-business owners would be able to borrow up to $150,000 to support their business efforts. The loans must be matched at least equally with funds from other sources, and borrowers are assessed a fee that would be used to cover any loan losses.
What makes this fund different is that loan repayments can be deferred. Interest still accrues on the loans but payment on these capital loans could be delayed for six months or a year, perhaps longer, giving companies time to develop their products and markets. Loans also could be paid back based on how well the company is doing.
"We want to give them time to breathe," Mercer said. Such a loan would have made a difference, Gocze said, with a project a few years ago that went sour. Gocze developed a hot-water heater that ran on solar power during the day and on electricity during off-peak times when electric rates were lower, saving the consumer money.
Gocze was given a FAME loan guarantee for only $72,000 on a loan from a bank and said the $150,000 maximum in the enterprise loan would have been better. The flexible repayment schedule could have helped Gocze expand into out-of-state markets where demand for solar power and use of off-peak electric rates was in greater demand. Instead, Gocze's funding ran out within a year while the bills have taken years to pay off.
The largest of the two loan programs, at $6 million, is the Agricultural Marketing Loan Fund. This loan fund expands upon the 1981 Potato Marketing Improvement Fund, which offered loans to help improve the quality and shelf life of Maine potatoes by funding improved storage facilities and centralized packing plants.
From about $5 million 15 years ago, the potato fund has grown to about $14 million, according to Mercer, and has resulted in a combined $32 million investment by banks, the businesses themselves and through the loans.
While the potato fund was limited to just one area, the Agricultural Marketing Fund will be open to businesses involved in aquaculture, animal husbandry, farms and businesses that process, store or market these products.
To be eligible, businesses can't borrow more than 55 percent of the cost of projects under $50,000 and 45 percent of the cost for projects that exceed $50,000.
John Harker, business development specialist with the Maine Department of Agriculture, sees many uses for it.
Aroostook County potato farmers could expand into alternative crops, such as wheat for the growing microbrewery industry or for feed for pig and beef operations in Canada. High-tech sprayers that reduce the amount of pesticides used on apple crops could be bought and apple crops could be bolstered by atmospherically controlled storage facilities and deer fences.
Gov. Angus King has pointed to Maine's developing cranberry industry as being ripe for these loans.
By Doug Kesseli
Question 7: Drinking water Towns ready to upgrade aging sewer treatment plants and public drinking water systems could qualify for funds if referendum Question 7 is approved by voters on Nov. 5.
The $10 million bond issue would provide $8 million to upgrade and replace water pollution control facilities and $2 million to improve public drinking water systems as required under the Safe Drinking Water Act.
Many Maine municipalities could benefit from the bond issue. The aim of several upgrades would be to eliminate pollution in coastal areas and streams, according to Dennis Purington of the Department of Environmental Protection. Areas now closed to shellfish harvesting could be reopened once treatment plants are upgraded or replaced, one of the largest projects the bond would fund.
According to Purington, $4 million of the bond proceeds would be directed toward replacement projects, with the Waldoboro Utility District expected to be the primary recipient. The Waldoboro district needs to replace its discharge system, which now does not meet environmental standards. Once replaced, the state could reopen adjacent areas to shellfish harvesting.
No bond issue has authorized funding for those types of facilities since 1993, Purington said.
The state's revolving loan fund could receive $2 million if the referendum passes, matching funds for $10 million in federal dollars. Several local communities, such as Bar Harbor, are now benefiting from the revolving loan program, which has an interest rate lower than the commercial rate. The fund helps municipalities upgrade sewage treatment facilities and eliminate or abate untreated discharges from sewer overflows.
Two $1 million projects are also included in the bond issue. The first, to be distributed through the Small Community Grants Program, could benefit individuals and businesses in more than 60 communities. Through that program, state grants would be directed to homeowners and businesses who need to upgrade their own sewage systems to eliminate inadequately treated discharges. Twenty-year loans are available through the program.
Communities which could benefit include Bangor, Brewer, Bucksport, Castine, Cherryfield, Clifton, Cranberry Isles, Dover-Foxcroft, Eagle Lake, Lubec, Otis, Sullivan, Swans Island and Winterport among many others.
The second $1 million would be distributed through the Overboard Discharge Program. Grants under that program target residential and commercial systems that discharge waste into shellfish harvesting areas or into small streams. There are 16 communities likely to win grants, if the bond is approved. They include Vinalhaven, North Haven, Owls Head and several other towns along the southern coast.
Public drinking water systems also will benefit if the bond issue passes. Two million dollars would be directed to a revolving loan program for communities which must upgrade their water systems to comply with the Safe Drinking Water Act.
Congress passed last month a revolving loan program for public water systems, which means the $2 million at the state level will be matched by $10 million in federal dollars.
More than 800 public water systems throughout the state could be eligible to receive loans through that program in 1997. A priority system, administered through the Bureau of Health's Drinking Water Program, will identify systems eligible for the first available dollars.
By Kathy Holliman

People: Hartman, Herbert Aho, Henry Gocze, Tom Mercer, Charles

Measure of intelligence

Author: Klose, Robert

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 Oct 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413887921?accountid=10457

Abstract: The gorilla affair actually reopens the book on animal intelligence in general. The sine qua non of natural science has traditionally been that only humans can think. This no longer seems true. If one denies that gorillas think, then [Binti]'s samaritan act must be attributed to instinct or reflex. But now we can't believe this. We have seen the evidence for ourselves: She carried the boy in a loving fashion to waiting arms rather than swing him about like a rag doll or tear him limb from limb. In Rwanda, by contrast, infants are thrown into the air by soldiers and bayonetted. Perhaps this is why the Binti affair came and went as quickly as it did. The hope was that this story would stir profound and protracted human interest. But no one wanted to think about it too much. It is my opinion that Binti knew exactly what she was doing. Gorillas are territorial, and no doubt her territorial instincts were aroused by the appearance of a human inside her compound. She had a choice, then: Save the child or do it harm. Given the number of human onlookers, she chose wisely. Had she hurt the child in any way, she would have been summarily shot and Descartes would have carried the day.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Measure+of+intelligence&amp;author=Klose%2C+Robert&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-10-24&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Not long ago much was made of the rescue of a 5-year-old boy by a gorilla. The boy had fallen 18 feet into the gorilla pit at an Illinois zoo and was retrieved -- with compassion aforethought -- by a large female, who carried the child with utmost care to anxious zookeepers.
I say much has been made of this. And rightly so. Humans, exhausted from their exertions in Bosnia, Rwanda, and Chechnya, are ready to seize upon any evidence -- no matter how slender the thread -- of humanity in their own species, if only out of nostalgia.
It is ironic that the thread of humanity they have seized upon was presented not by Homo sapiens, but by a near (and, if the DNA technologists have their way, getting nearer) relative, Gorilla gorilla. The event was enough to make a Republican blush with shame. And if Binti (the gorilla's name) sniffs good and hard, she will smell revisionism in the air: These creatures are not so bad after all; perhaps their time line on earth should not be puncutated by the profiteers.
The gorilla affair actually reopens the book on animal intelligence in general. The sine qua non of natural science has traditionally been that only humans can think. This no longer seems true. If one denies that gorillas think, then Binti's samaritan act must be attributed to instinct or reflex. But now we can't believe this. We have seen the evidence for ourselves: She carried the boy in a loving fashion to waiting arms rather than swing him about like a rag doll or tear him limb from limb. In Rwanda, by contrast, infants are thrown into the air by soldiers and bayonetted.
Which are the beasts? The picture grows muddled. Actually, animal behaviorists have suspected for a long while that animals think and that they experience emotions. I once saw a sort of sliding scale in a book, an inclined line illustrating the degree of thought evident in different animal groups. At the top of the grade were humans; slightly below them, the gorillas and chimps; followed by other primates, down through canines, felines, and precipitously bottoming out with lizards, mollusks, and academic trustees.
The advocates of the intellectual life of animals have several darlings among some of the big-brained species -- apes, dolphins, and seals. Each in its way has stirred scientists with its ability to comprehend and, in the case of chmps and gorillas, generate quasi-human language. These latter can't vocalize, but they have been taught to use sign language to get their human keepers to do their bidding.
And yet there is evidence aplenty that bigness of brain has little to do with intelligence. Larger parrots, for example, have walnut-size brains, and yet they have been taught to fabricate whole sentences, and in tones which connote their emotional state at the time. One famous papagei by the name of Alex, upon realizing that his owner was about to leave him at the vet, begged, "Come here. I love you. Wanna go back." It is enough to bring a gentle tear to the cheek of the hardened skeptic.
Interestingly enough, humans of 100,000 years ago already had brains of the present size; brains fully capable of sending a man to the moon or deciphering the genetic code. But they contented themselves with the meanest existence and produced only the crudest stone tools.
So what is it that prevents scientists and interested persons in general from whooping to the cause of animal intelligence? Or rather, who is it? The answer is Descartes, the amateur number jumbler of the 17th century. When he wasn't teaching math to the Queen of Sweden at ungodly hours of the morning, he was forging a philosophy of resistance to the idea that animals can think. For if they could, then they would be entitled to moral rights. At a time when moral rights were already in short supply among humans, so squandering any on animals was not even a consideration.
Perhaps this is why the Binti affair came and went as quickly as it did. The hope was that this story would stir profound and protracted human interest. But no one wanted to think about it too much. It is my opinion that Binti knew exactly what she was doing. Gorillas are territorial, and no doubt her territorial instincts were aroused by the appearance of a human inside her compound. She had a choice, then: Save the child or do it harm. Given the number of human onlookers, she chose wisely. Had she hurt the child in any way, she would have been summarily shot and Descartes would have carried the day.
Robert Klose is an associate professor of biological science at University College in Bangor.

Courts

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]17 Oct 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413815666?accountid=10457

Abstract: Travis S. Baston, 20, Ogunquit, illegal transportion of liquor by minor, license susended 30 days. Christopher A. Bolduc, 20, Biddeford, illegal transportation of liquor by minor, license suspended 30 days. Marion L. Healing the wounds

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]11 Oct 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413889740?accountid=10457

Abstract: If we read the story carefully, we see that the crime of Sodom was attempted rape, not "sodomy." In only a few scattered passages does the Bible condemn gay sex. Most of those passages are part of a "holiness code" that Christians have considered to be no longer valid. The fundamentalists emphasize parts of the Bible that seem to condemn gays, while they ignore similar passages that say people who work on the Sabbath should be executed, that forbid us to touch the skin of a dead pig (like a football), forbid the eating of shellfish, or forbid us to cut our beards. We must ask, why are only the condemnations of gays to be obeyed, when the rest of the "holiness code" is no longer considered valid?

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Healing+the+wounds&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-10-11&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: There are many churches, and even more interpretations of the Bible. But some people, like Will Nott (Letter, Oct. 1), have a hard time understanding how others could have an interpretation different from their own.
My understanding of the Bible suggests that the command that we love one another is stronger than any possible condemnation of gay sex. There's not much about homosexuality in the Bible, considering how big a book it is. It says much more about love, justice, and compassion than about gay sex. The Ten Commandments never condemn homosexuality, and neither did Jesus. But Jesus did condemn the self-righteous religious leaders who judged and condemned others.
If we read the story carefully, we see that the crime of Sodom was attempted rape, not "sodomy." In only a few scattered passages does the Bible condemn gay sex. Most of those passages are part of a "holiness code" that Christians have considered to be no longer valid. The fundamentalists emphasize parts of the Bible that seem to condemn gays, while they ignore similar passages that say people who work on the Sabbath should be executed, that forbid us to touch the skin of a dead pig (like a football), forbid the eating of shellfish, or forbid us to cut our beards. We must ask, why are only the condemnations of gays to be obeyed, when the rest of the "holiness code" is no longer considered valid?
In the New Testament, only Paul mentions homosexuality. But Paul thought is would be best for everyone to remain celibate. Most of us ignore that recommendation. Jesus said, "judge not, so that you will not be judged." In the Gospels, he mentioned love 47 times, and forgiveness 22 times. We would do well to follow such an example.
It is time to heal the wounds caused by last year's referendum. But now the same people who brought us that divisive referendum are circulating a new petition. They want to outlaw gay marriage, which is already against state and federal law. Another law to outlaw something that's already outlawed, just to stop something that isn't happening! We don't need another divisive referendum. I will decline to sign any such petition.
Rev. J. Mark Worth
Ellsworth

Officials lift oil-spill ban on shellfishing

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]09 Oct 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413857052?accountid=10457

Abstract: The ban on any type of fishing in Portland's inner harbor continued Tuesday as a result of the 170,000 gallon oil spill, but the state has lifted a shellfishing ban that covered 80 square miles.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Officials+lift+oil-spill+ban+on+shellfishing&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-10-09&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PORTLAND -- The ban on any type of fishing in Portland's inner harbor continued Tuesday as a result of the 170,000 gallon oil spill, but the state has lifted a shellfishing ban that covered 80 square miles.
The Department of Marine Resources lifted the shellfishing ban from Cape Elizabeth to the Royal River in Yarmouth Monday as crews continued to clean up the spill.
The shellfishing restrictions were put in place after the tanker Julie N struck the Million Dollar Bridge between Portland and South Portland on Sept. 27, spilling heating oil and bunker fuel that spread up the Fore River to Stroudwater Marsh.
Federal scientists have abandoned the use of a solvent called Corexit to flush oil from the marsh, noting that the solvent had thinned the oil to the point where it could not be recovered.
About 200 workers continued the cleanup Monday.
