____________________________________________________________

Penobscot Bay to be probed top to bottom

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]08 Oct 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413813582?accountid=10457

Abstract: In the study, which is expected to take several years, scientists will gather information on the bay's depths, makeup of the sea floor, circulation patterns, intertidal habitat, concentrations of chlorophyll, sea temperatures and the land cover of the Penobscot region. That information will be used to improve management of wild fisheries, such as lobster and urchins, to reclaim polluted or depleted clam flats, to restore inshore stocks of cod and haddock and to further develop the aquaculture industry. Organizations joining in the project are the University of Maine Geological Survey, the Bigelow Laboratory for the Ocean Sciences, Maine Maritime Academy, the Maine Office of Geographical Information Systems (GIS), the Department of Marine Resources, the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery, the Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife, and the Environmental Research Institute of Michigan, which has expertise in satellite mapping and a long-standing relationship with NOAA.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Penobscot+Bay+to+be+probed+top+to+bottom&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-10-08&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: AUGUSTA -- Gov. Angus King announced Monday the launching of a public-private venture that will give Maine its first up-close and scientific look at the rich yet largely unknown marine environment of Penobscot Bay.
The Penobscot Bay Marine Research Collaborative is funded by a $600,000 grant from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and administered by the Island Institute.
It will bring together nine research and marine resource organizations for a thorough surface-to-bottom study of the bay that is the critical link between the state's largest upland watershed and the Gulf of Maine.
King said one of his guiding principles in developing environmental policy "has been that we need better science. There have been a number of occasions when we've had to make decisions without data, a leap of faith. This is a major step in getting the data we need to provide a detailed look at what's over, under and in Penobscot Bay."
In the study, which is expected to take several years, scientists will gather information on the bay's depths, makeup of the sea floor, circulation patterns, intertidal habitat, concentrations of chlorophyll, sea temperatures and the land cover of the Penobscot region. That information will be used to improve management of wild fisheries, such as lobster and urchins, to reclaim polluted or depleted clam flats, to restore inshore stocks of cod and haddock and to further develop the aquaculture industry. Organizations joining in the project are the University of Maine Geological Survey, the Bigelow Laboratory for the Ocean Sciences, Maine Maritime Academy, the Maine Office of Geographical Information Systems (GIS), the Department of Marine Resources, the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery, the Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife, and the Environmental Research Institute of Michigan, which has expertise in satellite mapping and a long-standing relationship with NOAA.
Stressing that the goal of the study will be practical applications rather than just assembling data, King said the first step in meeting the challenge of economic development in Maine "is to identify our assets, and one of our major assets is the ocean. If we're going to use the ocean to benefit people's lives, we have to know what's out there. This is a crucial step towards making our coast as vital as it once was."
King praised the Island Institute for bringing the project together, saying the Rockland-based private, nonprofit organization "took the lead in developing the kind of public-private partnership we need. This is not a regulatory program in any way -- it's gathering information that will help us make better decisions about Penobscot Bay."
Researchers will use methods that combine satellite, aircraft, shipboard and land-based measurements to produce information and maps of the various layers of the bay. The results will be maintained at the Maine GIS office and will be available to fishermen and all others who use marine resources. Updates on the project will be available on the Internet's World Wide Web via the state of Maine home page.
As an example of the kind of practical applications the study could produce, Marine Resources Commissioner Robin Alden said that, while fishermen and scientists have had considerable success recently raising cod in hatcheries, "we know very little about releasing them into the wild -- we don't know enough about currents or where there are the proper bottom sediments. With this study, we can look at existing larval cod areas and determine the characteristics that can lead to successful restoration programs." The Penobscot Bay project is the second such effort funded by NOAA, the first being a study of the coast of south Florida.
Bob Feder of NOAA said, while the Florida project focused upon assessing and repairing the damage done to the marine environment by the extensive draining of swamps and development, the Maine study "is geared more toward keeping a relatively healthy ecosystem healthy, of how we can strike a balance between the environment and the economy.
"A tremendous team of public and private organizatins has been put together for this, and the result will be to bring the user of marine resources much closer in to the policy planning process, to create a true feeling of ownership. These people working hand-in-hand will leave something lasting -- a legacy -- to the people of Maine."

Cleanup continues after tanker crash Maritime Overseas Corp. promises to compensate area fishermen for oily losses

Author: Victoria Brett The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]30 Sep 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413835764?accountid=10457

Abstract: Cleanup crews continued to remove oil from the waters of Portland Harbor on Sunday, two days after a tanker slammed into a drawbridge, spilling 170,000 gallons of fuel oil. Fishermen, meanwhile, wondered when they could get back to work and how they would be compensated for their losses. George Blake, executive vice president of Maritime Overseas Corp., which owns the tanker, the Julie N, apologized to fishermen "for the destruction this unfortunate accident has caused." He assured that they would be compensated for damage to their boats, gear, and lost income. Fishermen were urged to take claim forms at the meeting. After the crash, 170,000 gallons of heating oil and the boat's own fuel spilled into the Fore River that runs between Portland and South Portland. As of midday Sunday, 300 cleanup workers from up and down the East Coast had recovered about 300,000 gallons of oil and water. Officials refused to speculate on what percentage of the spilled fuel had been recovered.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Cleanup+continues+after+tanker+crash+Maritime+Overseas+Corp.+promises+to+compensate+area+fishermen+for+oily+losses&amp;author=Victoria+Brett+The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-09-30&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PORTLAND -- Cleanup crews continued to remove oil from the waters of Portland Harbor on Sunday, two days after a tanker slammed into a drawbridge, spilling 170,000 gallons of fuel oil. Fishermen, meanwhile, wondered when they could get back to work and how they would be compensated for their losses.
Portland Harbor remained closed, but the Coast Guard said it would allow small commercial vessels to come and go as long as they called in their plans first.
"We don't want to impede the commercial fishing industry," Coast Guard Cmdr. Burt Russell said to more than 200 fishermen who turned out for a meeting Sunday afternoon.
But Eugene Bellanceau, a lobsterman from Windham, said his son couldn't even use their boat if he wanted to: It's covered in thick, black oil.
"Our boat was white, but it's black now," he told officials. "We set 300 lobster traps a year and now we can't set any."
Bellanceau and other fishermen with oiled boats, were urged not to use their vessels, because it would just create small oil slicks.
George Blake, executive vice president of Maritime Overseas Corp., which owns the tanker, the Julie N, apologized to fishermen "for the destruction this unfortunate accident has caused." He assured that they would be compensated for damage to their boats, gear, and lost income. Fishermen were urged to take claim forms at the meeting.
"We do recognize the financial impact on you and the fisheries. We intend to deal fairly with you," he said.
The Department of Marine Resources has issued a ban on fishing, lobstering and shellfish harvesting. The ban on shellfish -- clams and mussels -- extends as far east as Harpswell.
Pete McAleney, owner of New Meadows Lobster in Portland, was concerned about the immediate impact to the fisheries, but also the long-term reputation of Casco Bay lobster.
"If they smell like oil we'll refuse them," he said. "I'm not taking a chance by selling contaminated lobster."
McAleney, a wholesale dealer, buys about 25,000 pounds of lobster a day. Lately, he hasn't bought any.
"The protection of the marine environment remains our number one priority," said Cmdr. Russel "A great deal of people remain actively involved in this extensive recovery operation."
Containment and cleanup efforts started shortly after the Liberian-flagged tanker hit the Million Dollar Bridge on Friday morning, tearing a 30-foot gash in the ship's hull and damaging the quarter-mile drawbridge.
After the crash, 170,000 gallons of heating oil and the boat's own fuel spilled into the Fore River that runs between Portland and South Portland. As of midday Sunday, 300 cleanup workers from up and down the East Coast had recovered about 300,000 gallons of oil and water. Officials refused to speculate on what percentage of the spilled fuel had been recovered.
Four miles of containment boom snaked around the 560-foot Julie N, which remained docked at a terminal about a mile upriver from the damaged bridge.
Workers from federal and state wildlife agencies searched for birds injured by the oil. About a dozen birds were being treated by wildlife rehabilitators at an emergency center at the South Portland Armory. The Marine Animal Rescue Unit, which is affiliated with the New England Aquarium, surveyed the harbor for seals affected by the spill.
Lois Winter, of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, said eight seals were spotted Sunday swimming in oil-slicked waters. Winter said that when oil gets into their fur, the seals can lose buoyancy, lose insulation and suffer hypothermia. Clumps of fur may also fall out.
The seals did not appear distressed, but Winter said it takes several days for the oil to affect the mammals.
The Million Dollar Bridge, meanwhile, remained closed to traffic Sunday, but operators were able to lower and raise the drawbridge. The Maine Sunday Telegram reported that the 80-year-old bridge may have moved about 2 inches when the boat hit, and engineers were uncertain whether the two spans would align when the drawbridge was closed.
The National Transportation Safety Board was investigating the crash but said it could be months before a cause is released. A local harbor pilot was on the tanker's bridge when the ship, which is 10 feet narrower than the 95-foot opening in the drawbridge, hit the bridge on one side then bounced to the other side.
Illustration Caption: A veterinarian at an animal rescue center established at the South Portland Armory uses a feeding tube to rehydrate a bird that was the victim of the oil spill Friday in Casco Bay. (AP Photo)

Company / organization: Name: Maritime Overseas Corp; NAICS: 483111

Pine Hill club to mark hunting day anniversary

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]26 Sep 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413825702?accountid=10457

Abstract: The Pine Hill Shooting Club will celebrate the 25th anniversary of National Hunting and Fishing Day with demonstrations, exhibits and chances to try several shooting sports, including archery, Saturday at the Oyster River Range.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Pine+Hill+club+to+mark+hunting+day+anniversary&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-09-26&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: WARREN -- The Pine Hill Shooting Club will celebrate the 25th anniversary of National Hunting and Fishing Day with demonstrations, exhibits and chances to try several shooting sports, including archery, Saturday at the Oyster River Range.
The program will be held from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Saturday, Sept. 28, at the range off Route 90. Visitors may try their hand at muzzleloading, .22 rifle, shotgun and other firearms with help from qualified instructors.
The celebration will focus on the family outdoor tradition and long-standing commitment of America's hunters and anglers to wildlife conservation, organizers said. For information or to reserve space for an exhibit, call Robin Overlock at 273-2308.

East Coast fishing income up for '95

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]18 Sep 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413859909?accountid=10457

Abstract: Before 1994, Massachusetts had always taken first place. "Maine has better fish populations and has historically promoted diversification," [Jon Gibson] said, adding that Maine fishermen harvested 57 different species last year. "Maine is somewhat fortunate in that regard," Gibson said. "Many of the species are located mostly in the Gulf of Maine and not so much in the south." According to the National Marine Fisheries Services, commercial fisheries in the Northeast Region, which stretches from Virginia to Maine, brought in $983.1 million in revenue, with Maine topping the list. (AP Photo)

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=East+Coast+fishing+income+up+for+%2795&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-09-18&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PORTLAND -- Fishermen along the Eastern Seaboard sold their catch for more money in 1995 than in the previous year, despite the dramatic decline of New England groundfish and the Chesapeake Bay's eastern oyster, federal officials said Tuesday.
Revenue from commercial fisheries last year totaled $983 million, with Maine leading the 10-state region with $273.6 million, and Massachusetts following with $216.3 million, said Jon Gibson, spokesman for the National Marine Fisheries Service.
The total revenue for the area stretching from Maine to Virginia increased by 8 percent compared to 1994 and 11 percent over 1993.
Maine fishermen outsold their counterparts for the second year in a row by relying on their trademark lobster and diversifying their catch with high-value species such as sea urchin, shrimp and farmed Atlantic salmon.
Before 1994, Massachusetts had always taken first place. "Maine has better fish populations and has historically promoted diversification," Gibson said, adding that Maine fishermen harvested 57 different species last year.
"Maine is somewhat fortunate in that regard," Gibson said. "Many of the species are located mostly in the Gulf of Maine and not so much in the south."
Of all the fisheries, lobster was the moneymaker. New England harvested 66.1 million pounds of lobster in 1995 worth $206.6 million -- a 29 percent increase since 1993.
"In terms of value, lobsters are what carry the industry," Gibson said.
Sea scollops followed with 17 million pounds for $89 million, and blue crab collected $75 million. Others topping the list were the Atlantic salmon, menhaden, the surf clam, northern quahog and the sea urchin.
"What we have seen over the long haul is the decline in the importance of the actual fish species and an increase in the nonfish, like the bivalve, mollusks and crustaceans," Gibson said. Every state in the region, with the exception of Rhode Island and New Jersey, showed increased revenue over the 1993-1995 period. Delaware fishermen brought in the least money at $9 million.
Virginia's revenue increased the most -- 69 percent -- between 1993 and 1995, thanks to the harvest of more than 752 million pounds of menhaden, an industrial fish used in fish meal and fish oil, Gibson said.
But Virginia -- ranking third with $111.2 million in revenue -- and surrounding states also suffered with the collapse of the pricey eastern oyster, found in the Chesapeake Bay. Revenue from oyster decreased by 84 percent since 1993 because of two oyster diseases, MSK and Dermo. Fishermen harvested 9.2 million pounds worth $35.9 million in 1993, and only 1.8 million pounds in 1995 worth $5.8 million dollars.
"The eastern oyster is to that part of the country as the groundfish are to this part of the country," said Gibson in Woods Hole, Mass. "The difference is we haven't seen such a sharp decline so quickly. It's been gradual here."
Stocks of New England groundfish have been dropping since 1980, and are now at an all-time low, primarily because of overfishing. The Northeast's three traditional groundfish species -- cod, haddock and yellowtail flounder -- collectively accounted for revenue of $35.8 million in 1995, a 38 percent decrease since 1993. Groundfish now account for less than 4 percent of the region's earnings.
But while fishing revenues have increased overall, don't quit that day job to lead the seemingly romantic life of a lobsterman or fisherman.
The fishing industry is generally not a growing business. "It's still a hard way to make a living," said urchin diver Jim Bolen of Friendship. "It's getting scary enough that anyone else who has something to do should look at that to cover their butt."
Illustration Caption: According to the National Marine Fisheries Services, commercial fisheries in the Northeast Region, which stretches from Virginia to Maine, brought in $983.1 million in revenue, with Maine topping the list. (AP Photo)

People: Gibson, Jon

Cleaner water may be helping clam flats

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]20 Aug 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413818610?accountid=10457

Abstract: Shellfish officials in Freeport plan to open the last 200 acres of clam flats closed by old household sewage systems. Areas in Harpswell and Phippsburg and Wiscasset have also been approved for clamming. And about 1,000 acres of mudflats near Rockland were opened recently because of a new sewage treatment plant on the St. George River. In 1991, when Mick McGivaren began sampling the water in the Harraseeket River in Freeport, 70 percent of the flats were closed. Now -- after those last 200 acres are opened -- 98 percent of the flats will be deemed safe for digging.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Cleaner+water+may+be+helping+clam+flats&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-08-20&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: FREEPORT -- Cove by cove, stretches of previously closed clam flats in Maine have become open to diggers in recent years. Some say it's a sign of cleaner water.
In Casco Bay, in 1993, 44.5 percent of the bay's flats were closed. By 1995, the percentage of closed flats had dropped to 37 percent.
"What it means to me is progress and success and I hope that percentage closed continues to decline," said Paul Anderson, director of the shellfish sanitation program for the Maine Department of Marine Resources.
Shellfish officials in Freeport plan to open the last 200 acres of clam flats closed by old household sewage systems. Areas in Harpswell and Phippsburg and Wiscasset have also been approved for clamming. And about 1,000 acres of mudflats near Rockland were opened recently because of a new sewage treatment plant on the St. George River.
The ratio of open to closed clam flats is considered an environmental benchmark of how clean the water is.
In the late 1980s, the federal government began using stricter criteria for classifying shellfish areas. Those changes were so severe that many states had to close areas and put in new programs, said Anderson.
"Now, what we're seeing is the fruits of our labors. Our databases are flush with water quality data," he said.
In 1991, when Mick McGivaren began sampling the water in the Harraseeket River in Freeport, 70 percent of the flats were closed. Now -- after those last 200 acres are opened -- 98 percent of the flats will be deemed safe for digging.
"I'm seeing cleaner waters," said McGivaren. "Everybody's much more sensitive to the cleanliness of our waters and our shores."
But, while agreeing that the numbers indicate progress on the environmental front, others cautioned that there are other reasons for clam flats re-opening and there's still more to do to decrease pollution.

Casco Bay caterpillars target of spray bid Insect causing reactions in islanders, survey says

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]15 Aug 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413912084?accountid=10457

Abstract: Survey results will go to the state Board of Pesticide Control and state legislators from the area, said George Flaherty, Portland's manager for island affairs. City officials hope that if they can prove the caterpillars are a health threat, Portland will get state permission for wider spraying of the pesticide Dimilin. In May, with property owners' permission, the city hired a crop-duster to spray the pesticide over parts of Peaks, Great Diamond and Cushing islands. The same contractor sprayed two privately owned islands, Clapboard and Sturdivant, and parts of Falmouth on the mainland.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Casco+Bay+caterpillars+target+of+spray+bid+Insect+causing+reactions+in+islanders%2C+survey+says&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-08-15&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PORTLAND -- Officials are hoping a new survey detailing health problems caused by the browntail moth caterpillar on Portland's Casco Bay islands will persuade the state to use more pesticides to get rid of them.
The survey conducted this summer shows that 84 percent of those responding suffered skin rashes as a result of the tiny hairs on the caterpillars. Twenty-one percent said they had respiratory problems.
Survey results will go to the state Board of Pesticide Control and state legislators from the area, said George Flaherty, Portland's manager for island affairs. City officials hope that if they can prove the caterpillars are a health threat, Portland will get state permission for wider spraying of the pesticide Dimilin.
In May, with property owners' permission, the city hired a crop-duster to spray the pesticide over parts of Peaks, Great Diamond and Cushing islands. The same contractor sprayed two privately owned islands, Clapboard and Sturdivant, and parts of Falmouth on the mainland.
Dimilin is considered harmless to humans and other mammals, birds and fish. But some island residents, particularly on Peaks, oppose its use because it can harm lobsters and other shellfish, and because its long-term effects on health and the environment are unknown.
Because of the opposition on Peaks Island -- the bay's most populous island -- only the island's southwest corner was sprayed. That ensured that the pesticide could not drift onto properties where owners didn't want it.
Residents in areas that weren't sprayed have continued to suffer from the caterpillars this summer.
The respiratory problems and rashes occur principally in June and July, when the caterpillars mature.
The caterpillar hairs carry a toxin that has plagued islanders each summer for at least two years. The hairs get airborne and either drift against exposed skin or fall on items that people handle.
Some people react so violently to the caterpillar toxin that hospital emergency treatment, or prescription steroids, has been necessary.

Title: Casco Bay caterpillars target of spray bid Insect causing reactions in islanders, survey says:   [ALL Edition ]

First Class Act Postmaster makes Cranberry Island center of far-flung community

Author: Letitia Baldwin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]03 Aug 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413853864?accountid=10457

Abstract: Behind the scenes, busily sorting the day's mail, is Islesford Postmaster Joy Sprague. Sporting burgundy-red nails and a black "Sting" cap acquired at a recent concert of her favorite rock star, she cuts a flamboyant figure compared with most postal workers clad in official pinstriped shirts and blue pants. Speaking from Boston, U.S. Postal Service spokeswoman Alicia Gamow says the phenomenal growth in sales and revenue of the Islesford post office's Stamps by Mail service is proof Sprague's novel approach works. The daughter of an Islesford lobsterman who died at sea, Sprague has spent most of her life on Little Cranberry. A single mother with two daughters, she has been postmaster for nearly two decades. As a teen, she began working at the post office as a leave replacement. She became the youngest postmaster in the United States when she took over that job at the age of 20.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=First+Class+Act+Postmaster+makes+Cranberry+Island+center+of+far-flung+community&amp;author=Letitia+Baldwin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-08-03&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: CRANBERRY ISLES -- These summer days, Beal & Bunker's mailboat, Sea Queen, makes a 10 a.m. run to Little Cranberry Island about three miles off Mount Desert Island. Coarse canvas sacks stamped "U.S. Mail," along with crates of milk and other freight, are lifted off the boat onto a pickup truck waiting on the pier.
Loaded to the gunwales, the battered, black Toyota trundles up the road, past pink rugosa rosebushes and piles of green-wire lobster traps speckled with barnacles, to the Islesford Market in Little Cranberry's village, where the village post office is housed.
Literally a hole in the wall, the tiny post office occupies a corner of the store. Its window is framed by dozens of old metal mailboxes. Islanders young and old cluster around it. They chat and check out their boxes, anticipating the appearance of a letter.
Mail time is the high point of daily life in Islesford. Summer or winter, the ritual of going to the store and fetching the mail brings people out of their homes, binding together this small island community that boasts about 82 winter inhabitants and scores more summer people.
Behind the scenes, busily sorting the day's mail, is Islesford Postmaster Joy Sprague. Sporting burgundy-red nails and a black "Sting" cap acquired at a recent concert of her favorite rock star, she cuts a flamboyant figure compared with most postal workers clad in official pinstriped shirts and blue pants.
While black boxes on post office counters across the United States display postal transactions, the blue-eyed postmaster's radiant smile and friendly manner -- her personal touch -- have hundreds of people ordering postage stamps through the mail from her tiny Maine post office. She has filled orders from all over the United States and the globe, including Mexico, Turkey, Saudi Arabia, Puerto Rico and the Fiji Islands.
The U.S. Postal Service's "Stamps By Mail" program enables customers to order their postage stamps through the mail to avoid standing in line and other inconveniences. Orders are filled and returned postage-free.
Over the past decade, the Islesford post office's annual revenue from the Stamps By Mail service has skyrocketed. In the late 1980s, annual sales topped only a couple thousand dollars.
This year, they've hit $59,000. And that's not counting earnings over the next two months before fiscal 1996 ends.
The Islesford post office now ranks No. 1 in Maine for mail-order stamp sales.
Strangely enough, most of the Islesford postmaster's Stamps By Mail customers have never met her in person, nor have they ever set foot on Little Cranberry. But they know all about the church fair, the masquerade ball, the Christmas pageant, the Wits and Nitwits variety show and other happenings on the island.
Homespun approach
For years now, Sprague has enclosed with each stamp order a rambling, personal letter, handwritten in her unmistakable curlicue cursive, and a color snapshot of sea smoke swirling in the harbor, a double rainbow over a beach or another island scene.
In one letter last December, she described a winter solstice celebration on the island:
"At the coast guard beach, many came and gathered around a blazing bonfire. Enjoying music on tape by Paul Winter, we also made several six-foot-tall snowmen complete with kelp tongues," she wrote. "Snow clouds slowly made their way south, leaving behind a crystal-clear midnight sky pierced with diamond-like stars. The longest night of the year is tucked behind us."
Speaking from Boston, U.S. Postal Service spokeswoman Alicia Gamow says the phenomenal growth in sales and revenue of the Islesford post office's Stamps by Mail service is proof Sprague's novel approach works.
"Joy is really enthusiastic and puts her whole heart into whatever she does," Gamow says, recalling how Sprague once skipped rope to work as part of the Portland post office's commute-another-way program.
The Islesford post office's success comes at a time when other small post offices in Maine and across the nation have either shut down or are threatened with closure. A century ago, just about every Maine village boasted its own post office, but today only about 444 remain.
Another world
Born and raised in Islesford, Sprague says the post office and general store are the heart of the island. She and storekeeper Susie "Soos" Krasnow seem like soul sisters. Between them, the two women have created a unique, homey atmosphere.
"We offer the community a place where you can feel comfortable hauling up a chair, having a cup of coffee and joking around,"
Sprague says.
Walking into the old, red-shingled building housing the store and post office is like stepping into another time, a surreal world, or onto the set of a TV sitcom. A black-spotted plastic cow dangles from the ceiling. A gigantic poster of Marilyn Monroe adorns the wall. A pink satin ballet slipper and a necklace of bleached whelks and periwinkle shells hang beside mailboxes. A bouquet of pink lilies and carnations graces the post office counter.
In the store section, an older gentleman has fallen asleep in a wicker chair. Oblivious to the din, he has been napping for about half an hour while his sister shops and chit-chats. A dollhouse stands in between a mink teddy bear, Quaker Oats and Chinese sweet and sour sauce on the shelves. A xylophone and children's books are tucked beneath Oysterettes, Wheat Thins and other crackers. A striped, tail-less Manx cat prowls the aisle.
The daughter of an Islesford lobsterman who died at sea, Sprague has spent most of her life on Little Cranberry. A single mother with two daughters, she has been postmaster for nearly two decades. As a teen, she began working at the post office as a leave replacement. She became the youngest postmaster in the United States when she took over that job at the age of 20.
Home to far-flung community
More than five years ago, Sprague decided some ceremony was in order when a year-round resident became her 100th sender of the U.S. Postal Service's overnight and special delivery service, Express Mail. She presented a homemade batch of brownies to the customer.
But brownies just didn't seem enough fanfare.
"I thought of cream puffs," says Sprague, whose mother makes the decadent treats for the church fair and Saturday night bean suppers. "They just look like a party."
The postmaster began awarding cream puffs to every 25th Express Mail sender, establishing a tradition that has snowballed. The luscious sweets, with chocolate tumbling down the sides, weigh about 7 ounces apiece on the mail scale. Senders are photographed with their treats. Dubbed "The Cream Puff Hall of Fame," the photos hang on the post office wall.
Sprague credits Great Cranberry Island Postmaster Leigh Liebow with giving her the idea of writing a personal letter to Stamps By Mail customers. She says Liebow sends a friendly note to summer residents in the fall, reminding them to order their Christmas stamps.
The Islesford postmaster expanded on the idea, enclosing a personal letter and photo with each stamp order. She keeps a wide selection of stamps on hand, tailoring orders to her customers'
tastes.
For instance, a New York City resident once requested stamps to match her purple stationery. She received the abolitionist Harriet Tubman stamp and others containing purple, lilac, lavender and violet hues.
Or there's the artist in Reno, Nev. He told the postmaster he likes "things and pretty women." These days, she has been sending him Marilyn Monroe and antique car stamps.
Initially, Sprague's mail-order stamp customers were mostly summer people longing for Islesford. But news of the folksy letter, scenic photo and customized service spread. Pretty soon, strangers were placing orders.
Besides keeping the post office and her job intact, the island postmaster says it has been personally rewarding to connect with so many people. She says her customers treat her like a family friend, sending photos of weddings and other milestones in their lives. She says some appear at the post office and introduce themselves.
One California customer has proposed to her twice in person.
"He says, `Will you marry me, Joy?"' says Sprague, who is holding out for Sting. "He has done it twice now."
Just the other day, she received a card from John and Pauline Dullanty of Cambridge, Mass. The couple enclosed photos of themelves.
"We are watching the Olympics and thought of writing a note to our gold medal member of the U.S. Postal Service to say `thank you' for all the nice things you do for all your loyal followers," the Dullantys wrote. "Roses are red. Violets are blue. It's really a pleasure to send our thanks to you."
There are the two Dominican nuns in Detroit, Mich. They planned to visit Islesford, but one of them is battling cancer.
"She is being very courageous about it," Sprague says. "The therapy seems to be going well."
Or there's the fellow at the North Hampton County offices in Easton, Pa. Learning of Sprague's black standard poodle, Hemingway, he sent the canine a box of dog biscuits.
"He said, `Give the mutt a hug,"' she says, chuckling.
What is it about Sprague and the island that is attractive? The way she explains it, it sounds like the mystique surrounding Garrison Keillor's Lake Wobegon.
"I think it's the fact it's an island and the unique way of life that people find hard to imagine -- like being at the end of the dock with two weeks' worth of groceries and a nor'easter blowing." The postmaster muses. "I think people in America want that connection of a small community. They want to look {at} and feel a time that's being lost in this country."
Islesford summer resident Sarah Corson is among the postmaster's devotees. She loves to juxtapose stamps of jazz musician Louis Armstrong and Impressionist painter Mary Cassatt.
"I place her ear just above his trumpet," she says.
Corson says Sprague's stamps, letters and photos provide her with a spiritual link to Islesford during the winter. But she adds that the postmaster's joyful outlook is uplifting.
"She creates an atmosphere in which other people want to give," she reflects, noting that her husband has been known to play his accordion on the store's steps. "Joy is a metaphor for possibility."
Illustration Caption: Joy Sprague at work on Little Cranberry Island. Joy Sprague shows off some of the cream puffs she gives to customers. (NEWS Photos by Michele Stapleton)

Company / organization: Name: Postal Service; NAICS: 491110

Shellfish hatchery wins state grant Beals Island program needs funds to up production of soft-shell seed clams

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]31 July 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413806177?accountid=10457

Abstract: During the past 10 years, the hatchery has produced an annual average of 12 million half-inch soft-shell clams for stock enhancement purposes. Clams have been seeded on intertidal flats in 25 of the 45 coastal communities that have shellfish management programs. Hatchery-reared seeds have been planted in flats as far south as Kittery and as far east as Eastport.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Shellfish+hatchery+wins+state+grant+Beals+Island+program+needs+funds+to+up+production+of+soft-shell+seed+clams&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-07-31&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BEALS ISLAND -- The State Planning Office has awarded a $35,000 Coast Program grant to the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery, said Evan D. Richert, director of the office.
The grant is part of the office's "Investing in Washington County" initiative, a partnership with county residents to identify the most promising economic sectors and make state investments in them.
The grant will be used toward increased production of soft-shell seed clams; a shoreline survey of Cobscook Bay; and to improve communication between the clam hatchery and county communities regarding stock enhancement and water quality problems.
The grant also will fund several research projects on clams.
The Beals Island hatchery was established in 1987 and until 1995 was administered by the University of Maine at Machias, which also provided technical assistance and limited financial aid.
In January 1996, the hatchery program began its 10th year with a new administrative partner, a 16-member board of directors made up of individuals from academia, government, finance, business and industry.
During the past 10 years, the hatchery has produced an annual average of 12 million half-inch soft-shell clams for stock enhancement purposes. Clams have been seeded on intertidal flats in 25 of the 45 coastal communities that have shellfish management programs. Hatchery-reared seeds have been planted in flats as far south as Kittery and as far east as Eastport.
There have been technical advances in nursery and field grow-out phases of the program including the development of methods of overwintering clams -- rather than seeding flats in the fall -- that alter first winter survival rates from less than 20 percent to greater than 85 percent; and the discovery, through field experimentation, of factors that enhance growth and survival, such as the appropriate time of year to plant, optimal stocking densities, appropriate seeding areas, and the type of protective netting to use to deter predators.

Company: Beals Island

Shellfish market in clampdown Dealers, diggers, eateries feel pinch of flat closings

Author: Doug Kesseli Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]22 July 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413808360?accountid=10457

Abstract: As the summer tourism season peaks, shellfish flats from Portland to Matinicus Island -- the heaviest producers of clams and other shellfish -- were still closed this weekend to harvesters because of health concerns. Diggers remained idle, forcing some restaurants and fresh seafood markets to take steamers off their menus or go digging into the Canadian markets to bring steamers to their customers. Wholesale prices are expected to go up even when the ban is lifted and the supplies of clams recover. Before the ban, clams cost The Lobster Pound Restaurant in Lincolnville Beach about $75 per bushel; now they cost about $80. A restaurant official expects prices to increase by $10 per bushel or more once the ban is lifted because it is peak season. Whether it was helping the restaurant or hurting it, demand for the steamers has been down since the ban was put into effect. Some customers are hesitant to order clams in light of the ban, [Peter McLaughlin] said, although the restaurant only buys clams that are certified. Normally the restaurant sells about 40 bushels of steamed and fried clams during the week, but because of the ban it sold about six or seven bushels fewer than normal last week.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Shellfish+market+in+clampdown+Dealers%2C+diggers%2C+eateries+feel+pinch+of+flat+closings&amp;author=Doug+Kesseli+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-07-22&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Tropical Storm Bertha and subsequent rainstorms may have soaked much of the state, but they have left many clam diggers and dealers high and dry.
As the summer tourism season peaks, shellfish flats from Portland to Matinicus Island -- the heaviest producers of clams and other shellfish -- were still closed this weekend to harvesters because of health concerns. Diggers remained idle, forcing some restaurants and fresh seafood markets to take steamers off their menus or go digging into the Canadian markets to bring steamers to their customers.
The July 14 ban on digging for clams, mussels, quahogs and oysters was partially lifted last week and is expected to be lifted for most of the remainder of the state today as conditions have improved, said Paul Anderson, director of the Shellfish Sanitation Program for the state.
The ban was withdrawn for flats east of the Penobscot River and west of Cape Elizabeth Thursday, a few days after the ban went into effect. This left the restriction in place for flats from Portland Head Light to Matinicus Island as well as some more sensitive areas such as theBagaduce and Scarborough rivers and their estuaries.
Anderson said although much of the state's flats will no longer be restricted, some areas more sensitive to pollution, such as the Kennebec River region and the Medomak River region, may remain restricted areas for a few more days.
State authorities instituted the ban in the wake of Bertha, which dumped nearly a half-foot of rain in some areas. As a result, water bacteria surged above acceptable levels as some sewage treatment plants were pushed beyond capacity and overflowed into rivers that feed into the ocean.
"Obviously we want to open them as quick as possible within the boundaries of prudent public health," said Robin Alden, commissioner for Marine Resources.
Such flooding and subsequent bans aren't unusual. It's just the timing of this one that is drawing attention and concern in the state. Most bans in the past have occurred following springtime thaws and floods. This ban is hitting home for Mainers who rely on tourists' appetites for the shellfish.
"It's been real hard on both of us, dealers and diggers," said Roger Feltis, who not only harvests clams but also serves as a dealer, brokering them to local markets and into other states, like Massachusetts, where the clams can fetch higher prices.
Feltis, who operates Roger Seafood in Waldoboro, said prices diggers are getting for shellfish like clams were already abnormally low -- about $50 per bushel -- compared with several years ago when they were about $80 per bushel at this point in the year. Now, diggers will have to scramble to make up the lost time or lose a week in the clamming season that closes in the early fall.
Wholesale prices are expected to go up even when the ban is lifted and the supplies of clams recover. Before the ban, clams cost The Lobster Pound Restaurant in Lincolnville Beach about $75 per bushel; now they cost about $80. A restaurant official expects prices to increase by $10 per bushel or more once the ban is lifted because it is peak season.
But for some businesses still without clams, speculation about prices is premature.
At Jess's Market on South Main Street in Rockland, fresh whole clams for steaming are usually a big seller. With the ban still in effect, Jess Wiggin, the market's owner, is coming up empty-handed for the steamers. That means fewer sales and fewer customers coming in.
The only clams in the store are the deeper-water variety, the Mahogany clams or those found in cans on the store's shelves.
Wiggin, a certified seafood dealer, has erased the price of clams on the billboard in front of his store.
Wiggin had thought he was prepared for Bertha's repercussions. He had stocked up on clams and oysters before the storms hit.
"You have to think ahead in the seafood business," he said in his still-busy market.
Wiggin bought 30 bushels of the clams, three times what he'd normally pick up. The clams didn't last and by about midweek last week, he ran out.
At the Landing Restaurant in Rockland, with no steamers available, the chefs and cooks were busy preparing shrimp coctail as an appetizer for customers who had a yearning for seafood.
Up the coast from Rockland at Lincolnville Beach, however, steamers were available at the Lobster Pound Restaurant. But Executive Chef and Vice President Peter McLaughlin had to tap markets in Canada to get these steamers, and supplies were running low. McLaughlin estimated the restaurant had enough steamers to last through the weekend and perhaps into the early part of the week.
Whether it was helping the restaurant or hurting it, demand for the steamers has been down since the ban was put into effect. Some customers are hesitant to order clams in light of the ban, McLaughlin said, although the restaurant only buys clams that are certified. Normally the restaurant sells about 40 bushels of steamed and fried clams during the week, but because of the ban it sold about six or seven bushels fewer than normal last week.
McLaughlin looks at the ban as part of the price to be paid for doing business in Maine.
"It's normal," he said. "It's a given that the state is going to shut it down."

People: Wiggin, Jess McLaughlin, Peter

Shellfish ban ends in 2 coastal areas Flats east of Penobscot River safe

Author: Letitia Baldwin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]19 July 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413828708?accountid=10457

Abstract: Last weekend's torrential rains prompted the DMR Sunday to close the entire Maine coast to shellfish harvesting after the heavy rains caused some sewer treatment plants to overflow and discharge raw sewage into the sea. The emergency action followed the deluge that began Saturday. In a 24-hour period, Belfast got 5.5 inches of rainfall, while Ellsworth received 3 inches.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Shellfish+ban+ends+in+2+coastal+areas+Flats+east+of+Penobscot+River+safe&amp;author=Letitia+Baldwin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-07-19&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Clam diggers as well as tourists and Mainers hankering for steamers or a basket of fried clams will be relieved to hear the ban on shellfish harvesting has been lifted in two sections of the Maine coast.
The Maine Department of Marine Resources Thursday removed the prohibition on harvesting clams, mussels, quahogs and oysters east of the Penobscot River and west of Cape Elizabeth.
Harvesting is still barred in a section of coastline stretching from the Portland Head Light to Matinicus Island as well as the Bagaduce and Scarboro rivers and their estuaries.
The DMR's water quality specialists have been out taking water samples to ensure coastal flats that previously had been open to harvesting are not polluted following the recent spell of heavy rainfall.
"We've found the water quality is clean enough to warrant an opening," David Dennison, a water quality specialist at the DMR's Lamoine laboratory, reported Thursday.
Last weekend's torrential rains prompted the DMR Sunday to close the entire Maine coast to shellfish harvesting after the heavy rains caused some sewer treatment plants to overflow and discharge raw sewage into the sea. The emergency action followed the deluge that began Saturday. In a 24-hour period, Belfast got 5.5 inches of rainfall, while Ellsworth received 3 inches.
DMR officials say such closures are not uncommon. They say the closures are usually imposed when rainfall is heavy in the fall, early spring or in the aftermath of a hurricane. One such shellfish harvesting ban occurred last year and another early this past spring.

____________________________________________________________

Rain halts shellfish harvesting Sewage plants flooded

Author: Letitia Baldwin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]16 July 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413840089?accountid=10457

Abstract: State marine resource officials banned shellfish harvesting along the Maine coast Sunday after heavy weekend rains caused some sewage treatment plants to overflow and discharge raw sewage into the sea. The Department of Marine Resources indefinitely prohibited all forms of harvesting clams, mussels, quahogs and oysters. The prohibition could last up to a week, said David Dennison, a DMR water quality specialist at the department's Lamoine laboratory. Maine Shellfish in Ellsworth supplies clams, mussels, quahogs and other shellfish to hundreds of stores, restaurants and other businesses and institutions around Maine. Plant Manager Stephen Beathem said such closures can have far-reaching effects on business.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Rain+halts+shellfish+harvesting+Sewage+plants+flooded&amp;author=Letitia+Baldwin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-07-16&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: State marine resource officials banned shellfish harvesting along the Maine coast Sunday after heavy weekend rains caused some sewage treatment plants to overflow and discharge raw sewage into the sea.
The Department of Marine Resources indefinitely prohibited all forms of harvesting clams, mussels, quahogs and oysters. The prohibition could last up to a week, said David Dennison, a DMR water quality specialist at the department's Lamoine laboratory.
The DMR took the emergency action following the torrential rains that began Saturday. Within a 24-hour period, Belfast got 5.5 inches of rain and Ellsworth got 3 inches, said Dennison.
"This is greatly in excess of the normal rainfall," he said. "Such a heavy inflow of water can cause sewage treatment plants to overflow and directly discharge fecal matter into the ocean."
Castine, Machias, Yarmouth and Thomaston were among the coastal communities where treatment plants overflowed, according to the DMR.
Paul Anderson, head of the DMR's shellfish sanitation program, said the closure is a precautionary measure until his department's water quality specialists are able to take water samples and ensure that coastal flats previously open to harvesting are not polluted.
Anderson said such closures are not uncommon. He said they usually are imposed when rainfall is heavy in the fall, early spring or in the aftermath of a hurricane. He said one such shellfish harvesting ban occurred last year and another early this spring.
The closure comes at a time of the summer when millions of visitors pour into the state to sample "steamers" and other traditional Maine fare.
Maine Shellfish in Ellsworth supplies clams, mussels, quahogs and other shellfish to hundreds of stores, restaurants and other businesses and institutions around Maine. Plant Manager Stephen Beathem said such closures can have far-reaching effects on business.
"It shortens up your supply and drives prices really high," he said Monday. "Course, you have a certain amount on hand but that can run out."
Josette Pettegrow runs the 40-year-old Trenton Lobster Pound just before the Thompson Island Bridge linking the mainland and Mount Desert Island. She recalled one year when the flats were closed for most of the season.
"Right now, it doesn't have much impact on us. We had a {refrigerated} supply prior to the closure," she said Monday. "I feel much better having the closure than having someone get sick."
Illustration Caption: David Dennison, a Department of Marine Resources water quality specialist, tests water Monday off Lamoine Beach. (NEWS Photo by Kevin Bennett)

____________________________________________________________

Firm claws its way to top

Author: Kyle, Bruce

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]13 July 1996: A1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413924545?accountid=10457

Abstract: BEALS ISLAND--By the time the dishes are cleared from Maine's annual 40-million pound lobster feed, we Americans have gobbled, slurped and splashed our way through about 20 million pounds of the ultimate white meat, succulent and butter-drenched. That's the good part. Rotting out on the national back porch is a mammoth 10,000-ton trash bag- of stink-to-high-heaven lobster shells, bodies and goop--garbage so foul we swear next year we'll order out pizza. Down on Beals Island, generations-old Carver Shellfish Inc. is working to bring some modern table manners to the business, first by having launched a quick-frozen tail and claw line, which could send the lobster bib to the ash bin of history, and now by developing a process to turn every scrap of waste into something useful. (excerpt)

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Firm+claws+its+way+to+top&amp;author=Kyle%2C+Bruce&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-07-13&amp;spage=A1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   BEALS ISLAND--By the time the dishes are cleared from Maine's annual 40-million pound lobster feed, we Americans have gobbled, slurped and splashed our way through about 20 million pounds of the ultimate white meat, succulent and butter-drenched. That's the good part.
Rotting out on the national back porch is a mammoth 10,000-ton trash bag- of stink-to-high-heaven lobster shells, bodies and goop--garbage so foul we swear next year we'll order out pizza.
Down on Beals Island, generations-old Carver Shellfish Inc. is working to bring some modern table manners to the business, first by having launched a quick-frozen tail and claw line, which could send the lobster bib to the ash bin of history, and now by developing a process to turn every scrap of waste into something useful.
"We've been working for four years to add as much value as possible to lobster, to move away from merely selling an unimproved natural resource," says Raoul Pelletier, a career veteran of the food-processing industry who heads up the waste-recovery project. "The first phase was the frozen product, which we believe is every bit as good as fresh in taste and texture and vastly superior in consistency. The second phase we're in now is to recover value from the waste, to turn what has been a major liability for the industry into an asset."
The waste recovery project is funded in part by a $37,500 Fishing Industry Grant from the U.S. Department of Commerce through a program to help the industry develop new products and markets.
The heart of the project is a machine adapted from the poultry industry that separates lobster waste into two components: a meat paste and a ground powder of shell and fiber.
The paste, an orange pate, can be used as the base for soups, sauces, salad dressings, stuffings, perhaps even lobster burgers. Carver's will be working with the University of Maine Food Science Department this year to develop marketable products and to conduct taste-test focus groups.
The shell and fiber powder has been chemically analyzed and found to have great potential as a nutrient-rich additive to high-quality fertilizer and to feed for the salmon aquaculture industry.
"None of this is totally new," Pelletier said. "The Canadians have been extracting paste for years, the shells and bodies have been composted, but we're trying to take it to a level where one day the lobster industry will be waste free, where, instead of paying a composter to haul off our waste, we have a valuable product to sell."
The Maine lobster industry is riding high on several consecutive years of record harvests in the 40-million pound range, but Pelletier, like many, believes a drop back to the traditional harvests of 20 to 25-million pounds is inevitable.
"We're dealing with Mother Nature here, with cycles we cannot control," he said. "Right now, the predators of young lobsters--such as cod and haddock--are in decline, so the lobster population is up. When the predators come back, lobster will level off. When that happens, lobstermen will really see the benefits of adding more value to the product.
"I've worked in virtually every part of the food industry--candy, produce, fish, poultry--and this is the key everywhere: extract the maximum out of your raw material, turn what you've been throwing away into a product with value."
Only about 8 to 10 percent of Maine lobsters are processed, with the bulk going to the live market. Brent Beal, plant manager of Carver's Island Maid brand frozen shellfish line, says overcoming the public belief that the only good lobster is a live lobster will take time and an industry dedicated to quality.
"Anyone who buys live lobster knows what happens--you get one that's perfect, one that's tough as leather and one that's mush," Beal said. "With our quick-freeze process and quality control, the inferior lobsters never make it to market, the customer never gets a bad lobster. Our packaging has five layers of protection. We run abuse tests. We constantly evaluate quality. Right now, we're up to an 18-month shelf life with no loss of quality."
Carver's spotless processing plant produced about 800,000 pounds of cryogenically frozen lobster product last year and is aiming for a million this year, nearly all going to restaurants and hotels. About three-fourths of the product is raw green tails and the rest pre-cooked claws.
"The big surprise has been the claws," Beal said. "We sold 200,000 pounds last year and could have sold twice that if we'd had it. The Las Vegas casinos love them. We score the shell so you can just snap it open. They make great finger food."
While 40 million pounds of lobster worth more than $100 million is a pretty big deal down on the docks, Pelletier says lobstermen need to take a closer look at how they fit into the big food-industry picture.
"In the food business, 40 million pounds is nothing. Americans eat 40 million pounds of candy a day," he said. "The lobster industy has been under this terrible disadvantage of having to sell a live product. Imagine what would happen to the poultry industry if people suddenly thought they had to bring live chickens home from the store.
"Every sector of the food industry has the same challenge--deliver a product that is high quality, consistent and convenient and cut your waste to the absolute minimum. If you don't use it, you lose it

Subject: Waste materials; Seafoods; R & D; Food processing industry; Corporate profiles

Classification: 8610: Food processing industry, includes beverages & liquors; 5400: Research & development

____________________________________________________________

Firm claws its way to top Maine man says recycling lobsters may buoy profits

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]13 July 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413869829?accountid=10457

Abstract: "We've been working for four years to add as much value as possible to lobster, to move away from merely selling an unimproved natural resource," says Raoul Pelletier, a career veteran of the food-processing industry who heads up the waste-recovery project. "With our quick-freeze process and quality control, the inferior lobsters never make it to market, the customer never gets a bad lobster. Our packaging has five layers of protection. We run abuse tests. We constantly evaluate quality. Right now, we're up to an 18-month shelf life with no loss of quality."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Firm+claws+its+way+to+top+Maine+man+says+recycling+lobsters+may+buoy+profits&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-07-13&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BEALS ISLAND -- By the time the dishes are cleared from Maine's annual 40-million pound lobster feed, we Americans have gobbled, slurped and splashed our way through about 20 million pounds of the ultimate white meat, succulent and butter-drenched. That's the good part.
Rotting out on the national back porch is a mammoth 10,000-ton trash bag of stink-to-high-heaven lobster shells, bodies and goop -- garbage so foul we swear next year we'll order out pizza.
Down on Beals Island, generations-old Carver Shellfish Inc. is working to bring some modern table manners to the business, first by having launched a quick-frozen tail and claw line, which could send the lobster bib to the ash bin of history, and now by developing a process to turn every scrap of waste into something useful.
"We've been working for four years to add as much value as possible to lobster, to move away from merely selling an unimproved natural resource," says Raoul Pelletier, a career veteran of the food-processing industry who heads up the waste-recovery project. "The first phase was the frozen product, which we believe is every bit as good as fresh in taste and texture and vastly superior in consistency. The second phase we're in now is to recover value from the waste, to turn what has been a major liability for the industry into an asset."
The waste recovery project is funded in part by a $37,500 Fishing Industry Grant from the U.S. Department of Commerce through a program to help the industry develop new products and markets.
The heart of the project is a machine adapted from the poultry industry that separates lobster waste into two components: a meat paste and a ground powder of shell and fiber.
The paste, an orange pate, can be used as the base for soups, sauces, salad dressings, stuffings, perhaps even lobster burgers. Carver's will be working with the University of Maine Food Science Department this year to develop marketable products and to conduct taste-test focus groups.
The shell and fiber powder has been chemically analyzed and found to have great potential as a nutrient-rich additive to high-quality fertilizer and to feed for the salmon aquaculture industry.
"None of this is totally new," Pelletier said. "The Canadians have been extracting paste for years, the shells and bodies have been composted, but we're trying to take it to a level where one day the lobster industry will be waste free, where, instead of paying a composter to haul off our waste, we have a valuable product to sell."
The Maine lobster industry is riding high on several consecutive years of record harvests in the 40-million pound range, but Pelletier, like many, believes a drop back to the traditional harvests of 20 to 25-million pounds is inevitable.
"We're dealing with Mother Nature here, with cycles we cannot control," he said. "Right now, the predators of young lobsters -- such as cod and haddock -- are in decline, so the lobster population is up. When the predators come back, lobster will level off. When that happens, lobstermen will really see the benefits of adding more value to the product.
"I've worked in virtually every part of the food industry -- candy, produce, fish, poultry -- and this is the key everywhere: extract the maximum out of your raw material, turn what you've been throwing away into a product with value."
Only about 8 to 10 percent of Maine lobsters are processed, with the bulk going to the live market. Brent Beal, plant manager of Carver's Island Maid brand frozen shellfish line, says overcoming the public belief that the only good lobster is a live lobster will take time and an industry dedicated to quality.
"Anyone who buys live lobster knows what happens -- you get one that's perfect, one that's tough as leather and one that's mush," Beal said. "With our quick-freeze process and quality control, the inferior lobsters never make it to market, the customer never gets a bad lobster. Our packaging has five layers of protection. We run abuse tests. We constantly evaluate quality. Right now, we're up to an 18-month shelf life with no loss of quality."
Carver's spotless processing plant produced about 800,000 pounds of cryogenically frozen lobster product last year and is aiming for a million this year, nearly all going to restaurants and hotels. About three-fourths of the product is raw green tails and the rest pre-cooked claws.
"The big surprise has been the claws," Beal said. "We sold 200,000 pounds last year and could have sold twice that if we'd had it. The Las Vegas casinos love them. We score the shell so you can just snap it open. They make great finger food."
While 40 million pounds of lobster worth more than $100 million is a pretty big deal down on the docks, Pelletier says lobstermen need to take a closer look at how they fit into the big food-industry picture.
"In the food business, 40 million pounds is nothing. Americans eat 40 million pounds of candy a day," he said. "The lobster industy has been under this terrible disadvantage of having to sell a live product. Imagine what would happen to the poultry industry if people suddenly thought they had to bring live chickens home from the store.
"Every sector of the food industry has the same challenge -- deliver a product that is high quality, consistent and convenient and cut your waste to the absolute minimum. If you don't use it, you lose it."
Illustration Caption: Carver Shellfish Inc. markets quick-frozen lobster tails and claws. (NEWS Photo by Bruce Kyle)

People: Pelletier, Raoul Beal, Brent

Company: Carver Shellfish Inc

Manatee deaths blamed on red tide Scientists had feared infectious disease

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]03 July 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413873363?accountid=10457

Abstract: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- An unusual outbreak of red tide was to blame for the mysterious deaths of a record number of manatees this spring, scientists said Tuesday. Red tide is a toxic micro-organism that accumulates in shellfish. When the manatee deaths began in March, the red tide bloom was the worst it had been at that time of year since 1982, when a similar manatee die-off took place. Initially, scientists said red tide wasn't to blame because the pace of deaths was too quick and no sick or disoriented animals had been found, said Scott Wright, chief scientist for the Department of Environmental Protection.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Manatee+deaths+blamed+on+red+tide+Scientists+had+feared+infectious+disease&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-07-03&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- An unusual outbreak of red tide was to blame for the mysterious deaths of a record number of manatees this spring, scientists said Tuesday.
The finding is good news since it means the deaths weren't caused by an infectious disease that manatees could spread among themselves or carry to other areas. But it's bad news, scientists say, because there's no way to prevent it from happening again.
"These are natural occurrences," said Thierry Work, a scientist from the National Wildlife Health Center. "Large numbers of animals die but we can't control it. You can't stop a volcano."
Red tide is a toxic micro-organism that accumulates in shellfish. When the manatee deaths began in March, the red tide bloom was the worst it had been at that time of year since 1982, when a similar manatee die-off took place.
Between March 5 and April 27, 158 of the whiskered walrus-like animals in southwest Florida died, pushing the total deaths for the year to 304 -- a grim record. The previous record was set in 1990 when 206 manatees died.
Initially, scientists said red tide wasn't to blame because the pace of deaths was too quick and no sick or disoriented animals had been found, said Scott Wright, chief scientist for the Department of Environmental Protection.
Scientists suspected a viral infection or some new type of red tide.
But after testing water and manatee blood samples, scientists from the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta and the National Marine Fisheries Service found evidence of red tide.
They said cold winter temperatures forced the manatees to gather in the warmer waters of southwest Florida, where the red-tide concentrations were highest.
Manatees migrate from the Carolinas to Florida every winter. They have inhabited Florida's waters for the past 45 million years, but due in part to increasing motorboat traffic, their numbers have dwindled to about 2,600.

Mirror, Mirror In looking for a wood product they could build and sell, a Franklin couple finds a classic

Author: Letitia Baldwin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]29 June 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413817836?accountid=10457

Abstract: The Williamses' hunch proved to be a good one. A little over a year after moving to Maine in 1990, they began producing small wood-framed mirrors in a workshop adjoining their Cape home in the Hancock County town of Franklin. They have gone from selling several hundred a year to fine gift shops largely in Maine to supplying a couple thousand annually to retail stores as far afield as Washington state -- even Japan. Their pieces also have been carried in well-known catalogs such as Yield House, Eddie Bauer, Sugar Hill and Ballard Designs. Combing the weekly newspapers, they found a rental ad for a farmhouse and barn in Milbridge. They put down a two-month deposit on the property, sight unseen, and headed north. At first, Avis peddled the wood-framed mirrors out of the back of her Isuzu Trooper, selling to gift, bath, lighting, framing and furniture shops along the Maine coast. Sheepscot Pottery in Edgecomb was one of the couple's early accounts.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Mirror%2C+Mirror+In+looking+for+a+wood+product+they+could+build+and+sell%2C+a+Franklin+couple+finds+a+classic&amp;author=Letitia+Baldwin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-06-29&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Mirrors. They can create airiness and illusions of space in a room. They can enhance lighting and add a touch of elegance to a home.
Straightforward to build, and not so big they can't be shipped directly from their shop, framed mirrors seemed promising to Hugh and Avis Williams seven years ago when they were looking for a wood product they could build and sell together.
The Williamses' hunch proved to be a good one. A little over a year after moving to Maine in 1990, they began producing small wood-framed mirrors in a workshop adjoining their Cape home in the Hancock County town of Franklin. They have gone from selling several hundred a year to fine gift shops largely in Maine to supplying a couple thousand annually to retail stores as far afield as Washington state -- even Japan. Their pieces also have been carried in well-known catalogs such as Yield House, Eddie Bauer, Sugar Hill and Ballard Designs.
Initially, the Williamses built all of the mirrors themselves. Now, they employ three people.
"When we moved to Maine, we really wanted to create a lifestyle that we had control over, and we really like to work with our hands to create things," said Avis. "Hugh and I have no children together, so this product is our baby. The business and our employees have become, in a sense, a family."
Classic designs and consistent quality come to mind when describing the Williamses' line of wood-framed, beveled mirrors.
Turned rosette blocks -- the kind found on door frames and window casings in 19th century New England houses -- grace some of the mirrors. Others feature ornaments pressed from old Victorian dies and crown and dentil molding.
The Williamses' frames are made largely from Eastern white pine, but some come in oak and cherry with an oil finish. Others boast a stained or painted finish ranging in hues from mustard to burgundy. These days, the most popular style has been a crackled, lightly distressed finish.
Shaded by a row of old, handsome maples, the Williamses' granite-gray clapboard home with cream-colored trim and their adjacent workshop sit on a rural road winding along the eastern shore of Hog Bay in Franklin. Blue, green, brown and white antique bottles line the windowsills. A crab trap with small oyster shells caught in the wire mesh hangs as a sculpture on the wall.
Over coffee and freshly baked blueberry buckle, the Williamses relate that they previously lived in Wilmington, N.C. -- that state's largest seaport -- at the mouth of the Cape Fear River. She ran her own dress shop. He worked as a free-lance finish carpenter in the boat-building industry. Working with fine wood such as teak and mahogany, he finished the often-extravagant interiors of cruising sailboats measuring as long as 55 feet.
The two married in 1989. For years, Hugh had enjoyed an ideal living situation. He rented a charming saltwater farmhouse framed by live oak trees dripping with moss for the amazing price of $65 per month. He recalls his landlady lamenting when she had to boost his rent to $50 from $45.
"I hate to see things go up," he recalls her saying.
But the landlady died, leaving the property to her Lutheran church, and he was forced to move out.
By that time, Hugh and Avis had decided they were ready for a change of scenery. She had lived in Yarmouth and Kennebunk before and had always had it in mind to move back to Maine. Combing the weekly newspapers, they found a rental ad for a farmhouse and barn in Milbridge. They put down a two-month deposit on the property, sight unseen, and headed north.
Both driving vehicles hauling trailers behind, the Williamses and their two cats arrived in Milbridge to find their prospective Maine home unlivable. Leaving one of their vehicles and the two trailers in the driveway, they rented a motel room for the night and set out in search of an empty house to rent.
"We turned left from Route 200 onto the Hog Bay Road and drove a ways," remembers Hugh. "I said, `Avis that house doesn't look lived in."'
The clapboard Cape happened to be for rent. They moved in that night and have been there ever since. They ended up buying the place less than a year later.
During the couple's first year in Maine, Avis landed work hanging floral wallpaper in a shingle-style summer cottage on Grindstone Neck in Winter Harbor. That job led to Hugh's being hired to remodel the kitchen and upstairs bathroom in the same house.
The Williamses say it was Hugh's construction of some wooden frames for Franklin painter and sculptor Phil Barter that inspired the idea of coming up with a small wooden product they could make together.
At first, Avis peddled the wood-framed mirrors out of the back of her Isuzu Trooper, selling to gift, bath, lighting, framing and furniture shops along the Maine coast. Sheepscot Pottery in Edgecomb was one of the couple's early accounts.
"Luckily, mirrors fit into a variety of stores," Avis says. "They are good complements."
The Williamses credit the state-run Small Business Development Center's Maine Products Marketing Program with helping them devise a marketing strategy. They began traveling to trade shows in New York, Philadelphia and High Point, N.C.
"We were a little fish in a big ocean," she says. Adding to their delight, they found few if any exhibitors selling mirrors.
"There was almost nobody."
The trade shows were an education to the couple, who learned how to price and position their product for the wholesale market. They also acquired a sales representative.
The latest wave in furniture has been the worn look, so the Williamses learned the five-step crackled finish technique. First, a base coat of paint is applied to the frame. Next, a layer of glue is put on, followed by a topcoat and a clear coat of lacquer.
"You can watch it crackle before your eyes," says Avis, adding that the frames are lightly sanded in key spots to enhance the worn look.
The Williamses' latest coup has been to land a request from the Atlanta-based Ballard Designs retail catalog, which features fine home and garden furnishings, for an inventory of 450 mirrors.
Scrambling to fill the order, they also are preparing to show their product line at trade shows in Atlanta and Los Angeles.
In the midst of all this, the couple has bought and is renovating a more-than-a-century-old clapboard store -- known for years as Jerry's Hardware -- and adjacent buildings where they hope to relocate their shop.
The Williamses attribute their success to plain hard work.
"We put in an enormous amount of effort into making the business fly," says Hugh. "We are really on top of the quality control. You don't want to have to replace a mirror. That is as expensive as making it all over again."
Hugh also sees their ability to work together as key.
"I usually defer to Avis as long as I agree with her," he says, chuckling.
Illustration Caption: Avis and Hugh Williams are reflected in one example of their work. The couple produces several thousand mirrors a year. (NEWS photo by Michele Stapleton)

Company / organization: Name: Avis Inc; NAICS: 532111, 533110; DUNS: 00-697-7326
