____________________________________________________________

Unearthing the past Volunteers dig up the dirt on Red Paints

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]27 June 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413858610?accountid=10457

Abstract: Amateur mother and daughter archaeologists [Susan Moore] and Jessica Moore of Boylston, Mass., check through the pieces left after sifting a bucket of dirt removed from the [DeWitt Goddard] dig. (NEWS Photo by Scott Haskell) [Roger Willis] of Dover-Foxcroft and digging partner [Steve Gargiulo], a Falmouth teacher, examine rock fragments uncovered in their square at the Goddard site in Brooklin. (NEWS Photo by Scott Haskell) Steve Gargiulo (left), a Falmouth teacher, and Roger Willis of Dover-Foxcroft sift a bucket of dirt removed from the Goddard site in Brooklin. A whetstone (top right) was one of the items uncovered on the first day of field digging. (NEWS Photo by Scott Haskell)

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Unearthing+the+past+Volunteers+dig+up+the+dirt+on+Red+Paints&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-06-27&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BROOKLIN -- In a remote field near Naskeag Point, Steve Gargiulo gets precisely what he has paid for -- the privilege of troweling the same small patch of earth nearly incessantly for a week.
Scoop in hand, perched like a child at the edge of a sandbox, the bearded, purple-clad Gargiulo clearly is pacing himself as the midday sun blazes overhead. Seasoned by a previous dig in Searsmont, the amateur archaeologist patiently smooths away another layer of blackish soil in the 5-square-foot pit he shares with a partner.
"I'm taking it one scrape at a time," says the Falmouth schoolteacher, smiling. After all, what has been waiting for hundreds and thousands of years deserves painstaking care.
Like Gargiulo, many of the tuition-paying volunteers at the Maine State Museum's third annual field school confess to the allure of a common fantasy: finding an artifact on a par with the 11th century Norse coin amateur archaeologist Guy Mellgren turned up here at the Goddard site nearly 40 years ago.
"Oh, it would be real chummy to find another one," one ardent digger says.
That lone Norse coin found in 1957 helped focus the attention of state museum archaeologists on the privately owned site within an old shorefront estate named for its owner, DeWitt Goddard.
Archaeologists concluded the silver coin was introduced to the site through trade between local Indians and peoples to the northeast, possibly from Newfoundland or as far away as Greenland.
Although no other evidence suggesting a Norse presence here has been found, artifacts from several periods have inspired continuing fascination with the site, says field school project director Dr. Steven Cox, a state museum archaeologist.
So far the site has yielded 15,000 objects, including stone tools and pottery vessels. Many of the items, including the Norse coin, are on display at the museum in Augusta.
An article Cox co-wrote with colleague Bruce Bourque after their work at Goddard in 1979 and 1980 concluded that the site was a "major summer village during the period of Norse visits to North America, and that its population participated in extensive trade networks ultimately reaching as far north as Ramah Bay, Labrador."
The site appears to have been occupied, at least intermittently, for thousands of years. The epochs best represented by artifacts are the "late ceramic" from 1,000 to 500 years ago, and the "Moorehead phase" of 4,000 to 3,700 years ago.
Cox says the primary aim of this field school session, ending June 28, is to expand upon the findings of archaeologist Warren K. Moorehead, whose work in the early part of the century focused on burial grounds of the so-called Red Paint People living in what is now New England and Nova Scotia.
The name comes from the discovery of a reddish pigmented material found in the soil of the burial sites. Cox refers to the Red Paints as "Moorehead people" and areas such as Goddard known to contain their artifacts as "Moorehead sites."
Goddard is one of a very few Moorehead sites yet excavated that is not a burial ground, says Cox, and this is the first dig there since 1980. Cox hopes the current crew will unearth habitation features such as pits with datable food bones, allowing researchers to "isolate points in time."
"We know a lot about how Mooreheads buried people, but what I'm interested in is how they lived. Some of the most interesting stuff we haven't gotten to yet," Cox says of the digging.
By the middle of their first week, field school participants working as deep as 10 inches into the six pits were only beginning to hit the reddish-brown soil signaling a transition into the Moorehead period.
"The deeper you go, the earlier you get. We're just starting to come into subsoil," says field archaeologist Laurie LaBar-Kidd, adding, "This is a very famous site. It's really exciting to be here."
For LaBar-Kidd, the high point has been the discovery of possible post molds, dark patches in the soil indicating the former presence of vertical posts. Depending on their placement pattern, the markings might indicate that structures such as fish drying racks or habitations once stood here.
"That's actually the most fascinating thing. It's not the tools. It's the funny little signs in the ground," says the bandana-wearing archaeologist.
"I'd like to find a gouge or an adz," confides Susan Moore, a teacher from Boylston, Mass. Moore has participated in five digs in recent years, some of them with her daughter, Jessica, now 12, who has accompanied her to Goddard.
"The first time I took my daughter on a dig, she came only reluctantly. Then she found a piece of pottery in my square, and she took over," recalls Moore.
"I did not, Mom!" protests Jessica from her end of the pit.
At a Great Gott Island dig two years ago, Moore was "thrilled" to find an engraved bone that may have been a handle for a knife, and a piece of pottery that had been decorated with a stick.
That's when she got hooked.
"I think the fascination is just learning and appreciating the people that lived thousands of years ago -- how they made the best use of materials available to them, whether it was food, stone, or bones from animals," says Moore.
For Gargiulo, the dig fulfills dual purposes.
It speaks to his interest in human evolution, and "it's just a good break for me after a school year. I'm not home fighting with my wife and kids," he adds, laughing heartily. "This gives you some solid ground to transfer your emotions to. It's kind of like Buddhist meditation."
One of the older diggers in the group, white-haired Roger Willis of Dover-Foxcroft, said his first foray into archaeology was a dig sponsored by the University of Chicago in southern Illinois in 1935. Since retiring after a long career with paint retailer Sherwin-Williams & Co., he has been "messing around," he says.
Tending his pit, the lanky retiree allows that digging can take its toll. "It gets hard on the back and knees. I didn't bring my 10-pound coffee can," he says ruefully. "It's the perfect size to sit on."
For an instant, Willis brightens noticeably, having gleaned a potsherd from soil the color of coffee grounds. "Oh, come on, have a design," he pleads. Alas, it's a plain piece of pottery.
Before long, however, he will unearth a decorated piece, one of several found in recent days enhanced with designs made using cord-wrapped or dented sticks.
At the other end of the project area, digging partners Pat Skaling and Cynthia Melnikas keep finding flakes, which are byproducts of stone toolmaking, and small stone scrapers whose edges show evidence of having been worked by hand.
"This little baby is so pretty," says Melnikas, peering at a notched point of reddish-green chert she and Skaling found at Goddard last week. "We were very down and singing to the spirits. Then, five minutes later, we found this," she recalls.
Considered abundant at the site, the chert artifacts are believed to originate from the Munsungan Lake area in northern Maine, and to belong to the late ceramic period.
Owner of a Deer Isle bed-and-breakfast, Melnikas cut her teeth digging at a site in the Florida Everglades and now works at the Abbe Museum in Bar Harbor, specializing in American Indian antiquities.
Melnikas says she knows from experience that it is best to keep expectations at bay on a dig, but it's hard not to be excited when you think you're on to something.
For Skaling, a former teacher from Belfast, the ultimate find would be a seal effigy, a hope that may be wishful thinking. "We find little rocks we call effigies," she says. "Of course, they're nothing, but we use our imaginations."
She mentions seals because they are believed to have been a major food source for the late ceramic people, along with fish, deer and small mammals. A "fair number" of sea mink and great auk bones have been found in Moorehead sites, but Cox does not expect diggers to find them here.
While most such sites contain shellfish remains which help to preserve bones in the soil, Goddard apparently does not, because the seasonal habitation here did not coincide well with shellfish harvesting. The only type of older bones likely to be found here are burnt ones, which do preserve, says Cox.
Preservation is an issue for the field school in yet another crucial regard, Cox says. Since funds for archaeological work remain limited, tuition, room and board proceeds from sessions such as this summer's are the only funding likely to allow Goddard Site excavation to continue.
Its justifications seem obvious. Scanning the boat-strewn, blue-gray bay on this nearly perfect day, Cox adds, "I can't think of a nicer place to work."
Illustration Caption: Amateur mother and daughter archaeologists Susan and Jessica Moore of Boylston, Mass., check through the pieces left after sifting a bucket of dirt removed from the Goddard dig. (NEWS Photo by Scott Haskell) Roger Willis (left) of Dover-Foxcroft and digging partner Steve Gargiulo, a Falmouth teacher, examine rock fragments uncovered in their square at the Goddard site in Brooklin. (NEWS Photo by Scott Haskell) Steve Gargiulo (left), a Falmouth teacher, and Roger Willis of Dover-Foxcroft sift a bucket of dirt removed from the Goddard site in Brooklin. A whetstone (top right) was one of the items uncovered on the first day of field digging. (NEWS Photo by Scott Haskell)

People: Gargiulo, Steve Goddard, DeWitt Cox, Steven Moorehead, Warren K Moore, Susan

____________________________________________________________

Zebra mussels seen invading Vermont lake State officials joins Canadians in prevention, eradication plan

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]27 June 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413828517?accountid=10457

Abstract: The dozen or so towns on the Quebec side of Lake Memphremagog require boaters to wash their vessels before putting them into the lake to reduce the risk that boats will carry in the tiny mussels in bilge water or attached to the hull. Six washing stations have been built on Memphremagog's shores. No boat-washing ordinances exist in Vermont, and there are no zebra mussel washing stations at docks on the Vermont side of the Memphremagog. But now Newport is putting the final touches on a washing station it built in town. No mussels have yet been found in Memphremagog, a majestic high-altitude body of water that stretches almost 30 miles and straddles the Vermont-Quebec border.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Zebra+mussels+seen+invading+Vermont+lake+State+officials+joins+Canadians+in+prevention%2C+eradication+plan&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-06-27&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: NEWPORT, Vt. -- They might hitch a ride on a boat hull; they might ride in on a wave.
They are zebra mussels, the damaging mollusks that rapidly infested Lake Champlain, and now officials of the towns that share the Lake Memphremagog shoreline are teaming up to make sure they're not next.
"Life revolves around the lake," said Newport Town Manager Ken Magoon. "{Zebra mussels} come in, and the lake is dead."
The dozen or so towns on the Quebec side of Lake Memphremagog require boaters to wash their vessels before putting them into the lake to reduce the risk that boats will carry in the tiny mussels in bilge water or attached to the hull. Six washing stations have been built on Memphremagog's shores.
No boat-washing ordinances exist in Vermont, and there are no zebra mussel washing stations at docks on the Vermont side of the Memphremagog. But now Newport is putting the final touches on a washing station it built in town.
"This is why Magog hired me; it was to get Vermont going," said Raymond Cloutier, a Quebec environmental management expert who works with all the towns that share the lake. "We've been yelling since 1987 that we were surely going to have to organize something here."
The small striped zebra mussels, natives of Europe, are thought to have arrived in North America in the 1980s when they were carried into the Great Lakes in the ballast of an ocean-going freighter. They were first discovered in southern Lake Champlain three years ago.
The mussels can clog the inlet pipes for water and sewage plants, foul boat keels, and litter beaches with their sharp shells.
"It's an incredible problem," said Kevin Coffey, an Irasburg resident who serves on the board of the Lake Memphremagag Watershed Association. "They're so prolific that they actually wipe out the other mussel species that are in the lakes."
No mussels have yet been found in Memphremagog, a majestic high-altitude body of water that stretches almost 30 miles and straddles the Vermont-Quebec border.
In all, the lake covers 37 square miles or about 24,000 acres, said Kevin Hauser, a zebra mussel specialist at the Vermont Agency of Natural Resources. About 75 percent of the lake is in Quebec.
For the Vermont towns that share the lakeshore, Memphremagog is a captivating focal point as well as a spectacular opportunity for tourism and recreation in the winter and summer. An entrepreneur recently trucked a paddleboat onto the lake for excursions in the summer months. And town officials estimate that literally thousands of boaters and fishermen use the waters each year.
"It's a very busy lake," said Bob Orr, Derby's selectboard chairman. "People come from all over."
Memphremagog is especially important to the dozen or so Quebec towns, with about 150,000 residents, that depend on it for their drinking water, Cloutier said.
Quebec officials became concerned in the early 1990s when they perceived that for all of their efforts, zebra mussel pollution could well enter their waters from the unregulated lakeshores to the south while the issue languished in state and local files.
That's when they hired Cloutier.
Now Vermont is starting to get with the program, say lakeshore residents who have been watching the zebra mussel threat closely.
Derby and Newport officials are discussing the problem with Quebec officials. And more importantly, the first washing station funded jointly by those towns opened this month in Newport.
Signs at boat landings will direct boaters to the station, located at the town garage. The station, staffed 12 hours a day by an attendant, will provide a hose with high-pressure hot water for rinsing off boats. It will be free.
"I'm happy that the city of Newport is doing this at least," said Coffey. "They're playing catch-up to the Canadian side."
Although Quebec has enacted ordinances with fines for boaters who fail to wash their boats, Magoon and Orr were pessimistic about the chances of getting similar measures passed in their towns any time soon.
"This year it's going to have to be a conscience thing," said Orr.
Cloutier credited alarm about the mussels' impact on Lake Champlain with prompting the towns' action on protecting Memphremagog.
"{Lake Champlain} is infested except for the eastern arm of the lake," said Cloutier. "That is only protected by a causeway. How long is it going to take? Maybe a year, and the whole lake is done, it's cooked."
And zebra mussels aren't the only problem. Other non-native species are being discovered in bodies of water where they don't belong, he said.
"There are tons of things lurking all around," Cloutier said. "What is going to happen next year? What is going to happen next summer that we don't know is coming?"
Illustration Caption: Raymond Cloutier holds a vial containing dead zebra mussels collected from Lake Champlain in Newport, Vt. (AP Photo)

People: Cloutier, Raymond Orr, Bob

The fish are waiting

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 June 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/414027398?accountid=10457

Abstract: The reduced use of elemental chlorine and other technological improvements in papermaking during the last several years have significantly reduced the amount of dioxin in Maine waters. Some mills have switched to using chlorine dioxide. This process has much to recommend it, including the fact that the chemical compound can be produced on site, and so does not require the transport of tankers carrying chlorine. It is also safer in the mill in the event of a leak, and it greatly reduces dioxin discharges without requiring a mill to make extensive changes in its facilities, as other dioxin-reducing plans do.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+fish+are+waiting&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-06-24&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: When Gov. Angus King this spring set the worthy goal of eliminating the need for dioxin-related fish advisories by the year 2000 he probably did not expect the Environmental Protection Agency to stand in his way. But unless the federal agency establishes clear pollution-control regulations, operators of Maine paper mills will have a difficult time knowing what adjustments they need to make.
The EPA had pledged to present industry with a set of cluster rules by August of this year, but recently suggested that the rules would not be ready until late October, which, in practice, means sometime after the elections, perhaps early next year. Cluster rules are standards for related pollution problems -- ozone, air and water toxins, wastewater discharge -- established in relation to each other rather than trickled out of the agency one at a time. A separate, detailed study of specific dangers of dioxin was due out of the EPA years ago but has been caught in perpetual peer review.
Executives from bleach kraft paper companies joined with the governor last April in support of his plan to lower dioxin levels in fish but, understandably, want to know what the federal rules are going to be before they invest in expensive equipment that may not meet the new standards. If the paper companies are going to help Gov. King meet his goal by 2000, they need direction from the EPA soon on what constitutes best-available technology for reducing dioxin.
Dioxin is a byproduct of incineration and industrial processes that use chlorine. It accumulates in animals, fish and shellfish -- with animals at the top of the food chain generally having the highest concentrations. High doses of dioxin cause chloracne, and may cause some types of cancers and bring on reproductive and developmental problems.
The reduced use of elemental chlorine and other technological improvements in papermaking during the last several years have significantly reduced the amount of dioxin in Maine waters. Some mills have switched to using chlorine dioxide. This process has much to recommend it, including the fact that the chemical compound can be produced on site, and so does not require the transport of tankers carrying chlorine. It is also safer in the mill in the event of a leak, and it greatly reduces dioxin discharges without requiring a mill to make extensive changes in its facilities, as other dioxin-reducing plans do.
Whether this technology will be acceptable to the EPA is as yet uncertain. But the agency's slow pace in establishing regulations is preventing Maine, and all other papermaking states, from making better progress in reducing this toxin.

Aquaculture making waves

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]20 June 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413860116?accountid=10457

Abstract: Hank Stence is considered the father of Maine aquaculture, the holder of the state's first aquaculture lease. In a Forrest Gumpish way, he left the Navy in 1976, moved to Lubec to be near his mother, started diving for scallops and found himself thinking about hunting vs. gathering. Stence and Ralph DeWitt make up [Bob Peacock]'s new research and development team. Their first endeavor is an urchin hatchery, an idea spawned by a high school science project and nurtured by techniques borrowed from the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery. Hank Stence draws samples from a solution of brine and larval-stage urchins taken from research tanks at Peacock Canning in Lubec. Development of the urchins, which are kept in a closed, oxygenated system, is monitored by microscopic evaluation. (NEWS Photo by Michael York)

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Aquaculture+making+waves&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-06-20&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: LUBEC -- R.J. Peacock's spotless new Maine Freeze salmon plant gleams with high technology -- a $250,000 filleting machine, a $100,000 computer-guided laser fish cutter, a head and tail whacker at 50 grand, a patented flash-freezing process so top secret it's about to cost the Japanese a pretty yen to learn how it's done.
Of course, then there's the walk-in freezer scrounged for $300 from a remodeled grocery store, the stainless-steel walls and sinks salvaged from the defunct Limestone Air Force Base, the racks bought on the cheap from a bakery gone bust, all tucked into a cockeyed old sardine cannery that hasn't seen a lick of paint since FDR's first term.
Use it up, make it last, cobble it together. It's the Cobscook Bay way.
It's also the kind of development -- along with innovations in shellfish and seaweed farms and a just-unveiled urchin hatchery -- that has aquaculture poised to become a powerful economic engine in a region that has always been long on natural resources, but short on cash.
"Everything here is based on the sea: the cargo port, aquaculture, commercial fishing," said Bob Peacock, scion of the family business, ship's pilot, sardine packer, fish processor and a guy who has never met an impossibility he didn't like. "We're trying to create the kind of jobs that give our kids a reason to get a good education and the ability to stay here. We can't do that now, but we're building a new type of aquaculture that will."
What comes into Maine Freeze are slumbering salmon from a half-dozen local farms. What comes out are rock-hard blocks of Peacock's TruFresh brand, utterly indistinguishable from fresh except that they're precisely sized in plastic shrink-wrap (also patented), perfectly skinned and deboned, and flash-frozen in a concoction of brine and nontoxic chemicals at 40 below zero, a process that prevents the tissue damage that results from conventional freezing.
Ask the customers what they think -- the chefs of the Disney empire, of Marriott, of nearly every major hotel in Las Vegas, or the soon-to-be clients at Red Lobster, Steak & Ale and Bennigan's.
"This product was designed from the start for the food-service industry," Peacock said. "It has everything chefs want: exact portions, no waste, the highest quality. This has been a five-year project, but it's really starting to take off. It wasn't that long ago this room was filled with sardine packers doing piecework. Now we have 100 people working full time, and we're about to add a second shift. Not bad for little old Lubec."
It's also not bad for an industry that, despite $52 million in sales last year and a second-place finish on Maine's seafood money list, is ending its first decade in a slightly nervous state over a current market price that's less than half the $5 to $6 per pound of the early days.
Andy Stevenson of Maine Aqua Foods, a Canadian company with salmon pens in the bay and a hatchery in Bingham, said the price drop is both a challenge to employ better farming practices and an opportunity to make salmon an everyday meal instead of a special-occasion splurge.
"Sure, I regret I wasn't in aquaculture when salmon was six dollars a pound," Stevenson said. "I'd be relaxing on a beach in the Bahamas instead of squeezing eggs out of the rear end of a female salmon for the hatchery. ...
"There's no way the major producers -- the United States, Canada, Norway, Chile -- are ready to meet the exploding global demand of the future unless we improve our methods. If we do it right, salmon aquaculture will be a $200 million industry in Maine within 10 years."
The key, Stevenson said, is a shift from growing the most fish possible to growing bigger, better and stronger fish.
"At six dollars a pound, you could afford to put 100,000 smolts in the water, lose 45,000 to stress, disease and predation, and still make money," said Stevenson. "We're doing things today -- putting bigger smolt in the pens by being much more selective about brood stock, preventing disease with vaccination instead of trying to cure it with medicine, deterring predators -- that have cut our mortality to 5 1/2 percent."
While salmon remains the big dog on the aquaculture block, many say shellfish -- clams, mussels and now urchins -- are sniffing out a territory of their own.
Hank Stence is considered the father of Maine aquaculture, the holder of the state's first aquaculture lease. In a Forrest Gumpish way, he left the Navy in 1976, moved to Lubec to be near his mother, started diving for scallops and found himself thinking about hunting vs. gathering.
"It occurred to me as I was diving that people in other parts of the world, Asia in particular, had been farming the sea for centuries and here we were, in the most advanced country of the world, still chasing fish all over a huge ocean," Stence said. "I figured most people would starve to death if they had to hunt for their dinner every day, so I went down to the town office and applied for the first lease. Nobody even knew what I was talking about."
Stence, the farmer, started with 5 acres of true bottom land and, in genuine Down East style, planted an old onion bag filled with mussel seeds in the mud. "The idea was that sea water would flow through the bag, the mussels would grow, and the bag would blow up like Jiffy Pop. It worked."
Next, he tried oysters, with less happy results. "I was sowing oyster seeds when I kept noticing something moving out of the corner of my eye," Stence said. "It was two baby flounders, following behind me, eating every seed I'd planted. That's when I learned rule number one about aquaculture -- for everything you try to grow, there's always something bigger coming along to eat it."
Rule No. 2, he said, "is that you have to kill a few of whatever you're trying to grow to learn what you're doing. We've killed a few, but the nutrient level of Cobscook Bay is so high, the water quality is so great, there's enormous untapped potential.
"The people here have always been very protective of their natural resources, and it's about to pay off," Stence said. "What I see as the aquaculture of the future is polyculture -- a combination of small leases for salmon and shellfish, diversity that will protect your overall investment."
There will always be traditional fishermen, Stence said, but they and the farmers must work harder for peaceful coexistence.
"The biggest conflict today is with draggers. Our scallop season here opens November 1, a month earlier than the rest of the state, so we get 140 to 170 draggers up here, coming from all over. Of course we need to keep our farms out of the best scallop areas, but the draggers need to practice better conservation. The state needs to rotate open areas for dragging and to make our opening date the same as the rest of the state. This bay simply cannot support 170 draggers every November," he said.
Stence and Ralph DeWitt make up Peacock's new research and development team. Their first endeavor is an urchin hatchery, an idea spawned by a high school science project and nurtured by techniques borrowed from the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery.
With the state's young, $40 million urchin industry already in danger of imminent collapse from overfishing, DeWitt said the 10 million speck-sized larvae in the blue plastic tubs at the new hatchery will be the pioneers in an attempt to seed urchin beds and to create urchin farms.
"The kids at Lubec High did a science project keeping urchin larvae alive for a few hours," DeWitt said. "I heard about it and thought they were on to something, so we adapted Beals Island's methods for raising clams and started an apprenticeship program for high school kids interested in aquaculture. We've only had the hatchery running for a month. It's way too early to tell how it works, but we don't see any reason we can't grow urchins and keep this industry going. It's too valuable to just let it die."
The R&D team's second project, still on the drawing board, is an adaptation of Stence's old Jiffy Pop concept -- a sheet-sized piece of nylon fabric sewn into a bag, weighted and seeded with clams. The idea is that burying it in the mud for a few years and doing something else in the meantime beats mucking around in a knee-deep mud flat at every low tide.
Dale Sherrard, chairman of the Sunrise County Economic Council, said the latest innovations in aquaculture shouldn't surprise anyone who knows the people behind them.
"By necessity, folks around here are used to having to figure out a way to make something work when it probably shouldn't,"
Sherrard said. "Example: A couple of years ago, we had a sea cucumber industry grow up overnight, 100 good, full-time jobs.
Almost immediately, we came close to losing those jobs when it was discovered the waste decomposed to create a byproduct of some toxicity -- this new industry was going to be shut down before it really got started.
"We got some research money and found out that we could extract a red pigment from the waste that makes a nice enhancement for salmon feed," he said, "and the rest of the waste -- now nontoxic -- makes the best compost I've ever seen. I grew some monster corn with it last summer.
"We turned a problem into an opportunity," Sherrard said. "That's the way here -- whatever obstacle comes along, eventually we'll go around it, over it or through it."
Illustration Caption: Hank Stence draws samples from a solution of brine and larval-stage urchins taken from research tanks at Peacock Canning in Lubec. Development of the urchins, which are kept in a closed, oxygenated system, is monitored by microscopic evaluation. (NEWS Photo by Michael York)

People: Peacock, Bob Stevenson, Andy Stence, Hank DeWitt, Ralph Sherrard, Dale

My first car Regardless of condition, everyone has fond memories of the vehicle that gave them initial taste of freedom

Author: Tammy Lockhart Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]11 June 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413831026?accountid=10457

Abstract: A 1959 English Ford Thames, an import minivan, was Stephen McCausland's real first car, although a same-year English Ford Prefect, about the size of McCausland's desk, was the one that the Maine Department of Public Safety spokesman used to get his driver's test in the mid-'60s. The metallic blue, 12-seater Thames was a great vehicle, McCausland said. Luckily, his father was a mechanic and saw quite a bit of the Thames, for which parts were very hard to come by. McCausland has owned dozens of vehicles since then, but the Thames remains a great memory. He even has a picture of the Thames on the wall of his Augusta office.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=My+first+car+Regardless+of+condition%2C+everyone+has+fond+memories+of+the+vehicle+that+gave+them+initial+taste+of+freedom&amp;author=Tammy+Lockhart+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-06-11&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: It's a milestone like no other, almost eclipsing such revered remembrances as your wedding day or the birth of your first child.
It marked the brief time in your life when you possessed true independence, when the world was truly your oyster, when you finally knew that you were really going places and had the wheels to set your destiny in motion.
Say it quietly to yourself. "My first car ..."
Close your eyes and you are back behind the wheel. You can see every detail of the dash. All of the radio buttons are set on the coolest stations. The gas gauge is on "E," whether the motor is idling or off. A personalized key ring, for which you spent months searching before you even bought the car, dangles from the ignition. You loved that car, bondo and all. It was as close to nirvana as you will ever get. And some days, if the planets were in the right order and if it wasn't raining too hard, you could even get it to start.
If Americans are in love with their cars, their first courtship with a Vega or Falcon was blind adulation. Oh, how that first car treated us, always breaking down, barely passing inspection, always taking and taking and rarely giving anything in return. But how we loved it.
A 1959 English Ford Thames, an import minivan, was Stephen McCausland's real first car, although a same-year English Ford Prefect, about the size of McCausland's desk, was the one that the Maine Department of Public Safety spokesman used to get his driver's test in the mid-'60s.
The metallic blue, 12-seater Thames was a great vehicle, McCausland said. Luckily, his father was a mechanic and saw quite a bit of the Thames, for which parts were very hard to come by.
"I toted half of my high school class around town in that thing," McCausland recalled. "It could seat a dozen people. I tell you it made me a popular guy."
Years later, McCausland saw a van that looked similar to the Thames in a Brunswick junkyard. Unable to resist, he walked to the van, opened the door and slipped in behind the wheel. He then got out of the vehicle and popped the hood. There, after all these years, were his initials and those of his friends still carved into the roof of the hood.
McCausland has owned dozens of vehicles since then, but the Thames remains a great memory. He even has a picture of the Thames on the wall of his Augusta office.
Mathys Van Dam's first car was a 1934 Ford convertible. Pittsfield's recycling coordinator can still remember every detail of the car he drove around Boston as a teen-ager in the 1940s.
"It was black with a white top and had yellow wheels," he recalled. "The upholstery was brown leather, and it had a rumble seat."
Back in those days, "you were a rich man if you had a car," said Van Dam. He drove all over Boston in the car, paying between 15 and 17 cents a gallon to motor his way through the city's notorious traffic.
Van Dam says the car held a lot of great memories, as did his second car, a 1935 Pontiac in which he courted his wife. The Pontiac was not always as cooperative as the Ford, though, and had to be parked on a Boston hill and allowed to roll before it would start during the winter months, he said.
Karen Allen's first car was one some of us could only ever dream about having.
"It was a 1979 Ford Mustang, gray with maroon interior," recalled the assistant to the president at Kennebec Valley Technical College in Fairfield.
Allen's father bought the car for her while she was a junior in high school in Windham in 1984, and she made weekly payments to dad to reimburse him.
"A lot of people liked to ride with me," she said, laughing.
There was that day when she first drove the car. "I remember sitting in it for the first time and thinking, `This is great!' " Allen said.
She kept that car in great shape, probably better than the upkeep of her present car, washing it every week and having it waxed at least twice a year.
Steve Whitesel, Dexter town manager, remembers his first car, bought in 1959, like it was yesterday.
"Oh, was it a beauty," he said. "It was a 1938 Chevy coupe, hand-painted gray, with alternately painted black and white louvers. It was just a beautiful car."
Whitesel's father bought it for him during his sophomore year in Idaho.
"I'd gotten five A's and one B on my report card, and my folks decided that I was grown-up enough to have a car. Oh, it was just a gorgeous car. I tell you, I was the envy of my classmates.
"The next semester," Whitesel said, laughing, "I got five B's and one A."
While working at a canning plant, Whitesel let one of his friends borrow the car. It later came back with a cracked windshield, a grinding transmission and a knocking rod. The windshield and transmission were fixable, he recalled, but not so with the rod.
"I still think of that car a lot," he said. "In fact, I just saw one just like it the other day, and I said, `Hey, that's my car.' "
Whitesel still has pictures of the car back home in Idaho, and to this day, can still remember the first song he heard on the radio, which he had to personally install in the coupe.
"It was `Kansas City' by Wilbert Harrison. I started it up and that song came on, and, well ... I just loved that car."
Illustration Caption: John Gomes III of Bangor polishes the chrome valve covers on the 4.9-liter engine of his first car, a 1980 Trans Am he bought three years ago. (NEWS Photo by Kevin Bennett)

People: McCausland, Stephen Allen, Karen Whitesel, Steve

____________________________________________________________

Panel takes hard look at dangers of overfishing

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]08 June 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413812981?accountid=10457

Abstract: One short-term side effect of the urchin frenzy seems to be beneficial: Urchins are prodigious grazers, devouring kelp at astonishing speed. With no urchins left, a luxuriant kelp forest develops, providing protective cover for young lobsters and other valuable species of shellfish and fin fish. [Linda Mercer], who is overseeing the deployment of a $360,000 urchin research fund garnered from license fees, said the drastic change wrought by the urchin industry "shows how complex fishery management issues cannot be managed on a species-by-species basis. There is a real need to understand the interaction between species, to maintain a balance in the ecosystem." While the urchin "gold rush" clearly is on the wane, [David Cousens] cautioned that another unused species, the whelk, is on the brink of a boom. "Are we going to keep repeating this pattern of depleting a species, cleaning it out and then acting to preserve what's no longer there? We always do the damage long before the Legislature can act."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Panel+takes+hard+look+at+dangers+of+overfishing&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-06-08&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- Using sea urchins as a case study, a panel of fishermen and scientists on Thursday discussed how commercial fishing's all-out assaults on certain species can throw the entire ocean ecosystem out of whack.
The session, sponsored by the Island Institute and the Mainewatch Institute, included a screening of a new video, "Under Water, Out of Sight," produced and directed by David Conover. It looks at the impacts and stresses current fishing practices place on the complex Gulf of Maine environment.
Panelists were University of Maine oceanography professor Robert Steneck, Department of Marine Resources scientist Linda Mercer, lobsterman David Cousens, urchin harvester Jim James and marine biologist and fisherman Ted Ames.
Ignored by fishermen until less than 10 years ago, an explosion in the urchin population led to the establishment of Far East roe markets that has vaulted urchins to second place in value of wild harvests in Maine. Hundreds of millions of pounds have been taken in that period and the inshore ocean bottom virtually has been stripped clean.
One short-term side effect of the urchin frenzy seems to be beneficial: Urchins are prodigious grazers, devouring kelp at astonishing speed. With no urchins left, a luxuriant kelp forest develops, providing protective cover for young lobsters and other valuable species of shellfish and fin fish.
What remains unanswered, Steneck said, is what caused the urchin explosion in the first place and what will be the longer-term result of their sudden, man-made removal.
"This is an interesting case study of one species' impact on a whole ecosystem," he said. "Urchins are the dominant grazers -- commercial fishing tends to target the higher-level predators, the top of the food chain. From a scientific viewpoint, this is an excellent opportunity to see how this complex environment reacts when a dominant organism is targeted and removed suddenly."
While the urchin harvest has an up side for other species, Steneck noted that some recent fishing practices have immediate negative effects, citing the use of "rock-hopping" dragging gear that can scoop young groundfish from behind rocks that used to provide protective cover from predators.
Mercer, who is overseeing the deployment of a $360,000 urchin research fund garnered from license fees, said the drastic change wrought by the urchin industry "shows how complex fishery management issues cannot be managed on a species-by-species basis. There is a real need to understand the interaction between species, to maintain a balance in the ecosystem."
Cousens, president of the Main Lobstermen's Association, said fishermen and scientists "have been in adversarial roles for years, but that has to change. We're working more with scientists now, we've come a long way, we know what we need to do on management issues. Now the politics comes in, the hard part."
While the urchin "gold rush" clearly is on the wane, Cousens cautioned that another unused species, the whelk, is on the brink of a boom. "Are we going to keep repeating this pattern of depleting a species, cleaning it out and then acting to preserve what's no longer there? We always do the damage long before the Legislature can act."
James, head of the Maine Urchin Harvesters Association, said the explosion in his business and a decline in the last two years should be a warning to all fishermen of what can happen when an industry develops without a long-range plan.
"At first, the state sold as many licenses as it could, now we've got a moratorium. We had a boom, now we might be heading for a collapse. I've heard people say we should just wipe all the urchins out and get it over with. We have to decide whether restricting entry into a fishery is being elitist or preserving a resource," he said.
Ames, a marine biologist and the former head of the state gillnetters' association, said Maine has seen numerous boom and bust fisheries over the years and is only now realizing it doesn't have to be that way.
"We've seen the consequences of fishermen not working with scientists -- it leads to collapse. In groundfish, there are thousands of formerly well-employed fishermen who now no longer have a resource because we didn't deal with the issues. We need knowledge, we need data to make rational decisions," he said.

People: Steneck, Robert Cousens, David

New composting company aiming at retail market

Author: Kesseli, Doug

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]23 May 1996: A6.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413825230?accountid=10457

Abstract: BREWER - Mix unripened blueberries, leaves, and twigs. Add sawdust along with crushed blue mussel shells, peat moss and discard salmon parts and you wind up with a concoction unpalatable to even hungry bears. A new Maine company is hoping that this mixture will be the recipe for success, since it is gardeners, not gourmets, that the company is hoping will come to appreciate it. Coast of Maine Organic Products Inc., a newly established business in Portland, is now offering an all-purpose compost made from waste products, such as salmon remains, mussel shells and the leftovers from the blueberry harvest. Normally loaded onto barges and dumped in the ocean, these waste materials have found new purpose as a natural fertilizer. The company, incorporated in March, has named its mixture Penobscot Blend, although its ingredients come from Washington County. The compost comes in a plastic bag decorated on the front with a watercolor painting of islands and pine-tree covered peninsulas jutting out along Penobscot Bay. (excerpt)

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=New+composting+company+aiming+at+retail+market&amp;author=Kesseli%2C+Doug&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-05-23&amp;spage=A6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BREWER - Mix unripened blueberries, leaves, and twigs. Add sawdust along with crushed blue mussel shells, peat moss and discard salmon parts and you wind up with a concoction unpalatable to even hungry bears.
A new Maine company is hoping that this mixture will be the recipe for success, since it is gardeners, not gourmets, that the company is hoping will come to appreciate it.
Coast of Maine Organic Products Inc., a newly established business in Portland, is now offering an all-purpose compost made from waste products, such as salmon remains, mussel shells and the leftovers from the blueberry harvest. Normally loaded onto barges and dumped in the ocean, these waste materials have found new purpose as a natural fertilizer. The company, incorporated in March, has named its mixture Penobscot Blend, although its ingredients come from Washington County. The compost comes in a plastic bag decorated on the front with a watercolor painting of islands and pine-tree covered peninsulas jutting out along Penobscot Bay.
Backed by a $30,000 rural development federal grant through the Eastern Maine Development Corp., Carlos Quijano and his Coast of Maine company hope to hit paydirt with the compost.
Beginning this week, 200 tons of the 40-pound bags of Penobscot Blend are being produced and prepared for marketing to areas in southern Maine and New England, said Quijano, who spent more than two decades in commercial and investment banking with Chase-Manhattan Bank and now is president of a Portland consulting firm.
The third shipment this week went out Wednesday evening, headed for the Boston area and parts of New Hampshire. Quijano said another shipment, headed for Maine, will go out today.
Although primarily headed for the larger population centers, stores in Old Town, Camden and Rockland have already bought some to sell to customers, said Quijano.
The 40-pound bag wholesales for about $3.40 although Quijano expects the retail price to be about double that.
The idea for the compost came after a mussel farm in Tenants Harbor hired him out to find alternatives to their composting of the company's waste byproducts. He found that the often nutrient-rich materials were going unused, either being dumped in the ocean, or thrown in landfills.
"There's not much you can do with 1,000 pounds of salmon guts," he admitted late Wednesday, adding that unused parts of sea urchins, mussels and other shellfish also have limited uses. With an abundant and unused resource available and low-level production underway, Quijano and Coast of Maine are now looking for markets and for sales. Another 300 tons is expected to be produced in June for distribution for the fall and to be brought to trade shows in January.
Ultimately to wring the most efficiency and profit out of the project, Quijano sees producing 10,000 tons of the compost. And Quijano sees operations expanding into Maine's midcoast region.
Going into full-scale production will mean new jobs in job-poor Washington County. Not a lot of jobs, he said, but jobs nonetheless. It will also mean an environmentally-friendly and possibly profitable solution to waste produced in Maine's fishing industries.
As well as offering a hand up for gardeners and other green thumbs, Penobscot Blend is providing a new opportunity for the Brewer company that is packaging the compost.
Mixed and packaged in Brewer by W.H. Shurtleff Co., a well-known municipal supplier of road salt and other ice melters, Penobscot Blend is putting to work Shurtleff machines that traditionally have remained idle this time of year, explained Gerry Bosse, branch manager of the Shurtleff Brewer facility.
With little chance of a hefty snow or ice storm on the horizon, there's no need for the road salt and de-icers and no need for the machines and workers that package them.
Machines like conveyor belts and hoppers are now back on line, sifting out larger unwanted refuse from the compost, funneling it into bags and then sealing them.
To make Penobscot Blend, the recipe's ingredients are mixed together by the ton, not the teaspoon. Brought into Shurtleff's massive quonset hut, the seperate piles of mussel shells, peat moss, sawdust from hemlock, spruce and fir trees and the other materials are mixed together using a front-end loader and a wind rower.
The wind rower, borrowed from the University of Maine, makes long lines of the compost which sit until a moisture content of 40 percent is reached and the compost is readied for packaging.
For the South Portland-based Shurtleff, the off-season business is a welcome opportunity as the company looks to expand business and diversify its operations.
Bosse said the company will be expanding operations into recycling efforts and using its facilities for collecting, warehousing and then shipping products elsewhere. The company is looking for other uses of existing equipment as well as new areas where there is little to no competition and plenty of room to grow.
"We like to find products that no one else is doing," Bosse said.

Subject: Startups; Corporate profiles; Composting; Chemical industry

Location: US New England ME Brewer

People: Quijano, Carlos

Company / organization: Name: Coast of Maine Organic Products Inc; SIC: 2875

Classification: 8640: Chemical industry, includes rubber & plastics

Warren gives nod to clamming plan

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]07 May 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413814858?accountid=10457

Abstract: A mere 10 [Warren] voters -- including four selectmen who had to be there -- turned out to unanimously endorse a regional shellfish management ordinance and an interlocal clam management agreement that, if approved in upcoming votes in Cushing, South Thomaston, Thomaston and St. George, will create the rules and governing structure for the long-awaited rebirth of clamming on the river's flats. The ordinance, the "nuts and bolts" of how the five towns can prevent overharvesting, establishes requirements, harvest limits and fees for resident commercial and recreational licenses and nonresident commercial licenses, and sets penalties for violations. The number of licenses, the allowable harvest and the opening and closing of specific flats will be determined each year based upon the recommendation of the shellfish committee and a state biologist. Selectman John Crabtree, who helped develop the interlocal agreement, said the plan "makes all five towns equal partners, with equal shares. Everything is divided by five. Warren gets one-fifth of the licenses. There's no appropriation asked for, but if there is ever a need for money, Warren will be asked to raise one-fifth."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Warren+gives+nod+to+clamming+plan&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-05-07&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: WARREN -- A plan for five towns to oversee the revival and preservation of the St. George River shellfish industry easily passed its first test at a miniature town meeting here Monday.
A mere 10 Warren voters -- including four selectmen who had to be there -- turned out to unanimously endorse a regional shellfish management ordinance and an interlocal clam management agreement that, if approved in upcoming votes in Cushing, South Thomaston, Thomaston and St. George, will create the rules and governing structure for the long-awaited rebirth of clamming on the river's flats.
Most of the river has been closed to shellfish harvesting for the last 10 years because of pollution. Recent investments by Warren and Thomaston to improve waste water treatment and upgrade residential septic systems throughout the region make it likely the state Department of Marine Resources will approve the reopening of substantial areas within the next month or so.
It is estimated that the once-lucrative flats could sustain yields $1 million or more worth of clams each year if managed properly, but there is concern that the resource could be wiped out overnight if the flats reopen with no conservation plan in place.
While Warren took care of presenting information about the plan and bringing it to a vote in one night, the other towns will deal with those tasks in two sessions: St. George, public hearing May 13, vote May 28; Cushing, hearing May 13, vote May 21; Thomaston, hearing May 20, vote June 3; and South Thomaston, hearing May 15, vote May 29.
The ordinance and agreement were developed over several months by clammers and other volunteers with the Georges River Clam Fishery Restoration Project, formed in anticipation of the reopening of the flats.
The interlocal agreement calls the resource to be administered by a five-member joint board, with one selectman from each town. A 15-member shellfish management committee, with three members from each town, will serve in an advisory capacity to the joint board.
The joint board will have the authority to set the number of licenses to be issued each year, to establish license fees, to open and close flats for conservation, to set digging times and limits on harvest quantities, and other regulations and restrictions permitted by state laws and regulations. Recommendations of the management committee can only be rejected by the joint board with a unanimous vote.
The ordinance, the "nuts and bolts" of how the five towns can prevent overharvesting, establishes requirements, harvest limits and fees for resident commercial and recreational licenses and nonresident commercial licenses, and sets penalties for violations. The number of licenses, the allowable harvest and the opening and closing of specific flats will be determined each year based upon the recommendation of the shellfish committee and a state biologist.
The number of licenses will be divided equally among the five towns. It is hoped the project will be able to support itself, including the salary of a shellfish warden, on income from license fees and fines. The number of licenses to be issued the first year will be determined after it is know how much area will be certified for reopening by the state.
As an incentive for continued volunteerism, commercial diggers who perform 10 hours of management work a year, such as surveying clam populations and growth rates and monitoring water quality, will be able to purchase their licenses two days ahead of the next year's opening date.
Sherman Hoyt of St. George, the volunteer coordinator of the restoration project, said the reopening of the flats without a local management plan in effect "will bring an influx of diggers from all over the state -- a gold rush. I know some of our town clerks have gotten calls from diggers all over the state, asking when the flats will open. A resource that could add one or two million {dollars} to the economy year after year could be wiped out in a few weeks. We've had 25 to 40 people working on these documents. It's the best we could do -- I think it will be the best shellfish ordinance in Maine to prevent overfishing."
Selectman John Crabtree, who helped develop the interlocal agreement, said the plan "makes all five towns equal partners, with equal shares. Everything is divided by five. Warren gets one-fifth of the licenses. There's no appropriation asked for, but if there is ever a need for money, Warren will be asked to raise one-fifth."

Group seeds clam beds Americorps members set up growth experiments

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 Apr 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413867214?accountid=10457

Abstract: Also on Tuesday, Americorps members and other volunteers were in Lubec's Cobscook Bay, seeding 20,000 clams in two nets and 5,000 clams in each of five protector pockets. In Casco Bay, volunteers in South Portland and Scarborough were cleaning up flats, transplanting clams and conducting an inventory of predatory green crabs. According to Sam Chapman of the Waldoboro Shellfish Committee, the goal of the work here is to bring some modern aquacultural techniques to the potentially lucrative but neglected clam fishery. "Clams have become a forgotten resource, something people harvest when there's nothing else to do," Chapman said. "It's an unfortunate attitude, since clam harvesting could become an extremely important and sustainable industry. We're looking for ways we can make unproductive flats productive again and for ways to keep good flats productive." "I went clam digging once as a kid. Now I remember why I never did it again," [Justin White] said, taking a break from digging a trench in the pungent mud. "Actually, it's a good change of pace from most of the work we do, building trails and other conservation projects, but I definitely prefer the woods. My major is outdoor recreation -- I don't think clam digging's going to catch on as recreation."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Group+seeds+clam+beds+Americorps+members+set+up+growth+experiments&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-04-24&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: WALDOBORO -- It's a long way from the azalea gardens of Augusta, Ga., to the mud flats of Waldoboro, but for Americorps's Marjorie Goldberg, a day seeding clam beds was a truly "oozesome" experience.
"This is my first time on a flat -- we don't have anything like this in Georgia," the Americorps team leader said through a mask of muck Tuesday. "I never anticipated being in mud halfway to my knees when I signed up, but it's great. It's kind of fun to play in, plus we're doing something worthwhile."
What Goldberg and 20 other Americorps members were doing wallowing about in Arthur's Cove at low tide was setting up protected clam beds and growth experiments, part of the Seeding For Maine's Future program going on along the coast on the designated National Day of Service.
Americorps, called the domestic Peace Corps, has more than 100 members in Maine, working in projects in conservation, outdoor recreation, agriculture, public health, homelessness, education and youth programs. Members commit to a year of service and receive a living allowance, health insurance and a financial award for education.
Also on Tuesday, Americorps members and other volunteers were in Lubec's Cobscook Bay, seeding 20,000 clams in two nets and 5,000 clams in each of five protector pockets. In Casco Bay, volunteers in South Portland and Scarborough were cleaning up flats, transplanting clams and conducting an inventory of predatory green crabs.
According to Sam Chapman of the Waldoboro Shellfish Committee, the goal of the work here is to bring some modern aquacultural techniques to the potentially lucrative but neglected clam fishery. "Clams have become a forgotten resource, something people harvest when there's nothing else to do," Chapman said. "It's an unfortunate attitude, since clam harvesting could become an extremely important and sustainable industry. We're looking for ways we can make unproductive flats productive again and for ways to keep good flats productive."
The centerpiece of the experiment is to gauge the survival rate of clam larvae in pure, native mud sediment compared to those grown in a mixture of mud and sand.
"The hypothesis is that the grains of sand provide some protection to the seed clams and encourage better growth," said Chapman. "If it's so, I can see the day when harvesters will carry a bag of sand on each trip out and spread it as they work, gradually creating small plots of clam farms."
The idea of farming clams, rather than hunting them, could bring tremendous economic benefits to coastal Maine, Chapman said. "A town could lease a small area of a flat to an individual, who would be responsible for creating a good growth environment. A small, well-managed area, as small as a half-acre, could provide a person with a good living."
The biggest hurdle to developing privately managed clam farms on town-owned flats "isn't the biology or the mechanics or the ecology," Chapman said. "It's the social factor.
"The attitude now is that every bit of open flat has to be accessible to everyone, which doesn't do anyone any good if there's no clams," he said. "If towns would lease small areas to individuals, they'd create new employment opportunities and relieve some of the harvesting pressure from the wild flats.
"Everybody would win," he said. "The farmers would have a guaranteed area to improve and manage, and the wild harvesters would have less competition. ... The hard part will be convincing people to try something new."
Clamming wasn't something new for Americorps member Justin White, a Unity College student from Woolwich whose year of service will pay for one semester of school.
"I went clam digging once as a kid. Now I remember why I never did it again," White said, taking a break from digging a trench in the pungent mud. "Actually, it's a good change of pace from most of the work we do, building trails and other conservation projects, but I definitely prefer the woods. My major is outdoor recreation -- I don't think clam digging's going to catch on as recreation."
Illustration Caption: Americorps member Justin White wrestles with the mud in a Waldoboro flat Tuesday while laying a net to protect seed clams from predators. (NEWS Photos by Bruce Kyle) Marjorie Goldberg

Workers to seed flats at Lubec Clams to mature in Cobscook Bay

Author: Diana Graettinger Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]17 Apr 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413804523?accountid=10457

Abstract: [Sally Rier] and scores of other volunteers plan to dig their fingers deep into the muddy flats of Cobscook Bay on April 23 to reseed clam flats on the S-turn on South Lubec Road. The project is Lubec's part in the Americorps National Day of Service and will begin at 7:30 a.m. with a cleanup of the flats. "{The young clams} are anywhere from one-eighth-inch to one-half-inch, soft-shell clams that come from the Beals Island Shellfish Hatchery," Rier said. More than 200,000 seedlings will be taken to Cobscook Bay. In addition to community volunteers, members of the Cobscook Bay Clam Restoration Project and Americorps, others in the project include: the Lubec Shellfish Committee; Austin Dinsmore, manager of Stolt Sea Farms of Lubec; Hank Stence, research and development director at R.J. Peacock Canning and quality control officer for Maine Aqua Foods Inc.; the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery; and Victoria Dyer, town manager of Lubec.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Workers+to+seed+flats+at+Lubec+Clams+to+mature+in+Cobscook+Bay&amp;author=Diana+Graettinger+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-04-17&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: LUBEC -- Sally Rier is a native of this small seaside community, but the closest she has ever been to clams was when they landed on her dinner plate.
But Rier and scores of other volunteers plan to dig their fingers deep into the muddy flats of Cobscook Bay on April 23 to reseed clam flats on the S-turn on South Lubec Road. The project is Lubec's part in the Americorps National Day of Service and will begin at 7:30 a.m. with a cleanup of the flats.
"{The young clams} are anywhere from one-eighth-inch to one-half-inch, soft-shell clams that come from the Beals Island Shellfish Hatchery," Rier said. More than 200,000 seedlings will be taken to Cobscook Bay.
"We are not going to seed them all. We are going to winter some in floating trays in the water," she said. In trays the clams grow larger before reseeding. The clams must be in the flats for three years before they grow to legal harvest size.
The Americorps project is expected to help volunteers understand the relationship among the environment, sustainable aquaculture practices and natural resource-based economic develop- ment.
Some of the goals of the project are to reverse environmental pollution, restore exhausted clam flats, demonstrate that communities and government can work together, and demonstrate how scientific research can benefit the economy.
During the past few years, several groups have focused on the economic benefits of reseeding clam flats in the area.
Other Americorps groups, working with area shellfish committees, will reseed clam flats in Scarborough and Waldoboro.
Members of Americorps met in March with Cobscook Bay area experts to learn about clam seedlings and the moon snails that feed on them. Clam seedlings have experienced a 100 percent mortality rate in areas with high numbers of moon snails.
A survey of the proposed reseeding sites in Lubec will be done later this week to make sure the seedlings will thrive.
Rier, a member of Downeast HealthCorps, a part of Americorps, described Americorps as the equivalent of a domestic Peace Corps. "Instead of going to other countries, we stay here and work in either rural or urban areas," she said.
In addition to community volunteers, members of the Cobscook Bay Clam Restoration Project and Americorps, others in the project include: the Lubec Shellfish Committee; Austin Dinsmore, manager of Stolt Sea Farms of Lubec; Hank Stence, research and development director at R.J. Peacock Canning and quality control officer for Maine Aqua Foods Inc.; the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery; and Victoria Dyer, town manager of Lubec.
The educational component of the project will be provided by Lubec teacher Martin Mahar. Pupils in his eighth-grade class will be taught about water quality testing and demonstrate on-site testing.
Rier said more volunteers are needed. For more information, call Rier at 733-5541, Ext. 152.
Illustration Caption: Sally Rier inspects a clam flat along the South Lubec Road. (NEWS Photo by Diana Graettinger)

Dioxin commitment

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]13 Apr 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413839399?accountid=10457

Abstract: About six months ago, Gov. Angus King directed the commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, Ned Sullivan, to involve a range of interested parties to find ways to reduce dioxin discharges in Maine's rivers, with a long-term goal of eliminating these discharges from the state's paper mills. At a meeting Monday of business and environmental leaders, the governor announced that Maine's major paper mills had agreed to such a goal, although the agreement has no timetable for eliminating discharge of this toxin. What it does have, however, is an encouraging schedule that should continue the paper companies' recent record of significant dioxin-discharge reductions and give Maine better benchmarks to measure progress. Among the agreement's goals are the following: The state will create its own interim water-quality standard for dioxin. Currently, it uses the federal level, which has been the subject of intense debate and likely continued debate once the Environmental Protection Agency issues further guidance on this issue, as it is expected to do.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Dioxin+commitment&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-04-13&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The agreement between Maine's bleached kraft paper industry and the state is not quite an absolute pledge to eliminate dioxin, but it is important for at least two reasons. It recognizes that the health of the rivers has a direct effect on the health of Maine's people, and it correctly observes changes in the papermaking industry worldwide that will continue to dramatically reduce or eliminate dioxin discharges.
Dioxin is a byproduct of incineration, wood and coal-burning and industrial processes that use chlorine. Trace amounts are found in dairy products, meats, fish and shellfish. Animals at the top of the food chain generally have the highest concentrations. High doses of dioxin cause chloracne, and may cause some types of cancers and bring on reproductive and development problems.
About six months ago, Gov. Angus King directed the commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, Ned Sullivan, to involve a range of interested parties to find ways to reduce dioxin discharges in Maine's rivers, with a long-term goal of eliminating these discharges from the state's paper mills. At a meeting Monday of business and environmental leaders, the governor announced that Maine's major paper mills had agreed to such a goal, although the agreement has no timetable for eliminating discharge of this toxin. What it does have, however, is an encouraging schedule that should continue the paper companies' recent record of significant dioxin-discharge reductions and give Maine better benchmarks to measure progress. Among the agreement's goals are the following: The state will create its own interim water-quality standard for dioxin. Currently, it uses the federal level, which has been the subject of intense debate and likely continued debate once the Environmental Protection Agency issues further guidance on this issue, as it is expected to do.
Maine will continue its dioxin-monitoring program, which expires at the end of the current budget cycle, through the end of the decade.
The rivers in Maine will improve enough by 2000 for the Bureau of Health to remove a fish-consumption advisory for dioxin. The King administration may find achieving this goal difficult to verify. An advisory in Maine is issued for fish when dioxin levels exceed 1.5 parts per trillion. Background dioxin is 0.5 ppt, and there is some question about whether technology allows for scientists to make a distinction between these two points.
The DEP and the industry will use the resources of the Maine Science and Technology Foundation, the University of Maine and other organizations to find further ways to reduce dioxin discharges.
The reduced use of elemental chlorine in papermaking is certain to be central to further dioxin reductions. Some Maine mills have moved away from elemental chlorine to a process using chlorine dioxide. This latter process has much to recommend it, including the fact that the chemical compound can be produced on site and so doesn't require the transport of tankers carrying chlorine. It is also safer for workers at a mill in the event of a leak, and it can significantly reduce the level of dioxin discharges without requiring a mill to make extensive changes in its facilities, as other dioxin-reducing plans do. It does not, however, totally eliminate dioxin discharges.
Robert Huggett, science adviser to the EPA, said chlorine dioxide "is a solution to dioxin and other persistent, bio-accumulative, toxic substances in mill waste water."
As Maine moves toward its vision of cleaner rivers, it will face the question of how much it is willing to spend for incremental improvement. That, however, is a question for the future. What is encouraging now is that the state and Maine's mills have announced their commitment to cleaning the rivers.
