Experts mull economic ills of fish farms Aquaculturists work to stem tides threatening state's industry

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]13 Apr 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413805313?accountid=10457

Abstract: Maine Marine Resources Commissioner Robin Alden opened the meeting with an update on the most crucial issue facing the industry -- the possibility that strains of wild salmon native to Downeast rivers could be placed on the federal endangered species list, a move most in aquaculture say would kill their industry. Since the primary concern of federal regulators is that huge numbers of cultured salmon escaping from their pens will drive out the much smaller numbers of wild strains or infect them with disease, a key element of the state's plan will be to construct weirs in the affected Washington and Hancock county rivers. The weirs will allow the state to better assess the migration of wild strains as they return to their spawning habitat and will allow cultured escapees to be culled from the weirs before they can go upriver. "This is a very ambitious new approach to salmon restoration, using aquaculture techniques to raise wild strains to adult stage for release into our depleted rivers," she said. "We have two hatcheries doing this now. A major issue is whether cultured strains will genetically swamp the wild strains, so this proposal is quite significant. If the wild salmon population goes up, the threat goes down."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Experts+mull+economic+ills+of+fish+farms+Aquaculturists+work+to+stem+tides+threatening+state%27s+industry&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-04-13&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: EASTPORT -- Although the stated topic was the health of farmed fish, bacteria and parasites took a back seat at a conference Friday to the political and economic bugs threatening the health of Maine's fish farms.
The fourth annual New England Farmed Fish Workshop, held in the heart of Maine's $57 million salmon aquaculture industry, brought together more than 100 growers, state and federal managers and a panel of scientists for a discussion of the medical and regulatory issues facing the growing, but peril-filled industry.
Production at Maine's fish farms exploded last year to 22 million pounds, up from 14 million in 1994, with the value of the harvest jumping by $21 million. Aquaculturists, however, say the outlook isn't nearly as rosy as it seems, given the sharp drop in prices -- 30 percent in the last 18 months alone -- and their ongoing battles with cheap foreign competition, emerging diseases and unsympathetic federal regulators.
Maine Marine Resources Commissioner Robin Alden opened the meeting with an update on the most crucial issue facing the industry -- the possibility that strains of wild salmon native to Downeast rivers could be placed on the federal endangered species list, a move most in aquaculture say would kill their industry.
While a moratorium on new endangered-species listings gives the industry some breathing room -- at least until after the November election -- Alden said the state is using the reprieve to prepare a management plan it is hoped will convince federal regulators that farmed and wild salmon can coexist.
"A year ago, at this same conference, I said there was looming on the horizon the potential of this listing that would have extremely serious consequences for the industry," Alden said.
"Events have overtaken the federal process, leading to this moratorium. We don't know if this threatened listing will go forward, but as a state we are using the time to come up with an alternative, to develop a road map that will allow us to live under that listing."
Since the primary concern of federal regulators is that huge numbers of cultured salmon escaping from their pens will drive out the much smaller numbers of wild strains or infect them with disease, a key element of the state's plan will be to construct weirs in the affected Washington and Hancock county rivers. The weirs will allow the state to better assess the migration of wild strains as they return to their spawning habitat and will allow cultured escapees to be culled from the weirs before they can go upriver.
Alden said she is particularly excited about another part of the plan that will have the industry use some of its formidable hatchery capacity to raise wild strains to restock the rivers.
"This is a very ambitious new approach to salmon restoration, using aquaculture techniques to raise wild strains to adult stage for release into our depleted rivers," she said. "We have two hatcheries doing this now. A major issue is whether cultured strains will genetically swamp the wild strains, so this proposal is quite significant. If the wild salmon population goes up, the threat goes down."
With numerous government agencies concerned about aquaculture's impact on everything from wildlife to human health, and with the state's financial outlook as bleak as ever, Alden also cautioned the growers that the industry will have to use more of its own resources to solve its problems.
"The state's fish-health structure is not adequate to handle the explosion in aquaculture that's going on now, not just in fin fish, but in shellfish, urchins, eels, nori and so on," she said. "With the number of government commissions involved, there's a need for compromise, for a partnership between the industry, the state and the federal government. The state can never have the experts needed in salmon, eel and urchin pathology, so we need a collaborative effort."
According to Dana Stoffregen of the Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine, industrywide collaboration throughout the United States and Canada is essential for aquaculture to get the research and medications it needs to thrive.
Stoffregen said the $600 million U.S. aquaculture industry, working in isolated pockets on both coasts and the Gulf states, makes up such a small piece of the agricultural pharmaceutical business that there are only two 20-year-old antibiotics federally approved for use in farmed fish, medicines that are increasingly unable to combat emerging diseases. Stoffregen said the $2.3 million spent annually to develop new medicines for food-product animals is less than one-third of what is spent on medicines for household pets.
Why pharmaceutical companies aren't spending more, he said, "is because aquaculture is too fragmented to attract their attention. It takes 11 years and $22 million to bring a new food-animal pharmaceutical to market. If the industry in this country and Canada would band together, form what I call a North American Salmon Federation, you could have the clout to market better, to have a better regulatory atmosphere and to capture the interest of the pharmaceutical industry."
On a positive note, Chris Heinig of MER Assessment Corp. of South Harpswell, which conducts the state's monitoring program for aquaculture sites, said data gathered since 1992 shows that improved industry practices, such as the shift from wet to dry feed, are leading to significant improvements in the impact salmon cages have upon the immediate ocean environment.

People: Alden, Robin Stoffregen, Dana

Maine homeowners can create gardens that reflect certain themes

Author: Brian Swartz Advertising Staff Editor

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]11 Apr 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413819457?accountid=10457

Abstract: What comprises a coastal garden? The answer lies in its theme: a garden that accentuates sea and shore: In Maine, the ubuiquitous lobster trap and buoy symbolize the rockbound coast. So do seagulls and lighthouses; Empty mussel and periwinkle shells layer the intertidal zone in almost harbor and along most headlands in Maine. Intact scallop shells are fairly rare finds; Shed by their former occupants, crab shells often wash ashore, as do dead starfish and empty urchin shells; Colorful rocks and granite chips carved by wave and erosion are abundant along the shore. Nature casts ashore on PEI a bounty seldom seen on the Maine coast. Scallop shells abound, sprinkled intact or shattered along the shore like salt spilled from a shaker. Within an hour, the Maine couple gathered enough scallop shells to outfit two coastal gardens. At the Admiral Nimitz Museum of the Pacific War in Fredericksburg, Texas, a Garden of Peace (donated by the Japanese) mirrors traditional Japanese horticulture. The late [Phyllis MacKinnon], a [A Brewer] resident, developed a simple theme for a flower garden: She edged a plot of land with rocks, planted tulips, and called the site her "Rock Wall Garden." With a little imagination and components scrounged from as far away as Prince Edward Island, a Maine couple created a coastal garden in their home -- which is a 30-minute drive from the sea. A pond reflects its surroundings at the Asticou Gardens on Route 198 in Northeast Harbor. The gardens are famous for their flowing azaleas. The dawn's early light streams across a coastal garden created in a Maine yard some 30 minutes from salt water. (NEWS Photos by Brian Swartz)

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Maine+homeowners+can+create+gardens+that+reflect+certain+themes&amp;author=Brian+Swartz+Advertising+Staff+Editor&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-04-11&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The idea originated, fittingly, in a Canadian province surrounded by the sea.
Outside a house on a side street in Charlottetown, Prince Edward Island, a garden composed with bleached scallop shells, driftwood, and a lobster buoy or two spreads across the narrow strip between foundation and sidewalk. Obviously drawn from materials common to PEI, the garden blends well with the miniature rock wall that lines the adjacent walk.
The American couple briefly glimpsed the coastal-oriented garden while en route to downtown Charlottetown. An idea instantaneously clicked; why couldn't they create a similar garden at their home in Maine?
Theme gardens
Many gardens reflect specific themes. Behind the Admiral Nimitz Museum of the Pacific War in Fredericksburg, Texas, a lovely Japanese peace garden yanks the visitor half a world away to imperial Nippon. Its sand beds raked in the patterns evident at the Asticou Gardens in Northeast Harbor, its flowers and trees resembling the flora shot on-site for "Shogun," the garden invites a reflective stroll through its somnolent environs.
MDI's Asticou Gardens, so effectively utilizing the slightly sloped acreage sandwiched inside a Route 198 curve, blends Japanese design (the sand beds) and American functionality. Famous for its azaleas (there are people who will visit the gardens only when its azaleas bloom), Asticou incorporates native flora and topography (a pond, a brook, the slope from the road) to create an atmosphere that discourages loud noise and disruptive behavior.
A Brewer resident, the late Phyllis MacKinnon, maintained for some 40 years a rock garden that bloomed with tulips in the spring. She preferred the yellows and reds -- and planned her garden so something always bloomed until midsummer.
At their best, gardens emulate natural solitudes. The Charlottetown garden could not with its miniscule size. With this thought in mind, the Maine couple returned home via Cape Tormentine and the TransCanada to initiate their garden project.
Planning a coastal garden
What comprises a coastal garden? The answer lies in its theme: a garden that accentuates sea and shore: In Maine, the ubuiquitous lobster trap and buoy symbolize the rockbound coast. So do seagulls and lighthouses; Empty mussel and periwinkle shells layer the intertidal zone in almost harbor and along most headlands in Maine. Intact scallop shells are fairly rare finds; Shed by their former occupants, crab shells often wash ashore, as do dead starfish and empty urchin shells; Colorful rocks and granite chips carved by wave and erosion are abundant along the shore.
Elsewhere, the components can change: oyster shells along the Chesapeake, seashells along Caribbean shores. Large scallop shells, abraded white by surf and sand, litter the red sands of Prince Edward Island.
A coastal garden could incorporate all these materials, and even more, to create an effective theme. In true Yankee fashion, the Maine couple selected a frugal route to establishing their particular garden.
Where the dollar
makes a difference They agreed that any coastal garden in Maine must include a lobster trap -- and not just any trap. Only the traditional wood-slatted trap would suffice.
Intended for the tourist dollars, lobster traps built locally in Maine cost at least $20. Not so on Prince Edward Island, as the Maine couple discovered.
The morning after hatching their garden idea, they motored along the north shore, stopping at North Rustico to grab a sandwich. While approaching the town from the south, they had spotted a lighthouse, painted in the uniform white and red of most Canadian lighthouses, standing on the sandy spit guarding the west entrance to Rustico Bay.
Intrigued by the scenery, the Maine residents drove to the lighthouse (like so many on PEI, it must be approached on foot).
About 150 yards away, they went past several lobster traps stacked by a white picket fence.
A lobsterman's neat, well-maintained home, the couple agreed. Returning the same way, they noticed the "for sale" sign tacked to the lobster traps.
Four dollars, Canadian, was the asking price. With the exchange rate at 35 percent (as offered by the Irving Oil stations in Charlottetown), the price was about $2.60 American. The Maine residents dropped the appropriate coinage in a locked box nailed to the fence, stuffed a fresh lobster trap into their sedan, and headed for Cavendish.
Nature's bounty
The Maine couple spent that Saturday at Dalvay Beach, an incredible stretch of sand east of tourist-overrun Brackley Beach on the north shore. They caught some sun, swam in the warm ocean waters (nothing like the chill off Old Orchard Beach), and beachcombed.
Nature casts ashore on PEI a bounty seldom seen on the Maine coast. Scallop shells abound, sprinkled intact or shattered along the shore like salt spilled from a shaker. Within an hour, the Maine couple gathered enough scallop shells to outfit two coastal gardens.
Finding scallop shells proves difficult in Maine, where a rocky bottom and strong tides usually break empty shells. Mussel shells will suffice, though, as will periwinkle shells.
A local touch
Back in the States, the Maine residents designed their garden on paper. A lobster trap, no matter how positioned, sits low to the ground, so they bought a 6-foot length of picket fence, painted it white, and used it to backdrop the lobster pot.
Next, the couple shopped for fish nets and a lobster buoy. They found both, packaged for tourists, at a York Beach store.
The wife requested the garden be situated in the backyard, where she could see it from the kitchen-sink window. The coastal garden would be visible, but not blatantly so, from the road.
Unlike some gardens, this one was intended for the enjoyment of its architects, not passersby.
The couple prepared a 6-foot-by-2-foot bed by removing the underlying clay and replacing it with good dirt. They generously worked Maine-made bark mulch into the soil to reduce the weeds and retain moisture.
Then the homeowners braced the picket fence along the rear garden line and placed the lobster trap at a 45-degree angle to the fence. They draped the fish net from three spaced pickets, letting the mesh dangle over the fence and cover the trap.
To complete the effect, the couple hung the orange-and-white lobster buoy from a picket behind the lobster trap. They placed some scallop shells inside the trap and scattered others around it. The garden's final components were several small rocks found in MDI waters and various flowers planted to bloom by late summer.
The resulting garden, while not situated near salt water, brought a touch of the Maine coast to an inland yard.
Illustration Caption: At the Admiral Nimitz Museum of the Pacific War in Fredericksburg, Texas, a Garden of Peace (donated by the Japanese) mirrors traditional Japanese horticulture. ____________________________________________________________

Restoring old boats fills Pagels' sails Seaworthy vessels, saved from ramshackle state, fill eclectic Bar Harbor fleet

Author: Letitia Baldwin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]10 Apr 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413834180?accountid=10457

Abstract: Named after [Steve Pagels]' mother, the Natalie Todd is perhaps the fleet's flagship. The magestic white schooner, with its signature red sails, is a fixture in the waters around Mount Desert Island. While the ground is still frozen and snow remains in spots these April days, Pagels and other tour boat operators from Eastport to Kittery have begun the ritual of readying their vessels for the summer season. The buzz of sanders can be heard as crews prepare to paint. Rotten wood must be replaced, seams recaulked, gouges filled, stays, shrouds and other rigging checked, and a litany of other tasks performed. After being honorably discharged from the service, Pagels tried his hand at hardshell clamming in a gaff-rigged Muscongus Bay sloop -- the forerunner of the Friendship sloop -- on Great South Bay. He eventually landed his captain's license and divided his time between running a ferry hauling freight and garbage and taking people for cruises in the boats that by then made up his fleet, including a cat boat, a 1920s power boat and a two-masted sharpie schooner. Pagels credits Long Island boat builder Phil Shelton with introducing him to Maine. Shelton built for him the two-masted sharpie schooner before Shelton moved to Columbia Falls in the early 1980s. Seeing the potential for a tour boat business here, Pagels eventually also moved to Maine.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Restoring+old+boats+fills+Pagels%27+sails+Seaworthy+vessels%2C+saved+from+ramshackle+state%2C+fill+eclectic+Bar+Harbor+fleet&amp;author=Letitia+Baldwin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-04-10&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: It began when he was in third grade. He remembers using roofing tar to caulk seams, and spending exactly $5 to put a fresh coat of paint on his first boat. He rowed for hours in that flat-bottomed sharpie, exploring the tidal marshes of Great South Bay off Long Island, N.Y.
More than 70 boats later, Capt. Steven Pagels, a Bar Harbor tour boat operator, is still restoring boats, only they have grown considerably in size from the 12-foot rowboat of his boyhood. The work today also involves more hands. His latest project is a replica of a 19th century merchant sailing ship named Young America, which is being rerigged as a two-masted topsail schooner.
There are scores of tour boat operators along the Maine coast. Their vessels range widely from launches to windjammers. But Pagels stands out because of his passion for resurrecting old working boats and for the sheer size and diversity of his Bar Harbor-based fleet, which boasts a circa 1923 Great Lakes ferry, a Chesapeake Bay-style oyster boat and three schooners.
Named after Pagels' mother, the Natalie Todd is perhaps the fleet's flagship. The magestic white schooner, with its signature red sails, is a fixture in the waters around Mount Desert Island. While the ground is still frozen and snow remains in spots these April days, Pagels and other tour boat operators from Eastport to Kittery have begun the ritual of readying their vessels for the summer season. The buzz of sanders can be heard as crews prepare to paint. Rotten wood must be replaced, seams recaulked, gouges filled, stays, shrouds and other rigging checked, and a litany of other tasks performed.
One recent raw, rainy day, Pagels drove to Southwest Harbor to see how work was progressing on his latest project. Young America, its deck stripped of masts and rigging, lay up against the wharf's weathered pilings. The graceful white and green schooner, not to be confused with the entry in last year's America's Cup Race, sported a resurfaced deck, new bulwarks and deckhouses.
In a boat shop at the head of the wharf, Columbia Falls carpenter Dwight Huntley worked alone. The radio kept him company as he constructed new companionway stairs for Young America. He has done the bulk of the work involved in restoring and converting the 19th century-style square rigger replica.
Two years ago, Young America lay in a derelict state in Historic Gardner's Basin in Atlantic City, N.J. The schooner had once served as a training ship and maritime mascot to the city's seafaring past. But it had been out of commission for years. Grass had grown knee-deep on its rotted deck. Pigeons were living below.
Pagels had had his eye on Young America for nearly two decades. The square rigger had raced against sailing ships from Denmark, Norway, Spain, Colombia, Ecuador and West Germany in the 1980 Tall Ships races. He had failed twice to acquire the ship. Its derelict state did not dissuade, and may have induced him to make a third, successful pitch in 1994.
"She was just a mess, but her hull was structurally sound," Pagels remembers. He had the brigantine towed by tugboat from Atlantic City to Southwest Harbor where most of his marine restoration projects are carried out. "We opened up the hatch and there were these two seasick-looking pigeons."
"She was kind of unhappy-looking," Huntley adds dryly. He should know, having hauled more than 12 tons of rotten wood and other debris out of the dilapidated ship.
Young America has had a complete face lift. Bar Harbor shipwright Jim Elk soon will construct the vessel's gaffs, booms and topmasts from spruce trees harvested Down East. Within the year, Pagels will be at the helm of the two-masted schooner, taking people for sails out and around the Porcupine Islands in Frenchman Bay.
Whether it's Young America or his Great Lakes ferry, the Chippewa, the crafts in Pagels' eclectic fleet have certain things in common. Nearly all were once working boats performing a wide range of functions from carrying herring harvested in the Gulf of Maine to ferrying passengers and freight to Mackinac Island on Lake Huron. Most were discovered in a ramshackle state and had to be brought back to life painstakingly.
Pagels is the first to admit he is powerless at the sight of an old working boat that has been left to waste away on the shore or in a field.
"A friend once told me `If you take to alcohol the way you do to boats,"' he related, "`you are going to be the world's worst alcoholic."'
Originally from Bayport, Long Island, Pagels was wheeling and dealing in boats by the sixth grade. The flat-bottomed sharpie was succeeded by a 10-foot fiberglass sailboat bought for $90. He had saved up the money from his paper route.
The sailboat enabled him to venture across Great South Bay. He transported the craft from his family's house to the beach on a "little red wagon" with a carpet on top.
"It was kind of funny," he said, chuckling. "My parents were not that strict if you wanted to go out on the water. But heaven help you if you got into someone's car."
After graduating from high school, Pagels enlisted in the U.S. Army and was sent overseas to Turkey where he worked in communications at a U.S. base overlooking the Bay of Izmit. He refurbished three boats including a racing sloop during his 1 1/2-year stint.
Back at Homestead Air Force base in Florida, the young communications officer quickly bought an old Bahamian sloop tied up to a wharf with a for-sale sign nailed to its mast.
After being honorably discharged from the service, Pagels tried his hand at hardshell clamming in a gaff-rigged Muscongus Bay sloop -- the forerunner of the Friendship sloop -- on Great South Bay. He eventually landed his captain's license and divided his time between running a ferry hauling freight and garbage and taking people for cruises in the boats that by then made up his fleet, including a cat boat, a 1920s power boat and a two-masted sharpie schooner.
Pagels credits Long Island boat builder Phil Shelton with introducing him to Maine. Shelton built for him the two-masted sharpie schooner before Shelton moved to Columbia Falls in the early 1980s. Seeing the potential for a tour boat business here, Pagels eventually also moved to Maine.
To showcase his boat-building skills, Shelton built an 1890s-style freight schooner, Janet May, that formed the basis for Pagels' fleet. The ship was launched ceremoniously on the Narraguagus River in Cherryfield.
The Janet May eventually was joined by the Natalie Todd. Formerly called the Lady in Blue, the schooner-dragger had fished the Grand Banks and Georges Banks for nearly half a century. Pagels found it languishing alongside a pier in Gloucester, Mass., "for sale" scribbled on the pilothouse.
"It's where the old fishing boats go to die. It's kind of a nautical skid row," he related, recalling the vessel's condition. "She had a million-dollar bottom and a 10-cent deck."
Pagels had the eastern-rigged dragger towed back to Maine where it was gutted down to a shell and transformed into the three-masted schooner Natalie Todd.
Four years later, Stinson Seafood Co.'s sardine carrier, Lou Ann, went aground in heavy fog on a ledge called the "Old Woman," and sank just outside Prospect Harbor. The vessel was raised and the herring salvaged the next day. But the canning company opted not to rebuild the heavily damaged wooden hull.
"She was like the queen of Stinson's fleet," said Pagels who resurrected the vessel and converted it into his two-masted topsail schooner, the Francis Todd, an amalgam of family names.
In his mid-40s, Pagels delights in describing how he chanced upon each and every one of the scores of vessels he has acquired since his very first boat, the flat-bottomed sharpie. Each encounter is still fresh in his mind.
It's that boyish quality that keeps him fired for the next project.
So what's it going to be? "It's always the old working boat hauled up on the marsh bank,"
he mused. "It's the old castoffs that I have such an affinity for."
Illustration Caption: Steve Pagels with his latest project, the topsail schooner Young America, in Southwest Harbor. (NEWS Photo by Marc Blanchette)

People: Pagels, Steven Todd, Natalie Shelton, Phil Pagels, Steve

Paper mills promise end to river toxins Goal is to stop dioxin discharge

Author: Andrew Kekacs Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]09 Apr 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413798522?accountid=10457

Abstract: Seven Maine paper mills are committed to a course that would eliminate discharges of dioxin and other toxic chemicals into Maine rivers, according to Gov. Angus King. Dioxin and other toxic compounds are produced in minute amounts when wood pulp is bleached with chlorine. The chemicals pass through waste-water treatment systems and are released into Maine rivers where they enter the food chain. They are suspected of causing cancer, birth defects, and problems with the immune system. The seven Maine mills that use chlorine include James River Corp. in Old Town, Lincoln Pulp & Paper Co., Georgia-Pacific Corp. in Woodland, Boise Cascade Corp. in Rumford, International Paper Co. in Jay, and S.D. Warren Co. in Hinckley and Westbrook. Speaking to the group at the Falmouth headquarters of Maine Audubon Society, King announced several other initiatives to improve water quality, reduce the use of toxins, change forest practices, protect air quality, and clean up pollution. During the speech, the governor: Encouraged landowners and others to bring forward a plan that protects the health of Maine's forest without crippling its forest-based economy. "The age where we focus only on what we harvest is over," he said. "The age where we focus on the whole forest has begun."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Paper+mills+promise+end+to+river+toxins+Goal+is+to+stop+dioxin+discharge&amp;author=Andrew+Kekacs+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-04-09&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Seven Maine paper mills are committed to a course that would eliminate discharges of dioxin and other toxic chemicals into Maine rivers, according to Gov. Angus King.
"I believe this is an unprecedented national move, and I applaud the mills for their responsible and proactive approach to this issue," King said Monday in a major address on the environment at a conference in Falmouth.
The commitment could cost the mills tens of millions of dollars, but there is no timetable for achieving the goal.
Under the two-page agreement between the state and the owners of the kraft paper mills, the companies agreed to a "long-term vision" of eliminating the discharge of dioxin and other pollutants. However, the agreement also states that any strategy for achieving that objective "must be developed with an acknowledgment of the global, national and inter-corporate context within which Maine mills must operate and compete."
According to the governor, the agreement to eliminate dioxin followed months of negotiations between representatives of the paper industry and the Maine Department of Environmental Protection.
"We share the belief that Maine's water quality should protect and allow the propagation and consumption of healthy fish, shellfish and wildlife," the mills said in a statement released by the DEP.
Dioxin and other toxic compounds are produced in minute amounts when wood pulp is bleached with chlorine. The chemicals pass through waste-water treatment systems and are released into Maine rivers where they enter the food chain. They are suspected of causing cancer, birth defects, and problems with the immune system. The seven Maine mills that use chlorine include James River Corp. in Old Town, Lincoln Pulp & Paper Co., Georgia-Pacific Corp. in Woodland, Boise Cascade Corp. in Rumford, International Paper Co. in Jay, and S.D. Warren Co. in Hinckley and Westbrook.
Jeff Nevins, communications manager at the Boise mill, called the commitment "a reasonable road map to deal with this issue." He said the industry had made no commitment to any specific technology for achieving the goal.
"It is up to individual mills to look at their processes," said Nevins. "We're hoping we can ... achieve the end result the governor wants and still be cost-efficient, given the competitive position the industry is in."
Dioxin has been found in fish, lobster tomalley and clams. For the past 10 years, Maine residents have been warned to limit their consumption of fish from parts of the Penobscot, Androscoggin, Kennebec and Presumpscot rivers. Women of child-bearing age first were advised not to eat lobster tomalley in 1994.
The Natural Resources Council of Maine has been a staunch advocate of ending the use of chlorine by paper mills. Everett "Brownie" Carson, executive director of the state's largest environmental organization, applauded the governor's speech.
"The word `eliminate' leaves no word for ambiguity," said Carson. "The governor wants to end fish advisories in the rivers by the year 2000."
Having spent the past year establishing solid credentials as a pro-business governor, King apparently has turned his attention to the protection of Maine's air, land and water.
"It's been a while coming, but it was a very strong, affirmative commitment {to environmental improvements}," said Carson.
Observers said the speech was well-received by participants at a forum called ECO/ECO, which stands for economy and ecology. First convened in 1990 at College of the Atlantic, the group includes businesspeople, academics, bureaucrats, and representatives of environmental organizations. They seek to find common ground for ensuring Maine's economic and environmental health.
Speaking to the group at the Falmouth headquarters of Maine Audubon Society, King announced several other initiatives to improve water quality, reduce the use of toxins, change forest practices, protect air quality, and clean up pollution. During the speech, the governor: Encouraged landowners and others to bring forward a plan that protects the health of Maine's forest without crippling its forest-based economy. "The age where we focus only on what we harvest is over," he said. "The age where we focus on the whole forest has begun."
Pledged that the state would meet the federal standard for ozone pollution by 1999 so Maine people "can breathe healthy air every day of the year." He repeated his call for the U.S.
Environmental Protection Agency to force Midwestern states to comply with the Clean Air Act to reduce the amount of pollution that drifts into Maine.
Promised to work with businesses to cut the use of toxins in half by the year 2000. He also ordered an inventory of environmental compliance and toxins used within state government, and demanded a plan to progressively reduce the use of dangerous chemicals.
Vowed to reduce the number of clam flats closed to harvesting by 10 percent, and to decrease by the same amount the number of lakes and ponds that aren't suitable for fishing or swimming.
Committed the state to closing 150 remaining unlicensed landfills and eliminating 20 million old tires by 2000, and cleaning up 1,500 sites contaminated with petroleum by 2005.
"With your help, we can achieve this vision, and Maine will be a better place for our children and their children's children,"
said King.

Coastal landmarks in Down East atlas

Author: Diana Graettinger Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]04 Apr 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413806784?accountid=10457

Abstract: A 73-map atlas that provides 80 types of geographic information for the coast from Baileyville to Machias Seal Island off Cutler, and along the coast of New Brunswick, will be unveiled later this month at a meeting sponsored by the St. Croix Estuary Project. Rob Rainer, a spokesman for the St. Croix Estuary Project, said the project began in 1993. He said the Charlotte-Washington County project mirrored a similar project in Nova Scotia. "It involves a large number of local people providing site-specific geographical information. They mapped that along with other information collected from government agencies," he said in a telephone interview Wednesday. The data for the atlas were collected in 1994 and 1995. In February, the St. Croix Estuary Project partners -- Eastern Charlotte Waterways, the West Isles Clean Environmental Association and Fisheries and Oceans Canada -- developed the atlas.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Coastal+landmarks+in+Down+East+atlas&amp;author=Diana+Graettinger+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-04-04&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: A 73-map atlas that provides 80 types of geographic information for the coast from Baileyville to Machias Seal Island off Cutler, and along the coast of New Brunswick, will be unveiled later this month at a meeting sponsored by the St. Croix Estuary Project.
The maps detail the coastal assets and resources of Charlotte County, New Brunswick, and a portion of Washington County, and include information about the coastal infrastructure, culture and tourism resources, and marine, estuarine and shellfish resources.
Rob Rainer, a spokesman for the St. Croix Estuary Project, said the project began in 1993. He said the Charlotte-Washington County project mirrored a similar project in Nova Scotia. "It involves a large number of local people providing site-specific geographical information. They mapped that along with other information collected from government agencies," he said in a telephone interview Wednesday.
Rainer said the coastal infrastructure that was mapped included wharfs, piers, herring weirs and lobster pounds. "Anything that people have built that are basically in the coastal environment," he said.
In the area of cultural and tourism resources, the group mapped everything that might be of interest to tourists, including museums and libraries. The marine, estuarine and shellfish resources included all recreational fish and shellfish resources, as well as some bird habitat.
The data for the atlas were collected in 1994 and 1995. In February, the St. Croix Estuary Project partners -- Eastern Charlotte Waterways, the West Isles Clean Environmental Association and Fisheries and Oceans Canada -- developed the atlas.
Rainer said that data included in the atlas would be available at the Calais Free Library and at libraries in Canada. He said reproductions of digital computer- generated maps and database information also would be available.
"With the digital project we will be able to call up various layers of information, and you will be able to see how one feature relates to another. From a planning point of view that is very important," he said.
"From an educational point of view, we feel the atlas and the digital products will be of value for schools. If they want to learn about what is in their back yard, this is sort of a one-stop shop for a lot of the information about what you have in your area," he said.
People interested in specific maps, Rainer said, also could draw information from the digital file. "We print specialized maps right off the laser printer and provide that information. That is the value of the digital product because it gives you real flexibility," he said.
The meeting to unveil the map is scheduled for 1 p.m. Monday, April 15, at the Stella Maris Community Center in Blacks Harbour, New Brunswick.

People: Rainer, Rob

Menu at Augusta expo mixes talk, taste Maine mystique helps sales, say vendors at show for restaurant, lodging industry

Author: Sharon Mack Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]28 Mar 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413879592?accountid=10457

Abstract: "People across the country find that Maine stands for quality and attention to detail," said [Carol Tanner]. Tanner said she is constantly surprised at how many tourists tasted Maine-made specialties, then buy the products through mail orders. A secret to marketing within the state, she said, is local festivals such as the Common Ground Fair and the Maine Festival. "Let people taste your product. It's not as marketable just sitting on a shelf somewhere." W.A. Bean of Bangor, the state's oldest independent meatpacker, has discovered that shoppers on the Internet are also looking for Maine products. Owner Elizabeth Bean Tommer said, "The Maine mystique is what out-of-state buyers are searching for." Tommer said her company has teamed with another Maine company, Raye's Mustard Mill in Eastport, to market hams and mustard, natural partners, together. Featured as Maine producers were Oyster Creek Farm of Damariscotta, a mushroom producer; Maine Country Foods of Boothbay, seller of mussels, fish, lobster and shrimp bases, pates and bisques; Prima Gelati of Kennebunkport, offering fruit sorbets; Bean's of Bangor, hams and sausages; Mother's Mountain of Falmouth, mustards and sauces; the Wild Blueberry Association of North America; Humpty Dumpty Potato Chip Co. of South Portland; and Raye's Mustard Mill of Eastport.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Menu+at+Augusta+expo+mixes+talk%2C+taste+Maine+mystique+helps+sales%2C+say+vendors+at+show+for+restaurant%2C+lodging+industry&amp;author=Sharon+Mack+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-03-28&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: AUGUSTA -- The graying -- and widening -- of America -- are certainly having an impact on Maine producers, restaurateurs and innkeepers.
At the annual Maine Restaurant and Lodging Expo at the Augusta Civic Center this week, low-fat items and healthy foods were the trend: everything from organic yogurt to natural stone-ground mustards. Products grown and produced in Maine were a special hit.
The trade show Tuesday and Wednesday allowed people in the lodging and food businesses to meet each other, talk about and sample business trends, check out new and unique equipment and services, and even do a little marketing.
Clients are looking for no-fat, low-fat products, said Tom Snowman of Carl Smith Foods of Brewer. "Unfortunately, when you take out the fat and the calories, the price goes up," said Snowman.
"The biggest question I'm asked," said Stephanie Peavey of Great Eastern Mussel Farms, "is, `What is the calorie and fat content?"'
Although many of the suppliers offered healthy foods with fat-conscious consumers in mind, there was still an array of pizza vendors.
The mood was upbeat: With spring on the horizon, Maine businesses are looking ahead to a busy tourist season. But don't think they sat around idle all winter. Many of the Maine suppliers and producers at the trade show have been marketing themselves across the country, tying into the Internet and mail-order catalogs to promote Maine products nationwide.
Carol Tanner of Mother's Mountain of Falmouth, a mustard and sauce producer, was tempting inn and restaurant owners with an array of her products. She recently attended food shows in San Francisco, San Antonio and Boston. Maine products are instant hits, she said.
"People across the country find that Maine stands for quality and attention to detail," said Tanner. Tanner said she is constantly surprised at how many tourists tasted Maine-made specialties, then buy the products through mail orders. A secret to marketing within the state, she said, is local festivals such as the Common Ground Fair and the Maine Festival. "Let people taste your product. It's not as marketable just sitting on a shelf somewhere."
W.A. Bean of Bangor, the state's oldest independent meatpacker, has discovered that shoppers on the Internet are also looking for Maine products. Owner Elizabeth Bean Tommer said, "The Maine mystique is what out-of-state buyers are searching for." Tommer said her company has teamed with another Maine company, Raye's Mustard Mill in Eastport, to market hams and mustard, natural partners, together.
"We have teamed up because it makes more sense to market together," said Tommer. "It is unusual but perhaps is becoming more common."
Tommer said the Maine Department of Agriculture is extremely helpful in marketing strategies. Tommer said Bean's will be represented in the Maine pavilion in an upcoming food show in Pennsylvania. "We are just the type of company that needs their help," she said. "They are doing a really good job working with us."
Also represented at the show were the Maine Restaurant Association and the National Restaurant Association. Mike Carney, owner of Mr. Mike's Restaurant in Lincoln, is president of the MERA. He said Maine restaurants "are a growing market. In an industry where traditionally eight out of 10 fail within the first year, Maine restaurants are doing well because they adapt to change. It's a healthy industry."
"The restaurant industry has created more jobs in the past two years than any other industry," said Carney. "We have collected more sales tax than any other industry."
Carney said the greatest influence on Maine restaurants is the huge influx of restaurant corporations, such as Red Lobster and Olive Garden. "These chains are affecting our industry. This is not necessarily bad. We must adjust. Even supermarket salad bars affect us."
Carney said the greatest issue affecting all restaurants is the possible federal increase of the minimum wage. "I can't pay people $5.50 to dip ice cream," said Carney. He said the NRA and the MERA are lobbying against an increase.
At the trade show, national or regional distributors selling everything from tableware to giant mixers were represented. But at the heart of the show, in the center of the displays, the Agriculture Department had set up a special section: "Put Maine on Your Menu." The section promoted Maine products as diverse as mushrooms and sorbet.
"Food buyers know that visitors to Maine want to taste Maine, and they look for local products when they come to hike, sail, ski or simply relax," said the department's Judy Powell.
Featured as Maine producers were Oyster Creek Farm of Damariscotta, a mushroom producer; Maine Country Foods of Boothbay, seller of mussels, fish, lobster and shrimp bases, pates and bisques; Prima Gelati of Kennebunkport, offering fruit sorbets; Bean's of Bangor, hams and sausages; Mother's Mountain of Falmouth, mustards and sauces; the Wild Blueberry Association of North America; Humpty Dumpty Potato Chip Co. of South Portland; and Raye's Mustard Mill of Eastport.
Illustration Caption: John Gore of Cap Morrill's Fishmarket in Brewer and Stephanie Peavey of the Great Eastern Mussel Farms in Tenants Harbor serve up mussels at the Restaurant and Lodging Expo at the Augusta Civic Center on Tuesday. They were working in the Carl Smith Foods booth. (NEWS Photo by Bob Delong)

People: Tanner, Carol Tommer, Elizabeth Bean Carney, Mike

Brooklin sets sales date for shellfish licenses

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]23 Mar 1996: 1.

Ardolino defense begins Witness says boys respectful, open

Author: Nancy Garland Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]15 Mar 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413876570?accountid=10457

Abstract: [Matthew Ardolino] was voted "best dressed" boy by his fourth-grade classmates at the end of the academic year at the Harrington Elementary School, [Ann Roach] said. Her daughter, a classmate of Matthew's, was voted best-dressed girl, which is why she knew of the pair's honor, Roach said. The best-dressed award came about two weeks before Matthew died. Barry Frost, an Addison fisherman, said he saw nothing unusual occurring at the [Daniel Ardolino] household where he mowed the family's large lawn a couple of hours each day on June 25 and 26. Daniel and Matthew helped him clear away twigs and branches on June 25, he said. The boys also stood nearby the next afternoon as their father, a clammer and worm digger, skinned and fried eels. Frost said Ardolino spoke to Matthew when the child got grass stains on a new white T-shirt, but he denied the father was "hollering and screaming at his son." Asked by [Dan Lilley] if he saw any bruises on Matthew's arms or face or "anything that would make you want to call a doctor," Frost said, "I didn't see any problems, no."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Ardolino+defense+begins+Witness+says+boys+respectful%2C+open&amp;author=Nancy+Garland+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-03-15&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BANGOR -- Matthew Ardolino and his older brother Daniel were respectful boys who attended church regularly in white shirts and ties with their father even after their mother left home with a younger brother and sister, said a defense witness Thursday in Robert Ardolino's murder trial.
Ann Roach of Harrington, a school counselor for Union 98, said she knew the Ardolino family between 1989 and 1993 in her role as religious education coordinator for the Holy Name Church, a Catholic parish in Machias.
"All four children were beautiful -- Daniel and Matthew and the two younger children. They were open and polite with me," recalled Roach, the second witness for the defense to take the stand Thursday afternoon.
Robert Ardolino is charged with murdering Matthew nearly three years ago.
Matthew was voted "best dressed" boy by his fourth-grade classmates at the end of the academic year at the Harrington Elementary School, Roach said. Her daughter, a classmate of Matthew's, was voted best-dressed girl, which is why she knew of the pair's honor, Roach said. The best-dressed award came about two weeks before Matthew died.
Asked by defense attorney Dan Lilley if the boys "ever seemed inhibited or afraid to talk," Roach said , "No, not with me."
"Did their father ever shelter them or pull them away by the nape of the neck," Lilley asked.
"No," Roach replied.
Roach was one of several people who painted a picture of the Ardolino household starkly different from the one portrayed by prosecution witnesses in the first 6 1/2 days of the trial.
Matthew Ardolino died around midnight on Sunday, June 27, 1993, said Dr. Kristin Sweeney, the state's deputy chief medical examiner. He lay dead in the living room of the family home in Harrington for about four hours before Daniel, then 11, discovered his body, according to court testimony.
Autopsy results revealed the cause of death was peritonitis caused by a ruptured small intestine. Prosecutors claim the boy's fatal injury was the result of blows from his father. Robert Ardolino claims he is innocent of wrongdoing and that his son was fatally injured in a fall from a tree. Ardolino is standing trial on charges of depraved indifference, murder and manslaughter.
Afternoon testimony contrasted with the morning session when Maine State Police witnesses for the prosecution withstood repeated attempts by Lilley to discredit their tactics.
Retired State Police Detective Robert Cameron repeatedly denied he had investigated the case in a way that would justify a murder charge. Lilley attacked a three-hour interview Cameron and another detective had conducted with Daniel Ardolino on July 2, 1993.
"Let's lay our cards on the table," Lilley said. "The purpose of that interview -- you were trying to get Daniel to change his story, {to say} that the treehouse, it didn't happen.
"No," Cameron said.
A blow to the defense came shortly before noon when a forensic chemist at the Maine State Police laboratory testified that fibers collected on the ground under a treehouse on the Ardolino property "were not consistent" with the clothing Matthew Ardolino reportedly was wearing the day he died.
Early Thursday afternoon Assistant Attorney General William Stokes rested the state's case, and the defense took over. Five witnesses for the defense took the stand, describing Ardolino as a responsible father who showed his sons the work skills and the morality by which he survived.
Dr. Laurie Ludington, a Calais family-practice physician, said she found "no characteristic pattern of physical abuse," when she examined Daniel Ardolino on June 28, 1993, the day after his brother's death. The child had been brought in for an examination by a Department of Human Services caseworker less than 24 hours after he had been removed from his father's care by the state.
Ludington noted Daniel had a few scrapes, bruises and abrasions on parts of his body but they were "all typical and there were not a large number," she said.
Daniel's "affect" -- his emotions and self expression -- were calm and normal the day after his brother died. "I felt that was unusual under the circumstances," Ludington said.
Barry Frost, an Addison fisherman, said he saw nothing unusual occurring at the Ardolino household where he mowed the family's large lawn a couple of hours each day on June 25 and 26. Daniel and Matthew helped him clear away twigs and branches on June 25, he said. The boys also stood nearby the next afternoon as their father, a clammer and worm digger, skinned and fried eels.
Frost said Ardolino spoke to Matthew when the child got grass stains on a new white T-shirt, but he denied the father was "hollering and screaming at his son." Asked by Lilley if he saw any bruises on Matthew's arms or face or "anything that would make you want to call a doctor," Frost said, "I didn't see any problems, no."
Albion Kenney Sr. of Harrington, a shellfish conservation warden, said he had once gotten out of his truck to break up a "scrap" between the older Ardolino brothers. "I was about 50 yards from their home. Daniel had a stick and was chasing Matthew. I said, `Quit your fighting boys or you're gonna get hurt.' "
Under aggressive questioning from attorney Stokes, Earl Tyler Jr., a lawyer, said he was "instrumental" in getting Robert Ardolino to file sexual abuse charges against his ex-wife. The charges allegedly involved Matthew and Daniel Ardolino, but were never substantiated.
Tyler represented Robert Ardolino in an acrimonious divorce from Nan Ardolino. "I told him to be as aggressive as necessary" to get DHS and court records involving the allegations, Tyler said.
"Did that include making false allegations against the mother and the grandfather?" Stokes asked.
"Not to my knowledge. I believe them to be true," Tyler said.
Terming the session a "very good day for the defense," attorney Lilley said a key witness Friday will be Dr. Stephen Dunton, an Atlanta medical examiner.

People: Ardolino, Matthew Ardolino, Robert Roach, Ann Lilley, Dan Ardolino, Daniel

____________________________________________________________

Stewards of land must act in Maine

Author: Good, Michael J

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]12 Mar 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413803906?accountid=10457

Abstract: The multinational forest product industries must be held accountable to the people of Maine for their collectibe actions because have a contract with the people of Maine and are allowed to operate here. Property rights do not extend to biological devastation of whole ecosystems and the pollution of our collective coastal waters. In light of these serious problems, I suggest, in conjunction with the clear-cutting referendum, that the people of Maine initiate a "dioxin referendum" which would require that the responsible parties clean up the rivers of dioxin by the year 2002, although even this is not soon enough (remember DDT, that legacy lives on). The dioxin issue is one of the most serious pollution issues we face in Maine.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Stewards+of+land+must+act+in+Maine&amp;author=Good%2C+Michael+J&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-03-12&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: I am writing in response to a letter published Feb. 29 in the Bangor Daily News, titled, "Maine Green Party." The author first suggests that the Green Party's proposed clear-cutting referendum would "seriously harm all forest product industries in northern Maine, putting a lot of them out of business and severely reducing the size of other operations in an area of the state where trees are the biggest natural resource."
Let's look at some realities: From 1970 to 1990 total employment in the forest products industry of the northern forest states fell by 13 percent (almost 17,000 jobs). At the current rate of nonsustainable clear-cutting forestry practices this trend is predicted to continue -- despite a clear-cut referendum. (See "The Northern Forest Strategies for Sustainability," by Spencer R. Phillips, The Wilderness Society, 1993.)
Clear-cutting is just one of the nonsustainable events in the northern forest. Another more devastating long-term problem associated with the forest products industry is dioxin pollution. Fish and lobster eaters beware -- there are at least 75 different dioxins known to cause cancer and many are found in high concentrations in all waters below every one of the seven bleach kraft mills. Look at this figure: One paper company last year reported $240 million in profits. That is an amazing number of polluted lobsters, fish and shellfish for which they are responsible. The out-of-state stockholders are ecstatic, while the people of Maine and their freshwater and marine ecosystems have a serious pollution problem. The "closed-loop" technology to clean up the dioxins and other associated pollutants (and there are many) cost approximately $50-$60 million for a typical mill. That still leaves this one paper company a cool $180 million profit; a small price for these multi-national corporations to pay for a cancer-free nonpolluted environment. And that $50-$60 million is nothing compared to the long-term billions lost when our lobster markets are lost and the tourism dollars from sport fishing dry up. (Washington County already is feeling that blow to its "already fragile economy".)
The forest products industry is pulling the wool over the eyes of all Mainers and has our legislators in their back pockets. They are raping this beautiful state of our natural resources and selling them abroad to their multi-national partners while publicly claiming that all is "well in the hands of a paper company."
Hogwash! The forest products industry must be responsible stewards of the lands they use and the public waterways into which they dump their non-profit waste. They must stop seeking high short-term returns by selling valuable land for development rather than keeping it for sustainable timber management. The urbanization of Maine must stop. We need sustainable forestry practices, we need wilderness areas and the people of Maine must demand them before it is too late.
The multinational forest product industries must be held accountable to the people of Maine for their collectibe actions because have a contract with the people of Maine and are allowed to operate here. Property rights do not extend to biological devastation of whole ecosystems and the pollution of our collective coastal waters. In light of these serious problems, I suggest, in conjunction with the clear-cutting referendum, that the people of Maine initiate a "dioxin referendum" which would require that the responsible parties clean up the rivers of dioxin by the year 2002, although even this is not soon enough (remember DDT, that legacy lives on). The dioxin issue is one of the most serious pollution issues we face in Maine.
Fish and lobster should not be eaten from any waters with bleach kraft mills on them. This has dire monetary consequences for the fishing industry in particular and the ecotourism industry in general. The lobster and shellfish industry could be destroyed if this issue is not dealt with soon. Talk about job loss and billions in lost revenue! All for $50-$60 million? Real stewards of the land would see the long-term benefits of making this very small investment for future Maine generations.
It has been approximately 100 years since the Industrial Revolution began. In the 1970s we started to understand how chemical pollutants caused cancer and today we are beginning to understand that these pollutants trigger molecular events which lead to uncontrolled cell growth (i.e., cancer). The forest products industries must use this scientific knowledge by implementing socially responsible practices within the industry. If the forest products industry does not care about our great state than it is up to groups like the Green Party and others dedicated to a viable future to propose referendums that do so.
Maine people must not look naively and narrow-mindedly at the future nor must we believe every word spoken by the leaders of the forest products industry. Together, we can create "viable alternative jobs at decent wages" with a diverse economy. Together, we can make Maine the envy of all Americans.
Michael J. Good operates Down East Nature Tours in Bar Harbor.

Title: Stewards of land must act in Maine:   [ALL Edition ]

Clam contamination levels called outdated, too high

Author: Emmet Meara Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]04 Mar 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413795416?accountid=10457

Abstract: Clams get no respect, according to Bob Cummings of Phippsburg, who spoke at "clam day" at the Samoset Resort during the opening day of the Maine Fishermen's Forum. With state landings at $11 million, trailing only lobster, salmon and urchins, the clam industry is struggling to develop a stronger voice and badly needed controls, including a model clam ordinance. The clam industry is working to develop a Maine Clam Council and Clam Harvester's Association, organizations that the other fisheries have enjoyed for decades.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Clam+contamination+levels+called+outdated%2C+too+high&amp;author=Emmet+Meara+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-03-04&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKPORT -- Clams get no respect, according to Bob Cummings of Phippsburg, who spoke at "clam day" at the Samoset Resort during the opening day of the Maine Fishermen's Forum.
Levels for clam contamination accepted by government regulators date to the southern oyster fishery a few generations ago.
The standards are too high, he said. "There is not a shred of research to support these levels. If the same standards were applied to hamburgers or chicken, those industries would disappear," Cummings said.
Clams are no more dangerous to eat than eggs, he said.
This year's Fishermen's Forum featured an entire "clam day" Thursday. State Marine Resources Commissioner Robin Alden said she could remember when the weekend forums never even discussed clams.
With state landings at $11 million, trailing only lobster, salmon and urchins, the clam industry is struggling to develop a stronger voice and badly needed controls, including a model clam ordinance. The clam industry is working to develop a Maine Clam Council and Clam Harvester's Association, organizations that the other fisheries have enjoyed for decades.
With many clam flats devastated, local communities are starting to realize that it is up to them, not state officials, to protect the valuable resource. Many communities are taking a regional approach to protecting river and seashore beds through tougher regulations that protect the resource while controlling out of town diggers.
The town of Perry voted 55-5 recently to support a budget for a clam program. Eastport is turning off every other streetlight to raise money for a clam program.
It was suggested that a state bond, license fees or landing fees could be imposed to support conservation and protection pro- grams.

People: Cummings, Bob

Economy on mend in Waldo County Area will survive loss of Sears Island

Author: Walter Griffin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]02 Mar 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413992932?accountid=10457

Abstract: The news this week that Gov. Angus King is mothballing the Sears Island cargo port because of expensive environmental regulations cast a cloud over Waldo County. But even without the economic boost the port would have brought, the area's economic fortunes have been improving. As people pinned their hopes on Sears Island, things got worse. In rapid succession the county's shoe and poultry industries collapsed. First it was Maplewood Poultry and 600 jobs, next it was Waldo Shoe, with 200 jobs, then Penobscot Poultry with 500 jobs, and finally Truitt Bros. More than 100 poultry farm families scattered throughout the county also lost their livelihoods. There were no eel grass beds on the Long Cove side of Sears Island in 1983, the year the causeway from the mainland was built and unemployment in Waldo County reached 12.7 percent. But once the causeway was in place, the eel grass habitat expanded into the cove and attracted shellfish and spawning groundfish.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Economy+on+mend+in+Waldo+County+Area+will+survive+loss+of+Sears+Island&amp;author=Walter+Griffin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-03-02&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: SEARSPORT -- The news this week that Gov. Angus King is mothballing the Sears Island cargo port because of expensive environmental regulations cast a cloud over Waldo County. But even without the economic boost the port would have brought, the area's economic fortunes have been improving.
"We felt it was a natural thing for the area," recalled Larry Quinn, who managed a branch bank in Belfast when Sears Island looked promising, "It seemed at that time to be an economic shot in the arm during a time when we were looking at a pretty damn dismal economy."
The late 1970s and early 1980s was an era of 20 percent interest rates and 17 percent inflation. Unemployment throughout northern Maine was high, but Waldo County, home of Sears Island, not only was the poorest county, it also had the highest rate of unemployed at around 12 percent.
As people pinned their hopes on Sears Island, things got worse. In rapid succession the county's shoe and poultry industries collapsed. First it was Maplewood Poultry and 600 jobs, next it was Waldo Shoe, with 200 jobs, then Penobscot Poultry with 500 jobs, and finally Truitt Bros. More than 100 poultry farm families scattered throughout the county also lost their livelihoods.
Although many of the lost jobs were of the low-paying, semiskilled or piecework variety, the removal of those payrolls from the community had a ripple effect on the area's small businesses. A number of small markets and stores were forced to close their doors.
The more things got worse, the more the Sears Island cargo port was being looked to as a beacon of hope.
There were no eel grass beds on the Long Cove side of Sears Island in 1983, the year the causeway from the mainland was built and unemployment in Waldo County reached 12.7 percent. But once the causeway was in place, the eel grass habitat expanded into the cove and attracted shellfish and spawning groundfish.
It also attracted defenders. The focus on Sears Island began to turn to ecology, rather than the economy.
Then, when it appeared that the major export would be wood chips, even longtime port supporters such as labor unions began to waiver. The thought of Maine trees being chipped and shipped overseas to foreign paper mills only added to what was becoming more and more an emotional environmental issue.
Today, the county's unemployment rate hovers around 9 percent, -- still the highest in Maine -- but hope is on the horizon. The Belfast region has been rebounding from its staggering job losses even without the Sears Island project.
The old Waldo Shoe building is now home to a number of small businesses, the Truitt Bros. building has been refurbished and expanded by the wood products firm Matthews Bros., and the Maplewood Poultry plant has been taken over by potato processor Penobscot Frozen foods. The crumbling hulk of the Penobscot Poultry plant may still hover over the city's waterfront, but the grain mill at the foot of Main Street is long gone.
The most spectacular news has been the arrival of MBNA New England. The credit card firm is building an office complex in the city and expects to have 1,000 employees working there within the next two years. Whether that and other developments will be enough to boost Waldo County's unemployment rate out of the cellar remains to be seen.

Title: Economy on mend in Waldo County Area will survive loss of Sears Island:   [ALL Edition ]

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413827107?accountid=10457

Abstract: The stretch of black ice formed late Wednesday night at the base of Long Hill near a swampy tidal inlet from Sandy River Beach. The ice formation left that particular section of Route 187 very treacherous for drivers en route between Jonesport and Jonesboro, said police. [Patrick R. Cirone], who earlier had completed his workday at Carver's Shellfish Co. at Beals, was driving to his home near the Milton Beal homestead at Mason Bay.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Police+blame+icy+road%2C+speed+in+death+of+Jonesport+man&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-03-01&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: JONESPORT -- Slippery road conditions and speed were blamed in the death of a 23-year-old Jonesport man late Wednesday night when his car careened off Route 187 and struck a cluster of large hardwood trees.
Police said Patrick R. Cirone, a native of South Addison, was driving his 1992 Ford Mustang convertible north at 11 p.m. on the Sandy River Beach side of the Route 187 loop when he lost control on a long patch of black ice and skidded 442 feet out of control. The car then spun around and traveled backward another 149 feet before leaving the highway and slamming sideways into a large maple tree. The driver's side door of the car hit the tree.
Cirone died of head injuries at the accident scene before help arrived. The ice was sanded after the accident.
The stretch of black ice formed late Wednesday night at the base of Long Hill near a swampy tidal inlet from Sandy River Beach. The ice formation left that particular section of Route 187 very treacherous for drivers en route between Jonesport and Jonesboro, said police. Cirone, who earlier had completed his workday at Carver's Shellfish Co. at Beals, was driving to his home near the Milton Beal homestead at Mason Bay.
State police Trooper Gary Curtis of Cherryfield is investigating the accident, assisted by Sgt. Edward Bonney and Trooper Timothy McCadden.

Ellsworth city councilors approve $9,100 for design of compost facility

Author: Letitia Baldwin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]27 Feb 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413792069?accountid=10457

Abstract: Ellsworth city councilors authorized Ellsworth City Manager Tim King to spend $9,100 on the engineer's design for the facility, which would be built on several acres of city land near the Ellsworth transfer station off Route 1A. Those funds will also cover the cost of applying for a Maine Department of Envionmental Protection license for the composting operation. Ellsworth currently sends the bulk of its waste to be incinerated at Penobscot Energy Recovery Co.'s Orrington facility. This year, the city is paying just over $27 per ton to dispose of its waste at PERC. But city officials fear their tipping fees may be boosted substantially next year. Besides the disposal costs at PERC, Ellsworth is also spending $20,000 annually to truck sludge from its waste-water treatment plant to Browning-Ferris Industries Inc.'s Hawk Ridge facility in western Maine.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Ellsworth+city+councilors+approve+%249%2C100+for+design+of+compost+facility&amp;author=Letitia+Baldwin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-02-27&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ELLSWORTH -- Ellsworth officials Monday night authorized hiring an engineer to design a compost facility where sludge from the city's waste-water treatment plant and other material would be composted. The operation is seen as a means to further reduce the city's solid waste disposal costs.
Ellsworth city councilors authorized Ellsworth City Manager Tim King to spend $9,100 on the engineer's design for the facility, which would be built on several acres of city land near the Ellsworth transfer station off Route 1A. Those funds will also cover the cost of applying for a Maine Department of Envionmental Protection license for the composting operation.
King estimated the facility would cost between $30,000 and $50,000 to construct. The operation would largely consist of an asphalt pad where compost material would be heaped. A subsurface drain would be built to collect any leachate.
The city manager did not foresee any problems in obtaining a DEP permit.
"All indications are that they {the DEP} think it's a good site and there are no problems," he said.
After construction is completed, King said a private firm with expertise in a municipal composting operation would be hired to run the facility at an annual cost of $10,000. He said that entity would share revenue generated from the composted material's sale. He said a fee would be charged any other communities disposing of their sludge at the Ellsworth site.
"In essence, the operation would be self-supporting as far as the city is concerned," King said.
Gary Fortier, a councilor and Solid Waste Committee chairman, said the project holds promise for reducing the city's solid waste costs. He said sludge, shellfish waste, chipped wood, wet cardboard and wet newsprint are among the materials that could be composted.
"We can compost our sludge instead of spending $20,000 to take it to Hawk Ridge," he said.
Ellsworth currently sends the bulk of its waste to be incinerated at Penobscot Energy Recovery Co.'s Orrington facility. This year, the city is paying just over $27 per ton to dispose of its waste at PERC. But city officials fear their tipping fees may be boosted substantially next year.
Six years ago, Ellsworth was one of eight Maine towns that balked when PERC moved to amend its contracts with 95 Maine communities. In some of the amended contracts, tipping fees would have shot up as much as fourfold.
Dubbed the "Refuseniks," Ellsworth and the seven other towns refused to pay the proposed fees and threatened PERC's owners with a $9 million breach of contract lawsuit. PERC and the Refusenik towns eventually reached an agreement setting tipping fees for a five-year period that expires in 1997.
Besides the disposal costs at PERC, Ellsworth is also spending $20,000 annually to truck sludge from its waste-water treatment plant to Browning-Ferris Industries Inc.'s Hawk Ridge facility in western Maine.
In recent years, Ellsworth has made strides in reducing the amount of trash being incinerated at PERC. The city recycled about 25.5 percent of its waste last year. City officials also imposed a $1-per-bag trash disposal fee and began offering curbside collection of recyclables last summer. Since then, participation in the recycling program has risen 2 percent.
