____________________________________________________________

Ellsworth eyes composting plan City seeks to cut waste disposal costs

Author: Letitia Baldwin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]22 Feb 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413813981?accountid=10457

Abstract: Ellsworth city councilors next Monday night are scheduled to discuss possible construction of a compost facility. Maine Shellfish Co.'s waste, much of it clam and shrimp shells, the waste-water treatment plant's sludge, yard and eventually food and blueberry waste would be processed there. The compost would be sold as a way further to reduce the city's solid waste disposal costs. Ellsworth has already made significant strides in reducing the volume of solid waste sent to PERC. After the city imposed a $1-per-bag trash disposal charge and began offering curbside collection of recyclables last summer, participation in its recycling program rose 2 percent. The city recycled about 25.5 percent of its waste last year. Still, Ellsworth continues to send the bulk of its waste to PERC. The city paid a tipping fee of $26.44 per ton last year and is paying just over $27 per ton this year. The city is also spending thousands of dollars to send sludge from the waste water treatment plant to Browning-Ferris Industries Inc.'s Hawk Ridge facility in western Maine.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Ellsworth+eyes+composting+plan+City+seeks+to+cut+waste+disposal+costs&amp;author=Letitia+Baldwin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-02-22&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ELLSWORTH -- Officials are considering diverting the city's waste stream -- and dollars -- from the incinerator at the Penobscot Energy Recovery Co. to a composting facility that will put dollars back in city coffers.
Ellsworth city councilors next Monday night are scheduled to discuss possible construction of a compost facility. Maine Shellfish Co.'s waste, much of it clam and shrimp shells, the waste-water treatment plant's sludge, yard and eventually food and blueberry waste would be processed there. The compost would be sold as a way further to reduce the city's solid waste disposal costs.
The city would build an asphalt pad, surrounded by a 6- to 8-foot chain-link fence, on a parcel of city land across Boggy Brook Road from the transfer station off Route 1A. It would contract a firm with expertise in mixing and handling compost.
"We are continuing to look at the tonnage of waste we produce and what we can do instead of shipping it to PERC. This was the next logical step to look at," said Ellsworth Councilor Gary Fortier on Tuesday. He heads the city's solid waste committee.
Fortier said Ellsworth's tipping fees could go up next year when the city and seven other Maine towns' five-year contract with PERC expires. Six years ago, Ellsworth was one of eight Maine towns that balked at the Orrington company's move to amend its contracts with 95 Maine communities.
In some of the amended contracts, PERC's tipping fees would have shot up as much as fourfold. Dubbed the "Refuseniks,"
Ellsworth and the seven other towns threatened PERC's owners with a $9 million breach of contract lawsuit. PERC and the Refusenik towns eventually reached an agreement setting tipping fees for a five-year period that expires in 1997.
Ellsworth has already made significant strides in reducing the volume of solid waste sent to PERC. After the city imposed a $1-per-bag trash disposal charge and began offering curbside collection of recyclables last summer, participation in its recycling program rose 2 percent. The city recycled about 25.5 percent of its waste last year.
Still, Ellsworth continues to send the bulk of its waste to PERC. The city paid a tipping fee of $26.44 per ton last year and is paying just over $27 per ton this year. The city is also spending thousands of dollars to send sludge from the waste water treatment plant to Browning-Ferris Industries Inc.'s Hawk Ridge facility in western Maine.
Fortier believes a compost facility has potential to further reduce the city's solid waste disposal costs.
"This plan, if it works, will be able to take all of our sludge and seafood waste," he said.
Bar Harbor has had a municipal compost facility since the 1970s. The town composts its own sludge as well as Southwest Harbor's and sells the material for $24.57 per cubic yard to landscapers. Last year it cost $22.33 per cubic yard to run the facility, according to Bar Harbor Town Manager Dana Reed.
"It's definitely worthwhile. It's a lot cheaper than hauling it away," Reed said Wednesday. He said some neighbors have complained about foul odors, but it has not been determined whether the smell is coming from the compost facility or another source.
In Ellsworth, Maine Shellfish Co.'s plant manager Stephen Beathem estimates his company produces roughly 30 tons of clam and shrimp shells per year.
"It's a sought-after commodity because it contains trace elements that enhance the end product," he said Wednesday. A city councilor, he supports the idea of a compost facility. "I've always been an advocate of doing anything to reduce our solid waste costs."

People: Fortier, Gary

Spill experts seek lessons for Portland

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]06 Feb 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413873352?accountid=10457

Abstract: An organization that cleans up oil spills in Portland Harbor is studying last month's 828,000-gallon spill off Rhode Island in hopes it will lead to improvements in local emergency plans. [John M. Ferland]'s organization, which has a fleet of five boats and a warehouse filled with skimmers, containment booms and other cleanup gear, is the first line of defense against oil spills in Portland Harbor, where 500 oil barges and tankers transfer 100 million barrels a year.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Spill+experts+seek+lessons+for+Portland&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-02-06&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PORTLAND -- An organization that cleans up oil spills in Portland Harbor is studying last month's 828,000-gallon spill off Rhode Island in hopes it will lead to improvements in local emergency plans.
"It really highlighted for us the importance of the work we've been doing, and the need to keep that in focus," said John M. Ferland, general manager of Clean Casco Bay Inc.
Ferland's organization, which has a fleet of five boats and a warehouse filled with skimmers, containment booms and other cleanup gear, is the first line of defense against oil spills in Portland Harbor, where 500 oil barges and tankers transfer 100 million barrels a year.
Ferland's organization, trained to respond in less than two hours, is funded by six marine terminal operators. Another industry-funded group, Marine Spill Response Corp., is responsible for open water spills in Casco Bay.
The Coast Guard and state Department of Environmental Protection also have emergency response programs.
Ferland and two staff members traveled to Rhode Island soon after the spill to visit the site where a barge ran aground, spilling 828,000 gallons of heating oil into Block Island Sound.
He expressed special interest in how authorities coped with stormy weather and adjusted their cleanup strategies to protect birds, shellfish and other wildlife.
"Clearly, we're going to have a wildlife impact up here" if a spill occurs, he said. "And it's not going to take 800,000 gallons to do it."
Ferland said he and his staff associates plan to review lessons learned from their observations in Rhode Island.

Word from bridge: Look out! Chamberlain span between Brewer and Bangor losing concrete

Author: Doug Kesseli Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]03 Feb 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413821526?accountid=10457

Abstract: On a scale of 1 to 9, with 9 being considered brand new, the bridge's deck rates a 3, according to Gary Hoar, an assistant bridge maintenance engineer with the MDOT. The remainder of the bridge, its superstructure, however, rates a 6, based on a review by the MDOT a year ago. A score of 4 is considered federally as the level requiring some kind of intervention or review, Hoar explained. The $4.4 million project has been funded but shelved for several years, according to the MDOT officials, because up river is the old Bangor-[Brewer] bridge, which rates a 2 in terms of its deck and superstructure. That bridge is also called the Penobscot Bridge. Heavy-load traffic has been banned from that bridge, which also connects Bangor with Brewer. In August, the weight prohibition forced an ambulance carrying a shooting victim to add a mile to its trip to the hospital by crossing the Joshua Chamberlain Bridge.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Word+from+bridge%3A+Look+out%21+Chamberlain+span+between+Brewer+and+Bangor+losing+concrete&amp;author=Doug+Kesseli+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-02-03&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Phil Reid used to park his car underneath the Joshua Chamberlain Bridge before heading into Bangor's Sea Dog brew pub for a meal. Not anymore.
Friday morning, while delivering 30 pounds of lobsters to the Sea Dog from Young's Shellfish in Belfast, he watched as a 10-inch chunk of concrete dropped from the bridge just after a Rite Aid tractor-trailer rumbled by above.
"That's where I used to park," Reid recalled with a start as he watched the concrete fall harmlessly into an open space reserved by the city of Bangor for permit parking.
Curious, he left the loading dock, approached the spot and scanned the bridge above.
"I saw there was a bigger chunk up there and got the hell out of there," he said.
Such an episode is not surprising to state transportation officials, who caution that the advanced age of the bridge's decking -- it was built in 1955 -- makes it a prime candidate for cracks, holes and fragmenting concrete.
The warning to pedestrians and motorists: Watch out.
"That's going to happen periodically because the deck is in such bad condition," said Norman Baker, assistant bridge design engineer for the Maine Department of Transportation.
While still strong enough to support traffic and trucks, the bridge's underbelly is pockmarked with indentations, exposing the corroding steel used to reinforce the concrete.
On a scale of 1 to 9, with 9 being considered brand new, the bridge's deck rates a 3, according to Gary Hoar, an assistant bridge maintenance engineer with the MDOT. The remainder of the bridge, its superstructure, however, rates a 6, based on a review by the MDOT a year ago. A score of 4 is considered federally as the level requiring some kind of intervention or review, Hoar explained.
To prevent some concrete from falling, the MDOT has attached plywood to exposed concrete on the sides, where there is support to keep the wood in place. But Baker said unless holes develop from top to bottom, significant repairs aren't expected until the entire deck is replaced in 1998.
The $4.4 million project has been funded but shelved for several years, according to the MDOT officials, because up river is the old Bangor-Brewer bridge, which rates a 2 in terms of its deck and superstructure. That bridge is also called the Penobscot Bridge.
Heavy-load traffic has been banned from that bridge, which also connects Bangor with Brewer. In August, the weight prohibition forced an ambulance carrying a shooting victim to add a mile to its trip to the hospital by crossing the Joshua Chamberlain Bridge.
The replacement for the old Bangor-Brewer bridge, costing taxpayers about $13 million and increasing traffic capacity from two lanes to four, is expected to be completed in the fall of 1997.
With an average of 65,000 people traversing one of the three Bangor-Brewer bridges each day, Baker said it wouldn't be feasible to have both bridges under construction at the same time.

Company / organization: Name: MDOT Inc; NAICS: 541710

____________________________________________________________

Marketing Maine Supermarket section showcases products from the Pine Tree State

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]29 Jan 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413781428?accountid=10457

Abstract: [Bob Jacques] says Maine's smaller-scale specialty food producers tend to do things a little differently, showing up at his store unannounced, say, with a baby in tow, maybe just to say hello or to drop off some products for sampling. The personal connection Jacques forges with some is a remnant of days gone by, he says. Although products from The Mex are for sale in at least two other of the chain's stores, nowhere but in Augusta are they grouped in a Maine display, which makes a huge difference, she says. "I tend to think we're aiming at people interested in Southwestern food, but lots of people are interested just in Maine-made foods." Mike Demers of the state Department of Economic and Community Development is out to do just that. Jacques credits him and Dennis Proctor of the Maine Food Processors Association for much of the behind-the-scenes work that has helped keep the Maine-made food display going.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Marketing+Maine+Supermarket+section+showcases+products+from+the+Pine+Tree+State&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-01-29&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Unofficially, state Rep. Jill Goldthwait has thrown her support behind it. When she drives to Augusta from Bar Harbor, it's the first place she shops.
The display between aisles 5 and 6 at the Whitten Road Shop 'n Save there has become a pit stop for all manner of shoppers, who can pick and choose from among several shelves of items provided by 50 Maine specialty food producers.
Death by Chocolate made in Damariscotta is available, as are Wicked Wild Preserves from Edgecomb, and Maine Coast Sea Vegetables from Franklin. The range of producers represented spans much of the Maine map, especially coastal sections from south of Freeport through to Eastport on the Canadian border.
While some of the items are available at other selected Shop 'n Save stores, many are not. You can find stone-ground mustard here, beer, mustard made with beer, a multitude of jams and sauces, syrups, soups, soup mixes, baked goods and candy, and, appropriately, toothpaste.
Still in its infancy, the 7-week-old Maine-made products section was the brainchild of a department manager last Thanksgiving.
"This area's been hit by a rough economy," notes the display's coordinator, nonperishables manager Bob Jacques, "so we were looking for ways to increase sales."
Intended as a temporary display for the holidays, the popular diversion is beginning to look like a permanent fixture. In fact, moving the display from one part of the store to another touched off a mild panic, recalls Jacques. "You're not taking it down, are you?" customers demanded to know.
The Maine-made section made sense for the centrally located Augusta store, which in summer draws tourists and campers from the lakes surrounding the city, and in winter skiers headed to the western mountains. The Shop 'n Save owes much of its in-store traffic to its location just off the interstate.
For Jacques, an amiable Waterville native whose 30-year supermarket career began when he was 15, the fledgling Maine-made food venture has generated excitement for him, as well as for the food producers and the store's customers.
"Everything to do with these Maine products is pretty unique," says Jacques, for whom procuring the specialty foods is a huge departure from his normal routine.
Huge operations such as the Shop 'n Save supermarket chain, which is owned by Hannaford Bros. typically deal in high-volume shipments ordered by computer, and often delivered by strangers.
Jacques says Maine's smaller-scale specialty food producers tend to do things a little differently, showing up at his store unannounced, say, with a baby in tow, maybe just to say hello or to drop off some products for sampling. The personal connection Jacques forges with some is a remnant of days gone by, he says.
Co-owner of The Ampersand Store in Orono since November, Roberta Bradson browsed the section recently, saying she was impressed by the diversity of products. One favorite find was the dried mushrooms sold by Oyster Creek of Damariscotta. Her own Nilsdotter brand soup mixes have sold well since their inclusion in the display, she says.
A former nurse, Sandy Wardwell co-owns The Mex restaurant in Ellsworth with her husband, Bruce. The Mex sells five of its products through the Augusta store, including hot sauce and black bean soup.
"We've dealt with Hannaford Brothers for well over 10 years. They have a good heart for Maine companies," says Wardwell.
Although products from The Mex are for sale in at least two other of the chain's stores, nowhere but in Augusta are they grouped in a Maine display, which makes a huge difference, she says. "I tend to think we're aiming at people interested in Southwestern food, but lots of people are interested just in Maine-made foods."
Maria Savoy of Marika's Kitchen in Gouldsboro says that initially she was intimidated upon approaching Hannaford Bros. to sell her product, Laura's Scottish Shortbread. "But my experience was they were encouraging and wonderful," says Savoy.
She calls the Augusta store's new initiative a "really nice opportunity to expose other people to the products, and to help Maine business."
Mike Demers of the state Department of Economic and Community Development is out to do just that. Jacques credits him and Dennis Proctor of the Maine Food Processors Association for much of the behind-the-scenes work that has helped keep the Maine-made food display going.
Jacques and his wife now buy products from the department, including Shipyard Ale from Kennebunkport, McMillen's champagne mustard from Eliot, and Mother's Mountain mustards from Falmouth.
He expects the section to grow as he becomes aware of more products, saying, "This is nothing compared to what there is."
Here are two recipes using products found in the Augusta store's Maine-made food section:
Shrimp Remoulade
2 eggs 4 tablespoons paprika 1/2 cup Mother's Mountain Portland Beer Mustard 1 1/2 cups oil 1/2 cup vinegar 1 lemon 1/3 cup Mother's Mountain ketchup 3 bay leaves 2 teaspoons horseradish 3 cloves garlic 1/2 cup green onions 1/2 cup celery 1/4 to 1/2 cup parsley 3 pounds shrimp boiled and shelled Lettuce
Put eggs, paprika and mustard into mixing bowl. Slowly beat in oil. When thick add vinegar. Squeeze in lemon juice and drop in lemon pieces. Add remaining ingredients except shrimp and lettuce. Refrigerate six hours and then remove lemon pieces. Place shrimp on bed of lettuce on a large platter and dress with remoulade.
Classic Katahdin Cole Slaw
1 large head cabbage, shredded 1 small onion, finely chopped 1 carrot, grated 1 or more cups World Harbors Mount Katahdin Lite Cole Slaw Dressing
Combine all vegetables and mix with dressing.

Lobsters are really insects

Author: Barry, Dave

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]27 Jan 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413975580?accountid=10457

Abstract: I have always maintained that they are. I personally see no significant difference between a lobster and, say, a giant Madagascar hissing cockroach, wich is a type of cockroach that grows to approximately the size of William Howard Taft (1857-1930). If a group of diners were sitting in a nice restaurant and the waiter were to bring them each a freshly killed, steaming-hot Madagascar hissing cockroach, they would not put on silly bibs and eat it with butter. No, they would run, retching, directly from the restaurant to the All-Nite Drive-Thru Lawsuit Center. And yet these very same people will pay $24.95 apiece to eat a lobster, despite the fact that it displays all three of the classic lobster biological characteristics of an insect, namely: That is not all. According to articles sent in by alert readers (this was on the FRONT PAGE of The New York Times), scientists in Denmark recently discovered that some lobsters have a weird little pervert organism living ON THEIR LIPS. Yes. I didn't even know that lobsters HAD lips, but it turns out that they do, and these lips are the stomping ground of a tiny creature called "Symbion Pandora" (literally, "a couple of Greek words"). The zoology community, which does not get out a lot, is extremely excited about Symbion Pandora, because it reproduces differently from all other life forms. According to various articles, when Symbion Pandora is ready to have a baby, its digestive system "collapses and is reconstituted into a larva," which the parent then gives birth to by "extruding" it from its "posterior." In other words -- correct me if I am wrong here -- this thing basically reproduces by pooping.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lobsters+are+really+insects&amp;author=Barry%2C+Dave&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-01-27&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: I am pleased to report that the scientific community has finaly stopped wasting time on the origins of the universe and started dealing with the important question, which is: Are lobsters really just big insects?
I have always maintained that they are. I personally see no significant difference between a lobster and, say, a giant Madagascar hissing cockroach, wich is a type of cockroach that grows to approximately the size of William Howard Taft (1857-1930). If a group of diners were sitting in a nice restaurant and the waiter were to bring them each a freshly killed, steaming-hot Madagascar hissing cockroach, they would not put on silly bibs and eat it with butter. No, they would run, retching, directly from the restaurant to the All-Nite Drive-Thru Lawsuit Center. And yet these very same people will pay $24.95 apiece to eat a lobster, despite the fact that it displays all three of the classic lobster biological characteristics of an insect, namely:
1. It has way more legs than necessary. 2. There is no way you would ever pet it.
3. It does not respond to simple commands such as, "Here, boy!"
I do not eat eat lobsters, although I once had a close call. I was visiting my good friends Tom and Pat Schroth, who live in Maine (state motto: "Cold, But Damp"). Being generous and hospitable people, Tom and Pat went out and purchased, as a special treat for me, the largest lobster in the history of the Atlantic Ocean, a lobster that had probably been responsible for sinking many commercial vessels before it was finally apprehended by nuclear submarines.
This lobster was big enough to feed a coastal Maine village for a year, and there it was, sprawling all over my plate, with scary insectoid legs and eyeballs shooting out in all directions, while Tom and Pat, my gracious hosts, smiled happily at me, waiting for me to put this thing in my mouth.
Remember when you were a child, and your mom wouldn't let you leave the dinner table until you ate all your bussels sprouts, and so you took your fork and mashed them into smaller and smaller pieces in hopes of eventually reducing them to individual brussels-sprout molecules that would be absorbed into the atmosphere and disappear? That was similar to the approach I took with the giant lobster.
"Mmmm-MMMM!" I said, hacking away at the thing on my plate, and when nobody was looking, concealing my pieces under my dinner roll, in the salad, in my napkin, anywhere I could find.
Tom and Pat: I love you dearly, and if you should even have an electrical problem that turns out to be caused by a seven-pound wad of old lobster pieces stuffed into the dining room wall socket, I am truly sorry.
Anyway, my point is that lobsters have long been suspected, by me at least, of being closet insects, which is why I was very pleased recently when my alert journalism colleague Steve Doig referred me to an Associated Press article concerning a discovery by scientists at the University of Wisconsin. The article, headlined GENE LINKS SPIDERS AND FLIES TO LOBSTERS, states that not only do lobsters, flies, spiders, millipedes, etc., contain THE EXACT SAME GENE, but they also are all descended from a single common ancestor: Howard Stern.
No, seriously, the article states that the ancestor "probably was a wormlike creature." Yum! Fetch the melted butter!
And that is not all. According to articles sent in by alert readers (this was on the FRONT PAGE of The New York Times), scientists in Denmark recently discovered that some lobsters have a weird little pervert organism living ON THEIR LIPS. Yes. I didn't even know that lobsters HAD lips, but it turns out that they do, and these lips are the stomping ground of a tiny creature called "Symbion Pandora" (literally, "a couple of Greek words"). The zoology community, which does not get out a lot, is extremely excited about Symbion Pandora, because it reproduces differently from all other life forms. According to various articles, when Symbion Pandora is ready to have a baby, its digestive system "collapses and is reconstituted into a larva," which the parent then gives birth to by "extruding" it from its "posterior." In other words -- correct me if I am wrong here -- this thing basically reproduces by pooping.
So to summarize: If you're looking for a hearty entree that (1) is related to spiders; (2) is descended from a worm; and (3) has mutant baby-poopers walking around on its lips; then you definitely want a lobster. I myself plan to continue avoiding them, just as I avoid oysters, which are clearly -- scientists should look into this next -- members of the phlegm family. Have you ever seen oysters reproduce? Neither have I, but I would not be surprised to learn that the process involves giant undersea nostrils.
And don't get me started on clams. Recently I sat across from a person who was deliberately eating clams; she'd open up a shell, and there, in plain view, would be this stark naked clam, brazenly showing its organs, like a high-school biology experiment. My feeling is that if a restaurant is going to serve those things, it should put little loincloths on them.
I believe that Mother Nature gave us eyes because she did not want us to eat this type of food. Mother Nature clearly intended for us to get our food from the "patty" group, which includes hamburgers, fish sticks and McNuggets -- foods that have had all of their organs safely removed someplace far away, such as Nebraska. That is where I stand on this issue, and if any qualified member of the lobster, clam or phlegm-in-a-shell industry wishes to present a rebuttal, I hereby extend this offer: Get your own column.

People: Schroth, Pat

Retraining effort eyeing new wave Small businesses sought for fishermen

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]16 Jan 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413785404?accountid=10457

Abstract: The Department of Labor last summer announced a $3.2 million grant to retrain Maine and New Hampshire fishermen being forced out of business by declining fish stocks and increasingly stringent state and federal regulations. The program intends to retrain about 400 fishermen during the next two years. More than 80 have expressed interest since counseling and resource centers opened in coastal counties last fall. A survey of fishermen and the evolving shape of the New England economy make the focus upon business start-ups the logical choice, [Scott Tilton] said. "We heard from 160 fishermen, with an average of 20 years in the industry. That's a long time to be independent, setting your own hours, making your own plans. While this type of program usually retrains a person to go from a factory that's closing to a different factory that's still open, it makes no sense here to try to fit people into a mold they don't fit into. Tilton said a sense of personal history also is turning many fishermen into would-be entrepreneurs. "Most of the fishermen we talk to come from a long line of fishermen, going back for generations in the same small town. Many see the handwriting on the wall as far as needing to do something else for a living, but very few are willing to relocate to work in an established business.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Retraining+effort+eyeing+new+wave+Small+businesses+sought+for+fishermen&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-01-16&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- Given the natural aversion of Maine fishermen to time clocks, a federal program to retrain those displaced by their industry's decline is shifting the effort away from big-business recruitment and toward small-business creation.
Scott Tilton, director of the U.S. Department of Labor Fishing Industries Retraining Project, said Monday early returns from fishermen interested in changing careers "shows a strong preference for developing their own small-business opportunities rather than going to work for larger employers. They know the risks, they know the work involved and they clearly like being on their own, reponsible for themselves and their families."
The Department of Labor last summer announced a $3.2 million grant to retrain Maine and New Hampshire fishermen being forced out of business by declining fish stocks and increasingly stringent state and federal regulations. The program intends to retrain about 400 fishermen during the next two years. More than 80 have expressed interest since counseling and resource centers opened in coastal counties last fall.
A $250,000 pilot program launched in Cumberland County a year ago has started 27 fishermen on course for new jobs in such diverse fields as building and mechanical trades, computer and medical technology, commercial shipping, clerical work and the ministry.
A survey of fishermen and the evolving shape of the New England economy make the focus upon business start-ups the logical choice, Tilton said. "We heard from 160 fishermen, with an average of 20 years in the industry. That's a long time to be independent, setting your own hours, making your own plans. While this type of program usually retrains a person to go from a factory that's closing to a different factory that's still open, it makes no sense here to try to fit people into a mold they don't fit into.
"Maine has traditionally been a state of small businesses -- almost 90 percent -- and the trend appears to be moving even more strongly in that direction. For this program to be successful, we need a vision of what we want the fishing industry to look like and what we want Maine to look like."
Tilton said a sense of personal history also is turning many fishermen into would-be entrepreneurs. "Most of the fishermen we talk to come from a long line of fishermen, going back for generations in the same small town. Many see the handwriting on the wall as far as needing to do something else for a living, but very few are willing to relocate to work in an established business.
This is an issue of tremendous importance to Maine -- many small, coastal communities won't survive if the declining fishing economy isn't replaced by something else."
Outside of Cumberland County, where the program had a head start, the strongest early response is from Washington County, where 19 fishermen have inquired about retraining.
While some ask about becoming diesel mechanics or electricians, Tilton said, several fishermen way Down East are looking into two truly entrepreneurial enterprises -- shellfish aquaculture and cranberry growing.
"Both of those businesses have great, untapped potential and the region is well-suited for them," Tilton said. "It's farming a crop, rather than hunting the sea, but there are some similarities that make them attractive to fishermen, issues fishermen deal with every day -- nature, the elements, working outdoors, you're concerned with a harvest, your success depends a lot on your own individual effort.
"Two other benefits of shellfish and cranberries are that they aren't as capital-intensive as a lot of other ventures, and a successful operation could provide employment for a good number of people. There's a lot of potential if they're developed properly."
The retraining project is part of a $30 million federal emergency aid program to pare down the New England fishing industry so that a smaller but more healthy fishing fleet remains should fish stocks rebound. Other elements of the program include a revolving loan fund for business development and a boat buyout.
Although fishermen aren't breaking down the doors of the retraining centers, Tilton says a lot are giving serious thought to their futures, especially with new federal regulations in the works to cut the fishing effort further.
"A lot of fishermen I talk to are doing OK financially right now, but they know they're going to have to cross over sooner or later," Tilton said. "As the new regulations start to take shape this spring, I think we'll see more and more getting off the fence. It's an extremely tough decision, but it's not a decision that can be put off much longer."

People: Tilton, Scott

Tribe mulls regulating clam harvest

Author: Diana Graettinger Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]15 Jan 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413903097?accountid=10457

Abstract: Sovereign rights, clam conservation and the right of a municipality to establish ordinances to regulate clam harvesting were the topics of a meeting Saturday between representatives of the Passamaquoddy Tribe and officials from Eastport and Perry. Eastport and Perry have enacted shellfish conservation ordinances to regulate clam harvesting in their areas. The Eastport ordinance is important because of the plan to open Half Moon Cove, nearly 300 acres of clam flats in Eastport between Carlow Island, Snyder Road and Toll Bridge Road. "The Maine state DMR is ready to open Half Moon Cove to digging. What they are waiting for is the Eastport City Council and Eastport Shellfish Committee to decide how to deal with that opening," Hopkins explained. He said a survey is needed to ascertain the number of clams the area may have.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Tribe+mulls+regulating+clam+harvest&amp;author=Diana+Graettinger+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-01-15&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PLEASANT POINT -- Sovereign rights, clam conservation and the right of a municipality to establish ordinances to regulate clam harvesting were the topics of a meeting Saturday between representatives of the Passamaquoddy Tribe and officials from Eastport and Perry.
Although everyone at the meeting clearly was in favor of protecting the clam beds from overharvesting, there was no agreement on how to regulate harvesting.
Historically, tribal members have viewed Cobscook Bay as an entity open to anyone who cared to use it. In contrast, some neighboring municipalities believe that controlled access to only a limited number of licensed commercial clammers offers greater protection to that resource.
At the meeting Saturday, Will Hopkins, project coordinator for the Cobscook Bay Clam Restoration Project, talked about the condition of Cobscook Bay, efforts to increase productivity of the clam flats and the effort to develop a regional approach to clam management.
Eastport and Perry have enacted shellfish conservation ordinances to regulate clam harvesting in their areas. The Eastport ordinance is important because of the plan to open Half Moon Cove, nearly 300 acres of clam flats in Eastport between Carlow Island, Snyder Road and Toll Bridge Road.
The Eastport Marine Resource Committee recommends that if the Maine Department of Marine Resources opens that area for the harvesting of shellfish, the one-third of the cove that connects with Carlow Island should be open to clamming, but the remaining two-thirds should remain closed for conservation purposes. The flat has been closed since 1973 because of fecal-coliform pollution.
Some believe if the area is not regulated, it will be overharvested within weeks.
"The Maine state DMR is ready to open Half Moon Cove to digging. What they are waiting for is the Eastport City Council and Eastport Shellfish Committee to decide how to deal with that opening," Hopkins explained. He said a survey is needed to ascertain the number of clams the area may have.
The Eastport ordinance calls for licenses to be issued to 15 residents and two nonresidents.
Tribal legislative Rep. Fred Moore said that Passamaquoddys believe they have a sovereign right to marine resources in the bay.
"We as native people do subscribe to certain conservation methods ... but I need to address the issue of licenses. ... The Passamaquoddy people have not ever felt that they must obtain licenses in order to engage in the harvesting of any marine resources. That is not a new position. That comes from centuries and centuries of occupying this area," he explained.
Historically, Moore said, tribal members did not believe anyone owned the sea and that its resources were available to anyone. He said the tribe would have to go through an educational process.
"We must understand what has happened to the clams and other resources. We have to educate our people, and you must bear with us while we catch up on this issue. We must bring home the importance of the idea of conservation," the tribal representative said.
Eastport City Council Chairman Charlie Lewis told Moore that there was no effort to lock anyone out of the harvesting, but the city was looking at ways to protect the valuable resource.
Moore said there were fewer Passamaquoddy clam diggers than in years past. He estimated there were about 12 commercial diggers during the winter months and a few more in the summer.
Although the tribe has an ordinance that requires tribal members to be licensed for marine resource harvesting, there is no ordinance that specifically deals with shellfish harvesting. Moore said the tribe would not enter into any agreement with a neighboring community that would relinquish the tribe's sovereign rights.
"I can tell you if we did enter into any agreement, it would be subject to renewal on an annual basis. The tribe will not lock itself, or future generations, into something they could not pursue in the future," Moore explained.

People: Moore, Fred

County commissioner count revisited

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]10 Jan 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413904380?accountid=10457

Abstract: "We may sit on it until after the referendum," said the delegation's chairwoman, Rep. Theone Look, R-Jonesboro. She will propose emergency legislation to amend the existing commissioner vacancy law so the governor can appoint an interim commissioner until [Mary Follis]' term expires or she returns to the commission. A public straw poll last week at a meeting attended by 30 people unanimously opposed a five-member commission. Denying that his board has ignored the county's need for economic development, [Norman Nelson Sr.] said Tuesday that he and [Edward Cline] budgeted about $90,000 to sustain economic-oriented public service organizations this year. County grants for 1996 included $40,000 for the University of Maine Extension; $15,350 for program grants, including $4,200 for the Sunrise Economic Council and $2,500 for Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery; $11,340 for the Soil & Water Conservation District; $7,500 for Eastern Maine Development District; $6,160 for Regional Planning Commission; $4,800 for airports; and $3,000 for Resource Conservation and Development. [Harry Bailey], Sen. Vinton Cassidy, R-Calais, and Rep. Joseph Driscoll, D-Calais -- all members of the Legislature's Transportation Committee -- got "a major portion of the Department of Transportation's construction funds last year," Bailey said, to build a new $13 million cargo port at Estes Head in Eastport.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=County+commissioner+count+revisited&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-01-10&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: MACHIAS -- Most members of the Washington County legislative delegation say a larger board of county commissioners ought to enable the board to shoulder more responsibility for improving the county's economic future by building on its wood, aquaculture, blueberry and cranberry industries, and by squeezing development opportunities out of the Port of Eastport.
Rep. Harry Bailey, R-Grand Lake Stream, criticized the current commissioners this week for not doing more to promote economic development and for rejecting the delegation's successful legislation that gave the commission two additional seats.
"The commissioners in this county have been derelict of their duties. We need an aggressive board that will work with the governor and business to improve the economy of this county. I still feel the county needs five commissioners. I feel that this county is dying on the vine because of a lack of leaders who should be looking to develop the county," he said.
Commissioners Norman Nelson Sr. and Edward Cline, who have worked as a two-member board since last June, when Chairwoman Mary Follis was incapacitated by a freak highway accident, countered Bailey's criticism Tuesday, saying the governor's appointment of two additional commissioners would unnecessarily increase the county tax assessment by about $38,000.
The delegation and the commission are in agreement that a countywide referendum should be held in March or November for voters to resolve the commissioner count issue.
The delegation will meet this morning in Augusta to consider allowing the five-commissioner law to go unrepealed until after the referendum.
"We may sit on it until after the referendum," said the delegation's chairwoman, Rep. Theone Look, R-Jonesboro. She will propose emergency legislation to amend the existing commissioner vacancy law so the governor can appoint an interim commissioner until Follis' term expires or she returns to the commission. A public straw poll last week at a meeting attended by 30 people unanimously opposed a five-member commission.
Nelson predicts voters would discard the five-commissioner concept because "at our public meeting last Friday night, a good cross section of 30 county people were unanimously against having five commissioners. They only wanted the existing law amended to allow the governor to appoint an interim commissioner as a stand-in for Mary Follis."
Reps. James Layton, R-Cherryfield, and George Bunker, D-Topsfield, in interviews Tuesday, disagreed with Nelson's assessment of the straw poll. "It is absolutely foolishness for anyone to say that was a good cross section of county residents," Layton said. Only two people from his district, both from Addison, attended the public hearing, he said.
Denying that his board has ignored the county's need for economic development, Nelson said Tuesday that he and Cline budgeted about $90,000 to sustain economic-oriented public service organizations this year. County grants for 1996 included $40,000 for the University of Maine Extension; $15,350 for program grants, including $4,200 for the Sunrise Economic Council and $2,500 for Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery; $11,340 for the Soil & Water Conservation District; $7,500 for Eastern Maine Development District; $6,160 for Regional Planning Commission; $4,800 for airports; and $3,000 for Resource Conservation and Development.
"I know we have a severe unemployment problem, but I hope our legislators don't try to correct it with five commissioners," said Cline. "We've done what we could do, but those in Augusta have been no help. We had an opportunity to have 700 to 800 jobs by approving a casino for Calais, but they turned it down, saying it would corrupt us morally. It was they who didn't do their best work for this county."
Bailey, in his argument for a greater countywide vision of economic development, said, "A five-commissioner board would give this county a more broad range of vision of economic development at the grass-roots level." Several people interested in gaining the governor's appointment to a five-member board have mentioned in their resumes that they have a strong interest in building up the county's overall economy, he added.
A significant part of the commission's work, Bailey said, should be committed to attracting state and federal grants that can be used appropriately on economic development projects that result in generating jobs. "I think if we rely just on Dianne Tilton {executive director of Sunrise Economic Council} and the legislative delegation to get the job done, it isn't going to get done."
The county should develop "an economic development plan that unites, consolidates, and involves appropriate research people from the University of Maine, bankers, business leaders and administrators from our towns and cities. We've got knowledgeable people all around this county," he said. "We need to get them in a room together and plan some direction. We could get any amount of money necessary to create jobs. You can't overdo economic development."
Bailey, Sen. Vinton Cassidy, R-Calais, and Rep. Joseph Driscoll, D-Calais -- all members of the Legislature's Transportation Committee -- got "a major portion of the Department of Transportation's construction funds last year," Bailey said, to build a new $13 million cargo port at Estes Head in Eastport.
Eastport has already become New England's fastest-growing international cargo port and a critical part of the state's transportation network by shipping products to global markets. The Estes Head facility will be improved to accommodate 900-foot container ships. "But we won't be drawing on the container port's greatest potential if we don't make railroad container cars available," Bailey said.
"In the next 10 years, this county should re-establish train service between Machias and Bangor," he said. "For $20 million we could get the track. That would be a pretty good investment, considering $20 million only builds 15 miles of road."
"What Harry is saying makes a lot of sense," said Layton. You can't leave all that load on Dianne Tilton. A five-member board of commissioners would lessen the excuse that they are overburdened."
"The commissioners should lead the charge and we could pick it up and take it to the governor and the Legislature," said Bunker.

People: Bailey, Harry Nelson, Norman Sr Cline, Edward Follis, Mary Layton, James

Jonesport home, Beals plant burn

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]06 Jan 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413858995?accountid=10457

Abstract: Fires on Thursday and Friday destroyed part of a shellfish plant in Beals, and gutted the first floor of a home at the head of Dan Watt Beach in Jonesport. The Addison Fire Department was called as a backup on the Carver fire because Jonesport Fire Department's hose lines began to freeze in temperatures that hovered around zero.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Jonesport+home%2C+Beals+plant+burn&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-01-06&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: JONESPORT -- Fires on Thursday and Friday destroyed part of a shellfish plant in Beals, and gutted the first floor of a home at the head of Dan Watt Beach in Jonesport.
At 2 a.m. Thursday, fire destroyed an ice-making machine, a seafood products cooler, and a 30-by-30-foot section of roof at the Carver Shellfish Co. plant on the Black Duck Cove Road on Great Wass Island.
Fire Chief Randy Kelley said one of Carver's truck drivers, returning to the plant after a delivery, spotted the fire and alerted firefighters.
The Addison Fire Department was called as a backup on the Carver fire because Jonesport Fire Department's hose lines began to freeze in temperatures that hovered around zero.
An electrical wiring problem may have caused the fire, Kelley said.
At 1 p.m. Friday, fire gutted the kitchen and other rooms on the first floor of Eddie Hagan's house on Bridge Street in Jonesport.
Fast response by firefighters from the U.S. Coast Guard Station, located a few feet from the Hagan house, prevented more serious damage to the two-story dwelling. The fire may have been caused by an electrical wiring problem, the chief said.

War memorials planned in Rockland, Warren

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]03 Jan 1996: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413810959?accountid=10457

Abstract: In Rockland, the Rockland Area Veteran's Memorial Committee will sponsor an "After the Holidays" bottle drive to raise money. The organization is planning to erect a monument at the Mechanic Street Snow Memorial Park. Volunteers are involved from the Rotary, Kiwanis, Elks, Rockland Share the Pride, Rockland-Thomaston area Chamber of Commerce, American Legion, Veterans of Foreign Wars and Marine Corps League.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=War+memorials+planned+in+Rockland%2C+Warren&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1996-01-03&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- Rockland and Warren veterans are planning war memorials.
In Rockland, the Rockland Area Veteran's Memorial Committee will sponsor an "After the Holidays" bottle drive to raise money. The organization is planning to erect a monument at the Mechanic Street Snow Memorial Park.
Those interested in donating bottles should call 594-5026 or 594-2982 for pickup on Saturday, Jan. 6. Volunteers will be picking up bottles from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. Donations can also be dropped off at the American Legion Post on Maverick Street.
Volunteers are involved from the Rotary, Kiwanis, Elks, Rockland Share the Pride, Rockland-Thomaston area Chamber of Commerce, American Legion, Veterans of Foreign Wars and Marine Corps League.
In Warren, a war memorial committee has been at work gathering names of Warren natives who have served in the armed services during five wars. In a project expected to cost $11,000, bronze plaques attached to a stone monument will carry the names of the residents.
The monument will honor those who served in the Persian Gulf War, Vietnam, Korea, World War II and World War I. The names of the veterans are on a list at Town Hall, the post office and the Oyster River Grange for review.
Donations to the fund drive can be made any time. Those with questions should contact committee members William Chapman, Ed Boggs, Joe Cifaldo, Casey Smith or Art Jura.

Exotic species delicate

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]22 Dec 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413884786?accountid=10457

Abstract: Maine "snowbirds" heading to Florida for the winter months may find an unpleasant surprise in store for them. The red fire ant, introduced to North America from Brazil by ships docking in Mobile in the 1930s, has now become widespread throughout the entire Southeast. Packing a vicious bite, it has been observed killing young birds, reptiles, rodents, and fawns, the fire ant has no natural enemies in its adopted land. It has proven a deadly foe to native species in its path killing off up to 40 percent of all native insects in areas that it has invaded. The red ant has even proven fatal to some humans allergic to its venom while making life unpleasant for countless others who have suffered by its bite. According to Chris Bright, associate editor of World Watch, the red fire ant is only one example of what can happen when human activity introduces exotic species into new habitat.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Exotic+species+delicate&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-12-22&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Maine "snowbirds" heading to Florida for the winter months may find an unpleasant surprise in store for them. The red fire ant, introduced to North America from Brazil by ships docking in Mobile in the 1930s, has now become widespread throughout the entire Southeast. Packing a vicious bite, it has been observed killing young birds, reptiles, rodents, and fawns, the fire ant has no natural enemies in its adopted land. It has proven a deadly foe to native species in its path killing off up to 40 percent of all native insects in areas that it has invaded. The red ant has even proven fatal to some humans allergic to its venom while making life unpleasant for countless others who have suffered by its bite. According to Chris Bright, associate editor of World Watch, the red fire ant is only one example of what can happen when human activity introduces exotic species into new habitat.
Also in the 1930s, someone conceived of the idea of drying up the Everglades by covering it with seeds of the Melaleuca tree, a native of Australia noted for taking up large quantities of water. The result is a dense, impenetrable stand of trees that have displaced nearly every other type of vegetation. The Melaleuca has taken over 1.5 million acres of Florida wetlands and, says U.S. Agriculture Department expert Ronald Myers, "Soon the Everglades will be no more." Most exotic species have found their way into the United States by accident but a few have been introduced deliberately. The starling, native to England, has conquered the United States thanks to a theatrical society determined on introducing every bird mentioned in the plays of Shakespeare into North America. In the 1960s the state of Montana introduced the opposum shrimp into the Flathead River in hopes of providing food for another import, a species of salmon introduced as a game fish. Instead, the shrimp nearly destroyed the local zooplankton, the main food supply for salmon, and the fish population collapsed. Along with it went many species, as eagles, coyotes, and bears that depended on the salmon for food.
Exotic imports frequently cause economic, as well as environmental, damage according to Bright. The 1981 outbreak of gypsy moth caused losses to U.S. forests estimated at $764 million. The zebra mussel, a recently arrived shellfish from the Caspian, has already started to clog waterways throughout the east since entering the Great Lakes fromballast water pumped out of cargo ships. The mussel attaches to any available surface including powerplant water pipes forcing the industry to spend $60 million annually on maintenance and $800 million to redesign its cooling systems.
Although ecologists have numerous examples of the after-effects of placing exotic species in a new habitat, there is little in these "after the fact" cases that will allow a prediction of what damage a new introduction will cause.
Bright says the accumulated evidence can be summed up in three statement, all negative. It is impossible to say where an exotic imported species will establish itself, what damage it will do, or when it will do it. A species of dove introduced into southern Europe from Turkey maintained a low, constant population for more than two centuries until it exploded across the continent beginning in 1930. Why? No one really knows. In the American Midwest, says Bright, an ornamental garden shrub escaped into the wild displacing a number of native species. Again there is no good explanation except the suggestion that species spread out after having adapted to local climates and human activities. The Asian tiger mosquito arrived in the United States in the mid-1980s in water trapped in junk auto tires. Since then it has fine-tuned its daylight sensitivity.
Bright warns that the expanding global economy is giving rise to an equally expanding biological pollution in terms of exotic species into new habitats. Almost no scientific predictive evidence exists for such invasions and they should be guarded against as stringently as keeping infectious diseases from our shores.
Clair Wood is a science instructor at Eastern Maine Technical College and the NEWS science columnist.

Girl Scouts keep helpful holiday tradition

Author: Joni Averill Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]22 Dec 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413839763?accountid=10457

Abstract: For three years, the young Girl Scouts under the leadership of Penny Holmes and Nancy Hanlon of Brewer have helped out the less fortunate in their community. Now third-grade Brownies, the eight youngsters from Pendleton Street School are continuing the tradition they began as Daisy Scouts. They particularly enjoy their Christmas experiences, Holmes said. "They really have a great time buying gifts and getting them wrapped." Also last month, the troop purchased pet toys and cat box filler, delivering 200 pounds to the Bangor Humane Society. Two years ago, after a brother of a troop member made a visit to the Eastern Maine Medical Center emergency room, and the girls learned that no toys were available for waiting patients, the troop donated toys to the ER.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Girl+Scouts+keep+helpful+holiday+tradition&amp;author=Joni+Averill+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-12-22&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: For three years, the young Girl Scouts under the leadership of Penny Holmes and Nancy Hanlon of Brewer have helped out the less fortunate in their community.
Now third-grade Brownies, the eight youngsters from Pendleton Street School are continuing the tradition they began as Daisy Scouts. They particularly enjoy their Christmas experiences, Holmes said. "They really have a great time buying gifts and getting them wrapped."
Last year, Troop 589 participated in a yearlong project starting in October. "We helped out one particular family," Holmes said. "We didn't know who the people were. It was all done through the school. But each month the girls would do something different for that family."
Money to purchase food and gifts comes from the Scouts' magazine and cookie sales. This year, the girls put together a complete Thanksgiving dinner for a needy Brewer family.
"People just park when they see us coming," Holmes said about taking the entire troop shopping. "Actually, they head for the hills. The girls do all the grocery shopping and they have a wonderful time. People enjoy watching them."
Also last month, the troop purchased pet toys and cat box filler, delivering 200 pounds to the Bangor Humane Society. Two years ago, after a brother of a troop member made a visit to the Eastern Maine Medical Center emergency room, and the girls learned that no toys were available for waiting patients, the troop donated toys to the ER.
On Tuesday, Troop 589 held its annual Christmas party, which was another opportunity to help a neighbor in need.
This year, its Christmas gift request came from MERT, a local independent agency that helps support mentally handicapped adults. One client wanted a doll, the troop was told.
"The girls purchased the doll, and then each of them, instead of exchanging gifts among themselves, bought a gift for the doll," Holmes said.
In between the pizza and the cookies, they wrapped the gifts that will certainly make someone very happy this Christmas.
An event that helps kick off the holiday season in the Greater Ellsworth area -- the fourh annual Poinsettia Ball, which took place the first Saturday in December at the White Birches Restaurant in Hancock -- raised $14,000 for the Maine Coast Memeorial Hospital emergency room, MCMH development director Don Baril reported this week to the hospital's board of directors.
Katherine Heidinger and Bette Pierson served as chairwomen of a 13-member committee that spent four months organizing the fund-raiser. More than 280 people paid $50 per person for an evening of dining and dancing in a Christmas setting. The event was sponsored by R.H. Foster Inc. and Machias Savings Bank. Atlantic Salmon of Maine donated fresh salmon and Maine Shellfish fresh shrimp for the popular fund-raiser.
The $14,000 will be used to purchase an additional defibrillator for the ER and to revamp the ER reception area to provide more privacy for patients and family members. MCMH served more than 20,000 people last year through the hospital, the Eleanor Widener Dixon Memorial Clinic in Gouldsboro, and the Southwest Harbor Medical Center.
Even during the holiday season, the Kids Campaign to help save Fort Knox is not forgotten.
Friends of Fort Knox spokesman George MacLeod informs us that children at the Bucksport Middle School had volunteered to stuff envelopes Wednesday and Thursday for an emergency mailing for the restoration fund, but the snowstorm closed local schools, and it looked like the project would be left undone since vacation officially begins today.
But you can't keep good kids down, especially when they care about Maine's most visited historic site. This morning, several students are volunteering their time, at school, to stuff those envelopes.
Don't forget the Hampden Fire Department after-holiday bottle and can drive Jan. 1-15.
Drop off cans and bottles at the Fire Department, or call 862-4586 to have them picked up by a department member. The money raised goes toward the purchase of a hydraulic rescue tool.
Through mid-December, nearly one-third of the $15,000 goal has been raised. Raffle tickets are selling well, reports Lt. Frank Coombs, and may be purchased at the department or from any HFD member. In the first eight days of the canister drive, more than $160 in loose change had been contributed to the fund-raiser.
"The community has been very suportive and we want to thank them for this support," said Coombs.
The Standpipe, Bangor Daily News, P.O. Box 1329, Bangor 04402; 990-8288.

Clam diggers far from clear about future Industry members split on need for tightening or loosening limits

Author: Emmet Meara Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]11 Dec 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413896190?accountid=10457

Abstract: With big losses in digging jobs and sales during the past decade, the state's clam industry is struggling to restore depleted clam beds, while developing sophisticated controls to protect what is left of the resource. Waldoboro clam digger David Sanborn said the state's 1,627 licensed diggers should be allowed to dig "anywhere we want to on the 3,500-mile coastline." Sanborn and other clam diggers are collecting petitions to repeal all municipal clam ordinances, which normally restrict nonresident permits to a handful per year. If enough signatures are collected, the repeal measure will be on the state ballot, he said. Unrestricted digging would lead to "the death of the clam industry," according to James MacLeod of Brunswick, which protects its $2 million a year clam resource with a clam ordinance that is seen as a model for other coastal communities.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Clam+diggers+far+from+clear+about+future+Industry+members+split+on+need+for+tightening+or+loosening+limits&amp;author=Emmet+Meara+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-12-11&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKPORT -- With big losses in digging jobs and sales during the past decade, the state's clam industry is struggling to restore depleted clam beds, while developing sophisticated controls to protect what is left of the resource.
At a session on municipal clam management held at the Samoset Resort Inn on Friday, it was obvious that the several hundred industry representatives were split on a future course. Some wanted no regulation. Others wanted more regulation, even a tax on landings to raise money for research on reseeding and the effects of pollution by municipal waste treatment plants, paper mills and the blueberry industry.
Waldoboro clam digger David Sanborn said the state's 1,627 licensed diggers should be allowed to dig "anywhere we want to on the 3,500-mile coastline." Sanborn and other clam diggers are collecting petitions to repeal all municipal clam ordinances, which normally restrict nonresident permits to a handful per year. If enough signatures are collected, the repeal measure will be on the state ballot, he said.
"We want to be able to go anywhere and make a living, like our fathers did," said James Beam of Edgecomb.
Unrestricted digging would lead to "the death of the clam industry," according to James MacLeod of Brunswick, which protects its $2 million a year clam resource with a clam ordinance that is seen as a model for other coastal communities.
If laws were repealed, diggers would clean out "hot spots" like Brunswick, where some healthy flats remain, then move up the coast, MacLeod said. Even with its model clam ordinance, Brunswick was forced to close the flats for the winter "because they were hammered so bad," MacLeod said.
Repealing the municipal ordinances would place the clam industry into the same condition as the groundfish resource, said Joel Knee of West Bath. "If you open it up, you won't have a single clam left in West Bath," he said. He told the conference he was as much a Mainer as anyone in the huge Samoset meeting room, although he was born in Utah.
As usual, the clam management discussion considered the repeal of the 2-inch clam law. With Maine diggers prohibited from taking a clam smaller than 2 inches, a strong restaurant market for smaller "steamer" clams will go to other states, diggers said. Since the 2-inch law was passed in 1984, production has dropped by 67 percent, said Mike Brewer of Damariscotta. He favored repeal of the law.
No clam production area has been harder hit than Washington and Hancock county flats that used to produce 65 percent of the state's clam landings. Now the production is down to 22-23 percent, with an annual decline of $5 million in landings along with hundreds of jobs.
Clammers should welcome regulation and insist on greater water quality control, according to Will Hopkins of Eastport.
"I want to be able to shuck a clam on any flat and eat it. I don't want to worry about it. My father didn't have to worry about it and I don't want my kids to worry about it," Hopkins said. He said Maine should set goals of manufacturing paper without placing any dioxin in the water and making shellfish safe to eat, anywhere in the state.
Along the lengthy coast of Washington and Hancock counties, clam bed surveys in many towns are more difficult to conduct than in relatively compact communities like Brunswick, which has only 400 acres of beds and a population of 20,000.
In Eastport, with a population of 2,000, there are more than 1,300 acres of clam beds and "practically no clams." The Down East community is working with schoolchildren to monitor clam beds as a science project. "It beats the hell out of watching MTV," Hopkins said.
Since Robin Alden was named state Department of Marine Resources commissioner, Augusta has shown a marked improvement in attitude, Hopkins said. "We don't have to spit when we say `state' or `DMR' anymore," he said. Hopkins took the heretical step of suggesting a tax on clam sales to support reseeding and research projects.
The key to a comprehensive, working management system will be public relations and education, said Peter Angis of Scarborough. Towns should welcome recreational diggers, who can become an asset at budget time when funds are sought for seeding or other clam projects. Scarborough, described as the fastest-growing town in Maine, has continuing problems with development and its effect on the clam flats, Angis said. "Every new roof is a new problem," he said.
Community involvement is vital, said MacLeod. Brunswick rotates open flats every 10 days to protect the resource and keep its 86 clam diggers at work. With licenses sold at $100 a year, the town has a $60,000 budget for clam control and restoration.
Although clamming used to be thought of as the "saltwater poor farm, I am not ashamed to be a clam digger. I have dug for 30 years," MacLeod said.
Most speakers agreed that something has to be done in managing the flats. "You're lucky to get a peck of clams anywhere in the state," complained one woman.

Clammers seek answers for losses Officials shed light on shrinking industry

Author: Diana Graettinger Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]04 Dec 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413826230?accountid=10457

Abstract: The Maine clam industry has lost millions of dollars and thousands of jobs during the past decade, and people here want to know what can be done to make the industry in the Cobscook Bay area viable again. On Saturday, nearly 40 recreational and commercial clammers and members of the town's clam committees met at the Marine Technology Center to consider ways to improve management and increase productivity in the Cobscook Bay area clam flats. Closure of clam flats often leads to an outcry from local clammers. During the meeting Saturday, Paul Anderson, director of Shellfish Sanitation for the Department of Marine Resources, drew laughter when he began his presentation with a quick question and answer. "Why do we close clam flats, and who decides? I decide. Any questions?" he asked.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Clammers+seek+answers+for+losses+Officials+shed+light+on+shrinking+industry&amp;author=Diana+Graettinger+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-12-04&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: EASTPORT -- The Maine clam industry has lost millions of dollars and thousands of jobs during the past decade, and people here want to know what can be done to make the industry in the Cobscook Bay area viable again.
On Saturday, nearly 40 recreational and commercial clammers and members of the town's clam committees met at the Marine Technology Center to consider ways to improve management and increase productivity in the Cobscook Bay area clam flats.
The group also discussed sending delegates to a statewide meeting in Rockport on Dec. 8.
Closure of clam flats often leads to an outcry from local clammers. During the meeting Saturday, Paul Anderson, director of Shellfish Sanitation for the Department of Marine Resources, drew laughter when he began his presentation with a quick question and answer. "Why do we close clam flats, and who decides? I decide. Any questions?" he asked.
Clammers had plenty of questions about closure of the flats, environmental impact, and possible solutions to problems that close the flats.
Anderson explained that pollution hurts clamming. "We are talking about sewage pollutants, things that we know get into clams and make them harmful. That is why we close them," he explained.
Chemical pollutants such as Velpar, an herbicide used on blueberry lands, are not addressed by Anderson's department, although he admitted those issues need to be examined.
"Somewhere along the way, we need to bring in researchers, perhaps environmental protection agencies and other means of looking at those questions. I don't think we can expect the DMR to answer all those questions for you," he said.
Anderson warned that figures regarding the size of clam flats statewide should be viewed cautiously. He said there are about 98,000 acres of flats.
"Don't take these numbers as gospel because there are different ways of getting these numbers. But it has been said for the last 20 years that about a third of our flats are closed statewide. Of course, depending on where you live, 100 percent of your flats may be closed," he said.
The pollution problems the DMR examines include: municipal treatment plants; licensed overboard discharge; septic system straight pipes; septic system malfunctions; outhouses; waste left behind by domestic animals and wildlife; marinas and anchorages; and streams and other fresh water.
Anderson said water-quality monitoring involves 2,400 stations from Kittery to Canada, which are sampled six times each year. Once the water has been tested, the flat from which it was taken is placed in one of four possible classifications: approved, which means it may remain open; prohibited, which means it must close; restricted, which means there may be a pollution problem but it is not affecting the immediate area; and conditionally approved.
Anderson explained that flats receive conditional approval because of differing seasonal conditions.
"We might find out that it is dirty in the summer, but clean in the winter. Then we look around and see there is a marina and boats and a lot of summer activity. So then we will close it when the data is bad and have it open on the off-season," he said.
In order to reopen a flat, Anderson said, there has to be a change.
"I need to see that the water quality has improved. Or someone calls up and says `We got rid of those three failing septic systems, or the overboard discharge has moved, or we put in a sewage treatment plant and the outfall is over there where there aren't any clams,"' he said.
Anderson said the Department of Environmental Protection has two programs in place to monitor and replace licensed overboard discharge or failed septic systems polluting clam flats. He encouraged small communities in the area to take advantage of those programs.

Theft of rugs gets six-year sentence Property taken from homes in 3 counties

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]01 Dec 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413796892?accountid=10457

Abstract: Described as a born-again Christian and a clamdigger, a former Thomaston resident was sentenced to six years in prison Thursday for the 1993 thefts of rugs and other valuables from homes in Hancock, Washington and Lincoln counties. Jeffrey A. Herrick, 32, was found guilty in Hancock County Superior Court earlier this month on three counts of Class B theft and five counts of Class C theft. A jury found him not guilty of several related burglary charges. In appealing for a stiff sentence, Hancock County District Attorney Michael Povich described the crimes as the "systematic" theft of property from elderly people and owners of summer homes. "This is Mr. Herrick's profession," he said.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Theft+of+rugs+gets+six-year+sentence+Property+taken+from+homes+in+3+counties&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-12-01&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ELLSWORTH -- Described as a born-again Christian and a clamdigger, a former Thomaston resident was sentenced to six years in prison Thursday for the 1993 thefts of rugs and other valuables from homes in Hancock, Washington and Lincoln counties.
Jeffrey A. Herrick, 32, was found guilty in Hancock County Superior Court earlier this month on three counts of Class B theft and five counts of Class C theft. A jury found him not guilty of several related burglary charges.
In appealing for a stiff sentence, Hancock County District Attorney Michael Povich described the crimes as the "systematic" theft of property from elderly people and owners of summer homes. "This is Mr. Herrick's profession," he said.
Called in by Povich to recount Herrick's criminal history, Lincoln County District Attorney Geoffrey Rushlau cited several shellfish harvesting and driving violations, as well as what he described as a relatively minor animal cruelty charge.
Defense attorney Jeffrey Toothaker portrayed his client as a hard worker who had done well in recent times supporting his family with "woods work" in Wisconsin.
In addressing the shellfishing offenses, Toothaker suggested that Superior Court Justice Paul T. Pierson, the judge hearing the case, might be unfamiliar with clamming practices because of his Aroostook County background.
Clamming in closed areas is an "occupational hazard," virtually inevitable as more harvesting areas are closed each year, said Toothaker.
Speaking on his own behalf before the sentencing, Herrick described himself as a good person "with rough edges." He said he never stole any rugs, but did go once with an antique dealer to meet with owners of the kinds of rugs he knew the dealer wanted to buy. He said he never told police his side of the story because they didn't ask for it.
In imposing his sentence, Judge Pierson noted Herrick's "remarkable" and extensive criminal record, which includes two years in a Wisconsin prison on a manslaughter charge stemming from a car crash resulting in his boss's death.
Pierson said the series of thefts suggested that Herrick is a professional thief with little regard for the law. He said he would not require restitution for property owners' losses, because it was unlikely it would ever be collected from Herrick.
