Cap Morrill's lobsters travel far and wide

Author: Brian Swartz Advertising Staff Editor

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]30 Nov 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413786599?accountid=10457

Abstract: Maine lobsters often travel cross-country, thanks to Cap Morrill's Inc., the well-known Brewer business located at 7 Baker Blvd. in the East-West Industrial Park. Henry Morrill established Cap Morrill's in South Brewer in 1904. He ran a restaurant, a store, and a fish market there for many years, with his four sons (Henry, Carleton, Richard, and James) taking over by mid-century. Today, Phil Morrill, Carleton's son, and his mother and aunt, Stella and Cecile Morrill, own the company. In April 1992, the Morrills purchased a vacant building in the East-West Industrial Park, remodeled it, and moved their business there that November. "I had looked at buildings since 1985, and this was the first building that popped up for sale that met our needs," Morrill said.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Cap+Morrill%27s+lobsters+travel+far+and+wide&amp;author=Brian+Swartz+Advertising+Staff+Editor&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-11-30&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Maine lobsters often travel cross-country, thanks to Cap Morrill's Inc., the well-known Brewer business located at 7 Baker Blvd. in the East-West Industrial Park.
Henry Morrill established Cap Morrill's in South Brewer in 1904. He ran a restaurant, a store, and a fish market there for many years, with his four sons (Henry, Carleton, Richard, and James) taking over by mid-century. Today, Phil Morrill, Carleton's son, and his mother and aunt, Stella and Cecile Morrill, own the company.
"We distribute seafood locally and nationwide," Phil Morrill said. "We sold the restaurant some time ago, but we still have the fish market, which is in the same spot on South Main Street." The company employs 18 people.
In April 1992, the Morrills purchased a vacant building in the East-West Industrial Park, remodeled it, and moved their business there that November. "I had looked at buildings since 1985, and this was the first building that popped up for sale that met our needs," Morrill said.
The Morrills built a loading dock and added refrigeration equipment and lobster-holding tanks: fiberglass tanks that can hold 7,000-8,000 pounds and a large concrete tank that can store 144 pallets (about 14,000 pounds). If necessary, "with our overnight capacity, we can store 23,000 pounds (of lobster) here," Morrill said. The tanks are filled with fresh salt water trucked from the coast.
Cap Morrill's distributes seafood in the greater Bangor area with its own trucks. Carl Smith Foods distributes the company's products to Maine customers.
Distant markets are serviced by Federal Express or major airlines. "We are shipping everything from two or three lobsters to an individual, which would go by FedEx," Morrill said, "to a can (a container that holds 2,400 pounds) to go by air (from Bangor or Boston) to another distributor out of state."
Cap Morrill's ships lobsters and scallops to markets in California, Texas, and the Midwest. The company does a strong business in Florida, Morrill said. The Maine tourist season brings strong sales, as do such holidays as Mother's Day and Christmas.
"Lobsters are probably 80 percent of our business. Fish would be the other 20," Morrill said. "We're distributing scallops, haddock, Atlantic salmon, plus swordfish, tuna, halibut, clams, oysters, and periwinkles."
Illustration Caption: Cap Morrill's Inc. has been a Brewer institution since 1904. The company is now located in the East-West Industrial Park. (NEWS Photo by Brian Swartz)

Brunswick's shellfish warden to retire After 20 years of challenging work on the flats, Alan Houston to hang up his boots

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]28 Nov 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413782684?accountid=10457

Abstract: Alan Houston has come a long way from the days when clam diggers he regulates slashed his tires and threw mud at him. Now, as he prepares to retire after 20 years as Brunswick's marine warden and one of the state's most experienced wardens, Houston enjoys the respect of state legislators, scientists and environmental advocates. "I don't think clammers can be impressed by wardens. They're just someone there to play cat-and-mouse with," chuckled clammer James MacLeod. But the diggers "have more respect for Alan. Therefore they have to work harder to get around him."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Brunswick%27s+shellfish+warden+to+retire+After+20+years+of+challenging+work+on+the+flats%2C+Alan+Houston+to+hang+up+his+boots&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-11-28&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   BRUNSWICK -- Alan Houston has come a long way from the days when clam diggers he regulates slashed his tires and threw mud at him.
Now, as he prepares to retire after 20 years as Brunswick's marine warden and one of the state's most experienced wardens, Houston enjoys the respect of state legislators, scientists and environmental advocates.
Even some of the diggers will allow that Houston is OK.
"I don't think clammers can be impressed by wardens. They're just someone there to play cat-and-mouse with," chuckled clammer James MacLeod. But the diggers "have more respect for Alan. Therefore they have to work harder to get around him."
"We hope there'll be more people like him in time, with good training both in enforcement and management," said Dana Wallace, a shellfish management consultant who worked for 38 years in what is now the state Department of Marine Resources.
Houston, who is retiring from his $31,460-a-year job to spend more time with his family, is departing at a time when the economic value of Maine's shellfish resource is increasingly being recognized.
This month, the Casco Bay Estuary Project estimated that the economy could gain $3.7 million a year if the closed clam beds in Casco Bay were made fit to open.
The Gulf of Maine Council has proposed making restoration of shellfish habitat one of its priorities for the next five years.
Representatives from coastal towns will gather Dec. 8 in Rockport for a conference organized by the University of Maine Cooperative Extension to plan a strategy for increasing clam production statewide.
"People are looking up, trying to come to grips" with the problem, Houston said.
Houston became Brunswick's first full-time marine warden in 1976 at a robust time in the state's clamming industry. In 1973, a peak year, the industry employed nearly 6,000 people who dug 7 million pounds of steamers.
Later, flats began closing because of the threat or existence of bacterial pollution, generally from sewage discharges, throwing the industry into a slump by 1983.
In 1994, the clamming work force had shriveled to about 1,650 people, whose collective harvest was 2 million pounds. Though comparatively meager, the harvest fetched $8.8 million -- enough money to make soft-shell clams Maine's fourth most valuable commercial marine species.
As the clamming industry declined, its centers shifted from Washington County to Cumberland County, and towns like Brunswick, Freeport, Harpswell and Scarborough began devoting more attention to their flats.
When Houston was hired in Brunswick, the town's only requirement for clammers was that they have a license. Since then, the requirements have expanded, and so have Houston's responsibilities.
Nowadays, in addition to checking licenses, he samples water for laboratory testing; inspects shoreline properties for sources of pollution; posts mud flats that must be closed because of pollution or depleted stocks; lectures school children; and even lobbies the Legi- slature for new laws.
"When Alan's there, why, you know there's somebody there who knows what it's all about," said Rep. Theone Look, R-Jonesboro, a 10-year veteran of the Legislature's Marine Resources Committee.

Lamoine's first general store nears reality as plans OK'd

Author: Kathy Harbour Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]23 Nov 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413949083?accountid=10457

Abstract: A general store in Lamoine should open this winter, selectmen said Wednesday. To be situated at the intersection of Routes 184 and 204, the store will be the only one of its kind in Lamoine, a community that has no stores and few commercial enterprises. Lamoine voters overturned the community's traditional dry status last year, repealing a prohibition on the sale of beer and wine. The question on the repeal was brought to voters through a petition drive spearheaded by [Ruth] Keene and fellow entreprenuer David Schroeder. They said their plan for the store was contingent on being able to sell beer and wine.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lamoine%27s+first+general+store+nears+reality+as+plans+OK%27d&amp;author=Kathy+Harbour+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-11-23&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: LAMOINE -- A general store in Lamoine should open this winter, selectmen said Wednesday.
To be situated at the intersection of Routes 184 and 204, the store will be the only one of its kind in Lamoine, a community that has no stores and few commercial enterprises.
Both the Planning Board and the state Department of Transportation have approved the plans submitted by Ruth Keene for the construction of the 30- by 40-foot convenience store. With work already under way at the site, construction is expected to be finished by the end of January.
Lamoine voters overturned the community's traditional dry status last year, repealing a prohibition on the sale of beer and wine. The question on the repeal was brought to voters through a petition drive spearheaded by Keene and fellow entreprenuer David Schroeder. They said their plan for the store was contingent on being able to sell beer and wine.
The DOT has imposed several conditions on the project because of its location at what some have described as a hazardous intersection.
Included in the conditions are requirements calling for a 57-foot-wide entrance with a raised traffic island, a minimum sight distance in each direction of 450 feet, paved 6-foot-wide shoulders for 100 feet on each side of the entrance, and no parking for a specified distance on each side of the entrance inter- section.
Further, the town has requested that the speed limit in the area of the store be lowered to 35 mph, an action that must be approved at the state level since Route 184 is a state road.
Many in town have welcomed the addition of a general store, not only for the convenience, but also because of the taxes a commercial property can bring to the town. With about 1,300 residents, Lamoine has only a handful of at-home businesses and contractors with small yards.
The other significant commercial enterprises in Lamoine are more than a dozen active gravel pits, small shellfish-packing businesses and a lobster pound.
Others have said Lamoine is unusual because it has no stores or significant business growth.

Mirth and feasting, about 1800

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]23 Nov 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413948896?accountid=10457

Abstract: Harriet Beecher Stowe moved to Maine in 1850, with her husband, Calvin Ellis Stowe, a professor at Bowdoin College. In Brunswick, she wrote her famous "Uncle Tom's Cabin" and many stories about New England life, including "The Pearl of Orr's Island" (1862) and "Oldtown Folks" (1869). The latter offers a vivid description of Thanksgiving soon after the Revolutionary War, and is a particularly fitting reminiscence for today. People have often supposed, because the Puritans founded a society where there were no professed public amusements, that therefore there was no fun going on in the ancient land of Israel, and that there were no cakes and ale, because they were virtuous. They were never more mistaken in their lives. There was an abundance of sober, well-considered merriment; and the hinges of life were well oiled with that sort of secret humor which to this day gives the raciness to real Yankee wit. Besides this we must remember that life itself is the greatest possible amusement to people who really believe that they can do so much with it, -- who have that intense sense of what can be brought to pass by human effort, that was characteristic of the New England colonies. To such it is not exactly proper to say that life is an amusement, but it certainly is an engrossing interest that takes the place of all amusements. ...

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Mirth+and+feasting%2C+about+1800&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-11-23&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Harriet Beecher Stowe moved to Maine in 1850, with her husband, Calvin Ellis Stowe, a professor at Bowdoin College. In Brunswick, she wrote her famous "Uncle Tom's Cabin" and many stories about New England life, including "The Pearl of Orr's Island" (1862) and "Oldtown Folks" (1869). The latter offers a vivid description of Thanksgiving soon after the Revolutionary War, and is a particularly fitting reminiscence for today.
Are there any of my readers who do not know what Thanksgiving day is to a child? Then let them go back with me, and recall the image of it as we kept it in Oldtown.
People have often supposed, because the Puritans founded a society where there were no professed public amusements, that therefore there was no fun going on in the ancient land of Israel, and that there were no cakes and ale, because they were virtuous. They were never more mistaken in their lives. There was an abundance of sober, well-considered merriment; and the hinges of life were well oiled with that sort of secret humor which to this day gives the raciness to real Yankee wit. Besides this we must remember that life itself is the greatest possible amusement to people who really believe that they can do so much with it, -- who have that intense sense of what can be brought to pass by human effort, that was characteristic of the New England colonies. To such it is not exactly proper to say that life is an amusement, but it certainly is an engrossing interest that takes the place of all amusements. ...
When the apples were all gathered and the cider was all made, and the yellow pumpkins were rolled in from many a hill in billows of gold, and the corn was husked, and the labors of the season were done, and the warm, late days of Indian Summer came in, dreamy and calm and still, with just frost enough to crisp the ground of a morning, but with warm trances of benignant, sunny hours at noon, there came over the community a sort of genial repose of spirit, -- a sense of something accomplished, and of a new golden mark made in advance of the calendar of life, -- and the deacon began to say to the minister, of a Sunday, "I suppose it's time for the Thanksgiving proclamation." ...
We also felt its approach in all departments of the household, -- the conversation at this time beginning to turn on high and solemn culinary mysteries and receipts of wondrous power and virtue. New modes of elaborating squash pies and quince tarts were now ofttimes carefully discussed at the evening fireside by Aunt Lois and Aunt Keziah, and notes seriously compared with the experiences of other Aunties of high repute in such matters. I noticed that on these occasions their voices often fell into mysterious whispers, and that receipts of especial power and sanctity were communicated in tones so low as entirely to escape the vulgar ear. I still remember the solemn shake of the head with which my Aunt Lois conveyed to Miss Mehitable Rossiter the critical properties of mace, in relation to its powers of producing in corn fritters a suggestive resemblance to oysters. As ours was an oyster-getting district, and as that charming bivalve was perfectly easy to come at, the interest of such an imitation can be accounted for only by the fondness of the human mind to works of art.
For as much as a week beforehand, "we children" were employed in chopping mince for pies to a most wearisome fineness, and in pounding cinnamon, allspice, and cloves in a great lignumvitae mortar; and the sound of this pounding and chopping re-echoed through all the rafters of the old house with a hearty and vigorous cheer, most refreshing to our spirits. ...
At other times of the year we sometimes mummured at these labors, but those that were supposed to usher in the great Thanksgiving festival were always entered into with enthusiasm. There were signs of richness all around us, -- stoning of raisins, cutting of citron, slicing of candied orange peel. Yet all these were only dawning and imitations of what was coming during the week of real preparation, after the Governor's proclamation had been read. ...
The cheering anticipation sustained us through what seemed to us the long waste of the sermon and prayers; and when at last the auspicious moment approached, -- when the last quaver of the last hymn had died out, -- the whole house rippled with the general movement of complacency, and a satisfied smile of pleased expectation might be seen gleaming on all the faces of the young people, like a ray of sunshine through a garden of flowers.
Thanksgiving now was dawning! We children poked one another, and fairly giggled with unreproved delight as we listened to the crackle of the slowly unfolding document. That great sheet of paper impressed us as something supernatural, by reason of its mighty size, and by the broad seal of the State affixed thereto; and when the minister read therefrom, "By his Excellency, the Governor of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, a Proclamation," our mirth was with difficulty repressed by admonitory glances from our sympathetic elders. Then, after a solemn enumeration of the benefits which the Commonwealth had that year received at the hands of Divine Providence, came at last the naming of the eventful day, and, at the end of all, the imposing heraldic words, "God save the Commonwealth of Massachusetts." And then, as the congregation broke up a dispersed, all went their separate ways with schemes of mirth and feasting in their heads.

Weapons safety session scheduled at Rockland

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]20 Nov 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413797982?accountid=10457

Abstract: None available.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Weapons+safety+session+scheduled+at+Rockland&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-11-20&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- The Mid-Coast School of Technology Adult Education Department, in cooperation with the Knox County Sheriff's Office, will offer a weapons safety workshop at 6:30 p.m. Friday, Dec. 15, at the school in Rockland, to be followed by a practical session the next day, Saturday, Dec. 16, at The Oyster River Range and Gunshop on Route 90 in Warren.
"Responsible Handgun Ownership for Private Citizens" will be taught by firearms instructors certified by the Maine Criminal Justice Academy and assisted by other members of the Knox County Sheriff's Office. A registration fee of $10 will be charged; registration is limited to 12 participants 18 years of age or older on a first-come, first-served basis.
To register, call The Mid-Coast School of Technology's Adult Education program at 596-7752 or 594-2161.

Deluge keeps town crews busy Rivers watched for minor flooding; state bans clam, mussel harvesting

Author: From the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]16 Nov 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413785944?accountid=10457

Abstract: Another late-fall storm dumped rain across Maine Wednesday, flooding more cellars and culverts than rivers after much of the state had prepared for serious damage. [John] Bennett said 3 inches of rain had fallen at the Marine Patrol's Division II headquarters in Lamoine, which covers the section of coast from Thomaston to the Canadian border. Similarly, Port Clyde received more than 4 inches of rain, Camden was drenched with more than 3 1/2, and about 2 1/2 inches fell on Portland, according to Tom Berman of the National Weather Service. While emergency management officials were keeping an eye out for minor flooding late Wednesday on the Androscoggin, Kennebec and Piscataquis rivers, predictions of a major storm never materialized. Though prepared for the worst, officials from across eastern Maine agreed that Wednesday's storm didn't compare to the one experienced last weekend.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Deluge+keeps+town+crews+busy+Rivers+watched+for+minor+flooding%3B+state+bans+clam%2C+mussel+harvesting&amp;author=From+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-11-16&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Another late-fall storm dumped rain across Maine Wednesday, flooding more cellars and culverts than rivers after much of the state had prepared for serious damage.
The high winds and sleet experienced overnight had, for the most part, subsided by early morning, although heavy rains continued in eastern Maine until shortly before noon.
Because of the heavy rainfall, the Department of Marine Resources announced a prohibition on harvesting clams, mussels and other bivalve mollusks along the entire Maine coast.
"Municipal treatment plants can't handle the amount of fresh water infiltrating their systems so they discharge raw sewage," Marine Patrol Sgt. John Bennett explained Wednesday.
Bennett said 3 inches of rain had fallen at the Marine Patrol's Division II headquarters in Lamoine, which covers the section of coast from Thomaston to the Canadian border. Similarly, Port Clyde received more than 4 inches of rain, Camden was drenched with more than 3 1/2, and about 2 1/2 inches fell on Portland, according to Tom Berman of the National Weather Service.
In Bangor, poor visibility was cited as the cause of a pedestrian accident involving a young boy. The 7-year-old pupil was crossing Fruit Street on his way to school when he was struck by a vehicle. He was taken by the Bangor Fire Ambulance to Eastern Maine Medical Center, was treated for minor injuries and later released.
"It was just a torrential downpour," firefighter Tom Goehringer said. "You couldn't see anything out there."
In Bar Harbor, four fender-benders were attributed to weather conditions, and one car was stranded in a deep puddle.
Shortly before noon, the National Weather Service upgraded flood conditions from a watch to a warning for the Kennebec River, which was expected to crest late Wednesday.
Still, the river level should not have any major impact on the area, according to Carl McKenney, Somerset County emergency management director. He expected there could be minor flooding along the East River Road or in the riverside areas in Madison and Anson.
While emergency management officials were keeping an eye out for minor flooding late Wednesday on the Androscoggin, Kennebec and Piscataquis rivers, predictions of a major storm never materialized. Though prepared for the worst, officials from across eastern Maine agreed that Wednesday's storm didn't compare to the one experienced last weekend.
While the Stillwater, Kenduskeag, and Penobscot rivers were high in some areas, there were no reports of flooding.
"Everything is over," Steve Watson, Penobscot County emergency management director, said late Wednesday afternoon.
In Bucksport, police dispatcher Byron Vinton said he had received only one weather-related call, a sharp contrast to the flurry produced by the weekend windstorm that ripped the roof from the vacant Western Auto building downtown.
The caller Wednesday provided the morning's only report of a tree down.
"I think all the rest blew down the other day," Vinton joked.
Even if little actually was blown down, Mother Nature provided plenty of huffing and puffing during the early hours of the storm.
In Bangor, winds peaked at 57 1/2 mph shortly before 10 a.m. The Coast Guard Base at Southwest Harbor reported gusts of more than 50 mph that sent several tree limbs crashing onto power lines in Mount Desert.
The strong winds forced a 65-foot fishing vessel, the Lady D, ashore at the head of the harbor in Southwest Harbor early Wednesday, a visible reminder of the gale-force winds that ushered in the latest round of slashing rain.
In Rockland, the harbor master's boat took on water to the gunwales overnight, and one of the city's floats was damaged by pounding waves. Otherwise, damage around town was minimal.
As with the weekend storm, most of the power outages reported by Bangor Hydro-Electric Co. were in the Hancock County area.
Some 450 customers were without power at 7 a.m. Wednesday, although most were corrected by evening. With pockets of outages in the Bangor and Machias areas, more than 120 residents of Hancock County were still without power at 5 p.m., according to Hydro spokesman Bill Cohen. Some of those, Cohen said, were leftovers from the weekend.
"We were down to being on top of all but about a dozen customers in the Hancock County area who were still out of power from Sunday's storm when this one hit,' Cohen said. "Hancock got the worst of it from both storms."
By late afternoon, Central Maine Power Co. reported 600 customers were without power as crews continued to clean up after the storm. Even that paled in comparison to the outages attributed to the weekend storm that knocked out power to an estimated 70,000 CMP customers.
In many towns across eastern Maine, public works departments were kept busy digging out leaves clogging culverts and storm drains. In some cases, the water backed up onto roads.
A low area near the Park Street entrance to the University of Maine was filled with enough rainwater Wednesday afternoon to resemble a small pond.
"It's just like a lake over there," Francis Dunn of the university's maintenance department said as he fished leaves from a drain. "There's nothing we can do about that one, though."
In Lamoine, several roads were impassable during the height of the storm.
The Waldo County Sheriff's Department reported that dips in the road along Route 139 in Monroe and Route 137 at Sanborn Pond in Waldo were submerged by flowing water for a time and needed to be flagged by the Department of Transportation.
"Other than that, we're in pretty good shape," a spokesman said. "It was nothing like last Sunday."
Town crews in Pittsfield and Hartland were monitoring minor flooding around culverts and small brooks throughout those areas, but did not anticipate any major problems.
A blocked culvert on West Street in Pittsfield compounded a traditional flooding problem on a branch of Farnham Brook. Upstream from the flooding, water was still rising at the J.W. Parks Golf Course at midday and undermined a covered foot bridge that collapsed into the stream.
The Lindsay Brook system in Rockland overflowed its banks in many areas, sending floodwater cascading down city streets and onto the waterfront. High winds loosened metal trim on the Syndicate Block and a light pole at the corner of Main and Rankin streets was tilted by the wind.
With the minor flooding, plumbers and firefighters across the area earned their money during the storm, as they helped many residents clear their cellars of unwelcome rainwater.
Some first-floor tenants at the Wildwood Apartment complex in Lincoln were evacuated temporarily after a culvert on the property plugged and flooded apartments with 4 to 5 inches of water, according to public safety officials. Damage was believed to be extensive, according to firefighter Bud Thornton.
In Howland, a town that borders both the Penobscot and Piscataquis rivers, town officials said there had been a few reports of minor basement flooding. The Pittsfield Fire Department was called to pump out the cellar at one home, as well as to clear clogged storm drains on the street.
On the coast, Camden, Thomaston and Rockport also experienced high water and backed-up drains and cellars.
"All in all, certainly for the quantity of rain, it was pretty routine," said Bangor Public Works Director Arthur Stockus.
Illustration Caption: The Wednesday morning commute on Broadway was like driving through a carwash. (NEWS Photo by Bob DeLong) Ivar Manion loses control of his umbrella while walking down Main Street in Bangor during the rainstorm Wednesday morning. (NEWS Photo by Bob DeLong)

Petitioners may greet voters at the polls Five drives under way for next year's ballot

Author: John Hale Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]03 Nov 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413849362?accountid=10457

Abstract: Even as voters leave the polls Tuesday, Nov. 7, after casting ballots on this year's referendum questions, they may be asked to sign petitions that could lead to referendum questions on next year's ballot. Five petition drives are under way to place questions on the 1996 ballot. The campaigns are in varying states of readiness to collect signatures on Election Day. A sixth campaign reportedly has enough signatures already to guarantee a spot on next year's ballot. In addition, activists motivated by Ross Perot's call to form a new political party will be seeking voters who want to join the Reform Party and help win a place for the new party on next year's ballot.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Petitioners+may+greet+voters+at+the+polls+Five+drives+under+way+for+next+year%27s+ballot&amp;author=John+Hale+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-11-03&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: AUGUSTA -- Even as voters leave the polls Tuesday, Nov. 7, after casting ballots on this year's referendum questions, they may be asked to sign petitions that could lead to referendum questions on next year's ballot.
Five petition drives are under way to place questions on the 1996 ballot. The campaigns are in varying states of readiness to collect signatures on Election Day. A sixth campaign reportedly has enough signatures already to guarantee a spot on next year's ballot.
Those pushing for a referendum need to collect at least 51,131 voter signatures -- or 10 percent of the turnout for last year's gubernatorial election -- by 5 p.m. Jan. 29, 1996, to claim a spot on the ballot.
In addition, activists motivated by Ross Perot's call to form a new political party will be seeking voters who want to join the Reform Party and help win a place for the new party on next year's ballot.
Secretary of State Bill Diamond said petitioners must wait until after voters have cast their ballots to ask them to sign petitions. Election wardens decide how far away petitioners must be from voting booths.
Petitioners also are prohibited from campaigning, or wearing campaign buttons, on questions that are on this year's ballot, Diamond said.
The new Reform Party must collect 25,565 voter signatures -- or 5 percent of last year's gubernatorial election turnout -- by Dec. 14 in order to qualify for a spot on next year's ballot.
"We're not certain how close we are," said Stephen Bost, coordinator for the Reform Party in Maine, on Thursday. "We will have a heavy presence across the state on Election Day. We will certainly concentrate on cities and as many rural sites as possible. At this point, we're confident."
By signing the petition, voters are actually enrolling in the Reform Party. If the party's petition drive is deemed sufficient, the party will have to hold caucuses in every county and a state party convention before they are recognized, Diamond said.
The Reform Party was recognized in California this week and Bost said it is nearing recognition in Ohio.
Here's a look at petition drives that are under way:
Campaign finance reform -- The effort is jointly undertaken by 10 organizations including Common Cause of Maine and the League of Women Voters of Maine.
David Donnelly, a spokesman for the campaign, said this petition drive would limit what politicians can spend on Maine races for governor and the Legislature. The aim is to create incentives for candidates to spend 25 percent less than the average amount spent in these races.
The proposal also reduces the maximum amount of money that can be given to candidates by political-action committees and individuals. The maximum donation is reduced from $5,000 to $500 for PACs in the governor's race and to $250 in legislative races.
The proposal toughens enforcement of campaign-finance and election laws. It doubles lobbying fees to pay for better auditing of campaign-finance reports.
Donnelly said Maine Voters for Clean Elections expect to put 1,000 volunteers at polling places and to gather all their required signatures on Election Day.
Clear-cutting -- Members of the Green Party of Maine are circulating petitions that would ban clear-cutting in the unorganized townships, promote forest rehabilitation and encourage sustainable forest practices.
Jonathan K. Carter said the Green Party is looking for volunteers to collect petition signatures on Election Day. Interested people should contact the Green Party's office in Augusta.
Marijuana -- For the second year, Maine VOCALS are gathering signatures on petitions that would legalize marijuana.
Organizer Don Christen, leader of Maine VOCALS, said the proposal would legalize the use, growing and sale of marijuana. It would not be legal for minors younger than 18.
Christen said his group is looking for volunteers to collect signatures.
Motor fuel laws -- A petition drive organized by Belinda Gerry of Auburn seeks to overturn several recent mandates on car emissions and gasoline use.
Among other things, the proposal would prohibit state and federal governments from requiring the use of certain fuels; prohibit the state and federal governments from banning the sale of certain fuels; and prohibit the state and federal governments from starting any emission testing without approval by the Legislature and a statewide vote.
Diamond said there are constitutional problems with the petition, but he authorized the drive to start anyway because courts historically have chosen to decide constitutional questions after the proposals are considered by voters.
Clam digging -- David L. Sanborn, a Waldoboro clam digger, has started a petition drive that would do away with municipal shellfish regulations. Sanborn said his proposal would allow anyone to harvest clams, not just those now permitted by municipal ordinances. Sanborn said he doesn't know if he'll be at the polls Tuesday to collect signatures. He is looking for volunteers to work on his campaign.
Property tax cap -- Organizers say they have more than enough signatures to put a property-tax cap measure on the 1996 ballot. The proposal would cap property taxes in Maine at 1 percent of a home's current assessed value. Carol Palesky of Topsham is leader of the drive.
In addition to the active petition drives, two more are inactive.
A drive to require the state to pay 100 percent of the cost of local education is not actively seeking signatures and is short of the needed number of signatures.

Petitioners may greet voters at the polls Five drives under way for next year's ballot

Author: John Hale Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]03 Nov 1995: 1. [Duplicate]

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413836132?accountid=10457

Abstract: In addition to the five active petition drives for state referendum in 1996, Augusta reporter John Hale wrote in Friday's MaineDay about two petition drives that have become inactive. Full text: In addition to the five active petition drives for state referendum in 1996, Augusta reporter John Hale wrote in Friday's MaineDay about two petition drives that have become inactive. However, because of a production error, those paragraphs were removed from the story. One drive to require the state to pay 100 percent of the cost of local education is not actively seeking signatures and is short of the needed number of signatures. This drive was headed by Bruce Matthews of Coopers Mills. Another proposal to legalize medically assisted death in Maine was put on hold while the U.S. Supreme Court decides the fate of a similar law in Oregon. Darlene Grover of Brunswick is leader of this drive which is not now collecting signatures.
AUGUSTA -- Even as voters leave the polls Tuesday, Nov. 7, after casting ballots on this year's referendum questions, they may be asked to sign petitions that could lead to referendum questions on next year's ballot.
Five petition drives are under way to place questions on the 1996 ballot. The campaigns are in varying states of readiness to collect signatures on Election Day. A sixth campaign reportedly has enough signatures already to guarantee a spot on next year's ballot.
Those pushing for a referendum need to collect at least 51,131 voter signatures -- or 10 percent of the turnout for last year's gubernatorial election -- by 5 p.m. Jan. 29, 1996, to claim a spot on the ballot.
In addition, activists motivated by Ross Perot's call to form a new political party will be seeking voters who want to join the Reform Party and help win a place for the new party on next year's ballot.
Secretary of State Bill Diamond said petitioners must wait until after voters have cast their ballots to ask them to sign petitions. Election wardens decide how far away petitioners must be from voting booths.
Petitioners also are prohibited from campaigning, or wearing campaign buttons, on questions that are on this year's ballot, Diamond said.
The new Reform Party must collect 25,565 voter signatures -- or 5 percent of last year's gubernatorial election turnout -- by Dec. 14 in order to qualify for a spot on next year's ballot.
"We're not certain how close we are," said Stephen Bost, coordinator for the Reform Party in Maine, on Thursday. "We will have a heavy presence across the state on Election Day. We will certainly concentrate on cities and as many rural sites as possible. At this point, we're confident."
By signing the petition, voters are actually enrolling in the Reform Party. If the party's petition drive is deemed sufficient, the party will have to hold caucuses in every county and a state party convention before they are recognized, Diamond said.
The Reform Party was recognized in California this week and Bost said it is nearing recognition in Ohio.
Here's a look at petition drives that are under way:
Campaign finance reform -- The effort is jointly undertaken by 10 organizations including Common Cause of Maine and the League of Women Voters of Maine.
David Donnelly, a spokesman for the campaign, said this petition drive would limit what politicians can spend on Maine races for governor and the Legislature. The aim is to create incentives for candidates to spend 25 percent less than the average amount spent in these races.

Jonathan K. Carter said the Green Party is looking for volunteers to collect petition signatures on Election Day. Interested people should contact the Green Party's office in Augusta.

Organizer Don Christen, leader of Maine VOCALS, said the proposal would legalize the use, growing and sale of marijuana. It would not be legal for minors younger than 18.
Christen said his group is looking for volunteers to collect signatures.

It's all in the game Wild-bird recipes aren't exact science

Author: Dawn Gagnon Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]30 Oct 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413802766?accountid=10457

Abstract: Partridge, pheasant, duck, and woodcock are some of the wild game birds Mainers have known and loved for generations. But for most of the state's hunters and game cooks, the partridge has earned a special place as a hands-down favorite. "I'd say that for most of the people going out to hunt (game) birds, partridge is the favorite," said Warden Kevin Adam of the Maine Warden Service. They are relatively plentiful in Maine, and not that difficult to bag. Some traditional Maine ways to cook game birds are stewing, sauteing, roasting, or -- in the case of partridge and woodcock -- baking them in the middle of a pot of beans.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=It%27s+all+in+the+game+Wild-bird+recipes+aren%27t+exact+science&amp;author=Dawn+Gagnon+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-10-30&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Partridge, pheasant, duck, and woodcock are some of the wild game birds Mainers have known and loved for generations. But for most of the state's hunters and game cooks, the partridge has earned a special place as a hands-down favorite.
"I'd say that for most of the people going out to hunt (game) birds, partridge is the favorite," said Warden Kevin Adam of the Maine Warden Service. They are relatively plentiful in Maine, and not that difficult to bag.
And this fall is shaping up to be a banner partridge-hunting year in the northern part of Maine.
A mild winter, dry spring and ideal nesting conditions have resulted in a low mortality rate for partridge chicks and in some cases, second hatches.
Some traditional Maine ways to cook game birds are stewing, sauteing, roasting, or -- in the case of partridge and woodcock -- baking them in the middle of a pot of beans.
When it comes to the smaller species, such as partridge, game cookery can be tricky. The amount of meat the cook will have in the kitchen depends on the hunter's success -- or luck -- in the woods.
"They're mostly fluff," observes Robert Bulay of Old Town, who has achieved some local notoriety for his version of wild game stew. Once the feathers are plucked, there's not a whole lot left on the birds.
When my father, Don Daigle, offered to cook up a batch of partridge stir fry during a recent family gathering at our apartment in Bangor, I'll admit I was skeptical.
First of all, partridge doesn't exactly leap to mind when one considers stir-fry cookery.
And then I took a close look at the tiny, fragile-looking partridge breasts, and mentally counted out the five adults and two children who'd soon be seated around our kitchen table.
But Dad had already taken that into account and had picked up some chicken breasts as part of his contingency plan.
After he'd added a couple of large onions, sliced into long thin slivers, a package of sliced mushrooms, sliced red pepper and a little cornstarch and water to thicken the pan juices, the huge hunting-camp-sized skillet he'd brought with him from St. Agatha held enough stir fry for dinner that night and leftovers for a long afterward.
Seasoned with salt, pepper and soy sauce and smothered in vegetables, the patridge stir fry won raves for the dish that he first concocted from more basic ingredients during a hunting trip on the Maine-Quebec border.
Wild game stew is a family favorite in Bulay's household. His directions are simple and generic. Any stewable game -- partridge, rabbit and venison, to name a few, alone or in combinations -- can be used.
"You're not actually cooking," Bulay maintains. The stew practically makes itself. All the cook has to do is get it started, and toss the vegetables in when the time is right.
To some, the image of a pot of stew gently bubbling on the stove top evokes memories of a simpler era, a time when cookstoves served the dual role of heating meals and warming homes.
"This is not a quick thing," noted Bulay, for whom making stew is a daylong affair.
Bulay starts by putting the game, bones and all, in a pot with water and bringing the pot to a boil. He then leaves it to simmer away until the bones can be picked out of the pot, and the liquid has reduced itself to a rich broth.
Then he adds vegetables. Which ones are a matter of individual taste, or family preference.
As for amounts, he said, "You have to guesstimate." By his rule of thumb, the ratio should be somewhere between one-fourth and one-third part meat to vegetables.
Bulay recommends that the "harder" vegetables, the ones that need the most time to cook, go in the pot first. These would include chunks of carrot, turnip, beets or whole onions.
When these begin to soften, it's time to add the potato pieces. And when the potatoes are tender, in go the small vegetables such as peas or kernels of corn. By the time the latter are heated through, the stew is done.
"At the point where everything is done, I might taste it," Bulay said. Most of the time his stew is perfect -- or so he alleges. But once in a while, it needs a little kick. On those rare occasions, Bulay adds a splash or two of tamari, a Japanese version of soy sauce.
He never adds salt during the cooking process because, he says, it toughens meat. The time to salt is, "When you put the food on your plate." And only if your dinner needs it.
Recipes for wild game birds are difficult to find in mainstream cooking publications. Some of those who cook them best learned by doing or were the beneficiaries of methods passed along by earlier generations.
But for those of us who need specific directions when cooking, such as exact amounts and cooking times, Louise O. Kirkland, an extension educator from the Penobscot County office of the University of Maine Cooperative Extension, offers the following:
PAN-FRIED PARTRIDGE OR PHEASANT
2 birds, cleaned 2 tablespoons flour 1/2 teaspoon salt 3 tablespoons softened margarine 2 tablespoons hot water 1 cup cream Dash each of pepper and celery salt
Cut cleaned birds in half lengthwise. Combine flour, salt, pepper and celery salt. Dredge each portion thoroughly in flour mixture. Heat margarine in heavy frying pan. Sear, cook over low heat until game is tender. Add mixture of hot water and cream during cooking.
DUCK GUMBO
4 slices bacon, diced 1 cup chopped onion 1/4 cup flour 2 quarts boiling water 1/4 teaspoon pepper 1/4 teaspoon salt 1 cup chopped parsley 2 tablespoons gumbo file powder 6 cups cooked rice 1 duck, 3 1/2 to 4 pounds, cut up 2 cups shrimp, shelled 2 cups cooked tomatoes 1 cup chopped green onion 1 pint shucked oysters
In a heavy kettle, fry bacon until crisp. Add chopped onion, saute until lightly browned. Stir in flour, add boiling water, salt and pepper. Stir well. Add duck. Add more water to cover, if needed. Cover and simmer for 1 1/2 hours. Cool, skim fat from top. Add shrimp and tomatoes, cook 20 more minutes. Remove from heat. Add green onion, parsley, gumbo file and oysters. Serve over rice. (Makes 8 to 10 servings.)
CASSEROLE OF PARTRIDGE
Partridge breasts, legs 1 carrot, sliced 2 onions, sliced 3/4 pound mushrooms, sliced 1 can cream of mushroom soup 1/2 cup milk 1 large can chow mein noodles Salt, pepper
In water to cover, parboil partridge breasts and legs with carrot and onion for about 30 minutes. Drain water, remove meat from bones. Mix together meat, mushrooms, soup diluted with milk and noodles. Taste, seasoning with salt and pepper if necessary. Turn into well-buttered casserole dish. Bake at 350 degrees for 1 1/2 hours.
ROAST WILD DUCK
2 1/2 pound wild duck, cleaned 1/4 teaspoon baking soda 1 1/2 cups diced celery 1/2 cup diced onion 1/2 cup chopped raisins 2 cups bread crumbs 1/2 teaspoon salt 1/4 cup water 3 slices bacon 1 cup orange juice 1/4 cup sugar
Rub inside and outside of duck with baking soda, rinse and dry. Combine celery, onion, raisins, bread crumbs, salt and water. Stuff mixture into cavity, fasten closed with skewers. Place duck on rack in roasting pan. Cover breasts with strips of bacon. Bake uncovered at 500 degrees for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees and bake for about two hours, basting with orange juice and sugar.
PHEASANT EN CREME
1 pheasant, cleaned and quartered 1 10-ounce can condensed cream of chicken soup 1/2 cup apple cider 1 tablespoon plus 1 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce 3/4 teaspoon salt 1/3 cup chopped onion 1 clove garlic 1 3-ounce can sliced mushrooms, drained Paprika
Heat oven to 350 degrees. Place pheasant in ungreased 9x9x2-inch baking dish. Mix soup, cider, Worcestershire sauce, salt, onion, garlic and mushrooms. Pour mixture over pheasant. Sprinkle generously with paprika. Serves two or three.
Illustration Caption: Partridge stir fry blends the popular game bird with a selection of vegetables. (NEWS Photo-illustration by Bob DeLong)

____________________________________________________________

Ducks, dogs and decoys: The ritual lives on

Author: Hennessey, Tom

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]21 Oct 1995: PDA.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413774893?accountid=10457

Abstract: During "the rush hour," two hunters (right) hurry to get the decoys set before legal shooting time. They are pleasantly distracted, however, by the sound of air passing through primary wing feathers as a pair of black ducks scale out of the dawn sky. Decoys are set in purposeful disarray to imitate ducks that are resting and feeding comfortably. Some hunters prefer oversize decoys, which they believe are more visible to trafficking ducks. Discussions about the number of decoys necessary for attracting ducks are as endless as arguments about which chokes and shot sizes are most efficient for bagging the swift-winged fowl. Generally speaking, a good rule of thumb regarding decoys is "big water, big rig; small water, small rig." Big water usually refers to late-season hunting on coastal bays, where the adage, "The more the merrier," is worth remembering when rigging decoys. Often, a "confidence decoy" simulating a great blue heron - a marsh bird that doesn't tolerate human intrusion - is set near decoys to increase the all-is-well deception. Maine's sprawling marshlands, both coastal and inland, attract many species of ducks. Among the most common are black ducks, mallards, teal, wood ducks, whistlers, ringnecks and buffleheads.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Ducks%2C+dogs+and+decoys%3A+The+ritual+lives+on&amp;author=Hennessey%2C+Tom&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-10-21&amp;spage=PDA&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: How many decoys?
During "the rush hour," two hunters (right) hurry to get the decoys set before legal shooting time. They are pleasantly distracted, however, by the sound of air passing through primary wing feathers as a pair of black ducks scale out of the dawn sky. Decoys are set in purposeful disarray to imitate ducks that are resting and feeding comfortably. Some hunters prefer oversize decoys, which they believe are more visible to trafficking ducks.
Discussions about the number of decoys necessary for attracting ducks are as endless as arguments about which chokes and shot sizes are most efficient for bagging the swift-winged fowl. Generally speaking, a good rule of thumb regarding decoys is "big water, big rig; small water, small rig." Big water usually refers to late-season hunting on coastal bays, where the adage, "The more the merrier," is worth remembering when rigging decoys.
Often, a "confidence decoy" simulating a great blue heron - a marsh bird that doesn't tolerate human intrusion - is set near decoys to increase the all-is-well deception. Maine's sprawling marshlands, both coastal and inland, attract many species of ducks. Among the most common are black ducks, mallards, teal, wood ducks, whistlers, ringnecks and buffleheads.
Paddling and shooting
Caught off guard by the silent approach of the canoe (left), a pair of black ducks flush from behind an outcropping of willows wading the edge of a thoroughfare. Maine is blessed with an abundance of bogs, flowages and marshy waterways where jump-shooting from a canoe can be productive. Success, however, depends entirely on how quietly the canoe is handled. Black ducks are extremely wary and will flush out of range at the slightest splash or swirl of the paddle or scraping of weeds and stumps against the canoe. At the start of a jump-shoot, paddler and shooter positions usually are determined by the flip of a coin. The hunters switch positions after each shooting opportunity.
Hunter's best friend
The importance of a retriever to waterfowl conservation cannot be overemphasized. An experienced finder-and-fetcher will recover many crippled ducks that would be lost otherwise, especially in the spongy, hummocky hell of swamps and bogs. Because retrievers often recover ducks that were shot and lost by other hunters, discussions are not uncommon regarding the allowance of an extra duck in the daily limits of hunters who use trained retrievers. Aside from the conservation factor, watching an experienced retriever at work is pure pleasure. Also, unlike some hunting partners, the dog doesn't forget to set the alarm and never has to go home early.
Dawn's early light
When a Down Easter says he's "goin' birdin," it's likely he's headed for an offshore ledge to hunt eider ducks (left). And that, you may know, can be cold, rough, dangerous sport. Setting a line of decoys and landing on ledges when dawn is hinting at daylight and the tide's running hard requires seamanship, nerve, and the ability to convince yourself you'd rather be there than home in bed. But when the first flock of eiders tip their wings toward your decoys, there's no place you'd rather be.
The big sea ducks are insulated with down that sheds shot like a retriever shaking off water. Therefore, bring nothing less than a 12-gauge gun and plenty of shells marked No. 2. Tides, of course, are the governing factors in offshore gunning. Although decent shooting may occur at any tide levels, the best-by-far chance to warm barrels in a hurry is when low water and dawn coincide. That's when night-rafted eiders begin winging toward ledges to dive and feed on mussels and other mollusks.
Suffice it to say, the shooting can be fast and furious. Currently, it is estimated that nearly 60,000 adult eiders inhabit Maine's coast, and there are dawns when it seems the ducks are all in the air at the same time.
Without question, it's an awe-inspiring spectacle, but hunters shouldn't let it distract them from keeping an eye on winds, tides - and their boats. As one Down East gunner put it: "If a man's boat gets away from him out here, he'd better have either an Olympic medal in swimming or one hell of a high pair of waders."
Illustration Caption: News Illustratons by Tom Hennessey

Maine nets top fisheries revenue High 1994 figure attributed to efforts to market wider variety of seafood

Author: Letitia Baldwin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]18 Oct 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413773254?accountid=10457

Abstract: WOODS HOLE, Mass. -- Maine has surpassed Massachusetts as the top commercial fisheries state in New England, landing some $245.4 million worth of marine species last year -- a $20 million jump in revenue over 1993 -- National Marine Fisheries Service sources report. The Woods Hole-based Northeast Fisheries Science Center, a branch of the NMFS, released the report this month. Spokesman Teri Frady attributes Maine's rise to the top slot in seafood revenue to the state's diversification in fisheries over the years. "Maine, particularly as a state, has broadened the species that it lands," Frady said, noting Maine has a strong finfish aquaculture industry that generates more revenue than any other marine species after lobster. She said, "Maine has not been as dependent on cod and yellowtail flounder as Massachusetts."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Maine+nets+top+fisheries+revenue+High+1994+figure+attributed+to+efforts+to+market+wider+variety+of+seafood&amp;author=Letitia+Baldwin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-10-18&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: WOODS HOLE, Mass. -- Maine has surpassed Massachusetts as the top commercial fisheries state in New England, landing some $245.4 million worth of marine species last year -- a $20 million jump in revenue over 1993 -- National Marine Fisheries Service sources report.
Virginia landed more fish -- some 581.3 million pounds -- than any other state, but ranked third in revenue. Menhaden accounted for the bulk of that state's catch. Massachusetts took second place with 183.3 million pounds worth $206 million harvested last year.
The Woods Hole-based Northeast Fisheries Science Center, a branch of the NMFS, released the report this month. Spokesman Teri Frady attributes Maine's rise to the top slot in seafood revenue to the state's diversification in fisheries over the years.
"Maine, particularly as a state, has broadened the species that it lands," Frady said, noting Maine has a strong finfish aquaculture industry that generates more revenue than any other marine species after lobster. She said, "Maine has not been as dependent on cod and yellowtail flounder as Massachusetts."
Frady said Massachusetts has an aquaculture industry -- striped bass are being raised there in the town of Turner's Falls -- but it is not on the same scale as Maine, where salmon, trout, mussels, oysters and other marine species are cultivated.
After pen-raised finfish, Maine's sea urchin fishery is the third-largest moneymaker after lobster. Some 38.3 million pounds of the spiny green creatures were harvested last year, netting $33.1 million in revenue.
Bob Morrill, longtime statistician at the Portland office of the NMFS, says Maine has always been more diversified in its fisheries.
"Seaweed, worm diggers, offshore fishing, inshore fishing, Maine people have always been the real opportunists," he said. "The guy that's digging clams in the summer might be scalloping in the winter and hauling lobsters the next summer."
While Maine's revenue from commercial fisheries is up, the state's overall landings are on the decline. Some 233.9 million pounds of marine species were harvested last year, compared with 251.7 million in 1993. The same is true throughout the New England region, where landings dropped from 1.649 million pounds to 1.470 million over the past two years.
Morrill attributes the decline to the dramatic reduction of cod, haddock and yellowtail flounder stocks on Georges Bank and in the Gulf of Maine.
"I think it's a real indicator of the status of the stocks," he said.

____________________________________________________________

Wok This Way Top chef teaches Chinese cooking to hungry pupils

Author: Sharon Mack Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]02 Oct 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413825818?accountid=10457

Abstract: The idea of a world-class chef offering Chinese cooking classes from a rural Pittsfield farmhouse is intriguing. What is a New York restaurant owner, operator of three Chinese restaurants, doing in Pittsfield, and why in the world is he teaching cooking, giving away his secrets? "I want to share. You won't find anything healthier than Chinese food. No fat. No grease. All fresh vegetables," said Young, who also boasts that he uses no preservatives or monosodium glutamate in his cooking. "Chinese people avoid diabetes, heart attacks and high blood pressure. But Peter Young doesn't really cook Chinese food. What Peter Young does is dance with Chinese food. He's like a little bee, buzzing around the kitchen, vigorously washing vegetables, chopping bok choy at a dizzying pace, throwing the stir-fry ingredients up in the air as they sizzle, and then gracefully sliding the completed dish onto a huge decorated platter.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Wok+This+Way+Top+chef+teaches+Chinese+cooking+to+hungry+pupils&amp;author=Sharon+Mack+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-10-02&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The idea of a world-class chef offering Chinese cooking classes from a rural Pittsfield farmhouse is intriguing. What is a New York restaurant owner, operator of three Chinese restaurants, doing in Pittsfield, and why in the world is he teaching cooking, giving away his secrets?
With a twinkle in his eye, Peter Young tells all.
"I want to share. You won't find anything healthier than Chinese food. No fat. No grease. All fresh vegetables," said Young, who also boasts that he uses no preservatives or monosodium glutamate in his cooking. "Chinese people avoid diabetes, heart attacks and high blood pressure.
"That's why I teach," he said. "I want to help share my experience cooking with the public."
But Peter Young doesn't really cook Chinese food. What Peter Young does is dance with Chinese food. He's like a little bee, buzzing around the kitchen, vigorously washing vegetables, chopping bok choy at a dizzying pace, throwing the stir-fry ingredients up in the air as they sizzle, and then gracefully sliding the completed dish onto a huge decorated platter.
Don't expect a Julia Child look-alike or act-alike when you sign up. Young will most likely greet his new students in a sweatshirt and a ball cap, perched a little sideways on his head. And his classes come with a little "interpretation sheet" to help new students understand Young's heavy Chinese accent.
Right in the middle of roasting pork, he is as likely as not to launch into a story about serving egg foo yong to Barbra Streisand while he was a chef in New York. Or he might tell about his wife's career in Washington, D.C., as a court reporter during the Watergate hearings.
As Young cooks, his students take notes -- and drool. From the minute the first garlic bit hits the wok, the wonderful smells make it hard to wait until the end of class to fill your plate and eat.
At 69, Young is a testament to the healthful content of his cooking -- not a wrinkle creases his face. He takes no medication and is in perfect health, looking (and acting) much like a 40-year-old. Aside from teaching up to three classes a day, he maintains the family farm, tending chickens and ducks and a small herd of Holsteins.
Young often gives cooking seminars, at no charge, to local groups, and has provided healthful-cooking classes for businesses, schools and community gatherings. As part of a charity fund-raiser in 1991, he made more than 1,300 egg rolls in three days at the Pittsfield Egg Festival.
Young began his cooking career as a young boy in New York. He started out as a dishwasher and learned each level of Chinese cooking from master chefs, one step at a time. Born in China, he once turned down an opportunity to be a Chinese translator in the United Nations, when it was forming in the early 1950s.
"It only paid $45 a week," he recalled. "Dishwashing paid $50 a week, and that included all my meals and room and board."
As he worked his way through New York restaurants, Young invested in commodities and did well. And he traveled around the world, sampling food of other cultures.
In 1983, Young relocated to Maine and bought the former Anchorage Inn in Old Town, renaming it The Joy King. After his retirement in 1985, he gave the restaurant to his son.
But during his retirement, Young kept being asked over and over again to teach Chinese cooking. He often did demonstrations, and eventually, in 1991, he was persuaded to start a class. Over the years, the chef has developed a series of four classes, each specializing in a specific curriculum of 64 different Chinese dishes. He is now being pressured by alumni to add a fifth class.
Who takes these classes? State troopers, auto repairmen, lawyers, store clerks and me.
I really thought I knew how to cook Chinese food. I knew how to make rice, and I could stir-fry vegetables and meat. But the exotic terms used in the recipes -- subgum, gai din, lo mein -- confused me. Over the past few years, I kept hearing about Peter Young's classes. Everywhere I went, every time the subject of cooking came up, someone began raving about Young's classes.
What could be so special? I wondered. So I signed up, at $50 for eight classes (which include two main-course dishes), during which you get to eat the meals cooked. I figured that even if I didn't learn anything, I'd at least get eight meals for less than $7 each.
I got a lot more.
I got a crash course in healthful, substantial cooking which not only has made me a hit with my friends and family, but also has simplified my meal planning -- a big bonus for a working mom. Now, we often have a luscious dinner of beef lo mein (whipped up in 20 minutes) or a feast of teriyaki beef and pork fried rice -- all at a fraction of the cost of restaurant dinners.
I guess one of the clearest testaments to the popularity of Young's classes has been the appearance of decidedly Chinese offerings at the local supermarkets.
Five years ago, you couldn't have found bok choy or straw mushrooms in any of Pittsfield's grocery stores. Thanks to pressure from Young's students, bok choy and other Chinese offerings are now readily available locally.
The first thing Young's students notice is his energy level -- and his accent. Then we notice his manner of cooking, everything done with care, dignity and design -- and with health in mind.
Everything that can be used fresh, is. Only specialty Chinese-grown products -- such as bamboo shoots and water chestnuts -- are used from cans.
"Fresh. Fresh. That is the secret to good, healthy cooking," he testified.
Young will start a new round of classes in October. Typical beginning classes inlcude teriyaki steak, egg rolls and Chinese roast pork.
Other classes offer wonton soup, chicken fingers, sweet and sour pork, and a seafood selection. There are more than 64 recipes in Young's class offerings. Classes are limited to a maximum of 12 students. Information about his classes may be obtained by calling 487-5379.
Young's recipes at first may sound lengthy, time-consuming or complicated, but most of the actual time is involved in chopping and preparing the ingredients. Nearly all ingredients can be found at large supermarkets or bought through Young.
Almost all of this preparation can be done ahead of time. A Sunday afternoon of chopping usually yields enough items for two or three meals during the week. Sealed in bags, the meats marinate wonderfully, and the crisp vegetables remain fresh for days.
When actual mealtime comes, I grab several bags from the refrigerator and can serve a full-course Chinese meal in less than half an hour. Cleanup is one pan and the serving dishes. What could be easier, more delicious or more healthful?
This recipe sounds like a lot of work -- it isn't -- but the results are incredible.
Moo Goo Gai Pan
3 large, whole chicken breasts, skinned and boned
Marinade: 1/8 cup light soy sauce 1/8 cup vegetable oil 1 tablespoon cornstarch
Vegetables:
1 medium-size bok choy, sliced into strips, washed and drained 1 package celery hearts, cut into chunks, washed and drained 12 ounces mushrooms, sliced 1 8-ounce can water chestnuts, drained and sliced 1 8-ounce can bamboo shoots, drained 1 8-ounce package fresh snow pea pods
1/8 cup vegetable oil 1/2 teaspoon fresh chopped garlic 1/8 cup oyster sauce 1/4 teaspoon salt 1/8 cup light soy sauce 1 1/2 cups chicken stock 1/2 cup water 1/2 cup cornstarch
Prepare the chicken breasts. Slice into small pieces and chunks (Young's tip: Place breasts shiny side down -- they won't slide on the cutting block when being sliced.). Marinate the chicken overnight in the marinade.
Prepare vegetables (this can be done when preparing meat and then refrigerate them, or prepare just before the cooking commences).
When ready to cook, heat the wok on high heat and put in the vegetable oil. Add the garlic and brown. Add chicken, still in marinade, and oyster sauce. Cook two to three minutes. Remove from wok.
Add all the prepared vegetables to the wok, execpt the snow pea pods. Cover and cook six to seven minutes, then add salt, soy sauce and chicken stock. Bring to a boil. Put chicken on top of vegetables. Add pea pods.
Leave a hole in the center of food and when the juices begin to boil, add the water, mixed with the cornstarch, to thicken. Stir well and serve with rice.
For this recipe, Young says: "Don't forget to wash the rice before cooking so the starch is rinsed away and the rice won't stick together." Rinse in cold water until the milky starch is washed away.
Pork Fried Rice
3 1/2 cups raw rice
2 pounds roast pork, sliced thin and then chopped fine 1 Spanish onion, chopped fine 1 bunch scallions, chopped fine 1 pound bean sprouts, fresh or canned
1/2 cup vegetable oil 4 eggs 1/8 cup oil 1/8 cup light soy sauce 1/4 cup dark soy sauce Pepper
Cook the rice either conventionally or with a rice cooker.
In a hot wok, heat the vegetable oil and scramble the four eggs quickly. Cook until they are dry, remove from wok.
Add 1/8 cup oil and saute the onions. Add roast pork and rice. Add light soy sauce, dark soy sauce, and a dash of pepper. Cook two to three minutes.
Add the remaining vegetables and eggs and cook until heated through.
Illustration Caption: Chef Peter Young dishes out a heaping plateful of moo goo gai pan at a cooking class in Pittsfield. Chopping vegetables ahead can speed up the time to prepare a Chinese entree. (NEWS Photos by Michele Stapleton)

Title: Wok This Way Top chef teaches Chinese cooking to hungry pupils:   [ALL Edition ]

Publication title: Bangor Daily News; Bangor, Me.

Pages: 1

Publication year: 1995

Publication date: Oct 2, 1995

Publisher: Bangor Publishing Company

Place of publication: Bangor, Me.

Shellfish facility to reorganize in bid to stay alive Beals Island hatchery panel to create new mission, board

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]19 Sep 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413796721?accountid=10457

Abstract: The 8-year-old Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery will reorganize its governing structure in an effort to raise enough money to keep the hatchery alive. According to hatchery officials, $50,000 must be raised this year. Brian Beal, an assistant professor of marine ecology at UMM, said Monday that the meeting in the conference room of the science building will be the first of a series of critical meetings aimed at funding the hatchery, clarifying its geographic service area, and focusing the hatchery on the production of specific species of fish. "The selection and geographic makeup of the board will be critical to the hatchery's future and mission," Beal said, because the hatchery will continue to carry a strong influence in the service area that ranges from Kittery to Eastport. "If we can establish a board, we will move ahead. If we cannot get a board, that could end the hatchery."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Shellfish+facility+to+reorganize+in+bid+to+stay+alive+Beals+Island+hatchery+panel+to+create+new+mission%2C+board&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-09-19&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: MACHIAS -- The 8-year-old Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery will reorganize its governing structure in an effort to raise enough money to keep the hatchery alive. According to hatchery officials, $50,000 must be raised this year.
An ad hoc steering committee will meet at 10 a.m. Friday at the University of Maine at Machias to create a new mission statement and nominate a 12-member board of directors.
Brian Beal, an assistant professor of marine ecology at UMM, said Monday that the meeting in the conference room of the science building will be the first of a series of critical meetings aimed at funding the hatchery, clarifying its geographic service area, and focusing the hatchery on the production of specific species of fish.
After the committee produces the list of candidates for a board of directors, Beal will conduct informal interviews with each candidate before selecting the hatchery's initial board of directors.
"The selection and geographic makeup of the board will be critical to the hatchery's future and mission," Beal said, because the hatchery will continue to carry a strong influence in the service area that ranges from Kittery to Eastport. "If we can establish a board, we will move ahead. If we cannot get a board, that could end the hatchery."
A new board would be commissioned at its first meeting with organizational consultant Alan Reid of York Harbor. Reid, a consultant to philanthropic and charitable organizations, was hired by the hatchery to coach the new directors on fund raising and other skills needed for developing the hatchery as a catalyst for shellfish management in Maine.
Part of Reid's fee will be paid from a $3,500 grant that Beal acquired in July. The Collaboration of Community Foundations for the Gulf of Maine awarded the grant for the specific purpose of building an organizational structure for the hatchery. Some of the money will meet the cost of legal work needed to give the hatchery a nonprofit status.
Beal, who created the hatchery nine years ago, was supported by UMM in his endeavors as the hatchery's chief consultant. The hatchery has been operated under the auspices of UMM, and it has received numerous grants from state and national organizations interested in shellfish management.
"The grants were used, in part, to hire the hatchery's staff," he said, adding that the university has permitted him to serve as a part-time consultant until Dec. 31. "Due to changes in fiscal policy and additional faculty positions, UMM will no longer be able to play the role it has in the past. This presents the Regional Shellfish Hatchery program with a challenge and an opportunity," Beal said.
He expects the new board of directors to greatly enhance the work of the hatchery as a statewide public demonstration facility.
He said Maine clammers and coastal communities are finally beginning to see that the Regional Shellfish Hatchery represents real education and economic opportunities. "The facility can serve to retrain fishermen interested in shellfish aquaculture so that they begin to farm the ocean rather than hunt in the ocean."
The facility, because of its enormous production capacity for bivalves and crustaceans, can produce clams and other marine species for public stock enhancement or for growing on private leases. "There are a number of ways for the program to effect financial changes in the lives of fishermen and their families," he said.
The hatchery program has reached a point where "it is seen by many as a necessary and welcome player in the future health of shellfish aquaculture in Maine, particularly Down East," he stated.
The mission statement and a list of candidates for the first board of directors will be decided by Albert Carver of Carver Shellfish Co. of Beals; Dwayne Shaw, hatchery manager; Samuel Chapman, aquaculture coordinator for the Time & Tide Resource Conservation and Development Council at Augusta; William Hopkins of the Sustainable Cobscook Project at Eastport; Michael Hastings, aquaculture innovation center at Brewer; David Dow, marine advisory program leader for the Maine Sea Grant College Program at the University of Maine; Paul Thompson, aquaculture farmer at Cutler; Gayle Krause, professor of marine ecology at UMM; Jane Hinson, director of UMM special programs; and Beal.
