DMR considers trimming 21 jobs Changes could save $335,000 this year, but no enforcement cuts planned

Author: A. Jay Higgins Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]14 Sep 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413778439?accountid=10457

Abstract: Still coping with recession-induced staff cutbacks from 1991, the state Department of Marine Resources is planning to slash 21 more jobs from its depleted ranks to help Gov. Angus King meet his budget goal. Marine Resources Commissioner Robin Alden on Wednesday proposed consolidating a number of functions within her department and the phaseout of the agency's South Portland office. Alden estimated her reorganization plans would provide about $335,000 in savings for the balance of the fiscal year. She was pleased that none of the positions scheduled for elimination is from the enforcement division, where marine patrol officers represent the agency's front line.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=DMR+considers+trimming+21+jobs+Changes+could+save+%24335%2C000+this+year%2C+but+no+enforcement+cuts+planned&amp;author=A.+Jay+Higgins+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-09-14&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   AUGUSTA -- Still coping with recession-induced staff cutbacks from 1991, the state Department of Marine Resources is planning to slash 21 more jobs from its depleted ranks to help Gov. Angus King meet his budget goal.
King's Productivity Realization Task Force has pledged to come up with at least $45 million in budget savings by January.
Marine Resources Commissioner Robin Alden on Wednesday proposed consolidating a number of functions within her department and the phaseout of the agency's South Portland office.
Of the 21 positions targeted for elimination, most are clerical in nature. Only 12 are funded under the state's General Fund where the bottom-line savings are realized.
Alden estimated her reorganization plans would provide about $335,000 in savings for the balance of the fiscal year. She was pleased that none of the positions scheduled for elimination is from the enforcement division, where marine patrol officers represent the agency's front line.
"If it goes through as proposed, we have maintained the entire field capability," she said. "We haven't touched that at all. All we've done is streamline management by reducing some staff in the special services division."
Alden plans to consolidate all of the department's biological science functions under a reorganized management, eliminating and downgrading some supervisory positions. She also plans to consolidate the department's water quality, seafood inspection and toxins monitoring responsibilities under a single manager.
While some legislators have demanded greater efforts at consolidation among departments sharing common missions, there are clearly some instances in which seemingly simple tasks quickly become more complex. The departments of Agriculture, Human Services and Marine Resources all inspect food, for example. But Alden maintained it would be necessary for her division to retain authority for inspection of seafood because the process itself is extremely rigorous.
"It's more {rigorous} than agriculture because the product is a live product and therefore the rules are much stricter for the types of surfaces that you have and types of cleaning agents you must use -- it's down to the real minutiae," she said.
Like other department heads before her, however, Alden said she would be happy to pick up the inspection roles of competing departments. She offered one example where a Maine plant might process both crabmeat and shellfish.
State law gives the state Agriculture Department responsibility for crabmeat inspections, while Marine Resources is charged with inspecting shellfish.
"Through a memorandum of understanding, we could go in and do the agriculture inspection as well, so the public would only have one state person walking through the door," she said. "Clearly we ought to be working toward that, because the shellfish program is so rigorous and the Food and Drug Administration oversees it so tightly. My feeling about productivity is that the growing areas in the plants and the toxins should all be under one state agency."
Alden's report was presented to a subcommittee of the cost-cutting panel. The full task force will meet at 1 p.m. Sept. 20 in Room 228 of the State House to discuss the proposed

Just imagining Megabucks millions may not be on the horizon, but to be safe, we're ...

Author: Ruth-Ellen Cohen Of the News staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]08 Sep 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413780767?accountid=10457

Abstract: I regarded my lottery ticket despairingly -- once again the winning numbers had eluded me. For more than three years, I have invested a dollar a week in the Tri-State Megabucks so that I can hasten my ship coming in, but to no avail. In my fantasy, there I am, a Megabucks winner, hobnobbing with the rich and famous on a yacht in the Mediterranean. And there I am again, mingling with the affluent, the opulent and the well-to-do in Monte Carlo. My reveries know no bounds -- oh, the sights I would see, the things I would do and the magic which would unfold when the pot of gold at the end of my rainbow was finally discovered. A world tour would be first on my agenda. Bangor Travel helped me find one that cost a mere $33,900 for 23 days. A chauffeured limousine picks me up from my home and whisks me to the airport for a first-class flight to New York. There, my private jet, stocked with gourmet meals and wines, carries me to the likes of Marrakech, Prague, Saudi Arabia and Bangkok. I traverse the desert on a hot air balloon; I tremble with excitement as a game run thunders past me across the African plain; I let the tropical forest in Rio de Janeiro enfold me and make me one. Truly, the world is my oyster.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Just+imagining+Megabucks+millions+may+not+be+on+the+horizon%2C+but+to+be+safe%2C+we%27re+...&amp;author=Ruth-Ellen+Cohen+Of+the+News+staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-09-08&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: I regarded my lottery ticket despairingly -- once again the winning numbers had eluded me. For more than three years, I have invested a dollar a week in the Tri-State Megabucks so that I can hasten my ship coming in, but to no avail.
Even though the gods have yet to smile upon me, still I continue to be captivated by the lure of the good life. When the Megabucks' advertisements urge viewers to "just imagine," that's exactly what I do.
In my fantasy, there I am, a Megabucks winner, hobnobbing with the rich and famous on a yacht in the Mediterranean. And there I am again, mingling with the affluent, the opulent and the well-to-do in Monte Carlo. My reveries know no bounds -- oh, the sights I would see, the things I would do and the magic which would unfold when the pot of gold at the end of my rainbow was finally discovered.
In the 10 years since the Tri-State Megabucks lottery was started, 288 people -- most of them from Maine -- have found their pots of gold. Payouts total more than $560 million, with the largest -- $16.4 million -- won Jan. 25, 1992. Megabucks officials are celebrating the lottery's anniversary this month by adding $50,000 to each September jackpot.
Somehow this most recent devastation seems like the last straw. That's it, I vow, I've had it! The Megabucks computer wouldn't have me to kick around anymore; the lottery coffers would never again be padded by my dollar bills. Pie in the sky may be fine for others, but from now on, I'll take the high road.
Yet I couldn't help but allow myself one last dream of winning The Big One and being able to satisfy my every whim. So, then, if this is to be my last fantasy, nothing would do but it must be my most decadent, my most hedonistic, my most self-indulgent yet. Why, I grow heady just thinking about it ...
A world tour would be first on my agenda. Bangor Travel helped me find one that cost a mere $33,900 for 23 days. A chauffeured limousine picks me up from my home and whisks me to the airport for a first-class flight to New York. There, my private jet, stocked with gourmet meals and wines, carries me to the likes of Marrakech, Prague, Saudi Arabia and Bangkok. I traverse the desert on a hot air balloon; I tremble with excitement as a game run thunders past me across the African plain; I let the tropical forest in Rio de Janeiro enfold me and make me one. Truly, the world is my oyster.
It's only fitting that someone as rich as Croesus dress the part. I must be bedecked and bejeweled. Graduate gemologist Bruce Kaley of Perfect Proportions in Bangor advises me to purchase a flawless, pure-white, perfectly cut, 1-karat round diamond. It comes with a price tag of $40,000, but, explains Kaley, it's a great investment -- guaranteed to increase in value each year. A platinum setting? But of course!
Naturally, my comfort must never be compromised; and nothing less than a mink coat will ensure my ability to withstand the winter winds. And so, in the time-honored tradition of the well-dressed millionaire, I choose a full-length, mahogany-colored, custom-made ranch mink. Bob Pushard, vice president of operations of World Traders in Brewer, says I can expect to pay between $3,000 and $5,000. "OK!" I agree cheerfully.
Nor would it ever do for a millionaire to be without a place to unwind. Rig Reese, director of marketing at The Hinckley Co. in Southwest Harbor, suggests a 70-foot sailboat with cherry interior, complete with a microwave, air conditioning and computer -- in fact, with all the comforts of home -- so that I am never, ever inconvenienced, even when docked in the Caribbean or the South Seas. It'll run me around $3 million, he says. "Why not?" I decide.
Constant traveling may become tedious, however. I must have a place to hang my hat, I realize; a place to call home. Karen Koos of Saltmeadow Properties in Castine and Blue Hill tells me about a 14-room mansion on the ocean in Blue Hill. At $1.2 million, with more than 5,000 square feet of living space and its own dock, I deem it a worthy investment.
And because a girl's gotta have transportation, I'm off to Village Car Co. in Bangor. I've got my heart set on a sporty, two-door Mercedes Benz SL convertible -- in red, what else? I consider it a bargain at $80,000.
And then it occurs to me that I really must stop this extravagance.
Financial adviser Lindon S. Brown II of the Brown Co. in Bangor says that even Megabucks millionaires must have a budget and a financial plan. Winners should buy "toys," he explains, only after they have put some of their windfall in the bank or invested in stocks, bonds, mutual funds or even real estate.
In fact, Kim Moore, spokeswoman for the Tri State Lotto Commission in Manchester, N.H., says the majority of the Megabucks winners during the past 10 years have done just that.
Most have been "very conservative with their money," she says, using their winnings to pay bills, take a family trip or to make improvements to their homes or businesses. "Very few" have squandered their windfalls, says Moore.
Frederick Ayer of Newport, for instance, who won $373,000 in 1987, used his winnings to start his own trucking business. Ayer and his wife, Christine, also built a house and bought a time-share condominium, a camper and a couple of new vehicles.
The Ayers, who will receive $12,500 for 12 more years, agree that it's a comforting thought to know that a check will arrive each year. And, while they may have done a bit of splurging the first couple of years, Christine Ayer explains that intelligent managing of the money really does come "once the novelty wears off."
Meanwhile, Russell Shepherd of Bangor, who won $480,000 last year, says the money will make it easier for him to attend college and, later, to buy a bed-and-breakfast on the coast. Their Megabucks earnings of $16,000 a year for 20 years have enabled Shepherd and his wife, Lynne, to buy a camper, a house and a new truck, and to put money aside for their retirement.
"Is there a downside to winning the Megabucks?" I ask him, thinking of King Midas and the blessing that become a bane.
"Yeah -- that the checks will end!"
We both guffaw.
One Megabucks winner talks grimly about a drawback, however. After he won several million dollars a couple of years ago, the man, who wants to remain anonymous, says that there's no question but that he was happier before.
"Life has become too complicated," he says. "Too many people ready to take advantage of me."
See? I tell myself sternly. There's a perfectly good reason to forego purchasing a Megabucks ticket each week. Still -- while I know money doesn't buy happiness -- there's something to be said for instant gratification.
And, it seems such a small thing in which to indulge. Really, what harm can it do? And there! I've found a dollar in my pocket ...
Illustration Caption: NEWS Illustration by K. Sherretts

Groundfish decline a drag on New England's landings ranking

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]01 Sep 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413782797?accountid=10457

Abstract: New Bedford, Mass., edged out Portland last year to reclaim its title as New England's top fishing port, but it was a race in the wrong direction. According to 1994 totals just released by the U.S. Department of Commerce's National Fisheries Service, 65.8 million pounds of seafood were landed at the Massachusetts port, good for 18th place nationally. Portland's 63.9 million placed the city right behind, in 19th place. The only other New England ports on the federal agency's Top 60 list are Port Judith, R.I., in 20th place with 62 million pounds; Gloucester, Mass., in 22nd place with 50 million pounds; Rockland in 27th with 34 million pounds; and Provincetown, Mass., in 39th with 18 million pounds.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Groundfish+decline+a+drag+on+New+England%27s+landings+ranking&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-09-01&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- New Bedford, Mass., edged out Portland last year to reclaim its title as New England's top fishing port, but it was a race in the wrong direction.
According to 1994 totals just released by the U.S. Department of Commerce's National Fisheries Service, 65.8 million pounds of seafood were landed at the Massachusetts port, good for 18th place nationally. Portland's 63.9 million placed the city right behind, in 19th place.
The value of landings is a different story. New Bedford placed third nationally at $82.4 million and Portland was 10th at $43.6 million.
The only other New England ports on the federal agency's Top 60 list are Port Judith, R.I., in 20th place with 62 million pounds; Gloucester, Mass., in 22nd place with 50 million pounds; Rockland in 27th with 34 million pounds; and Provincetown, Mass., in 39th with 18 million pounds.
The collapse of haddock, cod and flounder stocks in the North Atlantic has all New England ports trending downward. The groundfish-reliant Massachusetts ports have been especially hard hit, seeing their pounds and dollars cut in half in two years.
Since 1992, New Bedford has tumbled from eighth place in quantity, and has dropped from a strong second on the money list to a distant third. During that same period, Gloucester has fallen from ninth in landings and 12th in value.
Bouyed by several years of record and near-record lobster harvests, Portland hasn't fallen quite so far -- in 1992 and 1993, the Maine port was ranked 14th in quantity and sixth in value.
In 1993, a drastic decline in groundfish landings and attractive prices that lured fishermen to fish auctions in Portland pushed the city past New Bedford for the first time, but the traditional order was restored last year.
The nation's leading port, for the seventh year in a row, is Dutch Harbor-Unalaska, Alaska, landing nearly 700 million pounds of fish, worth $224 million. The Alaskan port held on to its ranking despite a drop of nearly 100 million pounds caused by a decline in polllock and halibut landings.
The No. 2 and No. 3 ports -- Empire-Venice and Cameron, both in Louisiana -- have gone from also-rans to strong challengers because of a booming menhaden catch. Eight of the top 10 ports are either in Alaska or Louisiana. As a region, the entire Gulf Coast is showing the strongest gains.
The decline of New England ports "shouldn't surprise anyone, with groundfish taken almost totally from the picture," said Robert Lewis of the Maine Department of Marine Resources. "Along with lobster, cod, haddock and flounder have been the backbone of the business, and they're just plain gone. Portland had a nice surge in '93," he said Thursday. "With good prices at their auctions, fishermen were willing to go a little out of their way. But you can't sell what you don't have, so it's dropped back to where it was before. Thank God for lobster."
Lewis noted that Maine would show up stronger on the national list if lobstermen weren't so famously independent.
"In most states, you have a few major ports where everything comes in," he said. "In Maine, we have dozens of small towns with buyers on every dock -- Port Clyde, Spruce Head, Vinalhaven, Friendship -- and lobstermen like to deal with people they know. If you put $100 million worth of lobster into one port, say Rockland or Portland, they'd shoot way up."
The National Marine Fisheries Service also reports that Americans ate more seafood in 1994 than the year before, 3.93 billion pounds total, or 15.2 pounds per person. That is an increase from 1993 of 76 million pounds, or nearly a quarter-pound per person.
Of that 15.2 pounds, two-thirds was fresh or frozen fish and shellfish. Most of the rest was canned, with cured seafood, such as smoked fish, accounting for the few remaining ounces. Shrimp is the strongest growth area in seafood, with the 2.6 pounds per capita consumed in 1994, a record.
After languishing in the 11- to 12-pound range for nearly a century, the United States upped its per-capita seafood intake in the early 1980s and has consumed at least 15 pounds per person every year since 1985. The record of 16.2 pounds was set in 1987.
Fifty-four percent of the seafood eaten in this country last year was imported, while U.S. exports declined by 1 percent for the second year in a row.

Fishermen focus of funding Grants to assist shift from ailing industry

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]31 Aug 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413764728?accountid=10457

Abstract: Federal grants totaling $4.5 million, including more than a half-million dollars for Maine, have been awarded to 35 projects designed to help struggling fishermen in the Northeast move into new business ventures ranging from recycling sea cucumber waste and lobster bodies to cranberry farming. Of the $4.5 million, nearly half will go to aquaculture-related projects, a quarter to new business development, a fifth to developing markets for underused species, and the remainder to reduce "bycatch," the unintended harvest of juvenile fish and untargeted species. The Fishing Industry Grant Program is administered by the U.S. Department of Commerce's National Marine Fisheries Service. The grants are part of a $30 million package that also includes boat buyback and retraining programs to help New England fishermen shift their effort from the overfished groundfish species of cod, haddock and yellowtail flounder.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Fishermen+focus+of+funding+Grants+to+assist+shift+from+ailing+industry&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-08-31&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- Federal grants totaling $4.5 million, including more than a half-million dollars for Maine, have been awarded to 35 projects designed to help struggling fishermen in the Northeast move into new business ventures ranging from recycling sea cucumber waste and lobster bodies to cranberry farming.
Of the $4.5 million, nearly half will go to aquaculture-related projects, a quarter to new business development, a fifth to developing markets for underused species, and the remainder to reduce "bycatch," the unintended harvest of juvenile fish and untargeted species.
The Fishing Industry Grant Program is administered by the U.S. Department of Commerce's National Marine Fisheries Service. The grants are part of a $30 million package that also includes boat buyback and retraining programs to help New England fishermen shift their effort from the overfished groundfish species of cod, haddock and yellowtail flounder.
This is the second round of Fishing Industry Grants. The first, announced last winter, awarded $4.5 million to 28 projects, with aquaculture leading the way.
The second-round grants still must be approved by the Commerce Department, with the money expected to be available Nov. 1. Of the $4.5 million total, $2.1 million will go to Massachusetts projects, $688,000 to Maine, $607,000 to New York and $420,000 to New Hampshire, with smaller amounts to New Jersey, Rhode Island and Maryland.
The sole aquaculture project awarded to Maine is $65,700 to Mook Sea Farms of Damariscotta to develop production strategies for the farming of sea scallops.
Most of the awards to Maine are for the development of new business ventures:
$39,129 to Carver Shellfish Inc. of Beals Island to develop a paste from waste lobster bodies to be used as a base for soups, stuffing, dips and salad dressings, and to develop new uses for the shell and body.
$36,700 to Dean Bradshaw of Dennysville to help 12 fishermen start cranberry businesses.
$42,986 to the Sunrise County Economic Council of Machias to develop markets for sea cucumber waste such as dried additive for salmon feed.
$221,028 to the Maine Department of Marine Resources to test the feasibility of using commercial fishing vessels to conduct acoustic surveys of herring spawning stocks in the Gulf of Maine.
In the category of develping underused species, Stephen Geel of Jonesport was awarded $82,150 to develop a dehumidification process for sea cucumbers. In bycatch reduction, Ronnie Shepard of Stonington will receive $43,413 to evaluate a shrimp grate to reduce the harvest of juvenile shrimp and groundfish. Also, the state DMR will receive $160,604 to reduce bycatch in the whiting fishery through gear modification.
The largest grant is $458,378 to Mariculture Techologies Inc. of Greenport, N.Y., to develop commercial-scale aquaculture systems for summer flounder and to assess the potential for flounder farming in the Northeast and mid-Atlantic states.
Maine projects funded in the first round last year included developing a snow crab fishery, value-added products from sculpin tails, seaweed aquaculture, cod and haddock aquaculture and uses for shellfish waste.
Since then, the prognosis for groundfish stocks has grown more bleak, leading the National Marine Fisheries Service to enact an emergency closure of Georges Bank and to begin preparing more stringent fishing regulations.
"The crisis is continuing and worsening, and the measures that will be taken to address it will be more severe," Scott Tilton of the service's Family Fishing Assistance Center in Rockland said Wednesday. "That makes programs like these grants, the buyout, the retraining, more necessary than ever."
Some of the selections in the first round of grants, such as the seaweed project, were criticized for not being directly related to fishing, and Tilton expects more complaints this time around.
"I know some fishermen will ask why this is funding cranberries," he said. "It's for the same reason we have fishermen retraining to become diesel mechanics and medical technicians. We have to reduce, drastically, the pressure on groundfish and help fishermen support themselves and their families. If it's in aquaculture or an alternative species, fine, but some may have to start looking at other employment opportunities, even if they're outside of fishing."

Funds sought to protect Lake Wassookeag waters

Author: Tammy Lockhart Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]28 Aug 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413766083?accountid=10457

Abstract: The Dexter Utility District is applying for funding from the Maine Department of Environmental Protection's Small Community Grant Program to upgrade or replace the septic systems of property owners along Lake Wassookeag. The recent application comes on the heels of a successful award which the community received to upgrade septic systems on properties surrounding Echo Lake. Three property owners received funds for up to 90 percent of the total cost to replace or fix their failing septic systems. Additional funds are now being sought for other qualifying property owners. The goal for the Lake Wassookeag project is the same as that at Echo Lake: to identify septic sources which are contaminating the lake and secure state funds to assist the owners in repairing or replacing the systems.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Funds+sought+to+protect+Lake+Wassookeag+waters&amp;author=Tammy+Lockhart+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-08-28&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: DEXTER -- The Dexter Utility District is applying for funding from the Maine Department of Environmental Protection's Small Community Grant Program to upgrade or replace the septic systems of property owners along Lake Wassookeag.
The state grant program could provide up to 90 percent funding for sewage treatment and disposal systems to eliminate waste-water discharges which affect drinking water supplies, pollute shellfishing areas, degrade water quality, or cause a public nuisance. The program is intended to provide facilities in rural areas of the state not served by public sewers.
The recent application comes on the heels of a successful award which the community received to upgrade septic systems on properties surrounding Echo Lake. Three property owners received funds for up to 90 percent of the total cost to replace or fix their failing septic systems. Additional funds are now being sought for other qualifying property owners. The goal for the Lake Wassookeag project is the same as that at Echo Lake: to identify septic sources which are contaminating the lake and secure state funds to assist the owners in repairing or replacing the systems.
According to John Simko, Dexter Community Development Director, chances are good for the utility district to be awarded this grant, which could be for as much as $100,000.
"The DEP's Small Community Grant Program is designed to improve water quality across the state, and has earmarked their project funds into three categories. The town's Echo Lake project was awarded a grant, although for a diminished amount, mostly because it fell into the least-pressing category of water quality programs. Lake Wassookeag, as the singular freshwater supply for the entire public water system, is given the highest priority classification by the DEP. We're quite hopeful the project will be funded."
Better to ensure the grant's success, the utility district is seeking to define the needs of property owners along Lake Wassookeag. A survey will be sent to all property owners within the Lake Wassookeag watershed to explain the grant project and to request basic information regarding the type and current functioning of their septic systems. The letter will be mailed out today.
"The Dexter Utility District is asking for cooperation in the filing and return of these surveys from the land owners. The clearer the scope of the problem, the more likely Dexter will be awarded the grant. If we're not aware of the water quality problem, we can't fix it," Simko said.
If the grant is successful, year-round residents of Lake Wassookeag will be eligible for up to 90 percent of the repair of their systems. Businesses will have up to 50 percent of their costs covered and seasonal owners will be eligible for up to 25 percent of the total costs of the repairs.
"If the survey can be completed by this fall and the application completed before winter, funding for this project could be available as early as May of 1996," Simko said.

Filmmakers, Massachusetts shellfishers in dispute

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]26 Aug 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413782771?accountid=10457

Abstract: ESSEX, Mass. -- Local clam diggers and Hollywood filmmakers are at odds in a dispute pitting the 20th century against the 17th century. Clam diggers say Twentieth Century Fox officials don't want them or their motor boats within camera range on clam flats when filming panoramic views for the movie version of Arthur Miller's play "The Crucible." The play is about the Salem witch trials, and the film company is creating a replica of 1692 Salem on a slope of Hog island, which overlooks one of the area's richest clam beds.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Filmmakers%2C+Massachusetts+shellfishers+in+dispute&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-08-26&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   ESSEX, Mass. -- Local clam diggers and Hollywood filmmakers are at odds in a dispute pitting the 20th century against the 17th century.
Clam diggers say Twentieth Century Fox officials don't want them or their motor boats within camera range on clam flats when filming panoramic views for the movie version of Arthur Miller's play "The Crucible."
The play is about the Salem witch trials, and the film company is creating a replica of 1692 Salem on a slope of Hog island, which overlooks one of the area's richest clam beds.
"These guys are out there to make money, and they want to tell guys like me to go somewhere else, to take money out of our pockets. That's not fair," Ross Parody, 37, a clam digger, told the Boston Herald.
Because of the protests from local shellfishers, selectmen will hold a special meeting Monday to ask Twentieth Century Fox officials about their plans.
Ed Neal, chairman of the selectmen, said film company officials assured him they don't want to inconvenience anyone.
"But they don't want to see little clam boats bobbing up and down in their shots and guys bending over in their Wrangler jeans," he said.
Film company officials declined to comment to the Herald Thursday. Company location manager Charles Harrington said he will do his talking at the meeting Monday.
Filming of the multi-million-dollar movie is to begin Sept. 11. It will star Oscar-winning actor Daniel Day-Lewis and Winona Ryder.
Neal, who said film company officials told him there will be a minimum of panoramic shots, said the film's economic boost to the area would appear to outweigh minor inconveniences to clam diggers and boaters.
"I really don't think it's a big issue," he said, adding that the town has the legal right to close the clam beds if deemed necessary.
Some of about a dozen clam diggers working Cleveland Flat at low tide Thursday told the Herald they support their families that way.
"I don't think they have the right to tell us to move and not be willing to compensate us in some way," said Bill Appeltofft, 33.
The clam-digging season is peaking, he said, and it would be horrible if he had to stop working Cleveland Flat. He said he would be willing to dig somewhere else if the film company paid him $100 a day.
However another clam digger, Richard Tofuri, 20, had a softer view.
"If I can make the same day's pay on the other side of the river, I don't see what the big deal is," he said.
"I think it's great they picked Salem to film. It's a beautiful place."

Vote seen as setback for scallops proposal Backers to proceed with limited testing

Author: Walter Griffin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]25 Aug 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413765804?accountid=10457

Abstract: Coastal Waters Project's plan to restore scallops to upper Penobscot Bay was dealt a setback when the Board of Environmental Protection decided the Defense Department was not obligated to test the waters for petroleum contamination. Nevertheless, [Ron] Huber said his group hoped to convince Sprague Energy and Irving Oil, two private firms with storage facilities at the point, to take part in a public-private testing program. He said Lt. Col. Charles Renfro, commander of Defense Fuel Region Northeast, had agreed to contribute to the joint testing project. Renfro was traveling Thursday and could not be reached for comment. Huber said his group applauds the Defense Department for its offer to take part in the testing project. He added that Sprague Energy has also indicated an interest in participating in such a study. "We're waiting to hear from Irving Oil. Hopefully, we can soon find out if oil pollution is a significant reason for the decline of upper Penobscot Bay's once abundant shellfish."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Vote+seen+as+setback+for+scallops+proposal+Backers+to+proceed+with+limited+testing&amp;author=Walter+Griffin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-08-25&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   AUGUSTA -- Coastal Waters Project's plan to restore scallops to upper Penobscot Bay was dealt a setback when the Board of Environmental Protection decided the Defense Department was not obligated to test the waters for petroleum contamination.
The Pentagon operates a jet fuel tank farm at Mack Point on Long Cove, across from Sears Island. Coastal Waters had attempted to block the re-licensing of that facility until offshore testing was undertaken. The board rejected the appeal 3-2 Wednesday.
"We're disappointed by the board's ruling," CWP's Ron Huber said Thursday. "In effect, the board said that restoring upper Penobscot Bay's shellfish industry is not a high priority for the state."
Nevertheless, Huber said his group hoped to convince Sprague Energy and Irving Oil, two private firms with storage facilities at the point, to take part in a public-private testing program. He said Lt. Col. Charles Renfro, commander of Defense Fuel Region Northeast, had agreed to contribute to the joint testing project. Renfro was traveling Thursday and could not be reached for comment.
Huber said his group applauds the Defense Department for its offer to take part in the testing project. He added that Sprague Energy has also indicated an interest in participating in such a study. "We're waiting to hear from Irving Oil. Hopefully, we can soon find out if oil pollution is a significant reason for the decline of upper Penobscot Bay's once abundant shellfish."
Huber said the BEP was reluctant to order extensive testing because there was no conclusive evidence of major oil spills since the early 1970s. He said the Defense Department will conduct some testing in and near the drainage ditches and culverts that surround the terminals as part of the license renewal.
"There was some circumstantial evidence, but no proof of spills. We didn't have the resources to pull up a handful of muck and say, `look at this,"' he said.
Huber said his group has been working with Charles Stevens of Clams Fiesta in Rockland and local fishermen on a plan to restore the upper Penobscot Bay's shellfishery by re-introducing scallops and other shellfish from the outer bay to nutrient-rich Long Cove in Searsport.
"Placed in protected areas, these scallops will serve as spawning stocks whose larvae could recolonize dozens of square miles of the upper bay's sea floor," Huber said.
He noted that, unlike clams, the part of the scallop consumed by humans is not affected by coliform bacterial pollution. That distinction allows scallop fishing in many of the same areas that are closed to clamming.
"Before we can do anything," Huber said, "we need to know if there is significant oil pollution in Long Cove, as it could prove deadly to scallops and their larvae."
Huber said the "limited testing" of areas around the tank terminals should be completed by October. "At that point -- presuming it's not sweet and clean -- we will make the next move: to ask them to come up with a more comprehensive study."

Lamoine citizens to celebrate town's 125 years People of all ages will turn out to commemorate coastal community's rich and varied history

Author: Kathy Harbour Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]11 Aug 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413791357?accountid=10457

Abstract: At the end of a muggy Sunday afternoon, they straggled into the Lamoine Town Hall hauling saxophones, flutes, tubas, trombones, trumpets and clarinets. Lamoine is throwing open its doors for a birthday bash this weekend, bringing together its present-day residents for a parade, street dance, games and community art show, and inviting others in for a look at what this Down East Maine town used to be and what it is today. By the 1800s, the miles of coastline provided a year-round way of life, with shipbuilding a major industry. Over 60 vessels were built in Lamoine -- many two-masted schooners -- and most of those before the Civil War when Lamoine was known as East Trenton.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lamoine+citizens+to+celebrate+town%27s+125+years+People+of+all+ages+will+turn+out+to+commemorate+coastal+community%27s+rich+and+varied+history&amp;author=Kathy+Harbour+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-08-11&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: LAMOINE -- At the end of a muggy Sunday afternoon, they straggled into the Lamoine Town Hall hauling saxophones, flutes, tubas, trombones, trumpets and clarinets.
From age 7 to 47 and beyond, this ragtag band -- in shorts and flipflops, overalls and T-shirts -- had been pulled from sandy beaches and backyard barbecues to prepare for Lamoine's 125th birthday celebration.
Tuning up for this one-of-a-kind performance, band leader Jim Trembley enthusiastically coaxed an E sharp from the flutes and overlooked a discordant measure or two from his motley crew as they belted out the "Charleston" and "Rubber Ducky."
This band is Lamoine's present and future, ready to celebrate with music a community that once had and still claims vital ties to the sea.
Lamoine is throwing open its doors for a birthday bash this weekend, bringing together its present-day residents for a parade, street dance, games and community art show, and inviting others in for a look at what this Down East Maine town used to be and what it is today.
Locate Lamoine on any state map or fly over it for an aerial view and you can make good guesses about its past and present.
It is a town bordered on nearly every side by the ocean, and the trades of the sea sustained its earliest residents. Archaeologists have found that Native Americans first came to its shores, reaping the abundance of shellfish and marine mammals along the coastline during the winter months.
By the 1800s, the miles of coastline provided a year-round way of life, with shipbuilding a major industry. Over 60 vessels were built in Lamoine -- many two-masted schooners -- and most of those before the Civil War when Lamoine was known as East Trenton.
Its sea captains traveled the world, sailing their schooners to the Caribbean, South America and China.
If not engaged in shipbuilding, residents turned to farming, fishing, logging, blacksmithing, carpentry and running general stores.
The fishermen of the 1800s traveled to Nova Scotia and the Grand Banks for extended excursions, when cod and herring were the fish of choice. The fish were brought back to Lamoine to one of many wharves and smokehouses along the Jordan River, where the catch was dried and shipped off to Boston.
Roads were superfluous in early Lamoine. The highway was the sea.
By 1870, the town had incorporated, a fact made official by Gov. Joshua Chamberlain who signed the bill into law. The town was named after an early resident, Andre LeMoyne, who was one of an earlier group of French people who had hoped to establish a safe haven at Lamoine Beach for aristocrats escaping the French Revolution.
A bustling town in the late 1800s, Lamoine shipped ice to Boston from Blunt's Pond, canned sardines at the cannery at the local beach, and welcomed guests at in-town hotels -- Shore Acres at Lamoine Beach and the Gault Hotel at the present state park.
Steamboat service to and from Bar Harbor across Eastern Bay brought visitors to its shores, and sightseeing trips aboard schooners were ready for tourists who traveled to Lamoine in the late 1800s.
With a dwindling economy and a loss of jobs in the shipbuilding and shipping businesses, Lamoine's population began to decline after the heydays of the 1880s, reaching a low point during the 1930s and 1940s.
Today fewer than 50 boats, many of those pleasure craft, moor off Lamoine State Park. The pockmarks in the town's interior landscape are the gravel pits, now the major industry. As a bedroom community with no general store, post office, hotels or fish wharves, the town turns to the sea for pleasure, its seaside real estate a major resource.
This weekend several activities will mark the anniversary. On Friday, tours of seven of Lamoine's oldest houses and two of its churches will be conducted from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Tickets may be purchased at the Town Hall. Cassettes and a detailed map describing historic places included within a self-guided tour of Lamoine are available at the Town Hall or at the information booth at Coyne Field, both on Route 184.
The parade begins at 11 a.m. Saturday at the Lamoine Grange, with old-fashioned games after the parade at Coyne Field. A daylong yard sale will be staged from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. at the Grange Hall. Following a Grange supper at 5:30 p.m., silent movies with a piano accompaniment will begin at 7 p.m.
On Sunday, a craft fair will be held from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. at the Lamoine School, and a community art show and exhibit of Lamoine's history will be on display at the state park throughout the day. Admission to the park that day is free.
The community concert, with band and chorus, begins on Sunday at 2 p.m. at the state park, where several boats will be available for touring. Family sports activities will be ongoing Sunday afternoon at the park.
Illustration Caption: D.D. Hodgkins Fish Stand, circa 1880. The Lamoine Cornet Band, circa 1906.

Down East chefs, organic farmers plan benefit dinner

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413835874?accountid=10457

Abstract: The finest Down East chefs will join the area's organic farmers to present the second annual Benefit Gourmet Dinner at 7 p.m. Monday, Aug. 14, at Halcyon Grange Hall, Route 15, in North Blue Hill. The event, sponsored by and benefitting the Maine Organic Farmers and Gardeners Association, will feature food grown, caught or raised in Maine and will combine specialties from the finest inns and restaurants.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Down+East+chefs%2C+organic+farmers+plan+benefit+dinner&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-08-10&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BLUE HILL -- The finest Down East chefs will join the area's organic farmers to present the second annual Benefit Gourmet Dinner at 7 p.m. Monday, Aug. 14, at Halcyon Grange Hall, Route 15, in North Blue Hill.
The event, sponsored by and benefitting the Maine Organic Farmers and Gardeners Association, will feature food grown, caught or raised in Maine and will combine specialties from the finest inns and restaurants.
"Most of these places are buying locally grown and organic produce and cooking it every day," said Paul Volckhausen of Orland, one of the event's organizers.
A crabmeat canape from the Blue Hill Farm Inn will be served with Blue Hill Inn's famous potato salad and the renowned French bread from the Left Bank Cafe. Oysters from Spinney Creek Shellfish in Eliot will become Oysters Rockefeller by the chef of the Crocker House Inn on Hancock Point. The Manor in Castine will contribute its Oriental terrine, with a pasta dish from Maine Stay in Castine and blueberry pie from the Castine Inn.
Jonathan's in Blue Hill, Haystack in Deer Isle, the Pilgrim's Inn in Deer Isle, and Sow's Ear Winery in Brooksville also will contribute to the festive affair. Steamed mussels from Maine's Best Seafood and beer from a local microbrewery also are expected to be on the menu.
Farmers donating organic produce are Horsepower Farm, Happytown Farm in North Orland, King Hill Farm, Little Tree Farm, Beech Hill Farm on Mount Desert Island, and Chris Hurley and Nancy Veilleux of Penobscot.
For information, call 667-9212 or 326-9719.

____________________________________________________________

Still driven to drive at 100 West Jonesport's Gladys Smith is a big wheel on her birthday

Author: Letitia Baldwin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]09 Aug 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413834670?accountid=10457

Abstract: Humor, hard work and having a closeknit family may be some of the key elements that keep Gladys Smith going at the age of 100, but her beloved 1983 Buick Electra does for sure as she continues to drive herself on errands around West Jonesport. But she doesn't venture too far, as she did at age 88, when she traveled to France to stay with her granddaughter and family who were living in the Alsatian town of Soultz. She fears she'll get exhausted and won't be able to get back home. A tall, handsome woman with a heart-shaped face, Gladys Smith looked radiant as she was escorted into the Jonesport-Beals High School gym where she was honored by relatives, friends and neighbors at a big birthday bash Tuesday afternoon. She wore a brooch, a favorite blue floral print dress and a dainty crocheted cardigan for the occasion.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Still+driven+to+drive+at+100+West+Jonesport%27s+Gladys+Smith+is+a+big+wheel+on+her+birthday&amp;author=Letitia+Baldwin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-08-09&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Humor, hard work and having a closeknit family may be some of the key elements that keep Gladys Smith going at the age of 100, but her beloved 1983 Buick Electra does for sure as she continues to drive herself on errands around West Jonesport.
"I go to the cemetery, Fleet Bank, library and IGA grocery store," said the centenarian who has logged 40,105 miles since her copper and beige Buick was purchased in 1983.
But she doesn't venture too far, as she did at age 88, when she traveled to France to stay with her granddaughter and family who were living in the Alsatian town of Soultz. She fears she'll get exhausted and won't be able to get back home.
A tall, handsome woman with a heart-shaped face, Gladys Smith looked radiant as she was escorted into the Jonesport-Beals High School gym where she was honored by relatives, friends and neighbors at a big birthday bash Tuesday afternoon. She wore a brooch, a favorite blue floral print dress and a dainty crocheted cardigan for the occasion.
An easychair for the guest of honor was positioned in the middle of the gym. A string of letters spelling out "Happy 100th Birthday" hung from a long table laden with lobster rolls, crabmeat sandwiches and other refreshments. A triple-tiered white cake decked with lavender flowers formed the centerpiece on another table.
Before the reception, Smith reminisced about her long life in her pea-green house that sits on a knoll above a duck pond ringed with cat-o-nine tails. From her porch, she can see her three sons' wharf and lobster business, Smith Brothers, beside Abram's Cove and Moosabec Reach beyond.
Smith comes from a long line of seafaring folk. Her father originally came from Maryland where he fished for oysters in Chesapeake Bay. He switched to buying and fishing for lobsters after settling in Maine.
She spent part of her childhood on a saltwater farm in nearby South Addison. "My mind is just as good as it ever was. I could sit down and draw a picture of that farm," Smith mused.
Seated in an easychair in her living room, Smith pointed out an oil painting of a white-hulled schooner hanging on the wall. She said the Margaret Roper was one of five coastal schooners belonging to her late husband's grandfather.
Smith and her husband, Leon Smith Sr., had three sons and two daughters, their first girl dying at the age of ten. She remembers she kept as many as three cows and several hundred chickens to help feed the family.
"Land sakes, I did all the milking," she laughed, a broad smile breaking across her lined face.
After their children had grown up, it became an annual ritual for the Smiths to go to Florida from January until May 1, their wedding anniversary. A glass-doored cabinet brims with coral, conch and other seashells that are reminders of those happy days.
In her lifetime, Smith has witnessed many dramatic changes around town. She remembers the day when there was no electricity or sidewalks. She marvels at how Maine's fisheries have changed. She is amused at the demand for sea urchins, sea cucumbers and other marine creatures she would never dream of eating.
Slightly hard of hearing, Smith has few physical complaints save for her legs that sometimes "smart and burn." Her doctor says her circulation is fine and can't seem to find the origin of the discomfort.
"To tell the truth, I have an idea he thinks it's old age because he doesn't say anything," she chuckled.
Keeping busy seems key to Smith's longevity. She does much of her own cooking. She continues to read and crochet. She keeps in line her lively golden retriever, Goldie, that is a fraction of her age.
Brightly-colored crocheted afghans and pillows adorning practically every sofa and chair are evidence of her fine handiwork.
Smith has been crocheting a present for her grandson but won't reveal what it is.
"He tells me, `Nana, when you get that done, I want you to drive down so I can tell people my 100-year-old grandmother delivered it.' "
Illustration Caption: Whether at home (above) or in her beloved Buick Electra (top photo), 100-year-old Gladys Smith of West Jonesboro displays her sense of humor. (NEWS Photos by Michele Stapleton)

Yarmouth mulls wider clamming Commercial digging may resume

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]07 Aug 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413951198?accountid=10457

Abstract: The Yarmouth Clam Festival could, within a few years, be offering home-grown clams. The coastal town, which draws thousands of visitors to the annual midsummer festival that celebrates the clam, has been off-limits to commercial clam digging for nearly a decade. As a result, the mountains of clams served at the festival come from outside the town. Backed by some members of Yarmouth's Shellfish Commission and commercial diggers, the town is taking steps to revitalize commercial clam harvesting, a move some say will boost the local economy and help clean Casco Bay.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Yarmouth+mulls+wider+clamming+Commercial+digging+may+resume&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-08-07&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: YARMOUTH -- The Yarmouth Clam Festival could, within a few years, be offering home-grown clams.
The coastal town, which draws thousands of visitors to the annual midsummer festival that celebrates the clam, has been off-limits to commercial clam digging for nearly a decade. As a result, the mountains of clams served at the festival come from outside the town.
Backed by some members of Yarmouth's Shellfish Commission and commercial diggers, the town is taking steps to revitalize commercial clam harvesting, a move some say will boost the local economy and help clean Casco Bay.
The driving force behind the effort is Jay Pinkham, a recent addition to the commission. He points to the thriving clamming industry in Freeport, saying commercial clamming there employs 62 diggers and pumps about $1 million into the local economy.
If the clam population rebounds in Yarmouth, Pinkham and other commission members say, commercial diggers could be working the mud flats in two or three years.
More than one-third of Casco Bay's flats are closed to digging because of pollution. In Yarmouth, much of the shoreline on the town's islands are open for digging, but expansive flats on the mainland are closed because of pollution.
Pinkham has started work with biologists from the Maine Department of Marine Resources to study the Yarmouth shoreline for sources of pollution, such as outhouses and faulty septic systems and tanks.
A biologist's survey of the flats last fall showed that while the number of mature clams remains low, the number of seed clams is much higher than it has been in years. Small seed clams, which are from a quarter to a half-inch long, take about three years before they are large enough to harvest.
"I think Yarmouth is on the right track," said Ted Curtis, the commission chairman and shellfish warden in neighboring Cumberland. "If we still have abundant seed and keep up the fight to locate areas of potential contamination, we could maybe support some commercial digging."
The commission has refused to offer commercial licenses because the short supply of clams would not support an intensive harvest, Curtis said.
This year, as it has in the past, Yarmouth decided to sell only "mess licenses," geared toward recreational diggers who can harvest up to a peck of clams a day, usually enough for supper.
Ardley Cusack, Yarmouth's shellfish warden, said that with so much of Yarmouth's mainland closed to digging, issuing commercial licenses would cause an uproar.
"If you put commercial diggers on the islands, you can forget your recreational diggers, because there won't be any clams left," he said.

Rockland woman 1995 Sea Goddess Rain fails to put pinch on lobster fest Friday

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]05 Aug 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413804995?accountid=10457

Abstract: Julie Lynn Hedrich of Rockland was crowned Maine Sea Goddess at the 48th annual Maine Lobster Festival Friday night. Hedrich, 18, is the daughter of David and Charlene Hedrich. Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Rockland+woman+1995+Sea+Goddess+Rain+fails+to+put+pinch+on+lobster+fest+Friday&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-08-05&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- Julie Lynn Hedrich of Rockland was crowned Maine Sea Goddess at the 48th annual Maine Lobster Festival Friday night.
The runner-up crown princess is Sharon Diane Barrows, also of Rockland. Both women are 1995 graduates of Rockland District High School.
Hedrich, 18, is the daughter of David and Charlene Hedrich. She plans to attend the University of Maine to major in premedicine and microbiology. Her RDHS activities included Girls State, National Honor Society, theater, sports, jazz band, math team and student government. Her festival sponsors were Andrus Flowers and Gifts and the accounting firm of Simoneau and Norton.
Barrows, 18, is the daughter of Jeff and Lillian Barrows. She plans to attend Baker College, studying for a career as a social worker. At RDHS, she was active in sports, cheerleading, the community service group, peer helpers and Project Graduation. Her sponsors were Bruce Gamage Jr. Antiques and Shepard Motors.
The Sea Goddess Pageant was held at the Fishermen's Memorial Stage with 19 contestants vying for the crown, judged on their accomplishments and performance in interviews testing their knowledge of both current events and the state's premier crustacean. As Sea Goddess, Hedrich will represent the Maine lobster industry at events and trade shows during the coming year.
An unappetizing drizzle didn't keep a huge crowd from packing the fairgrounds to the gills Friday. Despite, or perhaps because of, a full-page ad in a local paper Thursday by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals and actress Mary Tyler Moore protesting the boiling of live lobsters, festival organizers predict shellfish sales in excess of 15,000 pounds this year, a good ton and a half beyond last year's record.
The first official duty for Hedrich and Barrows will be to preside over today's Harbor of Delights Parade down Rockland's Main Street at 10 a.m. Other Saturday events include tours of the Navy ship USS Stephen W. Groves, a blindfold rowboat race, a parade of lobster boats and an 8:30 p.m. performance by Motown legends Martha Reeves and the Vandellas.
The festival wraps up Sunday with a 10K road race, the codfish carry and the lobster crate race, with King Neptune returning to the briny deep at 5 p.m. until next year.

Steuben to mark 200th birthday Fireworks to cap daylong festivities

Author: Letitia Baldwin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]04 Aug 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413952256?accountid=10457

Abstract: Incorporated on Feb. 27, 1795, Steuben has grown from several hundred to 1,100 year-round residents. Traditions die hard in this town, where residents throughout the year have been re-creating their past in honor of the bicentennial. Earlier this year, they re-enacted the first town meeting, and this fall they plan to throw a grand ball and midnight oyster stew supper similar to one held a century ago.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Steuben+to+mark+200th+birthday+Fireworks+to+cap+daylong+festivities&amp;author=Letitia+Baldwin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-08-04&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: STEUBEN -- Residents will mark their town's 200th birthday by staging a full day of family entertainment commencing with a craft fair and culminating with a fireworks display Saturday night.
Incorporated on Feb. 27, 1795, Steuben has grown from several hundred to 1,100 year-round residents. Traditions die hard in this town, where residents throughout the year have been re-creating their past in honor of the bicentennial. Earlier this year, they re-enacted the first town meeting, and this fall they plan to throw a grand ball and midnight oyster stew supper similar to one held a century ago.
"I'd say the town doesn't like to see new changes," summed up Steuben's first selectman, Handy Pinkham. He has served on the board for more than three decades.
Steuben bicentennial committee members raised $5,000 for the fireworks show from the town meeting re-enactment and accompanying chicken pot pie supper, lobster stew and strawberry shortcake dinner, gospel concert, and numerous other fund-raisers. Additional funds raised will be used for the restoration of old town records.
Dyers Bay resident Barbara Jason is assembling a bicentennial quilt. The squares were sewn by more than two dozen women in town.
Saturday's bicentennial festivities kick off at 10 a.m. at the Ella Lewis School with a craft fair, pony rides, children's games, a horseshoe pitching tournament, a gospel music concert and antique car show. Trophies for five classes of antique cars will be presented at 1:30 p.m.
At noon, the Steuben Fire Department will hold a chicken barbecue, with potato salad, corn on the cob and blueberry pie. Acadia bagpipers and drummers will perform afterward.
The country-rock group Ambush will provide music 3 to 4 p.m. Crab rolls and other refreshments will be on sale.
At 6:30 p.m., Steuben resident Mary Alice Thurston and family, folk singer Ruby Gensheimer, pianist-composer Glenn Collind and balladeer Ron Williams will be among the local talent performing in a variety show in the grammar school gym.
The fireworks display will follow at 9 p.m. at the firehouse field off Route 1.

Maine's freshwater mussels abound

Author: Mary Anne Lagasse Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]26 July 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413801817?accountid=10457

Abstract: Freshwater mussels look like clams, but they are not one of the state's seafood delicacies. Of the 297 species of freshwater mussels in North America, only 11 species can be been found in Maine, said [Mark A.] McCollough. Some species, like the Eastern Elliptio, are common here, but others, like the Tidewater Mucket, are rare. The Tidewater Mucket can only be found in two or three sites; one site is the Chickawaukee River in Rockland. The Eastern Elliptio can be seen in nearly all lakes, ponds and rivers in Maine. It has brown to coppery-brown shells. The Yellow Lampmussel has yellowish colored shells and can be found in 15 of the state's watersheds, such as the St. George River, the Penobscot River, the Mattawamkeag River and the Sheepscot River.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Maine%27s+freshwater+mussels+abound&amp;author=Mary+Anne+Lagasse+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-07-26&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Freshwater mussels look like clams, but they are not one of the state's seafood delicacies.
Craving the taste of steamed clams, a group of Scouts recently gathered up a bunch of freshwater mussels and cooked them.
"They taste like an old piece of leather that was on the bottom of a stream for 10 years," said Mark A. McCollough, a wildlife biologist with the Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife, who was with the youngsters.
Of the 297 species of freshwater mussels in North America, only 11 species can be been found in Maine, said McCollough. Some species, like the Eastern Elliptio, are common here, but others, like the Tidewater Mucket, are rare. The Tidewater Mucket can only be found in two or three sites; one site is the Chickawaukee River in Rockland.
The Eastern Elliptio can be seen in nearly all lakes, ponds and rivers in Maine. It has brown to coppery-brown shells. The Yellow Lampmussel has yellowish colored shells and can be found in 15 of the state's watersheds, such as the St. George River, the Penobscot River, the Mattawamkeag River and the Sheepscot River.
Freshwater mussels have very complex anatomies, said McCollough. Muscles hold the two halves of the shell together. Inside the mollusk, there is a digestive system, a reproductive system and gills to breath.
Freshwater mussels purify water. All day long they filter water. They sieve out the phytoplankton and bacteria.
"An individual mussel in the course of 24 hours may filter hundreds of gallons of water," said the biologist. "They are constantly cleaning the water."
Mussels can move, but generally don't go more than a few yards from where they settle in the bottom of a stream, lake or pond. Some mussels, like the Eastern Pearl, may live for more than 100 years, much longer than the Eastern Elliptio, which lives eight to 10 years. Counting the dark rings on the shells will tell you the mussel's age.
One interesting thing about mussels is they cannot survive without an appropriate host fish to carry their young, McCollough said. Young mussels, called glochidia, are almost microscopic. They look like a tiny clam with little sharp projections. When they are released into the water, they float for a few days trying to find a fish to grab onto.
"It can't be any fish," said McCollough. "Each species of mussels has only one or two host fish. We don't even know at this time what host fish is necessary to keep these populations of mussels alive."
The glochidia latch onto the gills or the fins of a fish while undergoing a complete transformation into miniature adult mussels. After a few weeks, they drop off the fish and land on the bottom of the lake or stream.
Therefore, McCollough said, to maintain the mussel's existence it is not only important to maintain water quality, but also to maintain the fish species there.
Illustration Caption: Freshwater Mussels. (Photo courtesy Mark A. McCollough)

____________________________________________________________

Back to scriptures

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]25 July 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413778811?accountid=10457

Abstract: A recent letter attributed the reason for God's destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah to the gay lifestyle. Therefore gays are not acceptable to God. While this is an opinion held by some, it is not what current biblical scholarship has found. Nor what Jesus Christ seems to imply in Matthew's Gospel (Chapter 10, verses 11-15) about why these cities were destroyed. Jesus' statement compares a town's inhospitality for his gospel message with Sodom and Gomorrah's final fate. "I tell you the truth, it will be more bearable for Sodom and Gomorrah on the day of judgment than for that town." What is Jesus comparing? Is it sexual sin vs. hospitality? I don't think so.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Back+to+scriptures&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-07-25&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: A recent letter attributed the reason for God's destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah to the gay lifestyle. Therefore gays are not acceptable to God. While this is an opinion held by some, it is not what current biblical scholarship has found. Nor what Jesus Christ seems to imply in Matthew's Gospel (Chapter 10, verses 11-15) about why these cities were destroyed. Jesus' statement compares a town's inhospitality for his gospel message with Sodom and Gomorrah's final fate. "I tell you the truth, it will be more bearable for Sodom and Gomorrah on the day of judgment than for that town." What is Jesus comparing? Is it sexual sin vs. hospitality? I don't think so.
The misunderstanding that the sin of Sodom was sexual and in particular homosexual sex goes back to the story found in the book of Genesis. In this account, the people of Sodom wanted to "know" the messenger of God (an angel) at Lot's home. In the King James Bible, to "know" was commonly used for sexual knowledge as in "Adam knew Eve and begot Cain and Abel." The original Hebrew for the verb "to know" in the Sodom story is not the same word as used for sexual knowledge in other parts of the book of Genesis. Biblical research has known this since the 1950's, when books were published on the original language of this text.
In the English language today, because of this misunderstanding based on the King James Bible, we have the term "sodomy."
Many people use the text in Leviticus to condemn gays. This is the same book of the Bible that prohibits eating shellfish.
I can understand how many still cling to this viewpoint of ignorance. But several Christian denominations recognize the past injustice and today accept gays openly in their churches and even into their ministries, such as the Episcopalians and the United Church of Christ.
I do not wish to sound like I am mocking the holy scriptures. As a Christian, I follow Jesus and try to understand the Bible through his message of love and acceptance. I read scripture daily seeking to understand the texts through what Jesus taught.
When I read letters to the editor using the Christian faith against gays, I must speak out. God loves his creation. All of us! Thomas G. Stama Milbridge

Spudstock draws few fans, cool reviews Concert-goers disappointed by rain delays, cancellation of Blue Oyster Cult

Author: Mike McLaughlin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 July 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413966057?accountid=10457

Abstract: They were the ticket-holders of Spudstock '95 and, after the three-day music festival, many of them departed Sunday feeling less than satisfied with the experience. As he packed his hamburger grill into his white van Sunday morning, [Scott] Woodard said he and his friend traveled about six hours to get to the event in Aroostook County that was billed as featuring 21 live musical performances playing to approximately 30,000 people. Due to the inclement weather, Woodard and the rest of Friday's crowd saw a dramatic change in the performance schedule. One of the headlining bands, Blue Oyster Cult, did not play on Friday night as scheduled. Though it began to look doubtful as Saturday afternoon rolled around that the heavy metal group would play at all, some who were drawn to the festival partially because of the band's scheduled appearance refused to give up hope.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Spudstock+draws+few+fans%2C+cool+reviews+Concert-goers+disappointed+by+rain+delays%2C+cancellation+of+Blue+Oyster+Cult&amp;author=Mike+McLaughlin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-07-24&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   FORT FAIRFIELD -- Their eyes and ears absorbed more than 20 hours of live entertainment.
Their skin baked in the hot Fort Fairfield sun.
And now they have peeled out of here in search of a new adventure.
They were the ticket-holders of Spudstock '95 and, after the three-day music festival, many of them departed Sunday feeling less than satisfied with the experience.
"I'm a little disappointed," was the phrase used by many of the concert-goers, Scott Woodard of Portland among them.
As he packed his hamburger grill into his white van Sunday morning, Woodard said he and his friend traveled about six hours to get to the event in Aroostook County that was billed as featuring 21 live musical performances playing to approximately 30,000 people.
When Woodard arrived on Friday he saw the stage still under construction, a far less than expected turnout that would eventually total only 6,300 for the three days, and a brief rain shower that delayed the start of the show for about two hours.
The rain delay stirred up the crowd and some felt the bands and crews were a little wet behind the ears already when it came to life in the County.
"We pick potatoes in worse weather than this," one angry fan yelled from the area in front of the stage.
Due to the inclement weather, Woodard and the rest of Friday's crowd saw a dramatic change in the performance schedule. One of the headlining bands, Blue Oyster Cult, did not play on Friday night as scheduled. Though it began to look doubtful as Saturday afternoon rolled around that the heavy metal group would play at all, some who were drawn to the festival partially because of the band's scheduled appearance refused to give up hope.
"No one knows if they're going to play," said Josh Bokesz, 15, of Somersworth, N.H., as he played Hackey Sack with two of his friends, all three paying little attention to the lesser-known band playing on the Spudstock stage at the time.
Blue Oyster Cult never did play during the three-day event, making it the only cancellation. This early disappointment did not make a good first impression with many ticket-holders and it did not lay groundwork for good relations between ticket-holders and organizers. But people gamely found ways to have a good time.
"I was expecting 30,000 people to be crammed into this tight space," said Chris Berube of St. Albans. "I am still having a great time," he quickly added, though, as he relaxed on the grass in front of the stage and listened to the music of The Boneheads.
Pam McGary of Patten expressed a similar sentiment as she enjoyed the final hours of Spudstock on Sunday. "I loved it. I'm sorry there wasn't more of a crowd," McGary said while awaiting the arrival of country star John Anderson.
Many made their best efforts to enjoy the festival by participating in games of volleyball, soccer, Frisbee disk toss and -- judging by a banner that read "Use Hemp Daily" and a young man who asked a vendor if he could buy "Spudstock condoms" -- less public forms of entertainment as well.
When it came to enjoying themselves in front of the stage area, however, some of those listening to the bands felt restricted by security guards who discouraged dancing. The approximately 75 guards, dressed in black T-shirts and carrying their walkie-talkies, tried to avoid any slam dancing incidents that would harm others watching the performances.
"Dancing is part of the music, man," a frustrated Richard Flannery of Portland said, commenting on the actions of the security guards.
Neil Collins of Twisted Roots, one of the more high-energy groups at Spudstock, had no qualms about telling guards to leave the audience alone as he played his bass guitar on stage.
"They're all mad at me for giving them a hard time over the microphone," Collins of Portland said as he signed autographs for several youngsters who raced up to the side of the stage with their magic markers and "Twisted Roots" posters.
Although security was seen as too tight by many, Ham Robbins of the Rent-A-Medic service, hired to provide care for the sick or injured, said there were few serious injuries.
"It's all been real light duty," Robbins said. The medic from Greenfield added that one of his main concerns was extreme temperatures. But with adequate water supplies, he added, this problem was avoided.
With a 48-foot trailer of the official "Spudstock Water" left over after the event, dehydration wasn't much of a problem -- that is, if you had the $2 to dish out for it.
Perhaps Quiet Riot should have kept their "Spudstock Water" instead of giving it away to some adoring fans. The heavy metal group's crew got in a skirmish with the Spudstock crew and they all could have used a little cooling off.
Lance Sullivan of Ashland summed up Spudstock '95 as he took a drag on a cigarette and watched the final activities on Sunday morning.
"It was so-so, it could have been better," Sullivan said.
Illustration Caption: Some of the 6,300 people to attend Spudstock '95 listen to Twisted Roots of Portland Saturday night in Fort Fairfield. Attendance fell far short of organizers' prediction that 30,000 people would attend the three-day event in Aroostook County. (NEWS Photo by Michele Stapleton) Security personnel Dan Searway (left) and Dave Bernier, both of Portland, amuse themselves with yo-yos Saturday night as Spudstock '95 security had little concern during a band change. (NEWS Photo by Michele Stapleton)
