Eddie Money, Quiet Riot fan favorites at Spudstock Concert-goers like rockers

Author: Mike McLaughlin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 July 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413796083?accountid=10457

Abstract: At the 103 acres of potato land that was the site for Spudstock '95, ticket-holders reaped less live music than they expected, but it was clear many still dug the performance of Eddie Money. Despite not starting his show until the wee hours of Sunday morning, when many in Aroostook County were fast asleep, Money came out swinging on the Fort Fairfield stage. Money wasted no time in delivering some of his crop of hits to the Spudstock audience and kicked his set off with one of his biggest singles, "Two Tickets to Paradise".

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Eddie+Money%2C+Quiet+Riot+fan+favorites+at+Spudstock+Concert-goers+like+rockers&amp;author=Mike+McLaughlin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-07-24&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: At the 103 acres of potato land that was the site for Spudstock '95, ticket-holders reaped less live music than they expected, but it was clear many still dug the performance of Eddie Money.
One of the lead bands, Blue Oyster Cult, failed to perform for the three-day concert. They showed up Friday night, but due to bad weather, they never took the stage.
Despite not starting his show until the wee hours of Sunday morning, when many in Aroostook County were fast asleep, Money came out swinging on the Fort Fairfield stage.
"I never go to bed before 3:30 anyway," the singer said, after whipping his microphone around in a circle by its cord.
Money wasted no time in delivering some of his crop of hits to the Spudstock audience and kicked his set off with one of his biggest singles, "Two Tickets to Paradise".
Despite a very lengthy soundcheck by members of his road crew, Money's first few numbers were plagued with distracting technical problems on the stage. These were soon taken care of, however, and fans could focus their attention on the tall, shaggy-haired rocker they had come to see.
Money thrilled the rambunctious crowd gathered on the farmland with hits from his heyday in the late 1970s and '80s, and he also introduced fans to songs from his latest album, "Love and Money."
"After This Love is Gone," a ballad and the first release from his latest effort, has the potential to put Money back on the charts. With songs like "Where's the Party?" and "Shakin"' in his arsenal, however, fans wanted Money to make them dance, and he certainly didn't disappoint during his 1 1/2-hour performance.
In the crowd-pleasing department, Quiet Riot and The Guess Who were the only two acts that really gave Eddie a run for his money during the three-day music festival.
Quiet Riot, a successful heavy-metal group during the mid-'80s that has recently resurfaced with a new album, is not on tour, but traveled 3,500 miles to perform at Spudstock.
"I didn't travel 3,500 miles not to give you everything I've got," lead singer Kevin Dubrow said. "We're here to play an evening of politically incorrect rock 'n' roll for you, and that's the way it should be." Dubrow then went on to give his tender acoustic delivery of "Love's a Bitch."
Quiet Riot sounded much like the group of old on all of its material, and guitarist Carlos Cavazo gave an impresssive solo of at least three minutes in length, but it was the band's familiar songs, such as "Cum On Feel The Noize" and "Metal Health (Bang Your Head)," that struck the right chords with the Spudstock audience. It will be difficult for Quiet Riot's new work to silence some of the frenzy surrounding today's hard-hitters, such as Pearl Jam and Soundgarden.
Faced with the job of carrying the Spudstock concert between Quiet Riot's near-deafening show and Eddie Money's rockin' performance, The Guess Who's often mellow tunes wound up sounding a little like elevator music. Although the group's harmonies and often boyish stage antics were entertaining throughout the set, it seemed that many in the crowd were eager to hear The Guess Who's popular 1970s hit, "American Woman," which the quintet performed near the end of the show.
Most of the other rock 'n' roll acts drew sparse crowds to the stage-front area at Spudstock, but the event did give these lesser-known local bands, such as the high-energy, Portland-based Twisted Roots, the opportunity to increase their followings.
On Sunday, the final day of Spudstock, it was country roads that took the concert-goers home, and it was country music that set them on their way. Country acts Silver & Lace, Doug Kershaw and John Anderson added a little twang to the festivities.
Anderson, who was the biggest name in the 20 acts that appeared at Spudstock, belted out hits from his 1993 gold album, "Solid Ground," and his 1992 platinum work, "Seminole Wind," in front of the dwindling number of ticket-holders at the site on Sunday afternoon.
The singer performed with few fireworks and gave a straightforward delivery of his hits. After singing such songs as the jukebox favorite, "Swingin"' and the ballad "I Wish I Could Have Been There," Anderson said goodbye from beneath his black, 10-gallon hat to his laid-back and appreciative audience.
Illustration Caption: Steve Mesropian of Tongue Lash performs Saturday at Spudstock. (NEWS Photo by Michele Stapleton)

____________________________________________________________

Spudstock setup is under way

Author: Gloria Flannery Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]13 July 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413774942?accountid=10457

Abstract: A total of 32 hours of rock music played by 20 groups will reverberate from a hillside amphitheater at the Spudstock festival here July 21-23. "We are pretty psyched," said Jay McKenney of Fort Fairfield, the group's spokesman. McKenney, 31, and an elementary school teacher, plays the drums and sings. His brother, Matt McKenney, 32, plays the guitar, sings, and with the exception of one set of lyrics written by Jay, wrote all the music and words in the four or five songs described as "quite heavy rock." Ben Findlen, 18, a high school senior in Fort Fairfield plays bass guitar. John McNally, 27, of Westfield, plays rhythm guitar. "We want to salute Fort Fairfield," Bob Johnston, president of Spudstock Entertainment Inc., explained in his choice of the show opener. Johnston and his partner, Jim Ossie, are both Fort Fairfield natives who say the festival was planned as an economic boost to the town. They expect 30,000 people to show up.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Spudstock+setup+is+under+way&amp;author=Gloria+Flannery+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-07-13&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: FORT FAIRFIELD -- A total of 32 hours of rock music played by 20 groups will reverberate from a hillside amphitheater at the Spudstock festival here July 21-23.
A local group, Headcleaner, was chosen to open the festival at 4 p.m. on Friday.
"We are pretty psyched," said Jay McKenney of Fort Fairfield, the group's spokesman. McKenney, 31, and an elementary school teacher, plays the drums and sings. His brother, Matt McKenney, 32, plays the guitar, sings, and with the exception of one set of lyrics written by Jay, wrote all the music and words in the four or five songs described as "quite heavy rock." Ben Findlen, 18, a high school senior in Fort Fairfield plays bass guitar. John McNally, 27, of Westfield, plays rhythm guitar.
"If anything is going to go wrong with the sound, it will happen in the opening act," said Jay McKenney, delighted to lead the bands through the event being billed as the largest outdoor music festival in the history of the state.
"We want to salute Fort Fairfield," Bob Johnston, president of Spudstock Entertainment Inc., explained in his choice of the show opener. Johnston and his partner, Jim Ossie, are both Fort Fairfield natives who say the festival was planned as an economic boost to the town. They expect 30,000 people to show up.
Other acts signing on in the last few days are Doug Kershaw, a Cajun fiddler; Tongue Lash, an alternative rock group; and Dakota, composed of musicians from northern Maine and Canada.
Following Headcleaner in the Friday lineup will be Devonsquare, Bill Chinnook and the East Coast Horns, Rick Derringer, The Outlaws and Blue Oyster Cult, ending at 2 a.m. Saturday.
Rustic Overtones will start Saturday's 16-hour concert at 10 a.m. followed by Broken Men, Boneheads, Signs of Life, Skate the Razor, Tongue Lash, Twisted Roots, Quiet Riot, Guess Who and Eddie Money, ending at 2 a.m. Sunday.
Silver and Lace will open Sunday's performances at 10 a.m. Dakota, Doug Kershaw, and then John Anderson will wind up the festival at 4 p.m.
Johnston said contract riders on a majority of the national acts prohibit any type of camera or recording devices in the concert area.
While declining to release the number of tickets sold to date, Johnston said sales were "brisk" and reflected a "pent-up demand" for such an event.
"We're ready to make the Spudstock concert experience one of total joy ... great music, plenty of good food and beverages, wide-open spaces, that great Aroostook sky," Johnston said. "Everything people will need for a hassle-free good time is awaiting them."
The festival area on the 103-acre farm located 3.5 miles from town on the Center Limestone Road has been expanded with 27 adjacent acres for additional parking.
On Wednesday, the Spudstock sign was in place, a row of portable toilets had been brought in, utility workers from Maine Public Service were on site, fencing was going up, a tractor was pulling equipment over the grounds and some of the 27 committed vendors were choosing spots to set up business.
Fort Fairfield Police Chief Neil Saucier, who is coordinating security around a one-mile perimeter of the concert area, said 24 officers were assigned each day to cover the 72-hour period from Friday through Sunday. Some will be patrolling with all-terrain vehicles.
Johnston said the Portland-based security firm hired to work inside the concert area will bring about 50 people to town. He is advertising for volunteers to form a "peace patrol" and help with other aspects of the festival.
Metal detectors and "pat-down" searches will be utilized to keep out weapons and unauthorized alcohol. Two beer gardens will be set up inside the gate with doubled fencing to prevent passing beverages to the crowd.
Wrist bands given to patrons at the gate will permit concert access throughout the weekend.

WoodenBoat Show to open Friday in Southwest Harbor Officials hope for repeat of 1994 event that drew 10,000 people

Author: Harbour, Kathy

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]12 July 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413872903?accountid=10457

Abstract: Polished teak and mahogany-finished runabouts, a Bolger triple-keeled sloop, sleekly elegant yachts, and tireless workhorses of the sea will be moored together for three days this month at the 1995 WoodenBoat Show in Southwest Harbor. The WoodenBoat Show is sponsored by WoodenBoat Publications of Brooklin, the publisher of WoodenBoat Magazine. Before the 1994 show in Southwest Harbor, the company had staged the event for two years in Newport, R.I. The homegrown Maine business brought the event home to local waters for its 20th birthday celebration last year. Its whopping success on MDI -- drawing 30 percent more attendees than the 1993 event in Newport -- prompted show organizers to return for another year to Southwest Harbor. According to Valerie LaFrance, show manager, WoodenBoat intends to take the show on the road in 1996 to another region.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=WoodenBoat+Show+to+open+Friday+in+Southwest+Harbor+Officials+hope+for+repeat+of+1994+event+that+drew+10%2C000+people&amp;author=Harbour%2C+Kathy&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-07-12&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: SOUTHWEST HARBOR -- Polished teak and mahogany-finished runabouts, a Bolger triple-keeled sloop, sleekly elegant yachts, and tireless workhorses of the sea will be moored together for three days this month at the 1995 WoodenBoat Show in Southwest Harbor.
The Mount Desert Island community is playing host for the second consecutive year to an event that was a huge success last July, when more than 10,000 people streamed into the Hinckley Great Harbor Marina. About 3,000 people attended the 1994 show during the first four hours.
This year the show is two weeks earlier and will run from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Friday through Sunday, July 14, 15 and 16. As last year, parking is available at the Hinckley Co. lots in Manset, with frequent shuttle buses running to and from the marina.
The WoodenBoat Show is sponsored by WoodenBoat Publications of Brooklin, the publisher of WoodenBoat Magazine. Before the 1994 show in Southwest Harbor, the company had staged the event for two years in Newport, R.I. The homegrown Maine business brought the event home to local waters for its 20th birthday celebration last year.
Its whopping success on MDI -- drawing 30 percent more attendees than the 1993 event in Newport -- prompted show organizers to return for another year to Southwest Harbor. According to Valerie LaFrance, show manager, WoodenBoat intends to take the show on the road in 1996 to another region.
More than 130 wooden boats are promised for this year's event, as well as 75 of what show organizers call the "finest wooden boat builders, designers, and repair experts" in the business.
Kayaks, skin boats, row boats and canoes will line up on one finger of the dock where builders of 12- to 30-foot crafts will be featured. Boats in the 35- to 50-foot category, moored at another finger, will include such exhibitors as Benjamin River, Walsteds Yard of Denmark, Billings Diesel, Sam Devlin from Washington state, and International Classic Yachts.
Several historic vessels will moor at the C dock -- the 1926 Herreshoff Aida, the Shew & Burnham-built power cruiser Chewink, the Bahama schooner Anne, the Joel White trawler yacht Maine Idea, the 1961 ketch Sojourner Truth, the famous Arctic schooner Bowdoin from Maine Maritime Academy, and others.
Boats along the main dock -- the D dock -- will include the Bequia dinghy Snake, a flotilla of Dick Pulsifer's Hamptons, a Chesapeake Bay oyster buy boat, the "Elderyacht," which is specifically designed for older sailors, the William Hand motorsailer Sixpence, and the Balmy Days which will offer short charters during the show.
Alongside the B dock will be moored Yorel, the 83-foot Eldredge-McInnis motoryacht built by Hodgon Bros., the 1950 motorsailer Burma and the 1930 8- meter Angelita representing Rumery's Boat Yard.
A popular boat last year, the 63-foot Alden schooner When and If will return for the 1995 show. The boat was built in 1939 for Gen. George Patton. Rockport Marine will show its winter project Arawak, a 1931 Starling Burgess design, along with two other sailboats and a powerboat.
Brooklin Boat Yard will bring Sweet Olive, a 1991 Joel White design; High Cotton, a recently built Herreshoff Buzzards Bay 25; and the 1913 P Class sloop Olympian.
The 1925 Alden schooner Heart's Desire will offer short boat trips during the show.
Abundant exhibits are offered at the event, from historic exhibits to boats for sale. Smaller tents hold the exhibits of hardware, wood coatings and cleaners and chandlery supplies. Booths will include exhibits of spars, tools, sails, fasteners, models, books, ropework and more.
Tickets at the gate will be $7.50 per person and free for children under 12. Once inside the gate, attendees will be handed a guide to the event and a ballot to vote for their favorite boat in the show. Show organizers ask that all pets be left at home.

WoodenBoat Show to open Friday in Southwest Harbor Officials hope for repeat of 1994 event that drew 10,000 people

Author: Kathy Harbour Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]12 July 1995: 1. [Duplicate]

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413813120?accountid=10457

Abstract: Polished teak and mahogany-finished runabouts, a Bolger triple-keeled sloop, sleekly elegant yachts, and tireless workhorses of the sea will be moored together for three days this month at the 1995 WoodenBoat Show in Southwest Harbor. The WoodenBoat Show is sponsored by WoodenBoat Publications of Brooklin, the publisher of WoodenBoat Magazine. The homegrown Maine business brought the event home to local waters for its 20th birthday celebration last year. According to Valerie LaFrance, show manager, WoodenBoat intends to take the show on the road in 1996 to another region.

Full text: SOUTHWEST HARBOR -- Polished teak and mahogany-finished runabouts, a Bolger triple-keeled sloop, sleekly elegant yachts, and tireless workhorses of the sea will be moored together for three days this month at the 1995 WoodenBoat Show in Southwest Harbor.
The Mount Desert Island community is playing host for the second consecutive year to an event that was a huge success last July, when more than 10,000 people streamed into the Hinckley Great Harbor Marina. About 3,000 people attended the 1994 show during the first four hours.
This year the show is two weeks earlier and will run from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Friday through Sunday, July 14, 15 and 16. As last year, parking is available at the Hinckley Co. lots in Manset, with frequent shuttle buses running to and from the marina.
The WoodenBoat Show is sponsored by WoodenBoat Publications of Brooklin, the publisher of WoodenBoat Magazine. Before the 1994 show in Southwest Harbor, the company had staged the event for two years in Newport, R.I. The homegrown Maine business brought the event home to local waters for its 20th birthday celebration last year.
Its whopping success on MDI -- drawing 30 percent more attendees than the 1993 event in Newport -- prompted show organizers to return for another year to Southwest Harbor. According to Valerie LaFrance, show manager, WoodenBoat intends to take the show on the road in 1996 to another region.
More than 130 wooden boats are promised for this year's event, as well as 75 of what show organizers call the "finest wooden boat builders, designers, and repair experts" in the business.
Kayaks, skin boats, row boats and canoes will line up on one finger of the dock where builders of 12- to 30-foot crafts will be featured. Boats in the 35- to 50-foot category, moored at another finger, will include such exhibitors as Benjamin River, Walsteds Yard of Denmark, Billings Diesel, Sam Devlin from Washington state, and International Classic Yachts.
Several historic vessels will moor at the C dock -- the 1926 Herreshoff Aida, the Shew & Burnham-built power cruiser Chewink, the Bahama schooner Anne, the Joel White trawler yacht Maine Idea, the 1961 ketch Sojourner Truth, the famous Arctic schooner Bowdoin from Maine Maritime Academy, and others.
Boats along the main dock -- the D dock -- will include the Bequia dinghy Snake, a flotilla of Dick Pulsifer's Hamptons, a Chesapeake Bay oyster buy boat, the "Elderyacht," which is specifically designed for older sailors, the William Hand motorsailer Sixpence, and the Balmy Days which will offer short charters during the show.
Alongside the B dock will be moored Yorel, the 83-foot Eldredge-McInnis motoryacht built by Hodgon Bros., the 1950 motorsailer Burma and the 1930 8-meter Angelita representing Rumery's Boat Yard.
A popular boat last year, the 63-foot Alden schooner When and If will return for the 1995 show. The boat was built in 1939 for Gen. George Patton. Rockport Marine will show its winter project Arawak, a 1931 Starling Burgess design, along with two other sailboats and a powerboat.
Brooklin Boat Yard will bring Sweet Olive, a 1991 Joel White design; High Cotton, a recently built Herreshoff Buzzards Bay 25; and the 1913 P Class sloop Olympian.
The 1925 Alden schooner Heart's Desire will offer short boat trips during the show.
Abundant exhibits are offered at the event, from historic exhibits to boats for sale. Smaller tents hold the exhibits of hardware, wood coatings and cleaners and chandlery supplies. Booths will include exhibits of spars, tools, sails, fasteners, models, books, ropework and more.
Tickets at the gate will be $7.50 per person and free for children under 12. Once inside the gate, attendees will be handed a guide to the event and a ballot to vote for their favorite boat in the show. Show organizers ask that all pets be left at home.
Illustration Caption: Fancy wooden boats were the talk of the town in Southwest Harbor during the 1994 WoodenBoat Show. The program will be repeated July 14-16 and is sponsored by WoodenBoat Publications of Brooklin. (NEWS File Photo)

These Maine farms open their doors on 6th annual Open Farm Day

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]06 July 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413861333?accountid=10457

Abstract: PUDDLEDOCK FARM -- Margaret and Joseph Chernosky and Andrews & Luke. Puddledock Road, East Corinth. Sheep and beef farm. Puddledock Farm has an antique homestead, intensive rotational grazing of 21 ewes with lambs and nine shorthorn beef animals. It was chosen 1993 Outstanding Conservation Farm by Penobscot County Soil and Water Conservation District. There is an organic home garden, passive solar greenhouse. You can see manure pit, a gorgeous farm pond with trout, and a forest management program and an electric fencing system with 16 paddocks. The Chernoskys will explain all aspects of farm operations and conservation efforts. Open Farm Day Hours: Noon-5 p.m. Directions: from Rt. 15 in Corinth, take Rt. 43 east 3.5 miles, turn left onto Puddledock Rd., (by Tate's Strawberry Farm), first farm on the left. THOMAS FARMS OF GARLAND, INC. -- Jim, Sandra, Mary, Kevin & Terry Thomas and Alyce Thomas Masters. Center Road, Garland. Dairy farm. This family-run dairy farm has 200 milking cows. There will be tours of the barns ranging from calf barn to milking parlor and explanations of manure management, crop rotation, milking and feeding. Open Farm Day Hours: 11:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m. Directions: From Bangor, take Rt. 15 through East Corinth, take the left turn at the 4-corners past the DOT garage. Farm will be on the right about 3.5 miles in from Rt. 15. From Dexter take Rt. 94 to the Garland Store. Go north for 1 mile, then make a right turn. The farm will be approximately 1 1/2 miles on the left. DESEO FARM -- Henry, Catherine and Jan Hartwell with Judy & John Biggar and family. Route 222, Stetson. Horse and tree farm. This 5th generation farm boards and breeds horses plus gives riding lessons. Deseo Farm is a tree farm with their own sawmill, too. There are 160 acres bordering on Pleasant Lake. There are 29 head of horses, some are Buckskin Quarter Horses and Paints belonging to the family and the rest are boarders. There will be a tour of barns, a demonstration in Centered Riding teaching techniques handling young foals, an overview of the handicapped riding program. Sawing and woodsplitting demonstrations and tours of the woodlots will be given. In the morning there will be horse drawn wagon tours of woodlots featuring a 200 year old pine stand. There will be rides in the afternoon to lakeside recreation area (wilderness style). Open Farm Day Hours: 10:00 a.m -3:00 p.m. Directions: West on Rt. 222 from Union St. in Bangor approximately 17 miles. Farm is on both sides of highway. From I95 Etna/Dixmont Exit - take Rt. 143 North to Stetson (approximately 7 miles) right onto Rt. 222 go about 2 miles. SMITH FARM -- Judy and Larry Smith. 2377 Ohio Street, Bangor. Dairy farm. Smith Dairy Farm has 90 Holstein milkers and dry cows with an additional 70 heifers. The Farm was presented The Penobscot County Soil & Water Conservation District's Outstanding Conservation Farm Award for 1994. There will be a tour of farmstead facilities from 1 to 6 p.m. with an opportunity to view afternoon milking from 3:30 to 6:00 p.m. Open Farm Day Hours: 1:00 p.m.-6:00 p.m. Directions: From Bangor go out Ohio St. From I 95 go 4.5 miles, mailbox reads # AROOSTOOK

Full text: Last year on Open Farm Day, over 100 farms opened their doors to welcome more than 15,000 visitors! Who said that Maine is not an agriculturally-based state? In its sixth year, the project, through its participating farms, promises to increase awareness about how the goods that consumers use are actually produced.
The following listing can be your guide to Open Farm Day, 1995:
PENOBSCOT
PUDDLEDOCK FARM -- Margaret and Joseph Chernosky and Andrews & Luke. Puddledock Road, East Corinth. Sheep and beef farm. Puddledock Farm has an antique homestead, intensive rotational grazing of 21 ewes with lambs and nine shorthorn beef animals. It was chosen 1993 Outstanding Conservation Farm by Penobscot County Soil and Water Conservation District. There is an organic home garden, passive solar greenhouse. You can see manure pit, a gorgeous farm pond with trout, and a forest management program and an electric fencing system with 16 paddocks. The Chernoskys will explain all aspects of farm operations and conservation efforts. Open Farm Day Hours: Noon-5 p.m. Directions: from Rt. 15 in Corinth, take Rt. 43 east 3.5 miles, turn left onto Puddledock Rd., (by Tate's Strawberry Farm), first farm on the left.
THOMAS FARMS OF GARLAND, INC. -- Jim, Sandra, Mary, Kevin & Terry Thomas and Alyce Thomas Masters. Center Road, Garland. Dairy farm. This family-run dairy farm has 200 milking cows. There will be tours of the barns ranging from calf barn to milking parlor and explanations of manure management, crop rotation, milking and feeding. Open Farm Day Hours: 11:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m. Directions: From Bangor, take Rt. 15 through East Corinth, take the left turn at the 4-corners past the DOT garage. Farm will be on the right about 3.5 miles in from Rt. 15. From Dexter take Rt. 94 to the Garland Store. Go north for 1 mile, then make a right turn. The farm will be approximately 1 1/2 miles on the left.
STONYVALE, INC. -- John, Robert, Richard and Thomas Fogler, & Fred Goff with Brad Underhill. Fogler Road, Exeter. Dairy farm. This farm consists of 250 milking cows, 250 young stock and 600 acres. Milking is from 11:30 - 2:30, farm tours are offered and someone will be on hand to answer questions. Open Farm Day Hours: 10:00 a.m. - 3:00 p.m. Directions: Fogler Rd., Exeter.
MARSHWOOD FARM -- Anne & Kent Price. Route 222, Stetson. Dairy goat, sheep, pig, and chicken farm. There are 22 acres on this farm with vegetable and flower gardens. The house was built in 1865 and was restored in the 1970s. The care of dairy goats, milking and handling will be explained on Open Farm Day. Children may pet and play with goat kids. Open Farm Day Hours: 1:00 p.m. - 4:00 p.m. Directions: 4 miles west from West Levant (where 222 turns toward Stetson), 3 miles east of Stetson Village (crossroad of Rt. 222 & 143). Large green house with cream trim.
ASH HILL VIEW DEER FARM -- Gladys and Kenneth Swett, Shanna & Nathan. Swett Road, Carmel. Deer farm. The Swetts raise Red Deer and have 23 at the moment with 12 more yet to be born. There will be farm tours of handling facility and pastures. The Swetts will explain how deer are handled and raised and be glad to answer any questions. They are a member of North American Deer Farmers Association. Open Farm Day Hours: 10:00 a.m. - 3:00 p.m. Directions: Starting from the junction of Rt. 2 and Rt. 69, take Rt. 69 west approximately 1/2 mile. Turn left onto the Cook Rd. for approxiamtely 3 miles, at the first four corners take a left onto the Swett Road. Go 1/2 mile to the end of the road.
TRUE FARMS, INC. -- Gordon, Frank, Helen and Susan True. East Ridge Road, Charleston. Vegetable farm and greenhouses. This 300-acre farm features six greenhouses (one portable) and 80 acres used in growing a wide range of vegetables. On Open Farm Day the True Farms crew will demonstrate weed control and water management using black plastic mulch. On display will be specialized machinery used in laying, lifting and planting through black plastic mulch. Refreshments will be served. Open Farm Day Hours: 10:00 a.m. - 3:00 p.m. Directions: Rt. 15 to East Corinth, turn onto 43E towards Bradford/Hudson. Turn left onto E. Ridge Rd. Farm is approximately 2 miles on left. Sign in front.
HICKS DAIRY FARM -- Terry Hicks. Bean's Mill Road, E. Corinth. Dairy farm. This farm has 75 milking cows with stenchion barn. There will be tours of the farm. Open Farm Day Hours: 10:00 a.m. - 3:00 p.m. Directions: From Rt. 15 in E. Corinth turn onto Rt. 43 to Exeter, first 4 corners take left and go 3/4 of a mile.
UDDER CONFUSION DAIRY -- Sally, Darel, Douglas and Kim Smith. Route 11, North Bradford. Dairy and hog farm with small greenhouse. They have a 31 cow tie-up with Jerseys and run 9 to 12 sows selling feeder pigs and freezer pork and there is a small greenhouse and market garden. There will be farm tours and new litters of pigs can be viewed. Milking time is 5:30 for anyone interested in this operation. Open Farm Day Hours: 10:00 a.m.-6:00 p.m. Directions: Pick up 11 on 11A in Corinth, Charlston or Bradford Corner. Head north toward Milo, the Smiths are 2nd working dairy farm on the left after 11A joins 11, about 1 mile.
HILLACRE FARMS -- Carl R., Linda, Carl D. and Maryanne Smith. Route 222, Newport. Potato farm. This is a fourth-generation family farm. They grow mostly potatoes for the potato chip industry. They use a rotation crop of corn grain and rye. There are approximately 1,000 crop acres. You will have a tour of the warehousing facility for winter storage of potatoes and there will be equipment used in the production of potatoes for veiwing. Open Farm Day Hours: 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Directions: 3 miles east on Rt. 222 from Corinna Village on the left side of road. It is a set of white buildings with green trim.
DESEO FARM -- Henry, Catherine and Jan Hartwell with Judy & John Biggar and family. Route 222, Stetson. Horse and tree farm. This 5th generation farm boards and breeds horses plus gives riding lessons. Deseo Farm is a tree farm with their own sawmill, too. There are 160 acres bordering on Pleasant Lake. There are 29 head of horses, some are Buckskin Quarter Horses and Paints belonging to the family and the rest are boarders. There will be a tour of barns, a demonstration in Centered Riding teaching techniques handling young foals, an overview of the handicapped riding program. Sawing and woodsplitting demonstrations and tours of the woodlots will be given. In the morning there will be horse drawn wagon tours of woodlots featuring a 200 year old pine stand. There will be rides in the afternoon to lakeside recreation area (wilderness style). Open Farm Day Hours: 10:00 a.m -3:00 p.m. Directions: West on Rt. 222 from Union St. in Bangor approximately 17 miles. Farm is on both sides of highway. From I95 Etna/Dixmont Exit - take Rt. 143 North to Stetson (approximately 7 miles) right onto Rt. 222 go about 2 miles. SMITH FARM -- Judy and Larry Smith. 2377 Ohio Street, Bangor. Dairy farm. Smith Dairy Farm has 90 Holstein milkers and dry cows with an additional 70 heifers. The Farm was presented The Penobscot County Soil & Water Conservation District's Outstanding Conservation Farm Award for 1994. There will be a tour of farmstead facilities from 1 to 6 p.m. with an opportunity to view afternoon milking from 3:30 to 6:00 p.m. Open Farm Day Hours: 1:00 p.m.-6:00 p.m. Directions: From Bangor go out Ohio St. From I 95 go 4.5 miles, mailbox reads # AROOSTOOK
SHAKAREE RED DEER FARM -- Gary Dwyer, Mark Drew Farm Manager. French Road, New Limerick. Red deer farm. Shakaree has the largest herd of red deer in the Eastern U. S., with 650 deer on 200+ acres. A tour and demonstration of the handling facilities will be given on the hour. Viewing of the deer and explanation of the velvet, venison production, and breeding stock will be given by Mark Drew from 10 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. There will be land use comparison, venison nutrient comparison, carcass breakdown and fencing techniques explanations, as well as, a discussion of the stages and reasons for velveting. On July 9th there will be 100 plus deer still in velvet - great opportunity to see some beautiful antlers. Open Farm Day Hours: 10:00 a.m.-3:00 p.m. Directions: Coming from South take exit 61 off I-95, head east on Rt. 2 for 5.5 miles. Take a left at Tylers Store, drive 1 mile, farm is on your left. From North, take Rt. 2 out of Houlton drive 5 miles and take a right at Tylers Store.
RED BRIDGE FARM -- Gail & Stanley Maynard. River Road, Oakfield. Beef cattle farm. The Maynards have registered Scotch Highland Beef Cattle. You will get information on beef production especially Highland Cattle Production. Stop by and see this year's new calves. Open Farm Day Hours: 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Directions: Red Bridge Farm is 4.5 miles from exit I-95. Take exit 60 to Oakfield Village. At 0.6 mi. Oakfield Hardware on right - straight to Rt. 2. At 1 mile cross over R.R. tracks. At 1.8 miles turn left on River Rd. (farm sign posted). At 4.5 mi. straight into driveway.
WOOD PRAIRIE FARM -- Jim & Megan Gerritsen with sons Peter and Caleb. End of West Road, Bridgewater. Diversified certified organic seed potato farm. This farm is focused on the production of MOFGA - Certified Organic seed and tablestock potatoes, vegetables, milling grain, hay and livestock (sheep, draft horses, chickens and milk cow). There will be a walking tour of MOFGA - Certified Organic crops and an explanation of organic crop and livestock systems. Open Farm Day Hours: 1 p.m.-5 p.m. Directions: From Rt. 1 in Bridgewater take West Rd. (by Bridgewater Grammer School) to its end (3 miles). At T intersection turn left. Go 1/3 mile, farm is on the right.
PIRTC EDUCATIONAL FARM -- Maine School Administrative District #1. Ray E. Chelewski, Debbra Martin and Elizabeth M. Morgan. Fleetwood Extension, Presque Isle. Diversified fruit and vegetable farm. This 38 acre farm is wholly owned by an educational system and staffed by high school students. The farm has been in operation for 5 years. Major crops include a 5 acre apple orchard, 5 acres of strawberries, raspberries, and a wide variety of vegetable crops. The products are marketed through an on-site store, which is located in the program's greenhouse. Students employed by the farm will offer tours of both the greenhouse and the other sectors of the farm. On Open Farm Day there will be fresh strawberries for sale in the greenhouse store. Open Farm Day Hours: 12 noon -5 p.m. Directions: From Main St., Presque Isle, turn east on either Academy or State St. The farm is about 9 blocks up the road. From Academy St. it is on the left side. Turn left at Fleetwood Extension and go halfway up the street, you will see the store on the right. From State St. the farm is on the right. Take a right on Fleetwood, go halfway down the street and turn left towards the greenhouse.
HANCOCK
HORSEPOWER FARM -- Mollie and Paul Birdsall and apprentices. Horsepower Farm Road, North Penobscot. Diversified mixed vegetable and livestock farm. Horse Power Farm has sheep, chickens and pigs and is a certified organic commercial market garden. They use five Belgian draft horses for preparing seed beds, planting, cultivating, harvesting, haying and winter logging. They have 60 acres open, 15 acres tilled. Storage carrots, potatoes, dry beans, blueberries all grown organically and sold locally. There will be a spinning demonstration, draft horses at work, wagon rides, tour, lambs, piglets and chickens. Dry beans, frozen lamb, some market vegetables, white & colored fleeces, lambskins, handspun yarn for sale. Open Farm Day Hours: 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Directions: Rt. 15 - look for farm sign halfway between Rt. 1 and Blue Hill, proceed west 1/2 mile on Town Rd. to farm.
HAPPYTOWN FARM -- Karen and Paul Volckhausen. Happytown Road, North Orland. Organic vegetable farm. Happytown Farm has 5 acres of organic vegetables, pasture, small grains, sheep, chickens and maple syrup making. There will be farm tours highlighting organic methods including green manures, covercropping and composting. Open Farm Day Hours: 9 a.m.-4 p.m. Directions: From Ellsworth, take Rt. 1 towards Bucksport, 6 miles. Turn right on Happytown Rd. go 5 miles. Happytown Farm is on left. From Bangor, take Rt. 1A to East Holden, turn right onto Upper Dedham Rd. Follow Upper Dedham Road a couple miles until it forks; bear left at the fork. Continue past Bald Mountain, where road takes a sharp 90 degree turn. Go about 2 more miles from Bald Mountain. Happytown Road is a dirt road on the left. Follow Happytown Road 2 1/2 miles, farm is on the right.
DARTHIA FARM -- Cynthia and William Thayer with Sheila Unvala their daughter-in-law and 3 apprentices. West Bay Road, Gouldsboro. Diversified organic farm. Darthia Farm has 33 acres of mixed organic vegetables, small fruits, cheese & yogurt, jams, herb vinegars, and pesto. Also Scotch Highland Beef, turkeys, lamb, horse power with Haflinger horses, sheep and Border Collies. There is a spinning and weaving shop, hay rides, and mail order and farm stand. On Open Farm Day there will be milking demonstrations, garden tour, compost making, tour of animals and soil blocking in greenhouse. There may be horse drawn wagon rides and if there is any interest they will go into depth on any of the above. Open Farm Day Hours: 9 a.m.- 4 p.m. Directions: Located on Rt. 186 on the east side of Schoodic Peninsula, 1.7 miles from Rt. 1, 3 miles from Prospect Harbor. There are highway signs on Rt. 1.
RAVEN HILL FARM -- Betty and Ed Bradford. Old Route 1, Fire Road 140, Gouldsboro. Small diversified homestead-type farm. Raven Hill Farm has Alpine dairy goats, chickens, ducks, pigs and three vegetable gardens. There is a gift shop that sells goat cheese, goat leather products, goat milk soaps and shampoos & fresh vegetables. At 9 a.m. there will be a goat milking demonstration, 12:00 noon hoof trimming demo, 2:00 p.m. livestock guard dog discussion. There is going to be general farm tours, samples of goat cheese and printed material on raising goats. Open Farm Day Hours: 9 a.m.-5 p.m. Directions: From Ellsworth, take Rt. 1 towards Stueben. At the 2nd intersection of Rt. 1 and 186 go left on Fire Road 140 (old Rt. 1) (Follow signs to Alpine Shop) Go 2/10 mile, farm is across from the Gouldsboro Methodist Church.
ISLAND ACRES FARM -- Carl and Priscilla Woodward and Nina Kennedy. Route 15-A, Stonington. Shiitake mushrooms and free-range poultry farm. Farm Island Acres Farm features a small poultry processing plant and outdoor mushroom production, also a commercial compost pad. Tours of the slaughterhouse, outdoor poultry pens and mushroom yards will be offered and demonstrations of poultry processing equipment. You will learn mushroom techniques and tour the compost yard. Open Farm Day Hours: 10 a.m.-4 p.m. Directions: From Blue Hill, take Rt. 15 to Deer Isle Village, take right to 15A to West Stonington and go 4 miles. Farm is 2nd one on left after Stonington town line.
KENONA FARM -- Ken and Nona Silsby and Judy Manzo. Rt. 179, Osborn. Nubian goats. The Silsbys raise Nubian goats for show and pleasure. They have a milking herd of 8 to 10 animals, plus many kids for sale as foundation stock and pets. There will be an educational display of dairy goat products, soft cheese making demonstration, the dos and don'ts of good herdsmanship and hands on milking. There will be trimming and clipping demonstrations, petting pen for the kids to meet kids. At 11 am and 2 pm there will be hands on milking. There will be cheese and fudge making through the day and goat items for sale. Open Farm Day Hours: 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Directions: From Rt. 9, Aurora, take Rt. 179, 4 miles south. The farm is on the right. From Ellsworth, at the Ellsworth Falls Exxon, take Rt. 179 north about 20 miles. The farm is on the left.
KNOX LLAMALOT -- Elizabeth, Michael and Melissa Rowe. West Senebec Road, Union. Llama and donkey farm. Besides llamas and donkeys there will be a goat and a Vietnamese potbelly pig to see on the Rowe farm. There will be hands-on experience with the llamas including grooming, feeding, and general care. Get your picture taken with a llama. Open Farm Day Hours: 10 a.m.- 6 p.m. Directions: From Rockland (Camden Rt. 90 to Rt. 17 north) to Union, right on 131 north. 1/2 mile (across from white house with white picket fence drive up between 2 apple trees). From Augusta area, Rt. 17 to Union left on Rt. 131 north (see above). From Belfast, Rt. 3 towards Augusta left on Rt. 131 south. Approximately 15 miles (past Athern Vending). Farm is 2nd drive on right between 2 apple trees. From Rt. 1 in Waldoboro, Rt. 1 north to Rt. 235 north, left 12 miles to Union Common, left to Rt. 17 (1/2 mile) immediate right on Rt. 131 (see above).
AGRICOLA FARM -- Mark Hedrich. Route 17, Union. Diversified farm and a country store. This 117-acre farm uses an intensive pasture management system that includes rotational grazing. You will see Scotch Highland cattle from Brae Maple Farm, sheep/lambs Angora goats, and miniature donkeys. There will be wool spinning and weaving demonstrations as well as fresh flower arranging demonstrations at 11:00 a.m.and 1:30 p.m. Open Farm Day Hours: 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Directions: Corner of Rt. 17 and Clarry Hill Rd. 1 mile west of Union Village on Rt. 17.
SPRUCE MOUNTAIN BLUEBERRIES -- Molly Sholes, Kathy Bragg and Paulette Martin. Mount Pleasant Street, West Rockport. Blueberry farm. You will learn how wild blueberries are grown, the importance of intergrated crop management, weed control for fresh pack berries and some of the pitfalls. You can watch chutney being made; see the winnowing and pickover operation if the berries are ripe; otherwise see machinery. Open Farm Day Hours: 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Directions: After Rts. 17 & 90 traffic light, turn north on 17; go one block, turn left onto Mt. Pleasant St. Bear right, road goes up and turns to dirt. Two miles from traffic light road makes right angle turn to right, farm is yellow cape in turn.
CAPERCAILLIE DAIRY GOAT FARM/APPLETON CREAMERY -- Caitlin and Brad Hunter and Fiona. Gurneytown Road, Appleton. Dairy goat farm and creamery. This small-scale family farm milks ten to twelve registered goats and has a newly licensed goat dairy. They make cheese and yogurt with the milk and raise meat chickens and turkeys on the extra milk and whey left from the cheesemaking process. There is also a large organic garden. You will be able to sample goat milk and cheese and get basic information about dairy goat management and cheesemaking. There will be tours of the cheese dairy and watch milking demonstrations. The children will enjoy seeing the baby goats and exotic chickens. Open Farm Day Hours: 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Directions: From Rt. 17 in Union, turn at Eastside Restaurant onto East Sennebec Rd. for approximately 3 miles. Turn right onto Gurneytown Rd. and go 1 1/2 miles. Farm is grey shingled house and garage on left, look for farm sign.
PISCATQUIS
TRIPPING SHEEP ACRES -- H.G. & W.G. Sinclair. Pleasant Street, Brownville. Sheep, working tree farm and vegetables farm. The Sinclairs have 100 head of purebred Oxford and Targhee and natural colored and commercial crossbreed sheep. There will be wool spinning, blocking and some shearing, and hoof trimming demonstrations. There will be tours of the barn and the kids can play with the lambs. Vegetable stand will be open. Open Farm Day Hours: 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Directions: From Park St., Milo and Brownville Village, turn right at Mobil Station cross over bridge turn right on Pleasant St. Go 1 1/4 mile the farm is just beyond the end of paved road.
PONDVIEW LLAMAS -- Richard LeDuc, Katie Parker, Tagg and Levi LeDuc. John Dean Road, Milo. Llamas. There are 22 llamas on this 80 acre farm with 60 acres of fields. Information about Llamas and their health, breeding and feeding. Demonstrations of haltering, brushing and leading the llamas. Open Farm Day Hours: 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Directions: Coming from south on I-95, take exit 53 and go 21 miles north on Rt. 16. Coming from north on I-95, take Rt. 155 west to Rt. 16. Go 7 miles north on Rt. 16. Between Milo and LaGrange, at the junction of Rt. 16 and Rt. 11, take the DIRT road west over the railroad tracks. Farm is 1/4 mile, the first house on the right.
SOMERSET
GOOD WILL FARM -- Good Will Home Association, Arthur C. Thompson Jr., manager, M. Farmer, & A. Thompson Sr. Greene Road, Hinckley. Dairy farm. The Good Will Farm is a 50-milking cow dairy herd with 90 total head of cattle. You will learn about rotational grazing, raising dairy beef and their Water Quality Project. There will be a Good Will Hinckley Display. Tours of the farm operation will be given. Milking takes place at 3 p.m. HANDICAP ACCESSIBLE. Open Farm Day Hours: 9 a.m.-4:30 p.m. Directions: From Rt. 201, take Greene Rd. At the Field House turn right and follow the gravel road.
NORTH STAR ORCHARDS -- Judith and Everett Dimock, with Jennifer and Robert. Orchard Road, Madison. Orchard. Activities will include wagon ride through orchard, tour of storage and packing facilities, cider mill and retail store. Demonstrations of horticultural procedures, equipment or product depending on weather. Open Farm Day Hours: 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Directions: Following Rt. 201 N., to Lakewood Rd., turn left at golf course. Take first right (Rt.43), farm is 2nd road on left. Or take Rt. 43 east out of Madison Village.
THE APPLE FARM -- Marilyn and Steven Meyerhans. 104 Back Road, Fairfield. Home orchard. This home orchard has about 30 acres of apples, pears and plums using many rootstocks, 30+ varieties of apples, ongoing field trials with mulching, tree training, and pest control. The Meyerhans will discuss tree care; conventional Integrated Pest Management (IPM) and organic production. Open Farm Day Hours: 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Directions: From Skowhegan: Take Rt. 104 south from Skowhegan (approx. 5 miles) turn right onto the Back Road. From Waterville: take 104 north (approx. 9 miles from I95 Exit 34), turn left onto Bake Road. Farm is one mile in on the Back Rd.
MOUNTAIN ROAD FARM -- Skip and Cindy Fairfield. 54 Mountain Road, St. Albans. Dairy goats. This licensed farm has 14 milking goats. Milk products are sold at the farm store. The Fairfields will inform the public about dairy goats and their products and explain the history of breeds used world-wide. Children will be able to pet kids and go into their pens, and we will give a complete tour of the facilities and there will be product tasting. Open Farm Day Hours: 10 a.m.-4 p.m. Directions: Take routes 151 or 152 off Rt. 2 to Hartland. At the Fleet Bank in the center of town look for signs. Farm is 1 1/2 miles north of town.
JERRY SASS TREE FARM -- Jerry Sass. School Street, North Anson. Tree farm. There are 75 acres of mixed hardwood/softwood, with 3 small orchards for wildlife. Jerry's farm was Somerset County's Outstanding Tree Farm for 1994. There will be 30-45 minute walking tours with a discussion on intensive management of woodlot with small equipment, winter harvesting to promote an uneven stand management, enhance biodiversity and wildlife and recreational use. Possible demonstration of portable bandsaw mill on premises. Custom sawn lumber for sale. Open Farm Day Hours: 10 a.m. - 3 p.m. Directions: From North Anson center 1/4 mile West on Rt. 16 to Elm St. Market. Go North on School St. for 2 miles. Farm is on the left at Firewood For Sale sign at woodyard.
WESTON FARMS -- Tom and Sandy Weston with Joshua, Heidi, Noah, Burke, Hannah, and Melanie. 380 Weston Avenue, Madison. Vegetable and sheep farm. This farm is a working family farm with a market garden and registered Romney, registered New Zealand Romneys and Border Leicesters and crosses. They have the only registered, first generation New Zealand Romney Ram in the Northeast. They sell homemade products, canned pickles, jellies, crafts, handspun 100% wool, Angora (from their own Angora rabbits ), Mohair yarns and fleeces for handspinning. They make Fimo beads (Josh will demonstrate how they are made) and grow many different varieties of veggies and herbs and dried flowers and wreaths. They process and sell their own maple syrup. All done on premises. On Open Farm Day the Kennebec Valley Handspinners and members of the Maine Spinners Registry will be here handspinning and demonstrating the process from washing to dying to combing to spinning. They want to show how spinning can assure a better and finer product of greater value. A 150 year old barn loom will be on display. They offer 6-8 varieties of beans, 12-14 kinds of winter squash, many different pumpkin varieties. They are organic and would like their customers to know - Learn to love spots-They're organic! Open Farm Day Hours: 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Directions: At lights on Main Street in Madison, follow Weston Ave. (road along side Cumberland Farms) for about 1 mile till fields are on both sides of the road. Their white farm is after fields on left.
ROCKY HILL ACRES -- William and Leona Thomas. Route 2, Skowhegan. Miniature goat farm. At Rocky Hill Acres they raise Registered Pygmy Goats and Registered Nigerian Dwarfs. They show and sell the goats. The Dwarfs are miniature Dairy Goats. Also there is a miniature horse. There will be pamplets available on both breeds of goats and videos of goat shows, births and baby goats. They will tell the history of the goats and will be showing goats born in March and April. Open Farm Day Hours: 10 a.m.- 3 p.m. Directions: Exactly 2 miles west on Rt. 2 from the Canaan Post Office and exactly 5.5 miles east on Rt. 2 from the Skowhegan Post Office. Mail box #171 across from thier house.
FIBER-LEE FARM -- Robert and Leah O'Donnell. Lazy Lane, Canaan. Fiber farm. This is a small but growing farm where fleece is taken from animals and processed so it can be spun into yarn. At present the angora rabbit is their maine source of fiber plus two Cashgora goats. You will learn how to care for Angora rabbits and what to do with all the beautiful fiber. Demonstrations on spinning Angora and other natural fibers, blending and carding will be held at 10 a.m. and 2 p.m. Open Farm Day Hours: 9 a.m.-4 p.m. Directions: Rt. 2 to town of Canaan, take Hill Rd. for one mile then straight on Battle Ridge Rd. for two miles, street on the right is Lazy Lane, follow until you see Fiber-Lee Sign on garage facing you.
WALDO
MOUNTAIN VIEW FRUIT AND BERRY FARM -- Phyllis and Herb Schartner. Knox Ridge Road, Rt. 220, Thorndike. Pick your own strawberries, raspberries and apples farm. The Schartnerrs produce strawberries, raspberries, sweet corn, peaches and plums. There will be a learning tour of Integrated Pest Management practices for apples and strawberries. A wagon tour of orchard will discuss varieties of apples including old fashion varieties. Farm tour of other fruits as well as opportunity to take advantage of our Pick Your Own strawberries and free recipes. Open Farm Day Hours: 10:00 a.m. - 7:00 p.m. Directions: 2 miles N on Rt. 220 from Rt. 137 Jct., 2nd farm on the left past Mt. View High School. From Rts. 9 & 202 go 5 miles south on Rt. 220, look for sign.
WASHINGTON
PARK ROAD FARM -- Chris Guida. Cobscook Park Road, Edmunds Township. Scottish Highland cows and Scottish black face sheep farm. You will see fencing; control-led grazing; raw wool rug making; hide tanning and chewing; cow chasing; sheep chasing; hay help is welcome if sun is out. Open Farm Day Hours: 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Directions: Rt. 1 to Cobscook Park entrance then one mile beyond.
CROSS ROAD FARM -- Arnold and Bonnie Pearlman with son Jodi and one or two apprentices. Indian River Crossroad, Jonesport. Vegetable and fruit farm. The Pearlmans grow 110 varieties of potatoes, over 500 varieties of vegetables, 40 different kinds of apples. All are organically grown for 25 years. They compost with fish and seaweed for fertilizer. There will be a self guided tour. Open Farm Day Hours: 10:00 a.m. - 3:00 p.m. Directions: Follow signs from Rt. 1 to Mason Bay Road, Rt. 187 go 2.2 miles to Indian River Crossroad.
MUSTARD SEED FARM -- Janet, Paul, Zachary and Amity Beane. Talmadge Road, Talmadge. Vegetables and dried flowers. The Beanes grow many acres of dried flowers and vegetables that are pick-your-own. On Open Farm Day green peas and Larkspur flowers should be available for you pick. They will explain their farming operation and provide tour of fields. Open Farm Day Hours: 10:00 a.m. - 3:00 p.m. Directions: Halfway between Princeton and Topsfield in the town of Waite, on US Rt. 1 DOT sign will direct you to turn onto the Talmadge Rd. Farm is less than a mile from Rt. 1.
RIVER SONG - NIDDY NODDY -- Roland and Virginia Hooper. Chases Mill Road, East Machias. Diversified self-sufficient farm. The Hoopers raise goats, sheep, all their own vegetables, hens, meat birds, pigs and rabbits. You will see goat milking, hoof trimming, horn burning (dis-butting) on Open Farm Day. You will learn how to make a dis-butting box and enjoy the petting zoo and tour of the farm. There will be fresh goat's milk and cheese to taste. Children will be able to hold the kid goats. Open Farm Day Hours: 8 a.m.-Noon if they are haying or until 3 p.m. if not. Directions. Take Rt. 1 through the village of East Machias going east. Turn North at the Nazerine Church on Chases Mill Rd. Go 1 mile. The farm is the white mobile home on the right with a greenhouse and satellite dish in the yard. Follow the signs.
ROCK HILL FARM -- Tom and Doris Walker with Ben and Danyel. Big Rock Lane, Cherryfield. Diversified farm. The Walkers raise beef, sheep, goats, pigs, rabbits, horses and poultry. There are 140 acres on Rock Hill Farm with pastures, gardens and the greenhouse where organic seedlings are started for sale and for use in their gardens. You will learn about pasture rotation, care and feeding of livestock and how they raise most of their own food. There will be tours of the gardens and barns with a petting zoo. Open Farm Day Hours: 10:00 a.m. - 3:00 p.m. Directions: In Cherryfield, from Rt. 1 take Rt. 182 west, go 1 mile and turn left at Blue Seal Sign and go 2/10 mile. Road ends in the farm driveway.
BEALS ISLAND REGIONAL SHELLLFISH HATCHERY -- University of Maine, Machias. Dwayne Shaw, hatchery manager. Perio Point, Beals. Shellfish hatchery and demonstration facility. Beals Island is the only soft shell clam hatchery in the world. They supply clam seed to municipal management committees throughout the state and conduct research with a variety of commercial shellfish species. They work in cooperation with private aquaculturists. Tours of the hatchery center will be given on Open Farm Day where you'll see larva and juvenile stages of shellfish and lobster as well as, algal production which is used for food for shellfish. The visitors center has historical pictures of the clam industry. Open Farm Day Hours: 9:30 a.m.-2:30 p.m. Directions: Follow Rt. 1 to Rt. 187 to Jonesport. Cross the bridge to Beals and take a left at the bottom of the bridge and then the first left onto Perio Point.
MAINE SALMON, INC. -- Frank Ayres, Chris Ayres and Marshall Dewitt. Deep Cove Road, Eastport. Ocean-based salmon farm. Maine Salmon, Inc. raises Atlantic Salmon and Stealhead Trout in floating cages on Cobscook Bay. Boat tours will be facilitated by the Marine Technology Center, Washington County Technical College. Contacts: Chris Bartlett and JoAnn O'Grady (1-207-853-2518). Boat tour leaves on the hour 10:00 - 2:00, maximum 18 people per tour. Open Farm Hours: 10:00 a.m. - p.m. Directions: Rt. 1, take Rt. 190 to Eastport (approx. 7 miles). Turn right onto the Deep Cove Rd. directly across from Irving Station. Follow road for 1 mile to the Marine Technology Center. Turn left into parking lot and proceed straight to pier for Boat Tour.
STEEPLEBUSH FARM -- Jane Heart and Belden Morse. West Kennebec Road, Machias. Llama farm. At Steeplebush Farm they breed and raise llamas, sell them as breeding stock, sheep guards, companion animals, and pets. On Open Farm Day you can meet llamas, take them for walks, receive verbal and written information and see fiber uses. Open Farm Day Hours: 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Directions: Turn from Route 1 onto Roque Bluffs Road (next to Rier Motors & VIP Realty), proceed 2.3 miles to fork; bear left, proceed 1.5 miles. Farm is on the right.

Farms to welcome visitors on Sunday Owners to explain agricultural operations

Author: the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]05 July 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413880424?accountid=10457

Abstract: A story published in MaineDay Wednesday about Open Farms Day, which will be held Sunday, July 9, failed to note that Paul Birdsall's Horsepower Farm in North Penobscot raises market vegetables and storage crops. In Skowhegan, William and Leona Thomas will hold Open Farm Day at Rocky Hill Acres on Route 2, a miniature-goat farm. The Thomases raise registered Pygmy goats and Nigerian dwarf goats for sale and show. There is also a miniature horse on the Thomas farm. Other farms in Somerset County included in the event are: Weston Farms, Weston Avenue, Madison, vegetable and sheep farm with hand-spinner's exhibition and retail products available; Mountain Road Farm, Mountain Road, St. Albans, dairy goats, with a farm store, tour, petting of animals allowed; Jerry Sass Tree Farm, School Street, North Anson, tree farm with 75 acres of mixed soft and hardwoods, bandsaw demonstration; Good Will Farm, Greene Road, Hinckley, dairy farm with milking at 3 p.m., and tours.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Farms+to+welcome+visitors+on+Sunday+Owners+to+explain+agricultural+operations&amp;author=the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-07-05&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: A story published in MaineDay Wednesday about Open Farms Day, which will be held Sunday, July 9, failed to note that Paul Birdsall's Horsepower Farm in North Penobscot raises market vegetables and storage crops.
About 120 Maine farms will open their doors to visitors on Sunday, July 9, to help educate the public about the production of everything from cattle to clams.
Nathan Pennell, office manager for the Soil and Water Conservation District in Machias, said the event will give families an opportunity to have fun while experiencing Maine agriculture.
This is the sixth year for the Open Farms Day.
In Somerset County, one of the more unusual farms opening its operation to the public is the fiber farm operated by Robert and Leah O'Donnell in Canaan.
The Fiber-Lee Farm is on Lazy Lane.
This is a small but growing farm where fleece is taken from animals and processed so it can be spun into yarn. Angora rabbits are the O'Donnells' main source of fiber, augmented by fleece from Cashgora goats.
The O'Donnells will instruct visitors in the care of Angora rabbits and what to do with the fiber. There will be demonstrations of spinning, blending and carding at 10 a.m. and 2 p.m.
In Skowhegan, William and Leona Thomas will hold Open Farm Day at Rocky Hill Acres on Route 2, a miniature-goat farm. The Thomases raise registered Pygmy goats and Nigerian dwarf goats for sale and show. There is also a miniature horse on the Thomas farm.
Pamphlets will be available on both breeds of goats and videos of goat shows, births and baby goats.
Two Somerset County orchards will participate: North Star Orchards, operated by Judith and Everett Dimock, on Orchard Road in Madison, which will offer wagon rides through the orchard and displays and a retail store; and The Apple Farm on Back Road in Fairfield, which grows 30 acres of apples, pears and plums.
Other farms in Somerset County included in the event are: Weston Farms, Weston Avenue, Madison, vegetable and sheep farm with hand-spinner's exhibition and retail products available; Mountain Road Farm, Mountain Road, St. Albans, dairy goats, with a farm store, tour, petting of animals allowed; Jerry Sass Tree Farm, School Street, North Anson, tree farm with 75 acres of mixed soft and hardwoods, bandsaw demonstration; Good Will Farm, Greene Road, Hinckley, dairy farm with milking at 3 p.m., and tours.
North in the County, an educational farm staffed by high school students at Presque Isle, is one of three farms that will be open to offer an opportunity to learn about food and fiber.
The 38-acre farm owned by SAD 1 has an apple orchard, 5 acres of strawberries and raspberries and a variety of vegetable crops. The products are marketed through an on-site store off Academy and State streets.
Students will provide tours of their greenhouse and other sectors of the farm between noon and 5 p.m.
Other Aroostook County farms involved in the statewide event are the Wood Prairie Farm, owned by Jim, Megan, Peter and Caleb Gerritsen on the West Road at Bridgewater. The potato, vegetable and livestock farm will be open between 1:30 and 5 p.m.
Open from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. will be the Shakaree Red Deer Farm on the French Road in New Limerick and the Red Bridge Farm on River Road in Oakfield.
The Shakaree Red Deer Farm has the largest herd of red deer, 650 deer on 200 acres, in the eastern United States. Owners Gary Dwyer and Mark Drew will explain venison production and breeding stock. More than 100 deer will still have velvet on their antlers.
Washington County will provide a unique opportunity for visitors making their way to the only soft-shell clam hatchery in the world at Beals Island.
The hatchery supplies clam seed to municipal shellfish management and conservation committees throughout the state. The visitors center, featuring historical pictures of the clam industry, will be open from 9:30 a.m. to 2:30 p.m.
Atlantic salmon are raised in the ocean off Washington County. Maine Salmon Inc. raises salmon and steelhead trout in floating cages on Cobscook Bay. Boat tours will be conducted by the Marine Technology Center and the Washington County Technical College from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m.
In Hancock County, Horsepower Farm in North Penobscot will feature blueberries grown organically, a yarn spinning demonstration, draft horses at work, wagon rides, and lambs, piglets and chickens from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m.
The annual farm day is sponsored by the University of Maine Cooperative Extension, the Soil and Water Conservation District, the Maine Department of Agriculture and Threshold to Maine RC&D Area Inc. These agencies can provide information on additional farms open for visitors on Sunday.

Brooklin base for sea program

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]04 July 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413961653?accountid=10457

Abstract: Having recently relocated here from the desert Southwest, Hoyt has gotten his feet very wet indeed, running education programs for a marine research field office and pursuing an aquaculture venture on the side. MERI was founded in 1989 after marine research scientist Susan Shaw became concerned that large numbers of marine mammal strandings in the late 1980s might be traceable to environmental pollution. The Brooklin facility is the education field office of the research organization whose headquarters are in New York City. Hoyt's hiring in May to run the institute's expanding educational programs was no fluke. As a mammologist with a soft spot for mollusks and other sea life, Hoyt looks pretty natural amidst the marine mammal models of the MERI office in Brooklin village.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Brooklin+base+for+sea+program&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-07-04&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   BROOKLIN -- After 15 years working in zoos and museums out of state, Reg Hoyt has returned to his native Maine and to his first love, marine science.
Having recently relocated here from the desert Southwest, Hoyt has gotten his feet very wet indeed, running education programs for a marine research field office and pursuing an aquaculture venture on the side.
The Bangor resident recently became program director of the Marine Environmental Research Institute facility in Brooklin, where a full range of summer programs for children and adults begins this week. Offerings include naturalist-led cruises and island walking tours.
MERI was founded in 1989 after marine research scientist Susan Shaw became concerned that large numbers of marine mammal strandings in the late 1980s might be traceable to environmental pollution. The Brooklin facility is the education field office of the research organization whose headquarters are in New York City.
Hoyt's hiring in May to run the institute's expanding educational programs was no fluke. As a mammologist with a soft spot for mollusks and other sea life, Hoyt looks pretty natural amidst the marine mammal models of the MERI office in Brooklin village.
"As a child, I was a very avid beachcomber, extremely interested in marine life," said the Sanford native, who "started a saltwater aquarium before anyone said you could."
Hooked on marine sciences, he became disillusioned at a state college he attended in Florida when he couldn't inspect his plankton samples because microscopes were available only to graduate students.
After a stint in the Navy, Hoyt returned to Maine temporarily to enroll at Nasson College in Springvale, a smaller school more suited to his tastes. Ironically, a severe foot disorder made him switch his focus from marine sciences to "more terrestrial" work.
Once warned he might not be able to walk by age 35, Hoyt couldn't see slogging through mud flats indefinitely. He turned to museum work until he realized he preferred live creatures to preserved ones.
During several years in zoo work in the South and Southwest, he ran breeding programs for threatened species such as black-footed ferrets and Mexican wolves, appearing on television shows including "Captain Kangaroo."
Hoyt fondly remembers taking fox kits onto the show. "That was quite fun because the kits were extremely gentle," he said. But one wee critter, apparently attracted to the captain's bright yellow sleeve, took a firm toothhold and would not let go.
Hoyt's last job before returning to Maine was as curator of collections for the Phoenix Zoo. Successful foot surgery has helped smooth his transition to Maine and MERI, where his duties include leading short cruises for adults.
On two-hour trips perusing the waters of Naskeag Point, Eggemoggin Reach and Blue Hill Bay, Hoyt discusses the natural history of the area and its islands. Sightings of seals, porpoises, osprey, bald eagles and sea birds are as frequent as the tides.
MERI has permission to visit several privately owned islands, including Hog, Sheep, Pond and Babson. Each has its own character, says Hoyt. Sheep Island has the denuded character one would expect from sheeps' mowing, and Hog Island bears the remains of clay-firing pits.
The institute's children's programs aim at strengthening observation skills. Each program starts with a slide show preview of the creatures kids can expect to see. A licensed captain and naturalist then loads the children onto an inflatable Zodiac, zipping out to an uninhabited island for a day of exploring and discussion.
Naturalist Cydney Smith of Blue Hill, whose background is environmental science, says even local children are surprised to learn how much they don't know about their surroundings. They can identify seaweed, but not which of three local types they're treading on.
Past mussels and periwinkles, youngsters find themselves speechless in the game of naming species. Asked to name their favorite part of the day, first-timers usually holler "the boat ride!" Smith says.
Nonetheless, children seem eager to rethink their assumptions and misconceptions and to return to learn more. MERI does a brisk business in returning students, said Hoyt, whose own interests include oyster and nori aquaculture.
The Friday Explorer program most fully unleashes the talents of staff naturalists, Hoyt said. A coming workshop will entail tracing the form of a humpback whale onto Route 175, and counting how many car lengths fit into the stenciled shape.
Having recently presented programs at Blue Hill and Brooklin primary schools, MERI hopes to increase its educational outreach, although the stretch may depend on foundation funding.
MERI is a membership organization, depending on $25 donations from individuals and the occasional larger infusion from organizations such as the Brooklin Garden Club.
Hoyt is about to raise the organization's local visibility by entering an inflatable minke whale replica into Brooklin's Fourth of July parade. Fluke bearers will flap their wares alongside.
Illustration Caption: Reg Hoyt sits next to Naskeag Harbor, one of the areas where he conducts tours as program director of the Marine Environmental Research Institute in Brooklin. (NEWS Photo by Michele Stapleton)

Beals moves to protect clam beds Shellfish committee prepares ordinance to restrict out-of-town `rustlers'

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]04 July 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413961410?accountid=10457

Abstract: Town officials and resident clam diggers say they've had enough of clam rustlers. They are taking steps to protect the town's clam beds with a conservation program that should stop out-of-town clam rustlers in their tracks. First Selectman Verland Lenfestey, chairman of the newly formed Beals Island Shellfish Committee, said Monday that he would hand-carry the town's proposed clam conservation ordinance to Commissioner William Brennan in Augusta.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Beals+moves+to+protect+clam+beds+Shellfish+committee+prepares+ordinance+to+restrict+out-of-town+%60rustlers%27&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-07-04&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BEALS -- Town officials and resident clam diggers say they've had enough of clam rustlers. They are taking steps to protect the town's clam beds with a conservation program that should stop out-of-town clam rustlers in their tracks.
First Selectman Verland Lenfestey, chairman of the newly formed Beals Island Shellfish Committee, said Monday that he would hand-carry the town's proposed clam conservation ordinance to Commissioner William Brennan in Augusta.
A group of Beals residents, including several professional clam diggers, formed a clam committee last week. They elected Lenfestey as chairman and Ordman "Skipper" Alley Jr. as secretary.
Resident diggers recently complained to Lenfestey and his board that commercial non-resident clam diggers were openly harvesting the town's managed clam beds because the town has no ordinance that protects the beds.
Although the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery at Beals provides clam seedlings to several other coastal communities in the state, the town of Beals has failed to protect its own clams from out-of-town clam rustlers until now.
After Lenfestey and his committee fill out the appropriate clam conservation ordinance application papers, requesting approval from the Department of Marine Resources, Lenfestey and Duane Carver will hand-deliver the application to the DMR. Carver has expertise in clam and water sampling.
After the DMR gives conditional approval to the ordinance, Lenfestey will present the proposed ordinance to Beals voters for local approval. Then, with DMR's final approval, non-residents would be allowed to dig clams from Beals flats only in accordance with licensing regulations set forth in the ordinance.
