Prohibition is always a bad idea

Author: Robert E. Prasch and Falguni A. Sheth

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]04 July 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413813850?accountid=10457

Abstract: Richard Kochi's recent Op-ed column ("Letalize pot? Let's not.", BDN, June 24-25), was a provocative argument, articulate and impassioned, in support of the current prohibition of marijuana. Unfortunately, it was deeply flawed in its analysis of the issues surrounding marijuana usage. For those who missed Kochis' piece, the following paragraph summarizes his major points: If Kochis is to make his point successfully, he must establish that there is no legitimate, non-pernicious use of marijuana. Such an argument would be parallel to the grounds upon which the state has deprived us of the "privilege" of owning anti-aircraft missiles -- used properly, such a weapon has no purpose other than one that we would all wish to avoid. As a society, we simply cannot reasonably foresee a safe, legitimate use for such weapons by private citizens. However, such a case cannot be made for marijuana. Besides its usefulness in easing the pain of cancer patients who undergo chemotherapy, and in helping to cure glaucoma, moderate use of marijuana has been the source of pleasurable recreational usage -- for those who desire it, in the privacy of their own homes. However, society has a strong interest in preventing the use of automobiles and heavy machinery while under the influence; citizens will also be inclined to enforce age restrictions on users. Yet, neither of these restrictions is exceptional or the grounds for a sweeping prohibition; as we can see, these are already on the books for the use of alcohol and tobacco.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Prohibition+is+always+a+bad+idea&amp;author=Robert+E.+Prasch+and+Falguni+A.+Sheth&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-07-04&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Richard Kochi's recent Op-ed column ("Letalize pot? Let's not.", BDN, June 24-25), was a provocative argument, articulate and impassioned, in support of the current prohibition of marijuana. Unfortunately, it was deeply flawed in its analysis of the issues surrounding marijuana usage. For those who missed Kochis' piece, the following paragraph summarizes his major points:
For Kochis, marijuana should remain illegal because:
(1) people misuse marijuana (driving under the influence, getting high before school, etc.);
(2) people exhibit a psychological dependency on marijuana.
Furthermore, Kochis rejects arguments for legalization because he finds that:
(3) there are few concrete economic benefits to "hemp" as followers like to claim;
(4) the prohibition issue is not about individual rights since the misuse of marijuana involves costs to society;
(5) people who support legalization are simply trying to "rationalize their need to get high."
We would like to address each of these points in turn.
First, outlawing a product or an activity because of potential misuse by some individuals is as irresponsible as those peole who do the misusing. For example, matches, firearms, and boats are all great sources of convenience and, in certain contexts, recreation. On the other hand, when misused, they are important causes of tragic injuries or death. In fact, individually and collectively, they are the source of more fatalities than marijuana.
If Kochis is to make his point successfully, he must establish that there is no legitimate, non-pernicious use of marijuana. Such an argument would be parallel to the grounds upon which the state has deprived us of the "privilege" of owning anti-aircraft missiles -- used properly, such a weapon has no purpose other than one that we would all wish to avoid. As a society, we simply cannot reasonably foresee a safe, legitimate use for such weapons by private citizens. However, such a case cannot be made for marijuana. Besides its usefulness in easing the pain of cancer patients who undergo chemotherapy, and in helping to cure glaucoma, moderate use of marijuana has been the source of pleasurable recreational usage -- for those who desire it, in the privacy of their own homes. However, society has a strong interest in preventing the use of automobiles and heavy machinery while under the influence; citizens will also be inclined to enforce age restrictions on users. Yet, neither of these restrictions is exceptional or the grounds for a sweeping prohibition; as we can see, these are already on the books for the use of alcohol and tobacco.
As to his second point, it may be true that some individuals develop a psychological dependency on marijuana. However, the individuals upon whom Kochis, as a drug counselor, is basing his argument constitute a "sample bias." He obviously will never counsel those who are neither psychologically nor physically dependent upon marijuana, nor will he be likely to interact with those individuals who have achieved academic distinction, promotions, and job success regardless of their marijuana intake. We should add that people develop attachments to all kinds of things including alcohol, cigarettes, sailing, sex, and television. Again, the experiences and traumas of an unfortunate few are not legitimate grounds for so Draconian a policy as a categorical ban on a widely used drug. Just because shellfish may cause anaphylactic shock for some who are allergic to shrimp, it would be ludicrous to prohibit everyone from enjoying seafood. Recall that a prohibition passes a negative judgment on a large number of people who are otherwise law-abiding citizens. Are we to do this because of the difficulties of an unfortunate few?
Leaving the rights question aside, is a prohibition policy cost-effective? Do we not then create new psychological problems when we arrest otherwise law-abiding citizens and deprive them of "life, liberty, and happiness" because some other people show signs of dependence when they use marijuana? Legislating for all citizens based upon the traumas of a few individuals is not only illogical, but unbelievably patronizing. What we can do is offer assistance and guidance to those who need it, instead of saddling so many well-adjusted, upstanding citizens with criminal records and prison sentences for responsibly engaging in an otherwise consensual, socially harmless acitivity. The fact that someone, somewhere, takes a risk by trying marijuana is not grounds for passing a penalty which encourages the state to harass so many of our fellow citizens.
Third, Kochis suggests that the pro-legalization groups are disingenous when they claim that "hemp" has a wide variety of valuable and economically profitable uses. To an extent, he is correct. The fact that rope or baskets can be made from hemp does not make this product the basis of an economic miracle. However, there is economic value in the ability to tax and regulate the distribution of a legally saleable product. Moreover, the expense that goes into the DEA, narcotics police, local police efforts, mandatory drug counseling, etc. -- could be diminished or eliminated with the legalization and regulation of marijuana. The potential for very real savings on these programs would be tremendous, which is a point that Kochis overlooks when he urges readers to think of reducing social problems. Instead, a number of worthy programs could be funded, such as a civil service corps, subsidizied housing, etc. Alternatively, taxes could be lowered without this extravagant public expense.
Fourth, Kochis claims that a legalization argument based on "individual rights" does not hold water since "clearly there are social costs." Those may be the worst argument in Kochis' piece. Of course, there are social costs! Social -- and political -- costs are a necessary and legitimate burden of all rights. Consider the O.J. Simpson trial. before the days of individual rights, we could have saved Los Angeles County millions of dollars by torturing a confession out of the defendant, regardless of guilt or innocence. Social and political justice means individual freedoms must be balancedf with individual responsibilities. The cost of political freedom is responsible citizenship. The cost of recreational sex without protection can be exorbitant. But to abolish individiual liberties, on the assumption that no one is able to be responsible for themselves, sounds eerily like no freedom at all.
Finally, Kochis tells us, not once, but twice, that he suspects that those who favor the legalization of hemp are not publicly interested, but rather self-interested, i.e. rationalizing their own desire to "get high." What a fallacious and slanderous statement. We sincerely doubt that prominent conservative thinkers such as Milton Friedman, William F. Buckely or George P. Shultz are simply trying to pull one over us while they secretly "inhale." Although he attempts to belittle many public-spirited contributors to an important debate, Kochis implicitly agrees that one can be both self-interested and correct. He is idenitified at the end of the column as the "clinical coordinator for Substance Abuse Services at the University of Maine." As one who lives off of tax and tuition dollars, it is clear that Kochis has a stake in the outcome of the prohibition debate. People who read his condescending statements concerning the motives of those who favor legalization might be led to think that "people in glass houses..."
Robert E. Prasch is an assistant professor of economics at the University of Maine. Falguni A. Sheth has taught in the Philosophy Department at the University of Southern Maine.

Smoked salmon catches on

Author: Letitia Baldwin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]03 July 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413805116?accountid=10457

Abstract: That was the traditional Fourth of July fare in Maine and throughout New England when wild Alantic salmon ran in great numbers in the region's rivers and streams in June and early July back in the 18th and 19th centuries. The custom was to poach the fish and serve it with boiled white potatoes and green peas picked fresh from the vine. As people make their way through Ellsworth to Mount Desert island and points Down East this holiday, they may spot some trim, yellow and green signs pointing the way to Sullivan Harbor Farm in East Sullivan, where Leslie Harlow and Joel Frantzman produce a subtly-flavored, cold smoked Atlantic salmon that makes a unique gift for hosts and a fitting appetizer to serve guests on the Fourth. He and assistant Michael Bloomfield are preparing to slice the salmon. Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Smoked+salmon+catches+on&amp;author=Letitia+Baldwin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-07-03&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Salmon and peas.
That was the traditional Fourth of July fare in Maine and throughout New England when wild Alantic salmon ran in great numbers in the region's rivers and streams in June and early July back in the 18th and 19th centuries. The custom was to poach the fish and serve it with boiled white potatoes and green peas picked fresh from the vine.
As people make their way through Ellsworth to Mount Desert island and points Down East this holiday, they may spot some trim, yellow and green signs pointing the way to Sullivan Harbor Farm in East Sullivan, where Leslie Harlow and Joel Frantzman produce a subtly-flavored, cold smoked Atlantic salmon that makes a unique gift for hosts and a fitting appetizer to serve guests on the Fourth.
Built in 1820 by Capt. James Urann, Sullivan Harbor Farm has the air of an old English country house with its granite terrace, kitchen garden, perennial beds and flowing green lawns. So it was somewhat of a surprise to discover the sleek, high-tech operation housed in the renovated barn.
It's 9 a.m. and morning light streams through the skylight and classical music drifts through the air of the smokehouse. The sun-filled rooms are spare and spotless. They have been made appealing to the eye with powder blue counter tops, flecked oyster and white floor tiles and modern artwork adorning the walls.
A lean, agile man clad in jeans and a salmon-colored Lacoste shirt, Frantzman darts about amid various shiny stainless steel contraptions. He and assistant Michael Bloomfield are preparing to slice the salmon. They lift deep amber-colored fillets from shelves in a stainless steel rack wheeled out of the reaches of the cold room kept at 28.6 Fahrenheit -- well below the maximum temperature allowed by the state.
Frantzman shows Bloomfield how to peel back and remove the salmon's silvery skin in one swift, clean motion. One-by-one, fillets move through a German machine that cuts them into minute slices about 1/8 of an inch thick. They emerge and drop onto pristine, acrylic plates. The fillets are then vacuum-packed and readied for market.
Frantzman says the process actually begins when a southbound seafood truck grinds to a halt at Sullivan Harbor Farm and drops off a load of freshly harvested Atlantic salmon several times a week. The salmon is washed, stored in a cold room, and washed again before being cured in a mixture of salt and brown sugar.
The fish is then slowly cold smoked over a mixture of hickory, applewood and beech chips for about 10 hours in a Scottish-style kiln.
The difference between cold and hot smoked fish is simple. In the latter method, the flesh is actually cooked. The difference in taste is a matter of palate.
The Irish, Scottish and Norwegians are famed for their cold smoked products. But, as the fish-farming boom has hit the United States, more smokehouses have surfaced in Maine and the Pacific Northwest. In this state, there are at least a dozen, stretching from Portland to Lubec. Appledore, Duck Trap River Fish Farm, Horton's, Bud's and Jim's are among the best known.
Frantzman toyed with the idea of becoming a salmon farmer but decided it was too risky given the great capital investment required and uncontrollable factors inherent to the international market dominated by Norway. Smoking fish seemed more feasible given the abundance of farm-raised salmon in Maine.
No stranger to the food business, he ran a sporting camp for more than a decade on Little Lyford Pond near Gulf Hagus Gorge in Piscataquis County. He served guests a cold smoked salmon imported from Nova Scotia. He recalls how the fish was tasty but Saran-wrapped and sent via regular mail.
A woman with a broad smile, twinkle in her eye, and long blond hair, Leslie Harlow is an old hand at the food business. She co-owned and ran the Town Farm Restaurant in Bar Harbor and Orono.
She and Frantzman combed the Maine coast for a suitable location for their combination B&B/smokehouse. Three years ago, they discovered and bought the rambling, former Sullivan Harbor Inn, with its main house, barn and guest houses. It's a perfect site since it sits right beside U.S. Route 1 -- the highway on which much of Maine's farm-raised salmon travels to market.
A jungle had grown up in front of the 175-year-old captain's house and obscured the ocean view. A former Outward Bound instructor, Frantzman's mountaineering skills came in handy for limbing the immense trees. The house was not insulated and there was a litany of other repairs to be done.
Never having smoked fish, Frantzman spent a month at the Torry Research Station in Aberdeen, Scotland, learning everything from proper washing to cold smoking. He also gleaned advice from the operators of small smokehouses on the Isle of Skye and other parts of Scotland.
It's taken a couple of years but all the hard physical work and research is starting to pay off.
In the summer, Frantzman and Harlow get steady orders from the nearby summer colonies of Sorrento, Hancock Point and Grindstone Neck in Winter Harbor. They also ship smoked salmon around the country in the offseason.
The couple has also gone wholesale.
The founder and president of the Massachusetts-based seafood restaurant and retail store chain, Legal Seafood, gave Sullivan Harbor Farm a big chunk of business after sampling its fresh-tasting, flavorful salmon. Orders are coming from the Manhattan gourmet food company, Dean & DeLuca, Southern Seasons in Raleigh-Durham, N.C., and the West Point Market in Akron, Ohio.
While they are excited by the growth, they don't want to be consumed by their business and not enjoy life. Frantzman thinks one full-time employee is about enough.
"That's the limit of how we see ourselves," he says.
Smoked salmon pate
1 small onion or chives 1/2 pound smoked Atlantic salmon 8 ounces cream cheese 2 teaspoon horseradish 2 teaspoon lemon juice 1 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce 1/4 cup of Miracle Whip A few sprigs of parsley
In a food processor, puree onion or chives, salmon and cream cheese. Then add horseradish, lemon juice, Worcestershire sauce, Miracle Whip and parsley. Blend together on high speed until mixed well.

Full text: Aroostook County Superior Court Caribou
J. Freddie Ringuette, 42, St. Agatha, two revocations of probations, two one-year concurrent sentences.
Freda Saucier, 44, Fort Fairfield, theft by unauthorized taking or transfer, 10 days in jail, suspended, and one year probation.

____________________________________________________________

Deer Isle volunteer water monitors win state honors

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]13 June 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413841638?accountid=10457

Abstract: According to chairwoman Cherie Mason, at any given time the Deer Isle Conservation Commission's work might involve poring over water testing samples or working with high school students to plant a wildflower meadow.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Deer+Isle+volunteer+water+monitors+win+state+honors&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-06-13&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: DEER ISLE -- Sometimes playing scientist in your garage can pay off, as it did for conservation panel members recently honored with a state award for monitoring water quality.
According to chairwoman Cherie Mason, at any given time the Deer Isle Conservation Commission's work might involve poring over water testing samples or working with high school students to plant a wildflower meadow.
But the panel's work monitoring water quality won it the 1994-95 Sterling Dow Award, recently presented by the Maine Association of Conservation Commissions in Augusta. The Deer Isle commission's joint initiative with the state Department of Marine Resources led to the reopening of parts of Crockett Cove for shellfish harvesting, marine resources technician John Fendl of the DMR said Monday.
"We were thrilled when we got the award," particularly since other town commissions' projects seemed equally impressive, Mason said.
Recipient of a separate $1,000 award honoring her as an "environmental woman of action," Mason is known locally for founding the WERU-FM "Environmental Notebook" show, and as author of the children's book "Wild Fox."
Mason and her commission colleagues decided to give the prize money to Deer Isle Elementary School for installation of miniature greenhouses there.
Modeling its testing effort on another group's successful project, the Deer Isle commission tapped $3,500 in state grants to monitor water quality. Some money received from the state eventually was used to set up a water testing lab at Deer Isle-Stonington High School.

Chez casual Author publishes recipes for easygoing entertaining

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]12 June 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413770380?accountid=10457

Abstract: Author of "Easygoing Entertaining: The `Harry's Wild About You' Cookbook," Harry Schwartz is an ebullient, happy-go-lucky sort of guy who laughs easily and often. Endowed with the kind of laid-back temperament often associated with southern climes, the Iowa native makes his primary home in Florida, but has a summer home in Maine. A dread of Maine winters drives Schwartz from his Surry summer home each September back to coastal Florida, where the chef-philanthropist works at perfecting his own style of casual entertaining. His new book's marble-pink cover shows a deeply tanned Schwartz looking relaxed, to say the least -- his blousy, white shirt splayed wide open at the neck, his blooming five o'clock shadow framing his thick moustache.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Chez+casual+Author+publishes+recipes+for+easygoing+entertaining&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-06-12&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Wearing a ponytail and earring, the young entrepreneur looks entirely at ease in the setting, complete with candelabra and chandelier, pictured on his new book.
Author of "Easygoing Entertaining: The `Harry's Wild About You' Cookbook," Harry Schwartz is an ebullient, happy-go-lucky sort of guy who laughs easily and often. Endowed with the kind of laid-back temperament often associated with southern climes, the Iowa native makes his primary home in Florida, but has a summer home in Maine.
A dread of Maine winters drives Schwartz from his Surry summer home each September back to coastal Florida, where the chef-philanthropist works at perfecting his own style of casual entertaining.
His new book's marble-pink cover shows a deeply tanned Schwartz looking relaxed, to say the least -- his blousy, white shirt splayed wide open at the neck, his blooming five o'clock shadow framing his thick moustache.
"Life's really precious, and it's short, and I don't have to dress up to enjoy it," says Schwartz, during a recent interview. His amusement at that revelation erupts into high-pitched, spiraling laughter. He says a host must feel comfortable before he can put his guests at ease.
Biographical notes say Schwartz began cooking at the age of 5, taught by his mother, a talented cook and hostess whose artistic flair also made for some memorable table settings.
After college, Schwartz bought Borg Steel, a scrap-metal business in Tulsa, Okla., where he and wife Laurie opened two restaurants.
"I used to think everything about my life there was perfect, except for looking out the window and seeing a wall. I wished I could have looked out on the ocean," he once remarked.
Scrapping the metal business, the couple, who have a 7-year-old daugher, Alexa, bought a home in the Palm Beach, Fla., area, opening Surf & Sky Cuisine, a catering firm serving boats and private aircraft.
At home in Florida, Schwartz prides himself on maintaining a tight schedule.
"By 9:15 a.m., I have run four miles, swum a few laps, showered, dressed, walked Pongo (our Boston terrier), fed Felini (our Siamese), packed Alexa's lunch and snack for school, reviewed her spelling words, delivered her to her teacher and arrived at my office," he once wrote in a column. "As I sit down at my deck with a stomach that's craving a jalapeno cheeseburger with fries and a cola, but a metabolism that allows me some fat-free apricot yogurt and an apple, I begin to think about the rest of my day."
The day could include writing a newspaper column, working on a kitchen design, or planning a fund-raising event he will host, as he has done many times before. Some of the proceeds from his book will go to well-known charities.
Schwartz's current push is for his own television show, or at least a regular spot on someone else's.
"There is a feeling that happens when they go `4-3-2-1' that I can't explain. Live TV is my first choice -- it's so exciting," he said.
Earlier this month, he appeared on the "Today Show," grilling not only a lobster, but also a salad and a dessert for hosts Bryant Gumbel and Katie Couric. He is booked to appear on "Mike and Mattie" and "Regis and Kathie Lee."
When his work day ends, Schwartz may be found manning his regular post (the grill on his back deck), in uniform (running shorts and T-shirt), preparing dinner for his wife and daughter.
Schwartz says his ultimate dinner party would pair a few close friends and family, with Barbra Streisand singing during dinner. Celebrities he has cooked for include Burt Reynolds, Gary Collins and Peter Fonda.
Over the years, Schwartz started to put his original recipes into a computer, eventually compiling 200 for the book just out from Seaside Publishing of St. Petersburg, Fla.
Stressing simplicity, the book advises relying on fresh, readily available ingredients whenever possible. "I can't run to 14 different places to make dinner, and nobody else has the time to do it either," says Schwartz.
After visiting friends in Maine, the Schwartzes decided to look into buying a house here.
"We flew into Bangor, and stayed at the Blue Hill Farm Inn," Schwartz recalls. "Immediately we were smitten, found some builders to interview, and just rolled ahead."
They frequently entertain at their Newberry Neck home. One of his favorite gigs is impromptu catering of artists' receptions at the Leighton Gallery in Blue Hill.
Schwartz says Mainers are amply compensated for the severity of the weather, with respites such as shrimp in February, and fiddleheads in May. His idea of heaven is Maine in August and September, when he can shop at the Blue Hill Farmer's Market, and go to the Blue Hill Fair.
Here are some recipes from his book, which includes chapters on table settings, outdoor cooking, buffets, and the cuisines of the Orient and Southwest. Several of the photographs were shot in Maine by Lynn Karlin of Belfast.
Lobster Soup
1/4 cup butter or margarine 1/2 cup minced onion 1 cup sliced mushrooms 1/4 cup minced garlic 1 tablespoon cracked pepper 1 teaspoon salt 2 tablespoons all-purpose flour 2 1/2 cups whole milk or 1 1/2 cups milk and 1 cup cream for richer soup 1/4 cup tomato puree 1 1/2 cups cooked lobster meat, cut into chunks Oyster crackers or crusty French bread to serve with soup
In a deep, heavy pot, melt the butter over medium-high heat until foam subsides. Add onion, mushrooms, parsley, garlic, pepper, and salt to pan and stir four to five minutes.
Reduce heat to medium and sprinkle flour over the top of the contents of the pan, stirring and cooking for two minutes longer. Slowly stir in milk and tomato puree and cook while stirring until soup thickens.
Stir lobster meat into soup and cook two minutes more. Serve hot with oyster crackers and/or crusty French bread with butter.
Carrots with Blueberries And Pistachios
1/2 cup balsamic vinegar 1/2 cup extra virgin olive oil 3 tablespoons granulated sugar 1 tablespoon cracked pepper 3 tablespoons minced fresh shallots 1 teaspoon salt 3 cups grated sweet carrots 1 cup fresh blueberries, cleaned and rinsed 1 cup shelled pistachio nuts
Mix together the vinegar, oil, sugar, cracked pepper, shallots, and salt. Toss with carrots, blueberries, and pistachios. Cover and refrigerate up to four hours before serving. Serves 6-8.
Illustration Caption: Harry Schwartz, author of "Easygoing Entertaining: The 'Harry's Wild About You' Cookbook," appears at ease entertaining guests as well as creating in the kitchen.

Lobster proposal ready Monday, panel promises Marine Resources membership to poll lobstermen over weekend

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]10 June 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413779110?accountid=10457

Abstract: Leaving deadlines in its wake like chum gone bad, the Marine Resources Committee has given itself until Monday to absolutely, positively produce a lobster bill no one really seems to want, but many say Maine desperately needs. The essence of a compromise bill is to restrict entry into the business and to limit the number of traps allowed each fisherman, measures the independent-minded industry has long opposed, but now says are essential to stave off intervention by the National Marine Fisheries Service. The service estimates Maine lobster is overfished by 20 percent and stands ready to impose a management plan should Maine fail to act. A compromise version that has been on the committee's table for two weeks calls for a 1,200 trap limit, and some form of apprenticeship program and a license moratorium, with numerous exceptions, to limit entry. The bill also proposes dividing the coast into five zones, with elected councils of fishermen able to impose even more severe restrictions.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lobster+proposal+ready+Monday%2C+panel+promises+Marine+Resources+membership+to+poll+lobstermen+over+weekend&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-06-10&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: AUGUSTA -- Leaving deadlines in its wake like chum gone bad, the Marine Resources Committee has given itself until Monday to absolutely, positively produce a lobster bill no one really seems to want, but many say Maine desperately needs.
The essence of a compromise bill is to restrict entry into the business and to limit the number of traps allowed each fisherman, measures the independent-minded industry has long opposed, but now says are essential to stave off intervention by the National Marine Fisheries Service. The service estimates Maine lobster is overfished by 20 percent and stands ready to impose a management plan should Maine fail to act.
Maine now has 6,500 lobstermen fishing an estimated 3 million traps in its premier $75 million fishery with entry open to all and no trap limit.
The committee started more than a month ago with three bills, proposing trap limits ranging from 800 to 1,200 and provisions restricting entry, including a moratorium on new licenses, a rollback in the number of licenses to the 1994 level and a four-year apprenticeship program for newcomers.
A compromise version that has been on the committee's table for two weeks calls for a 1,200 trap limit, and some form of apprenticeship program and a license moratorium, with numerous exceptions, to limit entry. The bill also proposes dividing the coast into five zones, with elected councils of fishermen able to impose even more severe restrictions.
The deadline for committees to report out bills to the full Legislature was June 2, but Marine Resources, with some members in favor of trap limits and some adamantly opposed, was nowhere close to a consensus and so was granted an extension until this week.
The situation deteriorated at what was supposed to be the committee's final work session Wednesday, when those in favor of trap limits could not agree on an actual number and the entire panel was all over the map on how to restrict entry and the length of the apprenticeship program.
Many lobstermen stormed from the room, furious that the committee appeared to be on the brink of failure.
Fearful that a committee split three or four ways would not be taken seriously by the full Legislature, Sen. Jeffrey Butland, co-chairman of the committee, held a pair of meetings in his office Thursday, one for those favoring trap limits and the other for opponents, to try to get the 13 members back into two clearly defined camps.
The tactic seems to have worked for the pro-trap-limit side, which settled on a limit of 1,200, giving fishermen using more than that eight years to cut back.
That group also agreed to let the Department of Marine Resources design an apprenticeship program for new lobstermen, with a minimum length of two years, requiring experience as a sternman and seminars in biology, law and fishing practices. Those exempt from the apprenticeship program include those who held a lobster license or owned and operated a lobster boat before March 31, and those who held another commercial fishing license, other than shellfish and worms, before March 15.
Exceptions granted by individual appeal include those who let their license lapse for medical reasons and those who made a substantial investment in lobster gear before March 31. The DMR also would have rule-making authority for establishing an undetermined number of local management zones.
The anti-limit side did not reach agreement on any alternate legislation. A legislative source said Friday the attendance at the sessions in Butland's office suggest the pro-limit side may have at least the seven members needed to produce a majority report.
The committee then canceled what was supposed to be its final work session Friday to spend the weekend polling the lobstermen back home, promising to hold its final, final session at 1 p.m. Monday.

Church celebrates 50th anniversary Congregation has witnessed steady growth of Winterport chapel over the years

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]03 June 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413867917?accountid=10457

Abstract: The Calvary Apostolic Church will celebrate its 50th anniversary this weekend. Originally, the church was located in a building on Main Street, but in 1988 a new structure was built on Route 1A, just north of Winterport village. The Rev. W.E. Strout, the current pastor, arrived at the church in the fall of 1985. Strout is a graduate of Texas Bible College, where he received his bachelor's degree in theology.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Church+celebrates+50th+anniversary+Congregation+has+witnessed+steady+growth+of+Winterport+chapel+over+the+years&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-06-03&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   WINTERPORT -- The Calvary Apostolic Church will celebrate its 50th anniversary this weekend.
The church actually opened its doors in July 1944, but did not hold regular services until the spring of 1945.
Originally, the church was located in a building on Main Street, but in 1988 a new structure was built on Route 1A, just north of Winterport village.
The Rev. W.E. Strout, the current pastor, arrived at the church in the fall of 1985. Strout is a graduate of Texas Bible College, where he received his bachelor's degree in theology.
The attendance at Strout's first service 10 years ago was 43, but the congregation soon began to see steady growth.
Seventeen acres were purchased and members of the church labored to build the present facility, which seats 250 people.
Since then, the church also has started a van ministry, which reaches into several communities. The Sunday school, under the direction of Leroy Mayhew, has 33 staff members and a class for every age.
Because of its growth, the church also now employs a full-time associate pastor, the Rev. Bruce Briggs. A new building project, which includes plans to enlarge its sanctuary, Sunday School rooms and offices, is under way. The Community Food Bank also will be housed in the new facility.
On June 4, the church will celebrate both its anniversary and the Pentecost Sunday.
The Rev. Robert Linder, an evangelist from Oyster Bay, N.Y., will preach at the morning and evening services. The morning services begin at 10 a.m., while the evening services begin at 6 p.m.
Illustration Caption: Associate Pastor Bruce Briggs (left) and Pastor W.E. Strout serve the Calvary Apostolic Church in Winterport. (NEWS Photo by Bob DeLong)

____________________________________________________________

Wind and Raves Legends part of windjammers' pasts

Author: Emmet Meara Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]03 June 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413862092?accountid=10457

Abstract: Every windjammer worth its salt has a legend, a story about its glorious past, a special niche among the Maine Windjammer Association lineup. Each boat and captain has its fans. Each customer has a favorite vessel, for reasons only he or she can explain. The 95-foot ketch Angelique of Camden, with Capt. Mike and Lynn McHenry, is unique in that it was built and designed especially for the windjammer trade when it was conceived in 1980 by Imero Gobatto. The unique design features a deckhouse salon. The 89-foot schooner J. and E. Riggin of Rockland, captained by Dave and Sue Allen was built in 1927 for the oyster dredging trade and is noted for its speed. The Riggin won the first and only oyster schooner race on Delaware Bay decades ago. The Riggin was discovered and revitalized in 1974, and is now a National Historic Landmark.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Wind+and+Raves+Legends+part+of+windjammers%27+pasts&amp;author=Emmet+Meara+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-06-03&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   CAMDEN -- Every windjammer worth its salt has a legend, a story about its glorious past, a special niche among the Maine Windjammer Association lineup. Each boat and captain has its fans. Each customer has a favorite vessel, for reasons only he or she can explain.
The 95-foot ketch Angelique of Camden, with Capt. Mike and Lynn McHenry, is unique in that it was built and designed especially for the windjammer trade when it was conceived in 1980 by Imero Gobatto. The unique design features a deckhouse salon.
The 80-foot coaster Grace Bailey of Camden (alias Mattie), captained by Ray and Ann Williamson, was built in 1882 and hauled timber and granite to the West Indies until 1940.
The 89-foot schooner J. and E. Riggin of Rockland, captained by Dave and Sue Allen was built in 1927 for the oyster dredging trade and is noted for its speed. The Riggin won the first and only oyster schooner race on Delaware Bay decades ago. The Riggin was discovered and revitalized in 1974, and is now a National Historic Landmark.
The oldest in the fleet is the 64-foot coastal schooner Lewis R. French of Camden, captained by Dan and Kathy Pease, launched in 1871 in Christmas Cove. She earned her keep for a century hauling salt, fish, coal, lime bricks and even Christmas trees along the coast.
The 90-foot Mary Day of Camden, captained by Stephen and Chris Cobb, was built in the early 1970s, the first pure sail schooner built in Maine since 1930.
The 78-foot Mercantile of Camden, with Captains Ray and Ann Williamson, was built in Little Deer Isle in 1916 and carried fish, barrel staves and firewood for the lime kilns of Rockport. It became a cruise schooner in 1942 under industry founder Capt. Frank Swift.
The 82-foot schooner Nathaniel Bowditch of Rockland, captained by Gib and Terry Philbrick was built as a racing yacht in 1922 in East Boothbay and won special honors in the 1923 Bermuda Race. The Bowditch served under the Coast Guard during World War II.
The 112-foot Roseway of Camden, captained by George and Leslie Sloane, was built in Essex, Mass., in 1922 to be used as a sports fishing yacht, but spent 32 years escorting ships through Boston Harbor for the Boston Pilots Association. She has been carrying passengers since 1975.
The 78-foot Timberwind of Rockport, captained by Rick Miles, was built in 1931, and served as Portland's pilot boat for 38 years before being converted to a cruise schooner in 1969. She has never left Maine waters.
The 170-foot three-masted "ram schooner" Victory Chimes of Rockland was built in 1900 in Bethel, Del., to carry lumber up and down the shallow bays of the Chesapeake. The vessel was abandoned, then discovered and restored by Capt. Frederick Guild. The Chimes, now captained by Kip Files and Paul DeGaeta, is the only remaining three-masted schooner carrying passengers. The vessel was renamed the "Domino Effect" when it was purchased by a pizza magnate in the mid-1980s. But it returned to Maine and its original name in 1990.
Although it is bad form to mention it in Camden, Rockland has taken away the mantle of the "windjammer capital of the world," once available space was all taken up in Camden.
Rockland schooners that have chosen not to join the Maine Windjammer Association include the North End Shipyard fleet of Heritage, American Eagle and Isaac H. Evans, the Barnes family fleet of Pauline and Steven Taber plus independents Wendameen and Surprise.
For more information about schooner cruises, call the Maine Windjammer Association at 1-800-736-7981. Those windjammers not belonging to the association can be found in the telephone directory under their individual schooner names.

Title: Wind and Raves Legends part of windjammers' pasts:   [ALL Edition ]

Abstract: A Harpswell man has been charged with aggravated assault on a woman in a case that investigators believe is linked to last week's melee at the Harpswell Town Office over clamming licenses.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Harpswell+man+charged+with+assault&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-05-31&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: TOPSHAM -- A Harpswell man has been charged with aggravated assault on a woman in a case that investigators believe is linked to last week's melee at the Harpswell Town Office over clamming licenses.
Topsham police said a criminal summons has been issued to Michael Taylor, 34, who is scheduled to be arraigned June 14 on the charge stemming from a May 23 assault on Kitty Garland.
Garland, 29, of Brunswick was thrown from a car and spent the night hospitalized with a broken jaw and a large bruise on her head, investigators said.
The assault came within hours of the violence at the Harpswell Town Office that officials likened to a small riot. The melee occurred when angry diggers showed up at a meeting of the town's shellfish committee to protest the revocation of clamming licenses.
Garland is the sister of Scott Moody, the chairman of the shellfish committee.

____________________________________________________________

Red tide causes closures State's mussel ban expands

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]29 May 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413846334?accountid=10457

Abstract: It's impossible to predict whether newly expanded mussel harvesting closures due to the red tide will last a few weeks or the whole summer, a Department of Marine Resources official says. The state last Tuesday banned the harvesting of mussels and carnivorous snails from the New Hampshire border to Cape Elizabeth, then expanded the ban a day later to include the area between Basin Point in Harpswell and Small Point in Phippsburg. The state also closed an area around Phippsburg to the harvesting of all shellfish. That area is from Bald Head to northern Bear Island.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Red+tide+causes+closures+State%27s+mussel+ban+expands&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-05-29&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PORTLAND -- It's impossible to predict whether newly expanded mussel harvesting closures due to the red tide will last a few weeks or the whole summer, a Department of Marine Resources official says.
"This happens every year," said DMR's Robert Lewis. "Some years the problem is hardly noticeable, some years it approaches disaster proportions."
The state last Tuesday banned the harvesting of mussels and carnivorous snails from the New Hampshire border to Cape Elizabeth, then expanded the ban a day later to include the area between Basin Point in Harpswell and Small Point in Phippsburg.
The state also closed an area around Phippsburg to the harvesting of all shellfish. That area is from Bald Head to northern Bear Island.
Red tide is caused by algae that contains a natural toxin and it can be fatal if ingested by people, but the closures have the potential to hurt the shellfish harvesting industry as well.
"Red tides always make shellfishermen a little bit nervous," said Thomas Fahey, Harpswell's shellfish warden. "It can really cut down on the harvest and the amount of money they make."
Red tides are caused by blooms of microscopic plants. In Florida and California, the blooms turn the water red, but the algae in Maine is greenish and is not visible in the water, Lewis said.
The plants enter the meat of shellfish because of the way shellfish filter water through their bodies to feed. Red tides do not affect fish, lobsters or crabs.
People can get sick from eating shellfish contaminated by red tide because the microscopic plants contain a poison called saxitoxin.
Saxitoxin is one of the most toxic natural substances on earth, said John Hurst, who tests shellfish for the state. It hinders the ability of the nervous system to function, Hurst said.
One of the worst red tide outbreaks occurred in 1972, when 30 people in New England got sick. Lewis said there are no recorded cases of anybody in Maine dying from red tide poisoning.
For shellfish harvesters, the red tides limit the area where they can work at a time when shellfish are in the highest demand and selling for the highest prices.
Fahey said that during the summer, a bushel of about 1,200 clams will sell for about $150, three times as much as the rest of the year. "This just adds to the tension of being in this business," he said.

Title: Red tide causes closures State's mussel ban expands:   [ALL Edition ]

Clammers may face charges Official wants flats closed after brawl

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]25 May 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413825736?accountid=10457

Abstract: A Harpswell selectman plans to ask the state to close the local clam flats for 30 days as a result of a brawl in the town office that he likened to a rugby match. Fists and furniture flew Tuesday evening in the melee that went on for 10 to 15 minutes. Dozens of people were caught up in the fisticuffs and some suffered minor injuries, including bruises and a possible broken ankle. Selectman Ronald Johnson said he plans to ask Marine Resources Commissioner Robin Alden to shut down the Harpswell clam flats for 30 days.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Clammers+may+face+charges+Official+wants+flats+closed+after+brawl&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-05-25&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: HARPSWELL -- A Harpswell selectman plans to ask the state to close the local clam flats for 30 days as a result of a brawl in the town office that he likened to a rugby match.
Fists and furniture flew Tuesday evening in the melee that went on for 10 to 15 minutes. Dozens of people were caught up in the fisticuffs and some suffered minor injuries, including bruises and a possible broken ankle.
At least two people may face assault charges, said Cumberland County Sheriff's Deputy Terry Goan. He would not name the two and said the matter was being investigated by the District Attorney's Office.
Although it was unclear who threw the first punch and what triggered the violence, it appeared to be linked to unrest over the lifting of commercial digging licenses held by three people whom officials claim are not residents of the town.
Selectman Ronald Johnson said he plans to ask Marine Resources Commissioner Robin Alden to shut down the Harpswell clam flats for 30 days.
"These guys are going to have to be sent a message that stuff like that doesn't go on in this town," Johnson said.
An argument between Shellfish Committee Chairman Scott Moody and Paul Burr preceeded the violence. Burr is one of the three who lost his license and is threatening to challenge the town's action in court.
Moody, who has held the shellfish committee chairmanship for the past year, successfully lobbied for the town to break off a longtime arrangement in which diggers from Harpswell and Brunswick could work the flats in either community.
Johnson was at a meeting downstairs in the town office when he heard the fight break out upstairs and went to see what was happening.
Johnson said he saw two piles of 40 to 50 bodies rumbling, "just like rugby football."

____________________________________________________________

Brown travels sports world on his knees

Author: Dowd, Mike

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 May 1995: PDA.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413810772?accountid=10457

Abstract: The Waterville native has a booming orthopedic practice in Portland. But for three or four weeks a year, if your satellite dish is aimed right, you're apt to spy him standing on the sidelines of sports venues all over the world. He's the one with his eyes focused at knee-level. "My practice is limited to sports medicine, basically the knee," said the 49-year-old surgeon, who once played American Legion baseball for John Winkin in Waterville. "I spend 100 percent of my time on the knee. My specialty is knee reconstruction, ligament reconstruction, and arthroscopic surgery. A day doesn't go by I don't see a college or high school athlete." Remember Kirk Matthieu, the record-setting running back for Maine Maritime Academy a few years back? It was [Doug] Brown's surgical skill that kept Matthieu on the field, enabling him to rush for 5,180 yards despite two serious knee injuries.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Brown+travels+sports+world+on+his+knees&amp;author=Dowd%2C+Mike&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-05-24&amp;spage=PDA&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   If you can fix a damaged knee, the world of sports is your oyster.
Just ask Doug Brown, M.D., quite possibly Maine's best-traveled sports figure of the moment. That is, if he's not off in some operating room rescuing another limping athlete's career.
The Waterville native has a booming orthopedic practice in Portland. But for three or four weeks a year, if your satellite dish is aimed right, you're apt to spy him standing on the sidelines of sports venues all over the world. He's the one with his eyes focused at knee-level.
"My practice is limited to sports medicine, basically the knee," said the 49-year-old surgeon, who once played American Legion baseball for John Winkin in Waterville. "I spend 100 percent of my time on the knee. My specialty is knee reconstruction, ligament reconstruction, and arthroscopic surgery. A day doesn't go by I don't see a college or high school athlete."
Remember Kirk Matthieu, the record-setting running back for Maine Maritime Academy a few years back? It was Brown's surgical skill that kept Matthieu on the field, enabling him to rush for 5,180 yards despite two serious knee injuries.
That ability is also what's kept Brown traveling from Russia to Central America to South America tending to the knees and other aching parts of some of the top amateur athletes in the U.S. He travels at the teams' expense. Knee experts get to do that.
"I started out as a team physician at the U.S. Naval Academy," Brown said, replaying his introduction to his now two-decades-old global practice. "Through contacts there I got involved as an Olympic volunteer, which is basically a three-step program."
Step one, Brown was a physician at the U.S. Olympic training site at Colorado Springs in the early 1980s. He did so well he was selected to work the Olympic Festival, step two.
The third step is to work international events, which Brown began doing at the World University Games in Japan in 1985.
Since then, Brown has made 19 trips all around the globe with various U.S. amateur athletic teams. Women's gymastics... men's soccer... Lately, women's soccer. He's a physician for the U.S. Soccer Federation.
Next up: Brown will accompany the U.S. Women's National Soccer Team to Sweden for the second World Cup Championship games beginning June 6.
That's a long way for a former Bowdoin College hockey and baseball player to travel.
"I was always involved in athletics as a participant. When I got into orthopedic surgery, that choice was related to my previous experience in sports. I saw a lot of injuries. When I was doing my residency at the University of Vermont in the early '70s, sports medicine was just beginning," Brown explained.
He is a now a seasoned pro in the field. He performs more than a hundred knee surgeries a year. On the road, he deals with sprains, bruises and the psychological wounds that come with them. He even stitched up the forehead of a female soccer player who collided with another player trying to head the ball.
All those years of experience have led Brown to make some observations about modern sports and the human anatomy. Among them:
Women injure their knees in competition significantly more often than men.
"That's absolutely true in my practice. The incidence of serious knee injuries in young women, particularly women basketball players, is very high, for reasons we don't understand. The rate of injury is about double the rate of men in basketball. That's something that needs to be studied," Brown said.
Soccer is not the injury-free sport many parents believe.
"Soccer has attracted parents because it's non-violent. If you focus just on the knee, soccer is no free ride. The injury rate is only a little less than football," he observed.
Today's athletes are no more or less injury-prone than their predecessors.
"Increased participation is the reason there are so many knee injuries. A friend of mine does a lot of research in skiing. He's found the rate of injury hasn't diminished, it's stayed constant." Brown said.
The reason U.S. teams need someone like Brown traveling with them is simple.
"The major need for a physician is on extended trips outside the U.S. where you need a friendly face if anything happens," said Doug Brown, a friendly face, but more importantly, someone who knows how to fix a knee.
Illustration Caption: Brown

Five acts join Spudstock lineup

Author: Dale McGarrigle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]19 May 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413754793?accountid=10457

Abstract: Promoters of the planned Spudstock music festival have announced the headliners for the July event. Joining the lineup for the three-day concert set for July 21-23 in Fort Fairfield are John Anderson, Eddie Money, Blue Oyster Cult, The Guess Who and Rick Derringer. "This is not a single-performer event," said Bob Johnston, co-promoter of the event with Jim Ossie, both Fort Fairfield natives. "Even the lesser-known bands have horsepower in and of themselves."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Five+acts+join+Spudstock+lineup&amp;author=Dale+McGarrigle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-05-19&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Promoters of the planned Spudstock music festival have announced the headliners for the July event.
Joining the lineup for the three-day concert set for July 21-23 in Fort Fairfield are John Anderson, Eddie Money, Blue Oyster Cult, The Guess Who and Rick Derringer.
This quintet was added to 11 previously announced artists, which includes the Outlaws and Quiet Riot. Talent procurer Chuck Kruger of Thomaston estimated that the bands involved have racked up 150 Top 10 hits. He said Thursday that another one or two acts could still be added.
"This is not a single-performer event," said Bob Johnston, co-promoter of the event with Jim Ossie, both Fort Fairfield natives. "Even the lesser-known bands have horsepower in and of themselves."
Johnston said that the talent budget "exceeded six figures."
Country singer John Anderson is probably the hottest of the announced acts. His hit singles include "Country `Til I Die," "Money in the Bank," "Seminole Wind" and "Straight Tequila Night."
Rocker Eddie Money, who played in Bangor only last year, is best known for the 3-million seller "Two Tickets to Paradise." His other hits include "Take Me Home Tonight," "Baby Hold Onto Me" and "Shakin'. "
Guitarist Rick Derringer first gained popularity in the McCoys, with the chart-topping tune "Hang on Sloopy." He went on to perform with both Johnny and Edgar Winter, and to record the hit single "Rock & Roll Hoochie Coo."
"Don't Fear the Reaper," Blue Oyster Cult's signature tune, was on everyone's radio back in 1976. The tune made a comeback last year, heard in the Stephen King miniseries "The Stand."
Canadian rockers The Guess Who, with original members Jim Kale and Garry Peterson, will be bringing such hits as "American Woman", "Undun" and "These Eyes."
Tickets for Spudstock are being sold as a three-day package only, not in single-day increments. Tickets, which are general admission only, are $39 in advance and $50 the day of the show. Children under 12, accompanied by a parent or guardian, will be admitted free. Free camping will be available on the site located on Fort Fairfield's Center Limestone Road.
With the lineup pretty well set, Johnston confidently predicted, "We're going to sell 30,000 tickets, and probably have to turn people away."
Johnston said he was unable to give an estimate as to how many tickets have been sold thus far. But Ossie said that the co-promoters were generally pleased with the way ticket sales were going.
Johnston said that Canadians will make up 40 percent of the audience. Tickets are the same price in Canadian dollars.
"We want to give Canadians every encouragement, every inducement to attend Spudstock," he said.
The Spudstock hot line number is (207) 828-2787.

____________________________________________________________

Shellfish committee rejects clam plan Diggers adamant about keeping control

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]17 May 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413940733?accountid=10457

Abstract: At a public hearing Monday night at the town office, clam diggers and the conservation committee gave local resident Paul Thompson two reasons for rejecting his plan for leasing 10 acres of town clam beds to install about 2 acres of clam demonstration plots. Peter Taylor, one of the town's 54 commercial clam diggers, predicted that if any of Cutler's clam beds were leased to private clam farmers for experimental plots or other uses, the town would lose control over its industry. The day of free digging would be over, he said. His other reason for not wanting government intervention, he said, was because local clamflats have received a windfall of baby clams this spring. "There should be no need for developing a clam seed hatchery in the town," he said. "Seed is in every corner. Our clams are doing well. Clamming is looking up."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Shellfish+committee+rejects+clam+plan+Diggers+adamant+about+keeping+control&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-05-17&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: CUTLER -- The shellfish conservation committee wants a $35,000 federal grant used for rearing lobsters or other seafood, rather than for demonstrating how local clams may be grown more productively.
At a public hearing Monday night at the town office, clam diggers and the conservation committee gave local resident Paul Thompson two reasons for rejecting his plan for leasing 10 acres of town clam beds to install about 2 acres of clam demonstration plots.
Peter Taylor, one of the town's 54 commercial clam diggers, predicted that if any of Cutler's clam beds were leased to private clam farmers for experimental plots or other uses, the town would lose control over its industry. The day of free digging would be over, he said.
"We are scared to death to open that door. If we let our clams go, we won't get them back," he declared.
His other reason for not wanting government intervention, he said, was because local clamflats have received a windfall of baby clams this spring. "There should be no need for developing a clam seed hatchery in the town," he said. "Seed is in every corner. Our clams are doing well. Clamming is looking up."
Other diggers stated that Cutler's clam industry would be even stronger if the town was not compelled to sell 10 percent of its commercial licenses to non-residents. "That regulation is no good and we should get rid of it," one digger said. By one estimate, about 1,000 bushels of 2-inch clams are taken each year by non-residents.
Members of the shellfish committee recently completed a spot inventory of clam populations, however, and found Cutler's clam beds to have an abundance of clams smaller than the 2-inch minimum. One sampling, from a plot 2 feet square, yielded 60 clams. The average yield was 15 to 20 clams, however.
Thompson cautioned the diggers that the unusually large amount of tiny seed clams may represent a "one-year class of good seed," while future years may be less productive. "Five to 10 years ago, the seed wasn't here," he said.
In his four-year plan for enhancing the local clam industry, Thompson said he wanted the selectmen to close a 10-acre section of the most underproductive clamflats. He first needed the conservation committee's backing, which he failed to receive at the hearing.
Had his project won committee support, he would have developed a variety of test plots. He would have cleared all clams from some plots and planted baby clams from the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery. The plantings would have been covered with plastic mesh for predator protection. Some plots would have been left unprotected. Yet other plots would have retained existing clam populations.
Thompson, who received the $35,000 grant from the U.S. Commerce Department's National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration subject to the committee's backing, estimated that some of his managed plots would have produced double the average daily harvest -- "$200 a day instead of the $100 you now may be earning."
Although the committee did not support Thompson's clam plan, he did receive its strong support for an alternate plan to build a floating lobster hatchery within a private lease of 10 acres of sub-tidal territory in Cutler Harbor. The advantage of a floating hatchery, he said, is that you can expand by just adding another float. In the basement of the town office, where the original hatchery was operated successfully several years ago, there was no space to expand. Dampness from the salt water was bad for the building, and the original lobster hatchery was closed.
Oysters will be included in Thompson's new floating hatchery. "I've purchased some oysters and will be doing some test beds on a small scale," he said.

____________________________________________________________

Tremont unhappy with recycling deal Town vows it won't pay without service

Author: Kathy Harbour Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]10 May 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413774292?accountid=10457

Abstract: Discontent was raised at Tuesday's town meeting about Tremont's recycling contract with a private Southwest Harbor company. Tremont is one of several towns in the area, including Southwest Harbor and Trenton, that contracted with EMR for recycling. As part of that contract, according to Price, EMR agreed to build a facility where recyclables would be accepted and weighed, sorted and baled, and then readied for resale. Each town would then eventually recoup a percentage of the proceeds from the resale. Price said EMR has failed to construct the building, does no weighing by town, and does not sort or bale the recyclables for resale. "Over $250,000 has been sunk into this project by Tremont, Southwest Harbor and Trenton," Price said. "And so far, no building, no balers, no resale program, nothing."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Tremont+unhappy+with+recycling+deal+Town+vows+it+won%27t+pay+without+service&amp;author=Kathy+Harbour+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-05-10&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   TREMONT -- Discontent was raised at Tuesday's town meeting about Tremont's recycling contract with a private Southwest Harbor company.
Selectman Alison Price expressed displeasure with the contract with Eastern Maine Recycling, saying owner Lee Worcester has "breached his contract" with the town.
Tremont is one of several towns in the area, including Southwest Harbor and Trenton, that contracted with EMR for recycling. As part of that contract, according to Price, EMR agreed to build a facility where recyclables would be accepted and weighed, sorted and baled, and then readied for resale. Each town would then eventually recoup a percentage of the proceeds from the resale.
According to Price, those terms of the agreement have not been fulfilled.
"He hasn't lived up to his agreement," Price said, adding that selectmen will meet with Worcester in coming weeks to share mounting concerns that specific parts of the 10-year contract have not been fulfilled after three years.
Price said EMR has failed to construct the building, does no weighing by town, and does not sort or bale the recyclables for resale. "Over $250,000 has been sunk into this project by Tremont, Southwest Harbor and Trenton," Price said. "And so far, no building, no balers, no resale program, nothing."
EMR has indicated that it plans to have the building constructed this summer.
Southwest Harbor voters had a similar opinion at their town meeting last week. Voters there decided to delay appropriating any money for that part of the budget, giving their town officials times to decide whether the contract had been breached. They will continue the town meeting on June 29 to vote on the appropriation.
In Tremont, at the urging of town selectmen, voters appropriated the requested sum for solid waste and recycling. But selectmen assured residents they would be unwilling to pay EMR the amount owed if they found that the terms of the contract were invalid.
"Have faith in us that we will fight this battle," Price said. "We won't pay unless we have to."
With no discussion, Tremont voters slashed to zero a suggested $15,000 appropriation to pay for the disposal of fish and shellfish waste generated by local businesses. Last year the town appropriated $15,000 for the cost of composting 140 tons of crab waste. Without town funds, shellfish dealers will now have to foot that bill.
In other business, the fewer than 70 people in attendance passed the school budget as recommended and agreed the town could borrow up to $25,000 for the construction of a boat access ramp at Bernard. The state, through the boat facilities division of the Bureau of Parks and Recreation, has said it will fund 75 percent of the total cost of the project, which could be about $100,000.
The $25,000 debt will be repaid from the revenue the town generates at the town wharf property. Last year, Tremont earned more than $10,000 in revenue from that property.
Tremont voters on Tuesday also agreed the size of the school board should increase from three to five members, beginning with the 1996 town elections. The school board did not agree the change was needed, but the move was supported by the selectmen.

Tremont voters decide next week on officers, $1.99 million budget

Author: Kathy Harbour Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]04 May 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413782355?accountid=10457

Abstract: Voters will act on a combined $1.99 million budget at town meeting set for 7 p.m. Tuesday at the community building. Town Manager Fay Lawson said Wednesday that if the budget is approved as recommended by selectmen, property taxes will increase by no more than one mill. That increase would mean an additional $100 in the annual tax bill for property assessed at $100,000. The projected elementary school budget includes a minimal increase, Lawson said. Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Tremont+voters+decide+next+week+on+officers%2C+%241.99+million+budget&amp;author=Kathy+Harbour+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-05-04&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: TREMONT -- Voters will act on a combined $1.99 million budget at town meeting set for 7 p.m. Tuesday at the community building.
Election of municipal officers takes place from 1 p.m. to 8 p.m. on Monday.
Selectman Alison Price is running unopposed for another term. Patricia Pinkham is also unopposed for a three-year term on the school board, a seat being vacated by Don Ellis, chairman.
Town Manager Fay Lawson said Wednesday that if the budget is approved as recommended by selectmen, property taxes will increase by no more than one mill. That increase would mean an additional $100 in the annual tax bill for property assessed at $100,000.
The projected elementary school budget includes a minimal increase, Lawson said. The budget includes funds to rent a portable classroom for next year to deal with overcrowding. The school committee has chosen not to bring a school expansion project to a vote at town meeting, with that decision possibly to come before voters at a special meeting later in the year.
Voters at town meeting will be asked to approve borrowing up to $25,000 for the development of a boat access ramp at Bernard. The state, through the boat facilities division of the Bureau of Parks and Recreation, has given its assurance of state funding to pay for 75 percent of the cost to develop the ramp. The state has said the project should cost less than $100,000.
Lawson said the boat ramp would be for recreational boaters. She said the $25,000 debt would be repaid from the revenue the town generates at the town wharf property. Last year, Tremont earned more than $10,000 in revenue from that property.
Another warrant article likely to stimulate discussion at town meeting is a proposed increase in the size of the school board from three to five members. The article appears on the warrant at the suggestion of a resident who brought the proposal to the Board of Selectmen. The selectmen recommend passage of the article, but it is not supported by the warrant committee.
Lawson said she expects a written resolution from the school board, before Tuesday's meeting, that states the board also does not want to see its membership increase.
The selectmen and warrant committee are making no recommendation on whether the town should raise $15,000 for the disposal of fish and shellfish waste generated by local businesses. The businesses pay to have the shellfish waste trucked to one of two state-approved compost sites. Last year, more than 140 tons of crab waste was composted. The town appropriated $15,000 last year.

Harrington banks on clam project Restoration effort plants baby mollusks

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]26 Apr 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413819582?accountid=10457

Abstract: The town's clam conservation committee is gambling $373 that 1 million baby clams planted Sunday may be worth as much as $49,000 by the fall of 1998. The committee expects to reap at least $28,000 if the town harvests the 1 acre of clam beds that was reseeded in the new Norris Pinkham Sr. Memorial Clam Restoration Project, located off Oak Point in Flat Bay. Walter Shafer, secretary for the clam committee, said in an interview Tuesday that if the reclamation project results in a 60 percent clam survival rate, the next three spring and summer growing seasons should produce 400 bushels of 2-inch clams valued at about $70 a bushel -- or a total market value of $28,000.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Harrington+banks+on+clam+project+Restoration+effort+plants+baby+mollusks&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-04-26&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   HARRINGTON -- The town's clam conservation committee is gambling $373 that 1 million baby clams planted Sunday may be worth as much as $49,000 by the fall of 1998.
The committee expects to reap at least $28,000 if the town harvests the 1 acre of clam beds that was reseeded in the new Norris Pinkham Sr. Memorial Clam Restoration Project, located off Oak Point in Flat Bay.
Sixteen clam diggers and eight Narraguagus High School science students worked three hours Sunday to plant 1 million three-eighths-inch baby clams.
Walter Shafer, secretary for the clam committee, said in an interview Tuesday that if the reclamation project results in a 60 percent clam survival rate, the next three spring and summer growing seasons should produce 400 bushels of 2-inch clams valued at about $70 a bushel -- or a total market value of $28,000.
"Should those 1-year-old clams enjoy a survival rate of 100 percent, they could grow to 700 bushels, or $49,000 on the open market three years from now," said Brian Beal, a University of Maine at Machias marine scientist. He assisted the committee in its largest clam restoration project.
Shafer explained that the project got a lot of cooperation from the Department of Environmental Protection, a local lobster pound owner, volunteer clam diggers, and NHS students. It got 2 1/2 5-gallon buckets of baby clams from the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery.
A major player in the project was Richard Dorr, who wanted to expand his lobster pound about 1 acre on Flat Bay. Through an accord with the DEP, he agreed to compensate for taking of clam flats by putting up the $2,000 used to purchase 1 million clams from the hatchery for the restoration project.
Dorr also donated $500 toward Harrington's cost of purchasing $1,373 worth of plastic netting, leaving the town with a total dollar investment of only $373. The approximately 1 acre of quarter-inch mesh netting was later cut into 64 bed covers. Each cover measured 14 by 24 feet.
With committee Chairman Jim Benner supervising Sunday's reseeding project, the 64 seed plots were each seeded by Beal. He said it was the largest town clam seeding project that he had experienced in his eight years of work as consultant for the hatchery. He added it would be the only project of such size this year in Washington County.
Clam diggers dug 6-inch-deep trenches around each of the new 64 12-by-20-foot clam beds. Then the students, under supervision of NHS science teacher Ed Reynolds, cut the plastic netting into 64 covers that were placed on top of the clam beds to protect the baby clams from predators.
Edges of the netting were locked into place by a 6-inch-deep covering of mud. Participating students were Kelly Benner, Ryan Benner, Jim Burns, Andy Brady, Jessica Rau, Lee Shafer, Justin Torrey and Josh Willey.
The committee is considering several options in the management plan for the new clam project, which was named Sunday in honor of Pinkham, who made part of his living harvesting clams before he died on May 17, 1979, while working at Flat Bay.
Shafer said funds from an anticipated clam harvest in 1998 could be used to pay part or all of a clam warden's salary, or to purchase a warden boat. Also, if the clams are not harvested, their seed would help repopulate the Flat Bay region's larger clam beds.
