Top chefs rave about Maine seafood supplier Portland's Mitchell lines up all kinds of fresh fish for restaurants across the United States

Author: Victoria Brett The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 Apr 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413757677?accountid=10457

Abstract: Before Rod Mitchell, America's top chefs had to make do when it came to seafood. It wasn't always fresh and it certainly wasn't exotic. "When I arrived 15 years ago everything was fresh frozen," said Jean Louis Palladin, one of the nation's most prominent chefs and owner of Jean-Louis at the Watergate in Washington. "Twice a week I got a plane coming in from Paris. I had to buy fish from Paris and I didn't want to do that because this country can have the best product in the world," he said in a rich French accent. Then Palladin met Mitchell while vacationing in Camden about 15 years ago. Mitchell was running a gourmet shop selling wines, cheese and caviar.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Top+chefs+rave+about+Maine+seafood+supplier+Portland%27s+Mitchell+lines+up+all+kinds+of+fresh+fish+for+restaurants+across+the+United+States&amp;author=Victoria+Brett+The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-04-24&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PORTLAND -- Before Rod Mitchell, America's top chefs had to make do when it came to seafood. It wasn't always fresh and it certainly wasn't exotic.
"When I arrived 15 years ago everything was fresh frozen," said Jean Louis Palladin, one of the nation's most prominent chefs and owner of Jean-Louis at the Watergate in Washington. "Twice a week I got a plane coming in from Paris. I had to buy fish from Paris and I didn't want to do that because this country can have the best product in the world," he said in a rich French accent.
"I said, `Let's see, we are the same coast as France, why is there no fish in America?"' he said.
Then Palladin met Mitchell while vacationing in Camden about 15 years ago. Mitchell was running a gourmet shop selling wines, cheese and caviar.
The chef had an idea. He asked Mitchell to supply hand-picked scallops and fresh fish for his four-star restaurant in Washington, where dinner can easily fetch $100 a person not including wine and tip.
Mitchell agreed and was soon on the road to becoming the supplier of seafood to America's top restaurants.
Mitchell initially ran his business from the back of a pickup truck, driving from Rockland to Boston, buying fish and shipping it along the way. Now the 39-year-old runs a multimillion-dollar operation, Browne Trading Co., from a brick building on the Portland waterfront.
Shipping with Federal Express, Mitchell provides seafood for 150 restaurants -- with distributors in Atlanta and Denver -- but still deals directly with the top 20 or 30.
His client list is filled with renowned chefs at four-star restaurants. Wolfgang Puck in California depends on him, as does Daniel Boulud of Daniel's in New York. Other clients include the Ritz Carlton in Atlanta, Jasper's in Boston, and Lespinasse and Le Bernadin in New York.
"We are dealing with the elite of the elite," said Mitchell, dressed casually in jeans with a baseball cap as he heads to the Portland Fish Auction.
"We've changed the fish industry," he added. "Nobody else does it as well."
His customers agree.
"I could buy (seafood) much cheaper in New York, but it would not be the best. For the freshest and the best, he's the man," said chef Daniel Boulud.
The wholesale prices at Browne Trading Co. vary, with some prices on par with those at other wholesale fish supplies and others higher.
Maine salmon goes for $3.50 a pound. Eight gallons of hand-harvested jumbo Maine scallops are $97.60. The Russian Beluga caviar is $37.50 an ounce.
"I'm only looking for the perfect fish," Mitchell said modestly as he handled a recently caught salmon. He explained that it should be stiff and not soft. In a cod you have to "look at the eyes." Scallops: Flick them with your finger and if they move they're fresh. Don't keep lobster in tanks, and use shaved ice with fish to prevent bruising.
Those are just some of the Rod Mitchell tips to the perfect fish, crustacean or mollusk. That, and, "Never ever trust anyone in the seafood business," he said, adding that he's as picky about suppliers as he is about fish.
For example, a woman in Owls Head is his sole supplier of fresh crabmeat. He only trusts a chef-turned-fishmonger to ship him exotic seafood from Hawaii. And Mitchell had to travel to Russia to find the right caviar man.
Mitchell says there was no one like him 15 years ago because, unlike French food, "American cuisine hadn't grown up enough."
It has now. And it is expanding, with Mitchell filling demands for squid ink, octopus salad, sea urchin and baby eels.
"Little by little we have some products like nowhere else can have in the whole world," said Palladin.
Palladin calls Mitchell's product the "top-notch fish in the country."
"He's good for me and good for all the big shots in New York," he said.
Illustration Caption: Rod Mitchell poses with a Casco cod in Portland. (AP Photo)

____________________________________________________________

No reason to celebrate Earth Day

Author: Oden, Nancy

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]22 Apr 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413784272?accountid=10457

Abstract: To live we need clean air, pure water, unpoisoned food, shelter, warmth, friends, etc. Notice that "jobs" and "money" are not among life's necessities; earlier societies survived for millenia without "jobs" or "money." They did have to work, but it was for their own and their communities' well-being, not to fill some bloated corporate/agri-business' pockets. While corporations pay big bucks for self-serving Earth Day ads touting how "clean" they are because they've planted a few trees or recycled a few resources, let's remember how much they waste every day, and that they bring more toxic chemicals into use each year. Then there's Bowater, bringing in waste paper from all over the East Coast to recycle into new paper. Sounds good, doesn't it? What they don't tell us is that many colored inserts and magazines use toxic heavy metals in those pretty colored dyes. When they de-ink the paper, those heavy metal dyes go into the sludge, creating toxic waste, all of which is dumped right here in Maine.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=No+reason+to+celebrate+Earth+Day&amp;author=Oden%2C+Nancy&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-04-22&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: To live we need clean air, pure water, unpoisoned food, shelter, warmth, friends, etc. Notice that "jobs" and "money" are not among life's necessities; earlier societies survived for millenia without "jobs" or "money." They did have to work, but it was for their own and their communities' well-being, not to fill some bloated corporate/agri-business' pockets.
If we canceled all debts and lessened our "money" needs, we could be more self-sufficient, and less in need of "jobs" with corporate/agri-business. We wouldn't have to do their dirty work -- stripping and poisoning our natural resources. In fact, I'd bet we wouldn't let them do it at all.
While corporations pay big bucks for self-serving Earth Day ads touting how "clean" they are because they've planted a few trees or recycled a few resources, let's remember how much they waste every day, and that they bring more toxic chemicals into use each year.
It's spring, so it's time for another six-month-long spraying of pesticides into our woods, waters, air and bodies, causing great damage to our immune syl;stems and to Maine's natural flora and fauna.
I'm more than tired of having dangerous chemicals poured down on me, how about you?
Then there's Bowater, bringing in waste paper from all over the East Coast to recycle into new paper. Sounds good, doesn't it? What they don't tell us is that many colored inserts and magazines use toxic heavy metals in those pretty colored dyes. When they de-ink the paper, those heavy metal dyes go into the sludge, creating toxic waste, all of which is dumped right here in Maine.
Imports of garbage continued unabated. The incinerators in Portland, Biddeford, and Orrington, the dumps in Norridgewock (waste Management Inc.) and Hampden (Tom Sawyer's toxic mountain) all bring in out-of-state garbage. No one really knows what's in it, and no one's running a geiger counter over it.
Potatoes, blueberries, cranberries, apples, crown, Christmas tree farms, forests, roadsides, railroad rights-of-way, electric power line corridors, all get heavily dosed with chemicals every year.
Our taxes support the University Extension Services, long-time chemical pushers. You and I pay for the university's experimental farms. There the workers, under direction of Extension professors, carry out experiments with unregistered killer chemicals. They basically do the chemical companies' work for them, getting new, "better" (more toxic) pesticides approved for use on crops in Maine. You and I pay for this.
There is little experimentation on clean methods of growing food (bug scientists excepted), professors are allowed to accept "consultant" fees from chemical companies, though we pay them to work full-time for us. (I can hear the uproar now, and watch the professors' letters flow in. Nonetheless, it's true.)
Extension professors are responsible for the debacle in potato country, where they recommended piling up blight-infected potatoes. Common sense would have told anyone that airborne fungus should be moved away, instead of trying to kill it with ever more toxic fungicides.
Now, Extension is recommending even heavier pesticide spraying to kill the potato blights, instead of natural, clean practices. Organic farmers I spoke with, who keep pest camage down by rotating crops, building up soil with natural materials, and growing healthy plants, have had only minimal losses from the potato blights. Any natural farmer who knows planting the same crop on the same land for 50 years is bound to bring serious problems, and a steady diet of chemicals eventually just kills the soil so nothing will do well there.
In "wild" blueberry country, the herbicide Velpar is in our drinking water, and has not only killed plants the growers don't want (some of which are useful herbs), but many blueberry plants as well. You cannot keep dumping plant killers on any plant without doing damage.
Cherryfield Foods (owned by a Canadian conglomerate) is knocking down thousands more acres of Maine woods to make more blueberry barrens, which they plan to spray with pesticides with their usual abandon.
Now they've installed 65 miles of underground irrigation pipes, which lower the Pleasant River and nearby bodies of water to unacceptable levels so that Atlantic salmon and other fish fry will be unable to survive. Not only that, but they plan to use chemigation, where they put pesticides into the irrigation pipes and spray thousands of acres, with, you can bet, lots of leakage into the groundwater aquifer.
Does anyone think the pesticides will not back up into the Pleasant River?
Do you think Cherryfield Foods and Jasper Wyman & Sons own the rivers, our drinking water, the air we breathe? I sure don't.
Do you really want to hear all of this? Probably not. Isn't this just all too depressing? Yes, it is. But we have to know what's going on so we can decide whether we're going to let agriculture and industry kill our Earth or not.
We all know by now that pesticides are killing birds, beneficial insects, shellfish, ocean and freshwater fish, honey bees, animals, and us. Most people loathe the pesticide spraying, but feel helpless to do anything about it.
Can we get beyond corporate/agri-business' wall of selfish, gluttonous indifference? Not by appealing to their consciences, I can tell you. But there are actions we can take which will slow down their poisoning, and, if we persist, stop them:
Talk to your relatives, friends, and neighbors who use pestidides, express your concerns, buy yourself (and them) a subscription to Organic Gardening magazine, 33 E. Minor St., Emmaus, Penn. 18098, $20 a year;
Grow some of your own food;
Join a natural foods co-op to buy organically grown produce, grains, and just about everything else;
Watch carefully whenever pesticide spraying is going on near you. If you see pesticides drifting into water or other non-target areas, call the Pesticide Control Board immediately at 287-2731. Tell them you want to file a formal complaint, and to send an enforcement right away to get leaf samples. Be persistent with them. They're used to listening to sprayers; make them start paying attention to real people;
Fight for true democracy, where you and I make the decisions that affect our lives. If we had true democracy, we would be deciding whether pesticides would be sprayed;
Write letters to the editor of your local papers, the Bangor Daily News, state and federal representtives, and anyone else you think could help;
Join a petition campaign to stop aerial spraying of toxic chemicals in Maine. Toxic trespass (pesticide drift) cannot be controlled from airplanes or helicopters since air currents carry poisons into the lungs of all creatures in the area, including us, within minutes. To get petition forms, call me at 434-6228. We're doing this quickly to get signatures delivered to the Pesticide Control Board by mid-May.
Really read the daily newspaper, especially stories about the environment; get to know what you're talking about so the fake scientists can't snow you. Remember, they're paid to make agriculture and industry look good; we have to speak out for ourselves because no one else will.
No, people, there's nothing to celebrate this Earth Day. If we fight for and win some serious victories this year, then we can celebrate next year. But we need to let corporate America know we are not fooled; underneath their "green" images, they're covered by the same old filth.
We need to let corporate/agri-business know we're not going to let them poison us and our children to death. They need to know that either they clean up their act, or we'll do it for them. We're talking self-defense and survival here, people -- I can't put it any stronger than that. And just a small group can't do it alone. Earth needs YOU! Nancy Oden is an organic farmer, beekeeper, and citizen activist. She lives in Jonesboro.

Conservation essays due today at Machias

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]14 Apr 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413871372?accountid=10457

Abstract: April 14 is the deadline for entries in a writing contest for high school students. Entries should be sent to the Washington County Soil & Water Conservation District, P.O. Box 121, Machias 04654.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Conservation+essays+due+today+at+Machias&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-04-14&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: MACHIAS -- April 14 is the deadline for entries in a writing contest for high school students. Entries should be sent to the Washington County Soil & Water Conservation District, P.O. Box 121, Machias 04654.
The winning entry will be featured in a countywide student environmental education newsletter, and must discuss an environmental problem affecting the Washington County area.
The contest is designed to draw attention to the newsletter produced by Americorps members Jane Lamson of the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery and Karen Bert of the WCS&WC District. The newsletter is available at local markets in Machias, Columbia, Jonesport and Eastport, and at participating schools.

Jonesport diver salvages giant propeller

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]05 Apr 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413816640?accountid=10457

Abstract: Douglas Lindsay, 32, a scuba diver from Jonesport, said he was gathering urchins about 10 days ago in 40 feet of water off Red Head, the southeast tip of Beals Island, when he found a ship's massive four-blade propeller teetering on a ledgy shelf. With assistance from brothers Carroll and William Merchant of Jonesport, Lindsay spent several days rounding up 20 empty 55-gallon steel drums and ferrying them to the salvage site. Several dozen feet of chain were purchased. The trio spent Saturday and Sunday filling the drums with sea water and lowering them to the propeller that was encrusted with shellfish and other colorful forms of marine life. Lindsay chained the drums to the propeller and filled each with compressed air, but the scheme failed to lift the propeller that he estimated to weigh six tons.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Jonesport+diver+salvages+giant+propeller&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-04-05&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: JONESPORT -- Douglas Lindsay, 32, a scuba diver from Jonesport, said he was gathering urchins about 10 days ago in 40 feet of water off Red Head, the southeast tip of Beals Island, when he found a ship's massive four-blade propeller teetering on a ledgy shelf.
The huge propeller was lost about 75 years ago from a 298-foot steamship named in honor of Maine's 26th governor, Nelson Dingley Jr.
With assistance from brothers Carroll and William Merchant of Jonesport, Lindsay spent several days rounding up 20 empty 55-gallon steel drums and ferrying them to the salvage site. Several dozen feet of chain were purchased.
The trio spent Saturday and Sunday filling the drums with sea water and lowering them to the propeller that was encrusted with shellfish and other colorful forms of marine life. Lindsay chained the drums to the propeller and filled each with compressed air, but the scheme failed to lift the propeller that he estimated to weigh six tons.
"I had to be very careful not to allow the propeller to slip off the ledge," he said. "Although the shelf was only about 15 feet from shore, the next shelf was down about 120 feet or beyond my reach."
On Monday, Jimmy Lenfestey joined the salvage crew to help attach 10 additional barrels. At 2 p.m., as the last barrels were being filled with air, the propeller began rising slowly toward the surface.
The salvage operation required 27 tanks of compressed air.
For the next six hours, Lindsay towed the mass of barrels eight miles to Jonesport's Sawyer Cove Marina, where a crowd of citizens was waiting. For most, it was the largest propeller they had ever seen. It measured 15 feet in diameter. The drive shaft, about 12 inches in diameter, was broken off in the hub of the propeller.
Lindsay, a New Hampshire native who made Jonesport his home five years ago, said he intends to sell the propeller. "I've got an investment of about $1,500 in it, so I need a buyer," he said, adding that the price of naval bronze scrap metal is about 45 cents a pound, making the propeller worth more than $5,000.
Until he finds a buyer, he will display the propeller on the front lawn of his farm home near the Jonesport-Jonesboro town line, about 10 miles from the marina.
According to Victor Alley, a Jonesporter who discovered statistics on the Governor Dingley in a record of Merchant Steam Vessels of the United States, the vesssel was 298 feet long, 60 feet wide, and had an underwater draft of 17 feet. It had a gross tonnage of 3,826 tons and 2,856 net tons.
Its triple expansion engines and four oil-converted boilers produced 2,500 horsepower.
Built in 1899 at Chester, Pa., for the Portland Steam Packet Co., the ship was named in honor of Maine's 26th governor, Nelson Dingley Sr. Dingley served in the 74th U.S. Congress. With his brother, Fred, he owned the Lewiston Evening Journal newspaper. He died in 1899 and was buried in Oak Hill Cemetery, Auburn. The ship's first home port was Portland.
Bill Barry of the Maine Historical Society at Portland said the ship was designed to include a revolutionary new steel hull. With a crew of 74, it was used as a small ocean liner, carrying passengers and freight between Portland and Boston. Later, the ocean route was shifted to one between Bath and St. John, New Brunswick.
According to Charles Beal of Beals Island, during the latter service route in the 1920s, the ship ran aground at Red Head in the fog and lost the propeller, but survived and was towed to port for repairs.
In 1933, the Governor Dingley was dismantled at Baltimore, Md.
Illustration Caption: A huge propeller, believed lost about 75 years ago from the steamship Governor Dingley, was salvaged Monday from waters off Beals Island by scuba diver Douglas Lindsay of Jonesport. (NEWS Photo by Clayton Beal)

State officials reconsider plan to close clam flats

Author: The Associated Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]25 Mar 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413745797?accountid=10457

Abstract: Responding to complaints from clam diggers, state officials may scale back a plan to avert a potential pollution threat by closing clam flats in the Harraseeket River. Walter Foster, DMR's director of industry services, said he proposed the closure because state guidelines required him to assume that more pleasure boats on the river during warmer months pose a pollution threat because they might illegally discharge waste water into the harbor.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=State+officials+reconsider+plan+to+close+clam+flats&amp;author=The+Associated+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-03-25&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: FREEPORT -- Responding to complaints from clam diggers, state officials may scale back a plan to avert a potential pollution threat by closing clam flats in the Harraseeket River.
Last month, the Department of Marine Resources told diggers it would close the rich flats from April 1 to Nov. 1 between the outflow pipe of Freeport's sewage treatment plant and the marinas.
Walter Foster, DMR's director of industry services, said he proposed the closure because state guidelines required him to assume that more pleasure boats on the river during warmer months pose a pollution threat because they might illegally discharge waste water into the harbor.
State officials monitor the clam flats and periodically close some sections to digging for fear that tainted clams could make consumers sick and damage the reputation of Maine's clam industry.
But Foster said he is reconsidering the extent of the closure because of new information he received from town officials, environmentalists and local marine operators.
"They're providing us with the information we need now to make a better classification of the area," he said. "It indicates that the town and the marina operators have worked very hard to support the shellfish harvesters in the area in establishing the Harraseeket River as a no discharge area."
The local Shellfish Commission collected data for Foster that shows the sections of the river now open to digging are not at risk.
The Shellfish Commission is opposed to the closure, but said if the flats must be off-limits it should only be from June 1 to Sept. 15.
Foster said he expected a decision by next week.
"I'm feeling pretty optimistic about it," said Mick McGivaren, who is in charge of water quality testing for the commission.

____________________________________________________________

d is for dinosaur UMPI museum set to house vast collection of natural history

Author: Debra Sund Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]25 Mar 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413745318?accountid=10457

Abstract: Did you know that the Tyrannosaurus Rex, the lawyer-devouring dinosaur in the movie "Jurassic Park," never lived during the Jurassic period of prehistoric history, but actually came in the later Cretaceous period? There are a few of the gems one can learn while walking the halls of a University of Maine at Presque Isle building, where, after years in storage, vast collections of natural history are on display. For 20 years, there's been an intent to establish a natural history museum, possibly in a separate building on the Presque Isle campus. The lack of funds, however, inhibited the process.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=d+is+for+dinosaur+UMPI+museum+set+to+house+vast+collection+of+natural+history&amp;author=Debra+Sund+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-03-25&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Did you know that the Tyrannosaurus Rex, the lawyer-devouring dinosaur in the movie "Jurassic Park," never lived during the Jurassic period of prehistoric history, but actually came in the later Cretaceous period?
And would you believe that in the next 50 million years, California will become an island, and Saudi Arabia will meld with the Asian continent?
There are a few of the gems one can learn while walking the halls of a University of Maine at Presque Isle building, where, after years in storage, vast collections of natural history are on display.
Fossils, rocks, turtle shells, and flying prehistoric reptiles are the foundation of what will become the Northern Maine Museum of Science.
"Very few people realize how large a collection we have, partly because we weren't doing anything with it," said Kevin McCartney, the school's sole geology professor.
For 20 years, there's been an intent to establish a natural history museum, possibly in a separate building on the Presque Isle campus. The lack of funds, however, inhibited the process.
About a year ago, McCartney started going through the collections and began putting items in display cases along the halls on the second and third floors of Folsom Hall.
"That's a great way to do it, because that means the museum is right there where students can see it and you're not spending any extra resources to do it," McCartney said.
Working on a shoestring budget, McCartney, with the help of talented students, has started lining the halls with exhibits of natural science and history. With modest university funding and grants from NYNEX and the Davis Family Foundation, display cases were purchased, and the museum started becoming a reality.
If all is ready, McCartney hopes the museum will open in September, when the University of Maine System board of trustees meets at UMPI.
Over the years, the Presque Isle campus has acquired natural history items from a variety of sources.
Leroy Norton, a Presque Isle postal worker, collected "everything he could get his hands on" for about 40 years, McCartney said. Although an amateur, he documented items, such as turtle shells and mollusks, as he collected. Such methods will allow scientists to conduct research.
After Norton died in 1970, his collection, including a storage building, was donated to the university.
Portions of collections from the Portland Natural History Museum and from Ricker College in Houlton ended up in Presque Isle after those institutions closed.
In addition, faculty members have accumulated natural history pieces to use in classes and research.
"Out of all this, the University of Maine at Presque Isle has a very good collection of natural history," McCartney said.
Earl Oman, an UMPI work-study student, has built several displays. Oman's latest contribution is a Pterasaur, a flying dinosaur that lived during the Cretaceous Period. One-quarter the actual size, the replica of the flying reptile hangs in the stairway in Folsom Hall.
With wings outstretched, the dinosaur's eyes seem to follow people as they climb from the second to third floor of the building. The dark coloring of the prehistoric form's body was determined by its scavenger lifestyle, McCartney said.
The dinosaur is constructed out of chicken wire and steel with its body fleshed out in plaster of Paris. It was painted by Jeanie McGowan, a student from Presque Isle.
Oman also built the display "Six Hundred Million Years of Earth History," which depicts the movements of the continents throughout history. It even ventures a guess on what the earth will look like in another 50 million years.
Other displays show a tooth from a woolly mammoth, which is bigger than a grapefruit. One display case contains shark teeth, including one from a now extinct shark that was twice as large as the modern great white shark.
Walls displays depict the topography of Aroostook County and another explains the evolution of the dinosaurs.
Future displays will include a large sea turtle, a scale-model solar system, and aerial photographs of Aroostook County. Presque Isle High School students are helping create a "Power of Ten" display on the metric system.
Other possible exhibits include soil displays and agricultural practices.
Besides elementary and high school groups, the museum will fill a need at the university level, McCartney said.
"In Aroostook County, so many of the students don't have the resources to visit museums in Boston or even out of the County," he said. "This is going to give them an opportunity to see some quality science displays."
Illustration Caption: Geology professor Kevin McCartney (above) is organizing the Northern Maine Museum of Science at UMPI. Among the displays is the pterasaur, created by student Earl Oman. (NEWS Photos by Gloria Flannery)

____________________________________________________________

Town Meetings

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]23 Mar 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413937490?accountid=10457

Abstract: CUSHING -- In a 90-minute session Tuesday night, Cushing voters rejected a clam ordinance, but passed all articles, re-elected all officers and approved a budget of about $100,000 with little change from last year. "It was one of the dullest town meetings I have ever been to," said Friendship Town Clerk Beverly Zahner-Hoonout following the Tuesday night session, which ended in a mere 55 minutes. In balloting conducted Monday, Peter Mason edged Mary Merrill 159-113 for a three-year term on the SAD 40 board of directors. Carl Mueller was re-elected to a three-year term on the board of selectmen unopposed. Zahner-Hoonout was re-elected to her fifth term as clerk.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Town+Meetings&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-03-23&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Cushing
CUSHING -- In a 90-minute session Tuesday night, Cushing voters rejected a clam ordinance, but passed all articles, re-elected all officers and approved a budget of about $100,000 with little change from last year.
Town Clerk Norma Gardner, reelected to her seventh term, said Cushing residents couldn't seem to find anything to argue about this year.
Her husband, Richard Gardner, was re-elected as selectman unopposed to a three-year term.
Voters approved $15,000 requested by Fire Chief Arthur Kiskilla for a truck replacement fund. Chief Kiskilla said three of the fire engines are more than 20 years old and require high maintenance.
Friendship
"It was one of the dullest town meetings I have ever been to," said Friendship Town Clerk Beverly Zahner-Hoonout following the Tuesday night session, which ended in a mere 55 minutes.
The voters agreed to raise $368,000, only a slight change from last year's budget. All items were passed as proposed, including a reauthorization of the shellfish ordinance, which passed 166-85.
In balloting conducted Monday, Peter Mason edged Mary Merrill 159-113 for a three-year term on the SAD 40 board of directors. Carl Mueller was re-elected to a three-year term on the board of selectmen unopposed. Zahner-Hoonout was re-elected to her fifth term as clerk.
The town made no decision on a proposal to lease a new firetruck. The truck could be the subject of a special town meeting.
Corinth
About 60 Corinth voters attended their annual town meeting Tuesday, quickly dispensing with 58 articles in 1 1/2 hours.
Voter approval on all monetary requests resulted in a municipal budget of $546,478 for the coming year, according to Donald Strout, town manager. This will increase the tax rate of $9.50 per $1,000 valuation to about $10.
Voters approved a junkyard ordinance which will require all property owners who have three or more unregistered vehicles in their yards to obtain a junkyard permit.
The sum of $60,500 was approved to pay off the first-year payment to close the town's landfill. Strout said Corinth will qualify for the state program where the town will be reimbursed from the state for 75 percent of the closing costs. The estimated cost for the project is $200,000.
Voters also approved an article allowing for $30,000 worth of improvements to the tennis and basketball courts at the town's recreation field and $5,000 to pay for computer programming upgrades at the town office.
Annual elections were held Monday with 49 residents voting.
Frank Thomas won election to a three-year term as selectman, assessor and overseer of the poor. Michael McDonald was elected to a three-year opening on the SAD 64 board and Ardith Vesta was chosen as a trustee to the cemetery committee.
Marie McCorrison was elected town clerk. All candidates were unopposed.
Eddington
Recycling trash and naming roads were two of the hot topics during Tuesday's town meeting.
A total of $4,000 was added to the town's budget for a roadside recycling program, which is expected to begin this summer after the bidding process, according to Town Manager Audrey Fox.
Residents also agreed to let its board of selectmen give names to the town's unnamed public and private roads.
All told, Fox said, the town passed a budget of $348,184. That figure does not include a budget for the school system, Fox added.
Townspeople did vote down a yard sale ordinance, which would have restricted residents to no more than six yard sales per year, including no more than two sales in a 30-day period.
During Monday's town elections, Martin Somers won a three-year term as school district director. Somers won the position over Philip Robinson. Somers garnered 55 votes to Robinson's 34.
Paul Gargan and Russell Smith were each re-appointed selectmen for three years after running unopposed.
Pamela Violette won the 1-year treasurer position, also running unopposed.
Fox said she was very disappointed in the showing of only 53 people, out of a population of 1,900.
Parkman
Parkman residents took no action on proposed amendments to the town's land use zoning ordinance at the annual town meeting Saturday.
Many of those who spoke believed that if their lots met the road frontage and the minimum lot size requirements, that it should be enough.
Town officials had sought to prohibit spaghetti lots with the adoption of a lot ratio of 4-1. They also had hoped residents would amend the ordinance to require anyone to make necessary repairs to damage done to a town road on which maintenance had been discontinued.
About 50 people attended the more than two-hour meeting during which the following were returned to office: Merle Gilbert Jr., Board of Selectmen; Pat Johnson, chairman of the Board of Selectmen; Lorene Bridges, library trustee, and Paul Bridge, HAD 4 director. David Littlefield was elected to the planning board.
Residents traditionally have given the snowmobile excise tax refund to the Parkman Trailblazers Snowmobile Club, but this year a new club also asked for some of the funds. As voted, the West Road Riders Snowmobile Club will receive one-third of the refund if it can show proof of incorporation with the state to the town's tax collector. If they cannot, the full refund will go to the Parkman Trailblazers Club.
Residents approved all other articles in the warrant dedicated to J. Clifford Morin.
Verona
Town meeting begins at 7 p.m. Saturday, March 25, at the town office.
All elected officials, who serve one-year terms, are nominated and elected on the floor at town meeting. Verona has 401 registered voters, and a good percentage of those turn out for the annual meeting each year, according to Town Clerk Vivian Terrill.
Terrill said "nothing controversial and nothing unusual" is included on this year's warrant. The tax rate, she said, is expected to be similar to the current year.
Winn
Although the total budget approved by townspeople Monday is 4.9 percent higher than last year's, the amount to come from local taxes is $1,000 less.
The first half of the 1995 tax bills is due by Sept. 1. The second half is due by Dec. 1. Interest will be charged after Dec. 1.
In municipal elections held during the day, voters re-elected Alan Brown to a three-year term on the Board of Selectmen. Patricia Hussey was re-elected town clerk. Clinton Haynes was re-elected treasurer.
With 13 write-in votes Lynn Thibodeau was elected to a three-year term on the SAD 30 board. No name appeared on the ballot for that post.
Also, with 13 write-in votes, Sharon Webster was elected to a three-year term on the Hospital Administrative District 1 board of directors. No name appeared on the ballot for that post.

Ideas sought to ease burden on fish stocks Grant program has $4.5 million for New England fishermen

Author: Emmet Meara Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]22 Mar 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413808042?accountid=10457

Abstract: "If you have a good idea to help the fishing industry, now is the time," Scott Tilton of the National Marine Fisheries Service said Tuesday, as he explained the second round of the Fishing Industry Grant program to area fishermen. The grant program offers $4.5 million to the New England area to finance creative ideas to ease the load on fishing stocks. The deadline for applications is May 5. NMFS will conduct information seminars from 6 to 8 p.m. March 23 at the Ellsworth Library and from 10 a.m. to noon March 24 at the Portland Fishing Family Assistance Center. The FIG program is intended to assist the industry to promote the development of fishing and markets for underused species, develop methods to eliminate by-catch, and to create new business and alternative employment for those in traditional fisheries, according to Virginia Fay, who explained the program to midcoast fishermen at an afternoon session at Rockland City Hall.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Ideas+sought+to+ease+burden+on+fish+stocks+Grant+program+has+%244.5+million+for+New+England+fishermen&amp;author=Emmet+Meara+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-03-22&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- "If you have a good idea to help the fishing industry, now is the time," Scott Tilton of the National Marine Fisheries Service said Tuesday, as he explained the second round of the Fishing Industry Grant program to area fishermen. The grant program offers $4.5 million to the New England area to finance creative ideas to ease the load on fishing stocks.
The deadline for applications is May 5. NMFS will conduct information seminars from 6 to 8 p.m. March 23 at the Ellsworth Library and from 10 a.m. to noon March 24 at the Portland Fishing Family Assistance Center.
The FIG program is intended to assist the industry to promote the development of fishing and markets for underused species, develop methods to eliminate by-catch, and to create new business and alternative employment for those in traditional fisheries, according to Virginia Fay, who explained the program to midcoast fishermen at an afternoon session at Rockland City Hall.
Maine made out well in the first FIG round, which awarded $4.5 million to 28 of 201 proposals submitted, Tilton said.
The first round awards included:
$174,000 to develop a computerized jigging machine to John Williamson of Kennebunk.
$37,688 for a shellfish waste project to Albert Carver of Beals Island.
$44,250 for sculpin fisheries project to Kevin Hawkes of Phippsburg.
$50,000 to examine employment in Washington County to Diane Tilton of Machias.
$182,000 to develop a pole fishing industry to collect seaweed to manufacture nori for the Japanese sushi market to Ira A. Levine in Eastport.
$1.1 million to develop a marine hatchery for cod and haddock with $500,000 to Philip Conkling on Swans Island and $668,726 to David Miller at Franklin and Eastport.
Applications approved in New England included 11 proposals to expand harvesting of underused species, nine aquaculture projects and eight new business proposals.
The second round will be changed to emphasize new business opportunities with less emphasis on aquaculture projects, Fay said. Applicants who agree to relinquish multispecies fishing permits will be rated higher than others, she said. The impacts of the proposal will be given greater weight this time, she said.
Applications will be accepted for retraining programs that could take a fisherman off the water for a job in the carpentry or electrical businesses, Tilton said. The first priority will be to help those in the beleaguered groundfish industry, but other traditional fisheries will be considered, he said.
The FIG program is unique in that it asked the fishermen for the best way to help the industry, Fay said.
One St. George fisherman requested information for an application to expand facilities in the area to allow more docking area. Fay said new construction has been excluded from the program, but development of existing areas might be considered.
NMFS has created regional Fishing Family Assistance Centers to act as clearinghouses for information on available programs. Those interested in specific information or applications may contact Tilton at the NMFS office in Rockland at 594-2267.

____________________________________________________________

Green Party plans public clam forum Washington County fishery targeted

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]21 Mar 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413939103?accountid=10457

Abstract: A public forum to discuss the problems and future of the clam fishery in Washington County is being planned for mid-April by the Green Party to include several government, political and development organizations. Larry Lack, a Green Party member from Whitneyville, said Monday that the forum will include several clam research specialists, but the all-day meeting is intended to attract harvesters of clams and marine worms. "Some topics may provoke controversy, but not along party lines," he said. Lack is encouraging one or more municipal clam committee members from each town having clam flats to attend.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Green+Party+plans+public+clam+forum+Washington+County+fishery+targeted&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-03-21&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: MACHIAS -- A public forum to discuss the problems and future of the clam fishery in Washington County is being planned for mid-April by the Green Party to include several government, political and development organizations.
Larry Lack, a Green Party member from Whitneyville, said Monday that the forum will include several clam research specialists, but the all-day meeting is intended to attract harvesters of clams and marine worms. "Some topics may provoke controversy, but not along party lines," he said.
Lack is encouraging one or more municipal clam committee members from each town having clam flats to attend.
He wants open discussion on the feasibility of organizing clam diggers in much the same fashion as lobster fishermen have united under one or more organizations in the state. An organizer of clam diggers in the state's midcoast area will speak on that topic.
The need for mapping clam and worm beds to determine the location and population densities of clams and marine worms is another topic to be addressed.
While clammers say certain clam beds should be closed to conserve and repopulate the resource, wormers contend they shouldn't be prevented from taking worms from those same beds.
Differences of opinion are expected to surface on the increasingly frequent practice of leasing intertidal clam beds. Leslie W. Ranquist of Minturn has been invited to discuss the success of his 10-year lease of two previously unproductive acres of clam beds on Swans Island.
Although a speakers' schedule and other organizational details were incomplete Monday, Lack said the forum would be held in the lecture hall of the Science Building at the University of Maine at Machias. Saturday, April 15, is the tentative date for the conference, with April 29 an alternate date.
"Much depends upon the availability of speakers," Lack said. A final planning session will be held Thursday, March 23, by Green Party members who have been planning the clam forum since mid-February.
Last Thursday, the Washington County Commissioners gave Lack assurances that they would support the county's clam industry by becoming one of the forum's co-sponsors.
Lack told the commissioners that other co-sponsors included the Sunrise Economic Council, the Washington-Hancock Community Agency, the Republican and Democratic county committees and the Green Party.
"It (the forum) is not intended to grind a political ax ... and we are not doing it in response to the university's (Machias campus) decision to withdraw its financial support from the hatchery at Beals. We are trying to draw out ideas from everyone. It is intended to be an educational effort," he said.
Speakers scheduled to comment on clam history and restoration projects include Will Hopkins, project director for the Cobscook Bay Clam Restoration Project; Brian Beal, assistant professor of marine ecology at UMM and founder of the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery at Beals; Dana Wallace, a clam research scientist; David Clifford, Marine biologist from East Machias; Walter Schafer of Harrington, co-chairman of the Down East Regional Shellfish Committee; and Alan Huston of the Brunswick Clam Conservation Committee.
Hopkins will report on his goal of creating in the Eastport area "a regional team of local clammers, municipal shellfish committees, state and local agencies, scientific researchers, and others to develop a softshell clam habitat restoration and management plan for the Cobscook Bay region."
Last December, Hopkins' project received a $20,000 federal grant from the Northwest Atlantic Ocean Fisheries Reinvestment Program to help establish the Cobscook Bay Clam Restoration Project. The funds are administered by the Eastern Maine Development Corporation through the Sunrise County Economic Development Council.
Since December, the Jesse B. Cox Charitable Trust has provided the project $25,000 in private matching funds for a one-year period. The Nature Conservancy is the trust's fiscal agent.

Looking back at history through food

Author: Dawn Gagnon Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]20 Mar 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413858316?accountid=10457

Abstract: Food "really gets at the heart of your being," according to food historian and newly published author Sandra Oliver of Islesboro. "Whole nations have risen and fallen over it." Published by Mystic Seaport Museum Inc. of Mystic, Conn., Oliver's new book, "Saltwater Foodways: New Englanders and Their Food, At Sea and Ashore, in the Nineteenth Century" is the culmination of decades of research. While her book -- written for and about Mystic Seaport Museum and its exhibits -- focuses largely on the "foodway" of the southern New England coast, it is nonetheless peppered with references to coastal Maine, where Oliver now makes her home on the island of Islesboro, and other places up and down the Atlantic coast.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Looking+back+at+history+through+food&amp;author=Dawn+Gagnon+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-03-20&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Food "really gets at the heart of your being," according to food historian and newly published author Sandra Oliver of Islesboro. "Whole nations have risen and fallen over it."
And although most people fill their bellies at least once a day -- three times a day in this culture -- the role that food plays in human interaction and how food choices respond to technological and social change is a relatively new field of study.
"Food history is social history," Oliver points out. "Food is tremendously indicative of a whole lot of things."
It speaks volumes about distinctions among social classes and sexes, ideas and attitudes, likes and dislikes, customs and religion, she says.
Published by Mystic Seaport Museum Inc. of Mystic, Conn., Oliver's new book, "Saltwater Foodways: New Englanders and Their Food, At Sea and Ashore, in the Nineteenth Century" is the culmination of decades of research.
While her book -- written for and about Mystic Seaport Museum and its exhibits -- focuses largely on the "foodway" of the southern New England coast, it is nonetheless peppered with references to coastal Maine, where Oliver now makes her home on the island of Islesboro, and other places up and down the Atlantic coast.
It was at the museum that Oliver's interest in food history was sparked. And her interest began through her job developing a fireplace-cooking demonstration at Mystic Seaport Museum's Buckingham House in 1971, a time when the topic was largely uptapped.
Her quest for knowledge led her to study hands-on, open-hearth cookery at Old Sturbridge Village in Massachusetts and to pore over anthropology, folklore, agricultural studies, literature, historical geography, music, cookbooks, diaries, journals, ships' logs and provision lists, and more.
While at the Mystic museum, she started work on a cookbook on fireplace cooking but had to put it aside when she took on the job of supervisor of interpretations in 1978. By the time she left the museum in 1985, intending to write and work in food history, it was clear to her that more than a cookbook was appropriate.
"More is expected of food historians now," she says. "The field continues to develop all the time.
"A book is funny. It kind of inhabits you. I learned new things all the time," Oliver adds.
Also among the sources Oliver scoured for her book were newspapers, town records and probate inventories, manuscripts, period literature, books and more cookbooks, many housed at the museum's G.W. Blunt White Library at Mystic.
The result is a series of historical essays, richly illustrated with color photographs of New England dishes reproduced and depicted on the dinnerware they would have been served on; period engravings and woodcuts depicting food-related activities and advertising; and old portraits and photographs of people and places that figured in New England's cooking and eating traditions, both on land and at sea.
Each essay includes authentic period recipes, many with interpretations for the modern cook. In addition to a complete bibliography and chapter notes, Oliver includes both a cook's index and a general index.
Drawing upon what is known about the inhabitants of three historic homesteads on exhibit at the seaport museum and their contemporaries, Oliver gives us a peek into the kitchen of a Revolutionary War-era housewife and the contrasting cooking and eating habits of two 19th-century households -- a prosperous and pious shipbuilding family, and another, living on the edge and scrambling to get ahead through somewhat dubious business dealings.
Oliver takes us aboard sailing ships and fishing ships, and into the messrooms of the U.S. Life-Saving Service, the forerunner of today's Coast Guard. The ties of New Englanders to the sea brought them into contact with new foods, through seafarers' visits to other lands where they were introduced to exotic foods which they brought back home.
The author also examines traditional holiday fare, and the clambakes, shore dinners and chowder parties and myriad other occasions which define New England cuisine, and the fishing and shellfish industries with which New England so closely identifies.
Oliver will deliver a lecture Tuesday, April 18, at the Freeport Historical Society and is scheduled for a lecture and book signing at June 7 at the Penobscot Marine Museum in Searsport.
Following are some of the many recipes Oliver used to illustrate traditional New England cookery in her book.
Fish Chowder
This recipe originally came from "Hood's Combined Cook Books," published the C.I. Hood & Co., 1875-1885. Note the recommendation:
"Take either a cod or a haddock, weighing about 4 pounds, skin it, cut in small pieces and wash in cold water, take a scant quarter of a pound of salt pork, cut into small pieces and fry brown in the kettle in which the chowder is to be made; for a fish weighing 4 pounds, pare and slice 5 medium potatoes and 1 small onion; place a layer of potato and onion in the kettle, then a layer of fish, then dredge in a little salt, pepper, and flour; keep putting in alternating layers of potatoes, fish and the seasoning until all used; add hot water enough to cover; cover tight and boil gently 30 minutes; add a pint of milk and six crackers, split and dipped in cold water, and cook 10 minutes longer. To sharpen the appetite, take Hood's Sarsaparilla."
Coffee
This is how Charlie York made coffee aboard his fishing boat, the Fish Hawk. Oliver found the directions in the pages of "Charlie York: Maine Coast Fisherman," by Harold B. Clifford, 1974.
"We always measured our coffee in a glass that held exactly a quarter of a pound. We poured the water into our pot up to a certain mark; it made eight mugs. I think the biggest factor was the old blue agate pot that would hold maybe two gallons. It had the essence of coffee in it, like a pipe carries tobacco. Soap never touched it; when it was time to make new coffee we rinsed it overboard to dispose of the old grounds and some drops of sea water clung to it that helped to give it a flavor. We brought the water to a boil, poured in the coffee and moved it off the flame. We had a long-handled wooden spoon that we beat it up with for a minute or two. Then we crushed up an egg in the hand and dropped it in, shell and all; that settled the grounds. After setting for three, four minutes, it was ready to pour."
Illustration Caption: This is a portion of the cover of "Saltwater Foodways," written by food historian Sandra Oliver (top).

Shellfish hatchery asks county for funding help

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]17 Mar 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413858891?accountid=10457

Abstract: Brian Beal, a professor of marine ecology at the University of Maine at Machias, and Ron Kilby of the Washington County Extension office at Machias said the 8-year-old Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery must find new supervisory management and funding if it is to operate beyond Sept. 1. Beal, who will continue to be UMM's free consultant to the hatchery until September, said faculty changes and UMM's budget constraints forced the university last month to withdraw its annual contribution of $3,600 toward the hatchery's operating costs of about $75,000. The hatchery produces about 12 million baby clams each year for towns that manage their clam beds with leadership from clam conservation committees. Those clam committees are staffed in accordance with clam conservation ordinances sanctioned by the Depart- ment of Marine Resources and the participating towns.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Shellfish+hatchery+asks+county+for+funding+help&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-03-17&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   MACHIAS -- A shellfish hatchery asked the Washington County commissioners on Thursday to set aside some funding that would help sustain its marine industrial research programs and keep the hatchery in the county.
Brian Beal, a professor of marine ecology at the University of Maine at Machias, and Ron Kilby of the Washington County Extension office at Machias said the 8-year-old Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery must find new supervisory management and funding if it is to operate beyond Sept. 1.
Beal, who will continue to be UMM's free consultant to the hatchery until September, said faculty changes and UMM's budget constraints forced the university last month to withdraw its annual contribution of $3,600 toward the hatchery's operating costs of about $75,000.
The hatchery produces about 12 million baby clams each year for towns that manage their clam beds with leadership from clam conservation committees. Those clam committees are staffed in accordance with clam conservation ordinances sanctioned by the Depart- ment of Marine Resources and the participating towns.
Coastal towns from Kittery to Pembroke have purchased the hatchery's product at the rate of $2,000 per 1,000,000 baby clams.
Beal said the hatchery "isn't just a clam hatchery. Its programs include sea urchin research, sea scallop culture and lobster culture."
Kilby said that Pembroke, Harrington, Edmunds, Lubec and Addison will receive baby clams in 1995. Several other towns in western and southern Maine have requested seed clams.
Beal said that Eastport's clam beds are under consideration for a reseeding program.
Commissioner Chairman Mary Follis of Eastport said, "We (commissioners) need to look at our budget, which is in a state of flux at this time, to see what we can do" to provide some financial support for the hatchery.
Commissioners Edward Cline and Norman Nelson Sr. agreed to consider the hatchery's financial needs.
Follis said she would "like to see the county wholeheartedly support the hatchery," which would include financial support of a means to dispose of the hatchery's waste.
Beal explained that when the first soft-shell clam hatchery in the nation was established, on Pero Point at Beals in 1987, several towns in the area from Addison to Machiasport joined financially in the hatchery's research program.
The first three or four years failed to fulfill the towns' expectations of an imminent revival of the Down East clam industry.
"We made big mistakes," he said, but in the last four years the hatchery's two full-time employees and about eight UMM work-study students have worked with municipal clam committees to establish a viable reputation.
Brunswick and other southern Maine communities have developed strong clam industries as a result of Beals hatchery clams and the company's detailed management techniques.
"You don't go out and throw the seed on the flats and walk away. (The flats) need to be managed," said Beal.
Kilby promised that the Cooperative Extension budget, part of the university system's budget, also would provide funds to keep the hatchery functioning beyond UMM's Sept. 1 cutoff date.
Kilby said the hatchery could be used for educational purposes, and that its numerous programs could be dovetailed into the existing Washington County Water Quality Program.

A century full of life and love Island Falls woman, 100, takes a look back

Author: Annaliese Hood Special to the NEWS

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]16 Mar 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413828257?accountid=10457

Abstract: The hand-knit, thick woolen stockings hung every Christmas in the living room by the fireplace; her lithe, young body swinging from the rafters in the barn; the Fourth of July celebrations with bunches of bananas hung on the door for all the children who lived in the tannery houses across the way; the creamed oysters she ate at President Theodore Roosevelt's inauguration; the way the clouds and the water swelled together on Mattawamkeag Lake when she and her husband, Maurice, canoed on Saturday nights. Color dances all around her. Her crimson dress. Her pink button earrings. Her sparkling, slate blue eyes. I know now that if I could be as bright and sharp and lovely as she is, if I could lift myself from my chair and take a visitor on a tour of the photographs of my mother balancing eggs in her basket, or my father all handsome and whiskered, or my family's version of a Teddy Roosevelt, young and frisky in Island Falls, I would willingly risk it. The daughter of William and Mary Sewall, Cunningham has seen plenty of change. The railroad came through the year she was born. Rows of tannery houses sat across the street. Delmont Anderson had the first automobile. The iceman brought the ice packed in sawdust out from Mattawamkeag Lake. She remembers Emerson's store and M.D. Estes and all the precious penny candy. She remembers heading down the cellar stairs to pop popcorn in the furnace with her father, and she remembers his words to her, "Dotta, this house was built on honor."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+century+full+of+life+and+love+Island+Falls+woman%2C+100%2C+takes+a+look+back&amp;author=Annaliese+Hood+Special+to+the+NEWS&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-03-16&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Nancy Cunningham will deny it, but she remembers just about everything.
The hand-knit, thick woolen stockings hung every Christmas in the living room by the fireplace; her lithe, young body swinging from the rafters in the barn; the Fourth of July celebrations with bunches of bananas hung on the door for all the children who lived in the tannery houses across the way; the creamed oysters she ate at President Theodore Roosevelt's inauguration; the way the clouds and the water swelled together on Mattawamkeag Lake when she and her husband, Maurice, canoed on Saturday nights.
"He was made for me," she says lovingly. That is what is most memorable about Nancy Sewall Cunningham -- the honest love of a woman for her family.
Color dances all around her. Her crimson dress. Her pink button earrings. Her sparkling, slate blue eyes. I know now that if I could be as bright and sharp and lovely as she is, if I could lift myself from my chair and take a visitor on a tour of the photographs of my mother balancing eggs in her basket, or my father all handsome and whiskered, or my family's version of a Teddy Roosevelt, young and frisky in Island Falls, I would willingly risk it.
A tiny woman with eyes full of energy, Cunningham was born 100 years ago in an upstairs room of the house she still lives in today. With two brothers and two sisters, she was "the foolish baby," she says.
"I was a little scamp," she recalls. "I liked to make mud pies. I would take daisies and buttercups, pull them apart and mix them in. I was very particular about my mud. I used an old box they used to make mortar. I even swiped flour from the kitchen to get the right consistency.
"And sometimes I used to play down in the wagon shed until I came in covered with grease," continues Cunningham. "My mother would say, `Oh, my dear little girl, why do you get so dirty?' My mother was patience boiled down."
Cunningham leans onto her carved cane, as all 106 pounds of her stand catching her balance for a moment before she goes into the kitchen to show a visitor a partridge vine that her nephew Don brought her. All three of her "boys" -- her nephews Sam Sewall, Don Harmon and Bill Sewall -- come to see her every day.
"They are as good men as you could find anywhere," she says.
The daughter of William and Mary Sewall, Cunningham has seen plenty of change. The railroad came through the year she was born. Rows of tannery houses sat across the street. Delmont Anderson had the first automobile. The iceman brought the ice packed in sawdust out from Mattawamkeag Lake. She remembers Emerson's store and M.D. Estes and all the precious penny candy. She remembers heading down the cellar stairs to pop popcorn in the furnace with her father, and she remembers his words to her, "Dotta, this house was built on honor."
And close to that house Cunningham has stayed for most of her 100 years.
"This is where I belong. In this house," she says, quietly.
She did travel to Teddy Roosevelt's inauguration on March 4, 1905, when she was 9 years old. She attended college in Boston briefly. She lived in New York City with friends of the family in 1918 and in Portland with her Maurice for six years until they moved back in 1941, the year "Japan played that awful trick" on Pearl Harbor. They both traveled to the Badlands in South Dakota when the national park was opened.
Cunningham's father, William Sewall, was born in 1845 just two years after Levi and Rebekah Alexander Sewall came up through the woods from Phippsburg to Island Falls. She points to a brass pail hanging by the fireplace that came through those same woods at the same time. Here also is the lapstone on which her grandfather pounded leather for shoes and a cast-iron pressing iron used by her grandmother, a seamstress. Her mother's parents, Caleb and Mary Blakeney Sherman, settled in Oakfield when they arrived from New Brunswick, Canada, in 1864 with nine children, including 3-year-old Mary.
Cunningham loves the plants of the forests and fields with a passion that comes from knowledge and time. Her father first tucked her into the bow of a canoe on Mattawamkeag Lake when she was 3 years old. In those hours and hours spent together roaming the woods of Island Falls, her father passed on his love of nature. Just as his sister Sarah had taught him, he taught her the names and habits, how to recognize the vines and ferns and grasses in their seasonal clothes, the patterns of the clouds hovering over the lake waters. He would bring blue-eyed grass or a little orchid, something alive and indigenous to the fields and forests they loved.
History is important to Cunningham, but she is never stuck in the past. Things do change. "I do say so," she says. "I only wish I was clever enough to tell you."
Sincerely she says that there is no reason for anyone to remember her, but since she's asked, she says, "I want people to remember that I was kind." It is likely she will be remembered as kind, and also welcoming, humble and articulate.
When asked about regrets, Cunningham says only that she would have liked to have been a nurse or a druggist. She taught school, as was the custom for women, for three years until Maurice Cunningham walked her home one night.
He walked her home until three years ago last April 17, when he whispered to her, "We've had a pretty good time, haven't we, Nance?"
Illustration Caption: Nancy Cunningham, 100, is surrounded by photos and memories in the Island Falls home in which she was born (left and below). She uses a hand-carved cane given to her by a "girl" of 90 who thought Cunningham needed it more than she did (bottom). (NEWS Photos by Michael York)

Searsport mulls ordinances, elects officers

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]15 Mar 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413941545?accountid=10457

Dangerous decision

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]13 Mar 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413771180?accountid=10457

Abstract: Since the fall of 1986, my father, Richard Carver, and I have gladly permitted UMM, their faculty and students to use our wharf and attached two-story building and develop adjacent property to accommodate increased production of soft-shell clams with the construction of a 50-foot-by-20-foot greenhouse (1988). Again, in 1990, staff asked us if we would approve the construction of a 20-foot-by-20-foot education center so that visitors to the facility would walk away with a better understanding of the program and its benefits to coastal communities. We did so without hesitation or reservation because we believed, and still do, that this program represents one of the finest examples of positive community outreach that a campus of the University of Maine system enjoys.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Dangerous+decision&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-03-13&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: I read with interest, surprise and disappointment the recent article in your paper concerning a decision by administration at the University of Maine at Machias to withdraw its longstanding support of clam enhancement programming through the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery.
Since the fall of 1986, my father, Richard Carver, and I have gladly permitted UMM, their faculty and students to use our wharf and attached two-story building and develop adjacent property to accommodate increased production of soft-shell clams with the construction of a 50-foot-by-20-foot greenhouse (1988). Again, in 1990, staff asked us if we would approve the construction of a 20-foot-by-20-foot education center so that visitors to the facility would walk away with a better understanding of the program and its benefits to coastal communities. We did so without hesitation or reservation because we believed, and still do, that this program represents one of the finest examples of positive community outreach that a campus of the University of Maine system enjoys.
I find it difficult to believe that after all the excellent publicity this program has generated locally and along the entire coast of Maine for the past eight years that UMM could not see a way to continue its financial and managerial support. During these years, I've seen carloads and busloads of elementary and high schoolers, as well as tour buses filled with state legislators, flock to Perio Point to visit the shellfish hatchery and talk with staff and UMM students about the goings on.
Given the obvious educational benefits to UMM and Maine's coastal communities, one has to think long and hard why, after eight years of positive associations and partnerships with the various communities, that faculty changes and budget constraints at UMM would force this kind of decision.
As the owner of the property the hatchery resides on, I also find it difficult that UMM's administration did not have the courtesy to notify my father or me prior to the decision or even acknowledged our cooperative arrangement during these past eight years. I think it was rather presumptuous of UMM's administration to seek a new administrator of the hatchery without consulting us. That's not the way we work together here in Down East Maine.
I'm sure the decision to discontinue operating the Regional Shellfish Hatchery is one that is cast in stone; however, it appears that UMM's administration, which publicizes the fact that the campus is "on the move," is moving in a dangerous and shortsighted direction. Albert C. Carver President, BIRSH Beals

Town Meetings

Abstract: Three candidates are competing for two three-year openings on the SAD 56 board: incumbent Rhonda Bowden, Joan Farrar and Philip Millette. Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Town+Meetings&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-03-11&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Searsport
Searsport voters will fill three positions on the school board and one on the Board of Selectmen at the town election Tuesday.
The selectman's race pits incumbent Granville Gross against challenger Ronald Cook Sr. for a three-year term.
Three candidates are competing for two three-year openings on the SAD 56 board: incumbent Rhonda Bowden, Joan Farrar and Philip Millette. Dorothy Chocensky and Michael Hamilton are candidates for the remaining two years in the term of Glenn McFadden, who resigned from the board late last year. Chocensky was appointed to serve as an interim school director in January.
The ballot includes a referendum question on four proposed ordinances covering yard sales, the operation of junkyards and automobile salvage yards, cemetery fees and shellfish conservation.
The polls at the town office will be open from 10 a.m. until 8 p.m. Tuesday. The regular annual town meeting convenes at 9 a.m. Saturday, March 18, at the high school.
Athens
The annual town meeting in Athens will be held at 1:30 p.m. Saturday, March 11, at Athens Elemen- tary School.
Proposals included in this year's warrant drop the amount appropriated $20,000 from last year's figures. This should result in a small drop in the town's mill rate, according to town officials.
Issues to be dealt with Saturday include acceptance of a $75,000 grant to expand a town recreational park; a salary increase for the second and third selectmen's positions; and money to finish road work on the Dore Hill Road.
Charleston
The town will hold its annual election and town meeting at 10 a.m. Saturday, March 11, at the town hall.
Residents will elect two budget committee members, two recreation committee members, a selectman, a road commissioner and a fire chief, and will consider a 49-article warrant.
Articles include: appropriating $60,000 for plowing and sanding roads; $16,000 for maintenance of town ways; $59,669 for debt service; and $38,535.65 for solid waste management.
Voters will consider a request by residents of the Bacon and Fogg roads to appropriate $20,000 for rebuilding portions of the roads.
Garland
The debate over the 1994-1995 SAD 46 school budget doesn't appear to be over yet in Garland, with voters there Saturday to be asked if the town should hire legal help to find out if the school board acted legally this year.
The article states: "To see if the town will vote to authorize the selectmen to get a legal opinion on whether the SAD 46 board of directors acted beyond their legal authority in spending money in excess of the amount raised by voters of the member towns or act on anything relative, thereto, including legal action against individual members who so voted."
At issue appears to be the situation where voters approved a bottom-line budget for the year at one of six referendums, but did not approve local option money to fund the bottom line of the budget until six months into the budget.
Garland's annual town meeting, where this issue will be taken up, will start at 10 a.m. Saturday, March 11, at the grange hall.
In elections to be held that morning, Suzy Grant is running unopposed for town clerk; Steve Gudroe is unopposed for a three-year seat on the Board of Selectmen; Paul Robbins and Lawrence Folsom are seeking election to a one year term on the board of selectmen; Folsom is running unopposed for a three year term as assessor; and Ann Kucera and Arthur Jette are running for the three year opening on the SAD 46 board. Voters will elect a cemetery superintendent and a cemetery trustee.
Write-ins will be accepted at the meeting for any of these posts, but nominations from the floor will not, according to Suzy Grant, town clerk.
Newburgh
Both Newburgh seats on the SAD 22 board of directors will be filled during the annual town meeting at 10 a.m. Saturday, March 11, at Newburgh Elementary School on Route 9.
Leona Smith's term is expiring this month, and Stephen Johnson is vacating his term two years early because he is moving out of Newburgh.
Candidates for the two seats are Smith, Steve Whitcomb, Kurt Hoffman and Wendy Leuba.
Helen Mogan's term as first selectman is expiring, and she is the only candidate. Steve Eyles is the only candidate for the position of third selectman being vacated by Ron Darling.
Running for town clerk is Lois Libby, the incumbent, and for town treasurer, Lois Whitcomb, also incumbent.
The warrant for Saturday's meeting includes an amendment proposed by the planning board to the land use ordinance.
Voters are expected to consider acquiring a new firetruck.
Skowhegan
Skowhegan voters will go to the polls from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. Saturday to elect 15 officials. Elections will be held in the council room of the municipal building.
Voters will reconvene at 7 p.m. Monday, March 13, in the Skowhegan Opera House to conduct their annual town meeting.
Nine incumbent officials are not opposed in Saturday's elections. They are Selectman Donald Brough and Selectman David Summers, both for three-year terms; Selectman Lynda Quinn, two years, and Edward Conley Jr., current board chairman, also for two years.
Also unopposed are William Philbrick, for a five-year term as park commissioner, Rhonda Stark for town clerk and treasurer, and Gregory Dore for road commissioner.
In the selectman's race, incumbent Leonard Whitman is being challenged by Scott Nesbit and Michael Walker for a one-year term, and incumbent Walter Smith is opposed by Edward J. Conley as overseer of the poor.
Current SAD 54 directors Anne Gamage, Richard Irwin and Rupert White Jr. are opposed by June Washburn and John Forter for three open seats on the board of directors.
