UMaine marine scientist offers advice on reviving clam industry Down East

Author: Clayton Beal the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]09 Mar 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413754783?accountid=10457

Abstract: A research scientist from the University of Maine said Tuesday night that the lowly clam could become the economic backbone of the state's coastal communities if the natural marine resource was properly managed. Clam populations at Jonesport and other coastal towns could be brought back into production, but such a revitalization of the depleted industry would require "some hard work" by clam committees, businesspeople and others interested in the economic well-being of the Down East coastal region, [Brian] Beal said. His five practical methods of increasing clam production included: reseeding clam beds with wild or hatchery-reared clams; encouraging clam spat to attach itself to flats by installing low fences of either brush or plastic mesh netting; limiting the number of clams that can be taken from certain areas, in accordance with proper inventories of clam flat acreages; allowing more clams to spawn each year by closing specific clam beds from late May to mid-July during the spawning season; and creating "clam pounds" and using them as lobster pounds are used to stockpile product until the commercial market offers a profitable price.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=UMaine+marine+scientist+offers+advice+on+reviving+clam+industry+Down+East&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-03-09&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   JONESPORT -- A research scientist from the University of Maine said Tuesday night that the lowly clam could become the economic backbone of the state's coastal communities if the natural marine resource was properly managed.
Brian Beal, assistant professor of marine ecology and the university's coordinator of environmental resources, told residents that "more people must take an active role in the industry in each coastal community."
No selectmen or members of the town's clam conservation committee attended the two-hour meeting sponsored by the local Literary Club.
Beal explained the clam's life cycle and gave an overview of the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery that he was instrumental in forming in 1987. Richard Carver of Beals donated a wharf and buildings to the pilot hatchery on Pero Point at Beals. The project originated from a Washington County 4-H Extension program in nearby Jonesboro.
Clam populations at Jonesport and other coastal towns could be brought back into production, but such a revitalization of the depleted industry would require "some hard work" by clam committees, businesspeople and others interested in the economic well-being of the Down East coastal region, Beal said.
His five practical methods of increasing clam production included: reseeding clam beds with wild or hatchery-reared clams; encouraging clam spat to attach itself to flats by installing low fences of either brush or plastic mesh netting; limiting the number of clams that can be taken from certain areas, in accordance with proper inventories of clam flat acreages; allowing more clams to spawn each year by closing specific clam beds from late May to mid-July during the spawning season; and creating "clam pounds" and using them as lobster pounds are used to stockpile product until the commercial market offers a profitable price.
The future of clamming "is a bright one for those interested enough in becoming involved," he said. "Residents of Jonesport and other coastal communities must remember that a healthy clamming industry means more jobs in the community, more income for the schools, the Fire Department and ambulance service, more money spent in the community at various stores and markets, more money in the local banks, and in general, greater prosperity within the entire community."
The hatchery's staff, in its effort to restore the industry, learned from its past trials and errors and is now valued by some communities as a major player in the statewide clam restoration program. While Beals Island (which has no clam conservation committee), Machiasport, Addison and Jonesport no longer participate in the hatchery program, communities outside Washington County do. Scarborough, Friendship, Waldoboro, Brunswick, Kittery and Swans Island are enthusiastic participants.
One of the newest proposals in clam flat management in the Down East area involves a portion of clam flats in Cutler. Paul Thompson of Cutler has received a research grant to develop a clam management demonstration. He wants the Cutler Clam Conservation Committee to lease a portion of "the desert" clam beds for his experimental plot. Final approval of the lease would come from the Department of Marine Resources.
Swans Island officials began that town's clam leasing program in 1992. The three 1/4-acre leases have been successful. One clam farmer sold clams in Bar Harbor for $120 a bushel. Beal said it has been legal for a town to lease up to 25 percent of its clam beds.
Jonesport has about 1,500 acres of clam beds. He proposed Tuesday that if the town set aside about 300 acres in the cove north of Flake Point Bar as a management area and produced a volume of clams equal to the cove's 1975 production of 150 bushels per acre, the cove would produce $1.5 million worth of marketable clams each year. He made no estimate of how much time would be needed to restore the bed to its 1975 production level.

Shellfish hatchery's funding in limbo UMM to withdraw financial support

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]28 Feb 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413946848?accountid=10457

Abstract: Representatives of the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery will meet with University of Maine at Machias President Paul Nordstrom on Wednesday to discuss the university's intent to cease its financial support of the hatchery. Dwayne Shaw, hatchery manager, and Dr. Brian Beal, UMM's hatchery consultant, will meet with Nordstrom to discuss how the university may assist BIRSH in seeking funds to keep the hatchery operating in support of the Down East clam industry. Because Beal, a professor of marine ecology at UMM, is seeking a new position within the university that does not include hatchery duties, university officials said Monday that UMM cannot afford the salary and operational funding required to replace him.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Shellfish+hatchery%27s+funding+in+limbo+UMM+to+withdraw+financial+support&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-02-28&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   MACHIAS -- Representatives of the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery will meet with University of Maine at Machias President Paul Nordstrom on Wednesday to discuss the university's intent to cease its financial support of the hatchery.
Dwayne Shaw, hatchery manager, and Dr. Brian Beal, UMM's hatchery consultant, will meet with Nordstrom to discuss how the university may assist BIRSH in seeking funds to keep the hatchery operating in support of the Down East clam industry.
The hatchery is widely known for its shellfish research and for seeding clam flats that had been overharvested for years. Once an economic mainstay involving more than 2,000 licensed clam diggers, the Down East clam harvest has plummeted in recent years. Fewer than 400 diggers hold licenses, and their harvest is down 90 percent.
Officials at UMM said late Monday that faculty changes and budget constraints at the campus in Machias would force BIRSH "to find new management and funding if it is to continue its operations."
Because Beal, a professor of marine ecology at UMM, is seeking a new position within the university that does not include hatchery duties, university officials said Monday that UMM cannot afford the salary and operational funding required to replace him.
Shaw said UMM may relinquish all bookkeeping responsibilities as early as Sept. 1.
The university doesn't own the hatchery and is not responsible for its operation and management. However, Beal, a native of Jonesport, has generated funding for the hatchery through grants and has been overseer of the hatchery's operations since BIRSH was formed eight years ago.
Beal's skill as a grant writer has garnered hundreds of thousands of federal, state and foundation dollars to cover research and operating costs. Grant funds have been the primary source of income for the hatchery. The annual operating cost of BIRSH is about $75,000.
An outgrowth of a Cooperative Extension project in Jonesboro, the hatchery is a cooperative venture. Beal has contributed time and expertise. UMM has contributed about $3,600 per year toward the cost of operations. Coastal communities have purchased baby clams to seed mud flats. Richard Carver of Beals has donated use of his wharf and buildings at Beals for the hatchery. And UMM work-study students contribute labor as do AmeriCorps youth.
In a press release Monday, Nordstrom said UMM -- in the present economic climate and in light of the faculty changes -- is unable to make a long-term commitment to fund the hatchery.
A proposed bill in the Legislature would provide $15,000 a year for a two-year period, but this would provide only a small part of what is needed.
Nordstrom said he was apprehensive about soliciting federal funds to operate a local enterprise, echoing Gov. Angus King's caution about relying on federal funds for jobs.
"University people value the hatchery and would like to see it continue, but we simply do not have the money to support its continued operation," said Nordstrom.
The present arrangement will continue until Sept. 1, he said, while pledging UMM's support as the hatchery seeks a new management organization. "Whoever assumes management of the hatchery can count on UMM experience and expertise," he said.

Aquaculture rides the waves Competition, regulations slow growth for fish farming industry

Author: Diana Graettinger Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]25 Feb 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413749940?accountid=10457

Abstract: The aquaculture business is a $45 million-a-year industry in Maine, and it is especially critical to the economic development of Washington County. There are nearly 30 finfish farms in Maine; 16 of them are in Washington County, and the rest are in Hancock, Lincoln or Knox counties. There are 70 ocean-site leases containing 1,270 acres. According to a fact sheet provided by the Maine Aquaculture Innovation Center, there are several reasons the industry has been successful in Maine:

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Aquaculture+rides+the+waves+Competition%2C+regulations+slow+growth+for+fish+farming+industry&amp;author=Diana+Graettinger+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-02-25&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   The aquaculture business is a $45 million-a-year industry in Maine, and it is especially critical to the economic development of Washington County.
There are nearly 30 finfish farms in Maine; 16 of them are in Washington County, and the rest are in Hancock, Lincoln or Knox counties. There are 70 ocean-site leases containing 1,270 acres.
According to a fact sheet provided by the Maine Aquaculture Innovation Center, there are several reasons the industry has been successful in Maine:
Availability of clean water inland, and in the ocean.
Diverse areas that vary environmentally and facilitate species diversification.
An existing infrastructure to handle permitting research, development and extension.
The willingness of the government and commercial fishermen to accept aquaculture.
The existence of a strong marine and seafood processing infrastructure.
Although aquaculture has experienced remarkable early growth, there have been constraints on the industry, such as the expense of complying with regulations issued by agencies with overlapping jurisdictions, and competition with relatively unregulated foreign competitors.
In some areas there has been a lack of public understanding of aquaculture's potential impact on the economy and opposition from riparian owners to new ocean lease sites. Finally, the industry has been hampered by limited access to investment capital.
Tom Duym, division head of the Washington County Technical College Marine Technology Center, describes himself as an academician, not a fish farmer, and said he did not like the term aquaculture.
"A lot of the guys are fishermen who turned into fish growers," he said. He equated the activity to agriculture and farmers who annually produce a crop.
Since salmon aquaculture began in Maine, the industry has provided participants with the highs and lows of a Ferris-wheel ride. When foreign competition drove market prices down, discussions about diversification began.
"Because of the intense marketing going on worldwide, the price which attracted many people to the industry in the beginning dropped down to a position of cost-plus. There isn't the profit margin there was when it first started," Duym said.
When the business began in New Brunswick in the 1980s, farmers got $6.50 a pound for a product whose cost of production was around $3.25 a pound. Today's farmers get around $3 a pound, and production costs remain high.
Many hope the aquaculture industry will fill the gap left by declining traditional fish stocks in the Gulf of Maine.
"Traditional stocks, flatfish: cod, haddock, pollack; other roundfish as well as other species are under severe stress, and the aquaculturist realizes there is a lot of potential. But also the aquaculturists tend to look at a species from its value standpoint. In other words, no matter which species you grow ... you must be able to grow a fish where its cost of production does not exceed what you can get for it at the market, and that is the bottom line," Duym said.
Halibut farming has generated interest because of the price it brings. Halibut steaks bring upward of $7 a pound. Duym said it was a difficult species to get through the culture process at the hatchery level, and it had a high mortality rate.
The Marine Trade Center was involved in a project with Maine Aquaculture Innovation Center in Orono to obtain halibut brood stock. The project was funded by MAIC and Northeast Regional Aquaculture Center in Massachusetts. The aim of the project, Duym said, was to strip eggs and sperm from mature female and male halibut and get fertilized eggs.
Mike Hastings, executive director of the MAIC, said scarce state dollars have hurt the project. "What we try to do now, because we have so little state money to devote to research, is to use it to leverage federal dollars and private foundation dollars," he said.
MAIC projects include development of a halibut brood stock parentage for future aquaculture; collection of cod as a brood stock for a cod hatchery; an experimental nori farm near Deer Isle; marine-species nutrition work; and the initial start-up grant for the nori farm in Eastport. "We have had almost 60 research projects over the past five years," Hastings said.
Research, Hastings said, was critical to the future of the industry. "We need more research specific to our ocean environment. You can have a species that has been cultivated in one part of the world ... but to grow the same species in Maine requires more research, because our temperatures and currents are different, and the composition of the bottom is different," he said.
Duym said he believed the future would include the farming of marine finfish, shellfish and urchins, as well as nori and other marine vegetables. He said there was a race on worldwide to see who could perfect a method to grow blue-fin tuna.
"The analogy often used is that traditional commercial fishermen were the last of the buffalo hunters. What we are seeing right now is the transition from the buffalo hunter to the cattle farmer," he said.
Illustration Caption: Salmon pens in Prince Cove off Eastport are part of Maine's $45 million-a-year aquaculture industry. The salmon market, however, has seen its share of competition and market fluctuations. (NEWS File Photo)

Title: Aquaculture rides the waves Competition, regulations slow growth for fish farming industry:   [Indus Edition ]

Publication title: Bangor Daily News; Bangor, Me.

Pages: 1

Number of pages: 0

Publication year: 1995

Publication date: Feb 25, 1995

Publisher: Bangor Publishing Company

____________________________________________________________

Ecologist to speak as Jonesport assesses clam industry's future

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 Feb 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413746740?accountid=10457

Abstract: A marine ecology professor from the University of Maine at Machias will discuss the future of Jonesport's clam industry next month at Peabody Memorial Library. A native of Jonesport, [Brian] Beal has been asked by the local literary club to explain what practical measures should be taken to assure the future of the clam industry, which by 1993 had lost nearly two-thirds of its 1979 production level. According to the local clam committee, the town's clam landings are originating in beds on the town's outer islands. Few clams are harvested from clam flats on the mainland because most of the industry's mainland acreage is closed because of pollution or conservation practices. The two large clam beds at Great Bar and Flakepoint Bar in the town's Mason Bay district are open to winter digging.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Ecologist+to+speak+as+Jonesport+assesses+clam+industry%27s+future&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-02-24&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   JONESPORT -- A marine ecology professor from the University of Maine at Machias will discuss the future of Jonesport's clam industry next month at Peabody Memorial Library.
Brian Beal, assistant professor of marine ecology and the university's coordinator of environmental resources, will speak at 8 p.m. March 7 at Peabody Memorial Library.
A native of Jonesport, Beal has been asked by the local literary club to explain what practical measures should be taken to assure the future of the clam industry, which by 1993 had lost nearly two-thirds of its 1979 production level.
According to the local clam committee, the town's clam landings are originating in beds on the town's outer islands. Few clams are harvested from clam flats on the mainland because most of the industry's mainland acreage is closed because of pollution or conservation practices. The two large clam beds at Great Bar and Flakepoint Bar in the town's Mason Bay district are open to winter digging.
All of the town's waterfront on Moosabec Reach is off-limits to clamming because ocean water in the mollusks fails to meet minimum water quality standards set by the Environmental Protection Agency. The state Department of Marine Resources collects periodic water samples for tests performed at the DMR's laboratory in Lamoine. The DMR's enforcement branch closed the Moosabec Reach clam flats about six years ago.
E. coli bacteria, originating in failed septic systems and straight sewage discharge pipes, have polluted a significant amount of the town's estimated 1,800 acres of productive clam beds.
Members of the clam conservation committee, including Russell Batson and Lorenzo Wallace Jr., said Thursday that all of the town's outer islands were free of pollution and were open to harvesting by Jonesport's 44 licensed diggers. A resident commercial clam license at Jonesport costs $25, in addition to a required one-year state clam license costing $63.
Diggers are receiving $48 a bushel. Batson said his discussions with area clammers has convinced him that clam populations are beginning to show signs of revival.
Last summer, when clam prices reached $90 a bushel, some diggers in the Jonesport-Beals region were earning about $200 for three hours of digging. Arthur Alley of Jonesport said his daily production matched other high-producing flats anywhere in the state. Alley said he was convinced that natural regeneration was occurring.
Arpie Alley of Jonesport, a veteran clam digger and former warden for the local clam committee, also said the best way to revive the clam industry was to follow the proven policy of old-time clam diggers, who favored closing a large area of clam flats from May through September to permit clam spawn to repopulate.
Jonesport has no reciprocal digging rights with any other community, but recently joined the Down East Regional Shellfish Committee with neighboring towns Addison and Harrington. Committee members share ideas on how to manage and improve their clam flats. About 4,000 acres of clam beds in the three towns are expected to benefit from the regional meetings.

Shellfish officials seek legislation to fine clam poachers, nix community service

Author: (AP)

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]22 Feb 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413943340?accountid=10457

Abstract: Having to work in a soup kitchen, a church or a public library isn't as tough as paying $300 for digging clams without a license or in a closed area, say shellfish officials here. That's why they convinced freshman Rep. Tom Davidson, D-Brunswick, to propose a bill that would restrict the punishment for shellfish violations to monetary fines. It's not known how often shellfish violators work off their fines with community service. The West Bath District Court clerk's office keeps track of the fines, but not whether the fines were paid with labor or cash.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Shellfish+officials+seek+legislation+to+fine+clam+poachers%2C+nix+community+service&amp;author=%28AP%29&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-02-22&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BRUNSWICK -- Having to work in a soup kitchen, a church or a public library isn't as tough as paying $300 for digging clams without a license or in a closed area, say shellfish officials here.
That's why they convinced freshman Rep. Tom Davidson, D-Brunswick, to propose a bill that would restrict the punishment for shellfish violations to monetary fines.
"I thought that if, in fact, we're going to close these places off, we have to have enforcement that's much stronger than it is now," said Davidson.
It's not known how often shellfish violators work off their fines with community service. The West Bath District Court clerk's office keeps track of the fines, but not whether the fines were paid with labor or cash.
"I don't know where they're doing their community service, if they're doing it. They could be putting their grandmother's windows in," said Jim MacLeod, chairman of the town's marine resources committee.
He thinks that poachers can easily pay the minimum $300 fine for the first offense.
"They're probably standing there with $200 to $300 in their pocket, said MacLeod. "I think the judges are being duped."
Judge Joseph Field, who hands down community service sentences in West Bath District Court, said he had no public opinion on the proposed legislation.
Field said he turned to community service sentences during the recession when people coming to court could not afford hundreds of dollars in fines for various violations.
"People don't realize how high some of these numbers are in terms of people's lives," he said.
In most cases, people would rather pay the fine than be faced with the work or jail time, he said.
"I may be being hoodwinked. They may have bags of money, but frankly most folks with bags of money are going to be willing to shell out some of it to avoid community service."

Journalist gets endorsement to head Marine Resources

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]17 Feb 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413748650?accountid=10457

Abstract: Journalist Robin Alden moved closer to managing the waterfront, instead of covering it, when she received the ringing endorsement Thursday of a legislative committee to be the next commissioner of the Maine Department of Marine Resources. Alden, 43, founded what is now the Commercial Fisheries News in 1973, and since has started two other fisheries publications. She also has worked for the University of Maine Sea Grant program, helped organize the Maine Fishermen's Forum, now in its 20th year, and served on the New England Fishery Management Council. The long line of speakers supporting the nominee at Thursday's hearing included many individual fishermen and representatives of such organizations as the Maine Lobstermen's Association, the Downeast Lobstermen's Association, the Maine Sardine Council, the Maine Aquaculture Association, the Maine Seaweed Council, the Maine Fishermen's Wives Association, the Portland Fish Exchange, the Island Institute, the Maine Urchin Harvester's Association, the Maine Science and Technology Foundation and the Coastal Conservation Association for recreational saltwater anglers.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Journalist+gets+endorsement+to+head+Marine+Resources&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-02-17&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: AUGUSTA -- Journalist Robin Alden moved closer to managing the waterfront, instead of covering it, when she received the ringing endorsement Thursday of a legislative committee to be the next commissioner of the Maine Department of Marine Resources.
After hearing strong support from virtually every sector of the fishing industry, The Joint Standing Committee on Marine Resources unanimously recommend- ed the confirmation of Gov. Angus King's nominee for the state's top fisheries post.
If confirmed as expected by the full Senate within a few days, the Stonington publisher will become the first woman to govern Maine's fishing industry.
Alden, 43, founded what is now the Commercial Fisheries News in 1973, and since has started two other fisheries publications. She also has worked for the University of Maine Sea Grant program, helped organize the Maine Fishermen's Forum, now in its 20th year, and served on the New England Fishery Management Council.
The long line of speakers supporting the nominee at Thursday's hearing included many individual fishermen and representatives of such organizations as the Maine Lobstermen's Association, the Downeast Lobstermen's Association, the Maine Sardine Council, the Maine Aquaculture Association, the Maine Seaweed Council, the Maine Fishermen's Wives Association, the Portland Fish Exchange, the Island Institute, the Maine Urchin Harvester's Association, the Maine Science and Technology Foundation and the Coastal Conservation Association for recreational saltwater anglers.
Supporters praised Alden's comprehensive knowledge of all aspects of the fishing industry and marine science, as well as her editorial positions favoring increased input from fish- ermen in the development of fishing regulations and her reputation as one who builds bridges between competing groups.
Brian Beal, a shellfish scientist at the University of Maine at Machias, called Alden's nomination "one of the most sensible appointments in the history of the state. She is an eloquent speaker and a master of listening."
After listening to dozens of favorable comments during the two and one-half hour session, the legislators heard from one opponent, Augusta environmentalist Bob Lavangie. He criticized the lack of coverage in the fishery press of estuary pollution and Alden's connection through marriage to the gillnetting industry, which he called "a cruel fishery."
In her statement to the committee, Alden said she will continue as commissioner "to be a consensus-builder, to find in the diversity of opinion the underlying principles, to keep everyone at the table."
Rep. Herbert Adams, D-Portland, asked Alden how she will balance the need for fishermen to earn a living with the need to conserve and restore the resource. She said her position that "those who fish should help make the rules is based on my belief that the people who know the most about the behavior and abundance of fish are those who catch them. Anyone can make rules. We need rules that really work and people who are involved in making the rules will take responsibility for them."
Acknowledging her lack of experience in law enforcement, Alden said she will work closely with the Marine Patrol, adding that fishermen are the most ardent supporters of enforcement, if the regulations are fair and rational.
In response to questions from other committee members, Alden said she supports Maine becoming a leader in marine science, favors closers ties between traditional fishing and aquaculture, and promised that Maine will make strenuous objections should the federal government move ahead with plans to declare Atlantic salmon an endangered species, a development many fear would kill the Downeast finfish aquaculture industry.
Illustration Caption: Alden

____________________________________________________________

Local clammers eye success story Down East industry studies Brunswick setup

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]16 Feb 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413788338?accountid=10457

Abstract: Clam committees from three towns in Washington County learned this week that Brunswick's successful $2 million clam industry and Down East Maine share a common goal: to keep marine worm diggers out of closed clam beds. Alan Huston, a spokesman for the Brunswick Clam Conservation Committee, told the Down East Regional Shellfish Committee Monday night at Addison that his committee was pushing a bill that would prevent worm diggers and clam diggers from working in closed clam beds. He described the intrusion of worm diggers into closed clam areas as "a big problem." Huston, who attended the Down East committee's public meeting to explain how the city of Brunswick has built a $2 million clam industry in 19 years, said the legislation, sponsored by Rep. Tom Davidson of Brunswick, would protect soft-shell clams from being broken by fishermen's boots in closed clam beds. The city has 427.5 acres of productive clam flats. A legislative docket number is expected to be assigned to the bill within the next few days.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Local+clammers+eye+success+story+Down+East+industry+studies+Brunswick+setup&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-02-16&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ADDISON -- Clam committees from three towns in Washington County learned this week that Brunswick's successful $2 million clam industry and Down East Maine share a common goal: to keep marine worm diggers out of closed clam beds.
Alan Huston, a spokesman for the Brunswick Clam Conservation Committee, told the Down East Regional Shellfish Committee Monday night at Addison that his committee was pushing a bill that would prevent worm diggers and clam diggers from working in closed clam beds. He described the intrusion of worm diggers into closed clam areas as "a big problem."
Huston, who attended the Down East committee's public meeting to explain how the city of Brunswick has built a $2 million clam industry in 19 years, said the legislation, sponsored by Rep. Tom Davidson of Brunswick, would protect soft-shell clams from being broken by fishermen's boots in closed clam beds. The city has 427.5 acres of productive clam flats. A legislative docket number is expected to be assigned to the bill within the next few days.
If a clam bed is closed for regeneration, including reseeding, commercial worm diggers are allowed to walk through the mud flats in search of sandworms or bloodworms. Worms for sport fishermen are in demand year round on many markets including those in New York, New Jersey and Virginia.
Huston said clams should be given a legislative priority over worms because clams are for human consumption, but he expects wormers to oppose the proposed law that for the first time would restrict them. The worm industry had its beginning Down East in the mid-1950s. Earlier, Wiscasset was one of the first communities to develop a worm industry.
Albion Kenney, Harrington's clam warden, said the clam industry's closed areas need the long overdue protection.
Representatives from the Jonesport, Addison and Harrington clam committees were told that Brunswick had worked for 19 years to build up the city's clam industry. A total of 33,208 bushels of clams are expected to be harvested this year from a record 427.5 acres of clam beds.
He said the city's marine clam committee operates on a $78,000 budget, about $23,000 of which is raised through clam licenses and other revenue.
Although Brunswick's clam acreage is up this year by 32 acres, through reseeding programs, the 1995 harvest is estimated to be down by about 3,000 bushels from 1994, down by 2,000 bushels from 1993.
The decline estimated for this year in nine of the city's 16 clam beds may be compensated for by reducing the number of available clam licenses. The city has 99 commercial diggers who are allowed to harvest open beds night or day. Some consideration would be given to eliminating nighttime harvesting, he said.
One of the community's outstanding success stories expected this year should be in Smith's Cove, where 260 bushels were harvested in 1994. This year, the cove's flats are expected to yield 1,623 bushels. The spectacular growth in productivity was attributed to flexible management of the flats, including periodic closures allowing clams to spawn and grow to the minimum 2-inch commercial size.
Brunswick, 173 miles south of Machias, has the advantage of ocean water that is somewhat warmer than that which covers clam beds at Jonesport, Harrington and Addison. Clams grow faster in nutrient-rich warmer water, he said.
Brunswick's clams also have been aided by planting hatchery-raised seedlings. Some of the seed has been purchased from the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery at Beals.
Harvests timed to match market demands and higher summertime market prices have enhanced the incomes of Brunswick's clammers, some of whom earned $50,000 to $60,000 last year, Huston said. One digger earned about $70,000 during the 280-day season.
Walter Schafer of Harrington, co-chairman of the Down East committee that seeks to bring the three communities together to share ideas and methods of improving clam-flat production, said Monday that he was "convinced that what they do down there (in Brunswick) we can do up here."
Others from the three towns said that if a significant percent of clam-flat acreage were closed from May to September, production would increase.

EPA aids Gulf of Maine research $1.9 million grant to focus on habitat protection, water quality monitoring

Author: (AP)

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]07 Feb 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413815469?accountid=10457

Abstract: Efforts to preserve the Gulf of Maine got a $1.9 million boost from federal environmental regulators on Monday. The grant from the Environmental Protection Agency is intended to support work by the Gulf of Maine Council over the next decade on habitat protection, water quality monitoring and research, public outreach and polluton abatement and prevention. The Gulf of Maine stretches from Cape Sable, Nova Scotia, to Cape Cod, Mass., and includes the Georges Bank and the Bay of Fundy.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=EPA+aids+Gulf+of+Maine+research+%241.9+million+grant+to+focus+on+habitat+protection%2C+water+quality+monitoring&amp;author=%28AP%29&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-02-07&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   PORTLAND -- Efforts to preserve the Gulf of Maine got a $1.9 million boost from federal environmental regulators on Monday.
The grant from the Environmental Protection Agency is intended to support work by the Gulf of Maine Council over the next decade on habitat protection, water quality monitoring and research, public outreach and polluton abatement and prevention.
The Gulf of Maine stretches from Cape Sable, Nova Scotia, to Cape Cod, Mass., and includes the Georges Bank and the Bay of Fundy.
"The gulf is important to millions of people in this region, both as a recreational and an economic resource," said John P. DeVillars, regional EPA administrator for New England.
"Those of us at EPA would not be doing our job if we didn't provide the financial and technical support necessary to protect and improve this truly amazing ecosystem," he said.
Fishing and shellfishing have been major industries in the gulf, sustaining the work of nearly 20,000 fishermen and contributing hundreds of millions of dollars to the region's economy in recent years.
Also, the gulf's coastline draws millions of visitors each year and is a major contributor to the region's economy.
The Gulf of Maine Council includes representatives from Maine, New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Nova Scotia and New Brunswick. Its mission is to maintain and improve the gulf's environmental quality while allowing people to use its resources.
The Association of U.S. Delegates of the Gulf of Maine, a non-profit organization, will carry out the project's day-to-day work and administer the grant.
All four members of Maine's congressional delegation praised the EPA grant.
"Maine and the other states and provinces bordering the gulf have adopted a regional approach to protecting their common natural and economic heritage," said Sen. Olympia Snowe, R-Maine.

Should this murderer be paroled? Convicted killer from Vermont seeks release to live in Lincolnville

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]04 Feb 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413753151?accountid=10457

Abstract: Despite the protests of the victim's family and Vermont's Department of Corrections, the Vermont Parole Board this week granted a murderer his freedom, as long as he lives somewhere else. Like Lincolnville, Maine. By a vote of 3-2 on Tuesday, the Vermont board granted parole to Ray (Butch) Rebideau, provided he is accepted by authorities in Maine, where he served five of his 22 years in prison, or, as a second choice, Washington state, where family members live. Aho met Rebideau at the Warren prison farm where he was a volunteer working with inmates.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Should+this+murderer+be+paroled%3F+Convicted+killer+from+Vermont+seeks+release+to+live+in+Lincolnville&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-02-04&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- Despite the protests of the victim's family and Vermont's Department of Corrections, the Vermont Parole Board this week granted a murderer his freedom, as long as he lives somewhere else. Like Lincolnville, Maine.
By a vote of 3-2 on Tuesday, the Vermont board granted parole to Ray (Butch) Rebideau, provided he is accepted by authorities in Maine, where he served five of his 22 years in prison, or, as a second choice, Washington state, where family members live.
Corrections officials from Vermont and Maine are expected to take about 45 days to evaluate Rebideau's request to move to Lincolnville, where he has been offered a full-time job and temporary housing by David Aho, owner of a shellfish company. Aho met Rebideau at the Warren prison farm where he was a volunteer working with inmates.
Rebideau, 46, was convicted of first-degree murder in 1973 for the shooting a year earlier of Raymond Lestage in Royalton, a crime considered at the time to be one of Vermont's most brutal.
Lestage, visiting the Burlington area from Massachusetts, accepted a ride from Rebideau and two other men the night of Aug. 13, 1972. He was found shot to death in a cemetery the next morning.
Rebideau and the other gunman, Frank Berard Jr., were convicted of murder and sentenced to life in prison. The third man was convicted of being an accessory to the crime.
Rebideau was transferred to the Maine prison system five years ago in an attempt to resolve discipline problems that arose from having him and Berard incarcerated in the same Vermont facility. Rebideau's conduct apparently improved considerably in Maine, as he earned his way into the minimum-security prison farm at Warren, completed many college courses toward a future as a substance-abuse counselor and received glowing reports on his progress in anger-management classes.
He was first granted parole in December 1993 for residency in Washington state, but the Vermont board rescinded that action after a furor arose over the failure to notify Lestage's family and a fearful eyewitness of his pending release. Rebideau reapplied for parole last fall and was transferred back to Vermont in December.
Several members of Lestage's family attended the hearing Tuesday, unsuccessfully urging the board to accept the recommendation of the Vermont Department of Corrections that Rebideau be denied parole because of insufficient progress in the state's programs for violent offenders.
After the 3-2 vote to grant parole, one member of the victim's family was quoted by The Associated Press as saying Rebideau's "future and freedom became paramount to the parole board, while the reality of a heinous, brutal killing seemed to be forgotten."
Parole Board Chairwoman Alice Hafner, who voted against Rebideau's release, said Thursday she was troubled by a decision that disregarded the recommendations of her state's corrections officials and that asks the states of Maine or Washington to do something Vermont is not willing to do.
"Mr. Rebideau's parole is contingent upon his being accepted in Maine or Washington. He will remain incarcerated as long as he is in Vermont," Hafner said. "Maine was the first choice in the parole plan he presented, so it's now up to Maine to investigate and to decide whether to take him or not. While Vermont corrections said he needs more programming, what we heard from Maine, in favorable corrections reports and the testimony of a psychologist, was that he had been through enough programs and should be paroled. I can't say why the majority of our board put more emphasis on reports from Maine than on reports from our own state."
Peter Tilton, director of Maine's Division of Probation and Parole, said Friday the decision to accept or reject Rebideau "most definitely is our choice. These requests are not at all uncommon, but they are all investigated thoroughly. Once Vermont sends the information on this man's parole plan, we will evaluate the reasons behind it, any family ties, the living conditions, the employment opportunities, our ability to supervise and monitor." Tilton said the sentiment of the community and local police on accepting the parolee "is, to a certain extent, taken into account."
The reason Maine would even consider taking a parolee from another state, Tilton said, "is the Uniform Interstate Compact. Every state in the country has signed on to an agreement to allow people released from incarceration to transfer to other states. This is a very mobile society, with hundreds of thousands of people released from prison. We consider taking people from other states because other states reciprocate by taking ours. Without the compact, parolees could just go anywhere at any time, with no supervision or control. There have been occasions, not by Vermont, of states dumping violent offenders on other states. The compact is our protection against that."
Tilton said Maine now is home to about 20 convicted murderers released from other states. "What's interesting is that that is exactly the same number as we have sent to other states through the compact," he said. "Our imports and exports are balanced. In contrast, other states, like Florida, have many more coming in than leaving."
Aho said Friday he is willing to open his Lincolnville home and business to Rebideau because he is convinced the convict deserves a second chance.
"I met Ray through my volunteer work with inmates at the Warren prison farm, and from our first meeting, he has always come across as a sincere person who has worked hard to turn his life around," Aho said. "I'm a good judge of character. This is not a rash decision. I've put a lot of research into this. I've been working closely with his abuse counselor. I've gained a lot of insight into his situation. He's done his time, almost 23 years in prison, since he was a young man. I think it would be an injustice to keep him in after he's done so much to help himself."

Mystery meat no more Husson's food services wins national acclaim

Author: Nancy Garland Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]30 Jan 1995: 1.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413935960?accountid=10457

Abstract: If you want to hear a culinary horror story, engage someone who's been to college on the topic of cafeteria food. The resulting spew of culinary gore -- or culinary gaffe -- will rival Jason's machete-wielding antics in the latest "Friday the 13th" sequel. Fear no more, stomachs that have suffered the grease and grit of mystery meat and overcooked vegetables. Husson College, a 1,200-student campus in Bangor, can provide definite relief from cafeteria anxiety. The staff of the college's dining service runs a program that's "one of the best in the business," according to a national group that monitors college food. Husson ranked with the University of Pennsylvania, Rochester Institute of Technology in New York, Kansas State University and Ashland University in Ohio for its superior food and high-quality dining service, according to an article titled "The Best in the Business," in a national marketing newsletter put out by the Michigan-based National Association of College and University Food Services.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Mystery+meat+no+more+Husson%27s+food+services+wins+national+acclaim&amp;author=Nancy+Garland+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-01-30&amp;spage=1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   If you want to hear a culinary horror story, engage someone who's been to college on the topic of cafeteria food. The resulting spew of culinary gore -- or culinary gaffe -- will rival Jason's machete-wielding antics in the latest "Friday the 13th" sequel.
One Bangor woman recalled a frosted cupcake, complete with cigarette butt, gracing her food tray during a memorable meal on a Massachusetts campus.
A local chef recalled pulling a round hairball -- not just one piece of hair -- from an otherwise tempting bowl of minnestrone soup one chilly day when he was a college freshman in Maine.
Fear no more, stomachs that have suffered the grease and grit of mystery meat and overcooked vegetables. Husson College, a 1,200-student campus in Bangor, can provide definite relief from cafeteria anxiety. The staff of the college's dining service runs a program that's "one of the best in the business," according to a national group that monitors college food.
Husson ranked with the University of Pennsylvania, Rochester Institute of Technology in New York, Kansas State University and Ashland University in Ohio for its superior food and high-quality dining service, according to an article titled "The Best in the Business," in a national marketing newsletter put out by the Michigan-based National Association of College and University Food Services.
The newsletter is sent to more than 6,000 senior college officials nationwide. Husson Food Services was praised for being a "magnet for a variety of socially significant events."
Mixing culinary excellence with a true desire to serve, Mike San Antonio, Husson dining services director, has helped his program evolve into a key attraction for recruiting students to the central Maine campus.
It's "kind of a shock" to receive national recognition for a good job done every day, he said. The Husson Food Service Program "is a story waiting to be told," said San Antonio, who credited the enthusiasm and skill of his staff with making the program work.
On any given day, Husson students can sample entrees from the perenially popular baked turkey with cornbread stuffing to an occasional Shrimp Etouffee, which is an elaborate Cajun dish that includes three different kinds of pepper to bring out varied tastes.
A deli bar featuring cheese, meats and sandwich fixings stands beside a 33-item salad bar offering traditional fare for diners who want simpler meals, but San Antonio is most proud of the innovative dishes concocted by staff that offer high-quality taste and variety.
Spicy Peanut Chicken, a surprisingly delicious combination of vegetables, peanuts and fresh, tender chicken, will be one of the centerpiece entrees of the cafeteria's supper celebration of Chinese New Year Wednesday, Feb. 1. About 15 different dishes will be served at the event, part of the dining service's "Taste of the World" series.
San Antonio, who collects cookbooks in his spare time, may plan a breakfast for hundreds of local businessmen and women, while consulting with his chefs about an innovative meal to serve more than 600 students who will dine at Dickerman Dining Commons that evening.
In the past six months, Husson has served as host to a gubernatorial debate, which was televised from the dining commons, and a three-day Maine Senior Olympics event in September.
Mixing large-scale catering with the daily routine of feeding hundreds of students three times a day may seem daunting, but San Antonio says anything is possible with an enthusiastic attitude and a true desire to serve.
Dining service staff work hard to instill a family atmosphere in the dining room. From breakfast through lunch and dinner, "we want students to feel at home here," San Antonio said.
Formal dinners are put on by the dining staff once or twice a semester to acquaint students destined for heady business heights about the proper use of salad forks and soup spoons.
About once a month, the cafeteria puts on an installment of its "Taste of America" or "Taste of the World" series. On these days, the menu will feature food from various parts of the country, or various parts of the world.
Last October, the cafeteria threw a culinary bash to observe the German Oktoberfest rite. It also offered fare to mark mid-winter Mardi Gras in New Orleans.
The following recipes are samples of the fare to be served at Husson's Chinese New Year observance.
Spicy Peanut Chicken
by Doug Parent, chef, Husson College Dining Service
1 tablespoon sesame seed oil or vegetable oil 1 1/2 pounds chicken meat, boneless and skinless 1/4 cup carrots 1/4 cup celery 1/4 cup snow peas 1/4 cup red pepper 1/4 cup green pepper 1/2 cup dry roasted peanuts 1/8 teaspoon crushed red pepper 1/8 teaspoon cayenne pepper 1/4 cup hoisin sauce 1/4 cup oyster sauce
Prepare vegetables by washing, peeling and trimming. Cut all vegetables and chicken into 1/2-inch cubes and set aside. Heat oil over medium-high heat until smoking in wok or saute pan. Add chicken and stir-fry until browned and remove to a plate. Add vegetables and stir-fry until hot but still crispy, about 3 minutes. Return chicken to vegetables. Add peanuts and spices to meat and vegetables. Stir-fry 2 minutes. Add both sauces. Stir-fry 2 minutes.
Serves Six.
Special Fried Rice
By Ken Brezovsky, chef
Husson College Dining Service
1 tablespoon oil 1/4 cup scallions, 1/2-inch dice 1/4 cup red pepper, 1/2-inch dice 1/4 cup green pepper, 1/2-inch dice 1/4 cup water chestnut, sliced 3 eggs, scrambled 1/8 teaspoon salt 1/3 cup soy sauce 4 cups steamed rice 1/2 cup bean sprouts, washed
Heat oil over medium-high heat in a wok or saute pan. Add scallions, red pepper, green pepper and water chestnut. Stir-fry 5 minutes and remove to a plate. Prepare omelet with reserved eggs. Remove omelet and cut into small strips. Return vegetables and the eggs to the wok. Add salt, soy sauce, rice and bean sprouts. Stir-fry for 5 minutes and serve piping hot.
Serves Six
Double Chocolate Chip Cookies
By Craig Kenny, baker
Husson College Dining Service
2 1/3 cups shortening 3 1/3 cups sugar 1/2 cup powdered milk 1/4 teaspoon salt 6 large eggs 3/4 cup water 1/2 teaspoon baking soda 2 tablespoons vanilla 6 3/4 cups cake flour 1 1/2 cups cocoa powder 4 teaspoons baking powder 1 pound semisweet chocolate chips 1 pound white chocolate chips
With an electric mixer, cream together shortening, sugar, powdered milk and salt. Add eggs one at a time and incorporate fully before adding additional eggs.
Combine water, baking soda and vanilla. Let baking soda dissolve in the water. Add to the shortening and mix thoroughly.
Sift dry ingredients, add to the shortening and water mixture.
Add semisweet and white chocolate chips and fold into mixture. Scoop cookies onto a lightly greased cookie pan. Bake at 350 degrees for 9 to 10 minutes. Do not overbake. Cookies will be soft.
Makes approximately six dozen cookies.
Illustration Caption: Michael San Antonio, Husson's dining services director, in the kitchen of Dickerman Dining Hall. (NEWS Photos by Marc Blanchette) Oriental food is a regular menu item at Husson, and will be served in observance of the Chinese New Year.

The sea coots had the last word on the final day of hunting

Author: Hennessey, Tom

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]21 Jan 1995: PDA.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413748555?accountid=10457

Abstract: Dawn was a smudge of drizzle and fog that touched our faces with flannelly fingers as Rick Levasseur, my son, Jeff, and I rigged "coot" tollers on a tide-exposed point in Trenton Narrows. "If I were a coot I wouldn't want to fly in this weather," said Rick, a NEWS assignment editor recently inducted as a full-fledged member of the camouflage clan. The word "coot," you may know, is a colloquialism for the white-winged scoter, a large sea duck. As we moved our gear back from the flooding tide, a glance at my watch showed 10 minutes till gunning time. During that hurry-up-and-wait interim, several more squadrons of coots winged by in tight formation without giving our invitation a nod of acknowledgment. So murky was the fog and drizzle that the coots' white wing patches, which usually flash brilliantly against their overall black-plumage, were barely visible.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+sea+coots+had+the+last+word+on+the+final+day+of+hunting&amp;author=Hennessey%2C+Tom&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-01-21&amp;spage=PDA&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Dawn was a smudge of drizzle and fog that touched our faces with flannelly fingers as Rick Levasseur, my son, Jeff, and I rigged "coot" tollers on a tide-exposed point in Trenton Narrows.
"If I were a coot I wouldn't want to fly in this weather," said Rick, a NEWS assignment editor recently inducted as a full-fledged member of the camouflage clan. The word "coot," you may know, is a colloquialism for the white-winged scoter, a large sea duck.
"They'll fly," Jeff replied as he hooked a toller to the line anchored off the point and extending back to it. "But the question is whether or not they'll toll."
"Don't bait fate," I admonished my oldest offspring while handing him the last of the big, cork-bodied tollers. As though on cue, my words were punctuated by Rick's exclamation: "Look!"
A duck hunter needs no more direction than that. Instinctively, Jeff and I stood statue-still and cut our eyes toward the tollers.
Like winged shadows emerging from the shrouding fog, a dozen or so coots flew by without dipping a wing our way. "Damn," I thought, "I don't like the looks of that." I liked it even less when, seconds later, another silhouetted flock paid no attention to what the late Owen Osborne - a former NEWS sports editor and avid waterfowler - would have called "our Charlie McCarthy ducks."
As we moved our gear back from the flooding tide, a glance at my watch showed 10 minutes till gunning time. During that hurry-up-and-wait interim, several more squadrons of coots winged by in tight formation without giving our invitation a nod of acknowledgment. So murky was the fog and drizzle that the coots' white wing patches, which usually flash brilliantly against their overall black-plumage, were barely visible.
"Either they can't see us or they're just teasing us," Rick allowed. "Can you call them?" he asked, referring to my calling mallards and black ducks during the regular duck season.
"Coots don't actually call," I explained. "The drakes grunt a little, but that's about it. Don't worry, they see the tollers, they're just not responding to them."
"Why not?" Obviously, Rick's trigger finger was itchy.
"Some days they do, some days they don't," I answered.
"They sure did the last time I was here," said Jeff, who was restraining his young Labrador retriever, appropriately named "Coot," from charging into the water at each passing flock. "They came in like they were crashing a party."
Daylight amounted to no more than dawn grown gray. Steadily, the flooding tide boosted by a south wind flowed onto the point, forcing us to retreat with the tollers in tow. Actually, conditions couldn't have been better. Only the coots were uncooperative.
But it mattered not. The beauty of a coastal dawn, regardless of season or weather, never fails to provide me with a limit bag of artistic inspiration and spiritual fulfillment. Nowhere else does nature display its masterful works and wondrous order more clearly or dramatically than where the land rises from the sea.
While, minute by minute, the restless tide changed the character of the coastline, we watched the fog thickening and thinning. Rising from the ruffled gray water, it drifted ghost-like through spruce-spired headlands standing like ancient castles.
Flocks of old squaws recited their rhythmical chants as, like flung darts, they flew swift and straight. A string of black ducks wavered high above the opposite shore. Higher, still, an eagle soared and the chiming wingbeats of whistlers betrayed their unseen flight. Rockefeller couldn't have bought it, yet it didn't cost us a nickel.
When a fishing boat chugged through the narrows we anticipated a flurry of shooting. But the only ducks the boat disturbed was a string of mergansers that swept past us in single file. Shortly thereafter, perhaps realizing that if he were to fetch anything he'd have to do it on his own, Coot swam out and started a tug of war with a mooring buoy. Needless to say, the buoy won.
By midmorning the tide had shoved us back to where garlands of rockweed rimmed the shore. Save for a few scattered singles and pairs, the morning flights had ended. That is, of course, until we started taking up the tollers. Directly, five coots swung toward us, set their wings and then flared away. "See?" Rick reminded, "I told you they were just teasing us."
Simply put, the coots won on that last day of the sea-duck hunting season, but we were far from being skunked. Before leaving, nature again provided an opportunity to see, if not feel, the pulse of Planet Earth. While wading and unhooking decoys, we noticed streams of bubbles rising from the bottom for as far as we could see.
The point we were on was strewn with mussel beds, and as the tide covered them, the bivalve mollusks began feeding by pumping and filtering water, hence the bubbles. Think of streams of bubbles rising in a potful of simmering water, multiply it by hundreds, and you've got the picture.
After a somewhat soggy tailgate party of coffee and raisin-bran muffins, we loaded our gear and Coot into the capped pickup and departed. Admittedly, there was a degree of satisfaction in knowing that, for a year or so, we wouldn't have to worry about winds and tides and rigging tollers on the point, while wondering, of course, if the coots would toll.
Some days they do, some days they don't. It really doesn't matter.

High temps turning ice treacherous

Author: Hennessey, Tom

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]19 Jan 1995: PDA.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413733586?accountid=10457

Abstract: Most outdoors-oriented people know that moving water freezes slowly and usually less than solid, if at all. In fact, around these parts that principle often is applied to avoiding frozen water pipes by allowing faucets to trickle during periods of sub-zero cold. With that in mind, consider the amount of water now flowing into and onto lakes and ponds as brooks, bogs, rivers, and streams spill their burdens of rain and snow melt. The message is clear: the solderings of ice sealing bodies of water are corroding quickly and will continue to do so until the spates and warm weather subside. Mother Nature has a full bag of tricks with which to deteriorate ice in a hurry and, currently, she is putting them all to good use. You probably know the weight of water on ice forces it downward, causing it to become weakened by submersion. But do you know that the weight of 1 inch of water covering an acre of ice translates to about 113 tons? And so you won't think that seemingly outlandish figure is an exaggeration of the kind commonly attributed to fishermen, understand that it was provided by Wes Hallowell, a river engineer at the Kennebec Water Power Co. in Waterville. Again, what we have now is a flushing action of excess water that will weaken ice conditions significantly. Surely, you've seen how quickly water whirlpooling into your ice-fishing holes widens those openings in only a few hours. Consider, then, that as you read this the same kind of action is occurring in every break, crack, crevice, and pressure ridge wrinkling the ice of Maine's inland waters. Also, keep in mind that as swollen tributary waters subside, lakes and ponds will drop accordingly, causing more breaks in ice fields.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=High+temps+turning+ice+treacherous&amp;author=Hennessey%2C+Tom&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1995-01-19&amp;spage=PDA&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Without question, the recent serving of soft weather spells trouble for sportsmen. In this scenario, however, trouble can be spelled I-C-E. The frozen pavements of lakes and ponds were treacherous enough before the "January thaw" set in, but now, after the dissolving effects of rain, drizzle, fog, and spring-like temperatures, ice conditions could be described as totally untrustworthy.
Most outdoors-oriented people know that moving water freezes slowly and usually less than solid, if at all. In fact, around these parts that principle often is applied to avoiding frozen water pipes by allowing faucets to trickle during periods of sub-zero cold. With that in mind, consider the amount of water now flowing into and onto lakes and ponds as brooks, bogs, rivers, and streams spill their burdens of rain and snow melt. The message is clear: the solderings of ice sealing bodies of water are corroding quickly and will continue to do so until the spates and warm weather subside.
That, of course, increases the always-present dangers of water moving at inlets and outlets, around spring holes and in lakes that have currents. Such lakes usually are flowages created by dams. Include the influences of winds and you have to agree that, at the moment, it will make sense to postpone your ice fishing plans and, perhaps, tie a few more flies.
Mother Nature has a full bag of tricks with which to deteriorate ice in a hurry and, currently, she is putting them all to good use. You probably know the weight of water on ice forces it downward, causing it to become weakened by submersion. But do you know that the weight of 1 inch of water covering an acre of ice translates to about 113 tons? And so you won't think that seemingly outlandish figure is an exaggeration of the kind commonly attributed to fishermen, understand that it was provided by Wes Hallowell, a river engineer at the Kennebec Water Power Co. in Waterville.
Again, what we have now is a flushing action of excess water that will weaken ice conditions significantly. Surely, you've seen how quickly water whirlpooling into your ice-fishing holes widens those openings in only a few hours. Consider, then, that as you read this the same kind of action is occurring in every break, crack, crevice, and pressure ridge wrinkling the ice of Maine's inland waters. Also, keep in mind that as swollen tributary waters subside, lakes and ponds will drop accordingly, causing more breaks in ice fields.
Last, but by no means least, snow cover on lakes and ponds was, for the most part, removed by the recent thaw. The result is that, in some places, sunlight will penetrate ice and actually warm the surface water directly beneath it. This causes the undersurface of the ice to honeycomb and contribute to the corrosion of ice that may have been solid a few days ago.
Several lakes on Mount Desert Island are mostly clear of ice, reports fisheries technician Greg Burr, who works for the Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife. Echo and Eagle lakes are both clear of ice, Burr says, adding that Long Pond is practically open.
Tunk Lake of Township 10, which is between Franklin and Cherryfield, also has a large portion of open water, Burr said, adding that people were fishing on the lake on Saturday.
Even when January's traditionally frigid weather returns to make new ice, sportsmen should use caution when venturing onto frozen water. For sure, there'll be layers of water, slush, and snow-ice that will make traveling difficult and dangerous, to say the least. If you've left tracks in this neck of the woods for any length of time, you know there's plenty of winter left. Be patient, your ice-fishing shack isn't going anywhere and, besides, right about now there's probably about a foot or so of water in it.
Here's one you won't want to miss: come Jan. 22, 11:30 a.m.-2:30 p.m., the Hungry Hollow 76'ers Snowmobile Club will hold its annual Stew and Chowder Day at the clubhouse on Horseback Road in Levant. The public is invited to partake of an impressive menu featuring Al's Sensational Seafood Chowder, $5; Dawn's Best Beef Stew, $3.50; Dot's Awesome Oyster Stew, $5; Millie's Creamy Corn Chowder, $2.50. Biscuits, beverages, pickles, and crackers will be served with all of the above and the grill will be open if you prefer to order a hamburger or hot dog.
Frankly, after salivating over the aforementioned menu, I can't imagine opting for the latter - that would be like drinking beer when there's bourbon on the bar. Seeing as there's no snow to run your sled on and no football games on television, the 76'ers Stew and Chowder Day sounds like a great place to be on Sunday.
Thanks to wildlife biologist Brad Allen's recommendation, Maine's wild turkey hunters will have a chance to bag 250 more permits for this spring's May 1-29 spring hunt. Basing its decision on management data regarding Maine's expanding population of wild turkeys, the state's Fish and Wildlife Advisory Council recently voted to increase the number of permits from 500 to 750.
Applications for turkey-hunting permits are now available at hunting and fishing license agents statewide. The deadline for submitting applications is Feb. 1. Application forms will be mailed to hunters who participated in last year's turkey hunt.

Jonesport man proposes new lobster pound

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]20 Dec 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413808377?accountid=10457

Abstract: With fewer fin fish preying on lobsters, which may account in part for the current success of lobster fishermen, a Jonesport native is proposing to build a new lobster pound capable of holding about 80,000 pounds of lobster at Hopkins Point this spring. If the commercial project is approved, the [Charles "Buster" Huntley Jr.] pound would be the third man-made lobster enclosure on the north side of Moosabec Reach. There are about eight working lobster pounds on Beals Island, including two on Moosabec Reach. At a preapplication meeting with several agency representatives last week at Jonesport, Huntley and his consultants, Robert Costa of Perry and Bruce Colbeth of Beals, said the new holding facility would add to the 850,000 pounds of lobster stored each winter in the Jonesport-Beals area. Colbeth said the new pound would create another opportunity for fishermen to market the natural resource.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Jonesport+man+proposes+new+lobster+pound&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-12-20&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: JONESPORT -- With fewer fin fish preying on lobsters, which may account in part for the current success of lobster fishermen, a Jonesport native is proposing to build a new lobster pound capable of holding about 80,000 pounds of lobster at Hopkins Point this spring.
Charles "Buster" Huntley Jr. wants to build a $150,000 lobster holding facility on his property facing Moosabec Reach over an estimated three-month period beginning March 1, if he secures the required permits from state and federal agencies.
With approval from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, the Environmental Protection Agency, the Maine Department of Environmental Protection, and the Department of Marine Resources, Huntley would open his pound on July 1 within the town's approved maritime district.
David Killoy, a spokesman for the Corps of Engineers in Boston, said Monday that if he receives the Jonesport businessman's final permit application by the end of the year, Huntley could receive a decision by March 1. A 30-day public information and comment period would precede a one-month examination of the project by state and federal agencies.
If the commercial project is approved, the Huntley pound would be the third man-made lobster enclosure on the north side of Moosabec Reach. There are about eight working lobster pounds on Beals Island, including two on Moosabec Reach.
The project would use about 3 acres of a small cove on the shoreline a few feet south of Huntley's home. The L-shaped berm that would be erected to confine the lobsters would extend from Hopkins Point east about 300 feet. The design plan includes a long ledge as part of the overall retaining wall.
The berm would consist of gravel-filled sheet steel pilings about 17 feet tall, leaving bout 4 feet of its rocky top exposed at high tide. Moosabec Reach often has 12-foot tides.
Heavy stone riprap would protect the pound from eroding into Moosabec Reach. "One way to build it is the safe way," Huntley said. "When you have a lot of money invested in something, you want that investment to stand up. A 60-mile breeze is common here during the winter."
A native of Hopkins Point, he said he was very familiar with local storms, ice action and other conditions that would have an impact on the berm.
Other features of the pound would include a 2-foot-deep, water-filled trench dug along the inside edge of the berm. The trench is needed to prevent lobsters from crawling out of their enclosure. A single gate at the east end of the facility would enable it to be drained annually for cleaning and possibly harvesting of shellfish with approval of the Department of Marine Resources.
At a preapplication meeting with several agency representatives last week at Jonesport, Huntley and his consultants, Robert Costa of Perry and Bruce Colbeth of Beals, said the new holding facility would add to the 850,000 pounds of lobster stored each winter in the Jonesport-Beals area. Colbeth said the new pound would create another opportunity for fishermen to market the natural resource.
"For fall fishermen, pounds are the super value part of the industry," he said. "Without pounds, fishermen are at the mercy of the open market." A petition signed by 155 Jonesport area residents was presented in support of Huntley's project.
Colbeth explained why Down East lobster fishermen are landing about 75 percent of the state's total lobster catch, and why the lobster industry as a whole is having a growth year that may include a new production record.
"The groundfish are being caught up. The groundfish eat small lobsters," he said. "That's why we are now catching more lobsters. This industry is not suffering as other areas of the fishing industry are."
Poundkeepers fill their pounds from early September until mid-February. Few lobsters are caught from February until March. The facility would provide protection for softshell lobsters against natural predators.
Colbeth said Huntley was seeking permission to build a new pound because recent efforts to purchase the Flying Place lobster pound at Beals were unsuccessful. The facility, formerly owned by Edmund Alley, has been idle for about 20 years.
"I've been after it two years ... but the cost is too high," Colbeth said.

People: Huntley, Charles "Buster" Jr Colbeth, Bruce
