Christmas goose marks a family tradition

Author: Katrina Veeder Special to the NEWS

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]19 Dec 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413815190?accountid=10457

Abstract: Preheat oven to 375. Pat goose dry. Pull out fat from cavity. Rub inside and outside of goose with cut side of orange. Combine salt and pepper, and rub inside and outside of goose. Place orange, onion, bay leaves, and 12 drained prunes in goose cavity. Tie legs together. Place goose on rack in roasting pan. Pierce all over with small metal skewer or toothpick. Roast goose for 15 minutes. Reduce temperature to 350 and roast 30 minutes longer. Remove fat from roasting pan. Combine remaining 1/4 cup wine and 1/4 cup prune juice, and brush some over goose. Continue roasting goose until juices run clear when pierced in thickest part of thigh, basting goose with wine mixture and removing fat from pan occasionally. Strain prune poaching liquid, reserving prunes. Degrease roasting juices. Add 1/2 cup of poaching liquid to roasting pan and bring to boil, scraping up any browned bits. Transfer to heavy medium saucepan. Add Armagnac, remaining poaching liquid, and degreased roasting juices. Boil until flavors are intense, about 15 minutes. Knead butter and flour together. Whisk into sauce in small bits and simmer until thick, about 8 minutes. Add poached prunes and chestnuts, and heat through.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Christmas+goose+marks+a+family+tradition&amp;author=Katrina+Veeder+Special+to+the+NEWS&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-12-19&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: It's the event of the year.
Grandmother Thompson's Tiffany silverware is dragged out of the closet and polished, her grapevine crystal goblets and hollow-stemmed champagne glasses are washed, and her mother's leaf-imprinted, gold-edged china is brought out.
The plum pudding is made a month in advance, allowing for the marinating rum to soak into the pudding's every atom. The baked apples are slow cooked, and the oysters arrive fresh from Boston. The champagne is chilled, and the goose is roasted before the guests arrive in their tuxedos and evening dresses.
And children are left at home, with the babysitters.
Christmas Eve dinner has been done like this for at least 50 years, according to Eunice Phillips, who carries on the family tradition at her Hancock Point home.
"For as long as I can remember it's been done, and I'm 57," said the Elmira, N.Y., native. "I'm assuming that it's been something that my grandparents had been doing for years."
A few changes have been made over the years, of course. Guests no longer wear tuxedos and evening gowns, as it could be a little precarious getting out of the car wearing heels on Phillips' back road. The goose is no longer fresh, but arrives frozen from Shop n' Save.
"I think the geese that are being raised now are much better," Phillips said. "I never told my mother, but I tended to think that they were dry and extremely fat.
"I can remember taking out three coffee cans of fat," she continued, as her two Schnauzers, Phipps and Chips, cavorted on the couch with her. "But now I think they're moister and not as fat. I enjoy them."
The job of cooking Christmas Eve dinner passed to her while she was still in New York, although Phillip's mother dissuaded her from cooking goose after Grandmother Thompson's death.
"My mother, oddly enough, never liked goose, but always ate it at Christmas time," she recalled. "But when my (maternal) grandmother died, Mom came to me and said, `I don't know how to approach you with this but ..."
So the goose tradition went on hiatus for a few years, but Phillips knew she would bring it back when she left home.
"I'm the traditionalist in the family, so I guess I always knew that I would be the one that would be cooking," she said, noting that her Grandmother Thompson also had that inkling.
Phillips, a nurse manager at Bar Harbor's Summitt House, carries on the Christmas Eve tradition as best her schedule allows. This year, eight members of the Phillips clan celebrated the dinner Dec. 17, but at least the theme remains the same.
"We're a very close family," Phillips said, her white hair framing her blue eyes. "I like doing it. It's very gratifying to do something the everyone enjoys."
Roast Goose with Chestnut, Prunes and Armagnac
16-ounce package of pitted prunes
3 cups beef stock or canned beef broth
1 3/4 cups dry red wine
1 1/4 cups prune juice
12-13 pound goose
1 orange, quartered
1 tablespoon salt
1 tablespoon ground pepper
1 large onion, cut into 8 pieces
3 bay leaves
6 tablespoons Armagnac, Cognac, or other brandy
1 tablespoon butter, room temperature
1 tablespoon all-purpose flour
7-ounce jar of steamed or roasted chestnuts
Chopped fresh parsley
Combine prunes, stock, 1 1/2 cup of red wine, 1 cup of prune juice in a heavy medium saucepan. Simmer for 10 minutes. Remove mixture from heat. Transfer 12 prunes to small bowl, using slotted spoon.
Preheat oven to 375. Pat goose dry. Pull out fat from cavity. Rub inside and outside of goose with cut side of orange. Combine salt and pepper, and rub inside and outside of goose. Place orange, onion, bay leaves, and 12 drained prunes in goose cavity. Tie legs together. Place goose on rack in roasting pan. Pierce all over with small metal skewer or toothpick.
Roast goose for 15 minutes. Reduce temperature to 350 and roast 30 minutes longer. Remove fat from roasting pan. Combine remaining 1/4 cup wine and 1/4 cup prune juice, and brush some over goose. Continue roasting goose until juices run clear when pierced in thickest part of thigh, basting goose with wine mixture and removing fat from pan occasionally.
Transfer goose to platter and tent with foil. Let stand for 20 minutes.
Strain prune poaching liquid, reserving prunes. Degrease roasting juices. Add 1/2 cup of poaching liquid to roasting pan and bring to boil, scraping up any browned bits. Transfer to heavy medium saucepan. Add Armagnac, remaining poaching liquid, and degreased roasting juices. Boil until flavors are intense, about 15 minutes. Knead butter and flour together. Whisk into sauce in small bits and simmer until thick, about 8 minutes. Add poached prunes and chestnuts, and heat through.
Sprinkle with parsley.
Carve goose into thin slices. Spoon sauce, chestnuts and prunes over goose slices.
Illustration Caption: The baked apples are slow cooked, and the oysters (left) arrive fresh from Boston. Eunice Phillips rubs an orange onto her Christmas goose. (NEWS Photos by Michael York)

People: Phillips, Eunice

____________________________________________________________

Holden pupils see scenes of the sea Classes dive into study of ocean life

Author: David N. Walsh Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]09 Dec 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413817793?accountid=10457

Abstract: With their teachers, Joy Knowles and Jan Washburn, the pupils have participated for two months in the Maine State Department of Marine Resources-sponsored program called The Sea Comes to the Classroom. It does, in the form of a saltwater aquarium teeming with sea life. The children pointed out a sea whelk, a hermit crab, toad crabs, sea urchins, mussels, clams, scallops, oysters, deep-water slugs, and small fish called mummy chugs. First-graders Shelby Pickering (from left), Andrew Stevens and Brett Thurlow at the Winn-Lee Elementary School learn about starfish in the state's Sea Comes to the Classroom. (NEWS Photo by Mary Anne Lagasse) Second-grader David Madden and his classmates study a lobster from an aquarium at Holden Elementary School. He is a pupil in a class taught by Joy Knowles. (NEWS Photo by Marc Blanchette)

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Holden+pupils+see+scenes+of+the+sea+Classes+dive+into+study+of+ocean+life&amp;author=David+N.+Walsh+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-12-09&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: HOLDEN -- Children in the second grade at Holden Elementary School possess a knowledge of intertidal and tidal zone sea life that can easily equal or exceed that of any child who grew up on the Maine coast.
With their teachers, Joy Knowles and Jan Washburn, the pupils have participated for two months in the Maine State Department of Marine Resources-sponsored program called The Sea Comes to the Classroom. It does, in the form of a saltwater aquarium teeming with sea life.
A group of pupils from Knowles' and Washburn's classes gathered earlier this week to show off what they had learned.
Tyler Isherwood, his face close to the aquarium, said, "I like the oyster best because it is the first time I ever saw one. They eat plankton. You can't see it because it is microscopic."
Kelsey Haddix's favorite creature in the saltwater aquarium was the sea anemone. She pointed to the animal that "looks like a plant, only it's really an animal."
Kelly Crotty had no problem deciding what he liked. "The lobster. The way it moves. It's alive and pretty and it can mess up all the others."
Genna Duplisea wanted to be original and pick another resident of the tank, she said, but she said she too had to go with the lobster. "I would have to say the lobster, because the lobster ate the crab."
Kelly Crotty said it also ate a hermit crab when the aquarium was in her classroom.
Nicole LeBlanc said, "The scallop is best because it flies like a flying saucer and you can see its blue eyes when it is open."
David McDonald and Dane Woodhead said they were going to dissect a squid and write their names with its ink.
McDonald added that his No. 1 choice of all the creatures in the aquarium had to be the lobster.
"He doesn't pay attention to where he's going. One time he lost his elastic and ate a hermit crab and a scallop, and the sea cucumber died," he said.
LeBlanc pointed out other occupants in the water. "That's a sea slug, and that's a moon snail."
Woodhead and Ben Pooler liked the moon snail because when a starfish tries to eat it, "it makes a layer of slime and goo on itself and the starfish slips off."
The boys delighted in telling that the starfish's stomach comes out of its mouth to eat up clams and scallops.
"I like the lobster," said Pooler. "It fiddles around and does damage. It killed a clam and a hermit crab. The fish bother him."
The children pointed out a sea whelk, a hermit crab, toad crabs, sea urchins, mussels, clams, scallops, oysters, deep-water slugs, and small fish called mummy chugs.
The purpose of the program, said Elaine Jones, director of Marine Education for the Department of Marine Resources, is to train teachers to be knowledgeable about commercial and recreational fisheries and to assist them in passing that information on to students.
The course is also good for teacher recertification credits, and the teachers then can particpate in the department's classroom program.
Jones said she was pleased with the reaction she was getting from teachers from around the state and the degree of learning from the program that the children have shown.
Jones said she took the job with the department three years ago. "Before I got there, two educators traveled around the state and brought a cooler with sea life with them," she said.
She determined the program, as it was then, provided a service, but really was not training teachers. She managed to get some federal funding, and the program developed. She and two assistants administer the program to groups of teachers all over the state.
The department has five 40-gallon saltwater aquariums and two touch tanks, filled with intertidal and deep-water sea creatures.
The 100-gallon touch tank, which was not placed at the Holden school, said Jones, is an open tub with a refrigerated system because the water in both the tanks and aquariums has to be maintained at around 50 degrees. The tank is about 2 1/2 feet wide and 4 feet long.
The fish, shellfish and animals in the aquarium are fed with scallop meat. It doesn't dissolve in water and the children enjoy watching the animals, she said.
The children also get an understanding of the food chain, especially by watching the lobster. If they forget to feed the animals, the lobster turns on all the other creatures.
"We train the teachers and supply them with the animals," said Jones.
The course operates out of College of the Atlantic in Bar Harbor in the summers, where teachers are taken out in the field and taught about the different environments.
Illustration Caption: First-graders Shelby Pickering (from left), Andrew Stevens and Brett Thurlow at the Winn-Lee Elementary School learn about starfish in the state's Sea Comes to the Classroom. (NEWS Photo by Mary Anne Lagasse) Second-grader David Madden and his classmates study a lobster from an aquarium at Holden Elementary School. He is a pupil in a class taught by Joy Knowles. (NEWS Photo by Marc Blanchette)

People: Knowles, Joy Jones, Elaine

Perry men seek to harvest from sea Federal permit would allow offshore cult seaweed

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]06 Dec 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413785403?accountid=10457

Abstract: [Perry] -- Two Perry men have applied for a permit from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to install fixed and floating structures in waters off Eastport and Perry for the cultivation of green sea urchins, Atlantic deep-sea scallops, quahogs, waved whelks, blue mussels and seaweed species to include nori, dulse and Irish moss.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Perry+men+seek+to+harvest+from+sea+Federal+permit+would+allow+offshore+cult+seaweed&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-12-06&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PERRY -- Two Perry men have applied for a permit from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to install fixed and floating structures in waters off Eastport and Perry for the cultivation of green sea urchins, Atlantic deep-sea scallops, quahogs, waved whelks, blue mussels and seaweed species to include nori, dulse and Irish moss.
Stanley MacNichol and Thomas Pottle filed the application for the federal permit in compliance with Section 10 of the Rivers and Harbors Act of 1899, which provides for federal regulation of any work in, under or over navigable waters of the United States.
The applicants hope to use an irregularly shaped 150-acre subtidal area.
According to a public notice filed by the corps, "Legal size shellfish will be harvested from other areas during open season by traditional means and placed within the cultivation site. After additional grow out, and depending on market demand, they will be harvested and sold to U.S. markets. This bottom culture of shellfish will require no fixed or floating structures with the exception of two 16-by-12-foot bottom moored floating storage boxes which will hold urchins prior to harvesting."
The two men also have submitted a plan to install and maintain up to 40 seaweed grow-out systems. The systems will consist of individual 5-by-10-foot rectangular net panels suspended by buoys from timber stakes driven into the bottom. The net panels will be connected to form 5-by-60-foot units. Those units will be connected together in groups of 12, to form a 60-by-60-foot grow-out system.
An initial installation of 40 systems is planned, but the applicants may install up to 192 systems in the future. Nori and other seaweed species would be harvested seasonally, processed into dried sheets and sold to U.S. markets.
Comments on the application must be submitted before Dec. 30. Written statements should be sent to Jay Clement, at the New England Division, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, RR 2, Box 1855, Manchester 04351.

Company / organization: Name: Army Corps of Engineers; NAICS: 928110; SIC: 9700

____________________________________________________________

Company will clean Brunswick's clams Process makes polluted clams safe to eat

Author: (AP)

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]26 Nov 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413722458?accountid=10457

Abstract: The clams will be sent to Spinney Creek's plant in Eliot, where they will be cleaned through an extensive process called "depuration," which makes clams from some polluted areas safe to eat. Meanwhile, the Spinney Creek company needs Maine softshell clams to clean and sell to the high end of the shellfish market -- hotel restaurant chains such as the Marriott and city restaurants such as Boston's Legal Seafoods. Spinney Creek buys the clams, tests them and puts them into a big vat full of sterilized sea water that [Thomas Howell] calls a "squeaky clean disinfectant aquarium."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Company+will+clean+Brunswick%27s+clams+Process+makes+polluted+clams+safe+to+eat&amp;author=%28AP%29&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-11-26&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BRUNSWICK -- About 30 area clam diggers, along with diggers from the Spinney Creek Shellfish company were prepared to start working mud this weekend in the closed Bunganuc area.
The clams will be sent to Spinney Creek's plant in Eliot, where they will be cleaned through an extensive process called "depuration," which makes clams from some polluted areas safe to eat.
The venture is a joint effort between the company and the town. Spinney Creek's plant is the only depuration facility in the state.
"As a steamer, Maine shellfish is best. So, actually I never thought of purchasing from outside the state. The fact of the matter is, the resource is in this state and the way to get it is to work with the town," said Thomas Howell, president of Spinney Creek Shellfish.
The company plans to work a 20-acre stretch of mud at the mouth of Bunganuc Creek, probably until it freezes over and then at times during the winter, said Howell.
"This is just a bonus for the licensed harvesters that we have and it comes at a great time of year when our stocks are down," said Marine Resources Warden Alan J. Houston. "This gives them fresh area that hasn't been turned over a great deal."
The total stretch of clam flats in the Bunganuc area numbers between 70 and 80 acres. The area is closed because of poor water quality. Officials are trying to find out the source of the pollution. It could be large numbers of birds in the area, or nearby farms, said Houston.
"Our No. 1 goal is to get that area cleaned up," he said. But if the area opens, it could take a few years.
Meanwhile, the Spinney Creek company needs Maine softshell clams to clean and sell to the high end of the shellfish market -- hotel restaurant chains such as the Marriott and city restaurants such as Boston's Legal Seafoods.
Spinney Creek buys the clams, tests them and puts them into a big vat full of sterilized sea water that Howell calls a "squeaky clean disinfectant aquarium."
The sea water keeps the clams alive while they pump out contaminants. The clean water also doesn't let any more contaminants into their systems.
Within eight hours, said Howell, the clams are clean. But according to regulations, the process has to take 48 hours.
"As far as competition goes, most of the product we sell is sold in Massachusetts and New York. So these are Massachusetts and New York dollars coming up to Maine," said Howell.
Howell hopes to double his plant's capacity by next summer so that it can handle 60 bushels a day.
The number of areas that are open to depuration digging statewide is decreasing, said Skip Applin, a seafood technology supervisor for the Department of Marine Resources.
"As time goes by, these rivers will get better and pollution will be abated," he said.

People: Howell, Thomas

Jury sides with former BIW worker

Author: (AP)

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]25 Nov 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413795637?accountid=10457

Abstract: An indictment handed up in January alleged that [Daniel D. Chubbuck] received between $1,000 and $5,000 in workers' compensation checks between June 1990 and August 1991. BIW claimed that Chubbuck had earned income harvesting clams during the same period but failed to report it.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Jury+sides+with+former+BIW+worker&amp;author=%28AP%29&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-11-25&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BATH -- The trial of a former Bath Iron Works employee accused of stealing more than $1,000 in Workers' Compensation benefits has ended in an acquittal.
Daniel D. Chubbuck, 51, of Edgecomb, now faces a hearing before the state Workers' Compensation Commission on an attempt by BIW to terminate his benefits.
The shipyard had accused Chubbuck of failing to report his income from commercial shellfishing while he was accepting compensation benefits and then lying under oath about that income.
But jurors acquitted Chubbuck of two counts of theft and one count of perjury after witnesses failed to identify him in photos taken by a private investigator that showed a man on an urchin boat.
Witnesses had trouble determining whether any of the people in the photos was Chubbuck, who resembles his two brothers.
An indictment handed up in January alleged that Chubbuck received between $1,000 and $5,000 in workers' compensation checks between June 1990 and August 1991. BIW claimed that Chubbuck had earned income harvesting clams during the same period but failed to report it.

People: Chubbuck, Daniel D

Company: BIW

Fate of Spike the Maine lobster spurs debate

Author: (AP)

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]21 Nov 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413847554?accountid=10457

Abstract: United Airlines has offered Spike a free ticket home, both sides said. In a letter Friday, Mary Tyler Moore offered Gladstone's $1,000 to free Spike.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Fate+of+Spike+the+Maine+lobster+spurs+debate&amp;author=%28AP%29&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-11-21&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: MALIBU, Calif. -- If Spike wasn't so lovable, he'd be in hot water by now.
But lobster lovers come in all stripes, and some of Spike's admirers say it's wrong to want him just for his body. They planned a protest Saturday outside Gladstone's 4 Fish, where the 12 1/2-pound Maine lobster is living out his days on display in a tank.
They want him taken back to his North Atlantic home and set free.
Earlier this month, the popular restaurant on Pacific Coast Highway planned to give away the hefty 65-year-old shellfish as a contest prize. Spike would probably have ended up on someone's dinner table, but Gladstone's decided against it.
"The customers and the staff fell in love with him," said Gladstone's spokeswoman Gayla Simmons. "We got a special tank for him, and now people are donating time to keep it up. ..."
United Airlines has offered Spike a free ticket home, both sides said. In a letter Friday, Mary Tyler Moore offered Gladstone's $1,000 to free Spike.
"I am certain that by whatever means a lobster can feel and understand its surroundings, this one would prefer to be back home," wrote the actress-producer.

Company: Gladstones

Chamberlain veterans chapter plans meeting

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]17 Nov 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413741557?accountid=10457

Abstract: Chapter members participated in several Veterans Day programs in the Bangor area. They also assisted Elks Club members in serving 50 veterans who were bused to Bangor from the Veterans Center at Togus for the club's annual oyster stew and roast beef dinner on Saturday, Nov. 12.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Chamberlain+veterans+chapter+plans+meeting&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-11-17&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BANGOR -- The Joshua Chamberlain Chapter 1865 of the Military Order of the Purple Heart will meet at 7:30 p.m. Friday, Nov. 18, at the Bangor Elks Lodge on the Odlin Road.
Since its founding a year ago the order has grown to 136 members. Its goal is 150 members. Members of the local chapter are assisting other recipients of the Purple Heart in forming chapters around the state.
Chapter members participated in several Veterans Day programs in the Bangor area. They also assisted Elks Club members in serving 50 veterans who were bused to Bangor from the Veterans Center at Togus for the club's annual oyster stew and roast beef dinner on Saturday, Nov. 12.
The Elks, headed by Joe Kelley, donate up to $7,000 a year to the veterans at Togus.
Robert A. Darveau has been appointed adjutant of the Joshua Chamberlain Chapter to replace Jack Munroe, who was appointed chief of state for the Maine Military Order of the Purple Heart.
Mark Swan of Brewer was presented with a rifle won in the chapter's recent fund-raising raffle.

Penobscot Bay tests to probe jet fuel spills at Mack Point

Author: Walter Griffin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]11 Nov 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413746825?accountid=10457

Abstract: "The Defense Department made the right decision," [Ron Huber] said. "Penobscot Bay is one of the most important spawning and nursery areas of the Gulf of Maine. If the Gulf's fish stocks are to recover, estuaries like Penobscot Bay need to have chronic pollution sources removed." Huber said the fuel storage area supplied the pipeline to Loring Air Force Base in Limestone and the Brunswick Naval Air Station. He claimed that over the past two decades more than 7,000 gallons of JP-4 and JP-5, two forms of jet fuel, are known to have leaked from the facility. Huber said the environmentalists pressed their case to the DEP and DOD during meetings over the renewal of the terminal's license. "The DEP was reluctant at first to agree to the testing, but we convinced them that Penobscot Bay was worth saving," Huber said. "We have strong hopes for Penobscot Bay as it is managed today because the bay is very clean. That's why we want to make sure the muck directly underneath where the oil tankers dock gets tested thoroughly."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Penobscot+Bay+tests+to+probe+jet+fuel+spills+at+Mack+Point&amp;author=Walter+Griffin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-11-11&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: SEARSPORT -- Water and soil tests will be administered around the military storage terminal at Mack Point to determine if thousands of gallons of jet fuel spilled over the years has harmed Penobscot Bay.
Ron Huber, director of the Coastal Waters Project in Rockland, said Thursday that the Defense Department and Maine's Department of Environmental Protection had agreed to implement the tests in the general area of a 5,000-gallon spill that occurred in 1971. The decision was made in response to requests from commercial fisher- men and environmentalists concerned about the spill's possible effects on fish and shellfish.
"The Defense Department made the right decision," Huber said. "Penobscot Bay is one of the most important spawning and nursery areas of the Gulf of Maine. If the Gulf's fish stocks are to recover, estuaries like Penobscot Bay need to have chronic pollution sources removed."
Huber said the fuel storage area supplied the pipeline to Loring Air Force Base in Limestone and the Brunswick Naval Air Station. He claimed that over the past two decades more than 7,000 gallons of JP-4 and JP-5, two forms of jet fuel, are known to have leaked from the facility. Huber said the environmentalists pressed their case to the DEP and DOD during meetings over the renewal of the terminal's license.
"The services were claiming that the fuel had evaporated and was gone," Huber said. "The DEP was taking them on good faith instead of checking. They basically were walking around looking for oil sheen in puddles."
He said the testing was critical because scientists have linked petroleum contamination of the sea floor to incomplete egg development, deformed young and increased cancer in flounder and other bottom-dwelling fish species.
While much of the petroleum from the earlier spills is believed to have dissipated, Huber said that jet fuel additives, such as ethylene bromide, persist in the environment for an unknown length of time. Ethylene bromide is a powerful carcinogen that has also been linked to birth defects and infertility.
"The DEP was reluctant at first to agree to the testing, but we convinced them that Penobscot Bay was worth saving," Huber said. "We have strong hopes for Penobscot Bay as it is managed today because the bay is very clean. That's why we want to make sure the muck directly underneath where the oil tankers dock gets tested thoroughly."
The DOD plan calls for testing core samples of soil, sediment and water from around the terminal site for the presence of a host of petrochemicals, including polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, or PAH's, which have been linked to a variety of fish ailments. Tests will be taken of the ditch and culvert that carried the 1971 spill to the beach.
Work will begin next spring and will be paid for from the budget of DOD's Fuel Support Center, Huber said.
Charlie Stevens, vice president of Clams Fiesta Inc., of Vinalhaven, said the shellfish aquaculture firm had surveyed Penobscot Bay for potential aquaculture sites last year, but found levels of petrochemical pollution too high in most of the bay.
"As a businessman, I'm disappointed that most of Penobscot Bay is unsuitable for shellfish aquaculture," Stevens said. "It's not until you are below Vinalhaven Island that the water quality is good enough. This severely limits shellfish aquaculture in the midcoast area."
Coastal activist Bob LaVangie, who also attended the meetings with the agencies, said he was pleased by the DEP's interest in biomonitoring. Biomonitoring involves placing mesh bags of clean mussels underwater in the vicinity of the terminal at Mack Point and testing them six months later for accumulated pollution.
"This will give us an accurate picture of the pollution situation," LaVangie said, adding that he and the other concerned parties planned to provide financial assistance for the testing program.

People: Huber, Ron

Committee to assess shrinking clam harvest

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]11 Nov 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413744976?accountid=10457

Abstract: According to Randy Burns, a member of the committee, clam harvesters have been meeting regularly at the town hall since early summer to find ways to stimulate and revitalize the clam industry. Clam diggers and others interested in the once abundant softshell clam industry are frustrated with a diminishing resource and the regulatory process. Members of DRSC have been successful in enlisting the expertise needed to begin resolving problems that affect clams. Last August, [Julie Hachey] and Burns met with University of Maine President Fred Hutchinson in Harrington. Hutchinson was interested in problems that affect the clam industry, and has since outlined the group's needs to his research faculty from the university's Fisheries and Aquaculture Research Group (FARG). Dr. Brian Beal, a professor of marine ecology at the University of Maine at Machias, told the group that only 20 percent of the growth of a clam occurs between May and June. Sixty percent occurs between June and August. One hundred percent growth taks place between April and mid-October. The professor said the different growth patterns were important to consider when the group devises a clam management plan.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Committee+to+assess+shrinking+clam+harvest&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-11-11&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ADDISON -- The dwindling clam industry and the closing of clam beds because of pollution will be among issues for discussion by the Down East Regional Shellfish Committee and state officials at 7 p.m. Monday, Nov. 21, at Addison Town Hall.
Paul Anderson, a biologist with the Department of Marine Resources at Lamoine, and Charlie Parker, a water quality aide with the Washington County Cooperative Extension, will discuss pollution closures in the Jonesport, Harrington and Addison area.
According to Randy Burns, a member of the committee, clam harvesters have been meeting regularly at the town hall since early summer to find ways to stimulate and revitalize the clam industry. Clam diggers and others interested in the once abundant softshell clam industry are frustrated with a diminishing resource and the regulatory process.
The DRSC consists of delegates representing the shellfish committees of Harrington, Addison and Jonesport. Assisting in organizing the DRSC has been the Washington County Cooperative Extension.
Members of the new group elected Julie Hachey of Addison and Walter Shafer of Harrington co-chairmen of the committee.
Although the clam harvest this summer seemed encouraging when compared to the 1993 landings, DRSC members have chosen not to be overly optimistic about the future of the resource.
"Something is wrong out there. We see a lot of seed clams but they don't seem to develop," said Hachey, who digs clams in Addison.
The committee's outlook is confirmed by data from the Department of Marine Resources which suggests an 84 percent decrease in landings since 1984.
The three towns have more than 170 licensed diggers and 4,500 acres of potentially productive clam beds. This represents a significant economic resource to each town and the region, said Burns.
Burns and other members said in a press release Thursday that they can play an important roll in improving shellfish management by providing a means of communication between diggers, their towns and regulatory agencies such as the DMR. The DRSC will use information gathered to strengthen each town's local shellfish committee.
Several issues concerning the future of the clam resource have been debated by the committee. Topics of concern have ranged from scuba diving for clams to the issue of financial investment vs beneficial returns from clam seeding projects.
Burns said a strong consensus of opinion has developed within the group on several issues. These included the need for gaining assurance that other factors -- such as agricultural chemicals, overboard waste discharges, and marine bloodworms and sandworms -- are not having an adverse impact on the clam population.
Members of DRSC have been successful in enlisting the expertise needed to begin resolving problems that affect clams. Last August, Hachey and Burns met with University of Maine President Fred Hutchinson in Harrington. Hutchinson was interested in problems that affect the clam industry, and has since outlined the group's needs to his research faculty from the university's Fisheries and Aquaculture Research Group (FARG).
Dr. Brian Beal, a professor of marine ecology at the University of Maine at Machias, told the group that only 20 percent of the growth of a clam occurs between May and June. Sixty percent occurs between June and August. One hundred percent growth taks place between April and mid-October. The professor said the different growth patterns were important to consider when the group devises a clam management plan.
As a result of the DRSC's contact with Beal, the Harrington Shellfish Committee decided to work with the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery in a project to determine the effects of harvesting blood and sand worms on the survival and growth of seed clams.
Harrington, already involved in a reseeding program to begin in April, has requested from DMR a three-year conservation closure in two of the town's small coves. If granted, the closure would provide security for the seed clams and an opportunity for the town and hatchery to conduct necessary research.

People: Burns, Randy Hachey, Julie

Federal grants offer chances for fishermen Funds for jigging machines, fish

Author: (AP)

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]09 Nov 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413913627?accountid=10457

Abstract: Federal grants to Maine's struggling fishing industry are giving a boost to projects that range from boats with computerized "jigging machines" to farmed cod and haddock. The grants to Maine include $174,220 to study computerized machines that fish with hooks instead of nets. John Clyde Williamson, a Kennebunk gillnet fisherman, will work with three other people to study the jigging machines now used by some Icelandic fishermen. Under a $247,333 grant, a Maine "longline" fishing boat that uses hooks instead of nets will explore the mile-deep waters beyond Georges Bank to find out what kind of fish dwell there.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Federal+grants+offer+chances+for+fishermen+Funds+for+jigging+machines%2C+fish&amp;author=%28AP%29&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-11-09&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PORTLAND -- Federal grants to Maine's struggling fishing industry are giving a boost to projects that range from boats with computerized "jigging machines" to farmed cod and haddock.
The grants are part of a $9 million program intended to develop new opportunities for New England fishermen, while taking pressure off stocks of groundfish that have declined to historic lows.
Of 28 grants totaling $4.5 million that have already been awarded, eight have gone to Maine. An additional $4.5 million is to be parceled out across the region this winter.
The grants to Maine include $174,220 to study computerized machines that fish with hooks instead of nets. John Clyde Williamson, a Kennebunk gillnet fisherman, will work with three other people to study the jigging machines now used by some Icelandic fishermen.
Under a $247,333 grant, a Maine "longline" fishing boat that uses hooks instead of nets will explore the mile-deep waters beyond Georges Bank to find out what kind of fish dwell there.
The potential catch includes orange roughy, little-known types of redfish or a strange "oilfish" that is used as food and in laxatives.
Another grant, for $37,668, seeks to determine whether marketable products can be made out of lobster shells. If successful, it would help in the disposal of the shellfish wastes and create new jobs for fishermen.
An aquaculture project that seeks to develop techniques to cultivate cod and/or haddock in hatcheries has been awarded a $500,490 grant. The fish would be released in the ocean to replenish wild fish stocks or raised in fish farms to market size.
Another project, which received an $89,725 grant, is aimed at developing a cost-effective way to harvest nori seaweed, so individuals can establish seaweed farms.
The projects provide a glimpse into the future of New England's fisheries and fishing industry.
"These pose interesting ideas that are cutting edge in terms of using the resource," said William Brennan, commissioner of the Department of Marine Resources.
The $9 million in fishing industry grants is part of the $30 million in emergency relief money that the federal government said it would provide to help ease the impact of fishing restrictions aimed at stemming the decline in groundfish stocks.
The projects fall into three categories: developing underutilized fish species; creating opportunities in aquaculture; and creating new job prospects for fishermen who leave fishing.
Barbara Stevenson, a Portland fishing boat owner who was awarded a grant to fish in the deep waters beyond Georges Bank, said there are probably fish in the region nobody has ever caught commercially.
"Because it's such a large area and nobody's fished out there, it's too high of a risk, without a grant, to find something to fish on," she said.

Youth's tip leads police to Waldoboro burglars

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]03 Nov 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413851704?accountid=10457

Abstract: Waldoboro Police Chief Leroy Jones said Wednesday an investigation by the Knox County Sheriff's Department of a possible attempt to sell a stolen gun at the Oyster River gun shop in Warren led to the arrest of an adult and a juvenile for three burglaries in Lincoln County.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Youth%27s+tip+leads+police+to+Waldoboro+burglars&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-11-03&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: WALDOBORO -- Loose lips in Warren sank a pair of burglars in Waldoboro believed responsible for a string of break-ins.
Waldoboro Police Chief Leroy Jones said Wednesday an investigation by the Knox County Sheriff's Department of a possible attempt to sell a stolen gun at the Oyster River gun shop in Warren led to the arrest of an adult and a juvenile for three burglaries in Lincoln County.
Jones said Shawn Joslyn, 18, of Coopers Mills and a 17-year-old male juvenile have been charged with burglary and theft for two Oct. 20 break-ins in his town and another the same day in Jefferson, with additional cases still under investigation. Weapons, electronic goods and cash were taken in the three daytime burglaries.
The case broke late last week when an unidentified youth tried to buy an ammunition clip for a rifle at a Waldoboro gun shop. Unable to find what he needed, the youth mentioned to the clerk that he would try to find it at Oyster River. Concerned that the gun may have been stolen, the clerk notified the Knox County Sheriff's Department.
Deputy Donald Scribner found the youth at Oyster River. Although the rifle turned out not to be stolen, the youth told Scribner he knew about the burglaries, including who the burglars were and where the stolen property was hidden.
Jones said cracking the case "took some luck in getting the tip and getting the information we needed, and a good cooperative effort by Knox County.

People: Jones, Leroy

YES on Question 2

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]02 Nov 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413725787?accountid=10457

Abstract: "Do you favor a $9,000,000 bond issue for the following purposes: (1) Four million dollars for construction of local water pollution control facilities, providing the state match for $20,000,000 in federal funds; (2) $1,000,000 for the Small Community Program; and (3) four million dollars to provide for the investigation, abatement and mitigation of threats to the public health and environment from uncontrolled hazardous substance sites or other hazardous waste discharges." For Maine's larger communities, the Department of Environmental Protection will use $4 million from this bond to match $20 million from the federal government to bolster the State Revolving Loan Fund (SRLF). The SRLF lends money to communities at below market rates to underwrite sewage treatment projects.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=YES+on+Question+2&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-11-02&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: "Do you favor a $9,000,000 bond issue for the following purposes: (1) Four million dollars for construction of local water pollution control facilities, providing the state match for $20,000,000 in federal funds; (2) $1,000,000 for the Small Community Program; and (3) four million dollars to provide for the investigation, abatement and mitigation of threats to the public health and environment from uncontrolled hazardous substance sites or other hazardous waste discharges."
Twelve times since 1960, Maine voters have dug down to bond water-pollution control projects. Next Tuesday, it is important to the quality of Maine's environment, and the economic health of its communities, that this trend of support continue.
Question 2 will address three separate programs, two that will help ease the financial burden on cities and small towns to build or maintain sewage treatment programs, and a third that will continue funding of a statewide effort to repair damage to water quality done by hazardous substances leaching from uncontrolled sites.
For Maine's larger communities, the Department of Environmental Protection will use $4 million from this bond to match $20 million from the federal government to bolster the State Revolving Loan Fund (SRLF). The SRLF lends money to communities at below market rates to underwrite sewage treatment projects.
Approximately $99 million has been loaned out so far, and in 1995, if this bond is supported by voters, cities such as Skowhegan, Brewer, Dover-Foxcroft and Bangor will have access to a fresh infusion of money to pay for construction or major maintenance on local sewage treatment projects.
Another $1 million from the bond will go to small towns where central sewage treatment facilities are impractical, but where homeowners or sometimes municipalities themselves have failing septic systems that need to be corrected or replaced.
This program already has been supported eight times by the public (to the total tune of $12.5 million). The grants to smaller communities are important to protect both fresh and salt water (20 new grants this year went to clean up shellfish-harvesting areas).
When hazardous substances are detected leaching into the water, the state steps in. In four out of five instances, the DEP identifies the responsible party, but the mess still must be controlled and mitigated. Since 1983, Maine voters have approved three similar bonds totaling $7.3 million. Without $4 million in additional funds from this request, this needed program eventually grinds to a halt.
Clean water is an asset in which Maine has invested nearly $200 million during the past quarter century. It makes good sense to continue that investment by voting "Yes" on Question 2.

A sparkling evening Wine dinner is true taste of elegance

Author: Alicia Anstead Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]31 Oct 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413749384?accountid=10457

Abstract: This weekend, as part of "Autumn in Blue Hill," a celebration of wine and food sponsored by five businesses in the small coastal town, the innkeepers Mary and Don Hartley hosted a wine dinner of local delicacies and American wine. It was one of two wine dinners and several events, including more traditional wine tastings, seminars and meals, organized around wine and food over the weekend. After the innkeepers politely seated the 35 guests at assigned tables, the first wine of dinner, a Fume Blanc Reserve, was introduced by Tim Clark, who lives in Wells and represents Mondavi. This "smoky white" wine has a name coined by Mondavi and is considered one of the world's best complements to shellfish, according to Clark. It is called "reserve" because it is the top of the best, and also of note because it is the first of Mondavi's wines to be released with the environmentally-sensitive flange-top and natural wax seal. His bliss was interrupted by a knife tapping on a glass, and Clark prepared the diners for the next wine, Mondavi's hottest work, a 1991 Pinot Noir Reserve, which was served with consumme containing guinea hen and oyster mushrooms. A velvety red wine with hints of clove, cinnamon, cassis and berry flavors, the Pinot was the reason wine importers Ed and Judi Mansing drove from Portland to attend the wine dinner. Ed Mansing's car has the license plate "MR PINOT," and the Mansings closed their eyes as they sipped from the half-full balloon wine glasses.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+sparkling+evening+Wine+dinner+is+true+taste+of+elegance&amp;author=Alicia+Anstead+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-10-31&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: You've heard of bean suppers and hunters' breakfasts.
Now meet the wine dinner.
It might go something like this:
Through a fluted champagne glass, you see bubbles giggle off of candle light. You savor a bite of green olive tapenade canapes while listening to a woman talk about a book she wrote 20 years ago, or a man explain his reasons for leaving the city life behind. Each table setting has nine utensils and six different glasses. An aroma of gourmet foods so dreamily fills the air that you could happily go mad trying to decipher each nuance.
OK, OK. It's not something you're going to find in a church hall or school cafeteria. It won't be announced by a sign on the side of the road, and it won't be as affordable as a $5 meal. It may not even be something you understand completely because the jargon of hard-core wine drinkers leaves most people dry. And how many people really know -- or care -- what all that silverware is supposed to be used for anyway?
Still, a perfectly prepared wine dinner is a true taste of elegance and ecstasy for the palate. And Blue Hill Inn, which has been hosting wine dinners a couple times a year for five years, knows that it's on to one of the most delicious trends in fine dining today.
This weekend, as part of "Autumn in Blue Hill," a celebration of wine and food sponsored by five businesses in the small coastal town, the innkeepers Mary and Don Hartley hosted a wine dinner of local delicacies and American wine. It was one of two wine dinners and several events, including more traditional wine tastings, seminars and meals, organized around wine and food over the weekend.
Representatives from two major American wineries, Beringer and Robert Mondavi, attended the dinner and spoke about the wine served with each course.
The Maison Deutz, served with the tapenade, was a California sparkler, said Mimi Giammarino, who works for Wine World Estates in Massachusetts and came to Maine for the weekend to represent Beringer. A cross varietal wine that is "toasty," the Maison Deutz was a sweet start to the meal.
After the innkeepers politely seated the 35 guests at assigned tables, the first wine of dinner, a Fume Blanc Reserve, was introduced by Tim Clark, who lives in Wells and represents Mondavi. This "smoky white" wine has a name coined by Mondavi and is considered one of the world's best complements to shellfish, according to Clark. It is called "reserve" because it is the top of the best, and also of note because it is the first of Mondavi's wines to be released with the environmentally-sensitive flange-top and natural wax seal.
Local wine specialist, David Witter, who co-runs Blue Hill Tea & Tobacco Shop and is a wine consultant for the Blue Hill Inn, stuck his nose in the round goblet and breathed deeply the tropical fruit aromas, toasty citrus flavors, and rich spice, nut and vanilla undertones of the Fume Blanc. He raised his head and smiled while he swirled the liquid and lifted it to his lips. Combined with the Cape Neddick oysters with spinach and curry, the Fume Blanc was a winner with Witter.
"Very nice," he said. "Very smooth."
His bliss was interrupted by a knife tapping on a glass, and Clark prepared the diners for the next wine, Mondavi's hottest work, a 1991 Pinot Noir Reserve, which was served with consumme containing guinea hen and oyster mushrooms. A velvety red wine with hints of clove, cinnamon, cassis and berry flavors, the Pinot was the reason wine importers Ed and Judi Mansing drove from Portland to attend the wine dinner. Ed Mansing's car has the license plate "MR PINOT," and the Mansings closed their eyes as they sipped from the half-full balloon wine glasses.
"Wine enhances food and food enhances wine," explained Judi Mansing, who left teaching to become a wine importer with her husband. "It's that blend that makes a perfect marriage."
In keeping with her philosphy, Judi Mansing suggested tasting the wine first, then the food, then the wine. In doing so, all the best flavors would be brought out, and she was right. The flavor went from sharp to mild to heavenly.
Every wine dinner gets a little louder with each course, said Giammarino when she interrupted the dining clamor to introduce the Beringer Cabernet Sauvignon that would be served with gratin of lamb medallions with leeks and westphalian ham.
"It's a concentrated fruit," she said of the wine. "The soft tannin makes you feel you have little sweaters on your teeth. It shows itself beautifully."
Several diners nodded in agreement as they took their first sip and then began eating.
After dinner, figs with rocamadour, roquefort and aged cheddar cheeses were served with Beringer's 1990 Merlot. "It's not your typical Merlot," Giammarino said grinning widely and holding up a glass of it next to her face. She explained that the grapes for this red wine are grown in California's Howell Mountain Vineyard, which is 750 miles above sea level in Napa Valley and has incredible solar penetration by day but doesn't cool down at night. The intensity of heat makes for an fast growing season and a "mean Merlot."
The final wine of the evening was a delicate, fragrant varietal called Moscato d'Oro, which is grown from an ancient grape first used 5,000 years ago in the Macedonia region. Clark compared it to an Asti spumante without the fizz, and said it was perfectly suited to the apple tart that was served. Later, over espresso, David Witter said that American wines are increasingly popular and make up nearly 45 percent of wine sales in his Blue Hill shop.
"American wines have been really good for the last 10 years," he added. "The quality is every bit as good as the French wines, but you've got to be more selective. People used to buy labels. Then they bought countries. Now, I'd rather have them just buy wines."
Before the three-hour wining-dining experience ended, Chef Andre Strong, who designed the meal in conjunction with the wine representatives, greeted the diners. They applauded his artistic presentations and delicious cuisine.
"There was a subtlety in the food that allowed the wine to express itself, and gave it a whole new flavor," said one man through the applause.
With memories of sophisticated and enticing flavors swirling on their tongues, the guests filed out into the crisp Maine night. They were still warm inside, of course, and would be until they fell asleep in the gentlest of sated tempers brought on by a wine dinner.
Illustration Caption: Tim Clark of the Robert Mondavi Winery (top) explains the finer points of a bottle of Pinot Noir Reserve, 1991, to guests at the Blue Hill Inn wine dinner. Ed and Judi Mansing of Portland (below) enjoy a glass of Cabarnet Sauvignon, private reserve, Baringer 1987. (NEWS Photo by Bob DeLong)

Prohibition repeal debated in Lamoine Some say alcohol sale would ruin unique character of their town

Author: Kathy Harbour Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]28 Oct 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413795055?accountid=10457

Abstract: That low level of business activity leads [Lamoine] Selectman Bill Collier to speak in favor of changing the town's status from dry to wet. At a public hearing this week on the issue, Collier said the liquor prohibition keeps new business, such as hotels, restaurants and campgrounds, from considering a Lamoine location. Resident Bob Alvarez agreed. About 20 years ago, Alvarez tried the general store business, operating out of his former home near Lamoine State Park. "We couldn't make a go of it because we couldn't sell beer," Alvarez said. "No store is feasible anywhere without beer. We're going beyond the realm of reasonableness that we want to be a dry town." Alluding to Lamoine's self-described status as a bedroom community of Ellsworth, Alvarez said it was a designation that leaves residential property owners paying all the taxes. "All Lamoine is getting (as a bedroom community) is kids to educate. Unless you're a schoolteacher, there is nothing great about Lamoine being a bedroom community."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Prohibition+repeal+debated+in+Lamoine+Some+say+alcohol+sale+would+ruin+unique+character+of+their+town&amp;author=Kathy+Harbour+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-10-28&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: LAMOINE -- Wet or dry: It's a question of town character residents are debating in the days leading up to a vote on repealing prohibition in Lamoine.
Those favoring a repeal of the prohibition against the sale of beer and wine argue new business might move into town if liquor can be sold, bringing with it some tax relief for residents and improving the economic character of life for the community.
Others argue that prohibition is part of Lamoine's unique character as a bedroom community. A convenience store or restaurant, they contend, would mean more traffic, trash and noise.
The question of changing the town's classification from dry to wet goes before voters Nov. 8. Lamoine is now one of only 26 communities left in Maine where the sale of beer and wine is still prohibited.
A successful petition drive over the summer has placed the matter before voters. Two Lamoine residents drafted the petition as a precursor for their proposed plans to open a small convenience store at one of the more traveled intersections in this small coastal community.
Ruth Keene and David Schroeder contend their plans are contingent on the town's repeal of its prohibition status, as a convenience store could not succeed financially without the sale of beer and wine.
Schroeder says his store "will be a quaint little store in a quaint little town that happens to sell alcohol."
Lamoine, a town of about 1,300 residents, has no business district and no stores. Almost exclusively residential, the Hancock County town with 28 miles of shoreline has only a handful of at-home businesses and contractors with small yards.
Thirteen active gravel pits owned primarily by out-of-town companies, two small shellfish-packing businesses and a lobster pound compose the remainder of significant business enterprise in Lamoine.
That low level of business activity leads Lamoine Selectman Bill Collier to speak in favor of changing the town's status from dry to wet. At a public hearing this week on the issue, Collier said the liquor prohibition keeps new business, such as hotels, restaurants and campgrounds, from considering a Lamoine location.
"Without being able to sell alcohol, we'll never have a store here," Collier said. "We shouldn't keep on hobbling business in Lamoine."
Resident Bob Alvarez agreed. About 20 years ago, Alvarez tried the general store business, operating out of his former home near Lamoine State Park. "We couldn't make a go of it because we couldn't sell beer," Alvarez said. "No store is feasible anywhere without beer. We're going beyond the realm of reasonableness that we want to be a dry town."
Alluding to Lamoine's self-described status as a bedroom community of Ellsworth, Alvarez said it was a designation that leaves residential property owners paying all the taxes. "All Lamoine is getting (as a bedroom community) is kids to educate. Unless you're a schoolteacher, there is nothing great about Lamoine being a bedroom community."
But others argue the quality of life in Lamoine would be diminished if the town votes to allow the sale of liquor, as business growth could follow.
Edward Coan, whose property is adjacent to the proposed location for a store, contends Lamoine's status as a dry community is worthy of preservation. "One unique feature of Lamoine is that it is dry. We don't have stores. We have a fortunate situation."
Coan said this week any need for business in Lamoine is "watered down" by the proximity of Ellsworth only a few miles down the road. "Look at Trenton and Ellsworth, where liquor is readily available," Coan said. "See if you think life there is more rewarding to you or your children."
Resident Andrea Gabel-Richards wondered whether business development might "change the tenor of the town," bringing in "changes to Lamoine that won't be good."
Another resident agreed. "I like the idea of Lamoine being clean." She said she favored more bed-and-breakfast establishments or cottage industries that don't rely on alcohol sales. "We want businesses ... that won't mess up our landscape," she said.
Although debated as a matter of character for the town, questions about the effects of making alcohol more available are clearly part of the issue for some.
According to Collier, those who want to drink will drive anywhere to purchase alcohol. "Prohibition doesn't work. We don't reduce drinking in Lamoine (because of prohibition)," he said. "We just force people to go to Ellsworth," thus increasing the likelihood of people driving drunk.
But resident Mary Moore disagreed. "I don't want alcohol sold here." If a store in town sells beer and wine, she said, "it would make it easier for people to drink, particularly for kids."

People: Collier, Bill Alvarez, Bob Coan, Edward

____________________________________________________________

Cobscook Bay Spectacular Conservation efforts to preserve region's many natural beauties

Author: Tom Fuller Special to the NEWS

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]26 Oct 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413757446?accountid=10457

Abstract: Of particular importance to waterfowl biologists is the fact that Cobscook is a unique and vitally important haven for migrating and wintering black ducks, which have been singled out from all other waterfowl in North America as a species of international concern. Black duck numbers are down, and while most other wildfowl species have begun to respond to international efforts to restore their numbers, black duck numbers have remained tenaciously low. Cobscook Bay's importance is underlined by the fact that fully 25 percent of all black ducks discovered during Maine's annual mid-winter waterfowl count reside in the relatively small confines of this estuary. In the past decade, however, the pressure on the land has been building. More farms have been subdivided, more shorefront lots broken out, and more prime habitat threatened. Many individuals, and several private and public organizations, identified the threat relatively early on. In 1987, a group of farsighted, but short-funded, individuals formed the Quoddy Regional Land Trust (QRLT). With their self-imposed goal of preserving land in a small corner of Maine, namely the Cobscook and Quoddy regions of Washington County, the group began accepting development easements from concerned land owners. The Maine Coast Heritage Trust (MCHT) and The Nature Conservancy (TNC) also identified the threat and focused some of their attention on the Cobscook area. Yet funds were chronically short or entirely nonexistent to protect major sections of the bay. The tides in Cobscook Bay determine when fishermen go out. Low tide often means fishing boats are left high and dry (far left). Reversing Falls Park (above) lies on the southern point of Leighten Neck facing Crow Neck. Canadian geese are among the many species of birds in the Cobscook Bay area. (Tom Fuller Photos) Maine's rocky coast offers unending resistance to the power of the tides in the Cobscook Bay area. (Tom Fuller Photo)

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Cobscook+Bay+Spectacular+Conservation+efforts+to+preserve+region%27s+many+natural+beauties&amp;author=Tom+Fuller+Special+to+the+NEWS&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-10-26&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Cobscook Bay is a wild and humbling place. It lies at the eastern tip of the United States, in Maine, and has for centuries responded only to the natural rhythms of the earth. Those rhythms are not subtle here. They are emphatic and bold. They center on the regular ebb and flow of the most powerful tides in the country -- tides that every six hours rise and fall 24 feet, an average of 1 foot every 15 minutes.
The tides, and the rugged coastline that they batter, offer spectacular beauty to all who see them. But they also harbor one of the most fertile ecosystems in the country. With the immense flow of water throughout the complex that is Cobscook Bay comes an equally immense movement of nutrition. From the plankton and microscopic organisms on up the food chain through the shellfish and herring to the large aquatic mammals, seals and whales, the waters of Cobscook Bay are an immense breadbasket of life. In addition, the untamed coastline and adjacent uplands are filled with wildlife, much of it depending on the sea.
Bald eagles are the most spectacular example of the wildlife here. Seventeen pairs now nest and raise young on the islands and shores of the inlets and back bays of Cobscook. And up to 400 eagles winter here and feast on the abundant sea life. This concentration of eagles is the densest of any region in the Northeast and the core from which biologists hope will spring a rejuvenated population of our national symbol.
In addition, Cobscook and its shoreline is also a haven for thousands upon thousands of shorebirds, like sandpipers, yellowlegs, rails and herons; for unusual and rare water birds like loons and grebes; for both nesting and migrating waterfowl like Canada geese, brandt, gadwalls, teal, black ducks, wood ducks and mallards; for diving ducks like hooded mergansers, scaup, ring-necked ducks, goldeneyes and buffleheads; for upland mammals and birds, like woodcock, spruce and ruffed grouse, bobcats, river otters, deer, bears and moose. In fact, over 200 species of birds and animals have been documented in the area by biologists working in the Moosehorn National Wildlife Refuge on the western headlands of the bay.
Of particular importance to waterfowl biologists is the fact that Cobscook is a unique and vitally important haven for migrating and wintering black ducks, which have been singled out from all other waterfowl in North America as a species of international concern. Black duck numbers are down, and while most other wildfowl species have begun to respond to international efforts to restore their numbers, black duck numbers have remained tenaciously low. Cobscook Bay's importance is underlined by the fact that fully 25 percent of all black ducks discovered during Maine's annual mid-winter waterfowl count reside in the relatively small confines of this estuary.
Yet the spectacular beauty and unusual fertility of the region has brought on a familiar threat -- subdivision of the land and development. While Cobscook and its immediate vicinity has largely escaped the rampant love of the land that has transformed much of the Maine coastline into a sea of cottages, seasonal homes and tourist attractions, the inevitable swell of pressure has increasingly infringed on the wild places of the bay. Only its remote location and the ability of the rest of the coast to absorb the demand for more land have kept Cobscook relatively safe, until recently.
In the past decade, however, the pressure on the land has been building. More farms have been subdivided, more shorefront lots broken out, and more prime habitat threatened. Many individuals, and several private and public organizations, identified the threat relatively early on. In 1987, a group of farsighted, but short-funded, individuals formed the Quoddy Regional Land Trust (QRLT). With their self-imposed goal of preserving land in a small corner of Maine, namely the Cobscook and Quoddy regions of Washington County, the group began accepting development easements from concerned land owners. The Maine Coast Heritage Trust (MCHT) and The Nature Conservancy (TNC) also identified the threat and focused some of their attention on the Cobscook area. Yet funds were chronically short or entirely nonexistent to protect major sections of the bay.
With the signing of the North American Waterfowl Management Plan by Canada, the United States and Mexico in 1986, and the subsequent creation of the Atlantic Coast Joint Venture, a specific mechanism was created to coordinate the efforts of all organizations and individuals concerned with the accelerated decline of healthy wetlands habitat throughout the North American continent. The plan specifically encouraged cooperation throughout the conservation community to protect critical habitat.
In Maine, a unique assembly of public and private organizations pooled their knowledge and efforts to form the Maine Wetlands Protection Coalition under the patronage of the Atlantic Coast Joint Venture. Represented in the group were the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, the Maine Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife and the Land for Maine's Future Board from the public sector, and TNC, Ducks Unlimited, MCHT, QRLT, the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation and others from the private sector. They identified five significant focus areas in the state in priority, making the Cobscook Bay area No. 1 on the list.
The job of protecting the bay was divided into four phases, with the first phase budgeted for completion in 1991 and the last for 1995. A total of 7,137 acres and 76.2 miles of shoreline were targeted for protection.
The financial and inspirational leaders for getting the project off the ground were the Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife and the Land for Maine's Future Board. By providing more than $1.8 million from the citizens of Maine to initiate key acquisitions, federal matching funds were acquired to further protect important habitat.
"The fact that this project is highly rated nationally should confirm just how really unique and important Cobscook Bay is to fish and wildlife resources," said Gary Donovan, the director of the wildlife division for Maine. "To be part of this effort has been one of the most rewarding experiences of my career."
In addition, the vigor with which the state pursued protection for the area helped to cement the effort of the USF&WS to expand its Moosehorn National Wildlife Refuge to protect critical habitat in the Dennys Bay area of Cobscook. That effort is geared toward 1,190 acres of prime waterfowl staging areas and eagle nesting habitat and is well under way.
And with more matching funds acquired from the North American Wetlands Conservation Act in the summer of 1994, and with money anticipated from the Interior Department for Moosehorn, the entire project soon may be completed, essentially on time and under budget.
Yet if the public organizations have provided the map through the bureaucratic maze of paperwork and funding, it is the private organizations, namely QRLT, the MCHT and TNC, that have provided the inspiration and perspiration to help individual land owners in the region understand, appreciate and embrace the project.
Specifically, QRLT, led by Allan Brooks, its executive director, and Nancy Nielsen, one of its founding members and a guiding light, have done much to assure landowners that the preservation of their acres need not be a grudging concession to big government nor a painful sacrifice of their property rights. Indeed much of the preservation that has been accomplished in the Cobscook area involves both donated and purchased easements, where landowners retain title to their land but deed development rights to a land stewardship organization.
"The people of Washington County and Cobscook Bay well understand the importance of the project," said Nancy Nielsen, "and our being a very small, regional land trust helps ensure that area residents will always have an important voice."
The MCHT, which has specialized in land easements since 1970, has lent its expertise in the negotiation of easements and the sometimes complex meanderings of the legalities involved. And TNC has been especially interested in sites with particular value to endangered species.
Each of these organizations has served the important purpose of putting a human face on a large and complex process. That process has involved many individuals, and the private organizations have assured each of them that they are as important and critical as any others.
At least as important to the local residents in the area is the fact that many innovative methods for preserving the land have been used, often benefiting them financially. Saving the Bay also may prove of benefit because it is a unique and expansive area, with many natural features and much abundant wildlife. That fact alone may provide a substantial boost to the local economy.
The Cobscook Bay Habitat Protection Project is nearing completion. There are still several key tracts that must be conserved, but much has already been accomplished. Most importantly, however, is the fact that an area of unique beauty and unparalleled wildlife diversity and importance has been recognized for its intrinsic value and has been preserved for the future.

Polluting runoff closes clam flats

Author: (AP)

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 Oct 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413792669?accountid=10457

Abstract: Pollution caused by the water runoff and raw sewage contaminated coastal waters, forcing the state to stop the harvesting of shellfish, said Sgt. George Openshaw from the Maine Marine Patrol.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Polluting+runoff+closes+clam+flats&amp;author=%28AP%29&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-10-24&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: STONINGTON -- Storm runoff that followed two days of heavy rain Down East forced the state to close clam flats in Washington and Hancock counties, authorities said Sunday.
Most coastal areas along the midcoast and Down East recorded 3 to 5 inches of rain Friday night and Saturday, said Hendricus Lulofs, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service.
The highest rainfall total was measured in Deer Isle, which was deluged with 5.29 inches of rain, Lulofs said.
Pollution caused by the water runoff and raw sewage contaminated coastal waters, forcing the state to stop the harvesting of shellfish, said Sgt. George Openshaw from the Maine Marine Patrol.
