AmeriCorps begins Maine work Group involved in many projects throughout state

Author: Dawn Gagnon Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]13 Oct 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413784776?accountid=10457

Abstract: "There's no age limit but I suspect they're mostly fairly young," said Robert Blakesley, executive director of the Maine Community Service Program administered by the State Planning Office. Blakesley and his staff are charged with providing administrative services for AmeriCorps programs in Maine and for a new state commission appointed last month by Gov. John R. McKernan. While the concept isn't new to the Portland area, the peer assistance aspect AmeriCorps' young people will bring to it is, [Neil Taliento] said. AmeriCorps workers will place, supervise and monitor the youths sentenced to work. AmeriCorps worker Karen Malley, a marine studies student at the University of Maine at Machias from Fountain Hills, Ariz., checks jugs of tropical phytoplankton at the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery. (NEWS Photo by Scott Haskell) AmeriCorps worker Rob Klimas Jr. of Millinocket, a marine studies student at the University of Maine at Machias, injects a scallop with a relaxant to encourage spawning. (NEWS Photo by Scott Haskell)

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=AmeriCorps+begins+Maine+work+Group+involved+in+many+projects+throughout+state&amp;author=Dawn+Gagnon+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-10-13&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: In the year ahead, AmeriCorps members will get things done in Maine that for too long have fallen by the wayside for lack of human or monetary resources. Fifty-six men and women sworn in by President Clinton in Maine via satellite last month have already begun work in national and community service programs aimed at meeting human, environmental, public safety and educational needs.
Maine's AmeriCorps assignments run the gamut from building and rerouting trails and resolving neighborhood conflicts to arming refugees, seasonal farmworkers, at-risk youths and low-income people with the skills they need to improve their prospects.
Others aim to stamp out illiteracy, improve water quality, deliver AIDS-HIV awareness and education, and assist agriculture and fisheries agencies to inventory natural resources and conduct conservation education programs.
Touted as the Clinton Administration's domestic Peace Corps and the heir of the work legacy handed down by the Depression-Era Civilian Conservation Corps, AmeriCorps will engage thousands of Americans in similar work across the country that might not otherwise be done.
Participating programs represent a mix of projects, some that existed before and became part of AmeriCorps, and others that arose because of it.
Most of the funding for the effort comes from the Corporation for National and Community Service, established under provisions of the National Community Service Trust Act of 1993. Grants are competitive and can be renewed yearly.
While most of the 86 positions earmarked for five AmeriCorps programs in Maine have already been filled, some programs are still recruiting. The movement is still in its infancy and word is still getting out.
As a group, Maine's current AmeriCorps members defy description. They span all age groups from 17 on up and come from varied economic and educational backgrounds. The minimum requirement for some jobs is high school completion. Other positions require some college or vocational training.
It's unlikely that AmeriCorps members are in it for the money. Most will receive minimum wage -- well under what they'd earn doing the same work in the private sector. Some, however, will receive slightly higher pay for work requiring college degrees or vocational training. The minimum anyone can make is about $7,600 and the maximum is $12,000.
AmeriCorps members also will receive free health care and $4,725 educational awards for each year (1,700 hours) of service. Recruits serve for up to two years. The educational awards can be used for college or vocational education or to pay off student loans.
"There's no age limit but I suspect they're mostly fairly young," said Robert Blakesley, executive director of the Maine Community Service Program administered by the State Planning Office. Blakesley and his staff are charged with providing administrative services for AmeriCorps programs in Maine and for a new state commission appointed last month by Gov. John R. McKernan.
The 19-member Maine Commission for Community Service was established to "to encourage community service and volunteerism as a means of meeting critical human, environmental, educational and public safety needs throughout the state."
The commission will work in partnership with AmeriCorps and other federal programs to assist volunteer programs and foster networking among government and nonprofit groups serving Maine people. It was authorized to accept grants and gifts, initiate community service programs, and make subgrants to nonprofit agencies, communities and educational entities.
Following is a look at what Maine's five AmeriCorps teams will do this year:
Learning while conserving
Headquartered at Unity College, the College Conservation Corps of Maine began two years ago as a program of the state Department of Labor. This year, it falls under the umbrella of AmeriCorps.
The 20-member team led by Kenneth Spalding will carry out conservation projects, such as rerouting trails at Camden Hills State Park, Lake St. George State Park, Reid State Park, Baxter State Park and in Bangor and Bethel and elsewhere.
Members also will stabilize shorelines, clear and mark boundary lines, rebuild river access points and run the Unity Area Recycling Center. During the winter the group will live at the college, attending classes while working part-time. They'll work full-time during breaks.
Rural waters, trails and habitats
The U.S. Department of Agriculture's Soil Conservation Service landed a grant for a 20-member Rural Development Team assigned to rural locations in several counties.
This team's focus is water quality and resource protection. The job list includes developing a crop management program with cranberry growers, conducting lakeshore sanitary surveys, turning old railroad tracks into recreational trails, staffing a shellfish hatchery, studying fish habitats, inventorying natural resources, and conducting conservation education programs.
Lakes Coordinator Raymonde Violette and Samonoid Coordinator Amanda Smith-Hatch, are two of the four team members assigned to Aroostook County.
Smith-Hatch considers herself lucky to find a job in her field just four days after moving to Maine from Texas. "It was fate -- something I fell into," she said. With AmeriCorps, she can "do Peace Corps-type work without having to give up home life or American life."
St. John Valley communities with a stake in the controversial plan to bring Atlantic salmon to the upper St. John River beyond Grand Falls will be interested in the results of Smith-Hatch's work.
It entails gathering data needed to assess economic and other impacts of the salmon plan and studying potential salmon habitat on the section of river in Maine and its tributaries.
"I'm a neutral party," she said.
Violette's work also put her in a new setting. Her prior job was doing immunology research in a lab. This year she'll go out into communities to provide water-quality education to local officials, lakeside landowners, students and others.
The USDA also has Public Lands and Environment and Anti-Hunger and Empowerment Teams elsewhere in the country.
Making Portland safer
The largest AmeriCorps team in Maine was assigned to the Portland area. Sponsored by the Portland West Neighborhood Planning Council/Community Employment Project, Portland Youth for Public Safety will comprise 25 young adults, mostly in their 20s and 30s. Their aim is to prevent crime by getting at its roots.
The program has two main components, according to Director Neil Taliento. One will involve working with up to 100 first-time juvenile offenders this year who will be referred to the program by probation officers, police, the court system, and district attorneys.
The idea is to give the young offenders a chance to do community service as an alternative to jail or the youth center.
"Most of them are young people who have made a mistake," Taliento said. "This is a viable and cost-effective way to work with them."
While the concept isn't new to the Portland area, the peer assistance aspect AmeriCorps' young people will bring to it is, Taliento said. AmeriCorps workers will place, supervise and monitor the youths sentenced to work.
The other component of the public safety program centers on mediating conflicts in low-income neighborhoods before they escalate to the point where crimes are committed.
The team will schedule mediation sessions on "neutral turf" under the guidance of skilled professionals in an effort to resolve conflicts before they get out of hand, Taliento said. The goal is 100 mediations this year.
AmeriCorps members will receive training in mediation, conflict resolution and victim assistance. They will work in partnership with police, the Portland Housing Authority, public schools and other entities.
"It can work," Taliento said.
Migrant, seasonal farmworkers
The smallest AmeriCorps team -- at two members -- will be brought on board shortly, said Director Jack Frost of the Training and Development Corp.'s Career Advancement Program.
The TDC received funding for two posts from the American Association of Farmworkers Opportunity Program, which received a grant from the new federal service corporation.
After completing training, the two will travel around Maine educating seasonal and migrant farmworkers on how to reduce exposure to pesticides in berry, broccoli and potato fields, apple orchards and other farm industries that use them.
The AmeriCorps staff also will steer farmworkers to the health, educational and other support services available to them.
Addressing human needs
Nineteen AmeriCorps members are assigned to 10 projects run by Volunteers in Service to America, which has been brought under the AmeriCorps umbrella.
The projects range from addressing housing problems and homelessness and illiteracy to AIDS/HIV awareness and education, conservation and youth programs, assisting refugees and economic development, said Lisa Conley. Conley is assistant to Mary Pelky, state program director for the Corporation for National and Community Service and a non-voting member of the new state commission.
Pelky's Portland office will oversee VISTA members assigned to various locations in Maine. Among VISTA's projects are a building materials bank in Gray offering low-cost materials to low-income people; Waterville's Day Spring AIDS Support Group; a program that teaches low-income families in Washington County budgeting and living skills; Literacy Volunteers of America tutor training and the Displaced Homemakers Project.
AmeriCorps Pledge
"I will get things done for America -- to make people safer, smarter and healthier. I will bring Americans together to strengthen communities.
Faced with apathy, I will take action. Faced with conflict, I will seek common ground. Faced with adversity, I will persevere.
I will carry this commitment with me this year and beyond. I am an AmeriCorps Member. And I'm going to get things done."

____________________________________________________________

Thomaston group questions options for waste water Validity of November referendum raised

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]01 Oct 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413799439?accountid=10457

Abstract: Although the validity of a referendum is now being questioned by opponents, it appears likely Thomaston voters will be asked Nov. 8 to pass judgment on three options for waste-water treatment: upgrading the existing plant and continuing to discharge treated waste water into the St. George River; building an aerated lagoon system between the Oyster River and Beechwood Street and discharging year round into the St. George; and building the aerated lagoons, with the treated water sprayed on land most of the year and discharged into the river in the winter. [Shirley Wooster] said the town could upgrade its existing waterfront treatment plant for a fraction of the cost, "but a group with a lot of clout wants it off of the waterfront and have convinced the selectmen land-spreading is the only way. The odor from the plant now is only because it's not being operated properly. Other towns upgrade the plants and discharge into the water. Thomaston seems to be the only town that can't."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Thomaston+group+questions+options+for+waste+water+Validity+of+November+referendum+raised&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-10-01&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: THOMASTON -- A group of residents are ready to do battle with town officials over whether a waste-water treatment plan is too expensive, unnecessary and possibly illegal.
Although the validity of a referendum is now being questioned by opponents, it appears likely Thomaston voters will be asked Nov. 8 to pass judgment on three options for waste-water treatment: upgrading the existing plant and continuing to discharge treated waste water into the St. George River; building an aerated lagoon system between the Oyster River and Beechwood Street and discharging year round into the St. George; and building the aerated lagoons, with the treated water sprayed on land most of the year and discharged into the river in the winter.
The third choice is recommended by the Board of Selectmen, the sewer advisory committee and the budget committee. It is opposed by a group calling itself Thomaston Residents for Responsible Government, which says the land-spreading component would gobble up 175 acres of valuable wildlife habitat north and east of Studley Lane, in violation of the federal Natural Resources Protection Act and the town's own comprehensive plan.
The town is under a consent order from the Maine Department of Environmental Protection to end waste-water discharges that harm shellfish habitat. Shirley Wooster, a spokesman for the residents group, said Friday the land-spreading not only would destroy land that should be preserved, but also would make uninhabitable adjacent residential land.
"We are a land-poor town," she said. "There isn't much available for our children to build homes and no one's going to want to build on land next to a sewer treatment lagoon. The selectmen aren't looking into the future."
Wooster said the town could upgrade its existing waterfront treatment plant for a fraction of the cost, "but a group with a lot of clout wants it off of the waterfront and have convinced the selectmen land-spreading is the only way. The odor from the plant now is only because it's not being operated properly. Other towns upgrade the plants and discharge into the water. Thomaston seems to be the only town that can't."
The selectmen received a petition in August signed by 150 residents wanting a special town meeting on the options. Unhappy with the wording of the referendum ballot, the group withdrew its petition this week.
The ballot treats each option separately and gives the selectmen the right to choose a winner should two or more receive approval.
"Presumably, we have a democratic system of government," Wooster said, "but there's nothing democratic about a confusing ballot that lets the selectmen make the final decision. We asked for a choice and we've been denied that. The town says we're misinformed. We are very much informed. If we go ahead with this, our great-grandchildren won't be out of debt."
Town Manager Valmore Blastow said Friday that while the lagoon-land spreading option has the highest total cost, about $11 million, it is the only one eligible for federal and state grants, giving it the lowest local cost.
"The local cost would be about $5.2 million, compared to $6.5 million and $7.3 million for the others," Blastow said. "The DEP has made it very clear, in letter after letter, that it is the only option that appears to be legally, technically and economically feasible."
Blastow said the charge that the plan would violate federal law and town ordinances "assumes that we have a specific site picked out. That is not the case, it's putting the cart before the horse. Right now, we're just looking at a general area. After we get approval from the voters, we can then move into the site-plan process for an exact location. We may in the future run into problems with the federal law, but our main concern right now is staying in compliance with a consent order from the DEP and the attorney general."
The town attorney is researching whether the withdrawal of the petition asking for a vote requires a cancellation of the referendum, but Blastow said townspeople should assume for now that the vote will take place.

People: Wooster, Shirley Blastow, Valmore

Mussel shell find hopeful

Author: Tynan, Trudy

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]30 Sep 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413743939?accountid=10457

Abstract: The dwarf wedge mussel, which once ranged from Canada to Virginia is now found only in a scattering of spots, including a stretch of river used as a recharge area for the drinking water supply in the city of Keene, N.H., she said. A brisk battle has erupted over the past two years over attempts from the city of Wilson, N.C., to expand a drinking water reservoir to encompass a creek containing the mussels.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Mussel+shell+find+hopeful&amp;author=Tynan%2C+Trudy&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-09-30&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: NORTHAMPTON, Mass. -- A shell from a rare mussel believed to have disappeared from Massachusetts waters has been found in a pristine stretch of the Mill River.
The discovery raises hopes about the condition of the waterway, because the dwarf wedge mussel is extremely sensitive to chemical and other pollution, biologists said Thursday. But that enthusiasm was tempered by their inability to find any live specimens of the mussel, considered an endangered species by the federal government.
"It was a tremendous letdown," said Susi vonOettingen, an endangered species specialist with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's regional office in Hadley. "Five of us spent four hours searching the river and we didn't find a live one. We think they are there, but not in any numbers."
"The habitat looks good, and they may be recovering," she said of the Connecticut River tributary that is host to at least eight other rare species. "But it may also be an old population whose ability to reproduce has been knocked out by past abuses."
Researchers suspect the little mollusks, which are only 1 1/2 to 2 inches long as adults, have a life expectancy of about 14 years, a short time when compared to some other fresh-water mussels that can live for up to 90 years, she said. And, because, they feed by siphoning nutrients from the water, they are particularly susceptible to sediment.
"They can literally suffocate," vanOettingen said. Sediment also disrupts their ability to breed, and kills the young. After hatching, the larvae attach themselves to a common fish called the tessellated darter. When they drop off several weeks later they are a microscopic version of the adult and spend the next two years burrowing in the stream bottom, she said.
The dwarf wedge mussel, which once ranged from Canada to Virginia is now found only in a scattering of spots, including a stretch of river used as a recharge area for the drinking water supply in the city of Keene, N.H., she said. A brisk battle has erupted over the past two years over attempts from the city of Wilson, N.C., to expand a drinking water reservoir to encompass a creek containing the mussels.

Mom touts safety course for divers Mandatory course could have saved son's life, Portland woman says

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]29 Sep 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413722536?accountid=10457

Abstract: Maxwell doesn't buy into those objections. She said Wednesday the course was "extremely thorough and comprehensive. It was very pertinent to everything divers and tenders do, especially the CPR and first aid components. Tenders have a lot of responsibilities out there; this prepares them for anything that could happen. With divers having to go out farther and to dive deeper to find urchins, the information on decompression is very important." Like most urchin divers, his only training was open-water certification, intended for recreational divers. "He was very well-trained, he had an excellent instructor, but it just wasn't adequate for the conditions urchin divers work in," Maxwell said. "The part of the course emphasizing a dive plan -- knowing where the divers will be located, how long they'll be on the bottom, their proximity to the tender -- could have prevented his death."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Mom+touts+safety+course+for+divers+Mandatory+course+could+have+saved+son%27s+life%2C+Portland+woman+says&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-09-29&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PORTLAND -- Critics of the new state law requiring a safety course for urchin and scallop divers should talk to Nancy Maxwell of Portland. She took the course last week and says it could have saved her son's life.
A registered nurse, Maxwell didn't need to take the three-day course at Southern Maine Technical College -- she only wanted the extra training to pursue her hobby of underwater archaeology.
Her son, David, was 25 when he drowned last Nov. 3 while harvesting urchins in Biddeford Pool. It was only his second commercial dive.
That was one of six diving deaths in Maine in the last year and prompted the Legislature to pass a law making the safety course mandatory for all shellfish divers and tender operators. Only those who have completed the course will receive 1995 licenses from the Department of Marine Resources.
The law has been blasted by many in the industry as unnecessary, inconvenient and, at $170, too expensive.
Maxwell doesn't buy into those objections. She said Wednesday the course was "extremely thorough and comprehensive. It was very pertinent to everything divers and tenders do, especially the CPR and first aid components. Tenders have a lot of responsibilities out there; this prepares them for anything that could happen. With divers having to go out farther and to dive deeper to find urchins, the information on decompression is very important."
To those who say they get all the training they need on the job, Maxwell said, "I wish them well. I'm a nurse, I work in a high-risk, highly regulated industry, and I appreciate all the training I can get."
David Maxwell drowned at Fortunes Rocks in Biddeford Pool after he became entangled in the rope tied to his urchin bag. He tried to swim to the tender, but got caught in heavy surf.
Like most urchin divers, his only training was open-water certification, intended for recreational divers.
"He was very well-trained, he had an excellent instructor, but it just wasn't adequate for the conditions urchin divers work in," Maxwell said. "The part of the course emphasizing a dive plan -- knowing where the divers will be located, how long they'll be on the bottom, their proximity to the tender -- could have prevented his death."
Maxwell said many of her classmates came in as skeptics and left as believers. "A lot of them were suspicious at first, but everyone I talked to came away impressed. They covered so much material, everyone learned something valuable."
The DMR reported early this month that enrollment for the course was shockingly low. Of the nearly 3,000 divers and tenders licensed this year, only 50 had signed up for the course.
John Fetterman, the department's search and rescue coordinator, said Tuesday word that the DMR intends to enforce the law to the letter has had the desired effect -- enrollment has exploded to nearly 1,000 in the past two weeks.
The increased enrollment has allowed the DMR to answer one criticism of the program, that the course locations at technical college campuses are inconvenient.
"We've said all along that we'll be able to add sections and locations as enrollment picks up, and that's just what we're doing," Fetterman said.

People: Maxwell, Nancy

____________________________________________________________

Lubec schoolteachers and students get Audubon conservation award

Author: Paul Sylvain Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]22 Sep 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413728572?accountid=10457

Abstract: Two Lubec Middle School teachers and their pupils were honored Tuesday at the annual meeting of the Schoodic Chapter of the National Audubon Society for a continuing water quality study they initiated on Johnson's Bay and Lubec Narrows. In conducting the study, pupils gathered data through various tests and developed theories about the effects of human habitation on coastal ecology in the Lubec area. The project included controlled experiments conducted by the pupils either to prove or disprove their theories.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lubec+schoolteachers+and+students+get+Audubon+conservation+award&amp;author=Paul+Sylvain+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-09-22&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: CALAIS -- Two Lubec Middle School teachers and their pupils were honored Tuesday at the annual meeting of the Schoodic Chapter of the National Audubon Society for a continuing water quality study they initiated on Johnson's Bay and Lubec Narrows.
The teachers -- Marty Mahar and Rose Binder -- launched the project in 1993. The initial study combined math and science classes in studies of local water quality, and involved all sixth-, seventh- and eighth-graders at the school.
Sid Bahrt, one of 130 members of the local Audubon Society chapter, praised Binda, Mahar and their pupils for their conservation effort on Wednesday.
"It is outstanding what these two teachers and their students have done," he said. "It's an outstanding achievement and speaks well for their school."
The teachers were presented with the chapter's annual Conservation Award Tuesday night in Calais during the group's annual awards supper and meeting. They received a framed photo of a kestrel -- a sparrow hawk -- taken by Bahrt and hand-lettered by Nellie Walton of Calais.
Bahrt said what made the water quality study project unique was that it is ____________________________________________________________________ ___________an ongoing project. "We found that particularly interesting," he added. ____________________________________________________________________ ________ In June, the teachers and their pupils learned that the project had been selected by Anheuser-Busch as a finalist for its annual "Pledge and a Promise" environmental award.
Anheuser-Busch presents its Pledge and a Promise environmental award in recognition of school groups making lasting contributions to the environment.
In conducting the study, pupils gathered data through various tests and developed theories about the effects of human habitation on coastal ecology in the Lubec area. The project included controlled experiments conducted by the pupils either to prove or disprove their theories.
Binder said that earlier in the course of their study, the pupils developed an interest in local shellfish stocks and initiated a population study of clams in South Lubec.
"They have contacted municipal officials to try to develop a management plan for the flats," Binder said, adding that programs undertaken by the pupils as part of the study "have become an integral part of the math and science curriculum in the Middle School."
Funding for the project included a $12,000 grant from the GTE Foundation's Growth Initiatives for Teachers Program. With only 330 students, the Lubec school was the smallest of about 60 schools nationwide to receive a GTE award last year. About 90 pupils were involved in the initial study.

People: Binder, Rose Bahrt, Sid

Company: National Audubon Society

Oyster researcher seeks pearls of industrial wisdom

Author: Andrew Kekacs Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]20 Sep 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413724114?accountid=10457

Abstract: Before switching to oyster research in 1986, [Robert Hawes] was the university's expert on chicken breeding. The growth of aquaculture and a sharp decline in Maine's broiler industry led Hawes to switch his focus to shellfish. Mounds of shells in some coastal areas show that oysters were once abundant in Maine, according to Hawes. The combination of overfishing and pollution destroyed most of the large oyster colonies, but a wild bed remains in the Sheepscot River. In addition to growing oysters on river bottoms, Hawes and other researchers are studying the potential for "polyculture" -- growing the shellfish in mesh bags hung on salmon pens. It could be another source of income for Maine's salmon farmers, without requiring much investment of time or money.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Oyster+researcher+seeks+pearls+of+industrial+wisdom&amp;author=Andrew+Kekacs+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-09-20&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ORONO -- Charisma isn't on the Top 10 list of oyster attributes.
They sit on the bottom, year after year, filtering algae from the water and slowly growing larger.
When the time is right, they release clouds of eggs and sperm. A new generation swims off for a few weeks of freedom, then sinks to the bottom and begins to filter algae from the water.
"Even the scallop is more interesting," admits Robert Hawes, an expert on oyster breeding at the University of Maine. "These things just sit there. Someone once told me it was like breeding rocks."
Still, Hawes is the man that Maine oyster growers hope will develop faster growing, tastier and more disease-resistant shellfish.
Before switching to oyster research in 1986, Hawes was the university's expert on chicken breeding. The growth of aquaculture and a sharp decline in Maine's broiler industry led Hawes to switch his focus to shellfish.
"Maine has all the attributes (for successful oyster farming)," said Hawes. "It has almost 4,000 miles of coastline, some of the cleanest water on the East Coast, and it's near the major markets."
Despite the natural advantages, Maine's cultivated oyster industry is very small -- only five companies on the Damariscotta River.
"It's an excellent growing area," said Hawes. "The water temperatures are warm for Maine, which results in faster growth."
Mounds of shells in some coastal areas show that oysters were once abundant in Maine, according to Hawes. The combination of overfishing and pollution destroyed most of the large oyster colonies, but a wild bed remains in the Sheepscot River.
Oysters can't be grown in the open ocean. The best commercial sites are protected inlets with a good supply of algae and clean sea water.
Growers usually buy oyster larvae -- called spat -- from one of two Maine hatcheries and grow the shellfish in floating trays the first year. The trays protect oysters from crabs, starfish, snails and other predators.
Oysters are set on the bottom at the start of the second growing season and remain there until harvested about 18 months later.
The shellfish only grow from April to October, according to Hawes. After three growing seasons, they are at least 2 inches long and ready to be sold to restaurants for use raw "on the half-shell."
Good oysters -- those with attractive rounded shells and uniform sizes -- can be sold for 35 to 45 cents each, according to Hawes.
In addition to growing oysters on river bottoms, Hawes and other researchers are studying the potential for "polyculture" -- growing the shellfish in mesh bags hung on salmon pens. It could be another source of income for Maine's salmon farmers, without requiring much investment of time or money.
"The initial research is promising," said Hawes. "It appears that the oysters are capturing excess feed from the salmon pens, or that salmon feces stimulates algae growth in the pen."
Hawes and a colleague, Bruce Barber, also are trying to breed improved strains of shellfish. They are experimenting with oysters that have three complete sets of genes -- one from the father and two from the mother.
The extra set of genes makes the shellfish sterile, which improves quality. After spawning, oyster meat can be tasteless and watery for some time. The "triploid" oysters also seem to grow faster than native stock, according to Hawes.
"The genetically improved stock we produced and performed better than wild stock out of the (Damariscotta) river," he said. "It has been used commercially for two years, and it does seem to be doing better, both in the rate of growth and mortality."
Despite the modest research success, Hawes still has a tender spot in his heart for his former feathered friends. He raises bantam fowl at home and keeps a stuffed chicken next to the oyster shells in his office.
Although shellfish lack the personality of chickens, Hawes said, his work is not without rewards.
"On a summer day, it's a lot nicer on the river than it is in a hot, dusty chicken barn," he said.
Illustration Caption: University of Maine Professor Robert Hawes holds the shell of an American oyster. (NEWS Photo by Michael York)

People: Hawes, Robert

Shortnose sturgeon at center of debate on damming rivers

Author: Ned Porter Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]15 Sep 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413735760?accountid=10457

Abstract: The petitioner, Edwards Manufacturing Co. of Augusta, asks for "delisting" the fish only in the Kennebec System, which includes the Kennebec, Androscoggin and Sheepscot rivers. The company owns and operates Edwards Dam on the Kennebec. Though its hydropower license expired last December, the company continues to operate the dam under a one-year extension while the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission reviews its relicensing application. "Based on the abundance, viability, and distribution of the Kennebec System shortnose sturgeon population, as documented by studies over the period 1977 through 1994, it appears virtually certain that the original listing as endangered was in error, and that this conservative approach (i.e. listing) was taken because of a lack of scientific study and commercial data rather than a true paucity of fish," according to the petition, which was prepared by Northrop, Devine and Tarbell, a Portland firm providing engineering and environmental services. "The shortnose sturgeon population in the Kennebec and Androscoggin system was studied intensely from 1977 to 1981. Population estimates for that period averaged 10,000 adults. The spawning, feeding and overwintering habitats in the Kennebec are known, and they face few adverse impacts from development," the authors at NMFS said.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Shortnose+sturgeon+at+center+of+debate+on+damming+rivers&amp;author=Ned+Porter+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-09-15&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The population of shortnose sturgeon in the Kennebec River is so healthy that it does not warrant protection under the federal Endangered Species Act, according to a citizen-sponsored petition.
The petitioner, Edwards Manufacturing Co. of Augusta, asks for "delisting" the fish only in the Kennebec System, which includes the Kennebec, Androscoggin and Sheepscot rivers. The company owns and operates Edwards Dam on the Kennebec. Though its hydropower license expired last December, the company continues to operate the dam under a one-year extension while the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission reviews its relicensing application.
"The shortnose could be a stumbling block for relicensing. But it's not the biggest hurdle. Politics is," said Mark Isaccson, vice president of the company.
The dam is the first obstacle on the river for fish migrating upstream. Gov. John R. McKernan and a variety of conservation groups have called for removal of the dam to restore the fishery.
Neither side calls the shortnose sturgeon a make-or-break issue. But opponents of the dam have rallied around the fish.
"They (sturgeon) need the dam removed to restore their native habitat," said Margaret Bowman, of American Rivers, a national organization fighting to restore and preserve river systems.
As part of the Kennebec Coalition, American Rivers has been fighting for years to have the dam removed. At the same time, the group is working on a national level to see a policy established that would give FERC clear authority to order the decommissioning and removal of dams.
Bowman said her group just wanted the policy changed and didn't really care whether it was the Edwards case or another that established the precedent for such change.
Isaacson, the vice president of Edwards, sees American Rivers in a different light.
"They are very interested in establishing a precedent for dam removal," he said. "The dams they really want to remove are not on the Kennebec but in the Pacific Northwest and they thought we'd be a good place to begin. We're a small, private company with four employees."
In the course of preparing the application to FERC, the company compiled reams of information on the shortnose sturgeon.
The fish, whose range extends along the Atlantic Seaboard from New Brunswick to Florida, was placed on the original endangered species list in 1967. Adult shortnose sturgeon, which grow as long as three feet and as heavy as 20 pounds, are the smallest of the three species in eastern North America.
They feed on mollusks, crustaceans and insect larvae in the mud and gravel of river bottoms. They spawn in freshwater, where they remain as juveniles. On becoming adults they migrate seasonally from wintering areas in the saline parts of the lower river to the spring spawning areas upstream.
"Based on the abundance, viability, and distribution of the Kennebec System shortnose sturgeon population, as documented by studies over the period 1977 through 1994, it appears virtually certain that the original listing as endangered was in error, and that this conservative approach (i.e. listing) was taken because of a lack of scientific study and commercial data rather than a true paucity of fish," according to the petition, which was prepared by Northrop, Devine and Tarbell, a Portland firm providing engineering and environmental services.
Normally, the instigation to remove species from the list comes from the government itself. And in this case, Edwards' petition cited a review of the shortnose sturgeon prepared by the National Marine Fisheries Service in 1987. The review recommended that the fish in the Kennebec System be delisted.
"The shortnose sturgeon population in the Kennebec and Androscoggin system was studied intensely from 1977 to 1981. Population estimates for that period averaged 10,000 adults. The spawning, feeding and overwintering habitats in the Kennebec are known, and they face few adverse impacts from development," the authors at NMFS said.
"Therefore, we believe the shortnose sturgeon in the Kennebec System is not in danger of extinction or likely to become endangered now, or in the foreseeable future, and can be removed from the list of endangered species."
But the service never followed through on its recommendation. When the proposal was made available for public comment, nearly all of it was unfavorable.
"The view was that it was inappropriate to go forward without any long-term data," said Douglas Beach, an endangered-species specialist with NMFS. "There were a lot of quick and dirty studies from which we could infer that (the Kennebec population) was healthy. But it's a slow-going, long-lived fish. You really need years of data before you can say it's a healthy population."
At the state level, Tom Squires, at the Department of Marine Resources, has studied the sturgeon off and on since 1977.
"On the Kennebec, my feeling is that we don't have all the information yet," he said. "Definitely there's a large population of sturgeon." He added that more information is needed about exactly where the fish spend their winters, where they spawn and what stretch of river serves as a nursery.
Once it receives the petition, the federal agency has 90 days to determine whether the petition has merit.

Company: Edwards Manufacturing

Search may help mussels survive Biologists attempt to determine if two species should be listed as endangered

Author: Ned Porter Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]12 Sep 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413792808?accountid=10457

Abstract: Of the 11 species of mussels known to be in Maine, the stretch of river in northern Knox County contains six or seven; freshwater mussels are not well-researched creatures, so no one knows exactly. What biologists do know is the river contains two mussels that are candidates for protection under state and federal endangered species acts -- the yellow lamp and brook floater. The two mussels are in the pipeline of consideration for endangered status like a much more publicized species, the Atlantic salmon. The mussels are classified Category 2, candidates that may warrant listing but further information is required. With salmon, officials are just about through gathering information and must report their recommendation by Oct. 1. Officials are anxious to avoid a replay with mussels. Maine's commissioner of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife, Ray "Bucky" Owen, has already talked with landowners with property along rivers in Down East Maine that are home to the yellow lamp and brook floater mussels.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Search+may+help+mussels+survive+Biologists+attempt+to+determine+if+two+species+should+be+listed+as+endangered&amp;author=Ned+Porter+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-09-12&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: It's hard to search for freshwater mussels and paddle a canoe at the same time.
Peering down too intently into the stream looking for mussels in the gravelly bed increases the likelihood of not seeing the rock lurking beneath the surface and adding another scratch to the canoe bottom. Concentrating on the waters up ahead means missing mussels.
Finding mussels was the reason for spending a sunny day on the St. George River, so the three biologists from the Maine Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife put up with their canoes getting dinged now and again.
Of the 11 species of mussels known to be in Maine, the stretch of river in northern Knox County contains six or seven; freshwater mussels are not well-researched creatures, so no one knows exactly. What biologists do know is the river contains two mussels that are candidates for protection under state and federal endangered species acts -- the yellow lamp and brook floater.
After tying the canoes to streamside alders, the crew wades in shallows, stooping over glass-bottomed buckets searching the stream bed.
Mussels live a sedentary life. They stay anchored to the bottom, in some cases for as long as 100 years, filtering food from the water. Adult females spew millions of larvae, which must latch on to a fish to survive. For a few weeks they draw sustenance from their host before dropping off. They sink to the stream bed, burrow in and mature without moving too far.
Mark McCollough holds up a yellow lamp. Finding one is an acquired knack. Only a small slit of gill structure shows above the sand and gravel. The rest of it is anchored in the substrate. Keel Kemper slogs over holding a caliper. The shell is 83.7 millimeters long, nearly 3 1/2 inches. For perhaps 35 years that mussel has lived in the same spot.
"Probably of all the mussels in Maine, this is the most distinctive and a candidate for the federal endangered list," McCollough said. "The (U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service) is waiting for a summary of research on its status. A lot of what we're doing is gathering evidence to support moving it up or taking it off the list."
The two mussels are in the pipeline of consideration for endangered status like a much more publicized species, the Atlantic salmon. The mussels are classified Category 2, candidates that may warrant listing but further information is required. With salmon, officials are just about through gathering information and must report their recommendation by Oct. 1.
As a high-profile species, one the biologists call "charismatic," the salmon has received far more attention and money. McCollough and a colleague will spend about $10,000, $9,500 from the federal government, learning more about mussels in Maine. Research on Atlantic salmon in Maine will consume hundreds of thousands of dollars.
Ecosystems, not just species
The yellow lamp and brook floater require the same type of freshwater habitat that Atlantic salmon need, clean flowing water and a bed of sandy gravel. And the changes wrought by man harm both.
Over the years millions of dollars has been poured into the restoration effort for salmon, including the stocking of fry, habitat improvement and efforts to improve water quality. Precious little has been spent on mussels.
Stream beds cannot support healthy mussel populations and the waters no longer support strong salmon runs. Biologists have long advocated that it is time to move beyond the crisis management by species and to work on the system they inhabit. The bureaucracy is moving to embrace the change.
"In a nutshell, what we are talking about is more efficiently and effectively conserving our nation's plant and animal diversity through perpetuation of dynamic, healthy ecosystems," Mollie Beattie, director of the Fish and Wildlife Service, said last June during a speech in Orono at the convention of the Outdoor Writers Association of America.
"This means going beyond restoring or conserving a single species or a small group of species, and looking to take action that will restore and conserve all species in a given ecosystem," she said. "It also means looking beyond species themselves to the habitat they live in and determining how best we can restore and conserve that habitat."
She went on to say, "... the problems brought to light by the Endangered Species Act are far deeper than just the decline of a single species. Inevitably, endangered species indicate a problem in the natural ecosystem that, left unadressed, will ultimately affect people. They are signs of pollution and overuse of resources. Furthermore, they indicate that the economic or other activities causing the decline of the species cannot continue indefinitely. When growth is of a nature, speed, and scope that it pushes species to extinction and results in the unraveling of ecosystems, it cannot be sustained for very long."
The well-detailed activities that led to the decline of salmon contributed to the decline of mussels.
Mussels in decline
"Freshwater mussels are in trouble because pollution, dams and other water-control structures, channelization, dredging, and sedimentation of our once clean, free-flowing rivers and streams have all contributed to the degradation and loss of mussel habitat," Beth Swartz, a biologist with Inland Fisheries and Wildlife, wrote in a soon-to-be-published article.
The range of both the yellow lamp and brook floater extend from Maine south to the mid-Atlantic states. Both are scarce in the southern part of their range, where habitat destruction is more extensive.
Sitting in the bow of one of the canoes on the St. George, Swartz took a break from looking down past the gunwale. "We're looking on this river for sites where we could establish baseline data," she said. "We're just looking to find populations. Next season we hope to return to do a more thorough survey."
Biologists do not know all the populations of mussels in Maine's streams and rivers, ponds and lakes, let alone have baselines to know whether the numbers are growing or shrinking. The department started surveying mussels two years ago, with support from the Fish and Wildlife Service.
Before research started in Maine, the brook floater was known to live in six rivers and no more than three individuals had been found at any one site. The yellow lamp was documented at 10 locations.
Since then, Inland Fisheries and Wildlife biologists have searched more than 200 sites in more than 90 streams and rivers. The brook floater turned up in an additional 10 rivers, a few of which had healthy populations.
"Compared to most states within the range of these two species, Maine seems to have the best remaining populations and may be the last stronghold for these rare mussels," Swartz wrote.
Biologists suspect Maine may be an outpost of another mussel, the dwarf wedge, which is on the federal endangered list. It has been found in New Hampshire and New Brunswick but not in the waters of Maine.
With more biologists looking, new populations of mussels continue being discovered. In New Hampshire, an environmental biology student recently found a new colony of dwarf wedge mussels.
The little mollusk had held up a $35 million expansion of the Buckhorn Reservoir in Wilson, N.C., until biologists started searching and found more than 20 colonies.
The dwarf wedge mussel may have benefited from the intense interest in this case. But biologists are sounding the alarm for the 297 kinds of mussels found in the United States. Of the recognized species and subspecies, 21 are presumed extinct, 56 are federally listed as threatened or endangered and 69 are candidates for listing.
"...(W)e must argue their case based on sheer numbers in decline and their utility as indicators of environmental degradation. Water quality and the biological integrity of river systems are essential to the health, economic prosperity and long-term survival of humans," Richard J. Neeves, a renowned mussel specialist, said in a symposium two years ago.
Worries over status
Narrowing the field from 297 to two, the brook floater and yellow lamp, Paul Nickerson, an endangered species specialist with the Fish and Wildlife Service, said, "It looks like they'll be left in Category 2. At this point, it doesn't look like there's the data to support moving forward. There's new populations discovered in Maine. We feel there's no imminent threat to either (species). But we'll keep gathering information from throughout their range."
The likelihood of listing may have decreased, but some people still worry about the reprecussions of adding two more species to the 18 in Maine already federally listed as threatened or endangered.
Shortly after work started on whether salmon should be listed, the Maine Forest Products Council organized an "awareness workshop." It attracted more than 200 people. They were worried the Atlantic salmon could become the spotted owl of Maine.
Officials are anxious to avoid a replay with mussels. Maine's commissioner of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife, Ray "Bucky" Owen, has already talked with landowners with property along rivers in Down East Maine that are home to the yellow lamp and brook floater mussels.
Mussels are unlikely to generate much interest let alone hysteria, unless they hold up construction of a resevoir. In the minds of most people mussels are good for little, which dismays of biologists studying them. They aren't even edible.
"I've tried them boiled through five changes of water. I've tried them fried in batter. And they still taste like an old rubber band," Kemper said while paddling through a quiet pool on the St. George.
Illustration Caption: Keel Kemper and Beth Swartz, biologists with the Maine Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife, use glass bottom buckets to search the St. George RIver for different species of mussels (News Photos by Michael York)

Gulf of Maine is a biological nightmare

Author: Carter, Jonathan

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]03 Sep 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413753839?accountid=10457

Abstract: The Gulf of Maine because of unusual dynamic is considered one of the richest fisheries in the world. Fish landings have consistently declined over the last decade. The decrease is due to the degradation of the ecosystem by destructive fishing techniques, coastal development, and pollution. The decline in landings endangers the traditional fishing industry in Maine. Clearly fishing needs to be regulated and stocks need to be given time to rebuild. The New England Fishery Management Council's efforts to reduce fishing pressure by 50 percent in order to restore cod and flounder stocks within five years and haddock within 10 years is an achievable goal. We need to outlaw rapacious and destructive factory fishing such as pair trawling and dragging. Gill netting must be regulated to protect marine mammals with sonar locators on all nets, to reduce by-catch and juvenile stock by increasing mess size, and to restrict nets from anadromous migratory fish paths. In addition, increasing the legal size limit and closing off areas to protect juvenile fish would help to restore small independent fishing families is totally unacceptable. These families make a significant contribution to the unique character and economic well-being of the state. Limiting fishing days is not a solution or setting quotas based on previous catches. These regulations would effectively drive the small fishing boat out of business while allowing the big businesses to continue in their efforts to monopolize control of the Gulf of Maine fishery.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Gulf+of+Maine+is+a+biological+nightmare&amp;author=Carter%2C+Jonathan&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-09-03&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The food web is unraveling and the ocean inhabitants of the Gulf of Maine are sending clear messages of impending disaster. The crisis is real. The gulf is under siege from overfishing and the dumping of industrial wastes, untreated sewage, pesticide runoff, oil spills, and other discarded human toxins. Fish catches have dropped precipitously, and recent studies have found PCBs, heavy metals, hydrocarbons, dioxins, and excess nitrogen all along the Maine coast.
Although the Gulf of Maine is not yet on a par with the ecological deterioration found in such places as Chesapeake Bay or Boston Harbor, it is apparent that something must be done at once before it is too late. The oceans should never have been and can no longer be considered as a bottomless food supply or as a limitless disposal site. We call for an immediate unprecedented local, state, and national cooperative effort to assay the biological health of the Gulf of Maine.
The Gulf of Maine because of unusual dynamic is considered one of the richest fisheries in the world. Fish landings have consistently declined over the last decade. The decrease is due to the degradation of the ecosystem by destructive fishing techniques, coastal development, and pollution. The decline in landings endangers the traditional fishing industry in Maine. Clearly fishing needs to be regulated and stocks need to be given time to rebuild. The New England Fishery Management Council's efforts to reduce fishing pressure by 50 percent in order to restore cod and flounder stocks within five years and haddock within 10 years is an achievable goal.
We need to outlaw rapacious and destructive factory fishing such as pair trawling and dragging. Gill netting must be regulated to protect marine mammals with sonar locators on all nets, to reduce by-catch and juvenile stock by increasing mess size, and to restrict nets from anadromous migratory fish paths. In addition, increasing the legal size limit and closing off areas to protect juvenile fish would help to restore small independent fishing families is totally unacceptable. These families make a significant contribution to the unique character and economic well-being of the state. Limiting fishing days is not a solution or setting quotas based on previous catches. These regulations would effectively drive the small fishing boat out of business while allowing the big businesses to continue in their efforts to monopolize control of the Gulf of Maine fishery.
If the fisheries are to recover we also have to stem the tide of coastal development that has allowed coastal estuaries and marshes to be destroyed. These areas provide critical spawning ground for all our commercially important fish species. Many of the spawning sites are suffering as a result of the deforestation of the headwaters of our rivers. Deforestation results in excessive run-off which causes the destructive flooding of saline spawning grounds with fresh water.
In addition to habitat destruction, evidence suggests that years of massive pollution are taking their toll. Cancers, reproductive damage, genetic alterations, and immune suppression symptoms are occurring with greater frequency in ocean vertebrate populations. The fish in Casco Bay have the highest lead concentration yet recorded anywhere along the eastern seaboard.
Polychlorinated biphenyls (PCB), a compound that causes birth defects and learning disorders in children, has been found in lobsters and shellfish. The most carcinogenic substance known to science, dioxin, produced by paper manufacturers "up river" is showing up in coastal marine environments. Our bald eagles and lobsters have been contaminated. PCB and dioxin, like many other toxins, bioaccumulate in fatty tissue as they move up the food chain. It is more than apparent that the time has come to take immediate action in banning the flow of all toxins into the ocean. Once again, this will take all levels of cooperation from the individual to the global community.
The biological health of the Gulf of Maine is in jeopardy. Either we take the steps now to ensure its restoration or we will no longer have the bounty of its gifts in both economic and nutrition terms. As governor, I will work to accomplish the following tasks:
1. Create a toxics task force whose sole purpose will be to eliminate all point and non-point sources of pollution entering the Gulf of Maine.
2. Increase funding for the Department of Marine Resources for research and educational outreach.
3. Eliminate dioxin as a by-product of paper production.
4. Expand development of aquaculture in the areas of seaweed, shellfish, and finfish where appropriate.
5. Create marine santuaries to protect juvenile fish stocks and other marine organisms.
6. Develop with the Coastal Land Use Commission with the Office of Comprehensive Planning whose task will be to oversee coastal development and to aid municipalities in protecting coastal resources.
7. Assist in the local development of land trusts both for land protetion and low-income housing.
8.Increase sustainable economic development by expanding port opportunities in Eastport, Portland, and Mack Point, establishing ferry service from Eastport from Nova Scotia, and supporting ecotourism and recreation as small business endeavors.
The restoration of the oceans will provide a sustainable future both in ecological and economic terms for generations to come. I ask for your vote so that I may help initiate this vision.
Jonathan Carter is the Green Parety candidate for governor.

Clinton considering Maine visit President may wrap up vacation with Labor Day rally at BIW

Author: From Staff and Wire Reports

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]30 Aug 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413718908?accountid=10457

Abstract: [Clinton] would attend a rally at Bath Iron Works, Maine's largest employer, that recently signed a novel labor agreement with its workers. At a stop in Bangor, Sen. George Mitchell confirmed a report that Clinton was considering stopping in Maine over Labor Day weekend. "There has been no decision made at this time. Several locations are under consideration, including Maine," Mitchell said.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Clinton+considering+Maine+visit+President+may+wrap+up+vacation+with+Labor+Day+rally+at+BIW&amp;author=From+Staff+and+Wire+Reports&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-08-30&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: President Clinton may take a side trip to Maine on Labor Day during his late-summer vacation at Martha's Vineyard, Mass., published reports said Monday.
Clinton would attend a rally at Bath Iron Works, Maine's largest employer, that recently signed a novel labor agreement with its workers.
The president also may visit a YMCA camp near Augusta to attend a Labor Day picnic with host Joseph Brennan, a former two-term governor who is the Democratic nominee in this year's gubernatorial race.
At a stop in Bangor, Sen. George Mitchell confirmed a report that Clinton was considering stopping in Maine over Labor Day weekend.
Mitchell said he received a call from the White House a week ago and was told the president was considering several locations for a Labor Day speech.
One of those locations being considered is Maine, most likely at Bath Iron Works, said the senator.
"There has been no decision made at this time. Several locations are under consideration, including Maine," Mitchell said.
The president and his wife have been staying since Friday at the Oyster Pond estate of Richard Friedman, a Democratic fund-raiser and friend of Clinton's. They are expected to end their Martha's Vineyard vacation Sept. 7.
BIW, a shipbuilding company that has long relied on Navy contracts, is striving to break into the commercial market as the government scales back defense spending.
A Pentagon official last week suggested the possibility of further cuts in the Navy's destroyer program, a move that could weaken or even force the closing of BIW over the next decade.
The company's largest union's membership earlier this month ratified a contract that creates a new "team" approach to shipbuilding, which is designed to make the company more competitive and run more efficiently.
Instead of continuing the practice of workers concentrating on just one trade, pay increases during the three-year contract will hinge on a worker's skill level in a number of crafts. Workers and managers will share the responsibility for major decisions about the company's future.
Employees who diversify their talents through retraining will be rewarded.
Clinton would be expected to bring national attention to the new labor agreement if he visits Maine next week.
"We'd welcome the visit," said BIW's chief executive officer, Duane "Buzz" Fitzgerald.

Unsung Dungeness crab preferred to Maine lobster Washington state shellfish deserves greater exposure

Author: JOHN OWEN Seattle Post-Intelligencer

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]29 Aug 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413744685?accountid=10457

Abstract: During our recent vacation trip to Maine, we consumed lobsters singly, in pairs and in lobster rolls. We were also offered the opportunity to partake of lobster pizza in Camden, lobster ice cream in Bar Harbor and we very nearly succumbed. You see, from the moment you arrive on the coast of Maine until you take your departure, you are allowed to think of very little other than lobster. Every body of water is dotted with brightly colored lobster buoys. Take a walk along a cliff in Acadia National Park and you find yourself watching lobstermen harvest the day's catch. Take a stroll across a bridge in Boothbay Harbor and you immediately spot a mother and her two sons dropping one of the family lobster traps over the side of an outboard skiff. You don't really need a recipe for Dungeness crab. If you have some live ones, you toss them into salted boiling water and cook until they rise to the top, then cool, clean, crack them and serve with melted butter or freshly made mayonnaise. (I like to add some of the orange crab butter from the body when I make the mayo in my blender.)

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Unsung+Dungeness+crab+preferred+to+Maine+lobster+Washington+state+shellfish+deserves+greater+exposure&amp;author=JOHN+OWEN+Seattle+Post-Intelligencer&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-08-29&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The first thing that happens when you cross the border into Maine is that you involuntarily suspend all of your current dietary laws and restrictions.
Next thing you know a waitress is affixing a plastic bib beneath your chin and you find yourself muttering ribald comments like "Get a load of that chick" and "Is that a `keeper' or what?!"
"Chicks" are small lobsters, also known as "keepers." Hopefully you will encounter them freshly steamed, next to a vat of melted butter. There goes your diet. There goes your newly purchased L.L. Bean sports shirt as well, unless you securely fastened your bib.
During our recent vacation trip to Maine, we consumed lobsters singly, in pairs and in lobster rolls. We were also offered the opportunity to partake of lobster pizza in Camden, lobster ice cream in Bar Harbor and we very nearly succumbed.
You see, from the moment you arrive on the coast of Maine until you take your departure, you are allowed to think of very little other than lobster. Every body of water is dotted with brightly colored lobster buoys. Take a walk along a cliff in Acadia National Park and you find yourself watching lobstermen harvest the day's catch. Take a stroll across a bridge in Boothbay Harbor and you immediately spot a mother and her two sons dropping one of the family lobster traps over the side of an outboard skiff.
Drive along U.S. 1 and you'll be offered freshly cooked lobster from giant pots bubbling next to souvenir shops, farmhouses, gas stations, general stores and even, in one instance, as part of an auto body shop. And lobster rolls are on special under the golden arches at the McDonald's outlets.
To be fair about it, Maine lobsters are terrific. But, given my choice, I would still opt for a leggy Dungeness crab.
But tourists to Washington state are not subjected to the same nonstop sales campaign that carries the economy of Maine. That's because Washingtonians are more guarded toward our regional culinary treasure. We sneak our crab pots into the waters, retrieve them furtively and certainly never lead rivals to the mother lode with a dotted line of red, yellow and glowing green buoys.
We flummox the tourists, convincing them that espresso is the regional fixation. They leave here with sacks full of Starbucks in 13 different flavors. And the natives gaily wave them out of town, then rush home to crack a few crabs we've been hiding beneath some discarded tourist posters.
You don't really need a recipe for Dungeness crab. If you have some live ones, you toss them into salted boiling water and cook until they rise to the top, then cool, clean, crack them and serve with melted butter or freshly made mayonnaise. (I like to add some of the orange crab butter from the body when I make the mayo in my blender.)
Along with chilled red wine and a crusty French bread, this is the perfect accompaniment to a crab feast.
Potato-Pea Puget Salad
1 pound frozen green peas, thawed
5 large potatoes, cooked, peeled and cubed
1 bunch green onions, chopped
4 tablespoons wine vinegar
1 clove garlic
1 tablespoon fresh oregano (or 1/2 teaspoon dried)
1 tablespoon fresh thyme (or 1/2 teaspoon dried)
Salt, pepper
1/2 cup olive oil
Tomato wedges
1 small red onion, thinly sliced
1 small green pepper, sliced into rings
Dump the spuds, peas and green onions into a bowl.
In a smaller bowl, moosh together the vinegar, garlic, herbs, salt and pepper. Beat in the olive oil. Pour this sludge over the vegetables, toss and chill.
Serve with the tomato wedges, sliced red onion and green pepper rings.
My all-time favorite splurge feast are Dungeness crab legs prepared like this.
Crab Legs Laurelhurst
60 crab legs, shelled
1/2 pound butter
1 cup dry, white wine
Sprig of rosemary
1/4 teaspoon tarragon
Pinch of thyme
2 tablespoons parsley, chopped
Cracker crumbs
Melt the butter in a saucepan with the wine and herbs. Let simmer until reduced by half, then set aside to cool slightly.
Dip each shelled crab leg into the sauce, roll in fine cracker crumbs, salting and peppering lightly. Arrange on a flat baking dish. Sprinkle a little sauce over the top, then shove under a broiler until golden. Turn, return to oven until sizzling on second side and serve. Pour the rest of the sauce through a sieve over the legs.
You say that's too rich for your diet? OK, skip the lobster ice cream cone for dessert.

Voters elect new selectman in Brooklin

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 Aug 1994.

Abstract: At a special election Monday, residents cast 78 votes for Goodale and 69 for Robert Austin.

Full text: BROOKLIN -- Voters have chosen Fairfield Goodale to fill a selectman's position recently vacated by Kevin Poland. His term of office will expire in 1996.
At a special election Monday, residents cast 78 votes for Goodale and 69 for Robert Austin. A retired physician, Goodale is president of Blue Hill Memorial Hospital board of trustees. He also has served on the town's shellfish commission and the school building committee.
After four years on the Board of Selectmen, Poland resigned in June.

Seized scallopers return home from Canada Issue of international jurisdiction still unresolved

Author: Martinez, Jose

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]11 Aug 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413828930?accountid=10457

Abstract: NEW BEDFORD, Mass. (AP) -- With empty holds but hailed as heroes, the captains of the Alpha & Omega II and the Warrior steamed into home port Wednesday. "I feel good to be home, but I don't feel so good in the wallet," quipped Alpha & Omega II captain Charlie Rodriques, standing beside the Warrior. "It's a long ordeal, Charlie, a long ordeal," said the Warrior's skipper, Michael Willett, shaking Rodriques' hand for photo- graphers.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Seized+scallopers+return+home+from+Canada+Issue+of+international+jurisdiction+still+unresolved&amp;author=Martinez%2C+Jose&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-08-11&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: NEW BEDFORD, Mass. (AP) -- With empty holds but hailed as heroes, the captains of the Alpha & Omega II and the Warrior steamed into home port Wednesday.
The local fishermen who stirred up a diplomatic ruckus by seeking rich scallop beds in international waters had returned.
More than 150 relatives and friends greeted the fishermen at the pier, cheering and waving as the draggers slowly sidled up to the dock. Trawlers and draggers tied up nearby blasted their horns.
"I feel good to be home, but I don't feel so good in the wallet," quipped Alpha & Omega II captain Charlie Rodriques, standing beside the Warrior.
"It's a long ordeal, Charlie, a long ordeal," said the Warrior's skipper, Michael Willett, shaking Rodriques' hand for photo- graphers.
The two men are free on $5,000 bonds pending separate trials in Newfoundland this fall. If convicted of illegal fishing, they face fines up to $750,000 apiece.
The boats were seized July 26 by Canadian authorities, who have claimed control of the shellfish beyond Canada's territorial waters. But the U.S. State Department -- and the fishermen -- say the scallops are fair game.
Rodriques, 36, of Mattapoisett, says the scallopers steamed into a trap.
"It was piracy, it was uncalled for," Rodriques said, later adding: "They had five days while we were under steam to get out there to tell us, `No, you can't fish for scallops."
The fishermen and members of the Massachusetts congressional delegation have called for sanctions against Canada. The fishermen want to boycott Canadian fish. Washington wants Canada to drop the charges and fines and to compensate the boat owners for lost time at sea.
Bob Bruno, owner of the Alpha & Omega II, said the trip cost him $10,000 in fuel alone. He shook his head when asked about the added cost of food, ice and other supplies. "Something like this can put you under," he said.
Canadian Fisheries Minister Brian Tobin has said Ottawa gave the United States ample warning that it would prosecute Americans who harvested Icelandic scallops that sit on the continental shelf outside the 200-mile territorial limit.
Ottawa claims the Icelandic scallops are sedentary and theirs to regulate under international law. Washington disagrees, saying the mollusks swim, if not that well.
Bruno said he doubts he will send the boat back to the nose of the Grand Banks off Newfoundland until the dispute is resolved.
That came as a relief to Kathy DeBarros, wife of Alpha & Omega II first mate Thomas DeBarros. "And it's a shame, too," she said. "They checked it out before going there. But the Canadians want to control everything."
Away from the cameras and the crowd, a bare-chested Jared Carney stood on the Alpha's deck, holding his 20-month-old son, Zachary, and talking to his wife, Kim, who stayed on the pier. He spoke of the morning the 95-foot dragger was seized.
"It was scary. They had M-16s and they had guns on their sides," he said. "And they're not just the Fisheries guys, they were the Canadian Navy."

People: Rodriques, Charlie
