Captain's schooner draws a crowd Maine's WoodenBoat Show attracts 70-year-old sailor from Nova Scotia

Author: Kathy Harbour Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]01 Aug 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413808014?accountid=10457

Abstract: [Edward Murphy] had moored his schooner alongside the far dock at the WoodenBoat Show. It is a seaworthy craft shadowed in size, perhaps, by the bigger vessels, but richly warm in varnished mahagony and memory. A third generation business owner in Halifax, Murphy's heart and passion lie with the sea and his 1953 William J. Roue designed boat. The father of seven, with 10 grandchildren, Murphy sailed with four others to Maine's coast where he was joined by wife Elise, who had cautiously decided to forgo the fog and traveled by land. The WoodenBoat Show in Southwest Harbor drew large crowds during the weekend. (NEWS Photo by Bob DeLong) A 17-foot barrel-back runabout built by Chris Craft in 1941 and fully restored by Wayfarer Marine of Camden drew rave reviews at the WoodenBoat Show in Southwest Harbor. (NEWS Photo by Bob DeLong)

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Captain%27s+schooner+draws+a+crowd+Maine%27s+WoodenBoat+Show+attracts+70-year-old+sailor+from+Nova+Scotia&amp;author=Kathy+Harbour+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-08-01&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: SOUTHWEST HARBOR -- If he makes it to 90, and it's a wise bet that he will, Edward Murphy will set sail to Singapore on his schooner.
The 70-something sailor from Halifax, Nova Scotia, is too young to retire but old enough to dream of it. As captain of the 37-foot by 9-foot-6-inch Hebridee II, a Bluenose Junior schooner, Murphy told tales of the fog and the sea to all who came aboard this weekend.
Murphy had moored his schooner alongside the far dock at the WoodenBoat Show. It is a seaworthy craft shadowed in size, perhaps, by the bigger vessels, but richly warm in varnished mahagony and memory.
A third generation business owner in Halifax, Murphy's heart and passion lie with the sea and his 1953 William J. Roue designed boat. The father of seven, with 10 grandchildren, Murphy sailed with four others to Maine's coast where he was joined by wife Elise, who had cautiously decided to forgo the fog and traveled by land.
"I don't do boats and I don't do races," Elise laughs as she emerges from the far cabin to greet newcomers to the intimate quiet of the dining and sleeping quarters. Her passion, she says, is gardens.
"It'll sleep seven, if two know each other really well," Murphy quips, while settling in for another round of visitors at this three-day fest. In the calm of the cabin, with hundreds of feet passing by the tiny portholes, Murphy entertains with memories of races in Canadian waters from Marblehead to Halifax.
On the wall is a plaque from the American Schooner Association in 1987, a tribute, Murphy says, "for just being old and being around." But, an honor, his wife explains, for staging a festival of schooners at the waterfront.
With more than 8,000 people streaming through the WoodenBoat Show over the past three days, it was the tales of seaports and boat designs that enticed landlubbers and boatowners to step into cabins and settle into deckchairs on wooden boats of all decades and sizes.
Families piled their dogs onto schoolbuses to travel between parking lot and boat show, strapped babies into backpacks, and stepped in and out of shoes to look into and around boats.
Solo boaters settled into finely finished kayaks to ply the waters off the marina. Sailors who had moored offshore reached the show by dinghy, sharing the harbor with beefy ships such as the Invincible IV and the Principia, their captains manuevering for space in the waterways.
A show celebrating the tradition of wooden-boat craftmanship, the marina was shared by them all: the exquisite, the work horses of the sea, and even those making a comeback, such as the Chesapeake Oyster Buy Boat.
The veteran of fishing voyages since 1925, the Buy Boat is a cleaned-up boat nearly 35 feet in length, waiting for the finely tuned work of a master craftsman. Ralph Stanley of Southwest Harbor will turn the cargo hutch into a "floating condominium" for owner Holyoke Whitney.
The Murphys will float to Camden this week, enjoying the coastal Maine waters with other wooden boats that will sail away together from Southwest Harbor Monday morning in the WoodenBoat Cruise-in-(Good) Company event.
"Can one man handle this?" a visitor asks the captain.
"Well, if he's a man like me," Murphy responds, a twinkle in his eye and his weathered tan muscles flexing. But in case he needs some help on that trip to Singapore, his grandchildren are sailors in training, getting ready to follow where their granddad leads.
Illustration Caption: The WoodenBoat Show in Southwest Harbor drew large crowds during the weekend. (NEWS Photo by Bob DeLong) A 17-foot barrel-back runabout built by Chris Craft in 1941 and fully restored by Wayfarer Marine of Camden drew rave reviews at the WoodenBoat Show in Southwest Harbor. (NEWS Photo by Bob DeLong)

`Fine jewelry'

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]01 Aug 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413733419?accountid=10457

Abstract: The "karat" marking tells you what proportion of gold is mixed with the other metals. If 14 parts of gold are mixed with 10 parts of base metal, the combination is called 14-karat (14K) gold. The higher the karat rating, the higher the proportion of gold in the object. The lowest karat gold that can be marketed as gold in the United States is 10 karat. Jewelry does not have to be marked with its karat quality, but most of it is. If there is a karat quality mark, next to it must be the U.S. registered trademark of the person or company that will stand behind the mark, as required by the National Gold and Silver Stamping Act. "Plated," "gold-filled," "gold overlay" and "rolled gold plate" are terms used to describe jewelry that has a layer of at least 10-karat gold mechanically bonded to a base metal. If such jewelry is marked with one of these terms, the term itself must follow the karat quality of the gold used (14K gold overlay, for example). If the layer of karat gold constitutes less than 1/20th of the total weight of the object, any marking must state the actual percentage of karat gold, such as "1/40th 14K gold overlay."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=%60Fine+jewelry%27&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-08-01&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: When you go shopping for a piece of fine jewelry, perhaps to celebrate a special occasion, you may find yourself puzzled by terms that sales clerks use to describe gold, precious gems and watches. To help you understand the meaning of some typical terms used by the jewelry industry in its advertising, the Federal Trade Commission has shared with us the following information about fine jewelry. Although there is no commercial or legal definition for the phrase "fine jewelry," many retailers use the term to describe karat gold jewelry, gemstones and higher-priced watches.
Guidelines established by the Federal Trade Commission in cooperation with the jewelry industry state that the word "gold," used by itself, means "all gold" or 24 karat (24K) gold. Because 24K gold is soft, it usually is mixed with other metals to increase its hardness and durability.
The "karat" marking tells you what proportion of gold is mixed with the other metals. If 14 parts of gold are mixed with 10 parts of base metal, the combination is called 14-karat (14K) gold. The higher the karat rating, the higher the proportion of gold in the object. The lowest karat gold that can be marketed as gold in the United States is 10 karat. Jewelry does not have to be marked with its karat quality, but most of it is. If there is a karat quality mark, next to it must be the U.S. registered trademark of the person or company that will stand behind the mark, as required by the National Gold and Silver Stamping Act.
"Solid gold" can refer to any karat gold if the inside of the item of jewelry is not hollow. The proportion of gold in the piece of jewelry is still determined by the karat mark.
"Plated," "gold-filled," "gold overlay" and "rolled gold plate" are terms used to describe jewelry that has a layer of at least 10-karat gold mechanically bonded to a base metal. If such jewelry is marked with one of these terms, the term itself must follow the karat quality of the gold used (14K gold overlay, for example). If the layer of karat gold constitutes less than 1/20th of the total weight of the object, any marking must state the actual percentage of karat gold, such as "1/40th 14K gold overlay."
Platinum is a precious metal used in fine jewelry. It has a silvery appearance and usually is alloyed with a related metal called iridium.
Jewelry marked "silver" or "sterling silver" must contain 92.5 percent silver under jewelry industry guidelines. The mark "coin silver" is used for alloys containing 90 percent silver. Under the National Gold and Silver Stamping Act, quality-marked silver also must bear a U.S. registered trademark.
To qualify as "gemstones," minerals must possess beauty (affected by color, transparency and brilliance) which is brought out by cutting; durability (the stone's hardness and toughness); and rarity (taking into consideration size and quality). Some organic materials also are used in jewelry.
The most popular organic gem is the pearl. A pearl is the response of a mollusk to the presence of an irritating impurity accidentally introduced into its body. A cultured pearl is the result of the intentional insertion of a mother-of-pearl bead into a live mollusk. Whether introduced accidentally or intentionally, the pearl-making process is the same; the mollusk coats the irritant with a substance called nacre.
According to FTC guidelines, a synthetic or imitation stone cannot be offered for sale without disclosing that it is not natural. For example, a ruby made in a laboratory, having the same composition as a natural stone, must be described as "synthetic," "created," "laboratory-grown" or "man-made."
Next week we will continue by going into units of measurements involving gemstones and what to look for when purchasing a watch.
Consumer Forum is a collaborative effort of the Bangor Daily News and Northeast COMBAT. Send your questions to Consumer Forum, Bangor Daily News, P.O. Box 1329, Bangor 04402-1329. COMBAT is a membership organization with basic dues of $10 a year. For membership information write to the above address. Please enclose a large, stamped, self-addressed envelope.

Georges River Trust organizing canoe trip

Abstract: The Georges River Land Trust has organized a recreational canoe trip on the Thomaston to Warren section of the St. George River for 10 a.m.

Town's $7 million sewer project draws heated debate at hearing

Author: Emmet Meara Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]26 July 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413810353?accountid=10457

Abstract: Dwight Henry said state officials term the proposal a "wacky" solution. Henry supported moving the treatment plant off the Thomaston waterfront, but not at the expense of north-end residents. Many fear that spraying sewer waste on the land will pollute ground water, Henry said. Part of the area being considered for the disposal site is a farm owned by the Thorndike brothers. Paul Thorndike said Monday that the land is all clay and is too wet and unsuitable for waste disposal and supported the construction of a sewer pipe to the existing treatment plant in Rockland. Art Pease said the land proposed for a disposal site has had heavy erosion problems from heavy runoff into the Oyster River.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Town%27s+%247+million+sewer+project+draws+heated+debate+at+hearing&amp;author=Emmet+Meara+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-07-26&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: THOMASTON -- A proposed $7 million solution to the town sewer problems met strong opposition at a public hearing Monday night at Watts Hall. Board of Selectman Chairman Lee Ann Upham indicated a second public hearing will be called to answer questions raised by the public.
Many residents favored renovation of the current plant rather than moving the system to the north end of town near the Oyster River. About 100 residents attended the session.
Selectmen hoped to have the proposal before a town meeting in September.
Engineers told the crowd on Monday night that the current treatment plant is 27 years old and located on a restrictive site on the town waterfront on the St. George River. Renovating the existing plant was rejected as too expensive. Also rejected because of excessive costs were alternatives to extend pipelines to treatment plants in Rockland or Warren.
Selectmen and engineers have recommended a $7 million proposal with lagoon treatment and effluent either sprayed on land or discharged into the river, depending on the season. The proposal calls for using about 185 acres at the north end of town off Booker Street.
That area is clearly unsuitable for spraying effluent, said Dana Clukey. The land is marked with many deep ravines which run to the river. Any runoff would end up in the Oyster River, which empties into the St. George River, he said. "That land is so wet that you couldn't get a skidder in there in the spring," he said. Comments from engineers and consultant John Fancy that state law would not permit a spray program which caused any environmental damage brought laughter from the audience.
When selectman John Hathaway said the spraying will have minor odor problems but will not pollute land at the disposal site, one woman yelled out "Well, why don't you sell your land and move up there?"
Dwight Henry said state officials term the proposal a "wacky" solution. Henry supported moving the treatment plant off the Thomaston waterfront, but not at the expense of north-end residents. Many fear that spraying sewer waste on the land will pollute ground water, Henry said.
Diane Corbett said that leaving human waste in "open cesspools" could allow mosquitoes and flies to spread diseases like AIDS and cholera. She asked for concrete assurances from state officials that the health and safety of residents will not be compromised by the plan.
Part of the area being considered for the disposal site is a farm owned by the Thorndike brothers. Paul Thorndike said Monday that the land is all clay and is too wet and unsuitable for waste disposal and supported the construction of a sewer pipe to the existing treatment plant in Rockland. Art Pease said the land proposed for a disposal site has had heavy erosion problems from heavy runoff into the Oyster River.
Chairman Upham said the proposal was modeled after a highly successful program in Damariscotta. Officials from Damariscotta will be invited to any future discussions, she said. Selectman Peter Lammert said the same system has been used successfully in Greenville for decades.
Officials said the pipeline to Rockland would cost $8 million, plus other expenses including a $2 million "buy-in" cost. Selectman Upham reminded voters that they had agreed to abandon the current treatment plant site at the March town meeting.

People: Upham, Lee Ann Henry, Dwight

Study: Overfishing has stressed world's oceans to the limit Worldwatch Inst percent drop in catch

Author: Sonner, Scott

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]25 July 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413778170?accountid=10457

Abstract: "Although worldwide environmental degradation of the oceans contributes to the decline of marine life, overfishing is the primary cause of dwindling fish populations," said the report by the nonprofit Worldwatch Institute. "The oceans are not the unlimited reservoir of low-cost food they were once considered." All fishing grounds in the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, as well as the Mediterranean and Black seas, are in decline after peaking between 1973 and 1991, the institute said. If countries are to end overfishing, the report said, they must choose whether to favor large-scale, industrial fishers; medium scale fishers; or small-scale, community-based fishers.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Study%3A+Overfishing+has+stressed+world%27s+oceans+to+the+limit+Worldwatch+Inst+percent+drop+in+catch&amp;author=Sonner%2C+Scott&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-07-25&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: WASHINGTON -- The world's oceans have been fished nearly to the limits, after decades of fishermen using bigger boats and more advanced hunting technologies, according to a report released Saturday.
"Although worldwide environmental degradation of the oceans contributes to the decline of marine life, overfishing is the primary cause of dwindling fish populations," said the report by the nonprofit Worldwatch Institute. "The oceans are not the unlimited reservoir of low-cost food they were once considered."
A 5 percent decline in the worldwide catch since 1989 is due largely to more people fishing in large-scale, industrial operations, often in waters that are becoming more polluted, the report said.
Meanwhile, world population is growing at 1.6 percent annually, equivalent to the population of Mexico being added to the world each year, the report said.
"This is a global problem that has already caused armed confrontations between fishing nations, gunfire between fishers and hunger in the developing world," said Peter Weber, author of the report, "Net Loss: Fish, Jobs and the Marine Environment."
"If current mismanagement continues, we can expect a future in which millions of fishers are out of work. ... A future in which traditional fishing cultures from Nova Scotia to Malaysia disappear," he said.
After decades of rapid growth, all the planet's major fishing grounds are at or beyond their limits, and many have already suffered serious declines, the report said.
All fishing grounds in the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, as well as the Mediterranean and Black seas, are in decline after peaking between 1973 and 1991, the institute said.
Only the Indian Ocean fisheries are still increasing total output, although they are unlikely to expand much more and could be poised for serious declines, the institute said.
The total catch has shrunk by more than 30 percent in four of the hardest-hit areas -- the Pacific's east-central region and the Atlantic's northwest, west-central and southeast sectors.
The supply of fishery products grew at three times the rate of human population growth during the 1950s and '60s. But the once abundant North Atlantic cod now may be commercially extinct, western Atlantic bluefin tuna are down to only 10 percent of their former abundance, several North Pacific salmon species are on the brink of extinction and oysters in the Chesapeake Bay are at only 4 percent of former levels, the report said.
Declining catches have already cost more than 100,000 jobs in the last few years among the world's 15 million to 21 million fishermen, the report said.
"It is not just the number of fishers that counts, but also the size of their nets, the number of their hooks, the girth of their boats -- in short, their capacity to fish," Weber said.
From 1970 to 1990, the world's fishing fleet doubled, from 585,000 to 1.2 million large boats, the report said.
"Government policies have for the most part promoted overexpansion of the fishing industry" and primarily benefited industrial fishing, the institute said.
If countries are to end overfishing, the report said, they must choose whether to favor large-scale, industrial fishers; medium scale fishers; or small-scale, community-based fishers.

AmeriCorps grant to fund 8 jobs in Washington County

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]16 July 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413749249?accountid=10457

Abstract: "Twenty positions will be funded statewide, eight in the Down East RC&D area. The Washington County Soil & Water Conservation District will have two water quality coordinators; The University of Maine at Machias and the Beals Island Regional shellfish Hatchery at Beals will have five positions; and there will be one cranberry coordinator position working out of the Down East RC&D office in Cherryfield," he explained. "We were very fortunate to receive eight positions in Washington County." Nathan Pennell, office manager for the Washington County S&WCD office at Machias, said one of the two water quality coordinators would perform water quality studies on the St. Croix River watershed at Calais. The other coordinator would study the Chandler River watershed in the Jonesboro region, and would implement a coastal water quality monitoring program from Roque Bluffs to Addison. The studies will include recommendations favoring water protection and pollution cleanup.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=AmeriCorps+grant+to+fund+8+jobs+in+Washington+County&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-07-16&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The U.S. Department of Agriculture has awarded the state a grant to fund 20 positions in the AmeriCorps National Service project, including eight jobs in Washington County to benefit cranberry growers, staff a clam hatchery and conduct water quality studies.
The total cost of the ACNS project beginning in September is expected to be about $500,000. In addition to a federal grant of more than $300,000, several participating government agencies will provide matching funds for the overall project. Each agency will be expected to contribute about $1,800 toward each position funded with a stipend of $12,000.
AmeriCorps is President Clinton's national service initiative that allows people to earn college or vocational school scholarships or credit to pay off existing educational loans while performing critical service to meet human, environmental, public safety and educational needs.
Any Maine citizen, age 17 or older, is eligible to apply for one of the positions. The program will require applicants to have at least two years of college course work. There is no maximum or minimum family income requirement. Applications will be accepted until Aug. 5.
Those hired under the service program will work one year, earning $12,000. Those with a minimum of 1,700 hours of service, also will receive an educational award worth $4,725.
Dana Nelson, coordinator for the bi-county Down East Resource and Development agency at Cherryfield, prepared the grant application on behalf of several participating organizations. He said Friday that the grant was approved by the AmeriCorp Foundation.
"Twenty positions will be funded statewide, eight in the Down East RC&D area. The Washington County Soil & Water Conservation District will have two water quality coordinators; The University of Maine at Machias and the Beals Island Regional shellfish Hatchery at Beals will have five positions; and there will be one cranberry coordinator position working out of the Down East RC&D office in Cherryfield," he explained. "We were very fortunate to receive eight positions in Washington County."
The cranberry industry in Washington and Hancock counties will benefit from the enhancement of an Integrated Crop Management Program for growers. Nelson said the cranberry coordinator would work out of Cherryfield.
Nathan Pennell, office manager for the Washington County S&WCD office at Machias, said one of the two water quality coordinators would perform water quality studies on the St. Croix River watershed at Calais. The other coordinator would study the Chandler River watershed in the Jonesboro region, and would implement a coastal water quality monitoring program from Roque Bluffs to Addison. The studies will include recommendations favoring water protection and pollution cleanup.
Five ACNS positions will be utilized by the shellfish hatchery at Beals. They will be involved in a variety of hatchery operations, including experimental research on clam beds.

Company / organization: Name: AmeriCorps; SIC: 8399

Brunswick eyes lottery for clam digger licenses

Author: (AP)

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]15 July 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413813554?accountid=10457

Abstract: With the hope of avoiding another stampede of would-be shellfish diggers, officials in Brunswick are considering selling commercial clam licenses through a lottery system instead of through the town's old first-come, first-served system. Under the proposal, licenses would be sold based upon how many years diggers have held licenses here instead of which diggers reach the town hall first the morning of the sale day. This year, there were 90 licenses total. Fifty-three were sold to diggers who have held a license for three out of the last five years. About twice as many people as licenses wanted the remaining licenses.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Brunswick+eyes+lottery+for+clam+digger+licenses&amp;author=%28AP%29&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-07-15&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BRUNSWICK -- With the hope of avoiding another stampede of would-be shellfish diggers, officials in Brunswick are considering selling commercial clam licenses through a lottery system instead of through the town's old first-come, first-served system.
The Marine Resources Committee decided to recommend that the town change its system starting next spring so that new licenses are sold through a set of four lottery drawings.
Under the proposal, licenses would be sold based upon how many years diggers have held licenses here instead of which diggers reach the town hall first the morning of the sale day.
This March, several clamdiggers received minor injuries when an informal line among them broke down and some diggers were pushed and shoved in their rush for the town hall doors.
One month later, Darrell E. Pennell and Ray Trombley, two diggers who didn't receive licenses, filed a lawsuit against the town which is still awaiting a trial date in Cumberland County Superior Court.
Every year, Brunswick officials do a detailed survey intended to estimate the amount of harvestable bushels of clams in all of the town's shellfish beds. Those survey results then determine the number of licenses available for sale.
But, especially in recent years, the demand for licenses has been greater than the number of licenses available.
This year, there were 90 licenses total. Fifty-three were sold to diggers who have held a license for three out of the last five years. About twice as many people as licenses wanted the remaining licenses.
Following the stampede, in which several older men with families had been pushed out for licenses, there were suggestions of doing away with the survey information and selling more licenses.
But the committee opted for a new system instead.
"It is a good answer," said James A. MacLeod, chairman of the Marine Resources Committee. "We tried to be as fair as possible to everybody."

DMR closes clam beds from Trescott to Canada

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]15 July 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413712334?accountid=10457

Abstract: The Department of Marine Resources closed all clam beds Tuesday from Trescott to the Canadian border including Cobscook Bay, citing high levels of the plankton that causes red tide. An estimated 300 diggers will be affected by the move. He said the presence of red tide toxin in clams from the Cobscook Bay area exceeded federal limits, while clams from other flats in the closed area did not. To be sure none of the contaminated clams were harvested or sold for human consumption, DMR closed the entire area to harvesting. Although the red plankton is harmless to clams, it produces a toxin that accumulates in marine animals. Filter feeders, such as clams and mussels, thrive on plankton.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=DMR+closes+clam+beds+from+Trescott+to+Canada&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-07-15&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The Department of Marine Resources closed all clam beds Tuesday from Trescott to the Canadian border including Cobscook Bay, citing high levels of the plankton that causes red tide. An estimated 300 diggers will be affected by the move.
John Hurst, a biologist with the Department of Marine Resources laboratory at West Boothbay, said, "My two great concerns are for public safety and the well-being of fishermen. The public's safety comes first, although I am always aware of the needs of fishermen to earn a livelihood for their families."
He predicted a lengthy closure, based on a recent report of "high rises" of blooming plankton in the Bay of Fundy.
He said the presence of red tide toxin in clams from the Cobscook Bay area exceeded federal limits, while clams from other flats in the closed area did not. To be sure none of the contaminated clams were harvested or sold for human consumption, DMR closed the entire area to harvesting.
Although the red plankton is harmless to clams, it produces a toxin that accumulates in marine animals. Filter feeders, such as clams and mussels, thrive on plankton.
Humans who eat the contaminated shellfish can become ill from paralytic shellfish poisoning. Plankton is believed to originate in coastal rivers.
Robert D. Lewis of the DMR office in Augusta, said Hurst would continue weekly testing of the closed area. The red tide hot line for people with questions is 1-800-232-4733.
About 300 seasonal clam diggers were put out of work in the Cobscook Bay region, according to Sheldon Ashby of Pembroke Clam Co. in Pembroke.
"I have about 75 diggers who supplied me with clams," he said. That number includes about 25 who sold their clams to Lawrence Lyons, Ashby's buyer in Lubec, where flats also are closed.
Ashby said his best "money months" are June, July and August. To keep his customers supplied with clams, he is buying from western Maine dealers. "I can't get enough clams that way and it costs me about $10 a bushel, but I'll manage to stay in business and satisfy my customers," he said.
While Ashby's business is suffering, the diggers who were paid about $75 a bushel may be hurting the most. After taking home about $150 for about three hours of work each day, they are now out of the clam business. Also, if they wait to work in the blueberry harvest in eastern Washington County they may not find work until fields ripen about the second week of August.

Title: DMR closes clam beds from Trescott to Canada:   [ALL Edition ]

Essays celebrate Gould's wit, wisdom `Dispatches from Maine' collects columnist's best efforts from 50-year period

Author: Bea Goodrich Special to the NEWS

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]09 July 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413883146?accountid=10457

Abstract: The 85-year-old Maine author -- who has 28 notches in his literary belt -- writes with the fey sophistication of a wise troll. One can imagine the glint of amusement in his lively, bespectacled eyes as he penned these words in the foreword to "Dispatches from Maine": "We don't write books in Maine. We live books. We go hunting and fishing, we tend out on Grange meetings, we socialize as time permits, and after we've done enough living in Maine the pile is big enough and we send it to a publisher." As variable as Maine weather, "Dispatches from Maine" brings under discussion such subjects as what ever happened to marbles, the proper ritual for serving thick Barbados molasses and cream with oatmeal, how to cut the ice and fill it in the big icehouse behind the dingle, corn snow at sapping time, the day the author's father found a carpet tack in the cookie he was eating, laying the cornerstone at [John Gould] farm, and the greatest thing since sliced bread (Barbados molasses) ... these and myriad others equally wise, reflective, or just plain droll are flocked together like a parliament of owls.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Essays+celebrate+Gould%27s+wit%2C+wisdom+%60Dispatches+from+Maine%27+collects+columnist%27s+best+efforts+from+50-year+period&amp;author=Bea+Goodrich+Special+to+the+NEWS&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-07-09&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: DISPATCHES FROM MAINE, by John Gould, Norton, 199 pages, $23.
"Some love the meat, some love to pick the bones, " observed John Bunyan about reader reaction to his celebrated masterpiece, "Pilgrim's Progress." This challenge is built into John Gould's collection of essays winnowed from the aggregate of columns he wrote as a weekly feature for The Christian Science Monitor from 1942 to 1992.
The 85-year-old Maine author -- who has 28 notches in his literary belt -- writes with the fey sophistication of a wise troll. One can imagine the glint of amusement in his lively, bespectacled eyes as he penned these words in the foreword to "Dispatches from Maine": "We don't write books in Maine. We live books. We go hunting and fishing, we tend out on Grange meetings, we socialize as time permits, and after we've done enough living in Maine the pile is big enough and we send it to a publisher."
The lead piece in his omnium-gatherum, called "Buck-Saws and Christmas Trees," is the tuning fork for the 74 other essays in that it sets the tone for the laconic independence with which Maine natives are so closely associated. In it Gould explains how it happened that he converted "a grand piece of black walnut" into a bucksaw. He also sets down some of the aberrant impulses indulged in by his neighbors -- Chris Wadell, for example, who painted his hilltop silo with red, white, and blue stripes ("Not a man in the neighborhood commented on this improvement, and it is likely Chris never expected them to."), and Charlie Little's decision to set up a shapely fir tree on his front piazza one August and trim it with lights and strings of popcorn.
"Are we peculiar in our private belief that a man's own inclination is to be indulged?" asked Gould. "Hasn't conformity to rules of behavior taken a lot of snap out of life?"
Essayists are a breed apart. Like leaders in the game of snap the whip they startle and surprise readers with their sudden mental twists and turns. Gould does this in "Fame is Spelled in Lower Case" in which he puts a novel spin on the plight of inventors whose identity is often eclipsed by the success of their inventions. "When man makes the better mousetrap," writes the author, "his name will no doubt go on and on and on. But it probably will be spelled with a small letter ..." Who is Mr. Pitman, he demands. When and where did he live? He then reveals that Mr. Pitman is the inventor of the indispensable device that millions of farmers depend on to keep their mowers in operation, the pitman rod. Another condemned to lower-case anonymity is Mr. Peavey. Yet the peavey, a cant hook used by log rollers from Bangor to the four corners of the world, is de rigueur in logging circles.
Then there was the day Gould read a magazine piece about an Indian named Quadequina. In 1630 Quadequina gave the Pilgrims a bushel of popped corn for Thanksgiving. Given the fact that no suitable utensils existed back then, how had he popped the corn, wondered the author. A hot, flat rock, perhaps? This conjured up the risible vision of flying popcorn landing in the junipers, sweetfern, hardtack, alders, hackmatack and blueberry bushes, with Quandequina in hot pursuit.
As variable as Maine weather, "Dispatches from Maine" brings under discussion such subjects as what ever happened to marbles, the proper ritual for serving thick Barbados molasses and cream with oatmeal, how to cut the ice and fill it in the big icehouse behind the dingle, corn snow at sapping time, the day the author's father found a carpet tack in the cookie he was eating, laying the cornerstone at Gould farm, and the greatest thing since sliced bread (Barbados molasses) ... these and myriad others equally wise, reflective, or just plain droll are flocked together like a parliament of owls.
The author and his wife, Dorothy, live in Friendship. It was in the russet month of October 1942 that Gould appeared in print as "a country correspondent whose writings naturally have a distinct flavor of the soil." Readers chuckled over his dry wit, appreciated his sly sallies, and were captivated by his essays on Maine's lares and penates. Most of all they responded to his wisdom. And that is the peerless pearl in the oyster of "Dispatches from Maine."
Bea Goodrich's reviews are a monthly feature in the Books & Music section.

People: Gould, John

Island clam flats studied

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]06 July 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413752654?accountid=10457

Abstract: The red-line is a term that describes the flats around Casco Bay that have been closed for much of the last 40 years. Today, 49 percent of the bay's clam flats are off-limits to clammers, representing a loss of nearly 200 jobs in an area from Phippsburg to Cape Elizabeth. "These are vital clam flats around densely populated areas. When a flat closes, the clam diggers' lives are ruined," [Joseph Payne] said.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Island+clam+flats+studied&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-07-06&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: FALMOUTH (AP) -- Casco Bay's baykeeper says a plan to reopen a once thriving clam flat off Mackworth Island that was closed because of pollution is "a `win-win-win' situation."
"Polluted shellfish habitat can be rehabbed, jobs can be restored, and citizens can help get rid of the `red-line' by serving as stewards of the bay. We'll come up with a plan that everyone can be happy with," said Joseph Payne.
The red-line is a term that describes the flats around Casco Bay that have been closed for much of the last 40 years. Today, 49 percent of the bay's clam flats are off-limits to clammers, representing a loss of nearly 200 jobs in an area from Phippsburg to Cape Elizabeth.
"These are vital clam flats around densely populated areas. When a flat closes, the clam diggers' lives are ruined," Payne said.
The Mackworth Island project, sponsored by the conservation group Friends of Casco Bay, seeks to demonstrate that the cost of solving pollution problems can be offset by the resulting economic benefits.
The group plans to begin the project by assessing the clam population at the flat, which has been closed for the past decade.
If the flat proves to have a strong clam base, the group will develop a detailed plan on what will need to be done by the town, nearby residents and state officials to reopen it.
Cleanup programs over the past three decades have brought the bay's major sewage problems under control. The focus now has turned to smaller problems such as roadside waste runoff that are more difficult to pinpoint.
"When there is a heavy rainfall, waste from parking lots and animals grazing in nearby fields gets carried into the nearest stream," said Brad Sterl, a marine biologist with the Department of Marine Resources.

Dexter seeks grant for Echo Lake work

Author: Tammy Lockhart Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]29 June 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413817729?accountid=10457

Abstract: According to Dave Pearson of the town's code enforcement office, chances are good that Dexter will qualify for a loan. A letter is being sent to property owners in the Echo Lake area to find out if they are interested in participating in the program. Once the scope of the project is known, he said, a formal grant request will be sent. Inspections of the systems in the Echo Lake watershed will be conducted this summer by John Boucher, who is employed by the office through the Senior Citizen Employment Project, Pearson said.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Dexter+seeks+grant+for+Echo+Lake+work&amp;author=Tammy+Lockhart+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-06-29&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: DEXTER -- Town officials are seeking state funds to assist property owners in the Echo Lake watershed to upgrade or replace their property's septic systems.
According to Dave Pearson of the town's code enforcement office, chances are good that Dexter will qualify for a loan. A letter is being sent to property owners in the Echo Lake area to find out if they are interested in participating in the program. Once the scope of the project is known, he said, a formal grant request will be sent.
The funding would be provided through the Maine Department of Environmental Protection's Small Community Grant Program. This program can provide up to 90 percent grant funding of sewage treatment and disposal systems to eliminate waste-water discharges which affect drinking water supplies, pollute shellfishing areas, degrade water quality, or cause a public nuisance.
The program is intended to provide facilities in rural areas of the state not served by public sewers. The maximum project cost which can be funded by the program is $100,000.
Most facilities funded by the Small Community Program are for individual on-site septic systems. These can be either owned or operated by the municipality, or be privately owned.
Pearson said that if the town is successful in obtaining the grant money, the funds may be used to provide 90 percent of the cost of replacing systems for year-round residences; 50 percent of the costs for businesses; and 25 percent for seasonal buildings.
Inspections of the systems in the Echo Lake watershed will be conducted this summer by John Boucher, who is employed by the office through the Senior Citizen Employment Project, Pearson said.
If the survey can be completed by this fall and the application completed, Pearson said, the funding for the project may be available to the town in May 1995.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413789569?accountid=10457

Abstract: People who eat clams in restaurants or purchase them in local markets needn't worry because state law requires diggers to show where the clams are harvested, said Sgt.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Red+tide+hits+coast+of+southern+Maine&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-06-29&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: YORK (AP) -- A red tide that hit the coast two weeks ago has made it dangerous to eat clams, mussels, oysters and quahogs harvested from the affected areas, authorities said.
The area of concern stretches from the Piscataqua River north to Biddeford Pool, where clam flats have been closed. Lesser restrictions are in place as far north as Cape Elizabeth.
People who eat clams in restaurants or purchase them in local markets needn't worry because state law requires diggers to show where the clams are harvested, said Sgt. David Moulton of the Maine Marine Patrol.

____________________________________________________________

Prince Edward Island faces change Bridge opponents see `fixed link' as an end to idyllic way of life

Author: Clyde H. Farnsworth The New York Times

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]29 June 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413749015?accountid=10457

Abstract: Now a nine-mile-long bridge is being built, to connect Borden, Prince Edward Island, and Cape Tormentine, New Brunswick, across the narrowest part of the Strait of Northumberland. The rich landscape has been made familiar to millions by "Anne of Green Gables," the 1908 tale of an orphan from Nova Scotia raised in a snug Prince Edward Island farmhouse. Prince Edward Island attracts 700,000 tourists a year, many drawn to the site of the Green Gables house in Cavendish, northwest of Charlottetown.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Prince+Edward+Island+faces+change+Bridge+opponents+see+%60fixed+link%27+as+an+end+to+idyllic+way+of+life&amp;author=Clyde+H.+Farnsworth+The+New+York+Times&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-06-29&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: CHARLOTTETOWN, Prince Edward Island -- They have argued about it for at least a century -- whether there should be a bridge or tunnel between this verdant crescent-shaped island province and mainland Canada.
Some said a "fixed link" was needed to spur economic growth and create jobs; others said it would damage a delicate ecology and destroy the idyllic "island way of life."
Now a nine-mile-long bridge is being built, to connect Borden, Prince Edward Island, and Cape Tormentine, New Brunswick, across the narrowest part of the Strait of Northumberland.
"It'll open up the island," said Tracy Rogers, a Charlottetown native studying to be a secretary. "It'll increase employment and make it easier to come and go. People are just getting fed up with long delays at the ferry."
Hundreds of carpenters, electricians, ironworkers and engineers have invaded the island, Canada's smallest province, home to 130,000 people. Approach piers are already rising a few hundred yards beyond the ferry terminals.
Crews with tractors and bulldozers are preparing staging areas in ocher cliffs above the sea to make precast concrete bridge sections, which will be hoisted into place by giant floating cranes.
The $620 million project, to be completed in three years, is providing jobs in the country's most depressed region.
"I think most people are glad something is finally happening," said Ron Ryder, who edits a monthly supplement on the bridge's construction for a Charlottetown daily, The Guardian.
"It's been a long and emotional argument, but basically most people are for it." Fifty-nine percent of islanders who voted in a 1988 plebiscite favored a link. More recent polls also show a majority in favor.
But not everyone is for it, and to many opponents, the story is far from over. This project has been analyzed more extensively than any other in Canada's history.
Many doubters believe, despite reassurances from the builders, that ice and the unusually strong currents in the strait will play havoc with the bridge's vertical supports.
"Just wait till winter," said Bea Mair, president of Friends of the Island, the main group of environmentalists, traditionalists, fishermen and ferry workers who have fought the project and have yet to disband. "Ice will come and sweep the bridge away."
Another issue is whether the support structures will hold ice in the strait longer than normal. A delayed departure of ice each spring could cool water temperatures, affecting marine animals' reproductive cycles, and could cause large chunks of ice to damage parts of the seabed that are habitat for herring, oysters, hard-shell clams, lobsters and scallops.
"The long-term impact could be felt throughout the southern Gulf of Saint Lawrence in terms of reduced productivity and depressed fisheries," said Dr. Irene Novaczek, a marine biologist and chairwoman of the Canadian Oceans Caucus, a network of environmental groups. Much of the flora and fauna of the strait, she said, are not found elsewhere north of Cape Cod.
In spite of a $7.2 million federal compensation package, fishermen have little good to say about the bridge.
Francis "Buck" Watts, who catches herring and lobster in his 43-foot fiberglass boat, Evening Dew, is president of the island's 800-member Fishermen's Association. "Neither myself nor the association is against progress," he said. "But we are against the demise of an industry."
The bridge is directly over scallop and lobster beds and spawning areas for herring. While fishing continues elsewhere in the strait, fishermen fear permanent losses as a result of the construction activity.
Beyond economic and ecological concerns is the perception that a special way of life is about to end.
Many residents think the island, with its quiet roads, cow-dotted hills, long white beaches and low crime rate, is among the most livable places in Canada.
The rich landscape has been made familiar to millions by "Anne of Green Gables," the 1908 tale of an orphan from Nova Scotia raised in a snug Prince Edward Island farmhouse.
It remains largely as Lucy Maud Montgomery, the author, described it, "Below the garden a green field lush with clover sloped down to the hollow where the brook ran and where scores of white birches grew."
Prince Edward Island attracts 700,000 tourists a year, many drawn to the site of the Green Gables house in Cavendish, northwest of Charlottetown.
Although economic surveys indicate the bridge will increase tourism by 25 percent, many prefer their separateness.
Warren Delaney lives in a farmhouse on the main road between the Borden ferry slip and Charlottetown. Mowing his back lawn one recent afternoon, he said the bridge "means we'll get all that trash from New Brunswick and Nova Scotia."
Charlotte Preston is a clerk in a Charlottetown gift shop. Born here, she lived "away" for 17 years and returned because of the low crime rate. "I like being an island, not an isthmus," she said. "You don't rob a bank when there are limited ways to leave."
The debate has seeped into the folklore of the island. Here is part of one recent song, titled "Fixed Link," written and recorded by George Brothers, a musician who also works in a national park near Cavendish:
On the one hand, there's a way of life.
Some feel it will be lost.
The other side wants progress.
No matter what the cost.

Abstract: Query 2525 BUSSELL-LEIGHTON. Have much info on this family but seek data on their descendants. Jacob Bussell, first settler Bangor 1769-1770. He bapt. Apr. 24, 1726 Oyster River, N.H., son of John Bussell/Buzzell and Sarah Wibird; he mar. Hannah Leighton who d. before 1786. Jacob mar. 2 Aug. 27, 1786 Sarah Price Mansell, widow of John Mansell Jr. of Old Orrington. Jacob's son Stephen m. Lucy Grant circa 1770 and came to Bangor. He d. Treatment of lobsters at supermarket rapped

Author: Locke, Michelle

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 June 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413821225?accountid=10457

Abstract: [Diane Allevato] said after hundreds of lobsters were shipped into stores for a Father's Day special, her office started getting calls from people complaining that the lobsters were being jammed into tanks or kept in boxes and plastic bags.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Treatment+of+lobsters+at+supermarket+rapped&amp;author=Locke%2C+Michelle&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-06-24&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) -- A live lobster special put supermarket officials in hot water with some Northern California customers who worried the shellfish were suffering on their way to the cooking pot.
"Just because we find it difficult to empathize with them or we don't understand what they're feeling doesn't mean that they don't feel stress or pain," said Diane Allevato, executive director of the Marin County Humane Society.
Oakland-based Safeway Stores assured customers they would do everything possible to make the lobsters' last hours tolerable.
The controversy boiled over last week at stores in Marin County, an area just north of San Francisco known for its million-dollar mansions, breathtaking coastline and holistic-minded populace.
Allevato said after hundreds of lobsters were shipped into stores for a Father's Day special, her office started getting calls from people complaining that the lobsters were being jammed into tanks or kept in boxes and plastic bags.
"They were essentially suffocating," she said. Even though the lobsters were headed for a fairly gruesome death anyway, callers felt they were entitled to some consideration, she said.
Safeway spokeswoman Debra Lambert said the lobsters were kept out of water when stores ran out of room. Lobsters can breathe out of water, so it is not cruel to keep them in open plastic bags or boxes provided they are not crowded, are surrounded by moist towels and kept cool, she said.

Timing is everything when it comes to nailing trophy fish

Author: Hennessey, Tom

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]23 June 1994: PDA.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413740648?accountid=10457

Abstract: As he released the No. 2 rod and started winching up the downriggers, [Scott Clark] told his oldest offspring to shift the motor into neutral. But because the wind was astern, [Ben Clark] was still losing line. Directly, he yelled, "Dad, I'm out of line!" A swift glance at his son's reel caused the senior Clark to command: "Reverse and full power!" All that was left on Ben's reel spool was the knot holding the 10-pound test line. Luckily - and because of [Jason]'s swift action at the helm - Ben began regaining line. Then, allowing that Ben had hooked onto the state of Maine, his father took the rod to see if he could release the rock or whatever had snagged the bait. Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Timing+is+everything+when+it+comes+to+nailing+trophy+fish&amp;author=Hennessey%2C+Tom&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-06-23&amp;spage=PDA&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Along about mid-June, the brothers Jason and Ben Clark of Kenduskeag, ages 13 and 11, respectively, convinced their father, Scott Clark, that it was time to go fishing. After gathering their trolling gear and lunches, Clark and sons, along with Tim Ward of East Corinth, towed their boat to Green Lake.
It's no secret that fishing success depends largely on being in the right place at the right time, and on that particular day the location and timing were perfect. In fact, it took only about 45 minutes of trolling sewn-on smelts before the No. 1 rod popped in its downrigger. Ben mittened onto the bowed rod and began reeling, but to no avail - begrudgingly, the reel's drag gave line.
As he released the No. 2 rod and started winching up the downriggers, Scott told his oldest offspring to shift the motor into neutral. But because the wind was astern, Ben was still losing line. Directly, he yelled, "Dad, I'm out of line!" A swift glance at his son's reel caused the senior Clark to command: "Reverse and full power!" All that was left on Ben's reel spool was the knot holding the 10-pound test line.
Luckily - and because of Jason's swift action at the helm - Ben began regaining line. Then, allowing that Ben had hooked onto the state of Maine, his father took the rod to see if he could release the rock or whatever had snagged the bait. But when he tugged, something weighty tugged back - twice. Quickly, Scott handed the rod back to his son with instructions to brace his feet. He then ordered Jason to shift the motor back into neutral.
During the tug of war that followed, Ben derricked the togue to within a few feet of the surface eight or 10 times, only to have it bore back to bottom again. When the fish eventually was brought to the surface, it rolled onto its broad side and showed that only one hook of the treble hook was hanging in its jaw. Cap'n Clark immediately gave Jason the order to "shut 'er down."
As it sculled dangerously close to the motor's shaft and prop, Scott attempted to net the trophy togue but the transducer bracket was in the way. A lunging, last-ditch effort with the net was successful, however, and amid loud cheers and congratulations, the finned prize was brought aboard - minus the hook and with no hook on Ben's line. Talk about fisherman's luck. Later, while loading the boat onto the trailer, Tim Ward discovered the hook fouled in the boat's tranducer bracket.
According to the weights-and-measures apparatus, the togue was 28 1/2 inches long and weighed 10 pounds, 8 ounces. That, my friend, was a bragging-size fish and, being a fisherman, young Ben Clark knew well the stigma of "fish stories." Therefore, he immediately asked his father for a loan toward having the togue mounted. Considering the "interest" involved, I'd call that a sound investment.
On June 12, the Maine Highpower Rifle Shooters held a National Match Course high-power rifle competition at the Oyster River Range in Warren. The match sanctioned by the National Rifle Association included competitions at ranges of 200, 300, and 600 yards while firing from standing, sitting, and prone positions.
Eighteen shooters endured rain and mosquitoes as they tested their skills. The overall match winner and first expert was Dave Dow of Old Town, who shot a score of 476 out of 500, including 13 bullseyes out of 50. John Lynds of Scarborough shot his way into second place with a score of 467 and 11 bullseyes. Rocky Prout of Cape Elizabeth posted a score of 467 and seven bullseyes to win third place and second expert; and Ray Gastonguay of Westbrook won fourth place and third expert with a score of 455 and six bullseyes.
When the smoke cleared, Gus Norcross of Winthrop was named first sharpshooter with a score of 465 and 10 bullseyes; and Les Higgins of South Portland took first marksman honors with a score of 379 and six bullseyes.
Come July 9, the Highpower Rifle Shooters will hold a practice-training session at the Oyster River Range. The fee for the session, which is open to the public, is $15. Ammunition for .308 cal. rifles will be provided. The club's next scheduled match is a 200-yard offhand competition that will be held at the Capital City Rifle and Pistol Club in Augusta on July 19. For further information contact: Gus Norcross, 395-4515; Rocky Prout, 799-6071; Ray Gastonguay, 854-1458.
Many local sportsmen were shocked and saddened by the untimely death of Al Roberts of Brewer. Al was an avid and responsible outdoorsman who valued Maine's sporting traditions, particularly hunting, and who was a strong supporter of the constitutional right to own firearms. Needless to say, he'll be missed. I offer my condolences to his family and many friends.

People: Clark, Ben Clark, Scott Ward, Tim

Quebec fishermen worry about lobster stocks

Author: Jack Branswell Canadian Press

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]23 June 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413725806?accountid=10457

Abstract: L'ETANG-DU-NORD, Quebec (AP) -- Henri Deraspe steers his boat into the choppy waters of the Gulf of St. Lawrence as the pungent mix of sea breeze, fish bait and diesel fuel fills the air. His son Sylvain, 28, cuts up lobster bait at the back of the Steve D-8, named after Henri's eighth son. The two work hand-in-glove, pulling up lobster traps, rebaiting them and tossing the traps back to the depths off the Iles-de-la-Madeleine, Quebec's archipelago in the middle of the gulf.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Quebec+fishermen+worry+about+lobster+stocks&amp;author=Jack+Branswell+Canadian+Press&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-06-23&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: L'ETANG-DU-NORD, Quebec (AP) -- Henri Deraspe steers his boat into the choppy waters of the Gulf of St. Lawrence as the pungent mix of sea breeze, fish bait and diesel fuel fills the air.
His son Sylvain, 28, cuts up lobster bait at the back of the Steve D-8, named after Henri's eighth son.
The two work hand-in-glove, pulling up lobster traps, rebaiting them and tossing the traps back to the depths off the Iles-de-la-Madeleine, Quebec's archipelago in the middle of the gulf.
The nine-week lobster season is the backbone of the local fishing economy. It provided 1,000 jobs last year and brought in more than $18 million.
It's also a deeply rooted way of life, and there's widespread concern that lobsters may go the way of codfish and other disappearing stocks.
"If the lobster goes a lot of people will leave these islands," said Sylvain. "What would be left?"
There was a 6 percent drop in the number of lobsters caught last year, compared with 1992's record catch. A further 5 percent decline is predicted for this year.
Fisheries experts are confident these are normal fluctuations in the stocks.
"We don't see this as a decrease in the resource, but as a returning to normal levels," says Pierre Couillard, a shellfish expert in the gulf for the federal Department of Fisheries and Oceans.
"We're not panicking yet."
But some fisherman are, especially young ones like Sylvain. They fear that the combination of overfishing and pollution may lead to the death of the entire fishery in the southern gulf.
Sylvain blames greedy fisherman.
"Because we're young, they (older fisherman) don't want to listen to us," he said. "They just want to put as much money in their pockets so they can go to Florida."
His 55-year-old father, who has been fishing for almost 30 years, shares Sylvain's concern about the industry. "There used to be a good life in it, but I'm worried for him and his children."
There's a hot debate in the archipelago on the use of large lobster traps that measure up to 4 feet long -- a controversy also seen in Prince Edward Island and Nova Scotia in recent years.
Fishermen who use traps about half that length maintain the large ones are depleting the stocks.
"I have no doubt at all that it (the use of big traps) has to be stopped," says Urbain Miousse, 63, who has fished for 47 years off L'Etang-du-Nord, a fishing port on the island of Cap-aux-Meules.
"If we're not careful we're going to pay for it as we're doing with the cod."
But those using the large traps say the practice merely allows the available lobsters to be caught more quickly. They suggest their opponents are jealous of their larger catches.
Regardless, Fisheries and Oceans plans to change the rules for next year so that fisherman can use only 210 large traps or 300 small ones, instead of 300 of either.
Meanwhile, some fishermen are keeping undersized lobster. That could affect the stock's ability to regenerate.
"In this business you don't fish for today, you do it for tomorrow," said Alvin Dickson, another fisherman.
He noted that technological advances such as depth-finding equipment are making it harder for lobsters to avoid capture.
Fishermen are also worried about the Irving Whale barge, which sank in 1970 just west of the islands and may be raised next year.
They fear the vessel, now 190 feet below the surface, could crack open.

People: Deraspe, Henri

____________________________________________________________

Midcoast road runs from fresh water to salt water

Author: Brian Swartz Advertising Staff Editor

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]16 June 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413725786?accountid=10457

Abstract: The road starts in Swanville, a town in northern Waldo County. West of "downtown" Swanville, Route 141 spins off Route 131 where a traffic triangle stands near a large white farmhouse. It's here where a motorist traveling north on 131 with bad brakes could slip through the intersection and land in Swan Lake. The bridge isn't a problem to navigate. Below Searsmont, Route 131 follows a basically straight course through Appleton to an intersection with Route 17 in Union. Route 17 connects Rockland with Augusta; by now, once you've crossed the Searsmont-Appleton town line, you are entering Knox County. At 43.9 miles, Route 131 intersects with Route 1 in Thomaston. It's very confusing at this spot, because 131 does split right or left around a traffic island off the edge of Route 1. If you split right, you're pointed west toward Waldoboro; if you split left, you're pointed east toward Thomaston.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Midcoast+road+runs+from+fresh+water+to+salt+water&amp;author=Brian+Swartz+Advertising+Staff+Editor&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-06-16&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: You literally run out of road in Port Clyde.
There are places in Maine, like Oquossoc over in Franklin County, where a numbered road runs into the water. Depending upon your point of view, Route 4 either starts or stops at Haines Landing in Oquossoc Village. If it does stop there, and you don't apply your brakes in time, you could wind up floating in Mooselookmeguntic Lake.
The same problem occurs with Route 131, a rural highway that runs through Waldo and Knox counties. This road reaches water at both ends, however, and on a rainy day, no one should drive 131 with poor brakes.
The road starts in Swanville, a town in northern Waldo County. West of "downtown" Swanville, Route 141 spins off Route 131 where a traffic triangle stands near a large white farmhouse. It's here where a motorist traveling north on 131 with bad brakes could slip through the intersection and land in Swan Lake.
From its northern terminus, 131 dashes west past the Swanville Elementary School on the left and the Swanville Community Church on the right. Just beyond the church lies the Greenlawn Cemetery. Route 131 soon vaults across the Frankfort Road before hanging a left at Nickerson Mills.
Only 5 1/2 miles from Swanville, the highway crosses the tracks beside Waldo Station. Beyond the tracks, 131 passes a few houses and scattered barns. At the 6 1/2-mile point, there's a big gravel pit (called "The Pit") on the left.
At 7.3 miles, Route 131 crosses Route 7. At 8 1/2 miles, you will pass the Waldo Little League field on the right. In late summer, and despite the light rain, corn stands tall in a field beyond the diamond.
As 131 continues across the backside of rural Waldo County, it reaches the blinking red light located at the intersection with Route 137. Here, 9.6 miles from Swanville, you've got to stop and look both ways.
Past Route 137, 131 heads downhill into thick woods. Dutton's Greenhouse Nursery lies along both sides of the road at 11.4 miles from Swanville.
At 12.2 miles, Route 131 runs through downtown Morrill. There's the post office on the left; just beyond stand the Morrill Fire Station, an Irving gas station, and Honesty Grange No. 83. The last-named structure, a big white building with a steel-girder fire escape, stands on the right, a short distance from a cemetery and the Morrill Baptist Church, which are located on opposite sides of the road.
Then it's back into the woods.
The only excitement for the next few miles is watching the cracks in the pavement. There is little sign of human habitation until Mile 15.5, when 131 passes the white highway marker for Belmont.
Now you're apparently nearing civilization again. There are some modern homes, then a sudden stop at the Route 3 intersection and a quick peek at the Belmont Fire Station. Route 131 slides right for a short distance on Route 3, then dips left at Mile 16.2.
The road's headed for Searsmont, whose line marker stands at Mile 17.6. The drizzle intensifies on this gloomy afternoon.
Route 131 intersects with Route 173 at the 19.5-mile mark, above downtown Searsmont. At 20.1 miles, 131 crosses the St. George River by Sprowl Brothers Inc. Then it's past the Searsmont United Methodist Church and the Fraternity Village General Store and a sign that warns, "Narrow bridge."
The bridge isn't a problem to navigate. Below Searsmont, Route 131 follows a basically straight course through Appleton to an intersection with Route 17 in Union. Route 17 connects Rockland with Augusta; by now, once you've crossed the Searsmont-Appleton town line, you are entering Knox County.
Route 131 follows Route 17 a short distance eastward before spinning off across from the Barrett Hill Road and moving into South Union. The road goes into Warren where the town line bisects the high ground between Seven Tree and Crawford ponds, neither really visible from the highway.
At 40.0 miles, Route 131 hangs a 90-left left just above downtown Warren. You'll notice the Frank D. Rowe School on the left, but pay attention: There's a "stop-stop-stop" indicator just beyond the school at the intersection with Route 90.
Across 90, at Mile 40.1, Route 131 passes the Crowe Rope Co. on the left. The Oyster River Trap Co. stands on the right at 41.2 miles. There are a few other businesses along the portion of Route 131 that cuts across Warren; perhaps the most unusual is a Saab dealership located some distance from any population centers.
At 43.9 miles, Route 131 intersects with Route 1 in Thomaston. It's very confusing at this spot, because 131 does split right or left around a traffic island off the edge of Route 1. If you split right, you're pointed west toward Waldoboro; if you split left, you're pointed east toward Thomaston.
Split left.
The speed limit along Route 1 drops to 30 miles per hour at Mile 44.2 from Swanville. You should slow down, because you're passing the State Police Barracks (Troop D) and the Thomaston State Penitentiary on the right.
Don't stop for hitchhikers here.
Downtown Thomaston encompasses about one square block of businesses like the Corner Gift Shop, Thomaston Miniature Works, People's Heritage Bank, the Hairloft, McDonald's Drug Store, Thomaston Book & Prints, and the Thomaston Cafe and Bakery. Even today, with the torrential downpour splattering on the pavement, people are moving on the sidewalks.
At Mile 45.3, Routes 1 and 131 pass the Thomaston Public Library on the right. Just 0.4 miles farther east, 131 turns right at Montpelier and starts the run toard Port Clyde.
At Mile 47.1, the Riverside Variety stands on the right side of Route 131 on the northern edge of South Thomaston. Below the store, open fields lead downhill to the St. George River, by now tidal.
At Mile 49.0, you will pass Monika's Bed & Breakfast on the right. Not far past this establishment are metal tepees and Indian figurines, crafted by an as-yet unidentified sculptor.
Route 131 crosses into St. George at Mile 49.4. At the 50-mile mark stands the metal artwork produced by the Open Air Gallery, which obviously provided the Indian settlement located upriver. Pay particular attention to the metal figures of St. George fighting his dragon.
You will start rolling through downtown St. George at Mile 51.0. A tenth of a mile beyond lies the turnoff to Route 73 on the left. This is a back way into Rockland.
At 55.1 miles, you're nearing the water. There's a lobster pound on the left here, and on a day like today, with the rain-laden, on-shore wind, you can smell the ocean.
Also at 55.1 miles, there stands a sign bidding you a "Welcome to Tenants Harbor." St. George is several villages (St. George, Tenants Harbor, Martinsville, and Port Clyde) rolled into one convenient government.
You will pass a Gulf sign on the left. At 55.8 miles, the road takes a sharp, 90-degree lefthand turn just above the Golden Hand Gift Shop (on the left) and the Churchill Bed & Breakfast. A big cemetery rims 131 on the left, too.
At Mile 57.6, a sign says, "Welcome Martinsville: Come Again." Route 131 crosses an S-bend inlet (from right to left into Mosquito Harbor) at 58.2 miles from Swanville. A peculiar stone building stands back from the road at Mile 58.9. At Mile 59.1 is the turnoff to Drift-In Beach, a spot that locals would just as soon not advertise.
You crest a hill at Mile 59.8; below you lies the sea. You've reached Port Clyde, literally the end of the trail, with the Black Harpoon on the left and Genesis and Doolittle Country Gifts on the right. Beyond lie Port Clyde Pottery and the post office with its three parking spaces.
When you crest the hill by Gallery By The Sea, you will enjoy a lovely view of the working harbor. Now, you can either turn right and drive past the Port Clyde General Store, or you can plunge straight ahead and into Port Clyde Harbor.
Either way, Route 131 ends beside Monhegan Boats at Mile 60.2.
Illustration Caption: Route 131, a north-south highway along the spine of the Midcoast, runs from Swanville to the sea. The road runs through rural Waldo and Knox counties, cuts through downtown Thomaston (left) and ends at Monhegan Boat in Port Clyde (right), a village in St. George. (NEWS Photos by Brian Swartz)

Lubec pupils' study may win award

Author: Paul Sylvain Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]04 June 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413727308?accountid=10457

Abstract: [Rose Binder] recently noted that, along the way, the pupils developed an interest in local shellfish stocks and initiated a population study of clams in South Lubec. "They have contacted municipal officials to try to develop a management plan for the flats," Binder said, adding that programs undertaken by the pupils as part of the study "have become an integral part of the math and science curriculum in the Middle School."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lubec+pupils%27+study+may+win+award&amp;author=Paul+Sylvain+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-06-04&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: LUBEC -- A water quality study of Johnson's Bay and Lubec Narrows begun last year by Lubec Middle School pupils has been selected by Anheuser-Busch as a finalist for its annual "Pledge and a Promise" environmental award.
The project grew from a proposal submitted by Lubec Middle School teachers Marty Mahar and Rose Binder. The study, which combined math and science classes in scientific studies of local water quality, involved all sixth-, seventh- and eighth-graders at the school.
In conducting the study, pupils gathered data through various tests, and developed theories about the effects of human habitation on coastal ecology in the Lubec area. The project included controlled experiments conducted by the pupils to either prove or disprove their theories.
Binder recently noted that, along the way, the pupils developed an interest in local shellfish stocks and initiated a population study of clams in South Lubec. "They have contacted municipal officials to try to develop a management plan for the flats," Binder said, adding that programs undertaken by the pupils as part of the study "have become an integral part of the math and science curriculum in the Middle School."
Funding included a $12,000 grant from the GTE Foundation's Growth Initiatives for Teachers Program. With only 330 students, the Lubec school was the smallest of about 60 schools nationwide to receive a GTE award last year. About 90 pupils were involved in the study.
Anheuser-Busch presents its Pledge and a Promise environmental award in recognition of school groups making lasting contributions to the environment, Binda said. Binda along with Bethany Murray, a seventh-grader at the school, will be flown to Tampa, Fla., where they will represent Lubec on June 8 as an award finalist at ceremonies to be aired 8 p.m. on CBS.

Deputy sheriff receives department's top award Veteran officer's satisfaction is `helping people'

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413801909?accountid=10457
