George Openshaw was awarded a general commendation for several years of police service as a range officer; Deputy Sidney Hughes was promoted to the rank of sergeant; awards were given to outstanding civilians Shirley Anthony of East Machias, Anne Pike of Lubec, Jerry Hatch of Whiting, and Dean and Jane McGray of Addison; and certificates of appreciation for their work at the Washington County Jail were given to head cook Amy Wood and assistant cook Marilyn Fritz.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Deputy+sheriff+receives+department%27s+top+award+Veteran+officer%27s+satisfaction+is+%60helping+people%27&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-05-31&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: MACHIAS -- Deputy Sheriff John W. Farnsworth, recently chosen 1993 Deputy Sheriff of the Year by the Washington County Sheriff's Department, knows what he likes about his job.
"I get great satisfaction in helping people," he said. As a law-enforcement officer, Farnsworth said his basic approach includes having a positive attitude and respect toward people in general.
A 49-year-old native of Addison, Farnsworth was given the department's highest award by Sheriff John B. Crowley at the annual awards ceremony on Thursday, May 26, at Helen's Restaurant in Machias.
Crowley said Farnsworth responded to more than 300 complaints. The amount exceeded the number of responses made by any deputy last year.
The award recipient has worked as a part-time deputy since September 1987, when he was appointed by the then-Sheriff Harold Prescott. His career in law enforcement started more than 10 years ago, when he was chosen constable for the Addison area.
Farnsworth also has worked as a shellfish-conservation warden for Addison; a shellfish warden for Milbridge; and he was employed by Hall's Security Services at the U.S. Air Force Radar Communications Center at Columbia Falls.
As one of about 60 deputies, his primary assignment includes investigations of burglaries, thefts and domestic complaints.
Other awards were presented by Crowley. They included: 1993 Rookie of the Year, to Michael Crabtree, a contract deputy for Lubec; Corrections Officer of the Year for the Washington County Jail, Sgt. Judy Worcester; Dispatcher of the Year for the Washington County Regional Communications Center, John Hennessey.
Reserve Deputy Sheriff Sherrill Colford Jr. received the Leigon of Honor for Injury in the Line of Duty.
Commendations for job performance and dedication were awarded to Rodney L. Merritt, Danny Bunker, Frederick Moore III, Sidney Bridges, Luther Choate and Harvey Childs.
George Openshaw was awarded a general commendation for several years of police service as a range officer; Deputy Sidney Hughes was promoted to the rank of sergeant; awards were given to outstanding civilians Shirley Anthony of East Machias, Anne Pike of Lubec, Jerry Hatch of Whiting, and Dean and Jane McGray of Addison; and certificates of appreciation for their work at the Washington County Jail were given to head cook Amy Wood and assistant cook Marilyn Fritz.

Consumer group pushes for required warning on shellfish

Author: Andrea Foster States News Service

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]26 May 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413803132?accountid=10457

Abstract: Why label shellfish harvested from the Gulf of Maine, for example, when the disease-causing organism is found only in southern waters, [Lee Weddig] asked. He also said only oysters, clams and mussels can be infested with the bacteria. According to Public Voice, people most at risk of contracting Vibro vulnificus are those suffering from alcoholism, liver disease, cancer, diabetes, kidney disease, AIDS and intestinal disease. Pregnant women and the elderly also should not eat raw or partially cooked shellfish, [Mark Epstein] said.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Consumer+group+pushes+for+required+warning+on+shellfish&amp;author=Andrea+Foster+States+News+Service&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-05-26&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: WASHINGTON -- A consumer group on Wednesday pushed for the Food and Drug Administration to require stores and restaurants to carry warnings that raw shellfish can kill.
Public Voice for Food and Health Policy said at least 13 people have died since 1992 from eating raw shellfish containing Vibrio vulnificus. The organism occurs naturally in coastal waters, especially in the Gulf of Mexico during the summer.
"While raw shellfish can be a delicious appetizer, for the elderly, those with liver disease, and those with immune system disorders such as AIDS, it can also be a game of seafood roulette," Public Voice President Mark Epstein said.
But the National Restaurant Association and the National Fisheries Institute oppose the warning. Only medical professionals are prepared to educate consumers about the dangers of eating raw or undercooked shellfish, the groups said.
"It's too sweeping and too dire," said Lee Weddig, executive vice president of the Institute. The group represents 1,000 seafood companies, including 30 from Maine.
Why label shellfish harvested from the Gulf of Maine, for example, when the disease-causing organism is found only in southern waters, Weddig asked. He also said only oysters, clams and mussels can be infested with the bacteria.
Weddig said it makes more sense to have individual states decide whether to have warning labels for shellfish. Presently, California, Florida and Louisiana require these notices.
According to Public Voice, people most at risk of contracting Vibro vulnificus are those suffering from alcoholism, liver disease, cancer, diabetes, kidney disease, AIDS and intestinal disease. Pregnant women and the elderly also should not eat raw or partially cooked shellfish, Epstein said.
He accused the FDA of dragging its feet in requiring the warning labels. Public Voice has been pushing for the warning for two years.
"How many more deaths will it take before the FDA acts to protect these vulnerable consumers?" Epstein asked. Brad Stone, an FDA spokesman, said the agency is considering the proposal.

Company / organization: Name: Food & Drug Administration; NAICS: 922190; SIC: 9400; DUNS: 13-818-2175

Aquaculture lacks federal support Cohen says marine harvest programs need more government attention

Author: John S. Day Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]19 May 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413888399?accountid=10457

Abstract: According to [William S. Cohen], farmed salmon was Maine's second-largest selling aquaculture product in 1993, trailing only lobster. In addition to salmon, state fish farmers are producing trout, mussels and oysters, as well as a type of seaweed popular in Japan for use in sushi dishes. About one-third of all fish farming done in the Northeast is located in Maine. Most of the state's industry is found in Washington County, which experiences chronic high unemployment, Cohen noted.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Aquaculture+lacks+federal+support+Cohen+says+marine+harvest+programs+need+more+government+attention&amp;author=John+S.+Day+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-05-19&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: WASHINGTON -- During the 1992 presidential campaign, Ross Perot often pointed out that the U.S. Department of Agriculture was so over-staffed it had approximately one federal bureaucrat overseeing each American farm.
Sen. William S. Cohen recently discovered that the department, the federal government's third-largest agency with about 113,000 civil service employees, currently assigns just a single full-time worker to assist in the development of aquaculture programs, one of the fastest-growing of Maine's resource industries.
The federal government, Cohen decided, should pay more attention to harvesting the produce of lakes, rivers and seas. The Maine senator introduced legislation Wednesday that would create a national policy for fish farming. Among other things, it would provide the state's emerging aquaculture companies equal footing with other farms for federal assistance programs.
"As health-conscious people continue to demand more and more seafood products, fish farming will rise in importance," Cohen said. "The United States, despite having vast ocean access and technical know-how, ranks only 10th in the world in terms of aquaculture production."
The Maine senator said that lack of support by federal agencies may have contributed to the industry's "poor performance."
Cohen's bill would direct the Department of Agriculture to increase its focus on fish farming by improving technology data collection, expanding disaster and loan assistance programs and improving education programs about the industry.
The legislation could boost Maine's small but emerging aquaculture industry, the senator said. That industry currently generates sales of about $45 million annually. An estimated 500 full-time workers are employed by 30 aquaculture companies.
According to Cohen, farmed salmon was Maine's second-largest selling aquaculture product in 1993, trailing only lobster. In addition to salmon, state fish farmers are producing trout, mussels and oysters, as well as a type of seaweed popular in Japan for use in sushi dishes. About one-third of all fish farming done in the Northeast is located in Maine. Most of the state's industry is found in Washington County, which experiences chronic high unemployment, Cohen noted.
"Maine's aquaculture industry is relatively new, but it is expanding rapidly," the Maine senator said.

Company / organization: Name: Department of Agriculture; NAICS: 926140; DUNS: 14-383-5429

FDA cautious on flats Resuming harvest not 1st on list

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]18 May 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413808628?accountid=10457

Abstract: One area he foresees checking is Eggemoggin Reach, where flats from west of the Deer Isle-Sedgwick bridge to Cape Rosier remain closed. Having been contacted by private landowners in the Weir Cove area of Brooksville who are interested in a reopening, [Paul Anderson] expects the removal of overboard discharges there, and in nearby Orcutt Harbor and Horseshoe Cove. Last year's reopening of clam flats at the Salt Pond bordered by Blue Hill, Brooklin and Sedgwick has renewed harvesters' access to a significant resource. Other areas reopened in the past year include Crockett Cove in Stonington.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=FDA+cautious+on+flats+Resuming+harvest+not+1st+on+list&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-05-18&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: LAMOINE -- A state marine biologist says increasing scrutiny by the federal government inadvertently could render reopening of closed shellfish areas in Hancock County a lower priority.
Paul Anderson of the Department of Marine Resources says it is becoming increasingly difficult to focus on the reopening of harvesting areas, closed primarily due to water-quality problems. The federal Food and Drug Administration has begun to look more closely at areas the DMR already has reopened, seeking justification for the choices and assurance that shellfish from those areas will be safe for consumers.
The paperwork involved in documenting reopenings has drawn resources away from opening more areas, said Anderson. In his five years on the job, it seems every year the FDA adds an extra layer of requirements, he said. "The FDA is really cautious about this program. They don't want anyone getting sick," he said.
Although the biologist said he will continue to direct reopenings where feasible and warranted, the department may have to respond more slowly to requests.
One area he foresees checking is Eggemoggin Reach, where flats from west of the Deer Isle-Sedgwick bridge to Cape Rosier remain closed. Having been contacted by private landowners in the Weir Cove area of Brooksville who are interested in a reopening, Anderson expects the removal of overboard discharges there, and in nearby Orcutt Harbor and Horseshoe Cove.
Removal of the discharges could result in the reopening of harvesting areas along the Reach.
The town of Sedgwick is interested in reinspection of a closed area above Bagaduce Falls. Anderson said testing at a water-quality station there suggests the water still may be compromised, but the DMR will check the area on its next trip to Sedgwick.
Last year's reopening of clam flats at the Salt Pond bordered by Blue Hill, Brooklin and Sedgwick has renewed harvesters' access to a significant resource. Other areas reopened in the past year include Crockett Cove in Stonington.

Company / organization: Name: Food & Drug Administration--FDA; NAICS: 922190

Precursor on dioxin rules

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]14 May 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413783858?accountid=10457

Abstract: A summary of the draft report on dioxin, leaked last week to The New York Times, confirmed what environmentalists had warned for more than a year: that an in-depth look at this toxin would produce evidence of health risks more severe than what was commonly assumed. Dioxin is a byproduct of incineration, wood and coal-burning and industrial processes that use chlorine. Trace amounts are found in dairy products, meats, fish and shellfish. Animals at the top of the food chain generally have the highest concentrations. The EPA draft -- a final report is expected early next year -- offers evidence that dioxin may cause an increase in some types of cancers, could bring on reproductive and development problems and suppress immune systems.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Precursor+on+dioxin+rules&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-05-14&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: It is too soon to conclude that the word spilling from the Environmental Protection Agency about the effects of dioxin means tougher standards for producers of the toxin. But the draft of the EPA's long-awaited report should allow paper companies and other firms to prepare for what is likely to come.
A summary of the draft report on dioxin, leaked last week to The New York Times, confirmed what environmentalists had warned for more than a year: that an in-depth look at this toxin would produce evidence of health risks more severe than what was commonly assumed. Dioxin is a byproduct of incineration, wood and coal-burning and industrial processes that use chlorine. Trace amounts are found in dairy products, meats, fish and shellfish. Animals at the top of the food chain generally have the highest concentrations. The EPA draft -- a final report is expected early next year -- offers evidence that dioxin may cause an increase in some types of cancers, could bring on reproductive and development problems and suppress immune systems.
The research that went into these finding has yet to be reviewed by experts outside the agency and some debate has emerged among government agenices about details of the study, but the overall results of several years of gathering data point to tighter restrictions on the use of chlorine.
Arguing, as industry has, that it has already lowered chlorine use and dioxin production will not be persuasive if the EPA's findings hold up. The effort to reduce the level of dioxin in the environment mirrors a similar battle to remove lead. From gasoline to paint to solder for pipes, new sources of lead have been largely eliminated, to the benefit of children across the country.
Maine researchers found surprisingly high levels of dioxin in lobster caught off the coast last summer, leading to the warning that nursing mothers, pregnant women and women of child-bearing age should avoid eating lobster tomalley, which serves as the lobster's liver. The warning was a striking reminder that, although health, human and environmental, is the primary concern in these studies, economics -- in this case, fishing and tourist industries -- also are at risk.
A source-by-source elimination of dioxin could well follow the EPA report. Industries that produce dioxin as a byproduct, even in minute quantities, can either wait for state and federal regulations to hit them with sudden added costs or start gearing up now to be competitive without the use of chlorine.
They would be smart to start now.

Company / organization: Name: Environmental Protection Agency; NAICS: 924110; SIC: 9500; DUNS: 05-794-4910

____________________________________________________________

King novel stands tall on TV

Author: Dale McGarrigle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]07 May 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413751257?accountid=10457

Abstract: The opening two hours track what happens when a killer germ escapes from an Army base and decimates much of the population of the United States. The handful of survivors divide into two camps, based on the visions they receive, either that of the good Mother Abigail (played by Ruby Dee) or of the evil Randall Flagg (portrayed by Jamey Sheridan). The spread of the illness and end of civilization are graphically portrayed and visually riveting. Still the strong cast makes it an enjoyable ride. Standout performances include Sheridan as Randall Flagg, Gary Sinise as Stu Redman, the leader of the forces of good; Dee as Mother Abigail and Rob Lowe as silent, but strong, deaf-mute Nick Andros.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=King+novel+stands+tall+on+TV&amp;author=Dale+McGarrigle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-05-07&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: "The Stand" has finally found the proper video medium in which to flourish.
At 1,153 pages, Stephen King's epic adventure has too much going on to be condensed down into a two- or three-hour movie. ABC's eight-hour miniseries, airing at 9 p.m. Sunday, Monday, Wednesday and Thursday, is closer to the needed length, although it does drag in places and seem overly long.
Still, the miniseries delivers plenty of suspense and special effects, the visual equivalent of one of King's page-turner novels.
The opening two hours track what happens when a killer germ escapes from an Army base and decimates much of the population of the United States. The handful of survivors divide into two camps, based on the visions they receive, either that of the good Mother Abigail (played by Ruby Dee) or of the evil Randall Flagg (portrayed by Jamey Sheridan). The spread of the illness and end of civilization are graphically portrayed and visually riveting.
In the following two installments, King's morality play continues with the two sides traveling either to Boulder (the site of good) or Las Vegas (the home of evil, naturally), as God and Satan struggle for their souls.
The whole production takes a healthy suspension of disbelief, especially the climactic scene.
But still the strong cast makes it an enjoyable ride. Standout performances include Sheridan as Randall Flagg, Gary Sinise as Stu Redman, the leader of the forces of good; Dee as Mother Abigail and Rob Lowe as silent, but strong, deaf-mute Nick Andros.
The supporting cast delivers other strong performances, especially Matt Frewer as the psychotic Trash-Can Man, Adam Storke as musician Larry Underwood and Ray Walston as retired professor Glen Bateman.
Lowe's fellow former Brat Packer, Molly Ringwald, doesn't fare as well, as Redman's sniveling love interest, Fran Goldsmith. Also, some of the supporting forces of evil, including Corin Nemec's Harold Lauder and Shawnee Smith's Julie Lawry, don't seem as well developed as the good guys.
Despite being on the small screen, "The Stand" comes through with sweeping tableaus, both of destruction and nature. The $28 million budget shows up on screen. The production is also enhanced by the music, such as Blue Oyster Cult's "Don't Fear the Reaper" over the opening credits.
So while "The Stand" won't take a place among the great miniseries of all time, it's among the best network productions in the past several years.
Illustration Caption: Rob Lowe (front) in "The Stand."

People: Lowe, Rob

Rigid shellfish rules a surprise to dealers

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]07 May 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413717185?accountid=10457

Abstract: PORTLAND (AP) -- Some Maine shellfish dealers say they'll have to raise their prices or pay clam diggers less to compensate for the expense of strict sanitation guidelines being enforced this spring. Because their operations do not comply with the rules, two-thirds of the dealers have yet to secure licenses they need to sell clams, oysters and mussels. As a result, they risk fines, prosecution and seizure of shellfish they continue to sell.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Rigid+shellfish+rules+a+surprise+to+dealers&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-05-07&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PORTLAND (AP) -- Some Maine shellfish dealers say they'll have to raise their prices or pay clam diggers less to compensate for the expense of strict sanitation guidelines being enforced this spring.
The guidelines apparently caught many of Maine's 126 shellfish dealers off-guard.
Because their operations do not comply with the rules, two-thirds of the dealers have yet to secure licenses they need to sell clams, oysters and mussels. As a result, they risk fines, prosecution and seizure of shellfish they continue to sell.
William J. Brennan, commissioner of the state Department of Marine Resources, said Maine has no choice but to comply with the standards developed by an interstate commission.
Failure to do so, he said, could lead other states to clamp an embargo on Maine shellfish, endangering the $12.3 million-a-year industry.
"There may be elements of the plan that are too strident from a producer's perspective," said Brennan. "But the bottom line is these are standards we must adhere to, to engage in interstate commerce."
Brennan said most dealers are working to bring their operations into compliance, but he acknowledged that some may not be able to survive. As of Thursday morning, about 40 had been certified, a DMR official said.
The guidelines, which are being strictly enforced for the first time, are intended to meet consumer concerns about shellfish safety.

People: Brennan, William J Jr

Stonington seeks to make airport user-friendly

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]05 May 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413818948?accountid=10457

Abstract: Although the airport is used by only a minority of residents, the town would rely on it for emergency transport were the Deer Isle-Stonington bridge to become unusable even temporarily, [Roger Stone] said.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Stonington+seeks+to+make+airport+user-friendly&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-05-05&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: STONINGTON -- Town manager Roger Stone hopes anticipated improvements will make the municipal airport more aircraft-friendly.
The town is seeking funds from the Maine Department of Transportation for regrading and paving at the facility. Agency spokesman Ron Ray said this week that the project appears viable, and could be funded this summer once the formal application process is complete.
According to Town Manager Stone, many aircraft owners fear using the airport because debris from the dirt runway can damage airplane propellers. He estimated the improvement project would cost a maximum of $160,000, with the state funding up to 90 percent and airport users the rest.
One of 37 municipal airports in the state, the facility built in the 1950s is used primarily by businesses transporting items such as shellfish products and by individual aircraft owners.
Although the airport is used by only a minority of residents, the town would rely on it for emergency transport were the Deer Isle-Stonington bridge to become unusable even temporarily, Stone said.

People: Stone, Roger J

Is Velpar the villain some believe it to be?

Author: Beal, Brian F

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]05 May 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413736510?accountid=10457

Abstract: When administered to mice and rats it is rapidly absorbed and does not ____________________________________________________________________ ________accumulate preferentially in any tissue. Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Is+Velpar+the+villain+some+believe+it+to+be%3F&amp;author=Beal%2C+Brian+F&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-05-05&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: I am a shellfish biologist and ecologist as well as a former clam digger from Jonesport who has a serious concern about the health of the clamming industry in eastern Maine. Clamming is a traditional form of employment among coastal communities, especially in Washington and Hancock counties where, historically, between 45 to 75 percent of all clams in Maine are harvested.
According to statistics provided by the Maine Department of Marine Resources, during the period between 1984 and 1992, clam landings in these two counties declined by approximately 90 percent. Landings in Knox and Waldo counties also declined by about 82 percent during this same period. Curiously, clam landings in the four southwestern coastal counties rose by 20 percent.
My goal is to keep shouting loud enough so that someday people will know ____________________________________________________________________ __________and understand that a clam flat can be, with proper management and stewardship, ____________________________________________________________________ ____________to a coastal community like Jonesport what Georgia-Pacific is to the town of ____________________________________________________________________ __________Woodland: an economic boon. ______________________________ As a scientist, I wonder what the difference is between southern Maine and eastern Maine when it comes to natural clam abundance. What I know is that there are relatively few seed clams (individuals less than a year old or one inch) in eastern Maine where I have conducted research since 1984, compared with areas south of the St. Georges River. As a student at the University of Maine at Machias from 1975 to 1979, I assisted Dr. John Commito with studies of clam populations in flats in Lubec, Jonesboro, and Harrington. Why is there no comparison between numbers of seed occurring on flats then and now?
What is so different about eastern vs. southwestern coastal Maine besides the obvious differences in geography, seasonal water temperatures, riverine inputs, and perhaps geology? One fact is that flats Down East are not managed nearly as carefully as flats in the southern areas.
Good management does not come from luck, it costs, and since more public funds are available in Cumberland vs. Washington county, southwest coastal clam management programs are decades ahead of most feeble attempts here in eastern Maine. Can management alone explain the disparity? I estimate that since 1984, approximately 1,800 full-time and part-time jobs have been lost in Washington and Hancock counties due to the loss of the clamming industry. Each year fewer and fewer persons harvest clams in eastern Maine and still the clams do not seem to rebound, yet clammers in the southwestern counties fight each other for licenses because the resource is so abundant.
Apparently differences in harvesting intensity do little to help explain ____________________________________________________________________ __________the situation. Clammers in eastern Maine have a variety of explanations for the ____________________________________________________________________ ____________decline that vary from natural cycles, increased levels of worm digging, the ____________________________________________________________________ _________two-inch clam law, and now, Velpar. ______________________________________ I was quoted in a BDN article by Ned Porter (April 13) that focused attention on trace amounts of the herbicide Velpar (also known as hexazinone) showing up in wells near some blueberry fields as well as several Down East rivers near and dear to the hearts of salmon fishermen. I mentioned the fact that Velpar was first licensed for use on Maine's blueberry fields in 1984 which is when clam landings began to decline. This may be coincidental, or a spurious correlation. The fact is that no one really knows what happens to this herbicide when it enters the marine environment. We do know from the published literature that hexazinone is considered to have low toxicity to animals.
When administered to mice and rats it is rapidly absorbed and does not ____________________________________________________________________ ________accumulate preferentially in any tissue. Exposures at concentrations of 2,500 ____________________________________________________________________ __________to 5,000 ppm did not cause development abnormalities or mutagenic effects. ____________________________________________________________________ _______Short-term exposure studies in several species of fish, including juvenile ____________________________________________________________________ _______Pacific salmonids, indicated that levels maintained between 300-400 ppm would ____________________________________________________________________ __________usually kill 50 percent of the subjects within 96 hours. These levels are 1,000 ____________________________________________________________________ ____________times higher than those that have shown up in wells or in river water. ____________________________________________________________________ _____ Hexazinone is effective against some species of algae. A 1977 laboratory ____________________________________________________________________ _________study concluded that two to three weeks of exposure to concentrations of 1 ppm ____________________________________________________________________ ___________was sufficient to kill some species of macro- and microalgae. Because nobody ____________________________________________________________________ _________knows specifically what the level concentrations of hexazinone are for either ____________________________________________________________________ __________adult or larval clams, as a scientist, I think it should be investigated. ____________________________________________________________________
________ Because many clam flats in eastern Maine occur
adjacent to blueberry ____________________________________________________________________ ______fields, or are at the mouths of rivers that drain blueberry barrens, I think ____________________________________________________________________ _________that we owe it to ourselves and the clamming industry (or what passes for it ____________________________________________________________________ _________now) to investigate such things as microalgal densities, clam reproductive ____________________________________________________________________ _______output, and clam recruitment (the development stage of going from a swimming ____________________________________________________________________ _________larvae to a bottom dweller) in these and other areas. ________________________________________________________ Only through the use of carefully designed, unbiased, and well-replicated studies can we ever hope to pass judgment on whether Velpar (or any other chemical) plays a role in influencing the distribution and abundance of soft-shell clams. Until such time when critical and rigorous research is funded and carried out, we can only continue to speculate about the truth. This is neither productive nor satisfying and will never lead to unambiguous conclusions. Brian F. Beal is an assistant professor of marine ecology at the University of Maine at Machias.

Lab gives students fins-on experience Unity College aquaculture program benefits from new facility

Author: Walter Griffin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]30 Apr 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413710835?accountid=10457

Abstract: Dr. Jim Chacko, head of Unity College's aquaculture program, says the college's new teaching facility will enable it to train more graduates to work in one of the state's fastest growing industries. Chacko explained that the aquaculture industry supported the program with grants and by offering students intern positions at fish farms and hatcheries. Dr. Jim Chacko, aquaculture professor at Unity College, views specimens at the college's recently opened $100,000 aquaculture laboratory and teaching facility. (NEWS Photo by Walter Griffin)

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lab+gives+students+fins-on+experience+Unity+College+aquaculture+program+benefits+from+new+facility&amp;author=Walter+Griffin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-04-30&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: UNITY -- Dr. Jim Chacko, head of Unity College's aquaculture program, says the college's new teaching facility will enable it to train more graduates to work in one of the state's fastest growing industries.
The most interesting part of the facility, which opened this month, is the wet laboratory which houses tanks where students are exposed to raising fish under different conditions.
"It's a totally enclosed system," Chacko said this week. "Everything is recycled and recirculated. No new water gets added to the tanks. The whole idea is to give the students hands-on training. When they get out of here they won't have any problems. No culture shocks."
The wet laboratory replicates both fresh and salt water environments. Atlantic salmon and brook trout swim together in the large tanks, providing students with the opportunity to study fish up close.
"This is undergraduate education at its best with hands-on experience," Chacko said. "They handle the fish, they feed the fish. It the fish dies, they get a poor grade...just kidding."
Chacko is also a certified fish pathologist and is known to students as "Fish Quincy," a comparison to the television series about a crime-solving medical examiner. His sense of humor is evident in the layout of his department. Instead of numbered doors on the classrooms, they are labeled with fish names.
Chacko explained that the aquaculture industry supported the program with grants and by offering students intern positions at fish farms and hatcheries.
In Maine alone there are nine private hatcheries that produced 13 million pounds of salmon, steelhead or trout and employed upwards of 250 people in 1992. The state also has three shellfish farms that last year produced 1 million pounds of mussels and 1.2 million pounds of oysters and provided work for 50 residensts.
The emphasis of the Unity College program is on cold water species. "If somebody wants to come and raise catfish this is not the ideal place," he said.
The "rigorous program" is designed to handle 12 students each semester. Classes run the gamut from identifying diseases to nutrition and, most importantly, water quality.
"When you are dealing with this type of industry that is critical. If the water gets fouled, the first thing to go will be the fish," Chacko said. "We have all the basics here to run a real good undergraduate program."
Illustration Caption: Dr. Jim Chacko, aquaculture professor at Unity College, views specimens at the college's recently opened $100,000 aquaculture laboratory and teaching facility. (NEWS Photo by Walter Griffin)

People: Chacko, Jim

____________________________________________________________

Food and water are being poisoned

Author: Oden, Nancy

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]19 Apr 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413726907?accountid=10457

Abstract: Velpar isn't the worst of the poisons sprayed on our blueberries, cranberries, potatoes, apples, and other food crops in Maine. For example, the label for Guthion, which attacks the central nervous system, reads that Guthion poisoning causes, among other awful sympoms, "convulsions, low blood pressure, cardiac irregularities, loss of reflexes, coma, and, in extreme cases, death." Guthion is classified as highly hazardous to humans. Both Velapr and Guthion are sprayed from helicopters, and everyone's blueberry fields are done at once. So several times each spring and summer, we're trapped in a huge poison gas chamber, forced to breathe these known poisons: The helicopters spray Guthion, Velpar, Funginex, etc., right down to the ocean, drifting poison into clam fats and fisheries. Poisons travel down our rivers from the blueberry barrens and cranberry bogs into the coastal waters. Damage: loss of fish and shellfish for our local food supply, loss of clamming, fishing, and other marine-related jobs. Even though it's illegal, Guthion is often sprayed while honeybees are in the blueberry fields, killing them. Maine beekeepers would like to make a dollar renting bees to growers, but can't afford the losses. Spraying also kills Maine's natural pollinating insects, making us dependent on miteinfested, diseased, possibly killer bee-crossed bees coming up from the South. Damage: loss of natural pollinators, loss of honey for food, loss of beekeeper jobs.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Food+and+water+are+being+poisoned&amp;author=Oden%2C+Nancy&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-04-19&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Now that Velpar has been found in Atlantic salmon habitat, surely there's going to be an uproar. Good. It's about time, even if Atlantic salmon seem to generate more concern than human beings. I'll take it over nothing.
Regarding toxicity, the Velpar label states that DuPont Chemical Co.'s scientists:
(1) poured Velpar into rabbits' eyes and found that Velpar is corrosive to (destroys) eyes;
(2) force-fred Velpar to mice, rats, and dogs (where do they get dogs for their experiments?) until they observed "effects" and death;
(3) use Ethanol as the spraying agent in Velpar, which can cause liver, central nervous system, gastrointestinal tract, and reproductive damage.
And more. Not something I'd want in my water supply.
But Velpar isn't the worst of the poisons sprayed on our blueberries, cranberries, potatoes, apples, and other food crops in Maine. For example, the label for Guthion, which attacks the central nervous system, reads that Guthion poisoning causes, among other awful sympoms, "convulsions, low blood pressure, cardiac irregularities, loss of reflexes, coma, and, in extreme cases, death." Guthion is classified as highly hazardous to humans.
Both Velapr and Guthion are sprayed from helicopters, and everyone's blueberry fields are done at once. So several times each spring and summer, we're trapped in a huge poison gas chamber, forced to breathe these known poisons: The helicopters spray Guthion, Velpar, Funginex, etc., right down to the ocean, drifting poison into clam fats and fisheries. Poisons travel down our rivers from the blueberry barrens and cranberry bogs into the coastal waters. Damage: loss of fish and shellfish for our local food supply, loss of clamming, fishing, and other marine-related jobs.
Even though it's illegal, Guthion is often sprayed while honeybees are in the blueberry fields, killing them. Maine beekeepers would like to make a dollar renting bees to growers, but can't afford the losses. Spraying also kills Maine's natural pollinating insects, making us dependent on miteinfested, diseased, possibly killer bee-crossed bees coming up from the South. Damage: loss of natural pollinators, loss of honey for food, loss of beekeeper jobs.
Washington County's deer herd has been mysteriously disappearing for years. Some blame coyotes, but other areas have plenty of deer along with coyotes. I blame poisoned blueberries, of which deer eat many. Damage: loss of deer for local food supply, loss of hunting-related jobs.
Using pesticides and harvesting machines is killing the hand-weeding and many, many raking (harvesting) jobs. Last year, Cherryfield Foods, which is Canadian owned and the largest blueberry grower around here, brought in a dozen harvester machines from Nova Scotia to harvest their 7,000 acres, and shipped the harvested blueberries to Nova Scotia for processing. Then they bid on and won a USDA contract for 3-4 million pounds of blueberries for America's schoolchildren, all full of pesticides. Damage: health of our children, loss of weeding, raking, and local processing jobs, loss of profits to foreign country, hurting local blueberry growers and processors.
Fish in cages (salmon aquaculture) can't swim away from poisons, so they sicken, and are then medicated. These antibiotics and other medications add to the unwanted chemicals in our coastal waters, and in some cases create dead zones below salmon cages. Damage: unhealthy fish equals unhealthy food for people, greater mortality fof fish.
By poisoning coastal waters, our entire ecosystem is damaged. If there are few fish, shellfish, and other organisms, what will the shore birds, offshore birds, ducks, mammals, and reptiles eat? Damage: Collapse of food chain, loss of our food supply, loss of jobs.
The scientists have gotten us into this mess, and we, using our common sense, will have to get ourselves out of it. Looking at the world today, I've seen enough of science and technology for the moment.
Everyone, and that includes home gardeners, needs to stop using toxic chemicals. There are still traces of DDT around, for Pete's sake. We've got to give the earth and all the creatures on it, including ourselves, a chance to purge ourselves of the poisons we've been forced to ingest.
There are perfectly reasonable, common sense ways to grow food crops without poisons, and they are being done right now. Organic blueberries grown in Maine always bring at least a dollar a pound wholesale in the Portland-Boston market, which is crying for more. Sprayed blueberries brought 25 cents a pound last year and probably will bring no more this year.
People want unsprayed, organically grown food. This could be Maine's market strategy. Maine could be "The Clean One." Growers have been trading on the public's perception of Maine as "pristine," when we know it isn't true. It's past time to make the reality fit the perception.
It is unlikely "jobs" as such will come wandering into Maine. Reading the business pages one learns that industry and agriculture are becoming so chemical- and machine-dependent that jobs are scarce worldwide. What I want to know is, who will buy the products these super-efficient companies produce if so few of us have good jobs?
If we can assume we're mostly on our own to survive, and I think we are, then we should plan for more community self-sufficiency. Therefore, we citizens are going to need more control over our local natural resources: woods, waters, fields, streams, clean air and what gets dumped into all of them. We might even try something I've read about called "democracy." It's where you and I get to make the decisions that affect our lives.
No magical moneymen are going to come up here and help us; it's strictly up to us. But we have to stop the poisoning of our food supply and water or there won't be anything left to worry about.
And to those who whine that they must poison our water, air, and woods in order to create "jobs," remember this: There are no jobs on a dead planet.
Nancy Oden lives in Jonesboro.

Velpar worries shake berry industry EPA to reinvestigate data used in determining allowable safety limits

Author: Ned Porter Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]13 Apr 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413784244?accountid=10457

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Velpar+worries+shake+berry+industry+EPA+to+reinvestigate+data+used+in+determining+allowable+safety+limits&amp;author=Ned+Porter+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-04-13&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: New information that Velpar has been detected in Down East rivers has heightened concerns over the use of the herbicide that revolutionized Maine's blueberry industry.
An uproar followed reports last fall that Velpar was detected in several wells. Now comes news that very low levels of Velpar were discovered last summer in the Narraguagus River, its West Branch and the Pleasant River by researchers for the Maine Atlantic Sea Run Salmon Commission. They were looking for reasons behind the steady decline in the numbers of salmon returning to rivers Down East.
To date none of the detected levels of Velpar even approach what the U.S Environmental Protection Agency considers unsafe, but an EPA official said the agency is reinvestigating its data to determine whether to lower the limits.
Federal officials are considering whether Atlantic salmon warrant protection as an endangered species. The discovery of Velpar in salmon rivers only adds to the problems of a blueberry industry that is beginning to feel besieged.
When Velpar was found in wells in Aurora, Franklin and Gouldsboro residents around the blueberry barrens started agitating for changes to protect their drinking water. Some people in the shellfish industry also point to the use of Velpar as one reason for declining clam harvests.
"We're facing problems from many fronts, salmon, clams, the EPA, the public," said Edward J. McLaughlin, executive director of the Maine Blueberry Commission. "We seem to be getting blamed by anybody with a problem near a blueberry field.
"It's an emotional issue. All of the science in the world won't matter. People say, `I just don't want it,' " he said. "My belief is that the truth will surface somewhere along the line. My job is to keep this from hurting the industry the way Alar did the apple industry."
Five years ago, the apple industry took a beating after alarming reports that Alar, a chemical ripener, was suspected of causing cancer. The manufacturer subsequently stopped selling it.
A herbicide with the generic name hexazinone, Velpar is manufactured by DuPont Agricultural Products. The chemical controls weeds, killing them by interfering with photosynthesis. It is used by highway crews along roadsides and by farmers on alfalfa and sugarcane.
More than a dozen years ago someone noticed that blueberries came back stronger in the right of ways where hexazinone was applied. Maine blueberry growers first used it in 1983 and it is now in widespread use by the industry.
Wild blueberries are harvested in alternate years. On the fields left to vegetate, Velpar is applied in the spring with boom sprayers mounted on tractors. No license is required to buy it and no training is needed to apply it.
About 30,000 gallons a year are used, half a gallon per acre. The amount is half of what was applied during the height of its use several years ago, said David E. Yarborough, a blueberry specialist at the University of Maine. He added that use of the chemical has so reduced the growth of weeds that growers can apply less. Velpar has never been found on harvested blueberries.
Ten years ago there were 50,000 acres of blueberries. This year, with 600 growers, there will be about 58,000 acres. Fifteen years ago the harvest amounted to 20 million pounds. The annual average is now 60 million pounds.
It amounts to a $100 million industry, which provides about 1,000 jobs year round and 8,000 seasonally. Wild blueberries grow in every county of Maine except Aroostook. But more than 70 percent of the industry is in Hancock and Washington counties.
"It's been absolutely phenomenal what it's done for the industry," McLaughlin said.
A little more than 98 percent of crop is used as an ingredient in other products -- muffin mixes, chewing gum and the like. It is a bright spot in an otherwise beleagured Maine economy. McLaughlin has worked to develop markets for wild Maine blueberries as far afield as Israel.
"A large part of that can be attributed to Velpar. The biggest problem in the fields is weeds," he said. "Once we could control the weeds, we could do other things to increase production, apply feritilizer, irrigate and harvest mechanically."
However, the chemical is water soluble and readily migrates through the right kind of soils. So it turns up in the groundwater and water bodies near the fields.
The EPA currently classifies hexazinone as "practically non-toxic" to fish, water bugs and mollusks, and "slightly toxic" for crustaceans. And, for the time being, the EPA has issued a human health advisory for concentrations of 210 parts per billion.
DuPont is in the process of reregistering the chemical with the EPA. Based on new data and new analysis of existing data, the agency could lower the level to as little as 20 parts per billion. Al Heier, an EPA spokesman, said that the question is still open and that scientists are debating how likely Velpar is to cause cancer.
The herbicide is considered a severe eye irritant but is not likely to be hazardous if ingested according to a DuPont safety data sheet.
Nowhere on the Narraguagus River or its West Branch were levels of more than 1 part per billion found. Levels in some tributaries that drain the barrens ranged as high as 4.79 ppb.
The highest level in the Pleasant River, 1.53 ppb, was found at Saco Falls.
At one spot on Pork Brook Barrens, west of Route 193 and south of Route 9, the ground water tested as high as 32.51 ppb.
The concentration of hexazinone in the well for the Gouldsboro School was 6 parts per billion, for the Airline Community School in Aurora it was 8.9 ppb, and for a potential well in Franklin it was 4 ppb.
The findings raised fears and questions. After the discovery at the Airline School, officials switched to bottled drinking water until a filtration system was installed.
A meeting on the matter held by the Maine Board of Pesticide Control two months ago in Ellsworth drew more than 60 people. One person who attended the meeting was Geneva Duncan, a mother of two children who graduated from the Airline Community School.
"Can you tell me that it didn't do any harm to my children?" she said. "It hasn't killed anybody yet, but I don't feel at ease with this."
The clamming industry Down East has fallen on hard times in the last decade. People casting about for a cause see an increase in Velpar use coinciding with a decrease in the clam harvest.
"Maybe its a spurious correlation but not much else has changed, harvesting pressure or development of coastal industries," said Brian Beal, an assistant professor of marine ecology at the University of Maine at Machias. "Add it up. It begs the question, does Velpar have an effect?"
Beal wants to find out whether there are any trace amounts of the herbicide in the marine environment and whether there are differences between mud flats next to blueberry fields and those at a distance. He is seeking funding, about $75,000, for the two-year project.
Traces of Velpar started turning up in Down East rivers in 1991 after salmon officials began their investigation into the declining populations. Since then they have discovered more of the herbicide.
It is more likely that researchers got better at finding Velpar than the amount of it actually increased, said Kenneth Beland, a scientist with the commission.
"I'm not saying this has no impact. These fish are growing up in some areas of the watershed where there's a chronic background level of the chemical," he said. "We can't answer whether it's acting on a subtle level on the fish."
Nothing else is on the market that will serve the blueberry industry as well as hexazinone, Yarborough said. "There are alternative strategies. They can be more effective but would require more management and more labor."
An alternative includes cutting the weeds, which is effective against dogbane and ferns. Additionally growers can apply Velpar and other herbicides more selectively.
"Cutting down on the use of Velpar not only makes sense for the public but it can make financial sense," Yarborough said.
With the public growing increasingly wary of chemicals in the environment as well as contaminated food and water, the Maine industry is working overtime to address the problem.
"We're trying to be right up front," McLaughlin said. "We're spending about $50,000 directly and indirectly on the issue this year. We're funding research.

Full text: It's the season for academic awards in Maine, and we're saluting juniors on their 11th grade MEA test results and Maine Scholars Achievement Awards this week. Other students were involved in speaking, business and health occupation competitions.

Martin and Chancellor of the University of Maine System Michael Orenduff presented special citations to: Benjamin W. Anderson of Orono High School; Jeremy D. Dunham, Lincoln Academy; Ashley C. Aquaculture tops conference agenda

Author: Kathy Harbour Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]11 Apr 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413705159?accountid=10457

Abstract: Carter Newall of Great Eastern Mussel Farms in St. George explained how shellfish production is a good economic argument for clean water. Newall, who has played an active role in research into aquaculture, said a successful aquaculture venture must be built on sound environmental policy. Newall said that research about eelgrass has proven that the marine flowering plant is vital for many species of coastal marine life, such as juvenile fish and shellfish, particularly young mussels. That information, Newall said, demonstrates the connections between economic and environmental health.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Aquaculture+tops+conference+agenda&amp;author=Kathy+Harbour+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-04-11&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: CASTINE -- Aquaculture ventures are writing a promising chapter in the history of Maine's economic and environmental links to the sea, according to the general manager of a salmon aquaculture business on Swans Island.
Sonny Sprague of the Island Aquaculture Co. spoke Saturday at the Penobscot Bay Conference at Maine Maritime Academy. It was the second consecutive year for the conference that drew more than 100 people who considered the economic and environmental health of the region at several workshops during the day.
As a lifetime resident of a year-round island community, Sprague said the aquaculture business provides a livelihood to island residents while preserving the environmental health of the coastal waters.
Ken Curtis, president of MMA, underlined the importance of marine industries in his opening remarks. Listing Maine's three basic resources -- people, forests and the ocean -- Curtis said action must be taken to protect the sea.
Sprague explained how he and others had turned to the sea to ensure the long-term health and vitality of their year-round island community that had seen its young people leave and never return for lack of employment opportunities.
The former Swans Island selectman and a handful of others on the island in Frenchman Bay purchased the financially ailing company last year and managed to turn a profit. The bitterly cold conditions this winter spelled near disaster for the penned fish but quick processing saved the lot.
For Sprague and many others on Swans Island, aquaculture is providing a livelihood to the island community that historically has made its living from the sea.
Carter Newall of Great Eastern Mussel Farms in St. George explained how shellfish production is a good economic argument for clean water. Newall, who has played an active role in research into aquaculture, said a successful aquaculture venture must be built on sound environmental policy.
Newall said that research about eelgrass has proven that the marine flowering plant is vital for many species of coastal marine life, such as juvenile fish and shellfish, particularly young mussels. That information, Newall said, demonstrates the connections between economic and environmental health.
According to Les Watling of the University of Maine's Darling Marine Center, Penobscot Bay is home for a least 1,000 species of invertebrate animals and a perfect place for aquaculture.

People: Sprague, Sonny Newall, Carter

Prosecution seeks fines for lobster violations

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]08 Apr 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413817571?accountid=10457

Abstract: MONCTON, New Brunswick (AP) -- The prosecution is seeking precedent-setting fines and hefty license suspensions for six fishermen convicted of possessing undersized lobster and fishing lobster in a closed zone.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Prosecution+seeks+fines+for+lobster+violations&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-04-08&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: MONCTON, New Brunswick (AP) -- The prosecution is seeking precedent-setting fines and hefty license suspensions for six fishermen convicted of possessing undersized lobster and fishing lobster in a closed zone.
The six fishermen from Pointe Sapin, New Brunswick, were charged after fisheries officers injected ultraviolet ink into lobsters found in traps in a closed fishing zone and monitored where the shellfish were taken.
The fishermen are: Antoine V. Daigle, 56; Gerard Luc Daigle, 38; Eloi Robichaud, 59; Isidore Jr. Martin, 32; Jean Martin, 30; and Rene Savoie, 18.
All six were either boat captains or helpers on lobster boats.
In addition, buyer Remi Cormier, 28, of Richibucto, New Brunswick, in whose truck the poached and undersized lobsters were found, was convicted of illegal possession of lobster.
Sentencing was scheduled for April 15.
Crown prosecutor Alyre Boucher told Wednesday's sentencing hearing that past fines for identical crimes have averaged between $1,000 and $3,000, with license suspensions imposed for the first three to 10 days of the lobster season -- the most lucrative time of the season.
Boucher called the crimes major offenses by professional fishermen who ought to have known better. Worse still were prior related convictions on the part of Antoine and Gerard Daigle.

Catch tops 30-year fishery record

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]08 Apr 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413724236?accountid=10457

Abstract: Millions of pounds of fish and shellfish are brought to Maine ports each year, most caught in the Gulf of Maine and on the Georges Bank fishing ground. The amount of fish landed is a barometer of the overall well-being of the state's fishing industry.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Catch+tops+30-year+fishery+record&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-04-08&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PORTLAND (AP) -- Maine fishermen had their largest commercial fish harvest in 30 years last year, despite dwindling stocks of cod, haddock and other groundfish.
Last year's harvest peaked at 252 million pounds worth about $224.7 million -- breaking a record for revenue set in 1992.
"I would say, overall, when you look at all the pessimism bestowed on the fishing industry, this is a real eye-opener," said Robert Morrill, who compiles statistics for the National Marine Fisheries Service.
"This shows that the fishing industry hasn't rolled over and died," he said.
The decline in groundfish was compensated by strong catches of sea urchins, herring, lobster and other ocean creatures.
"The hallmark of Maine's fishery is diversification," said Penn Estabrook, deputy commissioner of the Department of Marine Resources.
Millions of pounds of fish and shellfish are brought to Maine ports each year, most caught in the Gulf of Maine and on the Georges Bank fishing ground. The amount of fish landed is a barometer of the overall well-being of the state's fishing industry.
It also shows the strength of the Portland Fish Exchange.

Waterville's ethnic menu features emu steak, alligator rib Tastes of the Colby College community influence restaurants' gourmet selections throughout Elm City

Author: Sharon Mack Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]04 Apr 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413704843?accountid=10457

Abstract: The influence of Colby College is responsible for the "flavor" of some of the restaurants, said [David Savage]. The Lebanese restaurants are an indication of the large Lebanese population in Waterville. Others restaurants simply are reflections of personal preferences, he said. One of Waterville's most unusual menus can be found at the Down Under Pub in the Concourse downtown. True to its Australian name, the Down Under offers kangaroo, emu and alligator, alongside pizza and sandwiches. For six years, owner Doug Hachey has cashed in on the Crocodile Dundee craze, offering deep-fried alligator bits, kangaroo steak, marinated emu and alligator parmesan to his most adventurous customers. The menu is exotic: shawarma (beef or chicken breast, marinated with special spices, skewered and roasted), falafel (ground chick peas, fava beans, parsley and garlic, blended and fried), hummus (chick peas blended with tahini sauce, garlic and oil), and tabbouleh (fresh parsley and tomato salad with onion, cracked wheat and oil.) And then there are the pies: sfeha with ground beef and onions, or zaatar with thyme and sesame seeds.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Waterville%27s+ethnic+menu+features+emu+steak%2C+alligator+rib+Tastes+of+the+Colby+College+community+influence+restaurants%27+gourmet+selections+throughout+Elm+City&amp;author=Sharon+Mack+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-04-04&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: If you have a craving for a Lebanese lamb kebob, head to Waterville. Or how about an emu steak or an alligator rib? For a special experience, try a dish called Seven Stars Around the Moon. Top it all off with a cup of Hawaiian coffee or some very English tea.
For a number of reasons, Waterville is fast becoming known for the variety of ethnic food available at its restaurants, pubs and gourmet shops.
"We certainly have some fabulous dining here," said David Savage, president of the Mid-Maine Chamber of Commerce. "There are a lot of fine restaurants providing some great eating experiences."
The influence of Colby College is responsible for the "flavor" of some of the restaurants, said Savage. The Lebanese restaurants are an indication of the large Lebanese population in Waterville. Others restaurants simply are reflections of personal preferences, he said.
"There really is something for everyone," said the Chamber president.
Last summer, the city held "A Greater Taste of Waterville" festival, which allowed all the local restaurants to participate. More than 1,000 people ate outdoors on tables set up in the streets, said Savage.
"It was the ultimate outdoor cafe and an incredible experience," said Savage.
One of Waterville's most unusual menus can be found at the Down Under Pub in the Concourse downtown. True to its Australian name, the Down Under offers kangaroo, emu and alligator, alongside pizza and sandwiches. For six years, owner Doug Hachey has cashed in on the Crocodile Dundee craze, offering deep-fried alligator bits, kangaroo steak, marinated emu and alligator parmesan to his most adventurous customers.
The atmophere of the pub, which is located beneath the Concourse, is very Australian: boomerangs, koalas, alligators and a shadow-box display of Australian groceries line the walls. Hachey says that most of those trying the imported delights do so for fun.
"We actually have a lot of summer camp counselors from Australia and New Zealand, however, that come in looking for a taste of home," he said.
Hachey said alligator is "a cross between pork and chicken. We use a special seasoning and deep fry the tidbits for an interesting snack."
Hachey said kangaroo and emu meat is tough, but with creative marinades and cooking methods, they can be "very nice."
The pub will soon add a nightclub, The Outback, upstairs where the Australian theme and food will continue.
Painted on the windows of Jorgensen's Main Street cafe is the motto, "A cup o' Joe is a wonderful thing," and when it is brewed at Jorgensen's, it truly is. A dozen carafes tantalize the visitor, offering a variety of hot coffee: hazelnut, French vanilla, rain forest nut. The little cafe also offers everything you need to grind, drip, brew, press, pour and enjoy coffee.
Jorgensen's has teas, in bulk and bag, from every country that has a tea bush. The cafe also offers an equally exotic variety of wines, coffees, and spices. Specialty mustards, extracts and garnishes fill the shelves. Irish cookies, English marmalade, Chinese fish sauce and Hawaiian coffee beans also entice patrons.
Recently expanded, Jorgensen's features outside tables in the summer. Inside, the booths are intimate, each with its own table lamp. Music from silent films of the 1920s fills the air.
The deli offers a wide range of international food, everything from curry chicken salad to peanut butter sandwiches. Pasta in a variety of flavors is made fresh daily to compliment the wide array of specialty cheeses and meats from around the world.
Two speciality businesses offer Lebanese fare: The Lebanese Bakery on Temple Street and Sitoo's Restaurant on Union Street.
The Lebanese Bakery makes all its creations "without modern processors, chopping it all by hand," said owner Salim Nasr. For 12 years, the bakery has been offering ethnic fare to Waterville's 300 Lebanese families.
The menu is exotic: shawarma (beef or chicken breast, marinated with special spices, skewered and roasted), falafel (ground chick peas, fava beans, parsley and garlic, blended and fried), hummus (chick peas blended with tahini sauce, garlic and oil), and tabbouleh (fresh parsley and tomato salad with onion, cracked wheat and oil.) And then there are the pies: sfeha with ground beef and onions, or zaatar with thyme and sesame seeds.
And, of course, there is the traditional Lebanese dessert, baklava.
Sitoo's, another Lebanese restaurant, also has baklava. The eating place, which has been at its location for 18 years, offers several lamb dishes, including kibbe.
"Kibbe is the Lebanese version of a meat loaf," said owner John Coro. "We use many spices, especially cinnamon and bulgur in the recipe."
The menu includes sweetbreads poached in wine and several American dishes.
All Sitoo's offerings are handmade on the premises, said Coro, except the baklava. "There is an elderly lady next door that used to own the restaurant," said Coro. "She still makes that in her kitchen, fresh every day."
And of course there are the Chinese restaurants: Mei Lam Lau in the JFK Mall, mostly Chinese offerings; Jade Island on the West River Road, specializing in Cantonese; Mei Chow in the Concourse; Triple Dragon at Elm Plaza; and Hunan Legends on Temple Street, specializing in Szechwan and Hunan style food.
At Jade Island, manager Tony Lee says his customers rave about a special dish called Seven Stars Around The Moon. The specialty consists of seven fantailed shrimp, chicken stuffed with Virginia ham, which battered and deep fried, Chinese vegetables, barbecue roast pork and rice.
At Hunan Legends, co-owner Dale Edwards said the most popular dish is General Tso's Chicken.
"It is a hot, spicy dish, prepared with chunks of lightly battered and deep fried chicken breast, with a very special sauce," said Edwards.
King Tran, owner of the Triple Dragon Chinese Restaurant said his customers' favorite is The Chef's Special, a rich combination of vegetables, beef and roast pork in oyster sauce.
Illustration Caption: Laya Joseph makes baklava at the Lebanese Bakery. (NEWS Photo by Marc Blanchette)

People: Savage, David Hachey, Doug Coro, John

Company: Sitoos Restaurant

Local man camps in order to clam

Author: (AP)

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]01 Apr 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413730944?accountid=10457

Abstract: He may have to sleep in his van, eat raw potatoes and forgo showers for a month, but Roy Banks isn't missing out on a commercial clamming license this year. Banks' monthlong wait would set a record in Scarborough. Other Maine towns have abandoned the first-come, first-served system and instead distribute shellfish licenses by lottery. CAMPED OUT in his van at the Town Hall in Scarborough, Roy Banks daydreams and watches the cars go by Thursday as he waits for April 20, when he hopes to claim one of three commercial clamming licenses that should be available. (AP Photo)

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Local+man+camps+in+order+to+clam&amp;author=%28AP%29&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-04-01&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: SCARBOROUGH -- He may have to sleep in his van, eat raw potatoes and forgo showers for a month, but Roy Banks isn't missing out on a commercial clamming license this year.
The 52-year-old Scarborough man says he'll camp in the Town Hall parking lot for a month to ensure that he will get one of the three commercial clamming licenses up for grabs this year.
Banks pulled his red van into the parking lot on March 22. He doesn't intend to leave until April 20, when the shellfish licenses will be distributed.
Banks' monthlong wait would set a record in Scarborough. Other Maine towns have abandoned the first-come, first-served system and instead distribute shellfish licenses by lottery.
Wearing a red sock hat, sweater, jeans and ski jacket, Banks said he's been "very miserable, very uncomfortable" living in his van. But, he said, "It's what you have to do."
Dick Haehnel, the town's shellfish conservation officer, said Banks is assured of getting one of the $100 licenses if he doesn't leave town property. If he leaves, he could lose his spot to other would-be clammers.
Banks said he closed down an upholstery business a year ago because he wanted a freer life, one that would allow him to spend more time outdoors.
He was too late to get a commercial license, so he settled for a recreational license. But that limited his take to one peck of clams per day. Haehnel caught him once for violating that rule.
This year, Banks wanted to make sure he didn't miss out on a commercial license.
So last week he loaded up the van with an old cot, sleeping bag, Army blankets, clean underwear and slippers. He eats raw potatoes and other vegetables and heats canned beef stew on a small butane burner.
When it's open, he goes into Town Hall to use the bathroom and take "bird baths" in the restroom sink. He exercises by walking laps around the lot. He passes time by listening to the radio and reading up on clamming.
Illustration Caption: CAMPED OUT in his van at the Town Hall in Scarborough, Roy Banks daydreams and watches the cars go by Thursday as he waits for April 20, when he hopes to claim one of three commercial clamming licenses that should be available. (AP Photo)

People: Banks, Roy

So-called pork barrel

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 Mar 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413717145?accountid=10457

Abstract: The [Rachel Carson] NWR land acquisition bill is part of an ongoing appropriation from the Land and Water Conservation Fund. Those monies comes not from taxes, but from the sale of off-shore oil leases. Congress long ago agreed that these monies should be used to fund conservation projects of national significance. And Rachel Carson NWR is of national significance. Duck hunters and bird watchers all along the Eastern flyway benefit from the conservation of these lands. Our fishing industry also benefits, as well as folks anywhere who like to eat Maine seafood because these salt marshes provide a tremendous nutrient supply that our finfish and shellfish resources require. All of these pursuits generate millions for our national as well as our local economies.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=So-called+pork+barrel&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-03-24&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: A recent article, "Lobbying group derides wasteful spending," described the Citizens Against Government Waste's 1994 list of so-called pork-barrel appropriation bills. The group accused Sen. Mitchell of playing the largest role in the passage of allegedly wasteful appropriations that benefit Maine.
The article also detailed CAGW's criteria for pork-barrel spending bills. These included items arising from only one chamber of Congress, items that greatly exceed the previous year's budget request or funding level, and items that "serve only a local interest."
I'm glad that NEWS writer John Day included CAGW's criteria list because it shows how this so-called citizen group, whose co-chair is national columnist Jack Anderson, is at best ill-informed. A brief look at some facts about just one of the eight Maine projects listed, a $2 million bill to acquire additional salt marsh estuaries at Rachel Carson National Wildlife Refuge, witnesses their inaccuracy.
The Rachel Carson NWR land acquisition bill is part of an ongoing appropriation from the Land and Water Conservation Fund. Those monies comes not from taxes, but from the sale of off-shore oil leases. Congress long ago agreed that these monies should be used to fund conservation projects of national significance. And Rachel Carson NWR is of national significance. Duck hunters and bird watchers all along the Eastern flyway benefit from the conservation of these lands. Our fishing industry also benefits, as well as folks anywhere who like to eat Maine seafood because these salt marshes provide a tremendous nutrient supply that our finfish and shellfish resources require. All of these pursuits generate millions for our national as well as our local economies.
Rachel Carson NWR has received acquisition funding every fiscal year since 1987, except for last year, when Maine's share of this national fund went to important projects at Moosehorn and Petit Manaan National Wildlife refuges and Acadia National Park. Rachel Carson NWR got zero acquisition money last year -- that's why this year's appropriation exceeds last year's.
Because of the importance of these estuaries, all members of Maine's congressional delegation for the past seven years have supported appropriations from this non-tax fund for acquisition of these special areas from willing sellers.
We in southern Maine who are aware of the importance of this project are grateful to the entire Maine delegation, including Olympia Snowe -- who we can't even vote for down here -- for their consistent support.
So who is the CAGW to tell us that this is a purely pork-barrel project designed only to increase the political capital of its sponsor? Bill Silliker Jr. Past president Friends of Rachel Carson National Wildlife Refuge Ocean Park

People: Carson, Rachel
