Clam diggers hurt in license crush 60 rush Brunswick town hall vying for 37 shellfish permits

Author: (AP)

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]22 Mar 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413773460?accountid=10457

Abstract: Some harvesters said that not getting a license will force them to dig illegally, constantly watching for the warden, in order to feed themselves and their families. Some charged that the town unfairly issued licenses to nonresidents and to part-time diggers. [Alan J. Houston] said that the town leaves the actual forming of the line to the harvesters, who have their own "code" or system of rules about how to line up. "Certainly the marine resources committee and other town officials can't go out there and hold everybody else's hand," said Houston.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Clam+diggers+hurt+in+license+crush+60+rush+Brunswick+town+hall+vying+for+37+shellfish+permits&amp;author=%28AP%29&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-03-22&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BRUNSWICK -- Several clam diggers suffered minor injuries Monday when more than 60 people rushed the doors of town hall to get 37 commercial shellfish licenses.
Two diggers were treated at Mid Coast Hospital and released, a hospital spokeswoman said.
Diggers said that the fastest runners -- many of them reportedly teen-agers -- were able to beat older diggers to the door.
In the rush, several people were knocked down, and one man broke his finger but first bought his license before going to the hospital.
Some harvesters said that not getting a license will force them to dig illegally, constantly watching for the warden, in order to feed themselves and their families. Some charged that the town unfairly issued licenses to nonresidents and to part-time diggers.
"I'm not going to be able to hold my head high much longer," said Stephen Fortin, who poached last year and plans to poach this year as well. "This is ridiculous," he said. "How does a 45-year-old man compete against a 17- or 18-year-old kid that just wants a summer job?"
Marine Resources Warden Alan J. Houston said officials followed the town's rules Monday and probably would discuss changes to them to prevent a similiar incident.
"The town ordinance here says first come, first serve. The line forms at 6:45 a.m.," said Houston.
The only criterion in getting a license was being a Brunswick resident and being one of the first 37 people in line. People had been in the town hall parking lot since Saturday. Some arrived between 2 and 4 a.m. Monday.
Houston said that the town leaves the actual forming of the line to the harvesters, who have their own "code" or system of rules about how to line up. "Certainly the marine resources committee and other town officials can't go out there and hold everybody else's hand," said Houston.
But that code apparently broke down. "In essence, the harvesters were fighting among themselves," said Houston.

People: Houston, Alan J

Fighting for aquaculture

Author: George Townsend and Sean Faircloth

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]22 Mar 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413701948?accountid=10457

Abstract: The Maine Chamber of Commerce and the Maine Alliance recently held a summit on economic growth strategy. Their report emphasized research and development, highlighting a handful of enterprises -- aquaculture prominent among them. Maine must target cutting-edge industries or lose jobs. Ironically, research dollars for aquaculture dropped 36 percent in the 1990s. Maine is doing exactly the opposite of what economists -- and common sense -- suggest. Maine cannot survive on service industries and summer jobs alone. Norway, New Brunswick, and Ireland are aggressively seeking aquaculture jobs. Maine's timidity will only expand the welfare rolls. A Finance Authority of Maine report said, "The market and price potentials of aquaculture products appear extremely encouraging. Aquaculture provides an opportunity to respond to consumer demand for high-quality seafood on a consistent basis. ... Yet the lack of investment in aquaculture has been prohibitive to growth." The federal government is now restricting the groundfish catch (cod, haddock, flounder). The Canadians are already moving toward groundfish aquaculture. Groundfish aquaculture will work as well on the coast of southern Maine as it will Down East! Unless Maine aggressively researches and develops groundfish aquaculture, Maine jobs will be lost.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Fighting+for+aquaculture&amp;author=George+Townsend+and+Sean+Faircloth&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-03-22&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Jobs. Jobs. Jobs. All politicicans talk about creating jobs. Rhetoric must become reality. Together with Sen. Harry Vose, the Maine Chamber of Commerce and others, we have offered legislation to help put Mainers to work: An Act to Encourage Economic Development Through Increased Investment in Aquaculture. Aquaculture (sometimes called fish farming) is the controlled harvesting of sea life (e.g. Atlantic salmon, steelhead, sheelfish, and seaweed).
Aquaculture means jobs. Aquaculture requires hatcheries (some in western Maine). A strong aquaculture industry will need suppliers of feed and equipment in state. Financial centers in Bangor and Portland will benefit. And, of course, we will create desperately needed jobs Down East. This legislation is a jobs program for all Mainers.
We must help the industry expand its physical infrastructure and its research and development base. First, a $5 million bond issue would go before the voters to create a revolving fund for low-interest aquaculture loans. The fund, modeled upon the successful $5 million Potato Marketing Improvement Fund, will promote the piers, fishpens, nets, and work platforms necessary to this high-tech industry. The Finance Authority of Maine would administer the fund.
Second, research money for the Maine Aquaculture Innovation Center would be restored to its previous peak budget of $302,000 (an increase of $113,000). The Bangor Daily News noted recently that the Norwegians are spending around $5 million a year on halibut research alone. They've pushed their salmon production from 120,000 tons in 1992 to 180,000 in 1993. (Maine produces 7,000 tons annually.)
The Maine Chamber of Commerce and the Maine Alliance recently held a summit on economic growth strategy. Their report emphasized research and development, highlighting a handful of enterprises -- aquaculture prominent among them. Maine must target cutting-edge industries or lose jobs. Ironically, research dollars for aquaculture dropped 36 percent in the 1990s. Maine is doing exactly the opposite of what economists -- and common sense -- suggest. Maine cannot survive on service industries and summer jobs alone.
Norway, New Brunswick, and Ireland are aggressively seeking aquaculture jobs. Maine's timidity will only expand the welfare rolls. A Finance Authority of Maine report said, "The market and price potentials of aquaculture products appear extremely encouraging. Aquaculture provides an opportunity to respond to consumer demand for high-quality seafood on a consistent basis. ... Yet the lack of investment in aquaculture has been prohibitive to growth."
Maine has a natural edge. University of Maine economist Jim Wilson says Maine's cool, nutrient-rich waters are the best natural environment for salmon and steelhead aquaculture in the contiguous states. Our waters are also excellent for shellfish and seaweed aquaculture. We have great potential in the halibut market.
The federal government is now restricting the groundfish catch (cod, haddock, flounder). The Canadians are already moving toward groundfish aquaculture. Groundfish aquaculture will work as well on the coast of southern Maine as it will Down East! Unless Maine aggressively researches and develops groundfish aquaculture, Maine jobs will be lost.
Aquaculture is a market worth fighting for. The non-partisan federal Office of Technology Assessment states, "Consumer demand exceeds production of catch-fisheries. The proportion of aquatic organisms raised by aquaculture is expected to climb from 11 to 25 percent of the global harvest by the year 2000." There are billions of dollars and thousands of jobs waiting for Maine in 21st century aquaculture. Do we sit on our hands and let the Norwegians, Irish and Canadians bump us out of our natural market? Or do we fight for Maine people and Maine jobs?
In 1990 the State Planning Office recommended research and development funding for the Maine Aquaculture Innovation Center. The state's Science and Technology Plan (October 1992) said the same thing. The Finance Authority of Maine recommended a revolving loan fund that would help aquaculture. The Maine Alliance and the Maine Chamber of Commerce this month targeted aquaculture as part of their economic development strategy. The experts are unanimous. Clean, sustainable jobs are there for the taking.
The only question is, do we want to help create jobs or do we just want to talk about jobs? The time to act is now. The 21st century is coming whether Maine is ready or not.
This aquaculture plan can dovetail with a group of economic development proposals. The Economic Development Committee has some excellent ideas. However, the committee's proposals, with bond issues similar to what is proposed here, do not allocate money for any specific industry. Each industry must start at square one to secure financing despite the fact that certain industries have been strategically targeted by the experts.
To improve on the Economic Development Committee's excellent proposal -- both sustantively and in terms of political viability -- a bond issue could be targeted at $5 million for each high-potential industry. Thus value-added forest products enthusiasts would favor the referendum for their part and aquaculture the same. Overall the people of Maine would benefit from a plan that specifically targets the industries that have greatest potential for future growth -- aquaculture chief among them.
The thrust of our aquaculture proposal can mesh with the Economic Development Committee's proposal. Without that change the overall proposal may be less viable on the ballot and less useful to our long-term growth. If our economic development plans are not aggressively targeted at high-potential industries like aquaculture, our efforts will be less successful. We cannot afford to miss this opportunity.
Rep. Sean Faircloth is a Democrat from Bangor and Rep. George Townsend is a Democrat from Eastport.

This would be spring fever, if Maine had a spring

Author: Kloehn, Steve

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]22 Mar 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413701353?accountid=10457

Abstract: On a fluky gorgeous day like Monday, the brown-gray ice pack recedes far enough to reveal things we have forgotton about. In Bangor, an abandoned mattress on the Griffin Road reappeared, as did an old shoe on Lincoln Street and the long-lost right lane of Main Street. Several people were injured in the town of Brunswick's running of the clam diggers. In this annual event, clam diggers line up to apply for a limited number of commercial shellfish licenses -- 37 this year. The rest of the state goes about its business with no apparent disruption, leading one to wonder: How did we ever settle on a five-day-a-week government anyway? And if a big state like California can do its weekly business in five days, shouldn't a small state like Maine be able to polish off its work in one or two days?

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=This+would+be+spring+fever%2C+if+Maine+had+a+spring&amp;author=Kloehn%2C+Steve&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-03-22&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Yesterday would have been the first day of spring, if we had spring in Maine.
In places where they do have spring, you can smell it. Warmth radiates from the earth with a rich, heady aroma. The wind stops, the sun beats down, and a 60-degree day seems warmer than any 80-degree day people can remember -- a day that demands shorts. Greenery erupts.
People who live in places that have spring celebrate the season in traditional ways -- they throw Frisbees and make goo-goo eyes in public and barbecue in unusual hats.
Here in Maine it is different. The Earth tilts, the days get longer, and we know we're halfway through winter. It's better, but it's not spring.
On a fluky gorgeous day like Monday, the brown-gray ice pack recedes far enough to reveal things we have forgotton about. In Bangor, an abandoned mattress on the Griffin Road reappeared, as did an old shoe on Lincoln Street and the long-lost right lane of Main Street.
A group of high school-age boys found enough blacktop on one driveway to play basketball. They even wore shorts, a singular act of denial. But with snowpiles in place of sidelines, the illusion was thin.
Still, the day after the vernal equinox is worth some sort of notice, and Mainers celebrated it in their own quirky way:
Several people were injured in the town of Brunswick's running of the clam diggers. In this annual event, clam diggers line up to apply for a limited number of commercial shellfish licenses -- 37 this year.
The way the town fathers imagined it, the would-be diggers would negotiate among themselves who was most deserving of the licenses and who was the neediest.
Instead, people began lining up on Saturday. When the doors opened, the diggers behind the first 37 decided that a footrace would be the most equitable way of selecting the licensees, and chaos broke out.
On the bright side, the licensing process makes raking clams look easy by comparison.
Augusta took the day off.
This, of course, is not a phenomenon limited to any particular season. But it does seem like the government's three-day weekends are coming more frequently these days, especially when there is a break in the weather.
These breaks have been inaccurately called "state shutdown days." The state, however, does not shut down -- just the State House, the bureaucracies sprawled all over Augusta and their satellite offices.
The rest of the state goes about its business with no apparent disruption, leading one to wonder: How did we ever settle on a five-day-a-week government anyway? And if a big state like California can do its weekly business in five days, shouldn't a small state like Maine be able to polish off its work in one or two days?
Farther north, experts tried to figure out how bad the flooding might be later in the presummer season.
Probably they know better than to think flooding can be predicted. But they also know that if a river does flood, as rivers tend to do, the people who get wet will demand to know why they were not warned.
So flood experts examine snow depth, water content, ice thickness, long-term forecasts and tea leaves.
Their conclusion? If it rains a lot, some rivers could flood. Don't say you weren't warned.
These are not signs of spring so much as symptoms of advanced cabin fever, and they are evident everywhere.
At the coffee shop that supplies most of my caffeine, the proprietors have taken to throwing a small rubber ball over the counter and across the room toward a small, empty fishbowl that sits in the middle of the floor. They have been doing this since January.
One has gotten the ball in the bowl 27 times. The other has made it about 15 times. Between them, they have taken several thousand shots.
On Monday, there was talk of warm weather and new activities and how the makeshift game would come to an end when spring arrived. But nobody rushed to pick up the fishbowl -- plenty of time for that later.
In the meantime, first one to 50 wins.

Fleet finds too few fish in the sea

Author: Timothy Egan The New York Times

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]07 Mar 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413705932?accountid=10457

Abstract: As for salmon in the Pacific Northwest, and three main commercial species in New England, the decline is catastrophic -- threatening to wipe out not just whole industries, but cultures and communities that are fused to the cycles of tide and sea currents. Fishing communities in Massachusetts are in such bad shape that Gov. William F. Weld last week requested emergency financial aid from the federal government. Thousands of fishermen are in "immediate danger" of losing their homes and boats this spring, Weld said. The trawler owners blame small boat operators who do not follow the rules, fishing out of season or using illegal nets. Environmentalists blame, among others, industries that have drained wetlands and dumped toxins into shallow bays.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Fleet+finds+too+few+fish+in+the+sea&amp;author=Timothy+Egan+The+New+York+Times&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-03-07&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: SEATTLE -- For the volunteers who count fish returning from the sea to fresh water, this has been the loneliest year ever.
The surging Pacific salmon and steelhead are gone; what the fish counters at the Puget Sound ship locks see when they stare at the glass wall separating them from the water is nothing but a reflection of their own faces.
Across the country, in Gloucester and New Bedford, Mass., the story is the same. After 350 years, the oldest American fishing area is largely barren of the great swarms of haddock, cod and flounder that sustained more than 10 generations of New Englanders and became millions of fish sticks.
The Atlantic fishermen have asked that the government treat them like earthquake disaster victims. Last week, they honked their boat horns in Boston Harbor to draw attention to their plight. To some, it was a funeral dirge.
From Chesapeake Bay, where oystermen are fading like fog in the afternoon sun, to the Gulf of Mexico, where grouper and red snapper are mostly a memory, people who pull fish from the sea for a living are singing the same sad song.
Government officials say most of the major commercial fishing areas in this country outside Alaska are in trouble, and worldwide, 13 of the 17 principal fishing zones are depleted or in steep decline.
As for salmon in the Pacific Northwest, and three main commercial species in New England, the decline is catastrophic -- threatening to wipe out not just whole industries, but cultures and communities that are fused to the cycles of tide and sea currents.
For the first time, there may be no ocean salmon fishing on the West Coast this year, a situation roughly akin to Georgia not producing any peaches.
Fishing communities in Massachusetts are in such bad shape that Gov. William F. Weld last week requested emergency financial aid from the federal government. Thousands of fishermen are in "immediate danger" of losing their homes and boats this spring, Weld said.
Aside from devotees of wild fish, however, consumers may not notice a shortage of fish at the supermarket. In recent years, farm fish raised in pens in Norway or South America have flooded the market, driving down the price of fish.
In some cases, the lowered prices have led fishermen to harvest more ocean fish in compensation. About 40 percent of the nation's important saltwater species have been overfished, meaning more fish have been taken than there are young fish to replace them, according to a recent report by the National Marine Fisheries Service.
Who is exactly at fault in the decline is much debated. Old-time fishermen blame factory trawlers -- boats the size of football fields that use sonar and satellite communications to track huge schools of fish in remote areas.
The trawler owners blame small boat operators who do not follow the rules, fishing out of season or using illegal nets. Environmentalists blame, among others, industries that have drained wetlands and dumped toxins into shallow bays.
Experts seem to agree on a few points. Pollution has indeed played a role: Pacific salmon have disappeared because the freshwater streams where they spawn have been soiled or are blocked by dams. Restoring the streams may cost in excess of $2 billion in the Northwest.
But, the experts say, fishermen themselves are also to blame for taking more than the sea could give back in New England, the mid-Atlantic and the Gulf.
"You can boil it all down to the fact that there are far too many fishermen and not enough fish," said Dick Schaefer, the conservation director of the national fisheries service.

Pollution testing plan gets broad support Sen. Cianchette raises funding question

Author: Adams, Glenn

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]03 Mar 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413713041?accountid=10457

Abstract: [James Reed Coles], D-Harpswell, told the Energy and Natural Resources Committee his proposed program in its first year alone would require nearly the $570,000 that has been spent on Maine's testing programs so far. Maine's monitoring program could cost $670,000 a year after that, said Coles, who handed committee members sheets listing several ideas on how to raise the money. DEP Commissioner Dean C. Marriott, who supports the bill, cited studies showing that mercury levels in Maine's eagles are among the highest in the nation. Also, he said, fish in the Androscoggin River have among the nation's highest dioxin levels, and there is "significant" contamination of bluefish by cancer-causing polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCBs.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Pollution+testing+plan+gets+broad+support+Sen.+Cianchette+raises+funding+question&amp;author=Adams%2C+Glenn&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-03-03&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: AUGUSTA -- Lawmakers found plenty of vocal support Wednesday for a proposal to monitor Maine waters for toxic pollution, but there were few concrete suggestions on how to finance it.
Rep. James Reed Coles' bill would create an ongoing program to test all of the state's waters to find out where pollution is the most serious.
The program would replace a patchwork of smaller programs that have been conducted in scattered locations around the state. Most of the tests have been financed by the federal government, and that money is gradually running out, according to the state Department of Environmental Pro- tection.
Coles, D-Harpswell, told the Energy and Natural Resources Committee his proposed program in its first year alone would require nearly the $570,000 that has been spent on Maine's testing programs so far.
Maine's monitoring program could cost $670,000 a year after that, said Coles, who handed committee members sheets listing several ideas on how to raise the money.
DEP Commissioner Dean C. Marriott, who supports the bill, cited studies showing that mercury levels in Maine's eagles are among the highest in the nation. Also, he said, fish in the Androscoggin River have among the nation's highest dioxin levels, and there is "significant" contamination of bluefish by cancer-causing polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCBs.
Only 3 percent of the total miles of Maine's rivers and less than 1 percent of its estuaries have been tested for toxic pollution, according to the Natural Resources Council of Maine.
Several fishermen and fishing industry representatives said they were concerned about pollution that could threaten the resource on which they depend for a living.
"We can't sell our products if we don't have clean water," said Gene Graffam, a shellfish harvester from Harpswell.
As a string of witnesses sounded similar concerns, Sen. Alton "Chuck" Cianchette interrupted the proceeding to tell the crowded audience, "We're already convinced. ... Please give us credit for getting the message."
The Newport Democrat said he and probably all of the committee members agreed there is a need for a monitoring program.
"We need to know how to fund it," he said.
Maine's paper makers believe the cost should be borne by all taxpayers through the state's General Fund, said Floyd Rutherford, president of the Paper Industry Information Office, who also spoke in support of the bill.
Rutherford said any monitoring should be objective and subject to federal standards to make sure the findings are kept in perspective. He also said health-risk assessments should be held to strict scientific standards.
The Natural Resources Council's Peter Washburn said in prepared testimony that there "is no perfect mechanism" for financing the program, and that finding a way to pay for it will require difficult choices.

People: Coles, James Reed

Renaissance man of lobster boats

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]23 Feb 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413924703?accountid=10457

Abstract: In the 17th and 18th centuries, a great flurry of boatbuilding on the Maine coast and elsewhere produced vessels capable of wartime and other uses. Somewhere along the line, people who recognized the culinary virtues of lobster, had access to boats to search out the shellfish in earnest. The first lobster boats were longer and narrower than what we think of now, and have always incorporated the displacement principle of propulsion. Instead of just skimming over the top of the water, they part it. Considered a dean of lobster boat construction in Maine, Arno Day inspects the sleek lines on one of his models at his Sedgwick workshop (NEWS Photo by Scott Haskell)

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Renaissance+man+of+lobster+boats&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-02-23&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BROOKLIN -- There is more than a tad of a twinkle in the eye of boat builder Arno Day as he describes the method of handling clients he developed in more than 50 years in the business.
In addition to the role of historian-philosopher that is part of Day's status as both a local and industry legend, he has also had to play salesman and psychologist.
For best results, he would humor his customers, politely listening to their suggestions while continuing to fashion their crafts as he saw fit.
Along the way, he would drop hints and suggestions, until the buyers became convinced they had come up with the grand designs themselves.
Day says lobstermen were a contentious lot, joking that he hated stormy mid-winter days in his shop, when lobstermen would hang around, and an argument was sure to ensue.
No two fishermen wanted the exact same boat, Day says. They would argue with each other and with him over details.
Just once in Day's career, a fisherman put his faith wholly in the boatbuilder's hands, in effect saying, "Build it the way you want, and I'll fish it," Day says,
Day discussed his work at a recent lecture in Bayview Hall, where a large crowd gathered to hear his version of the history of lobster boats.
"It takes a lot of patience, and you try to take instructions," he said of his work. "But there was no better group of people to work for than lobstermen. They appreciated everything you did, and they knew they were getting their money's worth."
No one knows when a boat was first used to snare a lobster, and that crustacean's capture was probably an accident. But Day likes to speculate on the beginnings of the tradition.
According to the fourth-generation boatbuilder now in his 70s, historians know that America's early settlers gathered seaweed for their gardens, probably picking up lobsters incidentally.
In Day's surmises, the first would-be lobsterman was a native American, who, having harvested all the seaweed on his home shore, set out by boat for greener pastures, inadvertently harvesting lobsters along the way.
At that time, you could practically reach down and be bitten by a lobster, they were so plentiful, Day said.
In the 17th and 18th centuries, a great flurry of boatbuilding on the Maine coast and elsewhere produced vessels capable of wartime and other uses. Somewhere along the line, people who recognized the culinary virtues of lobster, had access to boats to search out the shellfish in earnest.
Around 1915, the lobster boat as we know it was originated in the Jonesport-Beals area by a Nova Scotian.
The first lobster boats were longer and narrower than what we think of now, and have always incorporated the displacement principle of propulsion. Instead of just skimming over the top of the water, they part it.
To illustrate the principle of displacement, Day suggested trying to retrieve a slippery bar of soap dropped in a bathtub. When it shoots from your hands, that's displacement, Day said.
The shape of lobster boats has changed little since their inception, but they have grown wider to maximize comfort, stability and storage capacity.
Day shakes his head confoundedly at the "speed craze" he says some lobstermen are caught up in. "Lobster boats have been designed to win the race on the Fourth of July, so in some respects, they aren't ideal working boats," he says.
Illustration Caption: Considered a dean of lobster boat construction in Maine, Arno Day inspects the sleek lines on one of his models at his Sedgwick workshop (NEWS Photo by Scott Haskell)

Groups back bill targeting polluters

Author: (AP)

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]22 Feb 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413744810?accountid=10457

Abstract: Water pollution projects are languishing from inadequate funding in Maine, while local sewer rates are soaring, according to a report released Monday by an environmental group. It said 35 percent of the shellfish beds along the coast have been closed because of waste water contamination or lack of resources to certify them as safe. Also, beaches in the Portland area are routinely closed because of pollution, [Doug Bogen] said. Inland fish consumption advisories have been issued on 236 miles, or 22.5 percent, of Maine's largest rivers because of dioxin contamination. And 21 percent of Maine's lake acreage is not swimmable or fishable, it said.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Groups+back+bill+targeting+polluters&amp;author=%28AP%29&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-02-22&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PORTLAND -- Water pollution projects are languishing from inadequate funding in Maine, while local sewer rates are soaring, according to a report released Monday by an environmental group.
Clean Water Action and several other organizations that endorsed the report came out in support of federal legislation that would place more of the cost of cleaning polluted water on polluters instead of property taxpayers.
"People are fed up with paying ever-increasing sewer and water rates while beaches and waterways continue to be polluted," said Doug Bogen of Clean Water Action.
"It's time to identify new clean-water funding sources that don't put all the burden squarely on the backs of taxpayers," he said.
The report says water pollution is a problem along the coast and inland.
It said 35 percent of the shellfish beds along the coast have been closed because of waste water contamination or lack of resources to certify them as safe. Also, beaches in the Portland area are routinely closed because of pollution, Bogen said.
Inland fish consumption advisories have been issued on 236 miles, or 22.5 percent, of Maine's largest rivers because of dioxin contamination. And 21 percent of Maine's lake acreage is not swimmable or fishable, it said.
The report outlined several threats to Maine water, including raw sewage releases and industrial discharges.
The state's paper industry is the single greatest contributor to toxic waste in Maine's rivers, the report said.
"What we're proposing will serve notice to the paper industry that if they continue to use our rivers as a waste disposal (site), they're going to have to pay a price, literally," said Bogen.
The report said it will cost more than $1 billion to finance projects to meet current clean-water standards over the next two decades. The state has been receiving about $26 million per year in federal loan guarantees for the projects.
As a result, the report said, residential sewer rates have risen an average of 85 percent over the past five years in Maine's seven largest cities.
The group urged support for federal legislation that would put fees on toxic waste generators, producers of agricultural chemicals and commercial water users.
Rep. Tom Andrews, D-Maine, is a co-sponsor of the legislation.
"Access to clean water is a basic right that all Americans should share," Andrews said in a statement. "Unfortunately, what too many Americans do share are skyrocketing water and sewer bills to secure that right, because those who pollute our waters are not required to clean up their own mess."

People: Bogen, Doug

Bill designed to aid aquaculture

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]15 Feb 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413856502?accountid=10457

Abstract: "Maine's 30 aquaculture enterprises employ nearly 500 persons statewide at inland hatcheries, coastal grow-out sites, and seafood processing facilities," [Sean Faircloth] said. "This industry is a natural for Maine."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Bill+designed+to+aid+aquaculture&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-02-15&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: A Bangor representative has introduced a bill in the Maine Legislature that would promote economic development through investment in Maine's aquaculture industry.
Democrat Sean Faircloth's bill would result in a $5 million bond issue being placed before Maine voters. The money would be used to set up a revolving loan fund to be administered by the Finance Authority of Maine. New and expanding aquaculture businesses would be able to borrow money from the fund at reasonable interest rates.
The companies would likely finance their growth by combining the FAME loans with loans from private lenders.
The bill also would restore state support for applied research on aquaculture to $310,000, or the level where it stood in 1990. During the last four years, state support for aquaculture research has declined by 36 percent.
According to Faircloth, Maine aquaculture is the fastest growing segment of the state's food production industry. Businesses in the industry produce almost $50 million worth of mussels, Atlantic salmon, oysters, steelhead trout and clams at farmsites all along the coast.
"Maine's 30 aquaculture enterprises employ nearly 500 persons statewide at inland hatcheries, coastal grow-out sites, and seafood processing facilities," Faircloth said. "This industry is a natural for Maine."

Aquaculture in Maine

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]15 Feb 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413742939?accountid=10457

Abstract: Speculators on the future of aquaculture in Maine might consider the following: seafood will continue to be an important part of the world's diet; the food supply from the sea is far from inexhaustible; and the fishing industry must continue to move beyond open-sea techniques to provide the world with inexpensive food. Maine can take a crucial role in shaping the future of this industry. Aside from small shellfish operations, the difficulty of expanding Maine's aquaculture industry is in its startup costs. A finfish business can cost several million dollars to begin, and banks are understandably tentative about loaning large sums to this relatively new enterprise. If the state is to target enterprises that show promise, as economists are always urging Maine to do, however, aquaculture is a likely candidate for encouragement.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Aquaculture+in+Maine&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-02-15&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Speculators on the future of aquaculture in Maine might consider the following: seafood will continue to be an important part of the world's diet; the food supply from the sea is far from inexhaustible; and the fishing industry must continue to move beyond open-sea techniques to provide the world with inexpensive food. Maine can take a crucial role in shaping the future of this industry.
Competition in this industry will come not only from other countries, but nationally. Chile, Norway and Canada already have developing aquaculture industries, but so do Washington state, Alaska and several Eastern Seaboard states. If Maine is to succeed in this worldwide industry, it must be aggressive in its research, development and marketing.
Maine's relatively clean waters and good summer and winter water temperatures make it ideal for farming certain types of fish and mollusks. Cobscook Bay is especially conducive to sea farming. The state's $45 million industry, about one-third of the total amount of aquaculture in the Northeast, accounts for 450 full-time jobs at 20 finfish farms, eight shellfish farms and one farm growing nori, a seaweed favored in sushi and other Japanese foods.
Aside from small shellfish operations, the difficulty of expanding Maine's aquaculture industry is in its startup costs. A finfish business can cost several million dollars to begin, and banks are understandably tentative about loaning large sums to this relatively new enterprise. If the state is to target enterprises that show promise, as economists are always urging Maine to do, however, aquaculture is a likely candidate for encouragement.
The Maine Legislature will consider a bill this session that would spur investment in the aquaculture industry. LD 1759, sponsored by Sean Faircloth, D-Bangor, would put before the voters a $5 million bond issue to provide low-interest loans for capital investment to encourage more Mainers to become involved in the industry. It would also return the Maine Aquaculture Innovation Center in Brewer to its previous funding levels.
Lester Brown, president of the environmental-research group Worldwatch Institute, recently pointed out that the growth of the fish catch peaked in 1989, after multiplying four-fold since 1950. All 17 of world's major fishing areas have either reached or exceeded their natural limits, he said, and nine of those are in decline. Declining stocks for Maine fishermen threaten to destroy a traditional industry in the state. Aquaculture is one way to counteract this heavy demand on the sea.
It is also a way, over the long-term, to lower prices for seafood to allow it to compete with beef, poultry and pork. The U.S. Department of Agriculture recently reported that aquaculture's gains have come largely at the cost of non-farm seafood. "It will take a great deal of work," USDA economist, David J. Harvey, said recently, "developing new production and processing techniques before the aquaculture industry can compete on a direct price basis with the poultry industry."
The Aquaculture Innovation Center supports such research, which will enable fish farmers to expand their businesses and their markets. The center's budget, however, has been reduced during the recent difficult budget times, from a high of $308,000 to its current $190,000. Most of that money is disbursed in grants from several hundred dollars to $12,000 to $20,000 for research at such places as the University of Maine. Often, this state money is used to leverage federal dollars.
Like the Potato Marketing Improvement Fund, which helped retain jobs in Maine, the $5 million aquaculture loan fund is an investment in local industry and in the state's natural resources. Developed correctly, aquaculture could become a significant player in Maine's changing economy.

Title: Aquaculture in Maine:   [ALL Edition ]

____________________________________________________________

Sink this cargo port

Author: Huber, Ron

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]12 Feb 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413797397?accountid=10457

Abstract: What is it about Sears Island that makes these two agencies so concerned? In the early '80s, the Department of Marine Resources did research trawling in the vicinity of Sears Island. Results? As National Fisherman Magazine reported, the DMR discovered "a gigantic fish nursery." The DMR scientists found that these waters abounded with larval and juvenile cod, haddock, flounder, shrimp, halibut, pollock, smelt, alewives and about thirty other fish species. As we all know, populations of many of these species are at an all-time low. Destroying critical habitat for the young of these fish will condemn Maine's commercial fishing industry to a continued loss of their livelihood. That's why these agencies are so strongly against this project. The National Marine Fisheries Service also rejects MDOT's bizarre new plan to build the port on pilings above the shallows as still too damaging to the fisheries to accept. This will be good for the Japanese and Korean economies, but what about Maine? Like other states where woodchips are exported, Maine will quickly be stripped of the hardwood forests that attract so many tourists for the "leafpeeper" season. That provide vital raw maerials for furniture makers, wooden boat builders, even pallet makers. Chip mills buy hardwoods by the acres, taking all species at all ages, at a slightly better price than furniture and pallet makers can afford. The lure of quick money for "junk" owners as well as large companies like Champion, which recently opened a large woodchip export operation in North Carolina. The plan for Sears Island would require liquidating about 62,000 acres of hardwoods each year, wrecking Maine's tourism and furniture business while it dooms Maine's commercial fishery.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Sink+this+cargo+port&amp;author=Huber%2C+Ron&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-02-12&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The tempest over whether or not to build a cargo port on Sears Island has been portrayed by the Bangor Daily News as a conflict between elitist special interests and reasonable people trying to balance care for the environment with economic growth. Nothing could be further from the truth.
The battle is really between those who want to protect Maine's tourism and commercial fishing industry and those who want to strip Maine of its hardwood forests, for a quick inernational buck, regardless of the ecological consequences. Between Maine's finished wood products industry and raw material exporters linked to Korean and Japanese paper companies. Between hard science and robber baron economics.
Mainers should thank the Sierra Club and other advocates for the environment for two compelling reasons:
Maine's commercial fisheries. According to the National Marine Fisheries Service and U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, construction of the port on Sears Island will have a very negative effect on the commercial fisheries of Maine. Contrary to the BDN's recent editorial, destruction of eelgrass meadows, clamflats and other shallows in the area of the proposed port has not been completed. That's why these two agencies recently had this to say.
National Marine Fisheries Service: "The values of the eelgrass meadows, shellfish beds and shallow subtidal flats as foraging, shelter and nursery areas for marine species have been documented in great detail over the past two years. In our judgment, the marine impacts of the Sears Island cargo port project alone justify a finding that the project would cause significant degradation and is thus ineligible for a (Clean Water Act) Section 404 permit."
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service: "The potential adverse impacts to fish and wildlife resources are extremely serious. After 12 years of studying the environmental impacts associated with this project, we believe the time has come to be forthright with the Maine Department of Transportation and advise them that those impacts are unacceptable and violate the Clean Water Act Section 404 guidelines."
That's why these agencies are advising the Army Corps of Engineers to deny permission to dredge.
What is it about Sears Island that makes these two agencies so concerned? In the early '80s, the Department of Marine Resources did research trawling in the vicinity of Sears Island. Results? As National Fisherman Magazine reported, the DMR discovered "a gigantic fish nursery." The DMR scientists found that these waters abounded with larval and juvenile cod, haddock, flounder, shrimp, halibut, pollock, smelt, alewives and about thirty other fish species. As we all know, populations of many of these species are at an all-time low. Destroying critical habitat for the young of these fish will condemn Maine's commercial fishing industry to a continued loss of their livelihood. That's why these agencies are so strongly against this project. The National Marine Fisheries Service also rejects MDOT's bizarre new plan to build the port on pilings above the shallows as still too damaging to the fisheries to accept.
Tourism and woodworking industries. The real reason the McKernan administration insists that the facility be built on Sears Island instead of expanding Mack Point is that its primary use will be to export up to 600,000 tons of hardwood chips a year year to fine paper industries overseas. Japanese and Korean paper mills will not buy woodchips if they are contaminated with coal dust, as could happen if the mountains of woodchips that would exit Maine were alongside piles of coal at Mack Point.
This will be good for the Japanese and Korean economies, but what about Maine? Like other states where woodchips are exported, Maine will quickly be stripped of the hardwood forests that attract so many tourists for the "leafpeeper" season. That provide vital raw maerials for furniture makers, wooden boat builders, even pallet makers. Chip mills buy hardwoods by the acres, taking all species at all ages, at a slightly better price than furniture and pallet makers can afford. The lure of quick money for "junk" owners as well as large companies like Champion, which recently opened a large woodchip export operation in North Carolina. The plan for Sears Island would require liquidating about 62,000 acres of hardwoods each year, wrecking Maine's tourism and furniture business while it dooms Maine's commercial fishery.
What benefits will Mainers get out of this new port? In return for putting thousands of Mainers in the fishing, tourism and woodworking industries out of work, about eight jobs. Yes, eight! Woodchip mills employ eight workers on average to grind about 85 truckloads of logs a day.
Of course, a few dozen temporary jobs will he created to dredge out the eelgrass meadows and clamflats and construct the port, and the transportation industry will enjoy a decade of prosperity hauling hardwoods to Sears Island. But then, once the hardwoods are gone, those eight workers will join the thousands of unemployed fishermen, furniture makers and members of the tourism industry whose jobs they destroyed on the unemployment line. The trucks will be sporting "For sale" signs, and the Japanese and Koreans will be counting their money and moving on to other areas. All other imports and exports through the port will be the result of diverting cargo from the Eastport and Portland ports, taking e jobs along with them.
While this may be a "shrewd move," as your editorial puts it, it is also a cruel shell game, pitting regional economies against each other.
The Bangor Daily News may choose to call the Sears Island port' "the end of an economic funnel," but it could more accurately l be called "the end of an economic recovery." How can anyone promote such a shortsighted and destructive project?
Ron Huber is director of the Coastal Waters Project, a grass-roots network dedicated to protecting marine and estuarine habitat along the Atlantic coast of the United States.

Company / organization: Name: National Marine Fisheries Service; NAICS: 926150

MMA offers marine issues lecture series

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]05 Feb 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413768697?accountid=10457

Abstract: Professor Tom Shattuck of Colby College will present "Marine Aerosol Chemistry" at 4 p.m. Tuesday, Feb. 15, in the Alumni Lecture Hall. Shattuck said his work involves study of air masses over coastal areas, and because he studies particle masses, he sometimes subtitles his lecture with the pun, "What in particular are you breathing now?" Marine biologist Paul Anderson of the Maine Department of Marine Resources will speak on "The Role of DMR in Monitoring Coastal Waters" at 3 p.m. Monday, Feb. 28, in the Alumni Lecture Hall. Based at the DMR laboratory in Lamoine, Anderson has been involved in several reopenings of shellfish harvesting areas previously closed due to pollution.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=MMA+offers+marine+issues+lecture+series&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-02-05&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: CASTINE -- A series of five public lectures on marine topics ranging from water quality monitoring to marine snow will be offered at Maine Maritime Academy in the coming weeks.
The lectures are part of an annual series presented by the Academy's Corning School of Ocean Studies. The events will be held in the afternoon and are free of charge.
Professor Tom Shattuck of Colby College will present "Marine Aerosol Chemistry" at 4 p.m. Tuesday, Feb. 15, in the Alumni Lecture Hall. Shattuck said his work involves study of air masses over coastal areas, and because he studies particle masses, he sometimes subtitles his lecture with the pun, "What in particular are you breathing now?"
Shattuck hopes to have data from air sampling conducted off the Maine coast last summer available in time for the talk.
Marine biologist Paul Anderson of the Maine Department of Marine Resources will speak on "The Role of DMR in Monitoring Coastal Waters" at 3 p.m. Monday, Feb. 28, in the Alumni Lecture Hall. Based at the DMR laboratory in Lamoine, Anderson has been involved in several reopenings of shellfish harvesting areas previously closed due to pollution.
Clam flat closings are generally attributable to either excessive fecal coliform concentrations or to the naturally occurring algae blooms characterizing red tide.
The DMR usually reopens closed shellfish areas after water quality testing indicates that bacterial concentrations are within acceptable limits. Among the closed areas the DMR has reopened recently are Crockett Cove on the coast of Stonington, and Webber and Curtis coves in the Blue Hill area.
The remaining lectures in the series will be presented by University of Maine faculty members.
"Circulation in the Gulf of Maine" will be presented by Professor Neil Pettigrew at 3 p.m. Monday, March 7, in the Alumni Lecture Hall.
Professor Malcolm Shick will speak on "Solar UV Radiation and Oxidative Stress in Marine Organisms: A Spectrum of Responses," at 4 p.m. Monday, March 28, in Payson Hall.
The final lecture will be "Marine Snow and the Carbon Cycle: Not Just a Lot of Fluff," by Professor Cindy Pilskaln at 4 p.m. Monday, April 11 in the Alumni Lecture Hall.
For more information on the series, call 326-2256.

People: Shattuck, Tom

Little harm expected to lobster industry

Author: Carroll Astbury Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]05 Feb 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413741584?accountid=10457

Abstract: Jim Markos, general manager at Maine Shellfish in Ellsworth, agreed with [Buddy Lynch]'s assessment. He expected that some people would be wary of lobster for a while, but he didn't expect to see a long-term decline in business. He didn't receive any calls to cancel wholesale orders after the warning was issued. State officials say that a woman of child-bearing age could eat three, 1 1/4-pound lobsters a month, along with the tomalley, "without adverse risk." Markos said consumption patterns of lobster would indicate that most people ate lobster less than three times a month.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Little+harm+expected+to+lobster+industry&amp;author=Carroll+Astbury+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-02-05&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Seafood dealers expect little long-term harm to the lobster industry in the wake of the state's warning that the crustacean's tomalley contains trace amounts of dioxin.
The most convincing support for this prediction comes from Massachusetts, where a similar warning was issued in 1988.
Buddy Lynch, who manages Hook & Co. Lobster in Boston, said there was a short-term decrease in demand, but the industry rebounded quickly. He expects the same thing will happen in Maine.
"Two years from now, no one will even remember," Lynch said.
Jim Markos, general manager at Maine Shellfish in Ellsworth, agreed with Lynch's assessment. He expected that some people would be wary of lobster for a while, but he didn't expect to see a long-term decline in business. He didn't receive any calls to cancel wholesale orders after the warning was issued.
State officials say that a woman of child-bearing age could eat three, 1 1/4-pound lobsters a month, along with the tomalley, "without adverse risk." Markos said consumption patterns of lobster would indicate that most people ate lobster less than three times a month.
Another indication that the impact of the warning might decline with time is that there will be no on-going warnings issued. According to Hal Winters of the Bureau of Marine Development at the Department of Marine Resources, there won't be warning labels, signs or other notices required to constantly remind consumers of the dioxin.
"There probably won't be other action taken because of the limits of this particular advisory," Winters said.
The impact of the advisory may be magnified temporarily because it's winter and lobster sales are at a low point. Any decline will show up in sales. There are also a lot of Canadian lobsters flooding the U.S. market now.
In fact, Lynch said he had only Canadian lobsters in his tanks this week. "I've thought of putting up a sign ,`I sell only Canadian lobsters,' " he said. But he doubted that he would.
There have been no dioxin warnings issued on Canadian lobsters, according to Dave Aiken and Vlado Zitko of Canada's Department of Fisheries and Oceans in Saint Andrews, New Brunswick.
Zitko said the lobsters had been tested, but no warnings were necessary. He didn't have the results of the tests.
"It's a politically sensitive area, and tests can be done and not get wide distribution," Aiken said.

People: Lynch, Buddy

Eating dioxin

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]05 Feb 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413735388?accountid=10457

Abstract: The last is necessary not to confirm that even minute quantities of dioxin are harmful to humans, but to give opponents in the debate a common set of numbers. Evidence continues to accumulate that exposure to dioxin leads to increased instances of leukemia, lymphoma and cancer, and that it can cause reproductive and developmental problems. But what level of dioxin, however small, leads to what level of increased risk of these diseases? A possible shortcoming in the lobster study, in fact, was its lack of funds. Paid for by paper companies through the dioxin monitoring program, the study did not test all of its lobsters separately at each of four sites because of the cost of dioxin analysis -- $1,150 a test. Instead, it divided each site's lobsters into groups of five, separated the tomalley from the lobster flesh and tested a ground up composite of each sub group's tomalley and flesh. A more accurate, though more expensive, result could have been found by teating each of the 40 lobsters individually.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Eating+dioxin&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-02-05&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Three things become clear after the state's report on unacceptably high levels of dioxin in lobsters at various locations along the coast: Maine must take steps to reduce the level of the toxin in its environment; the state needs a far more extensive survey of the effects of pollution on its rivers, lakes and coastal waters; and the Environmental Protection Agency must step forward with its long-promised report on dioxin.
The last is necessary not to confirm that even minute quantities of dioxin are harmful to humans, but to give opponents in the debate a common set of numbers. Evidence continues to accumulate that exposure to dioxin leads to increased instances of leukemia, lymphoma and cancer, and that it can cause reproductive and developmental problems. But what level of dioxin, however small, leads to what level of increased risk of these diseases?
The EPA was to have produced a thorough study of dioxin by now, but has yet to finish its work. April currently is the expected time for a draft report to be issued for public comment. Though debate over acceptable risk levels will certainly continue after the release of the final report late this year, public policy has a better chance of proceeding once the report is issued.
In the lobster study, dioxin was found as part of the environmental background in the control group and at twice that level of the control group at two of the three experiment sites. Its conclusions were not encouraging. Nursing mothers, pregnant women and women of childbearing age should avoid eating lobster tomalley, which serves as a lobster's liver.
The results of this study will have a negative impact on the lobster industry, the tourist industry (though it remains to be seen how well informed summer visitors will be of the warning), and the paper industry, one source of dioxin. The key here is not to shoot the messenger, but to take steps to reduce the threat.
Dioxin can be found almost anywhere. It is a byproduct of incineration, wood and coal burning and industrial processes that use chlorine. Trace amounts are found in dairy products and meats as well as in fish and shellfish. Animals at the top of the food chain generally have the highest concentrations.
Like lead, ubiquitous in the environment from sources such as paint, gasoline and solder in cans, dioxin's removal is possible, source by source. Indeed, a paper industry trade magazine, Pulp & Paper International, saw the end of its contribution to the problem as inevitable. "Some market pulp producers who believe they can continue to bleach with chlorine in the future," it said, "may end up paying for their error" because of the growing demand for chlorine-free paper.
If the study on lobsters causes no other action, it should push the Legislature to consider a bill that would fund a five-year project to monitor Maine waters for toxic contamination. Currently, the state lacks a comprehensive view of the condition of its lakes, rivers and coastal waters. The lobster study demonstrates the potential danger in this ignorance.
The bill, LD 1446, would offer the state a valuable scientific basis for assessing risk and setting environmental priorities. At $550,000 a year, the bill is not cheap, but is a necessary cost of having allowed pollution to spread widely throughout the environment.
A possible shortcoming in the lobster study, in fact, was its lack of funds. Paid for by paper companies through the dioxin monitoring program, the study did not test all of its lobsters separately at each of four sites because of the cost of dioxin analysis -- $1,150 a test. Instead, it divided each site's lobsters into groups of five, separated the tomalley from the lobster flesh and tested a ground up composite of each sub group's tomalley and flesh. A more accurate, though more expensive, result could have been found by teating each of the 40 lobsters individually.
LD 1446 is due before the Legislature in two weeks. Legislators wondering whether the monitoring program is worth the cost should remember the lobster study and ask themselves about the costs incurred by all of Maine when pollution is left unchecked. The lobsters should serve as red warning flags.

Dioxin enters rivers as mill waste

Author: Andrew Kekacs Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]03 Feb 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413821002?accountid=10457

Abstract: In Maine, dioxin and related compounds are created in tiny amounts by seven paper mills that use chlorine to bleach wood pulp. The chemicals pass through waste treatment systems and eventually are released into Maine rivers. From the rivers dioxin enters the food chain and accumulates in the fatty tissue of fish, birds, animals and humans. Long-lived animals at the top of the food chain generally have the greatest concentration of dioxin in their bodies. The chemical was discovered in Maine rivers 10 years ago, when the EPA began a nationwide study of dioxin contamination. Scientists were surprised to discover the compound in fish from the Androscoggin River.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Dioxin+enters+rivers+as+mill+waste&amp;author=Andrew+Kekacs+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-02-03&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency considers dioxin to be one of the most dangerous man-made substances. It is a byproduct of industrial processes that use chlorine.
In Maine, dioxin and related compounds are created in tiny amounts by seven paper mills that use chlorine to bleach wood pulp. The chemicals pass through waste treatment systems and eventually are released into Maine rivers.
From the rivers dioxin enters the food chain and accumulates in the fatty tissue of fish, birds, animals and humans. Long-lived animals at the top of the food chain generally have the greatest concentration of dioxin in their bodies.
Dioxin causes a skin disorder called chloracne. It also has been linked to cancer, liver disease, reproductive and developmental problems, and damage to the immune and nervous systems.
Scientists for the paper industry and other manufacturers contend that the health risks of dioxin are overstated. Other researchers claim the chemical is more dangerous than originally feared.
To resolve the dispute, the EPA commissioned a comprehensive study of the health risks of dioxin. Release of the findings has been delayed repeatedly, but a draft report may be available in April.
The chemical was discovered in Maine rivers 10 years ago, when the EPA began a nationwide study of dioxin contamination. Scientists were surprised to discover the compound in fish from the Androscoggin River.
In 1985, Maine residents were warned to limit their consumption of fish from parts of the Androscoggin. The warning later was expanded to include parts of the Penobscot, Kennebec and Presumpscot rivers.
Meanwhile, the state's paper mills began to invest millions of dollars to change their bleaching processes. The concentration of dioxin found in fish from the four rivers declined steadily from 1989 through 1992.
Maine, however, has a very limited testing program for toxics. Until two years ago, the state tested only a few species of freshwater fish near paper mills for dioxin contamination.
Most states do only limited testing of toxics. David Bailey, senior attorney in the Washington office of the Environmental Defense Fund, said it can cost more than $1,000 to perform a single dioxin test, plus the cost of collecting the animal, preparing the sample and shipping it to the lab.
The possibility that dioxin is present in other types of seafood deserves further investigation, according to Dean C. Marriott, commissioner of the Maine Department of Environmental Protection.
The DEP and the Natural Resources Council of Maine are pushing for an expanded testing program. The Legislature balked at the cost in 1993, but it will take up the issue again this month.
Other states are far ahead of Maine in testing for toxics. Dioxin was found 11 years ago in lobster, crabs, bluefish, striped bass, carp, catfish, goldfish and eels in New Jersey.
In 1989, British Columbia closed eight areas near paper mills to the taking of oysters, clams, crabs and shrimp.
Dioxin and other industrial pollutants have been found in seafood caught along the Atlantic and Pacific coasts, in the Gulf of Mexico and the Great Lakes. In most of those areas, paper mills are not the source of the contamination.
Atlantic salmon and other anadromous fish, which spend only part of their lives in fresh water, once were thought to be relatively unaffected by dioxin. But National Fisherman, a trade magazine based in Rockland, reported four years ago that even sea-run salmon have begun to accumulate the chemical in their tissues.

Hot tomalley, science and green stuff

Author: Kloehn, Steve

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]03 Feb 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413798013?accountid=10457

Abstract: Green stuff indeed, snorted the lobster snobs. Don't they know tomalley is a delicacy? Green stuff indeed, chuckled the geographic snobs. Why do you think we give flatlanders bibs? "Preliminary analysis of data from tests conducted on lobsters taken off the coast of Maine indicate unacceptably high concentrations of dioxin in lobster tomalley," squawked an official advisory sent out Wednesday. This week, the governor goes to Washington and three of his henchpeople blurt out some bad news about lobster. (Mind you, these people work for a man who, in national publications, is pictured holding lobsters.) Maybe when the governor gets back he can say that what his people really meant is that if dioxin were found in lobster tomalley, that would not be so terribly bad, but more study should be done before anybody says anything rash. And then maybe he can schedule state shutdown days for the next time he leaves town.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Hot+tomalley%2C+science+and+green+stuff&amp;author=Kloehn%2C+Steve&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-02-03&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: It is a famous story by now, and has the additional virtue of being true:
Some 10 years ago, an Ellsworth police officer arrived at a local restaurant to quell a disturbance. Just inside the door, he encountered the two perpetrators, a 59-year-old woman from Ohio and a 61-year-old woman from California.
The women would not pay their bill. They had ordered Maine lobster, but when they cracked the critters open, the women found the meat covered with "green stuff."
The police officer explained that the green stuff was tomalley -- lobster liver -- and that all lobsters have it. The women still refused to pay.
Finally the officer advised the suspects that if they did not settle up, they would be issued a summons for theft. At that, the women paid for the lobster, but they never did eat the green stuff.
Oh, how Maine laughed at that one. Nothing better than a good tourist joke to ease the tension of a hot July day.
Green stuff indeed, snorted the lobster snobs. Don't they know tomalley is a delicacy? Green stuff indeed, chuckled the geographic snobs. Why do you think we give flatlanders bibs?
One columnist of note opined that these women must have arrived in Maine via the turnip truck.
As it turns out, their reaction was neither squeamish nor parochial -- merely prophetic.
"Preliminary analysis of data from tests conducted on lobsters taken off the coast of Maine indicate unacceptably high concentrations of dioxin in lobster tomalley," squawked an official advisory sent out Wednesday.
The press release was a joint effort of the Department of Human Services, the Department of Marine Resources and the Department of Extreme Pessimism; the letterhead alone suggests to me an unacceptably high concentration of bureaucrats.
Still, their announcement made a considerable splash. Women of child-bearing age should swear off the green stuff altogether, they warned, and the rest of us should cut back because "dioxin found in tomalley will contribute to the overall intake of this chemical, and to cancer risk in general."
This is about more than food. New Jersey and Massachusetts can maunder on about dioxin in shellfish and they will not raise too many eyebrows; but when Maine badmouths lobster, it trifles with its own state icon, not to mention the state treasury.
How to react?
Quibble with the science: The state bases its warning on a finding of 13 to 30 parts dioxin per trillion parts tomalley. First of all, the feds cannot even decide whether dioxin is dangerous, and they have been working on it for years. Second, at least one scientist says he never worries about eating anything measured in parts per trillion.
I comfort myself with the thought that I would never voluntarily eat a trillion parts tomalley.
Work the exquisite spin: The Maine Lobster Promotion Council earned every last penny of its budget Wednesday with this interpretation of dioxin in the tomalley:
"It is also a reassuring indication of the lobster's natural defense system at work, keeping the lobster meat wholesome, nutritious and delicious."
Yuk it up: "You know the lobster industry -- here today, gone tomalley." "Finally they found a way to get rid of the rats in Steuben. Feed 'em lobster." "So now our license plates have to have surgeon general's warnings on them?" And this was just in a newspaper office -- wait until witty people get hold of it.
Say "Never mind": Last week the governor went out of state. While he was gone, one of his commissioners reported that the Bangor Mental Health Institute could close. When the governor returned, he quickly spread the word that what his administration really meant was that AMHI would probably close before BMHI, but neither institution would be closed as long as he had anything to say about it. Never mind.
This week, the governor goes to Washington and three of his henchpeople blurt out some bad news about lobster. (Mind you, these people work for a man who, in national publications, is pictured holding lobsters.) Maybe when the governor gets back he can say that what his people really meant is that if dioxin were found in lobster tomalley, that would not be so terribly bad, but more study should be done before anybody says anything rash. And then maybe he can schedule state shutdown days for the next time he leaves town.
Of course, the likely reaction is a nationwide news flash and the same sort of lemminglike behavior that drove millions to throw out bacon, stock up on bran and quiver over their own mortality at every meal.
Then a handful of state officials can pride themselves on shooting a hole through both the lobster fishery and tourism with a single bullet. True, those two industries bring in a mountain of money for Maine's anemic economy.
But who cares about that green stuff, right?

Title: Hot tomalley, science and green stuff:   [ALL Edition ]

Publication title: Bangor Daily News; Bangor, Me.

Number of pages: 0

Publication year: 1994

Publication date: Feb 3, 1994

Publisher: Bangor Publishing Company

Place of publication: Bangor, Me.

Country of publication: United States, Bangor, Me.

Publication subject: General Interest Periodicals--United States

ISSN: 08928738

Source type: Newspapers

FDA expected to list tough seafood rules

Author: Marian Burros The New York Times

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]21 Jan 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413810179?accountid=10457

Abstract: The new regulations are a major shift in the government's efforts to insure the safety of seafood. They are aimed at preventing health problems from occurring rather than reacting to outbreaks of illness, said Dr. David A. Kessler, the commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration. In recent years, reports of several deaths from seafood poisoning, a devastating study by Consumer Reports on contamination of fish across the country and a constant flow of warnings from officials about tainted shellfish from various areas has shaken the public's confidence. Per-capita consumption of seafood in the United States has dropped about 8 percent since its peak in 1987, said Lee Weddig, executive vice president of the National Fisheries Institute, a trade group based in Arlington, Va.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=FDA+expected+to+list+tough+seafood+rules&amp;author=Marian+Burros+The+New+York+Times&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-01-21&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The federal government is expected to announce on Friday morning that it will for the first time require the seafood industry to keep detailed records of safety procedures and to label all shellfish to show where it comes from.
The new regulations are a major shift in the government's efforts to insure the safety of seafood. They are aimed at preventing health problems from occurring rather than reacting to outbreaks of illness, said Dr. David A. Kessler, the commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration.
In recent years, reports of several deaths from seafood poisoning, a devastating study by Consumer Reports on contamination of fish across the country and a constant flow of warnings from officials about tainted shellfish from various areas has shaken the public's confidence.
Per-capita consumption of seafood in the United States has dropped about 8 percent since its peak in 1987, said Lee Weddig, executive vice president of the National Fisheries Institute, a trade group based in Arlington, Va.
Both industry and consumer groups favor a more rigorous approach than the current piecemeal system that manages to inspect only a tiny fraction of the nation's seafood consumption.
But while the industry is delighted with the proposals because they might reassure people who have been nervous about eating fish, consumer groups say the new rules will not do enough to reduce illnesses and deaths from the consumption of bad seafood.
"This is a very positive first step that we've waited for eight years," said Caroline Smith DeWaal, director of legal affairs for Public Voice for Food and Health Policy, a consumer group based in Washington that has long lobbied for seafood safety legislation. "We've got a long way to go."
The same kind of system is being considered by the Agriculture Department to try to prevent tainted meat from reaching the public.
The Centers for Disease Control says 9,000 deaths occur each year from food poisoning, but it cannot say how many are caused specifically by tainted fish, meat or poultry, the three main offenders.
Congress has failed for several years to enact seafood-safety legislation, so the FDA decided to approach the problem administratively, using the authority it already has. The regulations will go into effect one year after a 90-day period for public comment ends -- probably in the spring of next year.
Under the new program, the government will continue its inspections.
