FDA to propose new seafood standards

Author: (AP)

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]14 Jan 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413841455?accountid=10457

Abstract: OMB spokesman Barry Toiv said Thursday he could not release details of the proposed regulations. FDA officials also declined to discuss details, but confirmed that the regulations were expected to be issued this month. The FDA has been working on the issue since the National Academy of Sciences issued a report on seafood safety in 1991 recommending new standards. The Agriculture Department is working to develop a similar plan for meat and poultry inspection.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=FDA+to+propose+new+seafood+standards&amp;author=%28AP%29&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-01-14&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: WASHINGTON -- The Clinton administration will propose new seafood safety regulations this month in response to concerns about shellfish contamination, the White House budget director said in a letter made public Thursday.
The Office of Management and Budget has completed its review of the proposed requirements for seafood processors, which will be issued by the Food and Drug Administration by the end of January, OMB Director Leon Panetta wrote.
In the letter to Rep. Jolene Unsoeld, Panetta acknowledged concerns Congress members had raised about waning public confidence in the safety of shellfish and other seafood. He did not indicate what would be included in the proposed regulations.
They likely will address such things as sanitary practices of processors, regulation of growing waters and the temperature of the seafood in shellfish at various stages of harvesting through distribution, said Doug Levy, an aide to Unsoeld, D-Wash.
"Right now you have a patchwork of state regulatory approaches," Levy said. "We are looking for FDA to adopt uniform guidelines with the authority to make sure they are implemented."
OMB spokesman Barry Toiv said Thursday he could not release details of the proposed regulations. FDA officials also declined to discuss details, but confirmed that the regulations were expected to be issued this month.
"It's a high priority project," Michael R. Taylor, deputy commissioner for policy at the FDA, said in a recent interview.
The FDA has been working on the issue since the National Academy of Sciences issued a report on seafood safety in 1991 recommending new standards. The Agriculture Department is working to develop a similar plan for meat and poultry inspection.
Carol Tucker Foreman, a former USDA official and chief spokesperson for the Safe Food Coalition, a group of consumer, public health and labor organizations, said there is a lot of work to be done.
"FDA doesn't even have the name, address and telephone number of people out there processing fish," she said.

Clammers bristle at new state regulations

Author: (AP)

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]13 Jan 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413714405?accountid=10457

Abstract: Shellfish diggers and dealers face new state regulations that would change the way they do business, and some clammers already are upset at the prospect. What really has diggers peeved, said John Lemont, is the paper trail that could lead to a crackdown on the many clam diggers who don't file income tax returns with the Internal Revenue Service.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Clammers+bristle+at+new+state+regulations&amp;author=%28AP%29&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-01-13&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: HARPSWELL -- Shellfish diggers and dealers face new state regulations that would change the way they do business, and some clammers already are upset at the prospect.
To protect the health of consumers, the state wants to force diggers to tag bushels of clams and mussels with the exact location of the flat from which the shellfish were harvested.
The purpose is to ensure that if a person eating a Maine clam anywhere in the country became sick, officials could quickly pinpoint the tainted flat and close it to further digging.
Now, when a bushel of clams is sold, the dealer records the name of the digger and the general location where the clams originated.
But if the Legislature passes the new bill, all that will change.
"None of us want to do it," Brunswick digger James W. Real said. For one thing, the tags are expensive, he said, and "I've got enough costs as it is buying licenses."
But what really has diggers peeved, said John Lemont, is the paper trail that could lead to a crackdown on the many clam diggers who don't file income tax returns with the Internal Revenue Service.
"That's what they're afraid of," said Lemont, a member of Brunswick's marine resources committee. "They're going to have to start paying their share."
Diggers aren't the only ones getting hit with new regulations. Shellfish dealers say they are feeling the pinch of new government standards.

____________________________________________________________

Poisoned flats

Author: Bridges, Albert

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]07 Jan 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413814986?accountid=10457

Abstract: For years we did useless state-mandated flat surveys and yearlong area closures. It was a waste of time. Clams were dying and no seed setting in. Ninety-eight percent of Brooklin's clam flats are barren. The only places any seed spat can set in and survive is where there is fresh water. And when the brook crosses a main road, forget it. This tells me that where enough chemical-free fresh water dilutes the toxic chemicals in the flats, a set of clams can survive. I think our flats are irreversibly impregnated with toxic chemicals to doom soft-shell clams and eventually surf clams, razor clams, quahogs and marine worms. My sad, sad prediction is that within 10 years, clams will not exist in Brooklin.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Poisoned+flats&amp;author=Bridges%2C+Albert&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-01-07&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: I am writing in response to the article on the Down East clam industry (BDN, Jan. 1-2). Biologist Brian Beal is correct on one count: There is apathy among diggers and townspeople. But the most apathy is in Augusta, including biologists.
When I was a chairman of our Shellfish Committee we repeatedly asked about having soil samples from our flats analyzed. The answer was always that they were swamped with paperwork and besides, the state had no facilities for testing soil samples, only water samples for coliform, etc.
For years we did useless state-mandated flat surveys and yearlong area closures. It was a waste of time. Clams were dying and no seed setting in. Ninety-eight percent of Brooklin's clam flats are barren. The only places any seed spat can set in and survive is where there is fresh water. And when the brook crosses a main road, forget it. This tells me that where enough chemical-free fresh water dilutes the toxic chemicals in the flats, a set of clams can survive.
It also tells me that something toxic has been running into our sea water and settling onto our flats since early in the 1970s. Where the best clamming used to be near low tide, now the only clams are way up the beach. Apparently, the longer the flats are under water, the more poison settles into it.
I think if samples were taken of flats where there are clams and compared with samples from barren flats, there would be seen a difference.
Don't expect the state to do it. There is big money in blueberries and Velpar, and the state Department of Transportation will continue to spray its poison herbicides along the roads. Any tests would be either lost or labeled "inconclusive" and the studies dropped.
I have been a commercial fisherman and clamdigger for more than 50 years. I can't tell you the Latin name for everything that swims as the biologists can. I do know what I see happening over the last 20 years.
I think our flats are irreversibly impregnated with toxic chemicals to doom soft-shell clams and eventually surf clams, razor clams, quahogs and marine worms. My sad, sad prediction is that within 10 years, clams will not exist in Brooklin.
It is not, as biologist Beal says, due to our apathy or lack of management -- it is due to the fact our flats are poisoned and the state is doing nothing and won't.
Not to worry. Clamdiggers can trade their hoes for blueberry rakes and try to survive on three weeks' summer work. Meanwhile, the biologists can retire on their pensions in 20 years. If I were a state politician or a biologist, I would grow a beard and never shave again. I couldn't look myself in the eye, and when you shave with your eyes shut, you can get cut.
Albert Bridges lives in Brooklin.

People: Beal, Brian

____________________________________________________________

Down East clam industry collapsing Harvest, jobs drop; clam management efforts questioned

Author: Bruce Kyle Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]01 Jan 1994.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413731545?accountid=10457

Abstract: ROQUE BLUFFS clam digger Herbert Richards Sr. returns to the flats after wading in to rinse his roller of clams. "I've made a damn good living clamming, and still do," said the lifelong digger. But where he used to harvest 10 bushels a tide, he now harvests one bushel or less. Many other diggers have given up as clams have become scarce Down East. (NEWS Photo by Scott Haskell) [Brian Beal], a biologist at the University of Maine at Machias, believes a lot more could be done to bring back the clam industry in Washington and [Hancock] counties. Harvests have dropped sharply in the last decade, and hundreds of jobs have disappeared. Part of Beal's job is running a hatchery for seed clams that some towns are using to upgrade their flats. Most of the interest is coming from southern Maine coastal communites. (NEWS Photo by Scott Haskell)

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Down+East+clam+industry+collapsing+Harvest%2C+jobs+drop%3B+clam+management+efforts+questioned&amp;author=Bruce+Kyle+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1994-01-01&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Brian Beal knows what's killing the once-mighty clam industry in Down East Maine.
"It starts with `A' and ends with `p-a-t-h-y,' " says the University of Maine at Machias biologist and shellfish expert.
"In the last 10 years, we've seen the collapse of a resource worth millions in Washington and Hancock counties, capable of providing thousands of jobs, with no action at the state level and no public outcry locally. What could be a powerful economic force in this region is being allowed to die," said Beal.
Statistics from the Maine Department of Marine Resources show utter devastation. More than 4.6 million pounds of soft-shell clam meat, worth $7 million, were harvested from the state's two easternmost counties in 1982. That figure plummeted to just more than 500,000 pounds last year. The 1982 landings were nearly 70 percent of the state's total. Last year's were less than one-fourth.
The job loss numbers are there too. Shellfish licenses issued Down East, theoretically limited by what local committees and the DMR agree can be supported by the flats, dropped from 2,200 to 410 in those 10 years. That's equivalent to the loss of 1,800 seasonal and full-time jobs, says Beal.
It's not, however, just a case of things being tough all over. Harvests in the southern Maine counties of Cumberland and Lincoln have increased steadily during the same period, surpassing Down East production for the first time ever in 1991.
The cause of the decline Down East cannot be known without a concerted research effort, Beal said, "and that's something the state and the communities haven't shown an interest in supporting. Until that's done, it's all speculation.
"For every theory, there are 15 others, equally good," said Beal. "You can look at environmental factors, slightly warmer weather and marginally higher water temperatures in southern Maine, which do contribute to slightly faster growth but don't explain how Down East accounted historically for half to three-fourths of the harvest.
"We're not talking about clams just not growing as fast Down East; we're talking about not finding young clams on the flats. Predation and pollution can't explain it. There probably are more natural predators in Scarborough than in Addison. Pollution from human and animal waste makes clams unfit to eat, but it doesn't kill them, and it's much more likely to be a problem in the more populated southern areas," he said.
One difference Beal is sure about is the attitude about managing the clam resource, and about clamming as an occupation.
"In Cumberland County, you find towns with active shellfish committees, working to locate pollution sources, basing their license numbers on scientific data from thorough surveys, enforcing ordinances, carrying out seeding and transplanting programs. The public perception of the value of the clam resource is overwhelming. They know that with proper management, this doesn't have to be a boom-and-bust industry," he said.
"Brunswick has its own marine resources department with a $60,000 budget and they harvest more than $1 million worth year after year," he said. By contrast, "Down East towns are looking at clamming as a less-than-honorable occupation not worth saving."
The attitude Down East is that raising "more than the typical one or two thousand dollars at town meeting is folly."
Beal isn't just another ivory-tower academic telling the locals what they're doing wrong -- he's a native Jonesporter who worked his way through the university at the end of a clam hoe.
More comfortable in waders than a tweed jacket, he often is found out behind the UMM science building, sifting barehanded through mud samples. Even his basement office, where computers share desk space with assorted mollusks, has the distinct aroma of the clam flat.
"As a scientist, I'm trained to conduct reasearch, to be dispassionate, but I do have an emotional stake in this," he said. "These are my own people here; half the people in Washington County are Beals. I know how hard it is to make a living here, so it's very painful to see this huge economic resource neglected."
Beal is technical adviser to the publicly owned Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery founded in 1987 by UMM and several communities. The hatchery produces 10 million baby clams a year and participating towns receive 500,000 seedlings for every $1,000 contribution.
There were some early setbacks in survival rates for the hatchery clams, Beal said, but an experiment showed how to increase survival dramatically, by transplanting in the spring instead of the fall. Meanwhile, interest in the hatchery has waned Down East, and support from foundations and agencies is threatened by the lack of local support.
"Southern Maine towns seem to have a better understanding of the way research works and the importance of stock enhancement. They're very active in our program. I had a call just the other day from Kittery Point. They want in. That's nice, but I would have jumped up and down if somebody from Dennysville had called," said Beal.
Down East resignation
The mood Down East is one of resignation. Alverie Preston of Roques Bluff and Arpie Alley of Jonesport have about a century of clamming between them and neither sees much hope for the future.
"I've been in this business since I was a kid. I've seen downturns before, but never anything like this," said Preston. "They've always come back before, but this time they're not coming back. I used to be able to make a decent living, but nobody can today. In the '70s, I could dig two or three bushels on a tide and make $50. Today, I could dig both tides and be lucky to make $50, but $50 doesn't buy what it used to."
Preston said the decline "is caused by a lot of circumstances. Nature just isn't putting out the seed, and even though we cut back the number of licenses, there are still way too many. There's no full-timers anymore. It's mostly people with other jobs who come in the summer, digging deeper and deeper, tearing up the flats. They've got a good steady job to go back to."
Preston's town issued 30 shellfish licenses this year, "and there's no way we should have had more than 10, with the condition of the flats, but cutting is very hard to do politically. We hash this over every year, but it always boils down to someone saying the guy next door has a license, so I want one too."
Alley, like most Down East diggers, is critical of the minimum 2-inch size law enacted in 1984.
"Not because of the minimum, but because they didn't put on a maximum size. The bigger the clam, the more it produces; you don't get babies from babies," he said.
Herbie Riggs gets $100 every two weeks as Lubec's shellfish warden.
"I've got 97 miles of shoreline to cover. It's impossible to do any kind of policing. If we seed a flat and close it for conservation, we'd just have people out there in the moonlight digging it all up for a few clams. There's just too much taking and not enough putting back. For this town, clamming's going to be a thing of the past."
Brunswick model
For management the way it ought to be, everybody points to Brunswick, where Marine Warden Alan Houston has a $60,000 budget, an Everglades-style airboat and an active army of volunteers.
"We have our own mini-Department of Marine Resources here. We survey our flats every year, instead of the three years the state requires. We seed, we transplant, and we find and eliminate pollution sources," Houston said. "We base our number of licenses, 88 this year, strictly on what the flats can support. Our top priority is to sustain clams as a steady source of income for the people of this town."
Down Easters might say wealthy Brunswick can afford to do what they can't, "but that's not at all true," Houston said. "Except for my rather modest salary as a police officer, our entire marine budget comes from license fees and fines -- lots of fines, an average of about $20,000 a year.
"We're the only town in the state with an airboat, and I can be on any flat at any time. That makes me real popular around here. When we close a flat for conservation, it's closed, period."
Digger Jim MacLeod, a member of Brunswick's Marine Resources Committee, says one difference between his town and towns Down East "is that we've always looked at clamming as a profession, not as a `welfare job' for people who can't do anything else. We have harvesters here making $40,000 a year because we're tough on poaching, we limit entry, we cut back on digging days, we make our decisions on the scientific information."
Brunswick also is willing to take on a threat, such as the University of Southern Maine, which plans to spread septic sludge on its demonstration cattle farm at Wolf Neck, and the state Department of Environmental Protection, which has approved the project.
Committee member Dr. Russ Pinfold, a veterinarian who can rattle off dozens of chemicals found in sludge, and the sicknesses and birth defects they may cause, says USM and the DEP "are making a terrible mistake and we won't let it happen. Bowdoin College was going to take part in this project, but we shamed them out of it and we won't let up until USM follows."
Chemicals questioned
One issue only whispered about Down East but openly discussed in Brunswick is the possible connection between the chemicals sprayed on blueberry fields in Washington and Hancock counties and the shellfish decline.
"It's interesting to me that they saw dramatic increases in blueberry yields at the same time their clams began disappearing," Houston said. "People there should know what's being put on the land. They should be suspicious of the effect on the intertidal zone. Those chemicals have to go somewhere; everything runs into the sea eventually."
The herbicide of choice since 1983 is Velpar, which gained federal approval for blueberry use through the work of University of Maine researchers and often is cited as a key component of the industry's explosive growth.
The chemical, classified by the EPA as "practically nontoxic" for everything from humans to shellfish, has been showing up lately in Hancock County ground water.
"Beware of those classifications," says Pinfold. "What you're talking about is a risk-assessment situation, where a certain amount of death and mutation is acceptable. I'd be willing to bet that there have been no studies done on the long-term, cumulative effects on shellfish reproduction."
Pinfold would win that bet. The DMR tests water quality only for bacteriological contaminants, not chemicals, and has not explored the connection between herbicides and shellfish reproduction since pre-Velpar days, when two-necked clams with gonadal tumors were found in three locations with high exposure to herbicides.
"What we found then was that the acid soils of Eastern Maine don't do a good job of breaking down some of these chemicals," said DMR biologist Robert Lewis. "No one has looked at what the herbicides and pesticides used now do to larvae, whether in some way they break the chain of reproduction, and we're not going to know until we have some research on it."
David Yarborough, blueberry specialist for the UM Cooperative Extension, said the university "has not specifically tested Velpar on clams, but there is nothing in the nature of the chemical to lead us to expect an effect on adult clams or the larval stages. I seriously doubt if there is any connection."
For Beal, the lack of solid data on herbicides is just one more example of the tremendous research gap for shellfish.
He suggests what is needed for the shellfish industry to survive: "From the highest levels of state government down to the local board of selectmen, we have to change the attitude that this is just clams. The state has to take these harvest numbers seriously and realize that a decline like this isn't just a natural cycle."
Illustration Caption: ROQUE BLUFFS clam digger Herbert Richards Sr. returns to the flats after wading in to rinse his roller of clams. "I've made a damn good living clamming, and still do," said the lifelong digger. But where he used to harvest 10 bushels a tide, he now harvests one bushel or less. Many other diggers have given up as clams have become scarce Down East. (NEWS Photo by Scott Haskell) BRIAN BEAL, a biologist at the University of Maine at Machias, believes a lot more could be done to bring back the clam industry in Washington and Hancock counties. Harvests have dropped sharply in the last decade, and hundreds of jobs have disappeared. Part of Beal's job is running a hatchery for seed clams that some towns are using to upgrade their flats. Most of the interest is coming from southern Maine coastal communites. (NEWS Photo by Scott Haskell)

People: Beal, Brian Houston, Alan Pinfold, Russ

Environment was big newsmaker in '93 AES pullout from Bucksport among region's top stories

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]28 Dec 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413906665?accountid=10457

Abstract: In January, oil-soaked debris from a Maine Maritime Academy training ship was found at the Riverview Cemetery in Bucksport, and at a scenic turnout in Prospect. A Virginia company, Eastern Technical Enterprises Inc., was charged with the illegal disposal of debris removed during an overhaul of the training vessel. In Brooklin, momentum building to draft a harbor ordinance was superseded by town officials' apparent discovery last fall of an ordinance requiring fees for use of the Naskeag Harbor landing. Residents had complained last summer that a Stonington fisherman left bait onshore, attracting rats, and that bait also floated ashore in front of Center Harbor homes. The year saw the opening of several shellfish harvesting areas that had previously been closed, as the Department of Marine Resources found water quality in the areas substantially improved. Reopened areas included the Benjamin River estuary in Sedgwick, most of Crockett Cove in Stonington, and Curtis and Webber coves in East Blue Hill.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Environment+was+big+newsmaker+in+%2793+AES+pullout+from+Bucksport+among+region%27s+top+stories&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-12-28&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: For hundreds of area residents, 1993 may be remembered as the year in which Applied Energy Services decided not to build where it wasn't wanted after all.
The Arlington, Va., company's withdrawal in October of the $309 million coal-fired power plant it proposed for Bucksport capped a three-year struggle that pitted environmental concerns against a desire for economic development of the town.
While awaiting the next round of court sessions in its appeal to overturn a town board's negative decision on the plant, AES officials decided to call it quits, validating the highly publicized statement a project manager made early on that the company would not build a plant where it was not wanted.
By the end of 1993, some local officials said they hoped to integrate environmental and economic interests in planning for Bucksport's future. Bucksport is expected to hold public hearings on environmental issues as officials draft related ordinances next year. At the same time, an economic development committee is continuing to plan projects such as an industrial park, as another committee explores the development of a marina at the local harbor.
In the Hancock County area, some of the other issues of environmental concern resolved or evolving in 1993 included the state's issuance of a consent agreement in March, following the discovery that biomedical waste found in 1992 at the Ellsworth landfill was disposed of by a housekeeping employee of an office building adjoining, and run by, Maine Coast Memorial Hospital.
The agreement fined the Ellsworth Hospital $2,500, and required the facility to serve as a collection center for needles used by household generators of medical waste.
In January, oil-soaked debris from a Maine Maritime Academy training ship was found at the Riverview Cemetery in Bucksport, and at a scenic turnout in Prospect. A Virginia company, Eastern Technical Enterprises Inc., was charged with the illegal disposal of debris removed during an overhaul of the training vessel.
In Brooklin, momentum building to draft a harbor ordinance was superseded by town officials' apparent discovery last fall of an ordinance requiring fees for use of the Naskeag Harbor landing. Residents had complained last summer that a Stonington fisherman left bait onshore, attracting rats, and that bait also floated ashore in front of Center Harbor homes.
Stonington officials have drafted a proposed ordinance banning the use of burners by local quarries. A petition had been circulated protesting noise and dust caused by burner use at a quarry run on church property.
In October, the formation a few months earlier of a group charged with monitoring the breeding success of loons in county waters appeared fruitful. Dozens of Loon Ranger volunteers submitted data collected during the summer suggesting that the breeding season had been a qualified success. The group, sponsored by Maine Audubon, is expected to continue its efforts next year.
September brought the reopening of the Clement septic sludge site in Orland, which for nine months was shut down after the Department of Environmental Protection ordered improvements to bring the facility up to licensing standards. After slow going the first couple of months, at least two of approximately 10 towns that used the site before the shutdown signed back on with the facility, the only one of its kind in the county.
The year saw the opening of several shellfish harvesting areas that had previously been closed, as the Department of Marine Resources found water quality in the areas substantially improved. Reopened areas included the Benjamin River estuary in Sedgwick, most of Crockett Cove in Stonington, and Curtis and Webber coves in East Blue Hill.
No one was injured during the recent emission of toxic ammonia gas at Allen's Blueberry Freezer Inc. in Ellsworth. Responding firefighters identified the source of the gas as a ruptured line on the company's cooling tower on East Main Street. Workers at the tower reportedly moved quickly to seal the leak. The matter remains under investigation.

Protein unmasked in shrimp allergy

Author: Jane E. Brody The New York Times

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]28 Dec 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413735720?accountid=10457

Abstract: [Dean D. Metcalfe] and Dr. P.V. Subba Rao of the Indian Institute of Science in Bangalore and their colleagues then looked further to determine which parts of shrimp tropomyosin bound to the antibodies in the blood called IgE, setting off an allergic reaction. They identified two regions, called epitopes, that attach shrimp tropomyosin to IgE. The finding was described in a recent issue of The Journal of Immunology.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Protein+unmasked+in+shrimp+allergy&amp;author=Jane+E.+Brody+The+New+York+Times&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-12-28&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Researchers in India and at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases have identified two regions of a protein that set off allergic reactions to shrimp and closely related shellfish.
The discovery makes shrimp one of a few allergenic foods for which the actual allergen has been purified and identified. This may lead one day to a means of desensitizing people who are allergic to seafoods, an allergy that can be dangerous.
The protein, called a tropomyosin, is found in the muscles of all animals, with tropomyosins in closely related animals being most similar to one another, said Dr. Dean D. Metcalfe, an allergy specialist at the institute who was a leader of the research.
The studies began with an extract from shrimp that had been shown to provoke allergic reactions. The researchers tested protein fragments from the extract against the antibodies of patients allergic to shrimp. They isolated tropomyosin as the protein provoking the allergic reaction. Dr. Samuel Lahrer of Tulane University and his colleagues have made a similar finding.
Metcalfe and Dr. P.V. Subba Rao of the Indian Institute of Science in Bangalore and their colleagues then looked further to determine which parts of shrimp tropomyosin bound to the antibodies in the blood called IgE, setting off an allergic reaction. They identified two regions, called epitopes, that attach shrimp tropomyosin to IgE. The finding was described in a recent issue of The Journal of Immunology.

Lady Knox DAR seeking new members

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]23 Dec 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413757804?accountid=10457

Abstract: Well-known DAR members include: Lillian Gish, Ginger Rogers, Anna "Grandma Moses" Huntington, Mary Ann Mobley, Margaret Chase Smith, Ella Wilcox, Edith Roosevelt, Eleanor Roosevelt, Mamie Eisenhower, Rosalynn Carter, Nancy Reagan and Barbara Bush.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lady+Knox+DAR+seeking+new+members&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-12-23&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- According to Regent-Bethany Berry, the Lady Knox Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution, is seeking new members.
Any woman who is not less than 18 years of age, and who is descended from a man or woman who served as a sailor, soldier or civil officer in one of the several Colonies or states, or in the United Colonies or States as a recognized patriot, is eligible for membership in the National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution. Admission to membership in the National Society shall be either through a Chapter or as a Member at Large.
Well-known DAR members include: Lillian Gish, Ginger Rogers, Anna "Grandma Moses" Huntington, Mary Ann Mobley, Margaret Chase Smith, Ella Wilcox, Edith Roosevelt, Eleanor Roosevelt, Mamie Eisenhower, Rosalynn Carter, Nancy Reagan and Barbara Bush.
NSDAR fact sheets are available at the Rockland-Thomaston Chamber of Commerce. For membership information, write to: Mrs. Roland Berry, 668 Oyster River Road, Warren 04864.

3 Down East sites eyed for seaweed farming

Author: Paul Sylvain Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]20 Dec 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413718819?accountid=10457

Abstract: More commonly known as nori, this reddish Asian seaweed, used to wrap sushi -- tidbits of rice, raw fish and other ingredients -- has been grown experimentally in Eastport by Stephen E. Crawford since 1991. Crawford, who is identified in the application as vice president and facility general manager with Coastal Plantations International, witnessed nori farming firsthand several years ago while working in aquaculture in the Far East. If the leases are approved, the nori will be grown on frames called ikadas. The ikada is described as a type of "raft" which allows the nori nets to be raised above water for periodic drying to kill weeds and other unwanted growths which cling to the nets. The frames are slightly larger than the nori nets. Coastal Plantations International estimates that its nori processing machine, located at the former Wass factory in Eastport, can process up to 150 pounds wet weight of nori an hour. The machine is designed for 24-hour-a-day operation, and as a result, is capable of processing "in excess of 3,000 pounds of nori daily, or 20,000 pounds a week," according to the applications.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=3+Down+East+sites+eyed+for+seaweed+farming&amp;author=Paul+Sylvain+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-12-20&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: EASTPORT -- Coastal Plantations International of Portland has announced plans to cultivate an exotic type of seaweed in three proposed lease sites in waters off Eastport and Lubec.
The Department of Marine Resources will conduct separate public hearings at the Washington County Technical College in Eastport on each of proposed lease areas, as follows:
1 p.m. Tuesday, Jan. 11, to discuss an application for aquaculture lease consisting of four tracts in an 18.6-acre site east of Goose Island and southwest of Mathews Island in Eastport;
7 p.m. Tuesday, Jan. 11, to consider an application for aquaculture lease consisting of 17 tracts totaling 82.64 acres south of Huckins Ledge, South Bay, in Lubec;
1 p.m. Wednesday, Jan. 12, to discuss an application for aquaculture lease consisting of four tracts in an 18.6-acre site between Spectacle Island and Goose Island in Cobscook Bay, Eastport.
In an addendum attached to each of the three applications, Dr. Ira A. Levine, president of Coastal Plantations International, explained that a "variety of marine macro seaweeds" would be incorporated at the sites. According to the application, porphyra vezoensis, a species of porphyra, had been previously imported into Maine from Washington State.
More commonly known as nori, this reddish Asian seaweed, used to wrap sushi -- tidbits of rice, raw fish and other ingredients -- has been grown experimentally in Eastport by Stephen E. Crawford since 1991. Crawford, who is identified in the application as vice president and facility general manager with Coastal Plantations International, witnessed nori farming firsthand several years ago while working in aquaculture in the Far East.
Crawford, in an earlier interview, described nori farming as "a remarkable, vastly overlooked industry." Said Crawford, "In Japan nori is by far the biggest part of aquaculture, far bigger than finfish or shellfish. It's a $2 billion global industry, with $25 million worth of nori consumed in the United States each year, all of it imported."
In 1991, Crawford obtained a test tube of nori filaments from Dr. Robert Waaland at the University of Washington. The filaments were tested at Bigelow Labs in Boothbay Harbor, where they were determined to be pure. Crawford then received permission from Maine's DMR to introduce the strain into the state's waters.
According to the aquaculture lease applications, "The cultivation of this exotic species in Maine's coastal waters is dependent upon the issuance and renewal of an exotic species import permit by the Maine Department of Marine Resources and subsequent review by the Conseil International Pour L'Exploration de la Mer Working Group on Introductions and Transfers of Marine Organisms."
In addition, dulse, kelp and Irish moss from local seed stocks in Cobscook Bay would also be cultivated in the tract sites. "The culture material is being grown to seed commercial quantities of nets for the future cultivation of an indigenous nori sheet," the application states.
If the leases are approved, the nori will be grown on frames called ikadas. The ikada is described as a type of "raft" which allows the nori nets to be raised above water for periodic drying to kill weeds and other unwanted growths which cling to the nets. The frames are slightly larger than the nori nets.
Nori production in Maine is seasonal, varying with local water temperatures. The applications state that the vegetative stage of nori growth in Cobscook Bay extends from mid-May to late-November.
The reproductive stage, meanwhile, extends from September to April. This phase is "done entirely in wet labs on land," where the water temperature can be artificially controlled. The applications explain that the original seed came in a vial from Washington State and that "no further seed shipments will be needed."
Continuing, the application states that, at the end of the reproductive phase, clean nets are placed over the spores in a 6-by-65-foot "seeding frame" built out of 2-inch PVC pipe sealed for flotation.
Up to 50 5-by-60-foot nori nets can be placed in one frame for seeding. Seeding occurs within two days in May, either at the lease site or under controlled conditions in a wet-lab tank.
The seeded nets are then placed in the water in rafts -- the ikadas -- designed to raise the nets out of the water for drying one or two hours each day. "This drying is done religiously for three to four weeks," the applications said, "as failure to do so results in failure of the crop."
At the end of this "nursery phase," the nori is long enough to cover the nets, reducing the risk of unwanted weeds. The nets are then placed in production systems and will not be raised from the water again until harvesting begins, about 30 days later.
The applications explain that the crop is harvested using a rotary cutter resembling an upside-down, reel-type lawn mower.
"The nets are raised over the side of the boat, dragged over the mower, which cuts the blades off, falling into baskets under the mower," the applications said. Within two hours of being harvested, the crop is taken to a factory where it is processed into paper nori sheets using a Japanese-type nori machine.
Maximum annual production, according to the applications, "is 400-500 pounds wet weight after four harvests per net. The nori "becomes inferior in quality" after the fourth harvest, or after about six weeks of growth. At that point, the old net is removed and replaced with a new seeded net.
Coastal Plantations International estimates that its nori processing machine, located at the former Wass factory in Eastport, can process up to 150 pounds wet weight of nori an hour. The machine is designed for 24-hour-a-day operation, and as a result, is capable of processing "in excess of 3,000 pounds of nori daily, or 20,000 pounds a week," according to the applications.
If the leases are approved, Coastal Plantations International anticipates that the project will initially result in the creation of at least six full-time positions -- a general manager, supervisor, lab supervisor and three general laborers -- and four part-time jobs, with the potential for 40 full-time positions possible during full production cycles.

People: Crawford, Stephen E

Company: Coastal Plantations International

Canadian lobster market in pinch

Author: Toth, Derrick

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]18 Dec 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413818110?accountid=10457

Abstract: High prices, weak markets, market manipulation and manmade quality problems are threatening the lobster industry with extinction, says Alan Baker, a spokesman for many of the region's buyers, processors and exporters. Colin MacDonald of Clearwater Fine Foods in nearby Bedford, the world's largest shipper of live lobster, says exports are down 30 percent. MacDonald cites two major factors. Fishermen are holding their lobster at wharfside in wooden pens called cars, controlling supply to drive prices up. At the same time, quality is down because the shellfish suffer stress and damage in the crowded cars, increasing the mortality rate.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Canadian+lobster+market+in+pinch&amp;author=Toth%2C+Derrick&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-12-18&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia -- The alarm bells ringing in the Atlantic groundfish industry for the last couple of years are starting to go off in the lucrative lobster sector -- but for different reasons.
Unlike the withering stocks of valuable bottom-dwelling species like cod and haddock, the lobster population appears healthy.
But high prices, weak markets, market manipulation and manmade quality problems are threatening the lobster industry with extinction, says Alan Baker, a spokesman for many of the region's buyers, processors and exporters.
"It's bottomed -- we've gone to the point of complete disarray," says Baker, head of the Canadian Atlantic Lobster Promotion Association.
"We have an industry that is on the verge of economic collapse."
The warning comes amid the single biggest lobster season in the region. About 1,700 boats are currently working off southwestern Nova Scotia to haul a catch worth about $100 million a year to the fishermen alone.
The majority of that catch will be caught by mid-January, says Baker, with about 75 percent of those tasty crustaceans destined for export. Major markets include Japan, France and Germany.
But pocketbooks are tightening in their flagging economies.
"That marketplace is governed by economic factors, the most important of which is Japan and Europe are going through a recession ... greater than our own and with no signs of recovery," he says.
"Lobster is too expensive. People will not buy it."
Colin MacDonald of Clearwater Fine Foods in nearby Bedford, the world's largest shipper of live lobster, says exports are down 30 percent.
MacDonald cites two major factors. Fishermen are holding their lobster at wharfside in wooden pens called cars, controlling supply to drive prices up. At the same time, quality is down because the shellfish suffer stress and damage in the crowded cars, increasing the mortality rate.
The foreign buyer faces uncertain supply, lower quality and too high a price, he says.

People: Baker, Alan

2 Hancock County clam flats open again

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]18 Dec 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413729020?accountid=10457

Abstract: Most of Crockett Cove, on the western coast of Stonington, has been reopened after a closure that took effect in early 1991, said Paul Anderson, biologist for the Maine Department of Marine Resources. A half-dozen overboard discharge problems in the area have been corrected, some with funding earmarked for such purposes through the state's Community Development Block Grant program. In Blue Hill, Curtis Cove has been reopened, much to the delight of enthusiastic clammers who consider it a rewarding venue, Anderson said. Webber Cove is reopened, although McHeard Cove remains closed. The DMR took a new look at Webber Cove after a clammer said he thought at least one overboard discharge there had been fixed, said Anderson, who added his hope that harvesters won't hastily deplete what appears to be an abundant clam resource in the reopened Blue Hill areas.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=2+Hancock+County+clam+flats+open+again&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-12-18&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: LAMOINE -- Friday marked the reopening of two Hancock county clam flats previously closed to shellfish harvesting, including one that harvesters have clamored to get back for nearly three years.
Most of Crockett Cove, on the western coast of Stonington, has been reopened after a closure that took effect in early 1991, said Paul Anderson, biologist for the Maine Department of Marine Resources. A half-dozen overboard discharge problems in the area have been corrected, some with funding earmarked for such purposes through the state's Community Development Block Grant program.
Only a northern section of the cove remains closed because a stream coming from a beaver flowage has moderately high concentrations of fecal coliform bacteria.
Crockett Cove is considered fertile clamming ground, Anderson said, adding that the CDBG program has been particularly instrumental in funding cleanups of such areas. Towns apply for the grants, which then may be used to improve individual property owners' septic systems.
Property owners meeting income guidelines can get as much as 90 percent of upgrade costs covered.
Fixing faulty septic systems generally leads to measurable improvement in water quality, which can result in the reopening of closed areas. Delays sometimes occur when DMR officials have no way of knowing cleanups have taken place until improvements eventually show up in the agency's water monitoring, Anderson said.
Even in situations in which DMR officials themselves intervene in some way before the improvements are made, information on progress with the systems is not always communicated to the agency, which Anderson said can result in prolonged closures.
The nearby Goose Cove also was reopened Friday, although it is not a prime shellfish area.
In Blue Hill, Curtis Cove has been reopened, much to the delight of enthusiastic clammers who consider it a rewarding venue, Anderson said. Webber Cove is reopened, although McHeard Cove remains closed.
Webber and Curtis coves had also been shut down after failing septic systems were discovered. Several faulty systems reportedly are still plaguing water quality in McHeard Cove.
The DMR took a new look at Webber Cove after a clammer said he thought at least one overboard discharge there had been fixed, said Anderson, who added his hope that harvesters won't hastily deplete what appears to be an abundant clam resource in the reopened Blue Hill areas.
For more information on the reopened areas or the remaining closures, call the DMR office in Lamoine at 667-5654. The information should also be posted at town offices in the coming weeks.

People: Anderson, Paul

Hancock recycling unit wins composting grant

Author: Kathy Harbour Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]17 Dec 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413713701?accountid=10457

Abstract: The demonstration project would experiment with composting mixed paper and organic waste generated by two Lamoine shellfish processors. Blue Ribbon Seafood Inc. and H.A. Boynton Shellfish Co. have started a crab-shell composting site on private property in Lamoine. The shells are presently mixed with sawdust. As part of the demonstration project, the shredded mixed paper collected by Coastal Recycling from schools, municipal offices and businesses would be shredded and baled. The shellfish dealers would pick up the bales of shredded paper at Coastal's [Hancock] center and transport the bales to their compost site. The Lamoine shellfish dealers will pay all costs associated with operating the compost site, as well as the expense associated with picking up the baled paper from the recycling center. It is estimated the shellfish dealers process 200 tons of organic waste each year. Coastal Recycling estimates it could prcoess 22 tons of mixed paper during that same time period.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Hancock+recycling+unit+wins+composting+grant&amp;author=Kathy+Harbour+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-12-17&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: HANCOCK -- Coastal Recycling was awarded a $18,938 grant this week to start a compost shredding project.
The capital investment grant awarded Coastal Recycling was one of 37 awarded statewide through the Office of Waste Reduction and Recycling within the Maine Waste Management Agency. The statewide total for grants announced this week is $2 million.
Each of the 37 projects are matching grants, with 25 percent of the cost of projects funded through local money. Those matching funds are already available in the Coastal Recycling budget.
For Coastal Recycling, the grant will provide funds for the regional recycling center to purchase a shredding system. Equipment will include a shredder, hay baler, engine and trailer to transport the equipment to its member towns. Twelve municipalities in Hancock and Washington counties are members of Coastal Recycling.
Mixed paper, including items such as paper towel tubes, paper board and cereal boxes, will be shredded and baled. The system will also chip clean wood waste for composting and landscaping projects.
Plans to operate a shredding system are linked to another application submitted by Coastal Recycling for a $20,000 demonstration grant from MWMA.
Coastal Recycling Director Nina Silvestrone said Thursday her organization has not heard the status of that grant application. Silvestrone said she is very hopeful the project will be awarded funds.
The demonstration project would experiment with composting mixed paper and organic waste generated by two Lamoine shellfish processors. Blue Ribbon Seafood Inc. and H.A. Boynton Shellfish Co. have started a crab-shell composting site on private property in Lamoine. The shells are presently mixed with sawdust.
As part of the demonstration project, the shredded mixed paper collected by Coastal Recycling from schools, municipal offices and businesses would be shredded and baled. The shellfish dealers would pick up the bales of shredded paper at Coastal's Hancock center and transport the bales to their compost site.
Because it would be a demonstration project, with potential applications for other businesses that generate organic waste across the state, the results of the composting operation would be monitored throughout the year. According to Silvestrone, the goal of the project is to determine the appropriate percentage of paper to shells for generating good compost.
The Lamoine shellfish dealers will pay all costs associated with operating the compost site, as well as the expense associated with picking up the baled paper from the recycling center. It is estimated the shellfish dealers process 200 tons of organic waste each year. Coastal Recycling estimates it could prcoess 22 tons of mixed paper during that same time period.
The application for a demonstration grant includes the cost of renting a shredding system for 12 months. The receipt of the capital investment grant provides money for the recycling center to purchase that equipment instead.
Funds would also be used to minitor the costs of the project, measure the nutrient levels of the compost and market the finished product.
One potential use of the compost would be on camproads. A Department of Transportation landscape architect has suggested the compost could stabilize shoulders and ditches on the unpaved roads. Clyde Walton, in a letter to Silvestrone, said the compost could not only cut down on erosion but could also protect the water quality of nearby lakes from excessive phosphorous runoff.

People: Silvestrone, Nina

Volunteers to dig for pollution solution

Author: Diana Graettinger Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]13 Dec 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413750046?accountid=10457

Abstract: "It wasn't that it was a major pollution station. We just found that once in a while we'd get these high scores of fecal coliform bacteria. That suggests there is a problem. It is an indicator of sewage, and if there is sewage in an area, it might have a potential for disease," said Paul Anderson, microbiologist with the Department of Marine Resources. Every two weeks the volunteers take samples of water and deliver the samples to the DMR laboratory for analysis. [R. Forrest Dillon] said water and ambient atmospheric temperatures also were recorded. Data from those tests led to the identification of the tributary that was dumping fecal coliform bacteria into the cove. JOHN FENDL (left), a technician for the Department of Marine Resources, DMR microbiologist Paul Anderson (center), and R. Forrest Dillon, administrative assistant of the Frenchman Bay Conservancy, review water quality in [Sullivan]'s Long Cove. (NEWS Photo by Diana Graettinger)

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Volunteers+to+dig+for+pollution+solution&amp;author=Diana+Graettinger+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-12-13&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: SULLIVAN -- Through the efforts of a few volunteers the Long Cove clam flats in Sullivan again may be open to shellfish harvesting.
The flats in Sullivan have been closed for years because of high levels of fecal coliform bacteria, which is found in rivers where sewage effluent is dumped. Water-quality tests conducted three years ago by the Department of Marine Resources confirmed that Long Cove was polluted.
"It wasn't that it was a major pollution station. We just found that once in a while we'd get these high scores of fecal coliform bacteria. That suggests there is a problem. It is an indicator of sewage, and if there is sewage in an area, it might have a potential for disease," said Paul Anderson, microbiologist with the Department of Marine Resources.
Because there were few buildings in the area, he said, DMR officials were uncertain about the source of the pollution.
Anderson said that although his department had not surveyed the area in several years, they knew the potential for pollution was there. He said DMR biologists were responsible for conducting such surveys.
"They'll take a team of diggers, draw a transit across the flat and dig at predictable locations. They'll dig, count and grade the clams and size them. The population surveys give them an idea of what there is now for a harvestable population, and what there may be in the future," Anderson said.
Because clams are filter feeders, Anderson said, they ingest small particles in the water.
"We measure fecal coliform pollution as an indicator of the sewage, because of the potential for those organisms to end up in the clams. If those clams are ingested by humans, and either are not well cooked or raw, people can get sick," he said.
Enter the Frenchman Bay Conservancy, a volunteer organization that won a state grant that allowed it to monitor water quality in the area every two weeks.
Gale McCullough, a harbor seal researcher who wrote the application for the matching grant, said the group had received $2,500 to pay for the testing equipment to monitor water quality in the area. The volunteers conducting the tests include R. Forrest Dillon, administrative assistant of the Frenchman Bay Conservancy, Anne Geier, Oliver Crosby, Jeff Boggs, Tim Rummage and Harry Cunningham.
Every two weeks the volunteers take samples of water and deliver the samples to the DMR laboratory for analysis. Dillon said water and ambient atmospheric temperatures also were recorded. Data from those tests led to the identification of the tributary that was dumping fecal coliform bacteria into the cove.
Anderson and Dillon walked the stream that feeds into Long Cove and discovered several possible sources of pollution.
"One of them pretends to be a septic system, but never really was one," Anderson said. He said effluent from that system oozes into Long Cove.
The owner of the system was anxious to get help, Anderson said, but until recently the landowner was unaware of the state programs available to help him. He said the Maine Department of Environmental Protection had $1 million to spend on such problems this year through its Small Communities Grant Program.
"The town has to formally ask the DEP for help, and they will. All they have to do is write a letter. ... The DEP will administer it. They estimate between $5,000 and $7,000 for each system," Anderson said.
Illustration Caption: JOHN FENDL (left), a technician for the Department of Marine Resources, DMR microbiologist Paul Anderson (center), and R. Forrest Dillon, administrative assistant of the Frenchman Bay Conservancy, review water quality in Sullivan's Long Cove. (NEWS Photo by Diana Graettinger)

People: Anderson, Paul Dillon, R Forrest

____________________________________________________________

No charges in lobster cargo case No criminal intent found for Connecticut rescuers

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]13 Dec 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413715992?accountid=10457

Abstract: [Bruce Hudock] said it took rescue workers about five hours to extricate two drivers. At the point of impact, [Driver Archie Pickering]'s truck cab had "become one" with the truck he hit, trapping the Deer Isle man's legs in a 2-foot space. The lower portion of one of Pickering's legs later was amputated at Greenwich Hospital. During the extrication period, rescue workers entered the cargo area of Pickering's truck to gain access to the driver. Some of the 50 lobster crates were rearranged, and ice and three crates were removed from the truck to make access easier. The three crates were placed alongside the truck on a foam surface, and the cargo area was left open. The decision stated that there was no evidence to suggest that Pickering's rescue was prolonged or affected in any way by the removal of the lobster crates. The workers reportedly removed the crates in full view of a police officer, a reporter, and motorists, rather than in secret. They also notified police of a money bag in Pickering's cab.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=No+charges+in+lobster+cargo+case+No+criminal+intent+found+for+Connecticut+rescuers&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-12-13&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: GREENWICH -- A Connecticut state attorney has decided not to pursue criminal charges against rescue workers who were accused of taking 14 crates of live lobsters from the scene of an accident that left a Deer Isle man seriously injured in October.
Based on the findings of a month-long investigation by state police, senior state's attorney Bruce Hudock decided the state could not prove any criminal intent on the part of rescue or fire personnel, who arguably would not have taken the $3,800 worth of shellfish had they known the owner meant the cargo from the damaged truck to continue to New Jersey.
Driver Archie Pickering of Deer Isle was driving about 50 crates owned by the Stonington Lobster Cooperative toward New Jersey the evening of Oct. 19, when the truck struck the cargo bay of another truck that was obstructing all three westbound lanes at the scene of a multivehicle accident on Interstate 95 in Greenwich, Conn.
Two serious accidents occurring on the highway that evening blocked traffic for several hours.
Hudock said it took rescue workers about five hours to extricate two drivers. At the point of impact, Pickering's truck cab had "become one" with the truck he hit, trapping the Deer Isle man's legs in a 2-foot space. The lower portion of one of Pickering's legs later was amputated at Greenwich Hospital.
During the extrication period, rescue workers entered the cargo area of Pickering's truck to gain access to the driver. Some of the 50 lobster crates were rearranged, and ice and three crates were removed from the truck to make access easier. The three crates were placed alongside the truck on a foam surface, and the cargo area was left open.
After the extrication effort, several Greenwich Fire Department members and possibly other rescue workers removed another 11 crates of lobsters and loaded most if not all of a total of 14 crates onto emergency vehicles, according to the state attorney's report.
The crates were distributed among several local fire stations, and lobsters were divided among workers there.
The remaining 36 crates were transferred to another vehicle by a representative of the lobster cooperative. The 14 crates taken by rescue workers had not been condemned by the appropriate state agency, and should not have been taken, Hudock wrote.
About 40 firefighters responded to the accident call.
After the incident, Lobster Co-op manager Skip Greenlaw filed a complaint with the Connecticut State Police. The police investigated, and Hudock issued his decision on Dec. 10.
Greenlaw could not be reached for comment Sunday.
The decision stated that there was no evidence to suggest that Pickering's rescue was prolonged or affected in any way by the removal of the lobster crates. The workers reportedly removed the crates in full view of a police officer, a reporter, and motorists, rather than in secret. They also notified police of a money bag in Pickering's cab.
"These facts are simply not the stuff of which criminal minds are made," wrote Hudock, who commended the efforts of rescue workers and their supervisors for their other efforts at the scene.
The rescue effort nonetheless was marred by the removal of cargo, Hudock wrote, noting that the cargo had not been condemned, nor had Pickering authorized its removal.
Chief Mark Dawson of the Sound Beach Fire Department, the official in command at the accident scene, was quoted as saying during the investigation that he had "thought the load would be condemned. It just happened."
Describing the incident as "distressing," Hudock wrote in his decision that Greenwich residents and business owners are entitled to know that their possessions and their lives will be protected by public safety personnel.
"The attitudes of a small number of fire personnel, paid and volunteer, toward the Pickering cargo can best be described as presumptuous and cavalier," wrote Hudock, who added that Chief Dawson ordered the taking of lobsters in at least one instance and gave implied consent to the taking of the rest.
Still at issue is whether the Greenwich Fire Department will make restitution for the entire loss, which Hudock contends was made possible by a breakdown in command.
New guidelines on the handling of cargo and personal property at emergency scenes also may be considered, and disciplinary actions may be taken against those considered responsible.

People: Hudock, Bruce Pickering, Driver Archie

Title: No charges in lobster cargo case No criminal intent found for Connecticut rescuers:   [ALL Edition ]

Christmas meal was no picnic aboard cargo ships Penobscot Marine Museum exhibit features Victorian Christmas

Author: Dale McGarrigle NEWS Feature Writer

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]08 Dec 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413733792?accountid=10457

Abstract: It's enough of a challenge for many cooks to prepare dinner for a dozen relatives on Christmas day. How about adding the obstacles of violent motion, no refrigeration and two different kinds of meals to prepare? That's what the cooks on cargo ships in the mid-1800s faced, according to food historian Sandra Oliver of Islesboro. Oliver delved into the question of food aboard ships while preparing an exhibit to be mounted during the Penobscot Marine Museum's Victorian Christmas Dec. 10-12 in Searsport. Also planned are a Paul Sullivan concert, magic by Bruce Johnson, caroling and special decorations at the Fowler-True-Ross House. Christmas dinner in the captain's cabin would consist of roast chicken, chicken pie, cooked beets, potatoes, bread, tomatoes, rhubarb pie, mincemeat pie, plum pudding, fruit cake and tea.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Christmas+meal+was+no+picnic+aboard+cargo+ships+Penobscot+Marine+Museum+exhibit+features+Victorian+Christmas&amp;author=Dale+McGarrigle+NEWS+Feature+Writer&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-12-08&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: It's enough of a challenge for many cooks to prepare dinner for a dozen relatives on Christmas day. How about adding the obstacles of violent motion, no refrigeration and two different kinds of meals to prepare? That's what the cooks on cargo ships in the mid-1800s faced, according to food historian Sandra Oliver of Islesboro.
Oliver delved into the question of food aboard ships while preparing an exhibit to be mounted during the Penobscot Marine Museum's Victorian Christmas Dec. 10-12 in Searsport. Also planned are a Paul Sullivan concert, magic by Bruce Johnson, caroling and special decorations at the Fowler-True-Ross House.
Oliver explained that the cook, usually a black man, would have to prepare two kinds of meals, with plain food for the crew and more developed meals for the ship's captain, the officers and their families.
"The cooks tried to recreate what the crew was familiar with when they went to sea," Oliver said.
Cooking at sea was grueling work, she said.
"Pots on the stove would be constantly shifting, with only railings around the stove to catch them," she explained. "The galley was a small, cramped space, which got incredibly hot in the tropics. He couldn't even cook when the weather was rough."
Food took on special meaning at Christmas time, Oliver added.
"Food is terribly important at sea, and the only way to celebrate Christmas was a special meal," she said. "It may look bland to us, but then, I don't think there's anything stimulating about a fast-food meal or a breakfast of coffee and toast."
The crew's Christmas dinner would consist of boiled salt beef or some fresh roast pork, boiled potatoes, unleavened bread, plum duff (raisin pudding) with molasses, and tea. Popcorn balls, cheese and mincemeat pie were other special treats.
Christmas dinner in the captain's cabin would consist of roast chicken, chicken pie, cooked beets, potatoes, bread, tomatoes, rhubarb pie, mincemeat pie, plum pudding, fruit cake and tea.
Meanwhile, families onshore in that era would dine on roast turkey, oyster soup, potatoes, celery, bread, mincemeat pie, plum pudding, tea, apples, grapes, nuts and oranges.
When cargo vessels left port, they would be stocked with durable foods such as salted meats, root vegetables, flour and molasses. Also livestock and poultry would be kept alive on board, to be slaughtered for special occasions. The ship's pantry would be reloaded when the vessel went into port.
Oliver first became interested in food history more than 20 years ago. While working at the Mystic (Conn.) Seaport Museum, she developed a program on fireplace cooking. She later branched out into food aboard ships.
Her research sources include ships' journals and logs, letters, business records, cookbooks and legislation.
Oliver publishes "Food History News," a quarterly that circulates throughout North America.
"Food history is a part of social history and women's history, and interest in it has grown over the past 10 to 15 years," she said.
For more information about Victorian Christmas, call the Penobscot Marine Museum at 548-2529.
Illustration Caption: Two of the captain's children play with a goat on a cargo ship during the late 1800s (Photo Courtesy Penobscot Marine Museum)

People: Oliver, Sandra

State may ask clammers to tag harvest State hopes tags will track health of clam resource

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]06 Dec 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413718001?accountid=10457

Abstract: The requirement would represent a major change in the way diggers conduct business day to day, said Skip Applin, seafood technology supervisor with the DMR. Officials agreed that most Maine clammers are probably unaware that the change may be forthcoming. Although the tag requirement is likely to be unpopular with clammers, officials say any attempt by the state to circumvent the federal regulations would probably render Maine clams unmarketable. "As unpalatable as this might be to harvesters, I don't think there will be any choice," said Applin. [Gerald Poole] said clammers, like other fishermen, always complain about new fees or regulations. "I don't want to hear the crying because I know how much they make," he said, contending that clammers can earn as much as $18,000 a year, even as license fees increase and stocks dwindle.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=State+may+ask+clammers+to+tag+harvest+State+hopes+tags+will+track+health+of+clam+resource&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-12-06&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: LAMOINE -- A marine biologist says new federal regulations to be proposed at the state level should make it easier to track the health of Maine's clam resource.
Paul Anderson of the state Department of Marine Resources said this week that proposed Food and Drug Administration rules requiring clammers to tag their harvests upon bringing them into dealers could help enforcement agencies trace undersized or contaminated clams to specific sources.
In the past, officials have had to rely on tags affixed by dealers for data on where the clams were harvested. Brooklin shellfish dealer Gerald Poole said that system has been problematic, as diggers don't always supply buyers with correct information.
"Ninety percent of the time they're going to lie," Poole said, either because they hope to keep their digging area secret or because they're digging somewhere they shouldn't. "When you buy clams, you have to know where they're coming from."
The proposed change would probably require clammers to fill in the tags with their harvesting license number, harvest date, and the most precise digging location they can supply.
Poole supports the rules, which regional FDA officials say were agreed to about a year ago at a meeting of the Interstate Shellfish Sanitation Conference attended by state and federal officials. Although the federal rules have been on the books for a year, some states have yet to disseminate the information or begin enforcement.
When the Legislature meets next month, the DMR is expected to seek approval to require diggers to use the tags. The wording for the state requirement would have to be drafted, and public hearings held.
The requirement would represent a major change in the way diggers conduct business day to day, said Skip Applin, seafood technology supervisor with the DMR. Officials agreed that most Maine clammers are probably unaware that the change may be forthcoming.
Informing all Maine clammers of the proposed change, and winning their support, could present a formidable challenge. "We have well over 1,000 harvesters in Maine, far more than in any other state" in the region, Applin said.
Although the tag requirement is likely to be unpopular with clammers, officials say any attempt by the state to circumvent the federal regulations would probably render Maine clams unmarketable. "As unpalatable as this might be to harvesters, I don't think there will be any choice," said Applin.
Regional FDA official Martin Dowgert agreed that clammers will probably chafe at the new requirement. "Here in Massachusetts, I'm finding that diggers are complying pretty well with it, although change is difficult. I know that change is hard for me," Dowgert said.
Poole said clammers, like other fishermen, always complain about new fees or regulations. "I don't want to hear the crying because I know how much they make," he said, contending that clammers can earn as much as $18,000 a year, even as license fees increase and stocks dwindle.

People: Poole, Gerald Applin, Skip
