____________________________________________________________

Agencies to pen urchin fishery session agenda Jonesport meeting to stress s

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]30 Nov 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413714877?accountid=10457

Abstract: It is critical that OSHA meet with sea urchin boat operators and urchin divers, scallopers and representatives of other fisheries, said Richard Steifken, a compliance officer for OSHA. "It is also very critical that we get the word out accurately, and be understood correctly" concerning OSHA regulations that are presently focused on the urchin fishery. On Monday, Steifken boiled down OSHA's regulations on marine commercial urchin diving by writing a one-page summary from a 16-page brochure of regulations that deal with urchin diving. He requested that the DMR insert the safety information with each $89 urchin diver license issued. Next year, all handlers of urchins will be required to have a tender's license. The Jonesport meeting, which may take place on Monday, Dec. 6, would be first in a series to stress safety in the urchin industry, because of the death of 24-year-old Matthew Rice of Old Town on Oct. 16. Rice was killed on his first urchin dive in waters off Jonesport. Last week, OSHA handed a $9,750 fine to Timothy Victory of Jonesport, owner of the boat from which Rice was diving. Three other divers have died accidentally in the last 11 months while scuba diving for the shellfish.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Agencies+to+pen+urchin+fishery+session+agenda+Jonesport+meeting+to+stress+s&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-11-30&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: JONESPORT -- A joint meeting by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, the U.S. Coast Guard and the Department of Marine Resources will be held at 10 a.m. today at the administration's office in Augusta, to prepare an agenda for an urchin fishery safety conference early next week at Jonesport.
It is critical that OSHA meet with sea urchin boat operators and urchin divers, scallopers and representatives of other fisheries, said Richard Steifken, a compliance officer for OSHA. "It is also very critical that we get the word out accurately, and be understood correctly" concerning OSHA regulations that are presently focused on the urchin fishery.
On Monday, Steifken boiled down OSHA's regulations on marine commercial urchin diving by writing a one-page summary from a 16-page brochure of regulations that deal with urchin diving. He requested that the DMR insert the safety information with each $89 urchin diver license issued. Next year, all handlers of urchins will be required to have a tender's license.
The Jonesport meeting, which may take place on Monday, Dec. 6, would be first in a series to stress safety in the urchin industry, because of the death of 24-year-old Matthew Rice of Old Town on Oct. 16. Rice was killed on his first urchin dive in waters off Jonesport. Last week, OSHA handed a $9,750 fine to Timothy Victory of Jonesport, owner of the boat from which Rice was diving. Three other divers have died accidentally in the last 11 months while scuba diving for the shellfish.
Other safety meetings will be held for fishermen at Portland, Stonington and other smaller ports.
Meanwhile, the fine assessed to Victory has thrown the urchin industry into disarray. Boat owners, fearing they may violate OSHA regulations and be slapped with a fine, won't take divers out; and because divers can no longer hire boats, dealers aren't able to supply their markets.
To make matters even worse, some divers in the Jonesport area are considering buying their own boats to anchor on urchin beds, where they can continue diving. "You can understand how the divers feel about this -- they have bills to pay and families to feed. But this could result in even more accidents," said Stephen Geel, manager of the urchin division at O.W. and B.S. Look Inc. at Sawyer Cove.
"The captains are all shook up about these OSHA regulations," he said. Dwight Carver, Farrell Beal and Ossie Beal are three of the captains who have vowed they will no longer take out divers.
"The boat owners thought they were the employees, because we paid the checks to the divers, and the divers were paying the boat owners for taking them out," said Geel. "Now they find out from OSHA that the situation is the other way around. The captain is the employer and the diver is the employee."
The resulting mixup has paralyzed the urchin industry. "The buyers are running behind all over the state. For example, yesterday I shipped out six 60-pound totes of urchins for two divers. Last year at this time, I was shipping 100 to 150 totes every day. We've had some bad weather, but the real reason is the regulations."
For each 60-pound tote basket, the diver is paid $42. The diver pays 40 percent to the boat owner and retains 60 percent.
Last year, Geel had 12 divers supplying him. This year, four out-of-town divers are trying to stick with him. The others are odd-jobbing around the Moosabec Reach area until the meeting next week, when they hope OSHA and the industry will form some kind of truce that will enable people to go back to work. But both the divers and the boat operators don't want to work at the expense of safety.
"I work on a sales commission. That's my income. So, if the divers don't bring in anything, I don't ship out anything and don't get paid," he said. "Last year, December was my biggest month. If I don't make it in December, I'm out of business. It is that simple."

Company / organization: Name: Occupational Safety & Health Administration; NAICS: 926150

____________________________________________________________

Magnetite called `compass in the brain'

Author: Wood, Clair

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]12 Nov 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413707634?accountid=10457

Abstract: More than 90 years ago, and long before magnetite was found in animals, a French scientist named Emile Jarval speculated that humans might be influenced by the Earth's magnetic fields. He coined the term "sixth sense" for the ability that blind people have to avoid bumping into obstacles and believed it was a magnetic-based navigational sense that helped them to find their way in unfamiliar surroundings. Evidence for such a "compass in the brain" gained credence in 1992 when a team of researchers from Caltech, led by geobiologist Joseph Kirschvink, found crystals of magnetite in human brain tissue. Kirchvink suspected the presence of the tiny crystals, measuring only about one-millionth of an inch in diameter, from dark patches that appeared in some magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans of brains and which were apparently caused by the presence of iron. His team was able to isolate the magnetite crystals and show they were identical to those obtained from several species of magnetic bacteria discovered in 1975.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Magnetite+called+%60compass+in+the+brain%27&amp;author=Wood%2C+Clair&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-11-12&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Over the years researchers have found magnetite, a magnetic form of iron oxide, in a wide variety of animals. It has been found in the bodies of Monarch butterflies and may explain, at least in part, how they manage to find their way north from Mexico to the northern U.S. and Canada each year. Researchers at the University of Florida speculate that tiny crystals of the mineral act as an internal compass by which the butterfly orients itself to the Earth's magnetic field. Magetite crystals have also been found in honeybees, salmon, homing pigeons, and even the lowly mollusk.
In 1981, British workers found the first magnetic sense of direction in mammals, the European wood mouse. When the animals were transported over 40 meters from their burrows in specially constructed boxes that isolated them from odors in their surroundings and sunlight, they still unerringly found their ways back. When transported in a box that produced a magnetic field contrary to that of the Earth, however, they became disoriented and actually headed in almost a 180-degree path from their burrows.
More than 90 years ago, and long before magnetite was found in animals, a French scientist named Emile Jarval speculated that humans might be influenced by the Earth's magnetic fields. He coined the term "sixth sense" for the ability that blind people have to avoid bumping into obstacles and believed it was a magnetic-based navigational sense that helped them to find their way in unfamiliar surroundings. Evidence for such a "compass in the brain" gained credence in 1992 when a team of researchers from Caltech, led by geobiologist Joseph Kirschvink, found crystals of magnetite in human brain tissue. Kirchvink suspected the presence of the tiny crystals, measuring only about one-millionth of an inch in diameter, from dark patches that appeared in some magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans of brains and which were apparently caused by the presence of iron. His team was able to isolate the magnetite crystals and show they were identical to those obtained from several species of magnetic bacteria discovered in 1975.
Kirschvink is not willing to speculate on the function of magnetite in the human brain. It might be a residual sensing system, he says, or it could simply be a means of storing iron. The discovery triggered widespread interest at the time, not because of its possible function, but whether its presence could cause adverse health effects in combination with low-level electromagnetic fields. We live bathed in a sea of electromagnetic fields (EMFs) produced by household appliances, electric motors, and power lines to name but a few sources. Many people suspect that these fields may have some sort of adverse effect on humans but lacked a mechanism by which EMFs could interact with biological tissue. The presence of magnetite provided that link and inevitably headlines like, "Tiny Magnets Found in Human Brain!! May Cause Cancer!!" followed Kirschvink's announcement. Until recently, however, there was no evidence that EMFs have any effect on the brain.
A team of U.S. and Swiss researchers have found what seems to be a distinct response by the brain to weak magnetic fields. As reported in Science, persons subject to epileptic seizures were hooked up to electrodes that would measure brain activity and then subjected to weak magnetic fields. When the subjects were exposed to magnetic fields similar to those produced by household appliances, their frequency of epileptic-like response increased dramatically. One had 25 bursts of activity after the field came on compared to only three in the same time period without the fields. Similar increases were noted in other patients tested. Although only three severely-epileptic patients were tested, one researcher said, "I don't think this is an artifact. It's for real."
We may never know the answer to the intriguing question of why humans and homing pigeons both have magnetite on the brain. You can be sure, however, research on its response to EMFs is only beginning.
Clair Wood is a science instructor at Eastern Maine Technical College and the NEWS science columnist.

People: Kirschvink, Joseph

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Weapons+safety+workshop+slated&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-11-11&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- The Mid-Coast School of Technology's adult education department, in cooperation with the Knox County Sheriff's Department will offer a weapons safety workshop at 6:30 p.m. Friday, Dec. 10, at the school. The workshop will be followed by a practical session the next day, Dec. 11, at the Oyster River Range and Gun Shop in Warren.
The workshop, "Responsible Handgun Ownership for Private Citizens," will be taught by firearms instructors certified by the Maine Criminal Justice Academy assisted by other members of the Knox County Sheriff's Department. A registration fee of $10 will be charged, and registration is limited to 12 participants 18 years old or older.
To register, call the Mid-Coast School of Technology's adult education program.

Shell heaps

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]10 Nov 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413781424?accountid=10457

Abstract: The federal government is shelling out $455,000 of taxpayers' money to protect archaeologically significant heaps of oyster shells that were discarded over a 2,000-year period by Indians along the banks of the Damariscotta River.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Shell+heaps&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-11-10&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The federal government is shelling out $455,000 of taxpayers' money to protect archaeologically significant heaps of oyster shells that were discarded over a 2,000-year period by Indians along the banks of the Damariscotta River.
The grant was awarded to the Damariscotta River Association, a local land trust. They plan to use $415,000 to acquire easement on right privately owned lots where the shell heaps now stand.
The Damariscott River Association has made $40,000 of taxpayers' money, right off the top.
What are they going to do with the lots, clean throw up and sell them or are they going to come up with a way to protect archaeologically significant heaps of oyster shells that were discarded over a 2,000-year period for the good of the taxpayer.
If the federal government can waste money on things like this, how can itsexpect to use a successful health care plan? Alfred Jenkins Brewer

Attorney wants more data on Lamoine suit

Author: Kathy Harbour Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]05 Nov 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413729292?accountid=10457

Abstract: Financial backers of the lawsuit were the owners of the two shellfish companies in [Lamoine] -- Dean Smith of H.A. Boynton Shellfish Co. and Mike Briggs of Blue Ribbon Seafoods Inc. The two businesses were informed last year that their commercial waste would not be accepted once the town's landfill was closed and the transfer station erected. [Hans Huessey] said Briggs indicated he wanted "to keep the options open" for a possible appeal. The attorney said he had not spoken with any of the plaintiffs about an appeal but would hold a meeting with them once the court acts on his motion and he determines the feasibility of an appeal. Smith said that next month he and Briggs will begin their own shellfish composting operation on private land they will lease for five years in Lamoine. The two business owners had developed a proposal with Coastal Recycling to operate a pilot composting project using shellfish and mixed paper at the site of the town's former landfill. The two companies average 400 tons of shellfish waste yearly.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Attorney+wants+more+data+on+Lamoine+suit&amp;author=Kathy+Harbour+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-11-05&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: LAMOINE -- The attorney representing six property owners whose lawsuit against the town of Lamoine was dismissed last week in Hancock County Superior Court has filed a motion seeking more information from the court.
A decision on whether plaintiffs will appeal the court's decision to dismiss the lawsuit is expected by the end of this month.
Bangor attorney Hans Huessey, who represents the plaintiffs in the civil suit, said Wednesday he had filed a motion this week asking for specific reasons why the court agreed to summary judgment in the case.
The civil suit, filed in July, called for a revocation of the permit granted the town for the construction of the transfer station. The six landowners contended they were misled by selectmen about options for the location of the facility.
According to Huessey, one of the financial backers of the lawsuit requested that the motion be filed and that options be kept open for a possible appeal of the court's decision.
Last week, Superior Court Justice Nancy D. Mills dismissed the case brought against the town. Two days later, the Board of Environmental Protection dismissed a petition filed by the plaintiffs calling on the board to hold a public hearing to consider revoking a DEP permit granted the town.
The timing of the lawsuit has been cited as a critical factor in both the court's decision to dismiss the case and the BEP's decision not to grant a public hearing. Assistant Attorney General Janet McClintock argued that any appeal of a DEP permit must be made within a specific time limit. The lawsuit was filed several months after the date allowed.
Huessey had argued a timely appeal by the landowners had been impossible, as the plaintiffs contend they were misled by the selectmen. He argued that the information on which the lawsuit is based was not available until after spring of 1993 and after the time period set by the DEP had expired.
Financial backers of the lawsuit were the owners of the two shellfish companies in Lamoine -- Dean Smith of H.A. Boynton Shellfish Co. and Mike Briggs of Blue Ribbon Seafoods Inc. The two businesses were informed last year that their commercial waste would not be accepted once the town's landfill was closed and the transfer station erected.
Huessey said Briggs indicated he wanted "to keep the options open" for a possible appeal. The attorney said he had not spoken with any of the plaintiffs about an appeal but would hold a meeting with them once the court acts on his motion and he determines the feasibility of an appeal.
The attorney also is awaiting a written decision by the BEP listing the board's specific reasons for dismissing the petition before deciding whether to appeal that decision as well.
Smith indicated on Wednesday he has no interest in continuing his financial support for any potential appeal of the court's decision. "It's a game the town can play for a long time, but I don't really want to," Smith said. "In my mind, things are pretty dead in the water now."
Smith said that next month he and Briggs will begin their own shellfish composting operation on private land they will lease for five years in Lamoine. The two business owners had developed a proposal with Coastal Recycling to operate a pilot composting project using shellfish and mixed paper at the site of the town's former landfill. The two companies average 400 tons of shellfish waste yearly.
Lamoine selectmen postponed consideration of that proposal in August while the lawsuit was pending.
Smith said he has no plans to reintroduce the composting proposal to the Board of Selectmen and will instead take his shellfish waste to the land he and Briggs are leasing for that purpose.

People: Huessey, Hans Smith, Dean Briggs, Michael

Economic future to be discussed Three forums slated in Sunrise County

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]02 Nov 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413791003?accountid=10457

Abstract: Dianne Tilton, chairman of a five-member planning committee for the forum, said Monday that the second and third sessions will be held Jan. 3 and Feb. 28 at the technical college. Tilton is director of the Sunrise Economic Council with offices at Calais and Machias. Others serving on the committee with Tilton are Richard Burgess of Machias, manager of Bar Harbor Banking and Trust Co.; Glen Avery, executive director of the Washington County Regional Planning Commission, Machias; Byron Burke, city manager of Calais, and Mary Follis, city manager and director of community development at Eastport.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Economic+future+to+be+discussed+Three+forums+slated+in+Sunrise+County&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-11-02&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: CALAIS -- The future of economic development and business in the Washington County region will be discussed at the first in a series of three citizen forums from 6 to 8:30 p.m. Monday, Nov. 8, at the Technical College on River Road.
The Citizen Forum on Economic Development is sponsored by the Maine Department of Economic Development. According to Michael W. Aube, commissioner of DECD, the forum will focus on the region's strengths, weaknesses and opportunities and the economic relationship among area cities and towns.
The Nov. 8 meeting is expected to identify regional services and resources. This would include an analysis of current economic effectiveness, proposed economic development, and preparation of a report to the Legislature.
By June 1, 1994, the council is expected to prepare a system of development regions, and by Dec. 1, 1995, the council must provide a long-term plan and a report to the Legislature and the governor describing the economic activity in each region and the extent to which the goals and objectives are being met.
Dianne Tilton, chairman of a five-member planning committee for the forum, said Monday that the second and third sessions will be held Jan. 3 and Feb. 28 at the technical college. Tilton is director of the Sunrise Economic Council with offices at Calais and Machias.
Others serving on the committee with Tilton are Richard Burgess of Machias, manager of Bar Harbor Banking and Trust Co.; Glen Avery, executive director of the Washington County Regional Planning Commission, Machias; Byron Burke, city manager of Calais, and Mary Follis, city manager and director of community development at Eastport.
Tilton said she hoped the sessions would attract large groups of people willing to share ideas on how to develop business and generate a stronger economy. With a population of 35,308, the county should be large enough to warrant consideration as a region by itself, she said.
According to the council's initial executive summary of the county's characteristics, the forest industry owns more than 50 percent of the forest land. The county is a significant resource of marine species, including clams and worms, herring, marine shellfish, and aquaculture. Agricultural crops are a major source of income, providing `tips' for wreaths in November; a healthy blueberry industry that includes a harvest in August and other jobs in fields and in three major processing plants; and a cranberry industry that is gaining attention and marketing potential. In 1987, 85,734 acres in the county was farmed.
The county's population is projected to grow by 5.3 percent during the next decade, according to the Maine Department of Human Services.

People: Tilton, Dianne

Water program update planned

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]02 Nov 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413756144?accountid=10457

Abstract: The water quality monitoring program is being accomplished by students from Jonesport-Beals High School who are monitoring water in the town's Indian River district, and are operating out of the hatchery's laboratory on Pero Point, Beals.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Water+program+update+planned&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-11-02&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: JONESPORT -- The Planning Board will be given a progress report on the local water quality monitoring program at 7 p.m. Wednesday, Nov. 3, at the Municipal Building.
The report will be given by Dwayne Shaw, assistant manager of the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery, and Barbara Arter, water quality specialist for the University of Maine Cooperative Extension.
The water quality monitoring program is being accomplished by students from Jonesport-Beals High School who are monitoring water in the town's Indian River district, and are operating out of the hatchery's laboratory on Pero Point, Beals.
Also, the board will consider requests for building permits from people owning properties on Route 187. Deborah Roberts of Indian River wants to alter the roof of her house and David Lamson wants to build a sun deck on his home.

Beals hatchery a boon to clamming industry

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]01 Nov 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413880874?accountid=10457

Abstract: On Friday, [Richard Haehnel, Scarborough] and four of Scarborough's commercial diggers drove eight hours round trip to work their "volunteer" day at the hatchery. Don Roy, Ron Willette, Keith Googins and Terry Twomey cleaned 85 window-screened trays that had been floating since July in the sheltered waters of Mudhole Cove at [Beals]. Last year, 140 trays of clams were cleaned and sorted by supporters of Scarborough's clam conservation program. Since 1988, Scarborough has placed 4.5 million clams in its own flats. The town has expanded its original 50 acres for clam management, through water quality monitoring, to 150 acres. SEVEN MILLION baby clams at the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery will be ready to be placed on tidal flats in April at Swans Island, Islesboro, Friendship, Scarborough and Beals. Grading the clams (left photo) are (from left) Manager [Dwayne Shaw]; and Don Roy, Ron Willette, Keith Googins and Terry Twomey, all of Scarborough. Richard Haehnal (right photo), a Scarborough clam conservation officer and four volunteers will return to Beals next spring to receive 1 million clams for their town's clam flats. (NEWS Photos by Clayton Beal)

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Beals+hatchery+a+boon+to+clamming+industry&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-11-01&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BEALS -- One of the best town clam industries in the state is the one at Scarborough because it has local support from its taxpayers and clam diggers, and because clams grow faster in southern Maine's warmer waters.
For a two-year investment of $2,000 in the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery's clam program, Scarborough's clam industry expects to harvest a total of 1,000 bushels of clams, valued as much as $85,000 in 1995.
"We were paying $3,600 cash for a million (baby) clams from a private producer, until in 1988 we started working with the hatchery at Beals," said Richard Haehnel, Scarborough's clam conservation officer.
"Our annual commitment to the hatchery is $2,000 and one full day of work at the hatchery for each of our commercial diggers." The hatchery is one of the best deals in the business, he said.
On Friday, Haehnel and four of Scarborough's commercial diggers drove eight hours round trip to work their "volunteer" day at the hatchery. Don Roy, Ron Willette, Keith Googins and Terry Twomey cleaned 85 window-screened trays that had been floating since July in the sheltered waters of Mudhole Cove at Beals.
After the cleaning, baby clams were graded according to size; young mussels were culled from among the clams; and the graded clams were packaged in 1-foot-square plastic bags. The 2-liter bags of clams will be placed in 24 secure metal cages, where the clams will spend the winter.
Next April, Haehnel and his diggers will return to the island to collect their 1 million share of the hatchery's 11 million clams.
"We will plant them in some of our best growing areas and where they will be protected against premature digging," he said. "Within two years, at least 50 percent of those clams will be 2 inches long and ready to be harvested commercially. We are fortunate down this way, because clams grow faster. It would take three years for clams up around Beals to reach the same size for commercial use."
Last year, 140 trays of clams were cleaned and sorted by supporters of Scarborough's clam conservation program. Since 1988, Scarborough has placed 4.5 million clams in its own flats. The town has expanded its original 50 acres for clam management, through water quality monitoring, to 150 acres.
The 85 trays processed Friday were taken from a total of 400 trays containing 11 million clams. The 85 were brought to the hatchery last week by Dwayne Shaw, the hatchery's assistant manager. High winds prevented Shaw from bringing more trays from their moorings.
Haehnel said his diggers are willing to donate a day of their time to the hatchery because their generosity earns them their annual commercial license three days before licenses go on sale at the town office.
The town has 25 commercial licenses to offer, including three nonresident commercial licenses. Twenty-three of the 25 commercial diggers have donated 12 or more hours to the hatchery.
Additionally, 25 two-peck licenses will be sold, and 240 one-peck recreational licenses will be available early in 1994. Any Scarborough resident age 65 or over can receive a free license to dig one peck of clams each day.
"If we didn't work hard and show it was a good and aggressive clam management plan, we wouldn't get the money" for the hatchery, enforcement and other program costs, Haehnel said. "We got started with a $5,000 grant from the Maine Aquaculture program administered by the University of Maine. We have given that back in time."
Last May, the hatchery received a $2,500 grant from Shore Stewards Trust of Ellsworth to build a marine laboratory to monitor the water quality over shellfish beds in the Moosabec Reach area.
Shaw and Lynn Alley, biology and science teacher at Jonesport-Beals High School, cooperated and opened the lab last June. Students are involved in the monitoring program. Next year, a grant of $1,000 from the Community Foundation will support the water project.
The hatchery and its programs have helped many clam programs in the Down East area. This year, millions of clams will be received by Swans Island, Islesboro and Friendship.
Illustration Caption: SEVEN MILLION baby clams at the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery will be ready to be placed on tidal flats in April at Swans Island, Islesboro, Friendship, Scarborough and Beals. Grading the clams (left photo) are (from left) Manager Dwayne Shaw; and Don Roy, Ron Willette, Keith Googins and Terry Twomey, all of Scarborough. Richard Haehnal (right photo), a Scarborough clam conservation officer and four volunteers will return to Beals next spring to receive 1 million clams for their town's clam flats. (NEWS Photos by Clayton Beal)

People: Richard Haehnel, Scarborough Shaw, Dwayne

Grant to fund aquaculture specialist post

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]01 Nov 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413816147?accountid=10457

Abstract: Karen Sparrow, Pittston, Chairwoman of the Time & Tide RC&D Council -- which serves Androscoggin, Knox, Lincoln, Kennebec, Sagadahoc and Waldo counties -- said that the aquaculture specialist initiative is designed to develop aquaculture-related businesses in the district.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Grant+to+fund+aquaculture+specialist+post&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-11-01&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: WALDOBORO -- The Time & Tide Resource Conservation and Development Council has received approval from the Maine Association of RC&D Areas to receive $15,000 for the Time & Tide Council's aquaculture specialist initiative.
Karen Sparrow, Pittston, Chairwoman of the Time & Tide RC&D Council -- which serves Androscoggin, Knox, Lincoln, Kennebec, Sagadahoc and Waldo counties -- said that the aquaculture specialist initiative is designed to develop aquaculture-related businesses in the district.
The aquaculture specialist position will work to develop the shad hatchery that has been successful for the last two years at the former squash factory in Waldoboro, and will attempt to increase the number of fish stocked in Maine rivers.
The specialist will also work with people who want to develop oyster businesses for diversification of their income, and several other initiatives that are on the cutting edge of technology.
Sparrow said that the $15,000 grant is approximately 25 percent of the total needs for one year and is a great start in the fund-raising effort to sustain this on the council for the betterment and improvement of the natural resource.

Volunteers, officials remember the day Kilkenney Stream died

Author: Kathy Harbour Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]01 Nov 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413747069?accountid=10457

Abstract: According to Jim Sohns, the water bureau supervisor at the Department of Environmental Protection's office in Bangor, investigators from his office had been called in to look at Kilkenney Stream by the time volunteers from Frenchman Bay Conservancy got there. "The whole stream was septic," Sohns said this week. Describing the odor of the stream as akin to a septic tank, Sohns said such polluted water could sustain absolutely no life until the stream has been able to flush itself over the course of several rains and weeks. As explained by Sohns, the pollution occurred when a pipeline from the blueberry processing plant ruptured or came apart at the headwaters of Kilkenney Stream.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Volunteers%2C+officials+remember+the+day+Kilkenney+Stream+died&amp;author=Kathy+Harbour+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-11-01&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: HANCOCK -- A small group of volunteers from the Frenchman Bay Conservancy were there the day it seemed the stream had died.
"The water smelled very bad," Gale McCullough said of the odor coming from Kilkenney Stream at the end of August. "We took a dissolved oxygen test ... it showed the water was dead."
The volunteers had been conducting water-quality monitoring tests at 12 sites in Hancock, Sullivan and Sorrento throughout the summer, as part of their collaborative efforts with the Department of Marine Resources and the state's Shore Stewards Partnership program.
On that day in late August, the group had inadvertantly stumbled upon the rancid effects of pollution from a nearby blueberry processing plant operated by Hancock Foods Inc.
According to Jim Sohns, the water bureau supervisor at the Department of Environmental Protection's office in Bangor, investigators from his office had been called in to look at Kilkenney Stream by the time volunteers from Frenchman Bay Conservancy got there.
"The whole stream was septic," Sohns said this week. Describing the odor of the stream as akin to a septic tank, Sohns said such polluted water could sustain absolutely no life until the stream has been able to flush itself over the course of several rains and weeks.
As explained by Sohns, the pollution occurred when a pipeline from the blueberry processing plant ruptured or came apart at the headwaters of Kilkenney Stream.
For about 24 hours, the blueberry process, a liquid high in sugar content, went directly into the stream. The stream turned a dark shade of purple, the blue herons left and all life died in the stream that winds its way down to the Skillings River.
A neighbor who uses water from the stream alerted the DEP at about the same time that the company discovered the ruptured pipe.
"There is no question (Hancock Foods) is the source of zero oxygen in that stream," Sohns said. "The stream can flush itself out, but people were not able to use the water until then."
Although the stream has not been tested recently, Sohns said he assumed enough time has elapsed for life to once again return to the stream.
The case has been referred to the DEP's Augusta office, with a consent agreement expected to be worked out with the company. A fine also is pending, Sohns said.
For McCullough and others who have gone out twice each month to the 12 sites, it was a good lesson in why the waters of Frenchman Bay should be considered a vital resource.
"We're just ordinary people who care about water," McCullough said in recent days. "Water is like the blood of the place; it carries life. We've been spending one season with these (12) sites, getting to know the seasonal ebb and flow of a place."
Quick to describe the group's role as giving support to those who have the scientific expertise to monitor water quality, McCullough said most of the water tests are conducted at DMR's laboratory in Lamoine.
That office conducts tests that ultimately determine whether a shoreline area can be open to the harvesting of healthy shellfish.
The work by Frenchman Bay Conservancy members means that additional information can be fed to DMR's office about areas that are closed to shellfish harvesting. The group has pledged to continue to monitor the same areas for five years.
The Shore Stewards Partnership involves many groups along the Gulf of Maine.

People: McCullough, Gale Sohns, Jim

Grant to protect old shell heaps

Author: (AP)

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]27 Oct 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413757430?accountid=10457

Abstract: The federal government is shelling out $455,000 to protect archaeologically significant heaps of oyster shells that were discarded...

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Grant+to+protect+old+shell+heaps&amp;author=%28AP%29&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-10-27&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: DAMARISCOTTA -- The federal government is shelling out $455,000 to protect archaeologically significant heaps of oyster shells that were discarded over a 2,000-year period by Indians along the banks of the Damariscotta River.
The grant was awarded to the Damariscotta River Association, a local land trust, which plans to use $415,000 to acquire easements on eight privately owned lots where the shell heaps now stand.

Students investigate Seal Harbor pollution MDI project may benefit residents, water supply

Author: Kathy Harbour Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]26 Oct 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413870484?accountid=10457

Abstract: For [Paul Anderson], the work being done this fall by the MDI students and again in the spring eventually may help the Seal Harbor community correct the pollution problem in the area. According to Anderson, whose office conducts the tests that can open or close shellfish harvesting areas, most of the eastern shore of the island remains closed to clam and mussel harvesting. The pollution problem extends from Salisbury Cove to Sand Beach, and from Sand Beach to Seawall. Anderson attributes much of the problem to the several sewage treatment plants in the area. One plant is adjacent to Stanley Brook in Seal Harbor, he said, adding that he is not certain it will be identified as a source of the pollution in the stream. In Bar Harbor, Northeast Harbor and Southwest Harbor the pleasure boats add to the pollution, he said. Required by law to dump their bilge three miles out, many do not comply. In some areas, there are discharges into the ocean from private residences.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Students+investigate+Seal+Harbor+pollution+MDI+project+may+benefit+residents%2C+water+supply&amp;author=Kathy+Harbour+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-10-26&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The headline on a story about students investigating pollution in Seal Harbor was misleading in that it suggested problems with the town's water supply. The students' project has nothing to do with the town's water supply, which is Jordan Pond.
MOUNT DESERT ISLAND -- Mount Desert Island high school students, armed with test tubes and curiosity, are involved in some real-world scientific sleuthing at a Seal Harbor stream.
Sophomores in Jane Disney's biology classes at MDI High School are testing the fresh water of Stanley Brook and the salt water at Seal Harbor as participants in the state's Shore Stewards Partnership, a program that involves many groups along the Gulf of Maine.
The students have taken samples of water at several sites in Seal Harbor each week this month, returning to the classroom to conduct water-quality tests and to design experiments. As described by Disney, the "hands-on" science is, in part, teaching students how it feels "to participate in an important endeavor."
With water quality along the southeastern shores of Mount Desert Island described as "gloomy" by Department of Marine Resources biologist Paul Anderson, the students are tracking down sources of pollution flowing into Seal Harbor.
Students recently followed Stanley Brook into the woods and discovered an abandoned landfill. The water running out of pipes from the dump was surprisingly high in bacteria, Disney said.
"We know where the stream is clean and where it is dirty. But we haven't identified the source," Disney said Monday, saying the landfill is a top suspect. Hooked on the mystery, students have consulted maps, contacted homeowners and looked for other possible sources.
Aware that the waters of Jordan Pond at the head of the stream are clean, the students continue to look for one or several sources of pollution that eventually end up in Stanley Brook and empty into the salt water of Seal Harbor.
The three-year project is part of a larger project that includes the DMR laboratory in Lamoine and volunteers from the Frenchman Bay Conservancy.
Disney and Gail McCullough, from the Frenchman Bay Conservancy, applied for a grant and received start-up funding for the project from the Shore Stewards Partnership, the University of Maine Cooperative Extension and the Maine Community Foundation.
The state has encouraged such partnerships between monitoring groups and high schools, with 20 high schools expected to be involved statewide with monitoring projects in the Gulf of Maine.
Volunteers from the conservancy are conducting similar monitoring projects at several sites in Sullivan and Sorrento, including Long Cove, the Head of Flanders Bay and Kilkenny Cove. That investigation already has turned up evidence of a high fecal load in a tributary coming into Long Cove in Sullivan.
For Anderson, the work being done this fall by the MDI students and again in the spring eventually may help the Seal Harbor community correct the pollution problem in the area. According to Anderson, whose office conducts the tests that can open or close shellfish harvesting areas, most of the eastern shore of the island remains closed to clam and mussel harvesting.
The pollution problem extends from Salisbury Cove to Sand Beach, and from Sand Beach to Seawall. Anderson attributes much of the problem to the several sewage treatment plants in the area. One plant is adjacent to Stanley Brook in Seal Harbor, he said, adding that he is not certain it will be identified as a source of the pollution in the stream.
In Bar Harbor, Northeast Harbor and Southwest Harbor the pleasure boats add to the pollution, he said. Required by law to dump their bilge three miles out, many do not comply. In some areas, there are discharges into the ocean from private residences.
"It's a gloomy picture," Anderson said, in describing the potential sources contributing to pollution on the MDI shores. A biologist who says his job is "making sure people eat clean clams," Anderson said the high school water-quality project will be illuminating for the students. "Not everything (in the area) is perfect and pretty. They'll see that there is human stress on the environment right in their own back yards."
In addition to working on some home-grown mysteries, students also may emerge from the experience "able to think more deeply about the impact of water quality" on different species. Disney hopes the field research will give students the flavor of scientific inquiry. "They will learn what it means to be committed to something important," she said.

____________________________________________________________

Clam monitoring team to develop river plan Survey to provide ideas for St. Croix management

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]21 Oct 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413727388?accountid=10457

Abstract: The sanitary survey was compiled by Paul S. Anderson of the Department of Marine Resources laboratory at Lamoine for use by the DMR and the bi-country estuary project. He was assisted by marine biologists John C. Fendl of the DMR laboratory at Lamoine and David Clifford of East Machias. The report found that a number of coves in the study area may contain "significant populations" of softshell clams. These include Elliott Flats, Loring Cove, Broad Cove, Mill Cove and Lewis Cove. Those populations will be surveyed in greater detail next year. Others participating in the inter-agency meeting at the Federal Building were Eve Preston, community development director for Calais; James Sohns of the Department of Environmental Protection; Rob Rainer of St. Andrews, coordinator of the estuary project; Dana Nelson of Cherryfield, executive director of Down East Resource Conservation & Development; John Hewett, executive director of the U.S. Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service, Machias; David Garcelon, soil scientist, Soil Conservation Service; and Nathan Pennell, office manager for the Washington County Soil & Water Conservation District.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Clam+monitoring+team+to+develop+river+plan+Survey+to+provide+ideas+for+St.+Croix+management&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-10-21&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: MACHIAS -- An international clam monitoring team, functioning under the administrative umbrella of the St. Croix River Estuary Project, met Tuesday and discussed a recently completed sanitary survey by the Department of Marine Resources.
The survey's results will be used with clam population surveys and a water monitoring program to develop an environmental management plan for the St. Croix River Estyary and Chamcook Harbour, New Brunswick.
Lee Sochasky, executive director of the St. Croix International Waterway Commission, presided at the meeting. She initiated a public appeal to all property owners on the river to become participants in the water monitoring program. "We will need 20 to 30 people for the program next year," she said.
Under the new Shore Stewards program funded by the Maine State Planning Office the volunteers will be trained to gather the weekly water samples. Water sampling kits will be provided. Sampling will take less than one hour and no travel will be required. The program is also funded, in part, by Environment Canada.
The sanitary survey was compiled by Paul S. Anderson of the Department of Marine Resources laboratory at Lamoine for use by the DMR and the bi-country estuary project. He was assisted by marine biologists John C. Fendl of the DMR laboratory at Lamoine and David Clifford of East Machias.
Anderson reviewed the study that was compiled last week to include the United States shores of the river from Elliott Flats at Calais to Gleason Cove in Perry. The area was previously surveyed by Harold Winters in 1979. Much of the area discussed in the report had never been surveyed for septic problems prior to the survey conducted in 1993.
According to the study, significant discharges into the river include: municipal sewage treatment plants at Baileyville, Milltown, and Calais and St Stephen, N.B., and paper mills at Woodland and Milltown. "These factors have caused the shores and flats of the St. Croix River estuary to be closed to the harvest of shellfish since August 22, 1969," the report stated.
Since 1969, the closure has been south to Gleason Point in Perry.
The report found that a number of coves in the study area may contain "significant populations" of softshell clams. These include Elliott Flats, Loring Cove, Broad Cove, Mill Cove and Lewis Cove. Those populations will be surveyed in greater detail next year.
Anderson explained that with recent improvements to the Calais municipal sewage treatment plant and renewed interest in the St. Croix Waterway by the St. Croix Waterway Commission, the DMR undertook the re-evaluation and shoreline survey project to identify problem areas and encourage pollution abatement.
The survey was conducted last May and June by the DMR. Water quality sampling efforts were increased during the summer, with additional help from Philip Holmes of the Waterway Commission.
Anderson concluded that the river should remain closed to all harvesting of clams until known sewage problems are corrected and water quality improvesd noticeably.
About 22 sources of sewage pollution were identified during the survey. They include malfunctioning septic systems, septic tank overflow pipes, licensed overboard discharges, active straight pipes, and sink drains. Details of the survey are to be shared with municipal officials.
Others participating in the inter-agency meeting at the Federal Building were Eve Preston, community development director for Calais; James Sohns of the Department of Environmental Protection; Rob Rainer of St. Andrews, coordinator of the estuary project; Dana Nelson of Cherryfield, executive director of Down East Resource Conservation & Development; John Hewett, executive director of the U.S. Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service, Machias; David Garcelon, soil scientist, Soil Conservation Service; and Nathan Pennell, office manager for the Washington County Soil & Water Conservation District.
Illustration Caption: PAUL ANDERSON (left) of the Department of Marine Resources and Robert Rainer, coordinator of water quality monitoring for the international St. Croix River Estuary Project, designated several sources of water pollution in the waterway at a meeting Tuesday. Biddeford faces fine for pollution of river

Author: (AP)

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]19 Oct 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413874847?accountid=10457

Abstract: This city may be fined $125,000 for discharging raw sewage and pollutants into the Saco River, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency said Monday.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Biddeford+faces+fine+for+pollution+of+river&amp;author=%28AP%29&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-10-19&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BIDDEFORD -- This city may be fined $125,000 for discharging raw sewage and pollutants into the Saco River, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency said Monday.
The EPA accused the city of violating the Clean Water Act since 1986 by occasionally releasing untreated and partially treated wastewater into the Saco River.
Periodic government inspections of the treatment plant revealed that operation and maintenance were poor, the EPA said. In addition, the laboratory sampling and analysis methods were substandard, the agency said.
The Biddeford plant discharges 2.6 million gallons of wastewater into the Saco River each day.
The pollutants may deplete the water's oxygen supply and harm aquatic life, while high levels of fecal coliform may be a health hazard to humans and lead to the closing of shellfish beds, the agency said.

Block `boondoggle'

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]14 Oct 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413734845?accountid=10457

Abstract: [Janet Myers]' statements that the wetlands and seagrass beds of the upper bay are unimportant are just plain wrong and only reveal an ignorance of how the Gulf of Maine's ecosystem works. The upper Penobscot Bay is a very important part of the spawning and nursery grounds for most of the recreationally and commercially fished species of Maine. For cod, haddock, flounder and dozens of other fish and shellfish species, the shallows of the upper Penobscot Bay area are crucial juvenile nursery areas, both for them and for the smaller fish they feed on. ...

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Block+%60boondoggle%27&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-10-14&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The ridiculous comments of MDOT employee Janet Myers trying to justify the construction of a chippermill cargo port in Sears Island only serve to prove that the decision by the EPA, the National Marine Fisheries Service, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, the Army Corps of Engineers and everyone else that believes in Maine's commercial and recreational fishery to oppose construction of the Sears Island woodchip terminal in the upper estuary of Penobscot Bay, is a decision wisely taken.
Myers' statements that the wetlands and seagrass beds of the upper bay are unimportant are just plain wrong and only reveal an ignorance of how the Gulf of Maine's ecosystem works. The upper Penobscot Bay is a very important part of the spawning and nursery grounds for most of the recreationally and commercially fished species of Maine. For cod, haddock, flounder and dozens of other fish and shellfish species, the shallows of the upper Penobscot Bay area are crucial juvenile nursery areas, both for them and for the smaller fish they feed on. ...
Wrecking the marshes and seagrass beds of the area to provide profits for a tiny international trade organization is not only bad science, but it is also bad economics. The experience in other parts of the eastern United States with this trade cabal is that they put local woodmills and furniture makers out of business by paying a slightly better price per cord than local businesses can offer. ...
The solution? Mack Point is more than adequate to handle central Maine's export needs. With the AES project kaput, there's no longer any worry about the coal powder from AES coal shipments contaminating wood shipments at Mack Point, so wood may safely, sustainably be sent through Mack Point.
Mainers have a history of doing the sensible thing. Blocking the Sears Island boondoggle is one of those sensible things, for the good of the fishermen, lumber companies, furniture makers and everyone else that makes their livelihood from Maine's natural bounty. Ron Huber, director Coastal Waters Project Rockland

People: Myers, Janet

Brooklin selectmen to pursue harbor ordinance

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]13 Oct 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413707310?accountid=10457

Abstract: [Louis Rouviere] said he interpreted an incident last week in which bait believed to belong to [James Williams] was spread all over the bar as a protest against the fisherman's activities. Williams has been accused by local fishermen of leaving shellfish waste and bait littering the scenic harbor. The harbor has been cleaner with the advent of autumn. Lobstermen will have pulled in their traps by early November, and there will be no market for the bait stored in the harbor for sale to fishermen in other seasons, Rouviere said.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Brooklin+selectmen+to+pursue+harbor+ordinance&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-10-13&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BROOKLIN -- Despite improved conditions at Naskeag Harbor, the Board of Selectmen still intends to pursue adoption of a landing ordinance.
Such an ordinance would govern use of the area from the landing and parking lot to the high-water mark.
Selectmen Louis Rouviere said no new reports of rats or trash being dumped at the harbor have surfaced, yet the board will spend the winter framing an ordinance that would go into effect next spring to prevent the kinds of problems seen this summer.
In late summer, residents reported seeing rats at the harbor parking area, where trash was overflowing from a town dumpster. The dumpster was removed to discourage dumping, which had included large items such as tires and a water heater.
Not long before, bait totes owned by James Williams of Burnt Cove Seafood in Stonington broke loose and beached in front of homes in Center Harbor.
Rouviere said he interpreted an incident last week in which bait believed to belong to Williams was spread all over the bar as a protest against the fisherman's activities. Williams has been accused by local fishermen of leaving shellfish waste and bait littering the scenic harbor.
Some of the local fishermen reportedly resent the use of the harbor by a significant number of competitors from other towns, who pay no fee to use the area the town must maintain.
Rouviere believes fishermen from outside the town should pay a fee to cover maintenance of the parking lot, which is used frequently by heavy trucks, and maintenance of the portable toilet.
The harbor has been cleaner with the advent of autumn. Lobstermen will have pulled in their traps by early November, and there will be no market for the bait stored in the harbor for sale to fishermen in other seasons, Rouviere said.
Trash and waste at the harbor have been at issue since at least spring.

People: Rouviere, Louis Williams, James

Publication year: 1993

____________________________________________________________

Blessing of animals keeps church busy

Author: Diana Graettinger Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]09 Oct 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413811054?accountid=10457

Abstract: The Rev. Walter Dickhaut, interim priest, and the Rev. John Hedger, retired, conducted the blessing. Although it is unusual to see such a collection of animals inside a church, parishioners at St. Francis seemed charmed by the assembly of children and adults who approached the altar with their pets. Before the service began, Dickhaut explained the blessing. "The first part has to do with St. Francis, the patron saint of the parish; a person who was particularly and peculiarly sensitive to other creatures. ...," he said, "not only animals, but growing things, the stars, the moon, and planets. The other part is simply a recognition of the interrelatedness of all creation and all creatures." THE REV. Walter Dickhaut and 7-year-old Misha Bridges of Sedgwick have a rabbit named Jack in hand for the blessing of the animals Sunday at St. Francis by the Sea Episcopal Church. (NEWS Photo by Diana Graettinger)

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Blessing+of+animals+keeps+church+busy&amp;author=Diana+Graettinger+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-10-09&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BLUE HILL -- Imagine God's pleasure on Sunday, when some of his most gentle creatures -- dogs, cats, rabbits, a llama, a hermit crab and a stuffed giraffe -- were at his house for the annual blessing of the animals.
The blessing was held at St. Francis by the Sea Episcopal Church, a white two-story wooden church in Blue Hill, located on a quiet section of Route 177.
The rather austere interior of the church, with its single wooden cross, simple altar and white wooden pews, was a beehive of activity Sunday as dogs and cats curiously eyed each other while waiting their turn to walk to the altar for the blessing.
This was the fourth year area residents had brought their pets to the service to celebrate the love that exists between humans and animals.
The Rev. Walter Dickhaut, interim priest, and the Rev. John Hedger, retired, conducted the blessing. Although it is unusual to see such a collection of animals inside a church, parishioners at St. Francis seemed charmed by the assembly of children and adults who approached the altar with their pets.
The largest animal present was a large black llama that was brought by Mark and Dana Llewellyn of Monroe. Baxter, a 2 1/2-year-old llama, is one of 10 llamas at the Llewellyns' Apple Hill Llama Farm.
"We are primarily breeders, but we have wool production with our llamas, and we also do backpacking," Dana Llewellyn said. She said she enjoyed bringing their llama to church. "This church has never had the honor of having a llama here, and our llama has never had the honor of being blessed," she said.
One young boy brought along a picture of his animal to be blessed, while another small boy, dressed in a suit and tie, proudly held up his hermit crab. Hermit crabs have no outer shell of their own and live in the empty shells of suitable mollusks. The crab that came to church Sunday was dressed in an attractive brown shell and seemed unconcerned by the attention it generated.
Also in the church were a young girl with a large fuzzy brown rabbit whose nose twitched during the entire proceeding, and a small baby who held out a small green-and-white stuffed giraffe that had seen hours of cuddling.
Before the service began, Dickhaut explained the blessing. "The first part has to do with St. Francis, the patron saint of the parish; a person who was particularly and peculiarly sensitive to other creatures. ...," he said, "not only animals, but growing things, the stars, the moon, and planets. The other part is simply a recognition of the interrelatedness of all creation and all creatures."
Hedger said he had attended a similar ceremony in New York City, where elephants, giraffes and camels were blessed. "Probably, because Barnum & Bailey Circus was in town at the time, and it was a wonderful thing to see," he said.
St. Francis of Assisi was born in Italy, the son of a cloth merchant. During his life, he rejected all earthly trappings and founded the Franciscan order. He used to preach to the poor and considered all of God's creatures equally important to the order of the universe. Born in 1181 or 82, he died Oct. 3, 1226. He was canonized on July 15, 1228. His feast day is Oct. 4.
Dickhaut said the blessing of the animals was held each year on the Sunday closest to the day of the commemoration of St. Francis.
Hedger concurred that the annual blessing evolved from the fact that the church is named after St. Francis.
"The pattern of the life of Saint Francis was to live with all creatures and bless all creatures. Historically, the blessing of animals has been a part of the Anglican church in Europe. We are carrying on that which has been done in many other Episcopal churches in this country, too," he said.
Illustration Caption: THE REV. Walter Dickhaut (left) and 7-year-old Misha Bridges of Sedgwick have a rabbit named Jack in hand for the blessing of the animals Sunday at St. Francis by the Sea Episcopal Church. (NEWS Photo by Diana Graettinger)

People: Dickhaut, Walter Hedger, John

Stevens, his victim, is being held at the same facility on several assault charges, and is recovering from a suicide attempt two weeks ago when he slashed his wrist with a razor blade. Cut lines snip fishermen's pact Traps a casualty of battle in competitive lobster war

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]30 Sep 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413754882?accountid=10457

Abstract: The harbor master for the Fox Island Thorofare area said Wednesday that a Stonington man's arrest for cutting several hundred lobster traps illustrates the continuing territorial battles among area fishermen. Foy W. Brown, one of North Haven's two harbor masters, said that several of his own traps were among those cut on Monday allegedly by lobsterman Sidney Eaton, 49, of Stonington, who was arrested Tuesday on Class C criminal mischief charges. Brown said Eaton has fished in the area for 30 years or more, and that territorial disputes usually have erupted between fishermen from North Haven and Vinalhaven.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Cut+lines+snip+fishermen%27s+pact+Traps+a+casualty+of+battle+in+competitive+lobster+war&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-09-30&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: NORTH HAVEN -- The harbor master for the Fox Island Thorofare area said Wednesday that a Stonington man's arrest for cutting several hundred lobster traps illustrates the continuing territorial battles among area fishermen.
Foy W. Brown, one of North Haven's two harbor masters, said that several of his own traps were among those cut on Monday allegedly by lobsterman Sidney Eaton, 49, of Stonington, who was arrested Tuesday on Class C criminal mischief charges.
The Department of Marine Patrol estimates that between 600 and 800 traps were cut, resulting in about $20,000 in property damage, not including the loss of unharvested shellfish.
Officials said Eaton had been observed cutting the trap lines in the area Monday afternoon. He was released on bail from the Hancock County Jail later on Tuesday.
Brown said that at least 10 fishermen's traps were damaged. One North Haven fisherman lost 300, and two brothers lost 200 between them, he estimated.
Brown said Eaton has fished in the area for 30 years or more, and that territorial disputes usually have erupted between fishermen from North Haven and Vinalhaven.
He said Eaton's alleged action may have been in retaliation for damage to his own traps by fishermen from one of the other towns.
As many as half of the fishermen affected by Monday's incident are relative newcomers to the fishery, Brown said.
The harbor master believes competition is hot in the area because of the relatively rich lobster resource there, adding that North Haven fishermen resent the influx of larger numbers of competitors from other, often larger, towns.
But Brown said he was unaware of any recent quarrels between Eaton and others until this week.
Tensions erupted in the form of trap cutting in the opposite end of the Thorofare early this summer, but incidents were resolved when North Haven and Vinalhaven fishermen made a gentlemen's agreement on boundaries.

People: Brown, Foy W Eaton, Sidney

Stonington man faces charges for cutting trap lines Officials say gear lost in incident was worth $20,000

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]29 Sep 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413695983?accountid=10457

Abstract: According to [Charles Rommell], [Sidney Eaton] was observed cutting the traps in Fox Island Thorofare Monday afternoon. Upon sighting Eaton during an investigation of the area Tuesday morning, the Marine Patrol vessel, Northern Lights, and a Coast Guard vessel escorted Eaton into Stonington Harbor, waiting to board his boat until landing because of rough seas. Officers from the Marine Patrol and Maine State Police met Eaton in the harbor, Rommell said. The fisherman was arrested without incident and transported to the Hancock County Jail, where Eaton later was released on bail.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Stonington+man+faces+charges+for+cutting+trap+lines+Officials+say+gear+lost+in+incident+was+worth+%2420%2C000&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-09-29&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: STONINGTON -- A local man was arrested on Class C criminal mischief charges Tuesday in connection with the cutting of ropes on 600 to 800 lobster traps. The traps represented approximately $20,000 in property damage, not including the effect on income of any shellfish lost in the incident.
Lobster fisherman Sidney Eaton, 49, of Stonington was arrested after his 25-foot lobster boat was escorted by law enforcement officials into the local harbor Tuesday morning, said Sgt. Charles Rommell of the Maine Department of Marine Patrol.
Rommell said several officers from three agencies became involved in the apprehension because of shared jurisdictional responsibility and a concern that Eaton might be armed.
According to Rommell, Eaton was observed cutting the traps in Fox Island Thorofare Monday afternoon. Upon sighting Eaton during an investigation of the area Tuesday morning, the Marine Patrol vessel, Northern Lights, and a Coast Guard vessel escorted Eaton into Stonington Harbor, waiting to board his boat until landing because of rough seas.
Eaton was found to be carrying a .45-caliber revolver, Rommell said. Officials will investigate whether any prior criminal record would put Eaton in violation for possession of firearms.
Officers from the Marine Patrol and Maine State Police met Eaton in the harbor, Rommell said. The fisherman was arrested without incident and transported to the Hancock County Jail, where Eaton later was released on bail.
A continuing investigation has not yet determined the ownership of all the damaged traps, and Rommell had no comment on possible motivation behind the incident.
Rommel said trap molestation is not common, but does happen occasionally all along the coast. The amount of property damage involved in this case was greater than average, he said.
"That is a large amount of gear," the officer said.
If convicted, Eaton could lose his fishing license for three years. Rommell said tampering with traps is considered by Marine Patrol to be among the most serious of offenses.

People: Eaton, Sidney Rommell, Charles

Dragon gets cool reception on Georges River Fishermen, others raise concerns about dredging

Author: Walter Griffin Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]28 Sep 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413711755?accountid=10457

Abstract: Although he agreed there was a problem with "the channel situation," [Peter Lammert] reminded those attending the meeting that Dragon Products accounted for one-third of the town's tax base. He speculated that the cement plant might be attracted to Thomaston because rail access to its waterfront property would not disrupt the tranquility of a residential neighborhood, as would be the case in Rockland. Selectman Stephen Mazzeo agreed. Mazzeo said he was present at a recent meeting between Dragon executives and Rockland officials. He said the company indicated to him that "Thomaston didn't fit into the process. ... They really prefer to do their hauling out of Rockland." James McCammett, a retired cement plant executive, said the company has the technology to perform the task. He said a similar project was studied 35 years ago, "because I was the one who did it." McCammett said Dragon needs to expand its customer base to remain in business. He assured the board that Dragon would abide by its regulations if it decided to locate a barge facility in town.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Dragon+gets+cool+reception+on+Georges+River+Fishermen%2C+others+raise+concerns+about+dredging&amp;author=Walter+Griffin+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-09-28&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: THOMASTON -- With the Georges River on the verge of becoming pollution-free and a thriving fishery once again, caution was raised over the idea of dredging the river to accommodate barge traffic for Dragon Products.
Fishermen, advocates for the environment and defenders of the river met with the Board of Selectmen Monday to warn against giving blanket support to Dragon in the event the company attempted to barge cement down river.
The meeting was also attended by residents who warned against dismissing Dragon out of hand without giving the company's plans a fair hearing.
Dragon officials have given no indication they intend to ship cement from a site the firm owns along the riverfront south of the Maine Coast Railroad trestle spanning Mill Creek.
Despite the company's silence, board Chairman Peter Lammert decided the idea deserved an official discussion after residents of Rockland's South End voiced strong opposition to Dragon's proposal to ship cement from the former Stinson Canning factory on Atlantic Point.
Although he agreed there was a problem with "the channel situation," Lammert reminded those attending the meeting that Dragon Products accounted for one-third of the town's tax base. He speculated that the cement plant might be attracted to Thomaston because rail access to its waterfront property would not disrupt the tranquility of a residential neighborhood, as would be the case in Rockland.
Jon Eaton of the Georges River Tidewater Association disagreed. Eaton pointed out that "massive dredging" of the river and its clam flats would be needed to handle the cement barges. He said the 50-by-250-foot barges have a 14-foot draft and carry 4,000 tons.
"Rockland is a deepwater port, Thomaston is not," Eaton said. "There is a major difference in dredging to a 10-foot minimum, which Thomaston has, to a depth of 18 feet for those barges. ... I would love to see them use the train line to get the cement to Rockland."
Eaton said the "configuration" of the river's estuary made it the "least viable option."
Selectman Stephen Mazzeo agreed. Mazzeo said he was present at a recent meeting between Dragon executives and Rockland officials. He said the company indicated to him that "Thomaston didn't fit into the process. ... They really prefer to do their hauling out of Rockland."
James McCammett, a retired cement plant executive, said the company has the technology to perform the task. He said a similar project was studied 35 years ago, "because I was the one who did it." McCammett said Dragon needs to expand its customer base to remain in business. He assured the board that Dragon would abide by its regulations if it decided to locate a barge facility in town.
Harbor Committee member Jeff Armstrong warned that a major dredging program to accommodate barge traffic would create "a situation where they are going to be taking over the river."
Mac Hyler said the town should be prepared to "co-exist" with Dragon. Hyler said he doubted a "reputable company" would attempt to bypass environmental regulations.
"I don't want to see any fishermen lose their jobs ... but we're living in a changing world," Hyler said.
When a Cushing fisherman remarked that the river was expected to be reopened for the harvesting of shellfish in a few years, Lammert said he was looking forward to the "war of the clam flats when the United Coast of Maine tries to dig that river on that first tide. It will be like the Oklahoma land rush."
Another out-of-town fisherman observed that "there hasn't been a smelt up the creek" since the river was last dredged in the mid-1970s. He added that striped bass were making a comeback and warned that another dredging program could be harmful to the river.
Cabot Lyman said that while he would "like to see some action" along the river he doubted the town could promote development with any success because of the fishing grounds. He said recreational boaters stay away during the summer because they do not want to disturb the lobster traps.
"You can open that river," Lyman said. "But you're going to have to do it over the dead bodies of the Cushing fishermen."

People: Lammert, Peter Eaton, Jon Hyler, Mac

Company / organization: Name: Dragon Products Inc; DUNS: 61-282-8897
