____________________________________________________________

Seafood prices rise faster than a Maine tide

Author: Pierre Franey N.Y. Times News Service

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]27 Sep 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413756008?accountid=10457

Abstract: This recipe for steamed mussels with mustard sauce can be prepared in less than a half-hour. Onions, shallots, garlic and butter form the basis for the sauce. When the mussels cook, they release their brine into the sauce. A touch of mustard at the end adds a piquant edge. You could also experiment with other flavors, like curry, fennel or Oriental spices.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Seafood+prices+rise+faster+than+a+Maine+tide&amp;author=Pierre+Franey+N.Y.+Times+News+Service&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-09-27&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Anyone who has been to a fish market in recent years knows that seafood prices have risen faster than a Maine tide. Cooks on a budget have to be resourceful, seeking lesser-known species in the market and being imaginative with preparation.
I recall how in the early 1980s American fishermen tossed monkfish back to sea because no market existed for them. The same applied to skate. To be sure, neither would win a deep-sea beauty contest. But each has distinctive flavors and textures that have been prized in Europe for centuries.
Today, both skate and monkfish are considered delicacies and are getting more expensive every year.
And what about mussels? Americans have long been shellfish lovers, but their attention has focused on oysters, clams, lobsters and shrimp. Mussels, bivalves that cling to coral and rocks, were always considered cheap and ordinary. Today, home cooks are learning how delicious mussels can be with the least amount of fuss. And they are far less expensive than oysters and clams.
Mussels are easy to clean. Immerse them in a bowl of cold tap water and stir them with your hand. When the water gets sandy, repeat with clean water two or three times. Cultivated mussels like those in Maine are cleaner than wild ones.
This recipe for steamed mussels with mustard sauce can be prepared in less than a half-hour. Onions, shallots, garlic and butter form the basis for the sauce. When the mussels cook, they release their brine into the sauce. A touch of mustard at the end adds a piquant edge. You could also experiment with other flavors, like curry, fennel or Oriental spices.
A steaming bowl of mussels with mustard sauce makes a fine lunch entree. A good side dish is sliced tomatoes with onions, a garlicky vinaigrette and blue heese. The broth has flavor to stand up to the cheese.

Title: Seafood prices rise faster than a Maine tide:   [ALL Edition ]

Publication title: Bangor Daily News; Bangor, Me.

Neighbors raise stink over shore conditions Naskeag Harbor landing fee suggested

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]22 Sep 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413744953?accountid=10457

Abstract: It's not unusual for rats to feed in harbor areas, said [Louis Rouviere], asserting he was unaware of their presence at Naskeag until now. At the selectmen's request, Marine Patrol officer John Mitchell reportedly asked Stonington fisherman Jim Williams to do something about his bait totes, some of which apparently had broken loose from his boat and floated to Center Harbor about a month ago. Rouviere recalled one woman trying to barbecue while fumes from the fetid bait nearly overpowered her and her cooking. "I told her to turn up her charcoal," said Rouviere, who chuckled in hindsight. Echoing [Gerard Poole]'s contention of last spring, Rouviere said Tuesday that a fee should be instituted for fishermen using the harbor landing. He believes the many out-of-town fishermen who profit from the harbor's use at town expense should pay a fee to help cover costs for items such as maintenance of the parking lot and of a portable toilet.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Neighbors+raise+stink+over+shore+conditions+Naskeag+Harbor+landing+fee+suggested&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-09-22&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BROOKLIN -- Critics of conditions at a local harbor have not only smelled a rat -- now they've seen them, and town officials say they are taking action.
Mussels, rotten bait and now bulky wastes have at various times been left to fester on, or to clutter, the scenic shore of Naskeag Harbor, a popular launching point for commercial fishermen.
Recent reports of rats foraging among spilled bait and overflowing trash have pushed the issue of harbor conditions back onto the Board of Selectmen's agenda.
Last spring, mussel waste left on shore prompted a complaint by resident and shellfish dealer Gerard Poole. That led to a cooperative cleanup of the shore, and to Poole's ultimate withdrawal of the complaint he had filed with town officials and area legislators.
Poole said in April that he hoped awareness raised during that particular incident, which was blamed on a Stonington-based commercial fisherman, would result in at least a brief period of soul-searching among town officials and the Brooklin Fishermen's Association as to whether a harbor ordinance should be enacted to curb the problems.
In addition to the mussel waste, Poole had cited the presence of human fecal deposits "all over the shore" and overcrowding of boats in the harbor as reasons for his complaint.
The Fishermen's Association decided not to back such an initiative, contending that the precipitating problem had been solved. Poole predicted that the issue would arise again.
Discovery of a water heater and tires dumped at the harbor was one of several recent events leading selectmen to look anew at the harbor situation, this time with the thought of enacting a landing ordinance to govern the zone between the high-water mark on town-owned land and the boats.
The board decided at its weekly meeting Tuesday to remove the harbor parking lot's dumpster to discourage people who have dumped bulky trash there. Selectman Louis Rouviere said the town picked up some excess trash at the lot all summer, but thought the problem would fade as the season ended.
Then the bulky wastes appeared, bait washed up near people's homes and rats were reported.
It's not unusual for rats to feed in harbor areas, said Rouviere, asserting he was unaware of their presence at Naskeag until now. At the selectmen's request, Marine Patrol officer John Mitchell reportedly asked Stonington fisherman Jim Williams to do something about his bait totes, some of which apparently had broken loose from his boat and floated to Center Harbor about a month ago.
The bait washed up in front of residents' homes, where it lay rotting until Williams had it removed, Rouviere said.
Rouviere recalled one woman trying to barbecue while fumes from the fetid bait nearly overpowered her and her cooking. "I told her to turn up her charcoal," said Rouviere, who chuckled in hindsight.
Echoing Poole's contention of last spring, Rouviere said Tuesday that a fee should be instituted for fishermen using the harbor landing. He believes the many out-of-town fishermen who profit from the harbor's use at town expense should pay a fee to help cover costs for items such as maintenance of the parking lot and of a portable toilet.
Heavy trucks use the lot for picking up the bags of mussels fishermen leave on Naskeag Bar, Rouviere added, and the town eventually will have to pay for resurfacing.
Acknowledging that harbor conditions have deteriorated since spring and early summer, Rouviere said the "possibility of it getting back to a crisis stage is still there."

People: Poole, Gerard Rouviere, Louis

Pending lawsuit stalls debate on merits of shellfish composting

Author: Kathy Harbour Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]20 Sep 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413796589?accountid=10457

Abstract: Financial backers of the lawsuit are the owners of the two shellfish companies in [Lamoine], the same people who have proposed to operate a shellfish composting project at the site of the former landfill. [Dean Smith] and [Mike Briggs] had developed a proposal with Coastal Recycling to operate a pilot composting program using shellfish and mixed paper at the site of the town's former landfill. Since the construction of the transfer station, the shellfish dealers can no longer dispose of the shells at a town facility. Complicating any consideration of the proposal for the selectmen is the continuing lawsuit, [Dick Davis] explained. "We told them when the litigation is settled or dropped, then we will talk about composting," Davis said.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Pending+lawsuit+stalls+debate+on+merits+of+shellfish+composting&amp;author=Kathy+Harbour+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-09-20&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: LAMOINE -- No public debate can be expected on the merits of a shellfish composting program until a lawsuit pending against the town is either dropped or settled.
According to Lamoine selectman Dick Davis, the three selectmen voted in recent days to postpone any decision or public hearing on the composting proposal while the lawsuit is pending.
The lawsuit, filed on July 1 by six Lamoine landowners with property adjacent to the new transfer station, calls for a revocation of the DEP permit granted the town for the construction of the transfer station. The abutters seek to revoke the setback waivers they signed, contending they were misled by one or more selectmen about options for the transfer station.
Financial backers of the lawsuit are the owners of the two shellfish companies in Lamoine, the same people who have proposed to operate a shellfish composting project at the site of the former landfill.
The position by Lamoine's Board of Selectmen may prompt another lawsuit against the town, one of the shellfish dealers said Friday.
For shellfish dealer Dean Smith, owner of H.A. Boynton Shellfish Co., the selectmen's position is "plain and simple blackmail. Tying the two issues together is asinine," Smith said Friday.
Smith said he and Mike Briggs, owner of Blue Ribbon Seafoods Inc., are now seriously considering filing their own lawsuit against the town. "We want a spot to compost," Smith said Friday.
Smith and Briggs had developed a proposal with Coastal Recycling to operate a pilot composting program using shellfish and mixed paper at the site of the town's former landfill. Since the construction of the transfer station, the shellfish dealers can no longer dispose of the shells at a town facility.
The dealers said they would cover any operating costs associated with the composting operation in order to have a nearby spot to dispose of their commercial waste. Coastal Recycling had proposed it would collect, shred and bale paper from selected businesses and schools to mix with the shellfish waste. The organization had also proposed that it would work to distribute or market the finished compost.
Complicating any consideration of the proposal for the selectmen is the continuing lawsuit, Davis explained. Despite assertions by the shellfish dealers that the lawsuit and the composting proposal should not be tied, Davis said selectmen think there is an important link. "We told them when the litigation is settled or dropped, then we will talk about composting," Davis said.
The dealers insist the proposal should be considered separate from the lawsuit. Smith said he and Briggs have no intention of withdrawing their financial support for the lawsuit.
Smith took issue with the selectmen's assertion that they could not consider a composting operation on the landfill property while that land is the subject of litigation. "But they didn't hesitate to go ahead and build a transfer station with the lawsuit pending,' he said.
"They are using baloney excuses," Smith added.
Selectmen, however, contend any decision about use of the landfill property should wait until the litigation is settled, as the people wanting to compost are the same ones financing the lawsuit.
Nina Silvestrone, executive director for Coastal Recycling, indicated her organization will look elsewhere for suitable property for the pilot project.

People: Davis, Dick Smith, Dean Briggs, Michael

____________________________________________________________

Maine's eider ducks are back Coastal bird's decline reversed by protections

Author: Tom Hennessey Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]18 Sep 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413717533?accountid=10457

Abstract: In autumn, it isn't unusual nowadays to see mile-long "rafts" of common eiders -- also called American eiders -- riding the gray swells surging along Maine's granite-sculptured coast. Conversely, it's difficult to imagine that, at the turn of the century, Maine's breeding population of common eiders -- Maine and Alaska have the only breeding populations of eiders in the United States -- was nearly eradicated. Not surprisingly, the culprit was man. During the 1800s, the fishermen-farmers inhabiting Maine's coast, including its islands, more than appreciated the meat, eggs and down of eiders. Therefore, the largest of North America's ducks -- an adult male eider weighs about 5 pounds, an adult female weighs about a pound less -- were exploited to the extreme. Because the ducks nest in colonies on uninhabited offshore islands, egg-gathering expeditions were unconscionably productive. Overhunting, especially during nesting seasons, also contributed greatly to the decline of Maine's eiders. So relentless were the assaults of man on the seemingly inexhaustible resource that by the early 1900s Maine's breeding population of common eiders reached its lowest known level. In 1907, for example, the National Association of Audubon Societies (now the National Audubon Society) reported only two pairs of eiders breeding on Old Man Island, lying about three miles southwest of Cutler. That year, the society provided the first protection for several species of Maine's sea birds, common eiders among them, by hiring wardens to protect nesting islands. Spring shooting was abolished and for several years it was illegal to shoot eiders during the regular hunting seasons. The enactment of the federal Migratory Bird Treaty in 1918 provided additional conservation regulations and by the late 1930s Maine's breeding population of eiders was recovering steadily. A survey conducted in 1943 estimated the population exceeded 2,000 nesting pairs. Today, Maine's Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife estimates there are more than 30,000 pairs.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Maine%27s+eider+ducks+are+back+Coastal+bird%27s+decline+reversed+by+protections&amp;author=Tom+Hennessey+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-09-18&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: In autumn, it isn't unusual nowadays to see mile-long "rafts" of common eiders -- also called American eiders -- riding the gray swells surging along Maine's granite-sculptured coast. Conversely, it's difficult to imagine that, at the turn of the century, Maine's breeding population of common eiders -- Maine and Alaska have the only breeding populations of eiders in the United States -- was nearly eradicated. Not surprisingly, the culprit was man.
During the 1800s, the fishermen-farmers inhabiting Maine's coast, including its islands, more than appreciated the meat, eggs and down of eiders. Therefore, the largest of North America's ducks -- an adult male eider weighs about 5 pounds, an adult female weighs about a pound less -- were exploited to the extreme. Because the ducks nest in colonies on uninhabited offshore islands, egg-gathering expeditions were unconscionably productive. Overhunting, especially during nesting seasons, also contributed greatly to the decline of Maine's eiders.
In the 19th century, however, sea duck hunting didn't necessarily relate to sport shooting, which was expensive and often ineffectual. Practicality dictated a much more efficient method, which was to drive ducks into confined areas -- coves, inlets, small bays -- where they were slaughtered.
Not by chance, then, do the words "egg" and "duck" appear frequently in the names of many Maine-coast locations: Egg Rock, Egg Island, Duck Cove, Duck Inlet, Great Duck Island, Ducktrap Bay, to name a few.
So relentless were the assaults of man on the seemingly inexhaustible resource that by the early 1900s Maine's breeding population of common eiders reached its lowest known level. In 1907, for example, the National Association of Audubon Societies (now the National Audubon Society) reported only two pairs of eiders breeding on Old Man Island, lying about three miles southwest of Cutler. That year, the society provided the first protection for several species of Maine's sea birds, common eiders among them, by hiring wardens to protect nesting islands. Spring shooting was abolished and for several years it was illegal to shoot eiders during the regular hunting seasons. The enactment of the federal Migratory Bird Treaty in 1918 provided additional conservation regulations and by the late 1930s Maine's breeding population of eiders was recovering steadily. A survey conducted in 1943 estimated the population exceeded 2,000 nesting pairs. Today, Maine's Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife estimates there are more than 30,000 pairs.
For the uninitiated, the singularity of that recovery cannot be appreciated without an explanation of the nesting habits, reproduction success, predation, and survival rates of common eiders.
Eider habits
Although the ducks will breed on forested islands, they prefer unforested locations where weeds, vegetation, and thickets of wild raspberry, rose, bayberry and such provide nesting cover. Depending on its size and available cover, an island may have a nesting population of eiders ranging from a dozen to more than 500 mated pairs.
Nesting usually begins in late April, when the paired ducks go ashore and the female selects the nest site. It formerly was believed female eiders didn't nest until 3 years of age. Recent studies, however, show that females nest in their second year. Males generally are 3 years old when they first mate.
Without question, an adult male common eider displaying nuptial plumage is one of North America's most handsome waterfowl. His dramatic black-and-white plumage accented with chartreuse cheek patches and bright yellow bill and legs are bold contrast to the conservative but purposeful beauty of the female's barred-umber feathering.
After preparing the nest site, the female begins laying her eggs. A clutch may consist of two to eight eggs, but the average is four. Only the female incubates the eggs, and once the 26- to 28-day process begins she rarely leaves the nest, usually only to drink. During the incubation period, females are sustained by stores of body fat and protein developed before nesting.
When incubation begins, male eiders leave the islands to congregate in flocks near offshore ledges and shoals. Soon afterward, they enter their summer molt, during which flight feathers are shed simultaneously. Consequently, the ducks are flightless for three to four weeks and must depend on their swimming and diving abilities for survival. Female eiders molt after the nesting season is completed.
Hatching success usually amounts to about 50 percent of a clutch. But because many ducklings are lost to predators, exposure or starvation in their first week of life, only a few survive to become fledged. Even in high-production years, only one duckling per mated pair of eiders may survive. The young usually are able to fly in about 60 days.
Considering the low survival rate of eider ducklings, the question is obvious: How did Maine's depleted population of eiders manage to recover? The answer lies in the longevity of adult eiders, which may live and breed for 20 years or more. In addition, their estimated annual survival rates vary from 80 to 90 percent. Low reproduction success is compensated by high adult survival.
Island trip
In late May, DIFW biologist Brad Allen, who provided the technical information for this story, invited me to accompany him on a survey of eider colonies nesting on Penobscot Bay islands. As we approached the first island, a dozen or more male eiders flew from the surrounding slate-gray sea. When we climbed to the top of the island and entered a sprawling cover of knee-high cow parsnip, a female eider immediately flushed and flew to the water.
Her nest contained four olive-color eggs partially covered with down. Hearing us approaching, the duck had hastily covered the eggs. When females leave nests of their own volition, the eggs are carefully covered to provide warmth and camouflage. In all, we found 15 eider nests containing clutches that averaged three eggs per nest. The island also was occupied by a colony of nesting herring gulls. We found six gull nests containing olive-color eggs speckled with brown.
Most of the female eiders flew into the water after flushing, but a few lit into brush and were captured, examined and released. Brad allowed the ducks had been on their nests about three weeks and it showed; prolonged fasting caused their breast bones to protrude. The 15 eider nests confirmed the biologist's observation that the number of male eiders seen around an island often indicated the number of nesting females.
As we left the height of the island, the gulls immediately began returning while the female eiders remained in the water. That provided the egg-addicted gulls a golden opportunity to raid the eiders' nests. Hovering over the island, the gulls communicated in guttural croaks while searching for unattended nests. Each nest, however, was carefully camouflaged with down, leaves and grasses after it was examined. That, combined with the thick cover, concealed the nests from the sharp-eyed predators.
You may know that gulls, particularly the great black-backed variety, are considered the primary predators of eiders' eggs and unfledged young. Again, the question is obvious: Why do eiders nest on islands occupied by breeding populations of gulls? The answer is another example of nature's intriguing weave of interactions.
Brad explained that eiders and gulls began nesting at about the same time. The gulls, he said, became highly aggressive and actually provided protection for eiders nesting nearby. If not for that, predation by transient and resident unmated gulls, along with crows and ravens, would be devastating.
But almost as quickly as the tide turns, that somewhat engaging aspect of eider-gull relationship changes to one of savagery. A clutch of eider eggs usually hatches simultaneously. This allows that when the ducklings' feathers are dry -- generally within 24 hours -- the female leads them to the water in one group. Here is where the life-and-death drama peaks: Unfledged and virtually unprotected as they leave the nest, the ducklings are attacked and devoured by gulls.
Instinctively, ducklings that make it into the water join other broods and therefore are protected by several females. Such groups are referred to as "creches" and remain intact until the ducklings are able to fly. In the interim, the ducklings' survival often depends on their innate diving and swimming abilities.
Human threat
Gull predation of eiders is a serious problem, but perhaps even more serious is the problem of controlling human disturbance of nesting eiders. Because of increasing interest in Maine's offshore islands as recreational sites, nesting colonies of common eiders are subjected to disturbance by picnickers, boaters, photographers, shell gatherers and sunbathers.
Brad explained that human disturbance during the hatching season usually resulted in female eiders' being driven from their nests and ducklings entering the water too soon. His concerns echo those of Howard Mendall, former leader of the Maine Cooperative Wildlife Research Unit, whose work in conserving and protecting Maine's breeding populations of eiders is widely known and respected.
In a paper written in 1968, Mendall prophesied the problem of human disturbance on nesting islands: "In the face of the increased coastal exploitation that we are almost certain to experience in the next few years, eiders and other colonial sea birds will not thrive without more adequate breeding ground safeguards."
Today, about 250 coastal islands are owned or controlled by state and federal agencies and conservation organizations. Among them are the Maine Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, The Nature Conservancy, National Audubon Society and Maine Audubon Society. Also, many privately owned islands are maintained to provide habitat for migratory sea birds.
Before we left the state-owned island, Brad posted a sign warning against trespassing between May 1 and July 15. Under skies layered with leaden clouds we then visited several other islands. One of them was so colonized with nesting eiders that the air was rank with their excrement. If the island were inhabited by sharp-nosed mammals -- raccoons, skunks, weasels -- they would have no trouble locating nests.
Like moats surrounding medieval castles, the sea surrounding nesting islands is a defense against invasion by mammalian predators. That protection, however, hasn't prevented diseases from reaching colonies of nesting eiders. In 1963, 1970 and 1974, epidemics of avian cholera spread through eiders nesting on several of Maine's midcoast islands. Since then, smaller outbreaks have occurred, the most significant in 1984.
Because the bacteria occurs in domestic chickens, the source of avian cholera was believed to be the poultry industry, which had processing plants on Penobscot Bay. Chicken parts, presumably carried from plant refuse and dumps by gulls, were found on islands where eiders had died from the disease. It was discovered later, however, that the bacteria also occurred in brackish island pools from which nesting eiders drank.
Also, it is believed that nesting densities contributed to the spread of avian cholera. Studies showed 90 percent of the diseased ducks were females, which as mentioned before, were weakened during incubation.
Last, an increasing gantlet of guns awaits Maine's eiders during hunting season. Because of reduced regular duck-hunting seasons (now 30 days overall) and a daily bag limit of three ducks, which may include only one black duck, interest in eider hunting is growing. The reasons are a 107-day hunting season -- Oct. 4 to Jan. 19 this year -- and a daily bag limit of seven eiders. Despite those liberal regulations, wildlife biologists report no evidence of excessive hunting pressure.
Here again, the ducks are protected by their harsh and unforgiving environment. During late fall and winter, the ranks of waterfowlers decline rapidly when temperatures drop, winds cut, and seas often are too rough for small boats.
The hardy eiders pay scant attention to Ol' Man Winter's temper tantrums. The ducks dive and feed on mussels, clams, periwinkles and other mollusks -- which are swallowed whole and ground in powerful gizzards -- while nor'easters turn white with rage and periods of bitter cold shroud islands and ledges with "sea smoke."
Without question, Maine's breeding population of common eiders can withstand nature's many adversities, but can the wonderfully wild sea ducks survive the tide of human disturbance again rising on offshore nesting islands? The answer is yes. But only if man, the predator who came close to eradicating them in the 1800s, realizes he is now the protector of the mile-long rafts that nowadays ride the gray swells surging along Maine's coast.

People: Allen, Brad

A joining of windjammers

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]16 Sep 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413787280?accountid=10457

Abstract: The oldest of the three 19th-century windjammers admired by onlookers Tuesday was the Lewis R. French, a 64-foot coaster built in South Bristol in 1871. Owned by Captain Dan Pease, the boat attracts passengers wishing immersion in traditional sailing methods. Owner-captain Pease explained that the Lewis R. French strives in several ways to maintain historic authenticity. The boat has no motor and a wood cook stove. Pease's one nod to the times is a new no-smoking policy. Unlike those windjammer captain-owners who had more conventional careers before getting into the cruising business, Pease always wanted to captain a windjammer, and acted accordingly by working on boats and in yards since his college days. Not that there was a maritime tradition in his family -- his father and grandfather were judges.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+joining+of+windjammers&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-09-16&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: BROOKLIN -- As sure a sign of autumn as asters, a cluster of tall ships glided into Naskeag Harbor Tuesday as part of the seventh annual WoodenBoat Sail-In.
Hosted by the Maine Windjammer Association to honor the tradition of working sail, the event featured association vessels originating from Rockport, Rockland and Camden sailing into the WoodenBoat magazine waterfront for their last gathering of the season.
Describing sailing conditions as "perfect," WoodenBoat School director Rich Hilsinger said the small craft warning issued Tuesday did not apply to these big boats, which reveled in the 20-knot winds.
Several of the Maine cruising fleet vessels, which the Windjammer Association represents and promotes, were built in Maine, although others were constructed in the Northeast. Ranging in size from 64 to 132 feet on deck, the various vessels also represent more than a century of boatbuilding, with a few built as recently as 30 years ago.
The people who own and skipper these boats have helped to keep the working sail tradition alive. But they now haul primarily human cargo rather than goods and raw materials as was done in the past. The boats offer three- and six-day cruises with a sailing training option in exchange for a cruise fee.
The oldest of the three 19th-century windjammers admired by onlookers Tuesday was the Lewis R. French, a 64-foot coaster built in South Bristol in 1871. Owned by Captain Dan Pease, the boat attracts passengers wishing immersion in traditional sailing methods.
For Belfast-born Trish Broud, now of Wheaton, Md., the vessel offered both escape and education.
"I decided that this is my vacation and I was not going to wash dishes," said Broud, who instead is helping the vessel's crew with several aspects of sail handling as part of her week-long cruise.
With at least two ancestors who were Maine sea captains, Broud had hoped to set sail for her own adventure aboard a windjammer on her honeymoon 25 years ago. That didn't work out, but the couple made sure to book passage aboard the Lewis R. French as part of their 25th anniversary celebration.
Owner-captain Pease explained that the Lewis R. French strives in several ways to maintain historic authenticity. The boat has no motor and a wood cook stove. Pease's one nod to the times is a new no-smoking policy.
"We try to do everything the way it would have been done 120 years ago," said the boyish-looking Pease.
Unlike those windjammer captain-owners who had more conventional careers before getting into the cruising business, Pease always wanted to captain a windjammer, and acted accordingly by working on boats and in yards since his college days. Not that there was a maritime tradition in his family -- his father and grandfather were judges.
After selling a boat he built with a partner, Pease used his proceeds to obtain the French eight years ago. He still has a lot to learn, he said, and has suffered somewhat with the weak economy, but business gets better each year.
Asked whether he would consider building a windjammer for his cruises as others in the fleet have done, Pease wasn't interested.
"It might be nice to build a new boat, but you could never duplicate a 120-year-old boat," he said.
Other vessels in the fleet Tuesday included the Isaac H. Evans, a 65-foot schooner built in New Jersey in 1886 for oyster dredging, the three-masted ram schooner Victory Chimes, built in Delaware in 1900 and the 71-year-old East Boothbay-built Nathaniel Bowditch yacht, a familiar sight to racing enthusiasts.
Illustration Caption: Pat Lown and daughters Emma and Jessica Creighton watch ships rock in the harbor at the WoodenBoat Sail-In Three schooners sail into Naskeag Harbor Tuesday (NEWS Photos by Scott Haskell)

People: French, Lewis R Pease, Dan Broud, Trish

Ellsworth to be Capital for a Day McKernan sets tight agenda

Author: Diana Graettinger Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]14 Sep 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413788945?accountid=10457

Abstract: [John R. McKernan]'s press spokesman, Cory Tilley, said Monday the governor's schedule was tight, and he was uncertain if McKernan would be able to meet with the negotiating teams. He said as of Monday, neither the EEA or the administrative negotiators had written to invite the governor, but he said his initial reaction to the suggestion was that it was not appropriate for the governor to be involved. He said if a detailed written request were sent, the governor might view the issue differently. Commissioners who will be in Ellsworth with McKernan are: Michael Aube, Department of Economic and Community Development; Dana Connors, Department of Transportation; Dean Marriott, Department of Environmental Protection; Leo Martin, Department of Education; Sawin Millett, Administrative and Financial Services; Charles Morrison, Department of Labor; Bernard Shaw, Department of Agriculture; Jane Sheehan, Department of Human Services; Jane Titcomb, Department of Professional and Financial Regulation; and Sherry Huber, Maine Waste Management Agency.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Ellsworth+to+be+Capital+for+a+Day+McKernan+sets+tight+agenda&amp;author=Diana+Graettinger+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-09-14&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ELLSWORTH -- On Thursday, Sept. 23, the city will be Capital for a Day and Gov. John R. McKernan has set a tight agenda for himself beginning with his arrival at 8:30 a.m. until he ends his day at 6 p.m.
One request the governor might view with interest will be from the Ellsworth Education Association. During a recent meeting with the Ellsworth School Committee's negotiating team, the EEA's head negotiator, Phil Sawyer, suggested that the two sides invite the governor to their next meeting.
The administrative team, led by School Committee member Tom MacDonald and Superintendent Bruce Sawyer, did not oppose the recommendation. The negotiations that are taking place in Ellsworth are unique in the county, if not the state, because the sessions are open to the public. Phil Sawyer said the governor had expressed an interest in such open sessions, and might like to attend.
The teachers and school committee remain at odds over wages and insurance contributions. The two sides plan to meet again on Sept. 23.
McKernan's press spokesman, Cory Tilley, said Monday the governor's schedule was tight, and he was uncertain if McKernan would be able to meet with the negotiating teams. He said as of Monday, neither the EEA or the administrative negotiators had written to invite the governor, but he said his initial reaction to the suggestion was that it was not appropriate for the governor to be involved. He said if a detailed written request were sent, the governor might view the issue differently.
"We are not closing the door. He would need to look at it to see what it entails," Tilley said.
Ellsworth is the 77th Maine community to be named Capital for a Day, an outreach program that enables the governor and top state officials to meet with local residents and hear their concerns and ideas.
"I am looking forward to meeting with the residents of Ellsworth. My Capital for a Day visits are helpful to me and my commissioners because we are able to get away from Augusta and into communities such as Ellsworth to get the input we need from working men and women throughout the state," McKernan said in a prepared statement.
Commissioners who will be in Ellsworth with McKernan are: Michael Aube, Department of Economic and Community Development; Dana Connors, Department of Transportation; Dean Marriott, Department of Environmental Protection; Leo Martin, Department of Education; Sawin Millett, Administrative and Financial Services; Charles Morrison, Department of Labor; Bernard Shaw, Department of Agriculture; Jane Sheehan, Department of Human Services; Jane Titcomb, Department of Professional and Financial Regulation; and Sherry Huber, Maine Waste Management Agency.
According to the schedule published by the governor's office, at 9:15 a.m. he will be part of an assembly at the Ellsworth High School. At 10 a.m. he will be at the Maine Coast Memorial Hospital, and at noon, the Ellsworth Area Chamber of Commerce will hold a luncheon for the governor at the Holiday Inn.
During the afternoon, the governor will meet with employees of the Maine Department of Human Services. At 2:50 p.m. he will visit the Union River Harbor Site, and at 3:15 p.m., he will visit the Maine Shellfish Co. At 3:55 p.m. the governor will take a walk down Main Street, and at 5 p.m. he will hold a town meeting at City Hall.

People: McKernan, John R

Plaintiffs in lawsuit seek BEP hearing

Author: Kathy Harbour Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]10 Sep 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413728579?accountid=10457

Abstract: As part of the lawsuit filed in Hancock County Superior Court on July 1, the property owners are seeking a revocation of the DEP permit. [Hans Huessey] said a motion has been filed in superior court requesting a stay in all proceedings pending review by the BEP. The plaintiffs in the suit, all abutting property owners to the transfer station, contend that the DEP granted a permit to Lamoine without the written approval of two of the property owners. The two landowners, Charles Reynolds Sr. and Charles Reynolds Jr., claim they never waived their rights to a 250-foot setback and that such waivers are required for a DEP permit.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Plaintiffs+in+lawsuit+seek+BEP+hearing&amp;author=Kathy+Harbour+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-09-10&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: LAMOINE -- Plaintiffs in a lawsuit pending against the town of Lamoine have asked for a hearing before the Board of Environmental Protection.
Hans Huessey, a Bangor attorney representing six Lamoine property owners in their suit against the town and the Department of Environmental Protection, confirmed Thursday that a request for a BEP hearing was made in recent days.
Huessey said he expected to hear within two weeks whether the BEP will grant the hearing to consider the plaintiffs' contention that a DEP permit given the town to construct a transfer station should be revoked.
As part of the lawsuit filed in Hancock County Superior Court on July 1, the property owners are seeking a revocation of the DEP permit. Huessey said a motion has been filed in superior court requesting a stay in all proceedings pending review by the BEP.
The town has filed an objection to that request, but the court has not yet ruled on the objection.
Construction of the transfer station was completed this summer, and the facility opened for business in August.
The plaintiffs in the suit, all abutting property owners to the transfer station, contend that the DEP granted a permit to Lamoine without the written approval of two of the property owners. The two landowners, Charles Reynolds Sr. and Charles Reynolds Jr., claim they never waived their rights to a 250-foot setback and that such waivers are required for a DEP permit.
Other landowners who are part of the lawsuit seek a revocation of the setback waivers they signed. They contend that they were misled by one or more Lamoine selectmen about the location of affordable and/or available sites for the transfer station. Further, they noted that they would not have signed the setback waivers if they had known the town had other options for the location of the facility.
The abutters claim they have suffered "substantial and potentially irreparable harm ... (as the) transfer station will cause them to suffer noxious odors, increased traffic, noise and diminishment of their enjoyment of their property."
According to Stu Marckoon, administrative assistant in Lamoine, no written complaints about noise or traffic have been forwarded to his office since the transfer station opened.
Two local shellfish dealers are footing the bills for the plaintiffs in the lawsuit. Dean Smith and Mike Briggs have voiced their opposition to the location of the transfer station since being informed the town would no longer accept their commercial waste once the landfill closed. They claimed that the 29-acre, town-owned property, a portion of which contains the now-abandoned dump, was a more appropriate location for a transfer station.
At present, the two business owners and Coastal Recycling are making a proposal to town selectmen to operate a shellfish compost at the site of the former landfill.
Marckoon said the town has spent about $3,500 in the past three months on attorney's fees related to the lawsuit.

Board to decide on composting hearing

Author: Kathy Harbour Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]10 Sep 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413706121?accountid=10457

Abstract: Questions about the proposal, spelled out in some detail by Coastal Recycling Executive Director Nina Silvestrone, remain for the town's selectmen. Stu Marckoon, administrative assistant in [Lamoine], listed those questions in a letter to Silvestrone shortly after her presentation to selectmen last week. Marckoon said selectmen want answers in writing prior to setting a public hearing on the proposal for Lamoine residents. Coastal Recycling's board of directors has also directed Silvestrone to pursue alternative sites for a shellfish composting operation if Lamoine rejects the proposal. Marckoon made note of the business owners' financial backing of the lawsuit in his letter to Silvestrone about the composting proposal. Referring to a conversation with the town's attorney, Marckoon said the attorney "feels that if the litigation involving the transfer station were cleared up, that would be a plus in locating this experiment at the landfill."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Board+to+decide+on+composting+hearing&amp;author=Kathy+Harbour+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-09-10&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: LAMOINE -- Lamoine selectmen are expected to decide next Wednesday if and when to schedule a public hearing about a proposal to place a shellfish composting operation at the town's landfill. Selectmen will meet at 6 p.m. at the town office.
The proposal, which was formally brought to Lamoine selectmen on Sept. 1 by Coastal Recycling, and Lamoine shellfish dealers Blue Ribbon Seafoods Inc. and H.A. Boynton Shellfish Co., would be a pilot project with operating costs covered by the two companies.
Coastal Recycling plans to request research and development funds from Maine Waste Management Agency to cover the costs of collecting, shredding and baling paper from selected businesses and schools to mix with the shellfish waste. Coastal Recycling would also work to distribute or market the finished compost.
Questions about the proposal, spelled out in some detail by Coastal Recycling Executive Director Nina Silvestrone, remain for the town's selectmen. Stu Marckoon, administrative assistant in Lamoine, listed those questions in a letter to Silvestrone shortly after her presentation to selectmen last week. Marckoon said selectmen want answers in writing prior to setting a public hearing on the proposal for Lamoine residents.
In response, Silvestrone said the major aspects of the project have been answered in the proposal. Other specifics, she said, would more appropriately be answered in any upcoming lease agreement.
Further, Silvestrone stated in her letter to Marckoon this week that any lease agreement would be premature "as the residents of the town of Lamoine have not been allowed the opportunity to consider hosting this project."
Silvestrone said Thursday that her board of directors has approved the project. The MWMA has also issued a letter welcoming a proposal for funding for the demonstration project. Brian Kavanah, from the Maine Department of Environmental Protection, said in late August that the Lamoine landfill site "could be permitted" for the composting project if certain operating conditions were met.
Coastal Recycling's board of directors has also directed Silvestrone to pursue alternative sites for a shellfish composting operation if Lamoine rejects the proposal.
Although the composting proposal is not directly tied to a lawsuit by abutting landowners in Lamoine, there is a relationship between the two, Marckoon said.
The lawsuit, which contends that the DEP permit for the location of the transfer station should be revoked, is being financed by the two shellfish dealers.
According to shellfish dealer Dean Smith in an interview this summer, he and Mike Briggs of Blue Ribbon Seafood had considered pursuing some legal action against the town when informed that their shellfish waste would not be accepted at the new transfer station. However, two attorneys advised the shellfish dealers that any lawsuit questioning the town's right to deny space to a commercial entity could prove extremely costly and protracted.
Smith said in July that he and Briggs were advised they couldn't stop the transfer station "and that the better tack would be to draw the abutters into the picture."
Marckoon made note of the business owners' financial backing of the lawsuit in his letter to Silvestrone about the composting proposal. Referring to a conversation with the town's attorney, Marckoon said the attorney "feels that if the litigation involving the transfer station were cleared up, that would be a plus in locating this experiment at the landfill."
Marckoon said the selectmen question what would happen if the town were forced to move the transfer station to the landfill site as a result of the lawsuit. He said there is some concern about whether the operators of the composting project would then move that site elsewhere.
According to Silvestrone, the DEP has indicated that more than one spot at the landfill property could be approved for the location of a composting operation.

____________________________________________________________

Jonesport lobster sale scam brings indictment for theft

Author: Margaret Warner Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]08 Sep 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413747313?accountid=10457

Abstract: The scam was revealed the day after it happened by an anonymous tipster who called himself "Deep Homard" -- French for lobster -- who took credit for engineering it on Look's behalf. The tipster, however, may have escaped the long claw of the law. No other names appeared on the indictment list in connection with the scam, and [R. Christopher Almy] would not elaborate.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Jonesport+lobster+sale+scam+brings+indictment+for+theft&amp;author=Margaret+Warner+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-09-08&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: A lobster dealer's attempt to settle a debt with a private sting operation six weeks ago has backfired, resulting in criminal charges against him.
Bert Sidney Look, 50, of Jonesport, owner of O.W. & B.S. Look Co. Inc., was indicted Tuesday for theft by deception for allegedly scamming "more than $20,000 out of various lobster dealers," according to Penobscot County District Attorney R. Christopher Almy. It is a Class B offense with a maximum sentence of 10 years in prison.
On July 24, a Port Clyde shellfish wholesaler who supposedly owed Look money was lured to the parking lot of Dysart's truck stop near the Hampden-Hermon town line along with a truckload of lobsters under the pretense that he would be supplying them for a lobster bake being given by Bangor author Stephen King.
Instead, the shellfish -- reportedly 7,000 pounds in 78 crates -- were unloaded into another vehicle while the broker, John Kostandin, was at a Bangor restaurant where he believed he would meet King.
The lobster sting has received wide publicity in Boston, where at least one newspaper gave it Page One play right after it happened and has tracked every subsequent development.
Almy said the sting hurt not just Kostandin, but the lobstermen who lost money because of it as well.
"He stuck it to a lot of honest lobster people down in Port Clyde," said Almy.
The scam was revealed the day after it happened by an anonymous tipster who called himself "Deep Homard" -- French for lobster -- who took credit for engineering it on Look's behalf. The tipster, however, may have escaped the long claw of the law. No other names appeared on the indictment list in connection with the scam, and Almy would not elaborate.

People: Almy, R Christopher

Neighbors complain of odors coming from PERC

Author: David N. Walsh Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]02 Sep 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413749988?accountid=10457

Abstract: It is not only the plant, she said, but also the truck traffic. "They don't put deodorizers on the trucks. That might solve a little bit of the problem. When we smell it, it seems to us the odor is coming from where they load and unload the trailers. The doors are open while the truck is in." Some of the loads coming to the plant, she said, carry shellfish. "That is pretty rank. The plant problems, she believes, could be solved if they installed a double door system, so the trucks had to go through one set of doors before the second set to the plant was opened. In answer to [Sue Kenney]'s complaint, Bob Field a spokesman of the PERC plant said, "We have received our share of complaints from the Kenneys, and others have complained about the odor. The major contributors to the odor are the trucks coming and going from the facility. We have had odor complaints five miles from the facility, but when we checked, those complaints correspond with trucks going by.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Neighbors+complain+of+odors+coming+from+PERC&amp;author=David+N.+Walsh+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-09-02&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ORRINGTON -- Sue Kenney and her husband Randy have a problem with the Penobscot Energy Recovery Plant. It stinks.
Orrington residents are not unique. When temperatures rise Hampden residents complain of Sawyer's landfill operation. Brewer residents complain of sludge and fertilizer on fields. And up until it was closed, residents in Brewer complained of the city landfill odors. Where ever there is a dump, a transfer station, or even a sewage treatment plant, summer heat can intesify the problem.
The PERC plant, she said, has not resolved the problems regarding odor. She said she has called the plant and they have done nothing. She and her husband have gone down to the plant to inspect the site and found the doors to the plant open when they are loading garbage.
"They need a double door system like MERC (the Maine Environmental Recovery Co. in Biddeford)," she said. "It is frustrating. We can't have weekend cookouts. It is a major problem. It ruins the neighborhood."
It is not only the plant, she said, but also the truck traffic. "They don't put deodorizers on the trucks. That might solve a little bit of the problem. When we smell it, it seems to us the odor is coming from where they load and unload the trailers. The doors are open while the truck is in." Some of the loads coming to the plant, she said, carry shellfish. "That is pretty rank. The plant problems, she believes, could be solved if they installed a double door system, so the trucks had to go through one set of doors before the second set to the plant was opened.
Kenney said there is a citizens' committee to handle complaints and concerns of that nature, but that hasn't met for some time. "Nothing was really resolved," she said. "They met with people because they do want to have good relations with the people around them."
Although the plant does not smell all the time, she said, it shoiuldn't smell at all. "I call every weekend, two or three times. If you are having a party or a gathering it can be embarrassing. You're eating lunch and then you smell that smell."
She said plant officials will say that the plant is a negative pressure system and it shouldn't be smelling. "It does smell and they all know it does smell." She said they have money to do all sorts of things and she would like them put some of that money into a double door system.
In answer to Kenney's complaint, Bob Field a spokesman of the PERC plant said, "We have received our share of complaints from the Kenneys, and others have complained about the odor. The major contributors to the odor are the trucks coming and going from the facility. We have had odor complaints five miles from the facility, but when we checked, those complaints correspond with trucks going by.
"We have looked at the double door system, but it won't do anything with trucks waiting to be unloaded." He said they see the trucks as the major source of odor. "It is true when the doors are open, some odor escapes, but it is intermittent when the doors are opened or closed. Double doors would probably take care of about 10 percent of the problem."

People: Kenney, Sue

Dig reveals importance of coastline USM interns find clues dating back to Ice Age

Author: (AP)

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 Aug 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413713852?accountid=10457

Abstract: Geographer Matthew Bampton, [Nathan Hamilton]'s partner on the project, is particularly intrigued by the prospect of a thriving prehistoric fish processing industry along the bay. Among the 8,000 artifacts excavated from the house are pieces of burnt flint. Before Europeans settled Casco Bay, Bampton noted, there is almost no evidence of warfare in the region. INTERNS CAREFULLY SIFT through the soil at the University of Southern Maine's archaeological dig in Phippsburg last week as they seek evidence of human habitation there. The two researchers leading the excavations hope to be the first to map out the history of humans and their environment all the way to the Ice Age. (AP Photo)

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Dig+reveals+importance+of+coastline+USM+interns+find+clues+dating+back+to+Ice+Age&amp;author=%28AP%29&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-08-24&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: PHIPPSBURG -- Maine's Stone Age residents were peaceable folks who ate lots of shellfish, rarely got cavities and became proficient in making tools.
And, like modern-day Mainers, they also recognized the value of oceanfront property on Casco Bay.
Two researchers who are leading a series of archaeological excavations on Casco Bay say they hope to be the first to map out the history of humans and their environment all the way back to the Ice Age.
Overlooking the rich marine basin where the New Meadows River empties into the Atlantic, archaeologist Nathan Hamilton surveyed the final dig of the summer-long project with the University of Southern Maine.
"Walk up to the top of that hill and get a look at the landscape," Hamilton said. "You're in close proximity to fresh water, it's a well-drained landscape, there's a nice place to dock your boat and there's an abundance of good food and good marine resources."
That's the way it has been since the start of the Holocene era, when glaciers receded north, creating a bountiful coastline of sheltered inlets, rocky beaches and rich river basins.
This single site, said Hamilton, holds clues that tell the story of humans and their bay all the way back to the Ice Age.
Geographer Matthew Bampton, Hamilton's partner on the project, is particularly intrigued by the prospect of a thriving prehistoric fish processing industry along the bay.
Bampton said there is evidence in some layers of dirt, especially those with a sunny southern exposure, that the guts and entrails of tons of fish were dumped there.
It's a sign, he said, that those spots might have been used to dry and preserve abundant catches to eat during leaner times.
"If we can look at how people used the environment in the past and how they use it now, we might be able to do something about declining fish stocks," Bampton said.
On this project alone, students have found more than 50 shell "middens," layers in the soil that hold such an abundance of clam shells they are almost certainly the remains of a prehistoric dump.
Higher up the sliver of land, another terraced hole reveals clues of man from a more recent age. Around 1720, white settlers arrived here and built the earliest known house in the river basin.
Among the 8,000 artifacts excavated from the house are pieces of burnt flint. Before Europeans settled Casco Bay, Bampton noted, there is almost no evidence of warfare in the region.
Illustration Caption: INTERNS CAREFULLY SIFT through the soil at the University of Southern Maine's archaeological dig in Phippsburg last week as they seek evidence of human habitation there. The two researchers leading the excavations hope to be the first to map out the history of humans and their environment all the way to the Ice Age. (AP Photo)

People: Hamilton, Nathan Bampton, Matthew

Two Irish officials visit local aquaculture sites

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]12 Aug 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413698242?accountid=10457

Abstract: "They were using a culture technique that was, at best, allowing a 5 percent survival of larvae to the first bottom stage, and that was just not acceptable," said [Brian Beal]. "The first thing I did was to closely examine the larvae of the European lobster using a microscope. Seeing that it looked remarkably similar to ours, Homarus americanus, I devised a plan that essentially copied the system that aquaculture specialist Sam Chapman and I had worked on for several years at Cutler. After several trials, they are now consistently acheiving survival rates of 50 percent and I have recently learned that researchers from Italy and England have adopted this culture system."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Two+Irish+officials+visit+local+aquaculture+sites&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-08-12&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: MACHIAS -- Two top officials from the republic of Ireland, representing an Irish- or Gaelic-speaking economic development agency known as Udaras na Gaeltachta, recently traveled to Washington County to tour local aquaculture sites.
Ruan O'Bric and Sean O'Naechtnan accompanied Brian Beal, assistant professor of marine ecology at the University of Maine at Machias, to sites on Beals Island, Cutler, Eastport and Lubec.
Ireland is similar in geographic size to Maine and relies heavily on fishing and creating products from its fisheries. Since the early 1980s, salmon and shellfish aquaculture in Ireland has become an important business, especially on the west coast where there are large pockets of traditional culture and language.
Ireland was once a major producer of European lobster, Homarus gammarus, but recently that industry has fallen on hard times due primarily to the lack of an effective management program for the species. Several groups in Ireland are now staging an effort to culture baby lobsters to enhance existing, but dwindling, stocks.
Professor Beal was invited in November 1992 to present a paper at an aquaculture symposium in Galway that focused on the Cutler Marine Hatchery effort. He accompanied lobster biologist Robert Bayer and two graduate students from the University of Maine. During their five-day visit, they toured various fish and shellfish culture facilities and a shellfish research laboratory where larval and juvenile lobsters are being raised.
Beal was invited again to Ireland in March of this year for three weeks to assist researchers in devising better culture systems that would result in high lobster survival through their delicate planktonic stage.
"They were using a culture technique that was, at best, allowing a 5 percent survival of larvae to the first bottom stage, and that was just not acceptable," said Beal. "The first thing I did was to closely examine the larvae of the European lobster using a microscope. Seeing that it looked remarkably similar to ours, Homarus americanus, I devised a plan that essentially copied the system that aquaculture specialist Sam Chapman and I had worked on for several years at Cutler. After several trials, they are now consistently acheiving survival rates of 50 percent and I have recently learned that researchers from Italy and England have adopted this culture system."
While in Washington County, the economic development officials visited the Beals Island Regional Shellfish Hatchery and Cutler Marine Hatchery. "We wanted to get a sense of the size of those two programs that have received considerable attention in Ireland," said agency executive director O'Bric.

People: Beal, Brian

DMR prohibits harvesting shellfish

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]09 Aug 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413717384?accountid=10457

Abstract: According to a notice issued Thursday by Sam Jones, administrative officer for DMR Commissioner William Brennan, the closure was ordered after tests conducted on shellfish samples collected in the affected area revealed "dangerous levels" of paralytic shellfish poison, also known as "red tide."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=DMR+prohibits+harvesting+shellfish&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-08-09&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: LUBEC -- The Department of Marine Resources has announced the immediate closure of waters between Moose Cove in Trescott and the Canadian border to the harvesting of shellfish.
According to a notice issued Thursday by Sam Jones, administrative officer for DMR Commissioner William Brennan, the closure was ordered after tests conducted on shellfish samples collected in the affected area revealed "dangerous levels" of paralytic shellfish poison, also known as "red tide."
The closure affects the harvesting of clams, oysters, carnivorous whelks and snails from the outer shores, flats and waters between Moose Cove and the Canadian border.
Soft shell clams, however, may still be harvested in the area northwest of a line drawn from Comstock Point in North Lubec, northeasterly to Shackford Head in Eastport and includes Cobscook Bay, South Bay, Straight Bay, Whiting Bay and Sipp Bay.
"The Cobscook Bay area is excepted from this closure," Jones said, "because tests show that the harvest of soft shell clams there can be permitted without threat to the public health."
Fishermen have been prohibited from harvesting mussels in the affected area since July 26, 1991. Additionally, the area has been closed to taking quahogs since July 13 of this year.

Maine festival gets national publicity

Author: Emmet Meara Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]07 Aug 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413697853?accountid=10457

Abstract: Festival officials said the combination of perfect weather, national publicity from "Good Morning America" and the visit of an expected 150 boats from the New York Yacht Club brought record crowds to the festival grounds on Thursday and Friday. The crew from the mammoth festival visitor, USS Thomas S. Gates, also swelled the crowd. On Friday, Christian got a T-shirt from local weathermen Peter Bouchard and Lou McNally from Maine ABC affiliates, then pronounced the weather "gorgeous" and did a lobster segment (Christian hates shellfish) with cookbook author Susan Herman Loomis. Loomis credited Jess's Market for cooking the lobster and Patricia Radcliffe for preparing the chowder. She also plugged the Maine potato industry (an "earthier taste" than Idahos) along with the blueberry industry. The Schooner Wendameen got some free air time and the band "Old Gray Goose" performed briefly at the end of the two hour show.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Maine+festival+gets+national+publicity&amp;author=Emmet+Meara+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-08-07&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- In one of the most successful days the Maine Lobster Festival has ever had in its 46 years, Sherrie Lee Leino, 18, of Rockland was crowned Maine Sea Goddess in front of the usual capacity crowds at the public landing on Friday.
The runner-up was Bobbi Jean Emery, 17, of Rockport.
Leino is the daughter of James and Sandra Leino and plans to attend Westbrook College and major in dental hygiene. She was sponsored by Little Caesar's Pizza, Fuller Cadillac, Dean's Flower Shop and Hair Dynamics. Emery was sponsored by the Emery Construction of Warren and plans to attend the University of Southern Maine, majoring in social work.
Festival officials said the combination of perfect weather, national publicity from "Good Morning America" and the visit of an expected 150 boats from the New York Yacht Club brought record crowds to the festival grounds on Thursday and Friday. The crew from the mammoth festival visitor, USS Thomas S. Gates, also swelled the crowd.
Director James Brickel, volunteering at the lobster feeding line, said the festival sold 2,500 pounds of lobster on Thursday, compared to about 750 pounds on the Thursday of last year's festival. "We are right on track. We had to go back three times to get more lobsters from Atwood's. We couldn't believe it." On Friday about 1,300 pounds had been sold by 2 p.m. with at least 100 people in the waiting line.
The only cloud on the horizon was rainy weather scheduled for Saturday's festival parade.
At the public landing, Assistant Harbormaster Jeff Edwards said about 60 of the expected 150 boats from the yacht club had arrived by 2 p.m. Friday with the full complement expected by sundown. About 25 of the boats will use available mooring space but the rest will drop anchor in Rockland's expansive harbor. "We have plenty of room for all of them," Edwards said.
The day's events began at 7 a.m. when ABC-TV weatherman shouted "Good Morning, America" from the roof of the waterfront Black Pearl Restaurant. Unfortunately the broadcast lost its satellite feed at just that moment and the picture went off the air. "Things are rocky in Rockland," said New York hostess Joan Lunden to the national television audience.
But the problems got ironed out soon enough to give the festival a national boost, the first since Real People filmed a segment of the now-defunct sardine packing contest in 1979. Former sardine packing champ Rita Willey once packed sardines with TV host Johnny Carson, but that was in 1970.
On Friday, Christian got a T-shirt from local weathermen Peter Bouchard and Lou McNally from Maine ABC affiliates, then pronounced the weather "gorgeous" and did a lobster segment (Christian hates shellfish) with cookbook author Susan Herman Loomis. Loomis credited Jess's Market for cooking the lobster and Patricia Radcliffe for preparing the chowder. She also plugged the Maine potato industry (an "earthier taste" than Idahos) along with the blueberry industry. The Schooner Wendameen got some free air time and the band "Old Gray Goose" performed briefly at the end of the two hour show.
The visit was not without controversy.
Volunteers who cranked up the "World's Largest Lobster Cooker" at 6:30 a.m. for the television show were a little steamed that the show never used the cooker, then used a lobster cooked by Jess's Market ... at the Maine Lobster Festival.
But Black Pearl Manager Peter Larsen said he was "thrilled" with the free national publicity "as long as nobody fell off the roof."
Illustration Caption: Sherrie lee Leino

People: Leino, Sherrie Lee

Shellfish composting on agenda at Lamoine Coastal Recycling proposal to be examined

Author: Kathy Harbour Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]06 Aug 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413795850?accountid=10457

Abstract: The compost site, if established at the now closed landfill property, would serve only the two shellfish dealers in [Lamoine]. Mixed paper, collected by Coastal Recycling from its member towns, would be shredded to compost with the shellfish waste. Mixed paper would include such items as cereal boxes and toilet tissue tubes, paper products not now recycled in the towns. Brian Kavanah, from the Maine Department of Environmental Protection, has said the landfill site in Lamoine could be used for composting if certain conditions could be met. Those conditions include covering the pile with tarps, removing excessive moisture, limiting the amount of shellfish waste placed there each year, grinding the shells before delivery to the site, and certain storage conditions. Kavanah, along with [Nina Silvestrone], [Stu Marckoon] and [Mike Briggs], visited the Lamoine property and property in Hancock in recent days. The visits indicated the Lamoine property was the more appropriate spot for a composting pilot project, Marckoon said.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Shellfish+composting+on+agenda+at+Lamoine+Coastal+Recycling+proposal+to+be+examined&amp;author=Kathy+Harbour+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-08-06&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: LAMOINE -- Lamoine selectmen are expected to consider by the end of this month a proposal from Coastal Recycling to establish a shellfish composting site at the old landfill.
Stu Marckoon, administrative assistant in Lamoine, said Thursday that the three selectmen indicated this week that they are "interested in seeing what will be proposed."
If specific concerns of the selectmen can be addressed and answered in the proposal, Marckoon said, townspeople then will be asked to vote on the project at a special town meeting.
The compost site, if established at the now closed landfill property, would serve only the two shellfish dealers in Lamoine. Mixed paper, collected by Coastal Recycling from its member towns, would be shredded to compost with the shellfish waste. Mixed paper would include such items as cereal boxes and toilet tissue tubes, paper products not now recycled in the towns.
As explained by Nina Silvestrone, executive director of Coastal Recycling, the compost heap could be a pilot project for the organization. The two shellfish dealers, Mike Briggs and Dean Smith, have agreed to underwrite the project by providing the equipment, labor, operation and start-up costs such as site development, Silvestrone said in an earlier interview.
Marckoon said the town should not incur any costs with the compost project, only that it would be placed on town-owned property.
The two shellfish dealers were informed last year that they would not be able to dump their shellfish waste at the town's new transfer station when the dump was closed. The two dealers stopped short of bringing legal action against the town in protest of that decision, but indicated months ago they thought the town should either provide a spot for composting the waste or room for temporary storage of the shellfish.
Brian Kavanah, from the Maine Department of Environmental Protection, has said the landfill site in Lamoine could be used for composting if certain conditions could be met. Those conditions include covering the pile with tarps, removing excessive moisture, limiting the amount of shellfish waste placed there each year, grinding the shells before delivery to the site, and certain storage conditions.
Kavanah, along with Silvestrone, Marckoon and Briggs, visited the Lamoine property and property in Hancock in recent days. The visits indicated the Lamoine property was the more appropriate spot for a composting pilot project, Marckoon said.
The town's new transfer station opens at 8 a.m. Friday, Aug. 6, despite a lawsuit by six abutting property owners. Those neighbors called for a halt to construction of the station, claiming they were misled by selectmen who, they say, informed them no other site was available and-or affordable.
The abutters contend they would never have signed setback waivers for the station if they had not been misinformed. Two of the property owners say they were never contacted and have not waived their rights to a 250-foot setback.
The town and the DEP have been named as defendants in the lawsuit. The lawsuit calls on the DEP to revoke the permit granted for the station.
Marckoon said the lawsuit has not yet been scheduled for its day in court. He hoped that once the transfer station is open the "neighbors' concerns will be alleviated."

People: Marckoon, Stu Silvestrone, Nina
