____________________________________________________________

Sting instigator doesn't like spotlight Loose lips of `Deep Homard' rocks boat of shellfish company

Author: Margaret Warner Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]28 July 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413678799?accountid=10457

Abstract: The target, John Kostandin, who lives in Port Clyde, brought a truckload of lobsters north to a spot near Dysart's truck stop Saturday night, having been told that he was supplying a lobster bake hosted by Bangor author Stephen King. From there, he was diverted to a restaurant where he was led to believe he would meet the author, who in reality had nothing to do with the deal. It has been anything but quiet since Sunday, when an anonymous tipster who calls himself "Deep Homard," appropriating the French word for lobster, began alerting the media about the sting and claiming credit for engineering it on behalf of the Look company. It quickly became a hot, er, tomalley in the news media, even making the front page of Tuesday morning's Boston Herald.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Sting+instigator+doesn%27t+like+spotlight+Loose+lips+of+%60Deep+Homard%27+rocks+boat+of+shellfish+company&amp;author=Margaret+Warner+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-07-28&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The beneficiary of a private sting operation last weekend at a truck stop near the Hampden-Hermon town line is less than pleased with the publicity it's received.
The Saturday night scam -- call it The Lobster Trap -- targeted a man said to owe about $30,000 to O.W. & B.S. Look Co. Inc. of Jonesport, a producer and supplier of shellfish.
The target, John Kostandin, who lives in Port Clyde, brought a truckload of lobsters north to a spot near Dysart's truck stop Saturday night, having been told that he was supplying a lobster bake hosted by Bangor author Stephen King. From there, he was diverted to a restaurant where he was led to believe he would meet the author, who in reality had nothing to do with the deal.
Meanwhile, back at Dysart's, the lobsters -- 7,000 pounds in 78 crates -- were unloaded over the objection of the truck driver and spirited away.
When Kostandin realized what had happened, he notified the Penobscot County Sheriff's Department, which is investigating whether any crimes were committed. That determination won't come until later in the week, according to Sgt. Fred Clarke. The value of the lobsters is a matter of some dispute, with estimates ranging from $20,000 to $40,000.
"We do not intend to mar the reputation of anyone, nor do we want to portray ourselves as some sort of modern-day hero," reads a statement the Look company released Tuesday. "We only wish to say that what we had hoped would be a quiet settlement of accounts, handled between our company and the debtor company, has been blown way out of proportion and has gotten way out of hand."
"As far as we are concerned, the account has been settled and closed," it stated.
But it has been anything but quiet since Sunday, when an anonymous tipster who calls himself "Deep Homard," appropriating the French word for lobster, began alerting the media about the sting and claiming credit for engineering it on behalf of the Look company. It quickly became a hot, er, tomalley in the news media, even making the front page of Tuesday morning's Boston Herald.
The faxed release, which the company said will be its only public comment on the matter, maintains that the target of the sting had owed Look money for 10 months. The company claims to have papers to back up that claim, but will not make them public. The sting, according to Look, followed repeated unsuccessful attempts by Look and professional collection agencies to settle the debt.
"Taking this into consideration, we did the only thing we felt we could do," the company said in its statement.
They hired "Homard" because he "is a comedian of sorts and has a great mind for scheming," according to the statement, and company owner Sid Look has known him for about three years.
"We have not, however, authorized any statement by `Mr. Homard' in connection with this matter or on behalf of this company," the statement reads.
So now it appears that "Deep Homard" is in deep -- what's French for doo-doo? -- with Look. Or at least in a lobster stew.

Groups take aim at recycling building debris Target: To cut volume, cost of waste disposal

Author: Stephany Boyd Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]27 July 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413724996?accountid=10457

Abstract: Stephen Beathem, chairman of the Recycling Committee, said the meeting could become freewheeling with participants welcome to take potshots at a preliminary proposal for dealing with debris at the city's transfer station. Disposal of demolition debris currently costs as much as $70 per ton. Beathem said he is unaware of any significant progress made by proponents of a debris disposal site proposed for Township 8. The recycling center is poorly equipped to store or process demolition debris, [Carolyn "Cookie" Patten] said. The two small bins earmarked for debris aren't big enough to handle the rubble from even one downed single-family residence.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Groups+take+aim+at+recycling+building+debris+Target%3A+To+cut+volume%2C+cost+of+waste+disposal&amp;author=Stephany+Boyd+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-07-27&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ELLSWORTH -- Hoping to stop what at worst looks like wholesale squandering of potentially valuable demolition debris, two usually separate municipal units will unite to tackle the issue.
The city's Solid Waste and Recycling committees will meet jointly for the first time at 7 p.m. Wednesday, July 28, at Ellsworth City Hall. The purpose is to discuss how to milk some value from castoff construction materials that are costly to have hauled away.
Stephen Beathem, chairman of the Recycling Committee, said the meeting could become freewheeling with participants welcome to take potshots at a preliminary proposal for dealing with debris at the city's transfer station.
Disposal of demolition debris currently costs as much as $70 per ton. Beathem said he is unaware of any significant progress made by proponents of a debris disposal site proposed for Township 8.
The Ellsworth committees hope to steer the city closer to the success rates some other towns have achieved in cutting the overall volume and cost of waste disposal.
Beathem gave the local recycling center generally good reviews, yet qualified his praise.
Beathem estimated that the facility was getting 15 to 20 percent of the waste stream. "That's not good," he said, "but it's far better than it was 15 months ago. We weren't getting anything then."
Recycling Committee member Carolyn "Cookie" Patten, considered a founder of the facility, said its greatest success had been the high volume of cardboard recycled by local businesses. Demolition debris presents a major challenge, she said, and may promise a lode of opportunity to reclaim some of recycling's costs.
The recycling center is poorly equipped to store or process demolition debris, Patten said. The two small bins earmarked for debris aren't big enough to handle the rubble from even one downed single-family residence.
Some of the material could be sorted and chipped or otherwise processed instead of being sent off for disposal, Patten said. As things now stand, the materials that fall to the wrecker's ball present the contractor who must dispose of them the biggest headache of all.
Patten said other issues facing the Recycling Committee include the need for more volunteers at the center. Hancock County Sheriff William Clark has expressed some interest in having jail inmates volunteer services there.
Recyclers also hope eventually to develop municipal composting. Waste generated from local blueberry and shellfish businesses is just that, Patten said -- wasted material that could become a resource if it were composted.
For now, an extensive composting program may be among the visions the city can little afford.
"We're looking at the most reasonable thing to do from the standpoint of money and ecology and everything else," Beathem said.

People: Beathem, Stephen Patten, Carolyn "Cookie"

Lamoine firm cited for wage violations

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]24 July 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413783284?accountid=10457

Abstract: [Bryan C. Briggs] could not be reached for comment Friday.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lamoine+firm+cited+for+wage+violations&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-07-24&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: A Lamoine seafood-processing company has been ordered to pay a total of $18,000 to 45 employees for violations of federal wage and hour laws.
The payments will settle a lawsuit brought by the U.S. Department of Labor in February against Sonja Beal Inc., which operates as M.C. Briggs Shellfish Co., and Bryan C. Briggs, its president.
Briggs could not be reached for comment Friday. The suit accused the seafood company of paying employees less than the minimum wage, neglecting to pay time-and-a-half for overtime, and failing to keep adequate records of employees' wages and hours. The court order was signed by Judge Morton Brody at U.S. District Court in Bangor. Brody also prohibited the seafood company from future violations of federal labor law.

People: Lamoine, A

Lamoine reconsidering composting issue Landfill eyed for possible site

Author: Kathy Harbour Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]23 July 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413707732?accountid=10457

Abstract: [Lamoine] Selectman Dick Davis said Thursday he and Selectman Arthur Alley will visit a shellfish composting facility in Gouldsboro this weekend. Of greatest concern to the selectmen, Davis indicated, is whether offensive shellfish odors can be controlled if a composting heap is placed at one edge of the Lamoine landfill. Increasing controversy has accompanied the construction of Lamoine's transfer station on Route 184, a facility that has no room for the storage or composting of the shellfish waste generated by two companies in Lamoine. The town must stop using its landfill, located on 29 acres off Route 184 and down the road from the transfer station, by July 31. Nina Silvestrone, executive director of Coastal Recycling, said Thursday her organization had interest in coordinating a pilot project for composting at the Lamoine site. In fact, she added, both [Dean Smith] and [Mike Briggs] have maintained an avid interest in learning about composting over the past year, indicating they could oversee any composting operation.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lamoine+reconsidering+composting+issue+Landfill+eyed+for+possible+site&amp;author=Kathy+Harbour+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-07-23&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: LAMOINE -- A suggestion to place a composting site at the town's landfill property is apparently up for reconsideration.
Lamoine Selectman Dick Davis said Thursday he and Selectman Arthur Alley will visit a shellfish composting facility in Gouldsboro this weekend. Of greatest concern to the selectmen, Davis indicated, is whether offensive shellfish odors can be controlled if a composting heap is placed at one edge of the Lamoine landfill.
Increasing controversy has accompanied the construction of Lamoine's transfer station on Route 184, a facility that has no room for the storage or composting of the shellfish waste generated by two companies in Lamoine. The town must stop using its landfill, located on 29 acres off Route 184 and down the road from the transfer station, by July 31.
Town selectmen decided to place the transfer station at the Route 184 location, contending it was the least expensive and most expedient alternative for the town. A jobs-bond grant helped finance the building that is nearing completion on the site, which is less than one acre.
Administrative Assistant Stu Marckoon explained in an earlier interview that trying to place a transfer station on the 29-acre landfill site would have required extensive and expensive engineering costs.
Shellfish dealers Dean Smith and Mike Briggs over the past year have protested the chosen site. According to Smith, the two men had asked the selectmen last spring to consider placing a composting site at the old landfill to handle the shellfish waste, but their suggestion was rebuffed. "We didn't propose it in a formal way (in writing)," Smith said Thursday, "but we got the feeling there was no use to after meeting with the selectmen."
Marckoon said Thursday the selectmen told Smith this week to submit a formal proposal for composting. "It's up to them to propose something ... and then we'll consider it."
Davis said there was apparently room at the landfill for composting and that the town did, in fact, know one outer boundary of the garbage at the dump. He said that if composting shellfish waste there seems a good alternative, selectmen would need to take the issue to a special town meeting. He indicated the town would need to sell the gravel off a portion of the land, and use those funds to help pay for the operation.
A representative from the Department of Environmental Protection has indicated that the landfill site could be used for composting without expensive engineering or licensing. In a letter dated July 2, 1993, Brian Kavanah from the department's Division of Solid Waste Facilities Regulations in Bangor said the location looked good "from an odor standpoint" as long as any shellfish wastes were covered by a water-repellent tarp.
Other regulations that might be imposed on the site, according to Kavanah, would include grinding the shells before placement there and getting rid of excess liquid.
Nina Silvestrone, executive director of Coastal Recycling, said Thursday her organization had interest in coordinating a pilot project for composting at the Lamoine site. In fact, she added, both Smith and Briggs have maintained an avid interest in learning about composting over the past year, indicating they could oversee any composting operation.
Silvestrone said Coastal Recycling viewed such a pilot project as a "golden opportunity," particularly since mixed paper could be shredded to compost with the shellfish waste. That mixed paper -- such as cereal boxes and toilet tissue tubes -- is presently not recycled and towns pay to ship such waste to PERC.
Any compost generated could be marketed by Coastal Recycling. The organization could also provide a shredder for the paper. Silvestrone said no other member towns in Coastal Recycling had the town-owned property that Lamoine has that is suitable for composting.
Marckoon said he had not yet told selectmen about Coastal Recycling's interest in a pilot project located in Lamoine. "I don't have anything concrete to propose yet," he said.
Another unresolved controversy surrounding the placement of the transfer station is one involving six abutting property owners. Those residents are currently involved in a lawsuit against the town and DEP, seeking to halt construction of the station and calling for compensation for non-economic injuries. The abutters are claiming they were misled by selectmen who, they say, informed them no other site was available and/or affordable for the transfer station.
They have contended they would never have signed setback waivers for the station if they had not been misinformed. Two of the property owners say they were never contacted and have not waived their rights to a 250-foot setback.

People: Davis, Dick Marckoon, Stu Smith, Dean Silvestrone, Nina

Title: Lamoine reconsidering composting issue Landfill eyed for possible site:   [HANCOCK Edition ]

Publication title: Bangor Daily News; Bangor, Me.

Lamoine reconsidering composting issue

Court news at Machias

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]22 July 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413849934?accountid=10457

Abstract: Bernard L. Grant, 19, Lubec, operating motor vehicle while under influence of intoxicating liquor, $350, seven days in jail, all but 48 hours suspended, one year probation with conditions of no possession or use of intoxicating liquor, subject to random search and testing for possession or use, and must undergo mandatory substance abuse counseling, license suspended 90 days. Orrin W. Chandler, 46, Jonesport, operating motor vehicle while under influence of intoxicating liquor, $350 fine, 48 hours in jail with credit for 16 hours of time served, license suspended 90 days.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Court+news+at+Machias&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-07-22&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: MACHIAS -- The following cases were processed in 4th District Court in Machias, July 6-16, with Judge John V. Romei presiding:
Wendy A. Naaykens, 26, East Machias, assault, 10 days in jail, all suspended, one-year probation with the condition of domestic-violence counseling.
Stephen A. Cowles, 24, Steep Falls, operating motor vehicle after license suspension, $100.
Scott E. Conlin, 19, Cutler, theft by unauthorized taking or transfer, 20 days in jail.
Sharley H. Fitzsimmons, 28, Lubec, fishing for shellfish without shellfish license, $100.
Orrin W. Chandler, 46, Jonesport, operating motor vehicle while under influence of intoxicating liquor, $350 fine, 48 hours in jail with credit for 16 hours of time served, license suspended 90 days.
Robert Ohnesorge, 37, Atlantic Beach, Fla., operating motor vehicle while under influence of intoxicating liquor, $350, license suspended 90 days.

Rifle match held at rebuilt shooting range

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]22 July 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413786378?accountid=10457

Abstract: [John Chandler] was largely responsible for the engineering of the expansion at Oyster River, said Arthur Jura, range owner. The range was lengthened to a maximum of 600 yards, to match the shooting ranges found at Camp Perry, Ohio, where national matches are held each year. The Oyster River Range has been in operation since 1972, when Jura moved his school photography business and a budding gun shop from Rockland to Warren. He and a shooting friend, Dick Freeman of Rockland, found 67 acres of undeveloped land on Route 90. Since then, the range has been home to nearly every type of formal and informal shooting sport, indoor and outdoor, including a popular rifle and pistol cast-bullet tournament held each spring.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Rifle+match+held+at+rebuilt+shooting+range&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-07-22&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: WARREN -- The Oyster River Range's newly expanded rifle range got a christening earlier this summer when 27 Maine high-power rifle shooters spent 10 hours on a boiling-hot day shooting the state championship match and Department of Civilian Marksmanship-sanctioned "leg match."
It was the first time since 1984 that such a match had been held at Oyster River Range, which reopened this June with its new 600-yard course after nine years of rebuilding.
The new Maine Rifle Champion is John Chandler of Auburn, who fired a .308-caliber service rifle and scored 476 of a possible 500 points. Chandler is a former Maine National Guard major and marksmanship coordinator and is a member of the Army Reserve. He is a bureau supervisor for the Maine Department of Environmental Protection in Augusta.
Chandler was largely responsible for the engineering of the expansion at Oyster River, said Arthur Jura, range owner. The range was lengthened to a maximum of 600 yards, to match the shooting ranges found at Camp Perry, Ohio, where national matches are held each year.
With the help of National Guard heavy equipment and engineers, 14,000 cubic yards of earth were moved to build the berm at the end of the range, including a target pit area with new target carriers. The backstop formed by the earthen berm is 175 feet wide and 35 feet high.
The long shooting day was a product of having each rifleman fire 50 rounds for the state match and 50 for the leg match. When no target-setters were available for the day's shoot, the shooters divided into three strings, each taking turns shooting, scoring and handling targets in the "pits."
The style of competition found at Oyster River Range is one of the older shooting disciplines, Jura explained, and requires concentration, endurance and training. Three shooting positions are used: off-hand (standing) at 200 yards; sitting at 200 yards; prone, rapid-fire at 300 yards. A prone, slow-fire course is shot at 600 yards.
It is rare to find a 600-yard range in New England; those ranges that provide 200-yard distances may use proportioned targets to produce the visual effect of the longer distances, but put competitors at a disadvantage when they go to Camp Perry to shoot in full 600-yard matches.
The Oyster River Range has been in operation since 1972, when Jura moved his school photography business and a budding gun shop from Rockland to Warren. He and a shooting friend, Dick Freeman of Rockland, found 67 acres of undeveloped land on Route 90. Since then, the range has been home to nearly every type of formal and informal shooting sport, indoor and outdoor, including a popular rifle and pistol cast-bullet tournament held each spring.
Jura said the accomplishment he was most proud of was formation and training of a junior shooting club, which won state and national recognition.
Jura said that he and his wife, Joyce, may re-enter the shooting sports after their retirement. He added that he still has seven grandchildren that may want to learn the shooting sports.

People: Chandler, John Jura, Arthur

Hunger, luxury and socialism in Havana

Author: Padula, Alfred

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]22 July 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413754894?accountid=10457

Abstract: Hunger is stalking the streets of Havana. The famous ration card which once sufficed for an adequate diet is no longer sufficient. Cubans love grains; but today there is not enough imported wheat to make bread. Cubans must depend on relatives and the black market to get by. Each day is a struggle. A visitor dines with a friend; we have candied grapefruit rinds. There is nothing else in the house. Cuba entices the foreigner with the promise of rapid repatriation of profits, cheap, well-trained and docile labor and simplified bureaucratic procedures. Luxury hotels financed by Spanish, Canadian, and European capital have sprung up all along the 10-mile strip at Varadero beach outside of Havana. [Castro] observed some years ago that you cannot build a socialist society with capitalist incentives, but that is exactly what he is trying to do now. He is emphasizing foreign capital, profits, dollars, competitiveness, individualism. He is decentralizing much of the economy. We asked a wise old communist, who is now head of Cuba's Chamber of Commerce, how these new ideas and values would play against the revolution's principles of collectivism and vertical control. Would the Communist Party survive? Would the revolution? He thought for a moment, and then concluded, with a shrug of his shoulders, "only a magician can tell."

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Hunger%2C+luxury+and+socialism+in+Havana&amp;author=Padula%2C+Alfred&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-07-22&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: There will be no celebrations in Havana this year to mark the 40th anniversary of the Cuban revolution. In the past, July 26 was an occasion for parades and speeches, but this time around, as the revolution confronts an economic crisis brought on by the collapse of the Soviet bloc, there is nothing to celebrate.
Hunger is stalking the streets of Havana. The famous ration card which once sufficed for an adequate diet is no longer sufficient. Cubans love grains; but today there is not enough imported wheat to make bread. Cubans must depend on relatives and the black market to get by. Each day is a struggle. A visitor dines with a friend; we have candied grapefruit rinds. There is nothing else in the house.
Bus service has been cut back because there is no petroleum or spare parts. Many factories have been closed down for want of electricity. The idled workers receive 60 percent of their salary, but Cuban officials say this and other generous subsidies which form part of the revolution's "social contract" with the populace will soon have to be reduced. Higher education has already been cut.
What is to be done? Castro, down, but not out, has launched a series of neo-capitalist experiments to save the revolution. Suddenly foreign capitalists and multinational corporations, once reviled as scoundrels and murderers, are being courted. The government has published a list of 130 projects from ice cream factories to steel plants for which it is seeking foreign partners.
Cuba entices the foreigner with the promise of rapid repatriation of profits, cheap, well-trained and docile labor and simplified bureaucratic procedures. Luxury hotels financed by Spanish, Canadian, and European capital have sprung up all along the 10-mile strip at Varadero beach outside of Havana.
The Spanish in particular have responded to this invitation, and have invested perhaps half a billion in tourist hotels. The Grupo Sol of Madrid has just completed a $150 million complex of hotels and vacation condos. These hotels are not designed to cater to visiting intellectuals doing "revolutionary tourism" at subsidized rates, but rather for bourgeois tourists from Canada and Europe and Mexico who want five-star services and are willing to pay for it.
In Havana old hotels are being refurbished and new ones built. Not far from the monument to the Battleship Maine, the government is building the 18-story Cohiba hotel. In the early moring, the hotel's shadow reaches across the city, touching tattered schools with broken windows and unkempt grounds.
This "in your face" contrast of luxury for foreigners and penury for Cubans threatens the social stability of the city. While Cubans try to get by on a bread ration of one roll a day, foreigners with dollars dine heartily on lobsters, beef, shellfish -- whatever they want -- in nearby restaurants.
The government is keenly aware of this contrast. It tries to reason with the populace, pleading for patience, arguing that when a tourist buys one chicken dinner, Cuba earns enough profits to buy 10 chickens for its citizens. But this is hard to swallow for citizens of a revolution in which equality and nationalism are the principal values.
Toward evening on the way to the upscale suburb of Miramar, disturbingly attractive young women in lycra outfits beckon to the passing traffic. They want dollars to buy clothes, go to discos and have a good time. The government which in the 1960s caried out a moral crusade against prostitution now shrugs its shoulders. Vice, government officials argue, is an inescapable cost of tourism.
Castro observed some years ago that you cannot build a socialist society with capitalist incentives, but that is exactly what he is trying to do now. He is emphasizing foreign capital, profits, dollars, competitiveness, individualism. He is decentralizing much of the economy. We asked a wise old communist, who is now head of Cuba's Chamber of Commerce, how these new ideas and values would play against the revolution's principles of collectivism and vertical control. Would the Communist Party survive? Would the revolution? He thought for a moment, and then concluded, with a shrug of his shoulders, "only a magician can tell."
Alfred Padula is a former foreign service officer for the U.S. State Department. He served as an analyst of Cuban affairs and was assigned to the U.S. Embassy in Quito, Ecuador. Currently, he is an associate professor of history at the University of Southern Maine.

Comedian Ellen DeGeneres brings her weird observations of life to Maine DeGeneres and comic/impersonator Kevin Pollak will perform Saturday at the Maine Center for the Arts

Author: Dale McGarrigle NEWS Feature Writer

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]22 July 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413683991?accountid=10457

Abstract: "I wasn't prepared for everything that ensued," said [Ellen DeGeneres], who will share the bill with comedian/impersonator [Kevin Pollak] at 8 p.m. Saturday at the Maine Center for the Arts. "Touring the country, I've learned that the average IQ is pretty down there. People actually expected me to be the funniest person in America." DeGeneres appeared regularly on "The Tonight Show" and "The Arsenio Hall Show." She has also been spotlighted on HBO specials, including "Women of the Night," "One Night Stand" and "The Young Comedians' Reunion." Her "HBO's One Night Stand -- Command Performance" received a Cable ACE Award nomination. Tickets for the Ellen DeGeneres/Kevin Pollak show are on sale at the Maine Center for the Arts box office, or by calling 581-1755.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Comedian+Ellen+DeGeneres+brings+her+weird+observations+of+life+to+Maine+DeGeneres+and+comic%2Fimpersonator+Kevin+Pollak+will+perform+Saturday+at+the+Maine+Center+for+the+Arts&amp;author=Dale+McGarrigle+NEWS+Feature+Writer&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-07-22&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Being named the "Funniest Person in America" was a mixed blessing for Ellen DeGeneres.
Earning that title after a nationwide search by Showtime in 1982 rescued her from a law office where she was working as a secretary, and gained her a nationwide tour. On the other hand, carrying that title was a heavy burden for the then-obscure New Orleans comic.
"I wasn't prepared for everything that ensued," said DeGeneres, who will share the bill with comedian/impersonator Kevin Pollak at 8 p.m. Saturday at the Maine Center for the Arts. "Touring the country, I've learned that the average IQ is pretty down there. People actually expected me to be the funniest person in America."
Still that led to other jobs, which eventually yielded a shot on "The Tonight Show" in 1986. She earned the distinction of being the only female comic to be invited by Johnny Carson to sit on the couch on her first appearance.
That was a long way from her start on a whim years earlier, when DeGeneres performed at a benefit after a request from some friends.
"I worked up some materials and did it," she said. "I wasn't nervous. Someone saw me that night and asked me to perform at a college. I decided that this is what I wanted to do. I started writing on a regular basis, and got into it."
During her lean years, DeGeneres did all manner of odd jobs. She tended bar, worked at a car wash, babysat, waited tables, demonstrated vacuum cleaners, served as an employment counselor and shucked oysters.
"Every single thing I did, I made weird," she said.
Audiences don't always appreciate the preparation and the timing that goes into successful stand-up comedy, said DeGeneres, who plays 100 to 150 dates a year.
"There are so many comedians on TV today that people think it's easier than it is, that anyone can do it," she said. "But any little disruption affects what you're doing, and can throw off the next joke and the next transition."
DeGeneres appeared regularly on "The Tonight Show" and "The Arsenio Hall Show." She has also been spotlighted on HBO specials, including "Women of the Night," "One Night Stand" and "The Young Comedians' Reunion." Her "HBO's One Night Stand -- Command Performance" received a Cable ACE Award nomination.
Like so many stand-up comedians before her, DeGeneres now wants to make her mark as an actress. She appeared in supporting roles in Fox's "Open House" and ABC's "Laurie Hill," both of which disappeared quickly.
Next she's starring in "These Friends of Mine," a midseason replacement series for ABC.
"It's about me and a bunch of friends experiencing life," DeGeneres explained vaguely. "It's not a groundbreaking show, but it's not a typical sitcom. It reflects my style of stand-up."
DeGeneres hopes to have a film lined up after the series is shot, but nothing is firm so far.
"I'm fine with blending my stand-up comedy and acting," she said. "But casting people keep seeing me as a stand-up comic only."
Tickets for the Ellen DeGeneres/Kevin Pollak show are on sale at the Maine Center for the Arts box office, or by calling 581-1755.
Illustration Caption: DeGeneres was crowned `Funniest Person in America' following a nationwide search conducted by `Showtime'

People: DeGeneres, Ellen Pollak, Kevin

Lobster festival to offer lecture

Recipes for dishes containing any fish or shellfish caught in Maine waters will be eligible. The dishes of the five cook-off finalists will be judged on taste, appearance, simplicity and appeal. Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lobster+festival+to+offer+lecture&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-07-20&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- The Maine Lobster Festival Seafood Cooking Contest will include a special lecture and lobster preparation demonstration this year. During the contest at 10:30 a.m. Friday, Aug. 6, Chef Bill Crowl will discuss and demonstrate the nutritional value of lobster and its use in various recipes.
Crowl, head chef of Peter Ott's Restaurant in Camden, has extensive knowledge of and experience in preparing lobster dishes. Crowl will also serve as a judge for the Seafood Cooking Contest. The other judge will be Bill Beale of the Spinnaker Restaurant in Rockport.
According to event organizers, Mildred Merrill and Mary T. Whitney, there is still time for creative amateur cooks to enter the cooking contest. Recipes for dishes containing any fish or shellfish caught in Maine waters will be eligible. The dishes of the five cook-off finalists will be judged on taste, appearance, simplicity and appeal. The deadline for submitting recipes has been extended until July 27. Cash prizes will be awarded. For more information and copies of the contest rules call Mary T. Whitney at 596-6459.
The 46th Annual Maine Lobster Festival will be held at Rockland's Harbor Park from Thursday, Aug. 5 through Sunday, Aug. 8.

Windjammer vessels named to historic register Seven still-active Penobscot Bay ships living examples of Maine nautical past

Author: Emmet Meara Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]20 July 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413709330?accountid=10457

Abstract: Seven vessels in the windjammer fleet have been added to the National Historic Register, "Quite a tribute to the people who restored them," [Reny Stackpole] said Monday. With the Bowdoin, which was designated in 1989, and the Victory Chimes, which is expected to be added, there will be nine historic vessels in Penobscot Bay. Isaac H. Evans, built in 1886 as an oyster schooner in Mauricetown, sailed Delaware Bay for 85 years, making her the oldest oyster schooner still under sail. More than 18,000 hours went into her restoration, and it was one of the first schooners to be rebuilt for the schooner trade. She is captained by Ed Glaser. J. and E. Riggin, captained by Dave Allen, was built in Dorchester, N.J., in 1927 for the oyster dredging trade. The Riggin is known for its speed and won the first and only formal oyster schooner race even held on Delaware Bay. In 1974, the owners found the unrigged hull moored off Cape Cod, towed her to Maine and rebuilt it as a passenger vessel.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Windjammer+vessels+named+to+historic+register+Seven+still-active+Penobscot+Bay+ships+living+examples+of+Maine+nautical+past&amp;author=Emmet+Meara+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-07-20&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- Penobscot Bay is the only place in the country with "living examples of working, sailing craft of historic significance" which date back to the turn of the century, according to Reny Stackpole of the Penobscot Marine Museum.
Seven vessels in the windjammer fleet have been added to the National Historic Register, "Quite a tribute to the people who restored them," Stackpole said Monday. With the Bowdoin, which was designated in 1989, and the Victory Chimes, which is expected to be added, there will be nine historic vessels in Penobscot Bay.
"They are a living example of the working, sailing craft and are a great calling card for Penobscot Bay," Stackpole said.
Stackpole has worked with the Constitution in Boston and the whaling vessel Charles W. Morgan at Mystic Seaport. But by charter, these vessels can no longer sail. The windjammer fleet is still active, carrying passengers on weekly trips across the bay.
The vessels added include the following:
American Eagle, built in Gloucester, Mass., in 1930, where she fished for 53 years. Two years of restoration by Capt. John Foss and his crew made the vessel "look and act like a new boat," Stackpole said.
Grace Bailey, built in Patchogue, N.Y., in 1882 as a coasting schooner hauling timber and granite for the West Indian trade until 1940 when she started carrying passengers. The 80-foot coaster was the flagship for the original schooner fleet and is now captained by Ray Williamson.
Isaac H. Evans, built in 1886 as an oyster schooner in Mauricetown, sailed Delaware Bay for 85 years, making her the oldest oyster schooner still under sail. More than 18,000 hours went into her restoration, and it was one of the first schooners to be rebuilt for the schooner trade. She is captained by Ed Glaser.
Lewis R. French, built in Christmas Cove in 1871, claims title to being the oldest vessel in the windjammer fleet. For more than a century the 64-foot coasting schooner carried salt fish, coal, lime, bricks and even Christmas trees, to pay her way. The French is skippered by Dan Pease.
Mercantile, launched in Little Deer Isle in 1916 as a shallow draft coaster. It carried salt fish, barrel staves and firewood for Rockport's lime kilns. It became a cruise schooner in 1942 under the ownership of Frank Smith, the founder of the windjammer trade, and is now captained by Ray Williamson.
J. and E. Riggin, captained by Dave Allen, was built in Dorchester, N.J., in 1927 for the oyster dredging trade. The Riggin is known for its speed and won the first and only formal oyster schooner race even held on Delaware Bay. In 1974, the owners found the unrigged hull moored off Cape Cod, towed her to Maine and rebuilt it as a passenger vessel.
The Stephen Taber, the oldest documented sailing vessel in continuous service in the United States. The vessel was built as acoasting schooner in 1871 in Glenwood, N.J., and earned her way carrying bricks, seed oysters, vegetables and coal, before joining the pleasure fleet. The Taber's captains are Ken and Helen Barnes.

People: Stackpole, Reny

____________________________________________________________

Funding requests top Lubec meeting agenda Mapping, assessing bill virtually doubled

Author: Paul Sylvain Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]19 July 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413708823?accountid=10457

Abstract: As [Mark Decoteau] explained Thursday, the bid had been readvertised to include a complete revaluation of private and commercial properties in Lubec in addition to assessing services, as had been originally advertised. Selectmen "forgot" that the May bid was the second part of a two-part bid submitted by [Gary L. Geaghan], and represented costs only for the additionally advertised revaluation services, Decoteau said. Geaghan's original bid for assessing stood unchanged. The realization, caught only after Decoteau arrived as new town office manager in June, meant the bid had been "effectively doubled," Decoteau said. "Instead of a $15,000-a-year job, it now is a $30,000-a-year job." It also meant that Honeywell's bid was about $20,000 lower, not $22,500 higher, than Geaghan's total bid.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Funding+requests+top+Lubec+meeting+agenda+Mapping%2C+assessing+bill+virtually+doubled&amp;author=Paul+Sylvain+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-07-19&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: LUBEC -- Residents here, just three months after holding their annual town meeting, will be asked at a special town meeting Tuesday to raise more than $21,000 in a seven-article warrant to cover additional municipal expenses for the coming year.
The meeting will begin at 7 p.m. Tuesday, July 20, at the Lubec High School.
A request for an additional $7,235 for increases in premiums for municipal insurance coverage tops the issues.
It could have been worse.
Earlier this month, Town Office Manager Mark Decoteau prepared selectmen for what he thought would be a more-than-$21,000 increase in annual insurance premiums. In looking closer at his figures, Decoteau discovered the increase was annual, and not monthly, through the remainder of the year.
Another article asks that $5,000 be raised for the lease of a Northern Data Systems computer package at the town office.
Selectmen this spring entered into a contract with Lubec-based Max-Parry Inc. for financial consulting services through the remainder of the fiscal year ending Feb. 28, 1994. The contract included provisions for leasing the computer system used by the firm.
By contract, the town is committed to paying the firm $500 a month, or $5,000 during the 10-month life of the contract, for a variety of financial services.
In return, Max-Parry agreed to provide computer software and hardware needed to establish a "completely integrated municipal management package" marketed by Northern Data Systems. The software package includes counter cash receipting, budgetary accounting, tax billing, payroll and record keeping of accounts payable, or warrant items.
Decoteau told selectmen Thursday that the computer hardware had arrived at the town office, and that tax and other data were already being entered into the system. He predicted that selectmen will begin receiving updated, line-by-line budget printouts "within the next few meetings."
The warrant's final article asks that an additional $8,800 be raised to pay for mapping and assessing services being provided by Gary L. Geaghan of Ellsworth.
In May, Geaghan was awarded a contract for three years to conduct an assessment and revaluation of private and commercial property in Lubec.
Geaghan's bid of $47,500 appeared to be the lowest of two proposals opened by selectmen, who turned down a $70,020 bid from Brenda G. Honeywell of Alexander.
But as Decoteau explained Thursday, the bid had been readvertised to include a complete revaluation of private and commercial properties in Lubec in addition to assessing services, as had been originally advertised.
Selectmen "forgot" that the May bid was the second part of a two-part bid submitted by Geaghan, and represented costs only for the additionally advertised revaluation services, Decoteau said. Geaghan's original bid for assessing stood unchanged.
The realization, caught only after Decoteau arrived as new town office manager in June, meant the bid had been "effectively doubled," Decoteau said. "Instead of a $15,000-a-year job, it now is a $30,000-a-year job." It also meant that Honeywell's bid was about $20,000 lower, not $22,500 higher, than Geaghan's total bid.
Selectmen in May favored Geaghan's proposal, not only for its apparent lower cost, but also because of his use of a Northern Data Systems program and hardware, making his system compatible with the Northern Data Systems computer installed last week at the Lubec Town Office.
Geaghan promised in writing to spend at least one day each week in Lubec. The town's assessing records will be entered into the computer, creating a permanent data base to build on.
A request for $100 in Article 6 resulted from an oversight in preparing the annual town meeting warrant and amounts to "routine housekeeping," Decoteau said. If approved, the money will be used "in support of the Lubec Charter Commission."
Residents at the April town meeting voted to establish the commission. However, a separate article to fund its operation was not included in the annual meeting warrant. As a result, no money was raised.
Residents on Tuesday also will be asked to authorize selectmen to acquire the Frederic C. Lawrence property "for the cost of back taxes due on that property," and to enact a municipal shellfish conservation ordinance.

People: Decoteau, Mark Geaghan, Gary L

Company: Northern Data Systems

Easement to protect bog

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]14 July 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413715083?accountid=10457

Abstract: Tolman said he chose to make the gift to honor his grandfather, Earl Tolman, and his longtime efforts to protect the Oyster River Bog and its environs. He also decided to do himself what he so often asks or other landowners -- to contribute either land or money to the land trust of which he now is president.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Easement+to+protect+bog&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-07-14&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- Maynard E. Tolman II has given the Oyster River Bog Association a conservation easement on 15 acres that he had purchased for the specific purpose of keeping it "forever wild."
Tolman said he chose to make the gift to honor his grandfather, Earl Tolman, and his longtime efforts to protect the Oyster River Bog and its environs. He also decided to do himself what he so often asks or other landowners -- to contribute either land or money to the land trust of which he now is president.
"The bog has great meaning to me," said Tolman, "having been raised on its edge and visited the interior many times over the years. Others should also know of its importance. My grandfather, Earl Tolman, was one of a few people that started the organization. ... I am the first board member to make a land donation. Perhaps this will spark others to do the same thing."
About 13 percent of the bog's 6,000 acres has been protected through contributions such as Tolman's.

People: Tolman, Earl

Jonesport gets landfill extension

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]13 July 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413760591?accountid=10457

Abstract: The Department of Enviromental Protection has given Jonesport authority to keep the town's landfill open until Aug. 30, 1993. Thereafter, the town is expected to operate a licensed solid waste transfer station at Snare Creek for Jonesport and Beals.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Jonesport+gets+landfill+extension&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-07-13&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: JONESPORT -- The Department of Enviromental Protection has given Jonesport authority to keep the town's landfill open until Aug. 30, 1993. Thereafter, the town is expected to operate a licensed solid waste transfer station at Snare Creek for Jonesport and Beals.
Karen Knuuti, representing the DEP, said in her recent letter to the town that Jonesport would be allowed to continue disposal of white goods, metals, construction and demolition debris, tires, municipal solid waste, and shellfish waste at the Snare Creek facility.
Last week, selectmen said they were waiting for a reply from consulting engineer Dean Bradshaw regarding the cost, effectiveness and durability of using ready-made cement retaining walls as compared with the cement and rip-rap proposed in his engineering plan for the Jonesport Transfer Station.
Bids for the construction will be requested as soon as an updated engineering report is received from Bradshaw.
Judson Carver, a local resident, discussed with the selectmen the town's policy on construction bids. Selectmen approved Howard Mills Jr.'s recommendation that bids be accepted from all interested contractors.

More Mainers muscling in on mussel treats

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]10 July 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413700328?accountid=10457

Abstract: "I invited them to try some of my mussels, but it was a tussle to even get them to taste them. They said `No, thank you, I don't eat mussels.' But pretty soon those who had tasted them began to take second and third helpings and said my smoked mussels were really good. Even some of the older men ended up eating mussels just like they'd eat dried fish," Thompson said. "There's almost no end to the way you can eat mussels," said Shelba Thompson of Cape Split Seafood Co. "Smoked and dipped in mustard or salsa, with cream cheese or sour cream on a cracker. Smoked mussels are wonderful because you can eat them plain, or dress them up into a great hors d'oeuvre. Fresh mussels can be steamed, and eaten plain or with a sauce, and they are absolutely delicious deep-fried." On Friday, Gay's Supermarket in Machias was offering 8 ounces of Cape Split Seafood's smoked mussels for $4.29. Also, a 3-ounce package of dried pollock was selling for $3.29. A variety of pickled mussels by Hamblen's Seafood from Deer Isle included vinegar, broth, onions, peppers, herbs and spices in an 8-ounce container for $3.99.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=More+Mainers+muscling+in+on+mussel+treats&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-07-10&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ADDISON -- Although natives of the Down East area tend to seriously resist change, they have begun to enjoy eating smoked mussels. Actually, David W. Thompson of South Addison has some of the area's "hard-boiled" fishermen literally eating out of his hand.
Thompson knows his fellow Down Easters almost as well as he knows his mussels.
When he was a young boy, he lived for a time on Great Wass Island, which is the larger island within the town of Beals. Later, he camped with his relatives at the Moose Peak Lighthouse Station, located on an island just south of Steele Harbor Island.
"My roots go way back among people in the Jonesport-Beals area," he said.
"After I started smoking mussels about eight years ago, I took some of them down to Osmond Beal's boat shop at Beals. It was in the wintertime, and several of the older men were sitting around and watching Osmond and his crew finish building a boat," he said.
"I invited them to try some of my mussels, but it was a tussle to even get them to taste them. They said `No, thank you, I don't eat mussels.' But pretty soon those who had tasted them began to take second and third helpings and said my smoked mussels were really good. Even some of the older men ended up eating mussels just like they'd eat dried fish," Thompson said.
Most people who try smoked mussels for the first time like them, especially if they like clams. Mussels are available from CSS all year, but the peak sales period is during the Christmas and New Year holidays.
"There's almost no end to the way you can eat mussels," said Shelba Thompson of Cape Split Seafood Co. "Smoked and dipped in mustard or salsa, with cream cheese or sour cream on a cracker. Smoked mussels are wonderful because you can eat them plain, or dress them up into a great hors d'oeuvre. Fresh mussels can be steamed, and eaten plain or with a sauce, and they are absolutely delicious deep-fried."
Long enjoyed in other areas of the country, mussels have become the "nouveau shellfish" in Washington County, according to Dianne Tilton of the Sunrise County Economic Council. The novelty seafood has become available in many grocery stores in the Down East area.
Cape Split Seafood, located on Moose Neck Road in Addison, harvests mussels and sells them to a growing number of regular customers. The company also cures and distributes dried fish and marinated periwinkles.
On Friday, Gay's Supermarket in Machias was offering 8 ounces of Cape Split Seafood's smoked mussels for $4.29. Also, a 3-ounce package of dried pollock was selling for $3.29. A variety of pickled mussels by Hamblen's Seafood from Deer Isle included vinegar, broth, onions, peppers, herbs and spices in an 8-ounce container for $3.99.
"The secret to mussels," according to Shelba Thompson, "is to dive for them. The mussels you pick up along the shore are gritty, but in deep water they're very clean."
David Thompson said he dives into 25 to 30 feet of water to gather mussels for his seafood company. Mussels grow from seed to commercial size in three years.
"They grow much faster than clams," said David. "A mussel siphons 12 gallons of water every 24 hours, so they eat a lot."
The company has grown since 1985 from a room in the Thompson house to a small building where the shucking took place. Later, the business moved to facilities at Jimmy Bucknam's clam factory. The Thompsons imported a pair of stainless steel "smokers" from England, and have used applewood sawdust and shavings to create the smoke for curing.
Within the next few weeks, the Thompsons will open a new 56-by-36-foot processing plant that will house the shucking room, coolers and a cooking room. The smoking operation will be retained at the present location until a second phase of construction expands the new plant.
The business employs about 10 people, including the Thompson family.

People: Thompson, David W

Company: Cape Split Seafood Co

____________________________________________________________

Lawsuit seeks to halt transfer station construction

Author: Kathy Harbour Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]02 July 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413761040?accountid=10457

Abstract: According to the lawsuit, filed on behalf of the plaintiffs by attorney George Singal of Bangor, the property owners are seeking a revocation of the setback waivers four of them signed last year. The setback waivers, for property owners within 250 feet of the transfer station site, were required as part of the town's permitting process from the DEP. As stated in the lawsuit, four of the property owners signed the waivers because they were told by one or more selectmen that no other site was available and/or affordable for the transfer station. They claim they also signed the waivers because the same selectmen said the station could not be located at the site of the present landfill and that the landfill site could not be approved by the DEP as a transfer station site. When contacted about the lack of waivers by all abutting property owners, the DEP decided a signature by the occupying landowner, [Joseph Reynolds], would suffice, [Stu Marckoon] said Thursday. The DEP has not revoked the permit based on that information, Marckoon added.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lawsuit+seeks+to+halt+transfer+station+construction&amp;author=Kathy+Harbour+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-07-02&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: LAMOINE -- A lawsuit against the town of Lamoine seeks to halt construction of the transfer station on Route 184.
Filed July 1 in Hancock County Superior Court, the lawsuit by six Lamoine property owners seeks a revocation of the Department of Environmental Protection permit for the transfer station and a cessation of all construction at the site.
The transfer station is about 85 percent complete and the town has received permission to keep its landfill open until July 31, when the building is expected to be finished.
Additionally, the lawsuit calls for compensation for the "noneconomic injuries" sustained by the property owners, costs associated with the lawsuit and any other relief deemed appropriate by the court.
The lawsuit names the DEP as the second defendant. Plaintiffs in the lawsuit are listed as John Smith, Joseph Reynolds, Charles Reynolds Sr., Charles Reynolds Jr., Nancy Sargent and Leon Sargent.
Two local shellfish dealers are footing the bill for the plaintiffs in the lawsuit. Dean Smith and Mike Briggs, owners of two fish processing businesses in Lamoine, have said in previous weeks that they wanted the town to halt construction of the station, since they have been informed their commercial waste will not be accepted at the transfer station.
Smith said Thursday two attorneys had advised them that any lawsuit questioning the town's right to deny space to a commercial entity could prove extremely costly and protracted. "So we were advised we couldn't stop it ourselves and that the better tact would be to draw the abutters into the picture."
Smith said the shellfish dealers had no plans to file suit themselves against the town.
According to the lawsuit, filed on behalf of the plaintiffs by attorney George Singal of Bangor, the property owners are seeking a revocation of the setback waivers four of them signed last year. The setback waivers, for property owners within 250 feet of the transfer station site, were required as part of the town's permitting process from the DEP.
As stated in the lawsuit, four of the property owners signed the waivers because they were told by one or more selectmen that no other site was available and/or affordable for the transfer station. They claim they also signed the waivers because the same selectmen said the station could not be located at the site of the present landfill and that the landfill site could not be approved by the DEP as a transfer station site.
The property owners contend that that information was not true. "Plaintiffs have since learned not only that there were other available and affordable sites on which the transfer station could be built, but also that the site of (the) existing landfill had not been ruled out by DEP and might have been approved," the lawsuit states.
The four state they have suffered "substantial and potentially irreparable harm in that the proposed transfer station will cause them to suffer noxious odors, increased traffic, noise and diminishment of their enjoyment of their property."
In June, Joseph Reynolds, Nancy Sargent and Smith signed affidavits indicating they would not have signed the waivers if they had known the town had other options for the station.
In addition, the lawsuit contends that two property owners -- Charles Reynolds Sr. and Charles Reynolds Jr. -- never waived their rights to a 250-foot setback and that such waivers are required for a DEP permit.
"Defendant DEP granted a permit to Lamoine for the establishment of the transfer station on the site abutting and within 250 (feet) of their property without their approval, in violation of state law," the lawsuit contends.
The lawsuit states the two Reynoldses "have suffered and will continue to suffer substantial economic harm due to devaluation of their property and noneconomic harm due to the presence of a solid waste transfer station ... and the associated traffic and diminution of the aesthetic quality of their land."
The two Reynoldses, heirs with four other family members to the property now occupied by Joseph Reynolds, also signed affidavits last month indicating they had never given their approval for any waiver to the setback requirements and signified they had no intention of giving the waivers.
According to town administrator Stu Marckoon, the two Reynoldses and the other heirs indeed were overlooked when the town sent out requests for setback waivers last year. The DEP and the engineer thought all necessary signatures had been obtained when the permit was granted.
When the mistake was brought to light on April 14, 1993, the town sent out letters asking for waivers from the heirs. One heir returned a signed waiver.
When contacted about the lack of waivers by all abutting property owners, the DEP decided a signature by the occupying landowner, Joseph Reynolds, would suffice, Marckoon said Thursday. The DEP has not revoked the permit based on that information, Marckoon added.
Marckoon contends the town could not have placed the transfer station on top of the present landfill. It is possible, he said, the town could have received a DEP permit to place the station elsewhere on the 29 acre site, but that option was ruled out due to the potential expense involved. The expense would have involved locating the outer limits of the buried garbage site, with associated engineering costs.
Since the other Route 184 site was available and since the site already had had hydrological information and engineering studies completed, it was chosen as the less expensive alternative, Marckoon said.

People: Smith, John Reynolds, Joseph Marckoon, Stu

Lobster festival to feature cookoff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]02 July 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413713909?accountid=10457

Abstract: The event will be held Friday, Aug. 6, on the festival grounds. Creative cooks are urged to participate. Recipes for dishes containing any fish or shellfish caught in Maine waters will be eligible.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Lobster+festival+to+feature+cookoff&amp;author=&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-07-02&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: ROCKLAND -- The Maine Lobster Festival Seafood Cooking Contest will continue a 16-year tradition of featuring some of Maine's best seafood dishes prepared by amateur cooks.
The event will be held Friday, Aug. 6, on the festival grounds. Creative cooks are urged to participate. Recipes for dishes containing any fish or shellfish caught in Maine waters will be eligible.
The dishes for the five cook-off finalists will be judged on taste, appearance, simplicity and appeal. The deadline for submitting recipes is Tuesday, July 20. Cash prizes will be awarded.
For a complete list of rules, write: Maine Lobster Festival Seafood Cooking Contest, P.O. Box 552, Rockland 04841, or call Mary T. Whitney.
The 46th annual Maine Lobster Festival will be held at Rockland's Harbor Park from Thursday, Aug. 5 through Sunday, Aug. 8.

Calais man calling for halt to dragging Flounder, shellfish catches dropping

Author: Diana Graettinger Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]02 July 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413708399?accountid=10457

Abstract: Today, the catch is less plentiful, but [Louis Bernardini] hopes to do something about it. His campaign includes a petition that will be sent to William Brennan, commissioner of the Department of Marine Resources. Bernardini said he believes the decline in fish and shellfish populations has been caused by the constant scallop dragging in the St. Croix River area. He said he would like to see the area closed to dragging on both sides of the border. Bernardini also sent a letter to Wendy W. Wright, director of the St. Andrews Biological Station in New Brunswick, to enlist her support. In his letter Bernardini said, "In the 1950s, '60s and '70s, one could catch flounder anyplace in the St. Croix all the way up to the narrows. Today, it is next to impossible to catch one in the river unless one goes to the mouth of the river on the Canadian or U.S. side. For the past 20 years, I have been fishing 15 to 25 lobster traps May through October, and have been seeing decreasing catches, especially in the last eight years," he wrote.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Calais+man+calling+for+halt+to+dragging+Flounder%2C+shellfish+catches+dropping&amp;author=Diana+Graettinger+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-07-02&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: CALAIS -- When Calais businessman Louis Bernardini was a young man, lobster, crab and flounder were plentiful in the St. Croix River, and a flounder could be speared in shallow water.
"The other day we pulled 35 traps. We never got a lobster, and we got three crabs," he said.
As a kid, he said, he used to catch many flounder. "You could stand in the mud flats, wait for the tide to come in and spear them," he said.
Today, the catch is less plentiful, but Bernardini hopes to do something about it. His campaign includes a petition that will be sent to William Brennan, commissioner of the Department of Marine Resources. Bernardini said he believes the decline in fish and shellfish populations has been caused by the constant scallop dragging in the St. Croix River area. He said he would like to see the area closed to dragging on both sides of the border.
Bernardini also sent a letter to Wendy W. Wright, director of the St. Andrews Biological Station in New Brunswick, to enlist her support. In his letter Bernardini said, "In the 1950s, '60s and '70s, one could catch flounder anyplace in the St. Croix all the way up to the narrows. Today, it is next to impossible to catch one in the river unless one goes to the mouth of the river on the Canadian or U.S. side. For the past 20 years, I have been fishing 15 to 25 lobster traps May through October, and have been seeing decreasing catches, especially in the last eight years," he wrote.
Bernardini said the crab population, once a major staple along the St. Croix, has nearly disappeared. "Eight years ago, I could catch three 5-gallon pails in a haul, and that was only keeping the largest ones. Today, 10 crabs out of 15 traps would be a lot," he wrote. He said he had discussed the problem with other area fisherman, who had noticed the same decline.
"The St. Croix River is being destroyed by the constant dragging. I have contacted Commissioner Brennan at the Department of Marine Resources in Augusta ... asking that the St. Croix be closed to draggers. ... I would like to see both sides of the river closed to dragging," he wrote. He has asked that the river be closed to all dragging from Liberty Point in Robbinston to Calais, and from St. Andrews to St. Stephen, New Brunswick.
Bernardini also plans to take his case to the St. Croix Waterway Commission, a nonprofit oversight agency that is focused on the future of the river.
Lee Sochasky, director of the St. Croix Waterway Commission, said in a telephone interview Wednesday that she had heard about Bernardini's concerns, but had not yet spoken with him. She said she would support a study to see what impact scallop dragging might have on flounder and lobster stock. She said she could not speculate on what may have caused a decline in the groundfish population.
"Many of the groundfish that were historically here and in the estuary have also disappeared; the causative factors may be further at sea or other things that we can't control. But if some of those factors are things we can control, we should be looking at those and making choices," she said.
She referred calls about scallop dragging to the Canadian Department of Fisheries and Oceans. They did not return a call to their office.

People: Bernardini, Louis

Clam spawning commences along coast

Author: Clayton Beal Of the NEWS Staff

Publication info: Bangor Daily News ; Bangor, Me. [Bangor, Me]01 July 1993.

https://search.proquest.com/docview/413704352?accountid=10457

Abstract: A seemingly harmless summer rain shower, similar to the series of thunderstorms that swept across the county on Wednesday, can be devastating to clam larvae left grounded on clam flats. The combination of a deluge of freshwater and a hot summer sun can be fatal to clam larvae, according to marine biologist David Clifford of East Machias. Many productive clam beds remain closed because of water pollution. "The clams themselves are perfectly healthy in those areas where too high levels of fecal coliform bacteria exist. The clams love it," said Barbara Arter of the Cooperative Extension office at Machias. "But it can make people ill." She is devoting her efforts to helping municipalities in the county improve water quality on clam flats. According to Clifford, Jonesporters had considered trying to establish a clam depuration plant to help local clammers harvest clams from flats closed because of pollution. With the new cleanup program in gear, however, members of the local clam committee and selectmen have decided against using a depuration plant. "They intend to do their own harvesting after they clean up the flats," he said.

Links: http://CX2EF4JW8J.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Clam+spawning+commences+along+coast&amp;author=Clayton+Beal+Of+the+NEWS+Staff&amp;issn=08928738&amp;title=Bangor+Daily+News&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=1993-07-01&amp;spage=NOPGCIT&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: MACHIAS -- The annual spawning of softshell clams is under way on Washington County's jagged coastline. During the next three weeks, many of the eggs released into area coves, bays and rivers will be fertilized by adult clams.
The life of the Maine clam -- from egg to adult marketable mollusk -- is marked by a host of natural predators and man-made threats.
A seemingly harmless summer rain shower, similar to the series of thunderstorms that swept across the county on Wednesday, can be devastating to clam larvae left grounded on clam flats. The combination of a deluge of freshwater and a hot summer sun can be fatal to clam larvae, according to marine biologist David Clifford of East Machias.
"Every phase of a clam's life has problems. Some are natural and some are caused by people," he said. Among the natural disasters that can wipe out clams are big coastal storms like the one that hit the clam beds at Cutler last winter and killed thousands of clams by washing them out of their bed.
The most serious plague on clams is pollution. "This area CLOSED TO ALL DIGGING of clams, mussels, quahogs, oysters, carnivorous whelks or snails BECAUSE OF POLLUTION" is too often the message posted along the perimeter of a cove where the environment may, to the nonscientific eye, appear to be in perfect order.
"You can't see it happening, but you can be sure that the clam's environment and food chain are being constantly influenced by water quality," Clifford said. "You can't pollute it and dig it too."
Towns that reject waste-water treatment plants or cluster systems set back the clock on the reopening of clam beds to commercial clam diggers.
"The good news," Clifford said, "is that all of the flats at the head of Cutler Harbor were reopened last year to diggers, because eight or 10 new cluster (septic) systems replaced the sources of pollution. The water cleared up very quickly." Also, two years ago, Moose River in Trescott was reopened to digging because the quality of water above the flats was improved as the result of a cleanup program.
Many productive clam beds remain closed because of water pollution. "The clams themselves are perfectly healthy in those areas where too high levels of fecal coliform bacteria exist. The clams love it," said Barbara Arter of the Cooperative Extension office at Machias. "But it can make people ill." She is devoting her efforts to helping municipalities in the county improve water quality on clam flats.
One of her prized projects involves a cleanup of clam flats at Jonesport, where the town, Jonesport-Beals High School and Cooperative Extension are teaming up in a long-term program to improve water quality. A new laboratory at J-BHS will be used to test water samples taken from test plots in coves and bays.
According to Clifford, Jonesporters had considered trying to establish a clam depuration plant to help local clammers harvest clams from flats closed because of pollution. With the new cleanup program in gear, however, members of the local clam committee and selectmen have decided against using a depuration plant. "They intend to do their own harvesting after they clean up the flats," he said.
Pollution has been "slowly and quietly" building up, during the past several decades in many of the coastal areas, said Clifford, because there are more homes located at the ocean's edge. Those homes have the modern convenience of running water and flushable toilets, while older homes and cottages had traditional outhouses away from the beaches. The relatively low concentration of fecal coliform bacteria from such facilities was not a problem 50 or 60 years ago.
People in the Down East area who frequently cooked and ate clams as part of their regular diet, according to Clifford, perhaps built up an immunity to some of the health problems that now worry public health officials. "Clams were not sold out of state in large quantities until the advent of the steamer market. Now, we have more regulations to protect the public health," he said.

People: Clifford, David
